Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP leader. An early election will be held on October 15th.
The popularity of the ÖVP new leader, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, propelled his party into first place in the polls. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to win the largest vote share. The most likely coalition to emerge is one that is led by the ÖVP and includes the FPÖ, although negotiations to form one could be fraught.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government would not lead to similar EU sanctions as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
We expect any new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2017-21), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.6% in 2016. We forecast an acceleration of growth this year, to an upwardly revised 2.5%, and that growth will moderate to 1.6% on average in 2018-21.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-21, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 1% in 2016, up from 0.8% in 2015, and we forecast an annual average of 2% in 2017-21.
In 2016 the current-account surplus decreased slightly, to 1.7% of GDP. We forecast that it will average about 2.5% in the coming years as a weakening trade balance is offset by strong tourism receipts.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21). As a result, the country remains in 12th place in the regional ranking but loses two places in the global ranking, dropping to 21st. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress likely to be limited.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. Little progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between the EU and the UK.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to tax system, owing in part to likely deterioration in government effectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely assuming a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power in 2017. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure here.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election will be held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.8bn and the goods import bill was US$143bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.3bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Following several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. The popular 31-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, has taken over the leadership of the ÖVP and will run as the party's lead candidate in the early general election on October 15th. However, probably owing to the party's poor performance in the polls (it has languished in third place since the first half of 2016), Mr Kurz decided to leverage his own popularity by demanding full control over the ÖVP and that the party appear on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party", which would also include a number of people not previously associated with the ÖVP. Following Mr Kurz's arrival as party leader, the ÖVP shot to the top of the polls, pushing the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) to third place, from first. The campaign still holds the potential to derail Mr Kurz's efforts, as he is inexperienced, especially on topics relating to economic policy, an area in which his main challenger, the current SPÖ chancellor, Christian Kern, is significantly stronger. However, owing in part to the ÖVP's lead (it is polling around 33%, compared with 25% for the second-placed SPÖ), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to emerge as the largest party in the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house of parliament).
Nevertheless, the election will be a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP will have been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the break-down of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited both from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz looks to be mostly drawing voters away from the FPÖ, in large part based on his strong stance on immigration and border control.
The most likely coalition to emerge after the election is one led by the ÖVP, with the FPÖ as a junior coalition partner, as the other parties-including the Greens; NEOS, a liberal party; and List Pilz, a new group recently set up by Peter Pilz, a former Green member of parliament (MP)-are unlikely to be large enough to help either the SPÖ or the ÖVP to reach a parliamentary majority. Risks to this outlook are high, as the election could turn, and coalition negotiations could falter because the FPÖ will probably demand significant concessions from Mr Kurz. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further. The government will struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters and the FPÖ is likely to struggle to translate its opposition on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect little progress on significant structural reforms, and the risk of an early election in the next parliamentary term is high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for October 15th 2017. The most likely scenario is that the rebranded ÖVP under Mr Kurz will win the largest share of the vote-but not an outright majority-and subsequently form a coalition with the FPÖ.
Elections for several state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the strong position of the FPÖ. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
We expect a new government to continue along the same line. Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the election in 1999 led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should the party join the next governing coalition. At that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was an unusual development, but since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in parliament in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries, Italy and the Netherlands.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Norbert Hofer, the FPÖ candidate-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU did not reform or if Turkey joined the bloc. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, we expect little progress. The next government, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right and is likely to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.4% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1.1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2017-21), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP. Despite only limited fiscal consolidation, robust economic growth will help to narrow the deficit slightly. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 84.6% in 2016 following a positive contribution from the Heta deal, to just below 75% in 2021. In the context of the quantitative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero; a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money; and a EUR60bn per month quantitative easing (QE) programme, which will run until the end of 2017. However, the economic recovery in the euro zone has maintained momentum-supported by an acceleration in credit growth-and looks to be more broad based. We expect another healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 2%, after growth of 1.9% on average in 2015-16. Although commentary from the ECB's president, Mario Draghi, was cautious in tone following the policy meeting in July, Mr Draghi revealed that the bank's policy-setting governing council would be discussing the future of the QE programme in the autumn of this year. We maintain our view that the bank will begin to wind down gradually, or "taper", the programme in 2018. Nevertheless, underlying price pressure remains relatively subdued, and downside risks to wage growth and the global economy during that year could yet slow the pace at which the ECB will reduce its monthly asset purchases. We forecast that the ECB will not raise policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany; this was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.6%, it remained below Germany's 1.8% growth.
However, the economy has recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.7% between July 2016 and June 2017. Although the labour market had in previous years struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, when the unemployment rate started to fall. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.9% this year. Furthermore, export and investment growth have also picked up. As a result, we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to an upwardly revised 2.5% this year, slightly above growth in Germany for the first time since 2005.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, when we forecast that the economy will expand by 2%. A worsening global economic environment in 2018-20, when we expect a policy-driven slowdown in China and a cyclical slowdown in the US, will weigh on growth in the second half of our forecast period, as will the continued lack of reform progress. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.5% in 2019-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 2%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has continued, and as political risk has waned in Europe but risen in the US. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. The value of the euro could yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the next general election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US. Nevertheless, we expect a gradual appreciation on average, to US$1.20:EUR1 by 2020, as the euro is supported by an ongoing recovery in the region and receives structural support from a large current-account surplus. A business cycle downturn in the US will weigh on the value of the dollar in 2020.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and moved the trade balance back into a small deficit in 2016. We expect the trade balance to fluctuate around the even point in the coming years as robust export growth is balanced out by an increase in import prices. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in our forecast period, of about 2.5% of GDP on average.

Country Forecast South Africa August 2017

[...]the number of people receiving ARV therapy soared from just 100,000 in 2005 to about 3.5m in 2016, which is enabling many victims to live longer and more productive lives. [...]in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+South+Africa&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+South+Africa+August+2017&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-08-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+South+Africa&amp;rft.issn=09668683&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: South Africa--highlights: Political outlook
The African National Congress (ANC) will remain the dominant political force and is likely to retain power at the next election in 2019, albeit with a smaller majority than in 2014 (when it won 62.2% of the vote). The president, Jacob Zuma, remains under pressure because of a series of corruption scandals and the ANC's relatively poor showing in municipal elections in 2016, when its voting share fell to a record low of 54%. The ANC is deeply divided into pro-Zuma and anti-Zuma factions, which are evenly matched, helping to explain the president's survival. The ANC's five-yearly electoral summit in December, when Mr Zuma will stand down as party leader (although not as national president), will have a decisive influence on the political scene.
South Africa--highlights: Demographic outlook

South Africa's population growth rate will remain muted in 2017-21, averaging just 0.9% a year, owing to the adverse impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The number of new infections and the annual death toll from AIDS are both on downward trends, and life expectancy is rising, helped by the expansion of treatment programmes, but the damage will persist into the medium term. The labour force will grow at a faster rate than the overall population, highlighting the urgency of job creation. Rapid urbanisation will present planning challenges and business opportunities.
South Africa--highlights: Business environment outlook

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
South Africa's business environment ranking is unchanged at 52nd in 2017-21, as improvements in some areas are offset by declines in others. Supporting factors include a sound banking system, disciplined monetary policy, a steady improvement in infrastructure and a gradual expansion of the black middle class. There are several deterrents, however, such as skills shortages, frequent strikes, strict labour laws and the burden of complying with black economic empowerment (BEE) regulations. Policy uncertainty will remain at a high level because of divisions within government over several key proposals such as a new mining charter (which tightens BEE requirements), a draft expropriation law (which could trim compensation) and a foreign direct investment law (which limits recourse to international arbitration). Legal challenges will probably overturn some of the most controversial plans, but uncertainty will persist in the interim.

South Africa's economy, being relatively small and open, will remain vulnerable to global developments and commodity price fluctuations. Growth will rise slightly to 0.8% in 2017-after slipping to just 0.3% in 2016 because of a crippling drought. A rebound in agriculture (and to a lesser extent mining) will be offset by weaknesses in other sectors, stemming from weak aggregate demand. In addition, policy uncertainty will stifle private investment. Growth will show a broad upward trend during 2018-21, but will remain relatively subdued in view of constraints such as high unemployment, skills shortages and frequent strikes. More positively, South Africa will no longer be short of electricity after new plant openings. Inflation breached the central bank's 3-6% target range in 2016, owing to drought, but will stay within the target band in 2017-21, despite possible temporary breaches.

South Africa's market will expand during the forecast period as the black majority is increasingly drawn into the mainstream commercial economy, boosting demand for goods and services across a wide range of sectors. Nonetheless, high unemployment and household indebtedness will constrain the rate of economic growth, despite a recent cut in interest rates. A weak outcome in 2017 will be followed by a gentle rebound in 2018-21, helped by the expansion of the black middle class, higher levels of financial inclusion, the rollout of low-cost housing and improved electricity supplies.

We expect real GDP growth to average 3.1% a year in 2017-30, underpinned by the gradual completion of major infrastructure projects, the rise of the black middle class and regional integration, although slow population growth will act as a constraint. Economic growth will quicken to 3.7% a year in 2031-50, driven by technological advances such as additive printing and cloud computing. Growth in capital stocks will outpace growth in labour productivity throughout the period.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it held its first all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won, and has dominated all of the subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009 and, most recently, in May 2014. However, support ebbed from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004, to 62.2% in 2014 and a worst-ever 53.9% in municipal elections in August 2016. Jacob Zuma assumed the presidency in 2009 and is serving a second (and final) five-year term ending in 2019.
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and an executive president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law of the land. The 400-member National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is fully independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog, the Public Protector, and for independent commissions on human rights, gender equality and the restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: Boosting growth, creating jobs, advancing black economic empowerment and reducing inequality-while maintaining fiscal and monetary discipline-are the main aims of government economic policy. Divisions within the ruling party, highlighted by a controversial cabinet reshuffle and the consequent loss of South Africa's investment-grade credit rating, mark a rise in policy uncertainty. The labour market will remain rigid and marked by frequent strikes, exacerbated by the political power of the trade unions. Skills shortages will persist, reflecting weaknesses in education. The environment for private enterprise will remain broadly accommodating, and opportunities for public-private partnerships will arise, although a new foreign direct investment law, when implemented, may limit recourse to international arbitration. Speeding up land reform without damaging farm production or alienating investors will remain a key challenge.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 14% with no exceptions. The corporation tax rate, at 28%, is likely to remain unchanged, but personal income taxes are moving higher because of revenue shortfalls. Planned special economic zones will, nonetheless, offer tax concessions.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for around 52% of GDP in 2015. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important, and it is the only region with which South Africa has a trade surplus.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The African National Congress (ANC) has dominated South African politics since the 1994 election brought an end to apartheid and white minority rule. The party won another comfortable victory in May 2014, albeit with a reduced share of the vote. The ANC, led by Nelson Mandela (1991-97), Thabo Mbeki (1997-2007) and now Jacob Zuma, steadily raised its voting share to a high-water mark of 69.7% in 2004, although support ebbed to 65.9% in 2009 and 62.2% in 2014 (and fell to an all-time low of 54% in municipal elections in 2016). The ANC continues to hold a large majority of seats in parliament under South Africa's proportional representation system of voting. The party also retained eight of the nine provinces in 2014. The ANC rules in partnership with the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) and the South African Communist Party (SACP) in a tripartite alliance.
Opposition: The Democratic Alliance (DA), which draws most of its support from minority voters (white, mixed-race and Indian), increased its share of the vote from 16.7% in 2009 to 22.2% in 2014 and remains the official opposition. The election of Mmusi Maimane as the DA's new leader in 2015 marked a watershed moment in South African politics. As the party's first black leader, Mr Maimane could help to spread the DA's appeal to the majority black electorate, especially in urban areas. Illustrating this, the DA secured 26.9% of votes in 2016's municipal elections. The Economic Freedom Fighters, a new party led by Julius Malema, who espouses a radical agenda, came third with 6.3% of the vote in 2014. Other opposition groups include the Inkatha Freedom Party and the breakaway New Freedom Party, which are both based in KwaZulu-Natal. Support for the Congress of the People (Cope), which broke away from the ANC to win 7.4% of the vote in 2009, collapsed to less than 1% in 2014 following protracted leadership disputes.

Next elections: The next general election is scheduled for May 2019.
Political outlook: Political stability
The ruling African National Congress (ANC) will remain in power until the 2019 general election, although its chances of winning another (sixth) term have receded. This reflects the party's worst-ever showing in last August's municipal elections and increasingly bitter internal divisions between supporters and opponents of the president, Jacob Zuma. The anti-Zuma faction fears that the president's string of corruption scandals will cause long-lasting electoral damage, whereas pro-Zuma loyalists are keen to protect existing patronage networks. A reshuffle by the president on March 31st-when he sacked the respected finance minister, Pravin Gordhan, and several other ministers-and a recent leak of a large cache of emails that appear to provide further evidence of the "capture" of state institutions by the Gupta brothers (businessmen close to the president) have exacerbated ANC in-fighting. The decision by two credit rating agencies to cut South Africa's sovereign credit rating from investment-grade to junk has added further tension, amid concerns that Mr Zuma's "capture" of the Treasury will amplify corruption.
Several high-profile ANC figures, and the party's allies-the South African Communist Party and the Congress of South African Trade Unions-are openly calling for Mr Zuma's resignation, but eight years in power have allowed him to build a strong support base. Both the anti-Zuma and pro-Zuma camps are evenly matched, including on the party's National Executive Committee, making it difficult to force the president's removal. Mr Zuma survived a no-confidence motion in parliament on August 8th, despite the speaker, Baleka Mbete, in a surprise decision, allowing a secret ballot. However, the president's 198-177 margin of victory suggests that at least 26 ANC legislators voted against him (while others abstained), which further weakens his position. Many of their colleagues similarly oppose the president but were reluctant to depose him (and his government), as this would have been an unprecedented act by parliament.
Barring Mr Zuma's early departure, the future of the ANC (and the wider political scene) will rest on the outcome of the party's five-yearly electoral summit in December. Mr Zuma will stand down as party leader (although not as national president) but is seeking to engineer the succession in favour of Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma (the former chair of the Africa Union Commission and his ex-wife) to maximise his influence during the remainder of his presidency. The anti-Zuma camp, comprising large sections of the urban population, trade unions and centrists, instead back Cyril Ramaphosa (the deputy leader of both party and country), who would probably pursue a more pragmatic agenda. Internal campaigning will intensify ahead of December as each side attempts to gain an advantage, although a deadlock could see a third, compromise candidate emerge. A failure by Mr Zuma to secure his preferred leadership team would increase the chances of his early departure from the presidency.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The constitution, painstakingly negotiated in the run-up to the 1994 election, is the bedrock of South Africa's non-racial, post-apartheid society, and is respected across most of the political spectrum. The constitution embodies a fairly robust separation of powers between the legislature, the executive and the judiciary, and provides for strong institutions such as a Constitutional Court and an inde-pendent central bank. These basic cornerstones of South African democracy are unlikely to face any serious threats over the outlook period. Constitutional amendments, of which there have been 17 to date, require the support of at least two-thirds of members of parliament (MPs)-rising to three-quarters for key provisions-but changes thus far (such as allowing floor-crossing by MPs and then subsequently rescinding the measure) have not significantly altered the balance of power. The ANC may seek to trim provincial authority during the forecast period, in favour of central government, but would face fierce resistance. The most recent amendment, which was implemented in 2013, extends the jurisdiction of the Constitutional Court. However, plans to lengthen the terms of the Court's judges, from 12 years to life, were dropped, reducing the risk of political appointees becoming embedded. The government has criticised some court rulings against controversial appointments and policies-leading the chief justice, Mogoeng Mogoeng, to rebuke the executive for interfering-but, despite the tension, The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that judicial independence will not be compromised.
However, there are several weaknesses in the current political system that work against effective government. First, the electoral code, based on pure proportional representation and a party list system, means that there is no direct link between MPs and their constituents, which gives Luthuli House (the ANC headquarters) and the executive much greater influence over legislators than would otherwise be the case. Linked to this, appointments to some key institutions (such as the National Prosecuting Authority) are often made for political reasons, which compromises their effectiveness. Second, the ANC's large parliamentary majority, coupled with opposition weaknesses, means that many important debates are hidden from public view within the party hierarchy. Other factors working against good governance are an increase in patronage and corruption under the president, Mr Zuma, and serious internal divisions between his supporters and opponents. The municipal election results in August 2016, when the ANC's voting share dipped to a record low of 54%-thereby allowing the opposition to capture three key municipalities-potentially herald an end to ANC hegemony. This would be positive for democratic deepening, but the speed of the process and the resulting outcome remain uncertain.
Political outlook: Election watch
The ANC's voting share shrank to 54% in last August's municipal elections, putting its majority at risk in 2019, although it typically does better in national polls, helped by higher turnouts. The ANC will hope that a new party leadership will revive its fortunes, especially given Mr Zuma's loss of popularity. However, leadership change alone may be insufficient to revitalise the ANC without renewed efforts to crack down on corruption, improve service delivery and spur job creation via much-needed structural reforms. The 2019 election outcome will also depend on the interim performance of the Democratic Alliance (DA)-and its coalition partners-in newly captured metropolitan councils. The challenges of expansion and running minority administrations will test the DA's reputation for stronger governance. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that the ANC will retain a small national majority in 2019 (with a similar voting share to 2016), although the opposition is well placed to capture Gauteng, to add to its control of Western Cape. The period of ANC hegemony is coming to an end, although the speed of the process and the resulting outcome are far from certain.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Jacob Zuma
The president, re-elected in May 2014, is due to stand down as leader of the African National Congress (ANC) in December 2017 and as president in 2019, after two five-year terms in each case. However, a series of corruption scandals, coupled with a sharp fall in the ANC's voting share in municipal elections in August 2016, have weakened his authority. A failure by Mr Zuma to engineer a victory for his preferred leadership team at the ANC's electoral summit in December could bring a premature end to his presidency.
Cyril Ramaphosa
The influential former politician-turned-businessman, and the deputy leader of the ANC (since 2012) and the country (since 2014), Mr Ramaphosa is one of the two frontrunners to become the new ANC boss in December. As a moderate and a pragmatist, with trade union roots, he draws support from both the ANC's centre and left, but faces opposition from the pro-Zuma camp. Mr Ramaphosa's lengthy period in business (when he became very wealthy) arouses some distrust.
Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma
The former chair of the African Union Commission and Mr Zuma's ex-wife, Ms Dlamini-Zuma is the other main contender to become the next ANC leader. As Mr Zuma's preferred successor, she is backed by the president's allies, but she could also be tarnished by the president's loss of credibility. Based on her extensive ministerial career (prior to joining the African Union), Ms Dlamini-Zuma would not be an inspired or reformist leader.
Gwede Mantashe
Now serving a second term as ANC secretary-general, Mr Mantashe is also chairman of the South African Communist Party, thus adding substance (and tension) to the tripartite alliance. As a powerful official and an effective administrator, he will play a kingmaker role when the ANC selects a new leader. Despite his implicit opposition to Mr Zuma, he will, nonetheless, continue to mediate between all wings of the tripartite alliance.
Baleka Mbete
The speaker of the National Assembly and chair of the ANC, Mr Mbete is one of several candidates that could emerge as the new ANC leader in December in the event of a deadlock between the two main contenders. Her surprise decision to allow for a secret ballot in a recent no-confidence motion against Mr Zuma boosted her profile. Zweli Mkhize, the ANC treasurer, is another potential compromise candidate, given his good working relationship with all the main factions.
Malusi Gigaba
Installed as finance minister in March 2017, after the president controversially sacked Pravin Gordhan, who was widely respected, Mr Gigaba is viewed as being loyal to Mr Zuma, but he is also relatively young and ambitious, from the next generation of politicians. He is potentially well placed to rise up the party hierarchy, provided his stint at the Treasury is not deemed to be a failure.
Julius Malema
Expelled from the ANC in 2012 for repeated defiance, Mr Malema's Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) secured third place in the 2014 election with 6.3% of the vote. The EFF regularly disrupts parliament, leading to its expulsion on several occasions, and will continue to espouse radical and populist policies, such as nationalisation and expropriation. The party won 8.2% of the vote in municipal elections in August 2016, giving it the balance of power in several municipalities.
Mmusi Maimane
Elected as the new leader of the Democratic Alliance (DA, the official opposition) in May 2015, the youthful Mr Maimane (aged 35) has enjoyed a swift rise up the party hierarchy since entering politics in 2010 and becoming the DA's parliamentary leader in 2014. His is helping to spread the party's appeal beyond minority groups to the black majority, as shown by the DA's improved performance in municipal elections in August 2016. His predecessor, Helen Zille, will retain the premiership of the Western Cape.
Thuli Madonsela
Named by Time, a US weekly news magazine, in April 2014 as one of the world's 100 most influential people, Ms Madonsela, a lawyer who helped to draft the constitution, became an increasingly effective anti-corruption fighter after she was appointed as public protector in 2009. A string of detailed reports, including into taxpayer-funded improvements to Mr Zuma's Nkandla homestead, bolstered her reputation. Replaced by Busisiwe Mkhwebane when her term ended in October 2016, she could enter the political arena.
Political outlook: International relations
South Africa, the most advanced economy in Africa, will play an important role in regional and world affairs. The country will remain deeply engaged with Africa, particularly Southern Africa, and will continue to support peacekeeping operations in the continent's conflict zones. Alongside fellow members of the Southern African Development Community, South Africa will also seek to build closer "South-South" ties, especially with fellow members of the BRICS grouping (Brazil, Russia, India and China) and with other African trade blocs. South Africa's prioritisation of African ties partly explains the submission in October 2016 of a notice of withdrawal to the International Criminal Court (ICC), which some argue unfairly targets the continent. However, South Africa revoked the withdrawal notice in March after a High Court in Pretoria ruled that the government is constitutionally unable to leave the ICC without first passing an act of parliament. South Africa's future membership of the ICC is therefore subject to a range of uncertainties.

The population will continue to grow relatively slowly
South Africa's population is projected to grow at a relatively modest rate of 0.9% a year in 2017-21, owing to the sustained impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit projects that the population will rise from an estimated 56m in 2016 to 58.7m in 2021, although the final outcome also depends on levels of net migration. According to the latest official estimates for 2017, 7.1m people were living with HIV/AIDS-the most of any country, and equivalent to 12.6% of the population. However, most AIDS indicators are now improving, helped by treatment programmes and education campaigns. The incidence rate (of new infections) fell to just 0.9% in 2017, for example, from 1.9% in 2005, and the prevalence rate among 15-49 year olds eased to 18%, its lowest level for ten years. Moreover, the number of deaths attributable to AIDS shrank to a multi-year low of 126,755 in 2017 (equivalent to 25% of all deaths) from a peak level of 345,185 in 2006 (49.2% of deaths), because of the rollout of anti-retroviral (ARV) therapy. Thabo Mbeki (the president from 1999-2008) initially dismissed the efficacy of ARV drugs, a stance that significantly worsened the AIDS crisis, but drug treatment gathered pace in 2007 and gained new momentum after Jacob Zuma became president in 2009. As a result, the number of people receiving ARV therapy soared from just 100,000 in 2005 to about 3.5m in 2016, which is enabling many victims to live longer and more productive lives. The costs of treatment are substantial, however, amounting to about US$2bn a year, funded mostly from domestic sources.
A small increase in the incidence rate and in AIDS-related deaths in 2015 raised concerns that progress against the disease had stalled (possibly because of treatment failings) but the figures for 2016 and 2017 reveal the resumption of a downward trend in both indicators. Nonetheless, AIDS will remain a significant source of mortality in South Africa into the medium term, and will continue to impose high costs at the household, corporate and national levels. The loss of trained workers, either through death or extended absenteeism, is particularly damaging in a country so short of skills. This requires organisations to adopt coping strategies, such as increased expenditure on training. A weak public health system, following years of mismanagement and underinvestment, is an additional challenge, leading to increased reliance on private healthcare for those who can afford to pay. The government plans to introduce a national health insurance system during the forecast period, but progress will be slow because of financial and logistical constraints.
Life expectancy will rise steadily
The success of ARV drugs is clear from the steady rise in like expectancy from a low 53.5 years in 2006 to 64 years in 2017, according to the latest official mid-year estimates, although there are divergences between different data sources. The improvement moved South African life expectancy closer to the average for other upper-middle-income countries, and a further increase can be expected during the forecast period. The age profile of the country will remain heavily skewed towards children and young adults: mid-year estimates for 2017 show that 56.4% of the population is aged under 30 years and 29.6% under 15 years. Average life expectancy and age profiles are markedly different according to population group. The black population-80.8% of the total in mid-2017-is more skewed towards the youth segment than the national average, whereas the white population-8% of the total, and typically more highly educated and wealthier-has an age profile more closely aligned with OECD averages. The other main population groups are mixed-race people ("coloureds"), with 8.8% of the total, and Indian/Asian, with 2.5%.
Rapid urbanisation will strain social services
South Africa has experienced urbanisation on a large scale (an estimated 65.3% of the population lived in urban centres in 2016), principally in the main metropolitan areas of Gauteng, namely Pretoria and Johannesburg, and the two coastal cities of Cape Town and Durban. Urbanisation will continue throughout the forecast period, lifting the proportion living in cities (and associated slums) to 68.5% by 2021. Urbanisation is boosting market potential but also raises challenges for policymakers, especially with regard to strengthening service delivery at the municipal level, where capacity is typically weaker. Urbanisation is being accompanied by the rapid growth of informal settlements in the vicinity of cities and towns across the country, fuelled by population movements from poorer provinces (such as Limpopo and North West) to richer ones, and migration from neighbouring countries. Poor service provision, high unemployment and inward migration will also fuel protests, some of which will be violent and tinged with xenophobia.
