Investment in critical infrastructure will facilitate business operations
South Africa's business environment rankings for 2017-21 remain unchanged at 52nd globally and seventh regionally, despite a small rise in the country's absolute score. As a key emerging market (and the most advanced economy in Africa), with vast mineral reserves, sound banks and a broad commitment to free markets, the country will remain an important business centre. Ongoing investment in critical infrastructure will facilitate business operations, and progress against HIV/AIDS is boosting life expectancy.
Companies will, however, face a significant number of challenges, ranging from slow GDP growth and high unemployment to elevated policy uncertainty. The fate of key legislation, such as a draft expropriation bill (which may reduce compensation), a foreign investment act (that limits recourse to international arbitration) and a new mining charter (which imposes stricter rules governing black economic empowerment; BEE), is currently unclear. Fudged and inconsistent policymaking (and implementation) reflects deep divisions within the ruling African National Congress (ANC) between supporters and opponents of the president, Jacob Zuma, who stands accused of corruption and patronage. The former main divide, between free-market moderates and left-wing interventionists, is now less significant (at least temporarily) as both stand in the anti-Zuma camp. A well-crafted National Development Plan outlines a framework for faster growth, but implementation is being impeded by government divisions. Other challenges include strict labour laws and frequent strikes (both of which reflect the political power of the trade unions), skills shortages, high crime rates and deep-seated inequality. More positively, South Africa has several robust institutions, such as an independent central bank (the South African Reserve Bank; SARB) and an impartial judiciary, which is increasingly being relied on to challenge controversial legislation. In addition, electricity shortages have now ended, helped by new plant openings, although rising real-term tariffs will offset some of the benefits.
Business environment outlook: South Africa's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Policy is broadly pro-business, but favourable moves, such as new special economic zones offering tax incentives, are accompanied by tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2019-21: Efforts to speed up land reform intensify, although the government rejects expropriation without compensation. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: A new foreign investment law risks limiting access to international arbitration, and a new mining charter is likely to impose new regulations. A draft expropriation law, which could affect levels of compensation, re-emerges from parliament.
2019-21: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships but remains opposed to the privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Some remaining exchange controls on capital flows are relaxed but others are retained. Selected trade tariffs are raised to protect vulnerable industries (such as steel). Efforts to build closer trade ties with key emerging markets continue.
2019-21: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes
2017-18: Tough fiscal conditions lead to higher direct and indirect taxes, although corporation tax rates remain unchanged. A carbon tax is introduced, but many details are still pending.
2019-21: Efforts continue to streamline and modernise the tax system, and expand the tax base.
Financing
2017-18: A rise in borrowing costs across the economy accompanies the loss of South Africa's investment-grade credit rating. Local banks remain sound and profitable on aggregate, and continue to be a key source of corporate financing.
2019-21: The central bank's continued independence helps to preserve financial system stability. Interest rates stabilise before edging lower, leading to cheaper borrowing.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour laws stay inflexible, despite the negative impact on employment, because of trade unions' political power. Rising wages (including a proposed national minimum wage) and the risk of strikes deter business from creating jobs.
2019-21: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Investment in transport and electricity boosts capacity, although bottlenecks persist. The rollout of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts telecommunications provision and cuts costs.
2019-21: The phased start-up of new base-load electricity-generating plants facilitates fresh investment in energy-intensive sectors, but rising power tariffs remain a deterrent.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.8 5.8 68 70 9 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The macroeconomic environment score stagnates in absolute terms for the forecast period, pushing down South Africa's global ranking to 70th (from 68th) and its regional ranking to tenth (from ninth). Real GDP growth will remain sluggish (averaging just 1.8% a year in 2017-21) but will show a broad upward trend, from 0.8% in 2017 to 2.5% in 2021, driven by modest rises in consumption and investment, and improved electricity supplies. Nonetheless, growth will remain vulnerable to global developments (such as the UK's exit from the EU and a slowdown in China) and to domestic policy uncertainty, and will be insufficient to bring down the high unemployment rate (currently 27.7%). A small interest-rate cut in July may give a small boost to growth, but recent downgrades to South Africa's credit rating by key agencies will dampen confidence. The current-account deficit will remain a source of vulnerability, although it will move within a fairly narrow range of 3.8-4.6% of GDP in 2017-21. The rand-a widely traded and market-determined currency-will resume depreciating in 2018-21 after a rare year of strengthening in 2017, although the pace of decline will taper off towards the end of the forecast period. Inflation breached the SARB's 3-6% target range by a small margin in 2016 (as drought drove food prices higher) but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects inflation to fall back within the target range in 2017-21 (except for temporary breaches), underpinned by prudent monetary policy and weak growth in demand.
The challenge of black economic empowerment
A unique, challenging and controversial aspect of South Africa's policy environment is the black economic empowerment (BEE) programme, which aims to redress the iniquities of the apartheid era-whereby most wealth and assets ended up in the hands of the white minority-by gradually transferring economic power to the black majority. Legislation governing BEE includes sector-specific charters and broader-based codes of good conduct, both of which set targets for ownership and other variables. Broadly speaking, BEE requires firms to have 25% black ownership, although the precise figure varies by sector (and foreign subsidiaries are largely exempt from equity transfer rules). Revised BEE codes of practice, which came into force in May 2015, cut the number of elements on a company's BEE scorecard from seven to five-ownership, enterprise and supplier development, skills development, management control and socioeconomic development-and reweighted the various components. Alongside other changes, this will make it harder for firms to earn (or retain) a BEE-compliant rating: non-compliant firms will be at a competitive disadvantage when bidding for government contracts or negotiating public-private partnerships. Apart from the problems posed by changes to the rules, two key questions remain unanswered after 15 years of BEE: how long will BEE remain in force, and is a once-empowered company always empowered? A new draft mining charter, unveiled in June 2017, dismisses the "once empowered, always empowered" principle, by requiring mining companies to set up new BEE deals to replace any that have lapsed (such as when black shareholders sell their stakes). A court ruling on the principle, which will have implications for other sectors, is expected in November. With regard to wealth transfer, BEE has been partly successful: the initial benefits were spread fairly narrowly (helping to create a new black elite), although a drive towards more broad-based empowerment (by including workers and suppliers, for example), may distribute the rewards more evenly.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.0 5.3 51 56 6 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Policy towards private enterprise will remain broadly accommodating, but problems in some areas will lead to a small deterioration in South Africa's global and regional rankings. Monetary policy will remain prudent, and public-private partnerships (PPPs) will become more commonplace (especially for capital projects), but levels of uncertainty are rising, especially since the president, Mr Zuma, carried out a shock cabinet reshuffle in March, including the sacking of his respected finance minister, and his replacement by a loyalist. This poses a threat to fiscal discipline, although the risks may not materialise. Under the guise of "radical economic transformation", Mr Zuma and his allies also back other controversial actions, such as expropriation without compen-sation, and increasing BEE ownership targets for mines. However, as shown by a key ANC policy conference in June, backing for such measures is lukewarm at best. The risk of radical policies being implemented is therefore small, but the level of uncertainty is high, especially in the run-up to the ANC's electoral summit in December. Coupled with concerns about higher taxes and labour militancy, investment is likely to be muted until the uncertainties are clarified. Business lobbying against controversial proposals can sometimes be effective.
Powerful parastatals (such as the power generator, Eskom, and the port/rail operator, Transnet) will continue to play a key role, despite suffering from weak management, political interference and financial indiscipline. This will limit private opportunity, although there will be some openings for PPPs and independent initiatives, especially in the energy sector. The ANC will not embrace nationalisation but will remain wary of outright privatisation, and proposals to inject private capital into ailing parastatals will face delays. The government's industrial policy will continue to offer incentives in some sectors, especially vehicles and textiles, and planned new special economic zones will provide tax concessions. The latest industrial policy iteration in May heralds support for steel, agro-processing and a new black industrialists programme.
Land reform will remain very challenging
Property and shareholder rights are respected and asset transfer currently takes place on a "willing buyer, willing seller" basis. A new draft expropriation bill (currently in abeyance), though compliant with the constitution, would, nonetheless, de-link compensation from market rates-by allowing the figure to be determined by a valuer-general in cases of dispute-although the courts would remain the ultimate arbiter. The draft expropriation bill is partly geared towards expediting the process of land reform, which is running well behind target. The government originally hoped to transfer 30% of white farmland to blacks by 2014, but the current level is about 10% because of a lack of funds, inefficient institutions and poor support for new black farmers. Other land reform proposals, such as setting a maximum cap on farm size and barring foreigners from owning farmland, risk damaging agricultural productivity and wider investor confidence, if not handled carefully.
Competition policy is becoming stricter
Policy towards anti-competitive practices is becoming stricter, as the competition authorities (comprising a commission and a tribunal) intensify their battle against cartels and over-pricing. This trend will continue in 2017-21, guided by the phased implementation of an amended competition law (originally passed in 2009). Changes already implemented include allowing the commission to launch a probe without receiving a formal complaint, while others remain pending, such as making directors criminally liable for misdeeds (which may come into force during the forecast period). However, the stricter line being taken by the competition agencies has the potential to be counterproductive. Securing approval from the competition authorities for mergers can be a lengthy process, especially for large deals involving foreign takeovers; conditions are typically attached, such as retaining jobs or supporting local suppliers.
A new company law provides for an alternative to bankruptcy
A new Company Act, which finally came into force in 2011 after several years of gestation, is broadly positive for business. Key benefits include the introduction of a new business rescue scheme (as an alternative to bankruptcy) and increased shareholder rights (to facilitate corporate governance). The new company law will mostly affect large firms and new enterprises, as most existing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) remain regulated by the Closed Corporations Act (of 1984), which is no longer an option for start-ups. The law also created the Companies and Intellectual Property Commission, which is charged with registering new firms and patents, although it will continue to struggle to eliminate the delays and inefficiencies that troubled its predecessor.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.0 6.4 58 54 7 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Policy uncertainties could hamper FDI inflows
South Africa will remain a key destination for non-oil foreign direct investment (FDI) in Africa during the forecast period, including in banking, telecoms, tourism, mining and manufacturing, helped by the country's role as a gateway to the rest of the continent, especially Southern Africa. This will facilitate a small improvement in South Africa's ranking during the forecast period, despite the uncertainties surrounding several key policies. A controversial new mining charter, for example, unveiled in June, could inhibit investment in minerals, although legal challenges by the Chamber of Mines have a good chance of overturning some of the measures. Foreign investors, for the most part, face the same challenges as domestic firms, including strict labour laws, uncertainties surrounding land rights and the dominant position of parastatals. Opposition by elements in the ANC to foreign influence in strategic sectors, especially towards foreign acquisitions of local firms, can be an additional obstacle. Deals can be subject to close scrutiny, and come with conditions attached, as was the case when a US retail giant, Walmart, acquired a majority stake in Massmart in 2011.
A new Promotion and Protection of Investment Bill, known more simply as the FDI bill, threatens to create a new raft of uncertainties. The bill, which was signed into law by the president in December 2015 but has not yet been implemented, limits recourse to international arbitration, leaving local courts responsible for settling disputes. The government claims that the new law will provide a more streamlined environment for FDI (compared with existing ad hoc arrangements), and that South Africa's constitution (and judiciary) provides sufficient protection. However, investors will remain wary until the full details are clarified. As the new law has yet to come into force, the impact will depend partly on the accompanying regulations. South Africa has also terminated (or failed to extend) around a dozen bilateral investment treaties with EU countries, believing them to have little impact on actual investment flows, which is exacerbating investors' concerns.
FDI will be driven in part by opportunities for PPPs, as well as private-led initiatives, especially in the field of infrastructure provision. For example, private firms, both foreign and local, are playing a leading role in the rollout of renewable energy (especially solar and wind), having invested almost US$14bn to date, with more projects planned, although delays in securing connections to the grid are a source of concern.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.9 7.3 55 52 6 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Exchange controls will be gradually liberalised
South Africa has progressively loosened exchange controls on capital flows in recent years, by moving from centralised directives towards prudential self-regulation. This trend is likely to continue, although some restrictions will remain in place. Liberalisation stalled during the 2008-09 global financial crisis (as the controls offered some protection, by constraining capital flight), but gained new momentum in 2010-11 when the Treasury embarked on a new wave of reforms. These include removing the ceiling for outward investment; lowering the ceiling on advance payments for imports; allowing South African companies to open foreign bank accounts without prior approval; permitting banks to invest 25% of their liabilities in offshore portfolio instruments; and offering concessions to foreign firms that set up headquarters in South Africa. Numerous restrictions and limits remain in place, however, and regulations are subject to amendment, which requires close monitoring to ensure compliance. Additional reforms remain under consideration, although liberalisation will be a gradual process, especially in view of lingering concerns about the stability of the global financial system.
Sluggish growth combined with an activist industrial policy will lead to protective measures in some cases (in the form of higher tariffs and anti-dumping duties)-such as for steel-although South Africa will seek to remain compliant with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules. Vehicle assembly, in particular, will continue to offer incentives to manufacturers, although these now take the form of production incentives (rather than trade-related incentives) in order to meet WTO requirements.
The Southern African Development Community (SADC) will progressively implement a free-trade area, but the initiative is running behind schedule because of wide economic and policy divergences between member states. Loftier ambitions for a customs union, a common market and monetary union are unlikely to be realised during the outlook period. The proposed merger of SADC, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) and the East African Community (EAC) into a Tripartite Free-Trade Area will potentially speed up integration by providing a harmonised framework, but a final agreement remains pending. Non-tariff barriers and poor infrastructure links are other serious obstacles. Nonetheless, regional integration will advance in stages, thereby increasing potential market size.
South Africa (and other members of the South Africa Customs Union) successfully negotiated a new economic partnership agreement (EPA) with the EU in 2014. The deal will facilitate deeper trade and investment ties, and provides improved access to the EU for South African agricultural exports. South Africa will also retain trade preferences in the US under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), which has been extended by ten years to 2025. South Africa's continued participation was under threat, because of restrictions imposed on US meat imports, but the issue was finally settled in January 2016. Nonetheless, South Africa's AGOA status will remain conditional on its policies towards trade liberalisation and investment protection.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.4 6.1 31 43 8 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Tight fiscal conditions will increase the risk of tax rises
Tight fiscal conditions, marked by sluggish growth and revenue shortfalls, will heighten the risk of further tax increases during the forecast period. This will lead to a fall in South Africa's global and regional rankings. Taxes remain on an upward trend following hikes in income tax in fiscal years 2015/16 and 2017/18 (April to March)-including a new top rate of 45%-and increases in capital gains taxes in 2016/17. The corporation tax rate (of 28%) is unlikely to be increased, but the government may raise the value-added tax (VAT) rate, currently at 14%, if the pace of fiscal consolidation falls behind schedule or if funds are urgently needed (for instance, to finance the proposed National Health Insurance plan). Other changes to the tax system will be implemented during the forecast period-including administrative reforms-informed by an ongoing review of taxation being undertaken by the Davis Tax Committee, which may not be completed until late 2017. The aim is to streamline the system and boost compliance, while also sealing loopholes and cracking down on evasion.
Tax incentives will continue to apply in some cases, including for small firms, which have enjoyed reduced corporation tax rates since 2013. A youth employment subsidy (via tax concessions) from 2014 remains in place, although its duration is uncertain. The government also proposes to offer a discounted 15% rate of corporation tax in proposed new special economic zones (which will replace the existing industrial development zones that do not offer tax concessions), but final approval remains pending.
New environmental and health-related taxes will be introduced during the forecast period, including a carbon tax (intended to curb emissions and improve energy efficiency) and, possibly, a sugar tax. However, implementation of proposals for a broad-based carbon tax continues to face delays, because of the complexity of the issue and the need to devise a suitable framework that does not unduly disadvantage local industry. Firms will continue to lobby against the measure, although some form of carbon tax will be introduced during the forecast period (possibly in the 2018/19 budget but probably later).
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.3 6.3 36 49 5 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Banks remain sound and well-capitalised
The banking system remains sound and well-capitalised, and is supervised effectively by the South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank), although challenges such as slow GDP growth and regulatory uncertainty explain the decline in the ranking. Banks' capital-adequacy ratios remain comfortably above prescribed minimum levels, and profitability (as measured by return on equity) remains satisfactory, despite a small dip to 16.6% in June from 17% a year earlier. Despite interest-rate rises totalling 200 basis points in 2014-16, the non-performing loan ratio remains low, and was unchanged at 2.9% in June 2017 from a year earlier. Banks are, nonetheless, facing weak overall demand for private-sector credit because of subdued borrowing by households. The growth rate in credit allocation to households fell to just 0.7% year on year in March 2017, before picking up to 2.9% in June, although both figures are negative in real terms. Lending to business is more robust, and grew by 8.8% in March, rising to 9% in June. A small, 25-basis-point interest-rate cut to 6.75% in July 2017 (which lowered the prime lending rate to 10.25%), will facilitate credit growth. Local banks will remain a key source of funds for private investment projects, as illustrated by their participation in the financing of renewable energy projects. Other key sources of financing are the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and, to an increasing extent, local development finance institutions, such as the Industrial Development Corporation.
The four dominant banks-Barclays Africa/ABSA, Nedbank, Standard and First Rand-are world-class players with strong international links. They are also, to varying degrees, expanding their presence in the rest of Africa, thereby cementing South Africa's role as a gateway to the rest of the continent. Smaller banks, especially those specialising in unsecured lending, are more vulnerable: Africa Bank (Abil) collapsed in 2014, although a rescue package by the SARB showed the regulator's willingness to act when financial stability is threatened. The withdrawal by Barclays from Africa, largely completed in June 2017 with the sale of additional shares to local institutional investors, poses no threat to the overall health or performance of the banking sector, but will lead to rebranding.
The policy front poses opportunities and challenges. Positively, initial implementation of the amended Financial Intelligence Centre Act in June, which met a deadline set by the Financial Action Task Force, removes a threat to the credibility of local banks and will help to tackle money-laundering. However, the long-delayed revision of the financial sector charter could see the imposition of tougher BEE rules. The phased implementation of more stringent Basel III regulatory standards in the lead-up to a 2019 deadline, alongside a new financial sector regulation bill, may impose additional costs.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-22 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.1 5.4 72 72 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The labour market will remain characterised by a strict regulatory environment, partly owing to the political power of the trade unions, and despite its negative impact on job creation. The official unemployment rate climbed to a record high of 27.7% in the first quarter of 2017-and was unchanged in the second quarter-but job creation will remain weak because of government resistance to reforms, alongside a high risk of strikes, and the obligations imposed by the labour components of BEE. A deep split in the labour movement between comparative moderates in the Congress of South African Trade Unions (an ANC ally) and a more radical tendency in the newly formed South African Federation of Trade Unions (Saftu), somewhat weakens the labour voice, but will also prove challenging for firms, as many unionised workers in the private sector are now members of Saftu.
Plans for a national minimum wage, to replace the current system of sectoral minimum wages, pose another potential challenge on the labour front. An advisory committee in November 2016 recommended a minimum wage of R20 (US$1.50) per hour-with partial exemptions in some sectors, to be phased in over two years-which it believes could help to alleviate poverty without denting employment. However, unions, business and government, meeting under the auspices of the National Economic Development and Labour Council (Nedlac), are struggling to conclude a final settlement, thereby adding to uncertainty.
Labour market relations have changed significantly in recent years, following the implementation of three pieces of amended legislation: the Employment Equity Act (2014), the Basic Conditions of Employment Act (2014) and the Labour Relations Act (2015). These, for the most part, are making an already difficult labour environment even more challenging by, for example, imposing new restrictions on the use of labour brokers, such as limiting temporary contracts (for low-paid workers) to a three-month maximum. The aim is to boost permanent employment, but it could prove counterproductive. A clause in the draft Labour Relations Act requiring pre-strike ballots was dropped following trade union pressure. Additional problems with the amended laws include the higher penalties and fines imposed for violations and the increased discretionary powers given to the labour minister. However, there are some inconsistencies between the various laws that have still to be tested in court. Dealing with labour issues will absorb an increasing proportion of management time.
Shortages of skilled workers will remain a key constraint
Skills shortages, exacerbated by HIV/AIDS, will remain prevalent in most sectors, pushing up the premium required to attract skilled workers and leading to the poaching of capable staff. The government, in partnership with the private sector, will maintain initiatives to boost the skills base, but progress will be slow, especially given weaknesses in the education system.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.0 8.2 35 26 3 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Substantial investment boosts infrastructure ranking
South Africa's infrastructure is relatively well developed, and certainly the best in Africa, although some bottlenecks and deficiencies will persist. Nonetheless, heavy and sustained public-sector investment in transport and energy-in a bid to lay the foundations for faster, long-term growth-explains the rise in South Africa's global and regional rankings for 2017-21. The dominance of parastatals restricts opportunities for private providers, although PPPs are becoming more common, in both energy and transport. Extending the Gauteng mass-transit railway (one of the largest PPPs), which opened in 2010, will continue during the outlook period. However, raising funds and deciding on end-user pricing will remain challenging, as illustrated by the long-running row over the introduction of tolls (in 2013) to finance Gauteng's highways, which continues to generate controversy.
New plant openings alleviate power shortages
Electricity shortages intensified in 2015, leading to frequent bouts of load-shedding, but the situation has improved significantly, and we expect supplies to be adequate in 2017-21, albeit at the cost of higher tariffs. Power cuts stemmed from lengthy delays in the construction of two new coal-fired plants at Medupi and Kusile-commissioned by Eskom (the parastatal power company and monopoly buyer)-but the first two of Medupi's six units have now been com-missioned and others will be phased in during the forecast period. Substantial private investment (of about US$14bn) in renewable energy (mainly wind and solar), facilitated by the Ministry of Energy, is also boosting supplies, although delays by Eskom in connecting new projects to the grid may deter new entrants. The improvement in supply from coal-fired, pumped-storage and renewable projects-alongside financial contraints-means the government's earlier plans for a new round of nuclear plant procurement are unlikely to come to fruition. Set against the benefits of a steady improvement in power supplies, electricity tariffs will continue to rise strongly in real terms-after a brief respite in 2017-imposing additional costs on firms, while also fostering a culture of energy efficiency (which presents both challenges and opportunities for business).
Ongoing construction of a domestic cable network will boost bandwidth
South Africa's telecoms market is among the most advanced in Africa in terms of technology and services provided. User costs are still comparatively high but are on a downward trend because of increased competition in all market segments. The arrival of new submarine fibre-optic cables and the ongoing construction of a domestic cable network will boost bandwidth, cut costs and promote the spread of high-end services such as broadband. A global study into cloud-computing readiness by the Business Software Alliance in 2016 ranked South Africa 14th out of 24 countries-a six-place rise. In a further boost to information and communications technology, South Africa will host the majority portion of the US$2bn Square Kilometre Array (SKA) complex, a powerful radio telescope to be situated in the Northern Cape. An initial segment opened in July 2016, to scientific acclaim, although the project will not be fully completed until 2024.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Policymakers face the difficult task of boosting economic growth within a context of global uncertainty, while avoiding macroeconomic imbalances. Adding to the challenge, South Africa's loss of its investment-grade credit rating will dent confidence and may lead to tighter monetary policy. Fiscal policy is now less certain, but any relaxation of spending restraints, despite offering a short-term stimulus, would risk higher debts and taxes. The main medium-term challenge is to overcome structural constraints to faster growth, such as infra-structure bottlenecks and skills shortages. Targeted industrial incentives will therefore stay in place and infrastructure investment will remain a priority, although wasteful spending poses a threat. The completion of key projects will facilitate business activity later in the forecast period, but labour market rigidities will persist and anti-competitive practice policies will become stricter.
Splits in government will complicate policymaking. Outright privatisations will be rare, and foreign acquisitions of domestic entities may face close scrutiny, although opportunities will arise for public-private partnerships. Uncertainty surrounding a new foreign direct investment law (which limits recourse to international arbitration) and a new expropriation bill will weigh on sentiment, as will disputes about new mining laws. Compliance with black economic empowerment (BEE) targets will remain a challenge for corporates, especially given ongoing changes to the legal framework. The presidency's call for "radical economic transformation" will raise the level of policy uncertainty, especially in regard to BEE and land reform, to the detriment of private investment.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021
Government expenditure 29.9 30.0 30.1 30.1 29.9 29.8
Government revenue 26.5 26.8 27.2 27.5 27.6 27.8
Budget balance -3.4 -3.2 -2.9 -2.6 -2.3 -2.0

Fiscal risks in South Africa are rising after Mr Zuma's sacking on March 31st of the respected finance minister, Mr Gordhan, and his experienced deputy, and their replacement by presidential loyalists. This potentially heralds an erosion of fiscal prudence, more frequent bail-outs for badly managed parastatals and the launch of costly, controversial and patronage-prone projects, such as nuclear power procurement. Fiscal indiscipline implies both higher public debt, which is already approaching the limits of prudence, and higher taxes. Underlining the threat, two credit rating agencies (Standard & Poor's and Fitch) cut South Africa's sovereign credit rating by one notch, from investment-grade to junk, following the reshuffle. The consequence will be a rise in the government's borrowing costs, especially for external loans, but also for rand-denominated securities-the primary source of government financing-of which a significant proportion is held by foreign investors.
The risks may not materialise in full, helped in part by the Treasury's institutional depth and the judiciary's watchdog role. Moreover, the new finance minister, Malusi Gigaba, says that the targets in the budget for fiscal year 2017/18 (April to March), prepared by his predecessor, will be respected. The budget envisages the deficit, as a proportion of GDP, falling to 3.1% in 2017/18, 2.8% in 2018/19 and 2.6% in 2019/20, including a primary surplus in each year. Practicalities suggest that the 2017/18 budget will be largely adhered to, but the risk of fiscal slippage will rise in 2018/19. The new minister's intentions will become clearer with the publication of the next medium-term budget policy statement in October. A key concern is that Mr Gigaba (unlike Mr Gordhan) lacks the authority to defy presidential instructions. Any significant retreat from fiscal consolidation would risk pushing up South Africa's public debt burden, and debt-service obligations, to injudicious levels. Our budget deficit forecasts are broadly unchanged, but any future revisions are more likely to be upward than downward.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 10.5 10.4 10.4 10.5 10.4 10.1

The direction of the next interest-rate move is uncertain, after the South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 6.75% in July, the first reduction for five years. The factors militating against a cut include recent downgrades in South Africa's credit rating (which could lead to a weaker currency and higher inflation) and rising US interest rates. However, inflation has now returned to within the SARB's 3-6% target range, because of a moderation in food prices after last year's drought, while the rand is proving fairly resilient. This gives the SARB scope for monetary loosening, especially in view of subdued GDP growth. A faster slide in the rand could oblige the SARB to reverse the cut in 2018, but a further reduction is possible, if inflation remains within target. We now expect rates to be broadly stable (marked by small adjustments only) in 2017-19 before a modest retreat in 2020-21. The SARB will retain its inflation-targeting mandate and its independence, despite recent efforts by the presidency to hobble the institution and erode its commitment to disciplined monetary policy.

We have kept our real GDP growth forecast for 2017 at 0.8% following a recent downward revision stemming from a range of weak indicators. These include a decline in manufacturing output and stagnant retail sales (in the first five months of the year), subdued credit allocation and a slump in business confidence, especially after South Africa's recent loss of an investment-grade credit rating, and a rise in policy uncertainty. Growth will be faster than in 2016 (when expansion slowed to just 0.3%) because of a strong rebound in agriculture in most locations (after last year's crippling drought) and a mild upturn in mining, in line with global growth trends. In addition, new plant openings will lead to a further improvement in electricity supplies, and tourism is likely to post a second consecutive year of expansion. However, most other sectors will continue to struggle, amid rising levels of unemployment, subdued aggregate demand and weak private investment. The risk of a damaging metalworkers' strike also weighs on the outlook.

Our forecast for 2018, of a modest acceleration in growth to 1.8%, remains unchanged, although the risks are mainly on the downside. The impact of the credit rating downgrade, on both confidence and private investment, may become more pronounced in 2018, especially if accompanied by additional downgrades or unfavourable policy developments (such as stricter regulation and fiscal indiscipline). Conversely, an improvement in the policy outlook, sparked, for example, by the early departure of Mr Zuma, would be growth-friendly. Weak job creation will continue to suppress aggregate demand, although real-term pay rises (for those in work) and a pre-election increase in government spending will provide a modest boost.
Prospects for 2019-21 remain relatively weak but with an improving trend. Growth will remain subdued in 2019, owing to a cyclical slowdown in the US and uncertainties surrounding the next South African general election. Thereafter, growth will edge up to 2.1% in 2020 and 2.5% in 2021, helped by the completion of major infrastructure projects in transport and energy, and a US rebound. The gradual expansion of the black middle class will spur outlays on goods and services, but structural constraints such as skills shortages and inefficient para-statals will continue to dampen economic activity. A negative external balance will also weigh on economic growth throughout most of the forecast period.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
On the supply side, the services sector will remain the largest (69.6% of factor cost GDP in 2016) and will continue to be a key source of growth, although expansion will slow in 2017, before regaining some momentum in 2018-21. Retailing/wholesaling (15.3% of GDP) will face a challenging 2017 because of high unemployment and slow consumer credit uptake, although a small interest-rate cut in July may provide a modest boost, especially to the black middle class. The large banking segment (22.1% of GDP, including real estate and business services) will benefit from higher rates of financial inclusion and from a gradual uptick in GDP growth. Transport and communications (9.4% of GDP) will gain from new investment in infrastructure and fibre-optic cables. However, with a penetration rate of about 150 subscriptions per 100 people, the mobile-phone market is saturated compared with the rest of Sub-Saharan Africa, and growth will come mainly from a transition to high-end services and higher data usage. Tourism has considerable potential-based on South Africa's varied natural attractions and favourable climate-and is also a labour-intensive activity, although high levels of crime will continue to be a deterrent. Tourism rebounded in 2016, after the government started to ease the tighter visa restrictions imposed in 2014-15, and further modest growth is likely during the forecast period.
The industrial sector (28% of factor cost GDP in 2016, including mining) will remain a key part of the economy, with growth showing a broad upward trend in 2017-21, after contracting in 2016. Manufacturing (13.7% of GDP in 2016) is broad-based by Sub-Saharan African standards and will remain a key employer and source of exports, although output is set to shrink in 2017, given sluggish domestic demand and competition from cheap imports, such as steel (despite higher tariffs). The key vehicle segment will benefit from new investment, spurred by incentives offered under the Automotive Production and Development Programme (APDP), which runs to 2020 (with an extension likely), as part of the government's activist industrial policy. Power supply constraints have now eased, helped by new plant openings, but rising tariffs are a challenge. Manufacturing will continue to face an elevated risk of strikes.
Mining makes a modest and declining contribution to GDP (8.1% in 2016) but accounts, directly and indirectly, for about 50% of export earnings. This leaves South Africa highly vulnerable to commodity price fluctuations and to a slowdown in China. Mining also suffers from regulatory uncertainty and labour militancy. Delays in finalising amended mining laws and a controversial new mining charter (which tightens BEE regulations) will continue to inhibit investment. The outcome of pending legal challenges to the new rules will have a strong impact on future trends. The agricultural sector is small (2.4% of GDP in 2016) and vulnerable to drought, but will continue to make an important contribution to exports (including fruit and wine), agro-industry and employment. However, erratic rainfall poses a high degree of risk: droughts in 2015 and 2016 (partly linked to the El Niño climate phenomenon), led agriculture to contract in both years, before a strong rebound in 2017.

Price data for the first six months support our annual average inflation forecast of 5.6% in 2017, down from a seven-year high of 6.6% in 2016, when a serious drought, coupled with brisk rand depreciation, led to a steep rise in food prices and a breach of the SARB's 3-6% target range. The situation will reverse in 2017, as a return to near-normal rainfall pushes down food price inflation. In addition, electricity tariffs will rise by less than the headline rate of inflation for the first time in ten years. Modest rand strengthening in the first half of 2017 is also curbing inflation, although depreciation will gain fresh momentum in the second half, because of high levels of political and policy uncertainty.
Inflation will average 5.5% a year in 2018-21, thereby meeting the SARB's target, despite temporary breaches. Factors keeping inflation in check include prudent monetary policy, spare industrial capacity, slack demand, stricter competition laws and efficiency gains arising from infrastructure investment. However, real-term rises in power tariffs (from 2018 onwards) and higher real wages for those in work will prevent inflation from falling more sharply. In addition, inflation risks stemming from rand depreciation will remain elevated.

The rand weakened slightly to R13.14:US$1 in July (from R12.89:US$1 in June) but remained stronger than a year earlier (by 8.9%). In contrast to brisk rand depreciation in 2016, the currency has been comparatively stable in 2017 to date, averaging R13.21:US$1 in the first seven months of the year, despite a string of adverse developments, such as the loss of South Africa's investment-grade credit rating (downgraded by two rating agencies) in April, and a high degree of political and policy uncertainty. However, despite temporary dips, the rand has proved surprisingly resilient, helped by a more favourable global monetary environment for emerging-market currencies: increases in US interest rates, for example, will be gradual, not rapid. The rand is also finding support from a mild upturn in mineral markets. The rand will, nonetheless, remain vulnerable to local and global uncertainties, leading to a quicker rate of depreciation in the second half of 2017, ahead of the ruling party's electoral summit in December, and the next round of assessments by rating agencies. Despite a renewed slide, we are again revising our annual exchange-rate forecast for 2017 to R13.67:US$1 (marking a first year of appreciation since 2011). We expect the rand to average R16.12:US$1 in 2018, before a more gradual fall to R20.5:US$1 in 2021.

The current-account deficit will widen slightly to 3.8% of GDP in 2017 and 4.4% of GDP in 2018. Export growth will be fairly healthy in 2017-18, thanks largely to a modest upturn in mineral markets. Non-mineral exports (such as cars) will benefit from South Africa's retention of trade preferences under the US African Growth and Opportunity Act. Import growth will similarly rise in 2017-18, underpinned by costlier oil and capital equipment for infrastructure projects-pushing the trade balance back into deficit (after a rare surplus in 2016)-although consequent improvements in logistics capacity and power supply will facilitate exports in the medium term. Notably, the invisibles deficit (on services, income and current transfers) will remain far wider than the goods deficit and will account for most of the current-account shortfall throughout the forecast period. Income payments to foreign investors and transfers to fellow members of the Southern African Customs Union will offset growth in tourism inflows and income earned by outward investors. Projections for 2019-21 show the current-account deficit fluctuating within a range of 4.3-4.6% of GDP, with the annual variation largely attributable to shifts in domestic and global growth trends.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in South Africa
Stocks and flows
South Africa is a prime destination for non-oil-sector foreign direct investment (FDI) in Sub-Saharan Africa. Inflows averaged US$4.5bn a year in 2012-16, although annual figures can vary substantially because of the discontinuous nature of FDI. Inflows peaked at a record of US$9.9bn in 2008, boosted by the US$5.2bn purchase of a 20% stake in Standard Bank by China's state-run Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC)-the second-biggest FDI deal to date-behind the acquisition of 56% of ABSA by Barclays (UK) in 2005. Eight years later, in 2013, Barclays brought together most of its African operations, including ABSA, under the Barclays Africa banner, before subsequently announcing its withdrawal from Africa (in 2016), as part of a global restructuring exercise. The sale of Barclays' majority stake in Barclays Africa, primarily to local investors, was completed in June 2017. FDI regained momentum after the 2009 recession, rising to US$4.6bn in 2012, buoyed by the purchase by Walmart (US) of 51% of Massmart, for US$2.4bn. Inflows jumped to US$8.2bn in 2013, before retreating to US$5.8bn in 2014, although South Africa was Sub-Saharan Africa's leading recipient of FDI in both years. A dip to US$1.5bn in 2015, before a modest rebound to US$2.3bn in 2016, reflects heightened investor concerns over domestic and global prospects. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI to be fairly buoyant during the forecast period, averaging US$3.7bn a year in 2017-21 (and rising towards the end of the period), helped in part by South Africa's status as a gateway to Sub-Saharan Africa. South Africa is also a major outward investor, especially in Africa, where local firms have a presence in a wide range of sectors, including services and infrastructure, as well as in more traditional natural resource exploitation. Outward FDI climbed to US$7.7bn in 2014, before ebbing to US$5.5bn in 2015 and US$3.3bn in 2016, thereby surpassing inward FDI in all three years.
Origin and distribution
The UK remains a key source of FDI, illustrated by deals with Vodafone and Barclays in recent years, alongside other significant investors such as Germany (Mercedes-Benz and BMW) and the US (Coca-Cola, Ford and Walmart). Investment from non-traditional sources, especially China (ICBC) and India (Tata and Cipla), is growing strongly. Banking, telecommunications, tourism, real estate, mining and manufacturing are the most attractive sectors. FDI in South Africa includes greenfield projects-in motor vehicles, pharmaceuticals, food-processing, information technology and beverages-and buy-outs of existing firms (such as Massmart). The economically powerful Gauteng province receives the bulk of inward FDI, followed by the Eastern Cape (including the Coega industrial zone), KwaZulu-Natal and the Western Cape, but the other five provinces attract less interest.
Determinants
Several factors drive inward investment, including South Africa's status as the most advanced economy in Sub-Saharan Africa (with close links to several other regional markets), a sizeable domestic market of 56m people (in 2016), strong tourism potential and world-class mineral wealth. South Africa's preferential access to the EU market, via a new economic partnership agreement (EPA) concluded in 2014, and to the US market, under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), which has been extended by ten years to 2025, also helps to support investment. Ongoing efforts to tackle infrastructure deficiencies in energy and transport will serve as an additional spur to FDI. Set against this are a number of deterrents, including a high degree of policy uncertainty, labour-market rigidity (and strikes), skills shortages, widespread crime and the dominant position of parastatals in several some sectors. Key areas of policy uncertainty include a tough new mining charter, a pending new FDI law that limits recourse to international arbitration and a draft expropriation bill that could affect levels of compensation. Privatisation prospects are limited, although there will be openings for independent operators and public-private partnerships, mainly in energy and transport.
Impact
FDI has a strong positive impact in South Africa, especially in key sectors such as automotive, telecoms, banking and mining, and has played a key role in boosting exports, facilitating growth and lifting employment. FDI provides capital, allows for the transfer of technology and skills and binds South Africa more closely to the global economy.
Potential
We expect inflows to rise steadily during the forecast period, from US$2.4bn in 2017 to US$4.9bn in 2021, helped by a pick-up in local growth, but global and domestic risks are significant. The impact on global trade and commodity prices of the Trump presidency in the US, the UK's intention to leave the EU (Brexit) and a slowdown in China all have the potential to impede investment flows. Policy uncertainty in South Africa over a range of issues will also inhibit investment, especially in mining. Inflows will, nonetheless, benefit from the government's activist industrial policy, especially in the automotive segment, and from the improvement in electricity supplies in 2017-21, which will allow for new investment in energy-intensive sectors. The retention of South Africa's AGOA status, after the settlement of a dispute about US meat imports, will also facilitate inflows, as will closer regional integration within the Southern African Development Community (SADC). The rollout of a domestic cable network will boost bandwidth and cut costs, helping to create a more accommodating environment for cloud computing and business-process outsourcing (given an English-speaking, educated workforce in a similar time zone to the EU). South Africa will remain a key base for companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions.

South Africa's consumer market is in the midst of a major transformation as the poor black majority is increasingly drawn into the mainstream commercial economy. The speed of the change will be determined by both the global and local economies, and by the effectiveness of government policies against poverty and unemployment. Notably, South Africa remains among the most unequal societies in the world, and many of these divisions are based on race (the legacy of apartheid). Race-based distinctions between upper- and lower-income groups will remain significant but will decline over time. The most recent income and expenditure survey shows that spending by black households (76.6% of the total) rose by 35% in real terms between fiscal years 2005/06 and 2010/11 (April-March), to R55,920 per household (US$7,700 at the prevailing exchange rate). By comparison, spending by mixed-race and white households rose by 21.8% (to R97,965) and by 16.1% (to R314,524) respectively. This shows that black spending is growing more quickly than white spending, but the absolute gap will remain large. Around 35% of households are currently categorised as middle class, but this will rise steadily during the forecast period.
Consumer spending will show a broad upward trend
Household spending growth in real terms was brisk following the 2009 recession, peaking at 5.1% in 2011, before trending lower to 1.7% in 2015 and 0.8% in 2016, the weakest rate since 2009. The downturn reflects high levels of household indebtedness, rising interest rates during the period, weak job creation and wages lost to strikes. Demand was also negatively affected by a severe drought in 2016, when household consumption of goods shrank by 0.1% (pulled down by a 7.3% contraction in durables), although consumption of services grew by 2.1%. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts a further decline in real consumption growth to 0.5% in 2017 (in line with rising unemployment), but we expect a gentle rebound during the remainder of the forecast period, helped by faster overall growth, more generous welfare payments, rising real wages (for those in work), higher levels of financial inclusion and the expansion of the black middle class.
Consumer spending will also benefit from the expansion of low-cost housing and electrification-which will boost demand for ancillary goods and services-and from the adoption of a more broad-based approach to black economic empowerment (BEE). The benefits of BEE have been spread narrowly to date, helping to create a new black elite (the so-called black diamonds, who generally display similar consumption patterns to rich whites). However, the drive towards more broad-based BEE, including employee share-ownership schemes and a focus on suppliers, may spread the gains more widely. This will facilitate the expansion of the black middle class, as well as boosting poorer market segments. Low-income households will also benefit from a steady rise in welfare payments. "Demonstration effect" purchasing by new middle-class entrants and blue-collar workers-and easier access to and greater reliance on credit-will expand markets for more expensive retail goods such as electrical appliances. The spread of modern shopping centres will reinforce the trend. The entry of Walmart (US) into the retail market in 2011, via its purchase of a majority stake in a local retailer, Massmart, is increasing competition in the retail sector, to the benefit of consumers.

Consumer expenditure will show a broad upward trend over the forecast period (at least in rand, if not in US dollar, terms), although the composition of consumption will not change radically. Food spending typically falls as a proportion of total spending as disposable income rises, but this will not be evident in 2017-21 because of the entry of subsistence-level rural dwellers into the commercial economy, the rise in the spending power of lower-income groups (which typically spend more of their money on food) and growing demand by the emergent middle class for higher-value-added food products. The share of total spending accounted for by housing (and household fuels) and will edge higher in 2017-21, because of costlier electricity, but most other categories will show little relative change, including leisure and education, clothing and footwear, health, and transport and communications.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Growth will revive gradually in 2017-21, underpinned by a modest pick-up in the global economy and an end to electricity shortages, although the outlook for commodity prices is mixed. Investment will strengthen, especially in infrastructure, although the public sector is hampered by fiscal constraints, and private-sector confidence is currently low (because of policy uncertainties). These factors also point to weak job creation. An interest-rate cut in July 2017 may give a small boost to growth, provided the reduction is not reversed in response to expected rand depreciation, which could stoke inflation. Structural constraints will persist into the medium term, including infrastructure bottlenecks, skills shortages and labour market rigidity. The threats posed by labour militancy and strike action are additional challenges, meaning that growth will remain sluggish, despite trending upwards.
The impact of HIV/AIDS will gradually dissipate in 2031-50
Demographic trends: South Africa's population will continue to grow at a slow pace, held back by the impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic, which may persist for another generation. However, the downward trend in new infections and deaths attributable to AIDS, and the ongoing rollout of treatment programmes, will reduce the impact of the disease in 2031-50. This will be accompanied by increased life expectancy, although overall population growth will remain relatively muted, as rising disposable incomes and urbanisation will lead to smaller families. The working-age population and the labour force will grow more quickly than the overall population, because of the high proportion of young people and inward migration from other African states. This will make it harder to bring down the unemployment rate. Another key demographic trend will be the rise in the proportion of urban dwellers, from 65.3% in 2016 to 80% in 2050.
External conditions: South Africa's performance, as a relatively small and open economy that is strongly reliant on mineral exports, will remain closely tied to world trends. This leaves South Africa vulnerable to disruptions linked to the Trump presidency in the US, the UK's intention to leave the EU (Brexit) and a Chinese slowdown. Multilateral trade liberalisation under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation may yield benefits, although the slow pace of progress means that freer trade will mainly be driven by bilateral and regional initiatives in the medium term. The Southern African Development Community (SADC) will progressively implement a free-trade area, although ambitions for a customs union, a common market and monetary union may not be realised until after 2030 because of economic and policy divergences between member states. Intra-African trade will continue to be held back by non-tariff barriers and weak infrastructure in 2015-30, but these constraints will ease in 2031-50. Ties with the EU will continue to deepen, following agreement on a new economic partnership agreement (EPA) in 2014. South Africa will retain preferential access to the US market-given the extension of the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) until 2025-although its eligibility will be subject to periodic reviews. South Africa's trade and investment ties with non-OECD states, especially fellow BRICS members (Brazil, Russia, India and China) will deepen over the long term, at the expense of traditional links with OECD partners
The quality of institutions will improve
Institutions and policy trends: The quality of institutions will improve, boosting transparency and accountability, but capacity constraints will persist, especially at provincial and municipal levels. Key institutions, such as the central bank and the judiciary, will retain their independence. The broad policy framework-which is based on a partnership between private business and the "developmental state"-will remain intact. In broad terms, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects moderate, centrist voices to prevail in the policy debate in the longer term, at the expense of pro-patronage forces and the interventionist left. The process will be helped by political realignments that could see the fragmentation of the ruling tripartite alliance-comprising the African National Congress (ANC), the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the South African Communist Party-and the emergence of a new coalition between moderates in the ANC and the opposition. Many current policy challenges will persist into the longer term, including skills shortages, high unemployment and the thorny issue of land reform, although investment will alleviate infrastructure constraints.
Productivity gains will boost growth in the longer term
Long-term performance: We forecast that real GDP growth will average 3.1% a year in 2017-30, helped by rising life expectancy, improved electricity supplies, the expansion of the black middle class, regional integration and global demand for commodities. Major infrastructure investments either under way or planned, and the gradual implementation of the National Development Plan, will underpin business activity, although slow population growth will serve as a constraint. Growth will quicken to 3.7% a year in 2031-50, driven by technological advances such as additive printing and cloud computing. Growth in capital stocks will outpace growth in labour productivity throughout the period, owing to a combination of skills shortages and investment in new technology.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.
