Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historic data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
SARB: South African Reserve Bank
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Country Forecast Turkey August 2017

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-august-2017/docview/1959007895/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: According to government plans, tax revenue, including social security contributions, will be about 33% of GDP in 2017, compared with an OECD average of about 35% (2015 data). According to balance-of-payments statistics, inflows of FDI, including sales of real estate to non-residents, declined to around US$13bn, or 1.4% of GDP, per year in 2012-14, before picking up to US$17.6bn, or 2% of GDP, in 2015. From 2008, although the government remained willing to privatise, market conditions deteriorated, resulting in less interest from foreign investors. Since 2013 potential deterrents have multiplied: less buoyant economic growth, mass anti-government protests, financial market volatility, government corruption allegations, the spillover of violence from the conflict in Syria and, most recently, the collapse of the peace negotiations with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and an attempted military coup in July 2016. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), greater Istanbul, which accounts for about one-fifth of the population, represents about one-quarter of household consumption expenditure.

Full text: Turkey--highlights: Political outlook
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, the narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened social and political divisions. The presidential reform, which will take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, both due in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president, and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incumbent president and leader of the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP), Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Turkey--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2011 2016 2021
Total 73.4 79.5 84.5
 Male 36.1 39.1 41.5
 Female 37.3 40.4 43.0
Period averages (%)   2012-16 2017-21
Population growth   1.6 1.2
Working-age population growth   1.8 1.4
Labour force growth   3.6 2.0
The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 79.5m in 2016 to 84.5m in 2021, with the female population continuing to outnumber the male population. The total population is expected to grow by about 1.2% per year during the forecast period (2017-21), compared with 1.6% during the historical period (2012-16).
Turkey--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.23 6.03 46 58 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment score for Turkey deteriorates only slightly in the forecast period (2017-21), but the country's global ranking falls by 12 places, to 58th. There is a consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, domestic political tension has created uncertainty about the direction of policy. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment (FDI). Important shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion. Adding to these problems is the impact of the failed coup on the business environment. The government has used emergency powers to seize or close almost 1,000 firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement. Foreign companies' assets have not been seized, but reports in July 2017 indicated that some 600-700 German companies had been under investigation. The seized firms, which are being administered by the state through the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund, will be sold off.
Turkey--highlights: Economic outlook
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021
Real GDP growth (%) 3.0 4.5 4.1 4.3 3.9 4.0
Consumer price inflation (av, %) 7.8 10.3 8.0 6.3 5.7 5.2
Budget balance (% of GDP) -1.1 -2.0 -2.3 -2.2 -1.9 -1.7
Current-account balance (% of GDP) -3.8 -4.0 -4.2 -4.3 -4.3 -4.0
3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 10.4 11.1 9.2 10.6 10.0 9.5
Exchange rate TL:US$ (av) 3.0 3.6 3.7 3.9 4.0 4.1
Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3% in 2016, in part owing to the disruption to the economy from the failed coup but also because of faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in the final quarter of 2016, supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. We expect growth to accelerate to 4.5% in 2017 and to an average of 4.1% in 2018-21. The central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, is forecast to widen from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.2% of GDP per year in 2017-19, before narrowing to 1.7% in 2021. The government debt/GDP ratio has edged up slightly, but we expect it to remain around 30% in 2017-21. We expect the Central Bank of Turkey to have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira.
Turkey--highlights: Market opportunities

The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local currency terms. Income distribution is uneven by European standards. We expect GDP per head to rise from US$24,270 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates in 2016 to about US$30,500 in 2021. GDP per head in Turkey will be about 65% of the EU28 average, an increase of about 7 percentage points in ten years.
Turkey--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2017-30 2031-50 2017-50

Turkey's economic growth performance is expected to surpass that of the EU28, as a result of its more favourable demographic profile and larger productivity increases. However, at an average of 3% per year in 2017-50, real GDP growth will be well below the performance recorded in 2004-07 and 2010-15. Improvements in the policy environment could produce substantially better results, but there is still uncertainty about the impact of changes to Turkey's political and institutional framework and the country's commitment to seeing through the reforms required under the EU accession process.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance

a In 2015 pro-Kurdish groups contested the election as a party, HDP. In 2011 pro-Kurdish candidates from the Peace and Democracy Party (BDP) ran as independents to bypass the 10% vote threshold. b Includes votes obtained by the BDP in 2011.
The religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) scored a landslide victory in the snap parliamentary election on November 1st 2015, winning almost 50% of the vote and restoring its majority in parliament (317 seats out of a total of 550), which it had lost in the poll in June. The result ended months of domestic political uncertainty and sealed the dominance of Turkish politics by the AKP and the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The AKP did not win the minimum 330-seat super-majority needed to revise the constitution, but following the failed coup in July 2016 the Nationalist Action Party (MHP) agreed to back the AKP's constitutional reform bill designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. The presidential reform, which was put to a referendum in April 2017, was narrowly approved amid allegations of vote fraud and will take effect after the next parliamentary and presidential elections due to take place by late 2019.
Political outlook: Political stability
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit maintains its negative medium-term political outlook. The narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened the social and political divisions. The "justice march" from the capital, Ankara, to Istanbul, headed by Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the leader of the opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), ended peacefully on July 9th, but further protests are likely, keeping high the risk of clashes between protesters and pro-government supporters or a government clampdown. The presidential reform, which will take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, both due in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president, and moves the country closer to one-man rule by Mr Erdogan.
Mr Erdogan and the AKP have continued to tighten their grip on power. The state of emergency law introduced after the failed coup has been repeatedly extended on a three-month basis. We expect it remain in place for the foresee-able future, because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and silence government critics. More than 100,000 people-mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media-have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk remains high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
For much of the AKP's 15 years of single-party rule, political and government effectiveness have improved. The economy has been well managed and significant social reforms, notably the healthcare reform, have been implemented. However, in recent years, domestic power struggles have intensified, resulting in a resurgence of violence since mid-2015 and a failed coup attempt in mid-July 2016. The power struggles and related violence have weakened government effectiveness and Turkey's democratic institutions. In response to the failed coup the government introduced emergency rule, which has remained in place, allowing the government to carry out an extensive purge of personnel in the military, the judiciary, the police force and academic institutions suspected of having Gulenist links. The extent of the purge risks undermining institutional capacity on a lasting basis.
Since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised. In 2017 pressure from Mr Erdogan and other members of the AKP on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower official interest rates has eased-they have focused their attention increasingly on Turkey's private-sector commercial banks-but it could resume at any time despite above-target inflation following a sharp slide in the value of the Turkish lira in late 2016/early 2017.
Concerns about judicial impartiality and efficiency unlikely to be resolved
Concerns about the impartiality and efficiency of the legal system are unlikely to be resolved over the forecast period, given the continued politicisation of the judiciary. An AKP constitutional reform package, which was approved by referendum in 2010, changed the appointment procedure and composition of the High Council of Judges and Prosecutors (HSYK) and the Constitutional Court. The changes facilitated the replacement of conservative secularist-nationalists in the judiciary with Gulenists, who until 2013 were close allies of the AKP. Shortcomings in the judicial process were highlighted in coup plot investigations and trials that began in 2007. These were only addressed at appeal stage, and after suspected Gulenists in the judiciary began investigating allegations of government corruption in late 2013. The purge of Gulenists from the judiciary accelerated after the failed coup. Their replacements will probably be chosen for their loyalty to Mr Erdogan and the AKP, possibly from other religious sects. The upheaval is likely to increase uncertainty in the judicial process and prolong cases further. The courts' tendency to interpret the law in favour of the state and at the expense of the individual is unlikely to change, especially in cases involving minority rights and freedom of speech.
Foreign businesses operating in Turkey can reduce some of the uncertainty caused by the legal process by incorporating international arbitration clauses into their contracts. These help to shorten the time that it takes to resolve commercial dis-putes and prevent, in most cases, the need for intervention by the Turkish courts.
Corruption in the public sector is seen as a major deterrent by potential international investors. Legislation has been introduced to tackle it. However, implementation will continue to be a problem and political patronage is likely to remain widespread. The public procurement law of 2003 was drafted to meet EU standards, but has since been watered down and amended so that important sectors, such as transport and energy, were excluded. Turkey has improved compliance with the OECD's anti-bribery convention.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held in 2019, but they could be earlier if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. Given the popularity of the president, and his party's ability to control the election process, we expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging him. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round with just over 50% of the vote against a joint candidate presented by the CHP and the right-wing MHP. The MHP's support in parliament for the presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties will consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the MHP leadership's decision to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 election and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation, which would boost the AKP's seat share. Under the consti-tutional changes approved in the referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Recep Tayyip Erdogan
Mr Erdogan, who became Turkey's first directly elected president in August 2014, has completely dominated the political scene since the 2002 general election. Under his leadership, the Justice and Development Party (AKP) that he co-founded in 2001 comfortably won general elections in 2002, 2007 and 2011. This was largely owing to the comparative economic stability that the AKP delivered, but Mr Erdogan's personal appeal was instrumental, as was his religious and conservative outlook, which is shared by much of the electorate, but not by the AKP's political opponents. After the AKP unexpectedly lost its parliamentary majority at the general election in June 2015, Mr Erdogan adopted a more confrontational stance, which contributed to a deterioration in the political and security environment. The shift coincided with a collapse in the peace process with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), leading to a reversion to a military strategy against the PKK. Mr Erdogan's roots in political Islam have prompted his secularist opponents in the military and judiciary to try to unseat him on several occasions. All such challenges have been rebuffed. So, too, were mass protests against his rule in mid-2013, and allegations from erstwhile Islamic allies of corruption in his government. He only narrowly escaped capture and possibly even death on the night of the attempted coup on July 15th 2016. The failed coup is likely to mark another important step in Mr Erdogan's efforts to stifle dissent, weaken checks and balances, and concentrate power in his own hands. It has helped him to accelerate his plans to replace the parliament system of government with an executive presidency.
Binali Yildirim
Mr Yildirim became prime minister after his appointment as leader of the AKP on May 22nd 2016. Handpicked by Mr Erdogan, he replaced Ahmet Davutoglu when Mr Davutoglu resigned following a fallout with the president. Mr Yildirim has been a close ally of the president since 1994, when Mr Erdogan became mayor of Istanbul. He was one of the longest-serving members of the cabinet during Mr Erdogan's time as prime minister in 2003-14. On his appointment Mr Yildirim placed renewed emphasis on implementing the transition to a presidential system of government to end the ambiguity around Mr Erdogan's role, which under the 1982 constitution was supposed to be largely ceremonial and above party politics. This was superseded by changes to the constitution approved by referendum in April 2017. Mr Yildirim stepped down as party leader in May 2017 so that Mr Erdogan could be re-elected, uncontested, as chairman of the AKP.
Kemal Kilicdaroglu
Mr Kilicdaroglu became leader of the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP) just over a year before the 2011 general election in which he was well beaten by Mr Erdogan. Mr Kilicdaroglu is a less divisive figure than his predecessor, Deniz Baykal, but he lacks the political presence or skills of Mr Erdogan. The CHP's problems are not merely questions of personnel. As it stands, the party looks incapable of ever again marshalling sufficient support to win a national election. Under Mr Kilicdaroglu the CHP unsuccessfully opposed Mr Erdogan's push to establish an executive presidency. Following the April presidential reform referendum, the CHP called for the result to be nullified over allegations of electoral fraud, but failed to harness widespread public concern about the referendum campaign and outcome. However, Mr Kilicdaroglo's "justice" march from Ankara to Istanbul in June-July 2017 to protest against the jailing of a CHP member of parliament was the single boldest expression of opposition activism during the AKP's 15-year rule, but its galvanising effect on the opposition to Mr Erdogan already appears to have faded.
Devlet Bahceli
Mr Bahceli has been leader of the opposition Nationalist Action Party (MHP) since 1997 after the death of its founder, Colonel Alparslan Turkes. Calls from within the party for a change of leadership intensified following the MHP's poor performance in the November 2015 general election, but amid the increased political uncertainty of the post-coup-attempt environment his main challenger, Meral Aksener, was expelled from the party in early September 2016, effectively ending any possibility of a change of party leadership. While a junior partner in a broad left-right coalition government in 1999-2002, Mr Bahceli tried to move the party from the extreme right to the right-of-centre, showing a willingness to compromise on some sensitive issues such as the abolition of the death penalty and increased protection of minority rights for the Kurds as required by the EU for the opening of EU membership negotiations. This transition has been reversed since the party returned to opposition, especially on the Kurdish issue. Mr Bahceli and his party strongly opposed the AKP government's peace negotiations with the PKK. After the collapse of the process in mid-2015 and the AKP's reversion to a military security strategy against the PKK, the differences between the AKP and the MHP leadership narrowed considerably, resulting in the MHP leadership deciding to back Mr Erdogan's presidential reform plans.
Political outlook: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's inter-national relations with its traditional Western allies.
Having deployed armed forces to back rebel groups in Syria to fight IS and prevent the expansion of territory held by US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds, Turkey risks becoming embroiled in the conflict. Tensions and the risk of confrontation between Turkey and US-backed forces could escalate once IS is defeated. The US administration appears unlikely to grant Turkey's request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey on charges of masterminding the failed coup. Even if the AKP government provides evidence of his role in the coup that would stand up in a US court, there would be a strong chance that his extradition would be rejected on the grounds that he might not get a fair trial in Turkey.
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. The sus-pension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Turkey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but are pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.

Population growth remains high by European standards
Turkey is the third-largest country by population in Europe, after Russia and Germany. Official population figures have been compiled using an address-based registry since 2009. These figures are lower than previous estimates from door-to-door censuses, but are believed to be more reliable. The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 79.5m in 2016 to 84.5m in 2021, with the female population continuing to outnumber the male population. The total population is expected to grow by about 1.2% per year during the forecast period (2017-21), compared with 1.6% during the historical period (2012-16). The pace of population growth has slowed in recent decades, mostly owing to the declining birth rate, which in turn reflects the combined impact on fertility rates of urbanisation, an improvement in the education level of women and wider use of birth control. Nevertheless, population growth remains high by European standards.
From an average of 17.5 births per 1,000 inhabitants in 2012-16, the crude birth rate is expected to fall to an average of 16.1 per 1,000 in 2017-21. The infant mortality rate will continue to decline, but will remain high in comparison with European countries, as the national average is pulled up by the south-east and east regions, as well as by rural areas. The crude death rate will remain broadly unchanged, at an average of 5.8 per 1,000 population in 2017-21.
Although ageing, the Turkish population is young in a European context and will remain so throughout the forecast period. In 2016 those aged 14 and under were estimated to comprise 25.4% of the population and the 65-plus age group accounted for just 7.7%. In 2021 the share of under-15s will still be high, at about 23.3% of the population, and the over-65s are expected to account for 9.1%.
The urban population, which is currently estimated at 73.9%, will rise further as rural families, insufficiently supported by agriculture, continue to seek better living standards in towns and cities. The drift of population from smaller and poorer urban settlements to larger and richer ones will also continue. As a result, all major cities in the west and south (including Ankara) will continue to grow rapidly. Although earthquake-prone, Istanbul and its surrounding area is likely to become the largest conurbation in Europe-the population was already 14.8m at end-2016, up from about 11m at end-2007. Other cities and towns to witness particularly strong population growth include prosperous industrial centres like Bursa and Konya, and Antalya, on the Mediterranean coast.
The population of the Kurdish-inhabited south-east, which accounts for about 10% of the total population, has increased steadily, despite strong outward migration. The still-high natural population growth rate in the region will contribute to the rapid expansion of the populations of cities like Gaziantep, Sanliurfa and Diyarbakir. By contrast, the populations of many rural areas in northern, eastern and central Turkey will dwindle. Even some of the larger urban centres in these poorer and more remote regions could lose population as birth rates slow and migration westwards and southwards continues. This could possibly be accelerated in the south-east by the eruption of violence since mid-2015, which has pushed the conflict between the state and the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) close to the level of its most violent days in the 1990s. Some western and southern areas that are still classed as rural may maintain their populations as a result of intensive agriculture, tourism and/or proximity to major cities. This may also be true of lowland parts of the south-east benefiting from irrigation schemes.
Participation rates will remain well below the OECD average
Despite solid growth in the population of working age, Turkey has the lowest labour force participation rate of any OECD country. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), it averaged 52% in 2016 (just under 72% for men, 32.5% for women) compared with an OECD average rate of over 70%. Participation rates in urban areas are lower than in rural areas, reflecting that rural women are typically classified as "unpaid family workers" and are, therefore, counted as workforce participants and employed persons. Low workforce participation rates among urban women probably reflect inadequate job opportunities and the persistence of traditional gender roles. This situation is changing slowly, as illustrated by a gradual rise in recent years in the urban female participation rate. However, the rate is expected to remain low by European standards throughout the forecast period.

a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2017-21), but its global ranking falls by 12 places, to 58th. There is a consensus among policymakers on the need to maintain macroeconomic stability. However, domestic political tension has created uncertainty, which has deepened since the failed coup on July 15th 2016, about the direction of policy. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment (FDI). Important shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion. There is a also risk of macroeconomic volatility, stemming from Turkey's heavy dependence on external finance for growth and the prospect of less abundant global liquidity in the coming years.
Domestic political tension has created uncertainty about the direction of policy
Adding to these problems is the impact of the failed coup on the business environment. The government has used emergency powers to seize or close almost 1,000 firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement. Foreign companies' assets have not been seized, but reports in July 2017 indicated that some 600-700 German companies had been under investigation. The seized firms being administered by the state through the Savings Deposit Insurance Fund will be sold off.
Major attractions for investors include Turkey's geographic location, the size of the potential market, its young and growing population, a customs union with the EU, free foreign-exchange and capital flows, and a large and dynamic private sector. The public finances are in good health and the financial system is well capitalised and regulated. We expect improvements in the quality of infrastructure. A wave of post-coup suspensions and dismissals in the civil service may weaken institutional capacity for some years to come, both at regulatory bodies and in the judiciary.
Business environment outlook: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening-up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade and tourism following the lifting of Russian sanctions. Possible increase in protectionism under the new US administration.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. Political pressure on c0mmercial banks to reduce interest rates. Renewed pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey cannot be ruled out.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.1 6.1 62 64 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Our assessment of the macroeconomic environment focuses not on headline GDP growth (which is measured in the market opportunities category) but on economic stability, which aids business planning and promotes investment. We expect past improvements in Turkey's macroeconomic environment to be maintained in the forecast period. Since coming to power in 2002 the government has established a record of sound fiscal management. Although public borrowing has risen to support economic activity since the failed coup, we expect the government, mindful of the role that fiscal indiscipline played in past crises in Turkey, to return to a relatively tight fiscal policy in the near term, as it did after an expansionary phase during the global financial crisis in 2008-09. We also expect that the financial system will remain solid following the restructuring and improved supervision following Turkey's crisis in 2001, even though some of the macroprudential measures introduced by the Central Bank of Turkey and banking regulator since late 2013 have been unwound in 2017 to allow banks to expand lending.
As a large importer of energy and other raw materials, with perennially wide current-account deficits and substantial external-debt repayments (especially by the private sector), Turkey continues to rely heavily on external financing. For this reason, changes in global financial conditions or investor sentiment could cause high levels of volatility in Turkish exchange rates and market interest rates, with a significant impact on conditions for the domestic financial and productive sectors.
Volatile domestic demand, reliance on indirect taxation, limited price competition in some sectors-particularly agriculture-and the sensitivity of prices to exchange-rate and commodity-price movements have made it difficult to reduce consumer price inflation to low single-digit figures. We anticipate only a gradual reduction in the volatility and average level of price increases during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.0 5.5 39 53 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey's scores poorly in this category. The state retains a significant role in many sectors, there is widespread political patronage, the legal system is politicised and corruption is rife. Private property is generally well protected and private enterprise is encouraged, but the use of emergency powers introduced in response to the failed coup, to seize or close firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement has created uncertainty. The value of seized assets amounts to about US$11bn in sectors including healthcare, education, construction, furniture, retail, energy and other sectors.
The seizure of firms since the failed coup has created uncertainty
The government supports private-sector investment and employment with incentives such as tax breaks and social security and credit subsidies, with an emphasis on underdeveloped regions, technology, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), production of currently imported intermediary goods and "strategic" sectors, such as defence, aerospace, automotive and pharmaceuticals. State lending programmes for small businesses have expanded since the failed coup as the Treasury has expanded its guarantees for banks, allowing them to lend to riskier customers. The government's desire for easier business lending is also evident in plans that have been floated to allow banks to securitise their existing loan portfolios.
Despite frequent legal challenges, privatisation is well advanced in numerous sectors, which include refining, petroleum products, parts of the energy sector, steel, mobile telecommunications, and tobacco and alcoholic drinks. The sale of power-distribution networks has been completed and the government aims to continue divesting some generation assets. However, the pace of privatisation has slowed amid market volatility in 2014-17.
Free competition is the norm in most sectors, and the Competition Board has power over mergers and acquisitions (M&A), price-fixing and abuse of market position. Like most other regulatory agencies, however, the Competition Board has limited independence, sharing competencies with government ministries. The public sector still plays the leading role in gas and water, rail transport, tea and sugar production, infrastructure and social services, such as healthcare, and education. The state has a significant position in banking (about 30% of total assets), mining, the defence industry, postal services and legal gambling, and retains large stakes in Turk Telekom (30%) and Turkish Airlines (49%). State dominance of natural-gas imports means that it controls a major input cost for the economy. There is a state-owned broadcaster (TRT), a state-owned home-builder (TOKI) and a state-owned oil and gas exploration company (TPAO). There are also sectors in which one or more private firms, including privatised companies, hold strong market positions.
Price controls operate for various reasons in electricity, gas, petroleum, telecoms and pharmaceuticals, and are expected to be introduced for bank charges. Competition is also inhibited by the large shadow economy, smuggling of petroleum products, cigarettes and many other items, and violation of intellectual property (IP) rights in many sectors, from software to fashion.
State assets transferred to the Turkey Wealth Fund unlikely to be privatised
Political and financial uncertainty may delay planned sales of state assets. Depending on market conditions, most of the following could be privatised by the end of the forecast period: operating rights for more ports, the national lottery and horse racing concession, shares in toll roads and bridges, TOKI, Vakifbank, more power plants, municipal companies in Istanbul, and some state-owned land. Control of the three main state banks-Halkbank, Ziraat and Vakif banks looks set to remain in government hands, and Ziraat and Vakif banks have recently launched an Islamic finance branch. The state banks may sometimes be used as a source of patronage.
The establishment in August 2016 of the Turkey Wealth Fund has removed some government assets from control of the privatisation agency. The wealth fund is designed to help finance large public works by using its assets as collateral, making sales of the assets under its control less likely. The fund now includes assets such as the state stake in Turkish Airlines, Halkbank and Turk Telekom, as well as Ziraat Bank, the Borsa Istanbul, and pipeline operator Botas.
Build-operate-transfer (BOT) or public-private partnership (PPP) schemes will increase the role of the private sector in the management of airports, water and irrigation facilities and hospitals. The railways are being restructured and the rail network separated from train services, but the state will still play a dominant role.
Despite public ownership of major assets, a more liberalised energy sector will emerge as a result of privatisation, new investments, the Electricity Market Law of March 2013 and changes in regulations that will widen consumer choice over power providers. A new wholesale trading platform is being established, aimed at setting a reliable market price for electricity and, in time, perhaps for gas and coal. Gas market reform has lagged behind electricity, but a new gas market law has been drafted and could be approved in the forecast period although the presence of Botas in the portfolio of the Wealth Fund may complicate plans to unbundle its assets.
Additional legislation on IP rights has been pending at parliament since 2016. The changes would replace a patchwork of decrees on the subject and strengthen IP rights in harmony with EU practices. Turkish, as well as foreign, companies are increasingly sensitive on this issue, so there is also likely to be progress in enforcement.
Political patronage and exclusive business networks will continue to play a significant role in business life. Companies close to government circles may be boldest in entering public tenders or operating in sectors where major decisions are taken by politicians, regulators or bureaucrats. Industrial policy may facilitate favouritism or uncompetitive arrangements. Some companies may face higher bureaucratic obstacles or tougher tax inspections than others.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.4 6.4 50 54 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Foreign direct investment will continue to be welcomed in most cases
Turkey's politicised judicial system and its poor record on corruption remain major deterrents for potential foreign investors. As a result, FDI inflows have been modest compared with most central and east European countries. Nevertheless, the government and most sections of society regard FDI in a positive light, and high levels of foreign ownership in industry and services are widely accepted. Turkey's heavy dependency on foreign-capital inflows gives the government additional incentives to attract FDI. Foreign-ownership restrictions are limited to a few areas, including broadcasting and civil aviation. The courts and sections of the public are occasionally hostile towards foreign investors when environmental issues or natural resources are at stake. A law passed in 2012 has boosted sales of property to foreigners by easing restrictions and waiving the condition of reciprocity for most countries. Foreign home owners are now given 12-month renewable residence permits. The new Turkish Commercial Code passed in 2012 clarified the rights of local agents, representatives or franchisees to compensation if their contracts are terminated.
Privatisation in energy and other sectors may provide opportunities for foreign investors, often in conjunction with local partners. The government will especially promote FDI in greenfield and expansion projects that can further its industrial policy goals, including import substitution and technological innovation.
In principle, foreign investors will continue to have the same access to government incentives as do domestic investors. Plans to improve the general investment environment by cutting red tape and streamlining the legal system will benefit foreign as well as domestic businesses. Restrictions on repatriation of profits are highly unlikely, even at times of financial market stress.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.3 7.3 50 52 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey will remain committed to a broadly open trading regime. Under the 1996 customs union with the EU, it has customs-free trade in manufactured goods with EU member states and has adopted the EU common customs tariff, but has refused to grant Greek Cypriot ships and planes access to Turkish ports and airports unless the EU facilitates direct trade between the EU and the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), which is not recognised internationally except by Turkey. Turkey's import regime reflects the EU's free-trade agreements (FTAs). It has bilateral FTAs with the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA), almost all EU partners in south-east Europe and the Mediterranean, as well as with Georgia, Chile, South Korea and Mauritius. Turkey is negotiating or pursuing FTAs with many other economies, especially countries such as Mexico, which have FTAs with the EU that give them an advantage in bilateral trade with Turkey, as well as reducing Turkey's privileges as a customs union partner. It has started initiatives aimed at negotiations with 10 other countries or blocs, including Canada and India. The Turkish lira has been fully convertible since 1989, and capital-account controls have never been considered since, regardless of exchange-rate swings and financial market volatility.
In the absence of a Cyprus settlement, Turkey is likely to resist EU pressure to open ports and airports to Greek Cypriot ships and planes. Similarly, without progress in its EU accession negotiations, Turkey is unlikely to lift restrictions on EU meat and used-car imports, eliminate discriminatory taxes on alcoholic drinks and tobacco products, or open up trade in services.
Domestic policy instability may delay renegotiation of customs union with EU
Turkey and the EU have agreed to revisit the current customs union agreement with a view to expanding it to potentially cover agricultural goods, services and public procurement, but talks have not yet started. Some EU politicians suggest that talks should be linked to political criteria. The proposed EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)-effectively an enhanced FTA-would have had a significant impact on Turkey's trade policies but political and public opposition in the EU and the US means that it is off the agenda for the foreseeable future.
The government is highly unlikely to impose capital controls. It is also unlikely to resort to outright protectionism, despite its efforts to encourage domestic production of items currently imported in large quantities. However, short-term protective measures will continue to be employed to limit imports of textiles, petrochemicals and other items from lower-cost countries. Concerned by high food price inflation, the country has established a Food Committee to examine and possibly revise the system of tariffs on agricultural products. This may lead to a relaxation of restrictions on agricultural imports.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.7 5.7 50 61 15 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
As a percentage of GDP, tax revenue is low by OECD standards owing to high levels of evasion. According to government plans, tax revenue, including social security contributions, will be about 33% of GDP in 2017, compared with an OECD average of about 35% (2015 data). The corporation tax rate is 20%. Personal income tax rates range from 15% to 35%. The tax-free allowance for wage and salary earners varies from the equivalent of 50-90% of the minimum wage, according to the number of their dependants. Withholding taxes are widely used, but about 70% of tax revenue comes from indirect taxes, including value-added tax (VAT), which is levied at a standard rate of 18% (with lower rates of 8% and 1% for some items), and special consumption taxes on some goods and services, such as petroleum, alcohol, tobacco products, motor vehicles, telecoms services and banking transactions.
Obligatory social security contributions normally consist of 20.5% of gross salary, up to a certain limit, from the employer, 14% from the employee and a combined total of 3% to the Unemployment Insurance Fund, from both parties. Tax breaks, social security premium reductions and incentives are available to encourage investment in underdeveloped regions, important sectors and technological innovation, as well as to support employment. The tax administration can be unpredictable and disputes are common.
Frequent changes in tax regulation and evasion are likely to persist
Frequent changes in tax regulation are likely to persist, as will widespread tax and social security evasion, which is encouraged by frequent amnesties and opportunities to restructure arrears. The latest example was announced after the failed coup. Plans to simplify the tax system have been on the government agenda for some time, but as of August 2017 draft proposals had not been adopted.
Foreign companies will continue to be treated in the same way as Turkish companies. Turkey is expected to expand the already substantial number of double taxation agreements that it has during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.6 6.6 26 38 9 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Banking is well regulated, well capitalised and profitable. Non-performing loans (NPLs) as a share of total credit are low but have edged up since late 2015, although to only just above 3% in May 2017. The recent expansion of lending to small companies may have helped keep this figure low. The three main state-controlled banks-which operate largely on a commercial basis-and the four largest private banks controlled 74% of total assets at end-2016. The remainder is shared among another 45 institutions, including five Sharia-compliant "participation banks" and non-deposit-collecting investment banks. Government intervention in the sector is rare, but in February 2015 regulators took control of Bank Asya, an Islamic bank linked to the Gulenist movement. It was closed in the wake of the coup.
The banking system is solid, but curbs on credit growth have been relaxed
Bank lending growth has recorded periodic surges since 2010, driven by falling government borrowing needs and strong domestic and global liquidity. By mid-2016 the annual rate of credit growth to the non-financial sector had slowed to about 10%, from 45% in late 2011, with lending to businesses growing faster than lending to consumers. Following an easing of some reserve requirement ratios by the Central Bank of Turkey to halt the slowdown, credit growth accelerated to about 20% in the first half of 2017.
Weaker companies may experience difficulty obtaining bank credit, but the strongest Turkish companies, like Turkish banks, have access to loans from foreign/offshore banks and to local and international bond markets. The pace of share offerings on the volatile Borsa Istanbul has slowed in recent years. Market capitalisation is low, at about 26% of GDP in 2016. About 63% of the free float is foreign-owned. Private equity funds have become a significant alternative source of finance.
There is growth potential in the financial sector, despite some interest- and exchange-rate volatility and a likely deterioration in credit quality. Low domestic savings will remain a constraint, but changes to the private pension system will help to increase the availability of finance with longer maturities. Tighter global liquidity could reduce credit to the private sector.
Changes in bank ownership may occur, particularly for smaller banks, without changing the overall structure of the sector. The current government's antipathy towards private bank owners and sympathy for consumers and credit customers will encourage tighter regulation of certain banking activities, such as credit-card issuance.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.1 6.2 45 48 14 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Several factors will continue to limit the attractiveness of the labour market in the forecast period. There is a large, young labour pool, but workforce participation is only about 52%, partly owing to traditions that discourage female employment. Despite a greater number of years of formal education, the average level of education and skills remains below average European standards, and mismatches between education and the needs of the labour market persist. Employment of foreigners is exceptional and obtaining work permits can be problematic, but some restrictions have been eased. Informal employment and subcontracting are common way of avoiding tax, as well as legal obligations and rigidities, creating unfair competition, undermining safety standards and hindering productivity gains. In formal employment, hours and conditions are generally regulated and inflexible. Part-time working has increased but remains relatively low, at about 12% of total employment.
In response to employers' complaints about high labour costs, the government has sought to lighten the burden of social security contributions, especially for underdeveloped regions and the employment of young people, women and people with disabilities. Following a 30% rise in 2016 the gross minimum wage is relatively high at TL1,778 (US$504) a month.
The change to severance pay may take several years to implement
Companies complain that the system of severance pay, under which employers are liable to pay substantial lump sums to employees who retire or are made redundant, is too generous, hindering formal hiring. The government plan is to establish a severance pay fund, to which employers will contribute, but attempts to win acceptance of the plans from unions have met with resistance. The change to severance pay may take some years to implement.
The government aims to make the labour market more flexible-for example, by permitting the establishment of private employment agencies to supply temporary staff-while improving access to unemployment benefits. We expect the use of flexible employment contracts in the formal sector to increase only slowly. Proposals to set the minimum wage by region to take account of productivity and cost-of-living differences are not likely to be politically acceptable.
Labour market activation and education policies will raise skills levels and workforce participation only gradually. Despite the government's commitment to reducing unregistered employment, it is likely to remain a significant issue throughout the forecast period.
Restrictions on union membership, strikes and lock-outs that are incompatible with international norms promoted by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the EU are unlikely to be lifted. Unions may be influential in a few sectors but are unlikely to become stronger or more militant.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.6 7.0 45 48 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey's infrastructure is broadly adequate for doing business. Recent years have seen investment by national and local government and the private sector, leading to some visible improvements, ranging from rapid growth of domestic air travel to the gradual extension of the natural gas pipeline network to almost all provinces and the spread of broadband Internet access and mobile-phone services. As in most countries, the number of fixed-line subscriptions has declined steadily, but mobile-phone penetration has risen rapidly, reaching 95% in early 2017. Computer ownership is low, but an estimated 76% of households had access to the internet in 2016, up from below 20% a decade earlier.
Infrastructure shortcomings will persist in most cities including urban overcrowding, congestion, earthquake risk and strains on water supply and waste disposal systems and the energy network. Rural infrastructure should improve a little in most places. Major irrigation works, including those in the south-east, will proceed slowly.
Major infrastructure projects are under way, but shortcomings also persist
Improvements in transport infrastructure will be piecemeal, and as a whole it will continue to lag behind EU standards, especially given the long distances between cities. The Marmaray rail project, including a tunnel under the Bosphorus, opened in late 2013 along with sections of the Ankara-Eskisehir-Istanbul fast train project. Rapid rail services, which already exist between Ankara and Eskisehir and between Ankara and Konya, will be extended westwards, to Izmir, and eastwards, to Kayseri and Sivas, around the end of the forecast period. There are plans to extend the rail network to Batum and Tiflis in Georgia.
Following the completion of the Ankara-Istanbul motorway in 2007, a connecting motorway link to Izmir is being built, incorporating a bridge over the Gulf of Izmit that opened in 2016. A third Bosphorus road bridge and related stretches of motorway in the north of Istanbul also opened in 2016. A Eurasia road tunnel is planned under the Bosphorus in the heart of Istanbul. These projects are being carried out on BOT terms.
Public and private investment will ensure that seaport capacity expands, despite bottlenecks and incomplete privatisation of management rights at some state-owned ports. A third Istanbul airport, tendered in May 2013 on a BOT basis, could start operating in 2018. During the forecast period there may be some progress on the "Istanbul channel" Bosphorus bypass ship-canal project.
Assuming moderate economic growth and improved energy efficiency, energy sector privatisation and market liberalisation will continue. Legislation facilitating the privatisation of lignite reserves is being implemented. Private investment (coupled with limited public investment) may be enough to increase power-generation capacity, cut transmission and distribution losses and prevent blackouts. Policies favouring energy generation from local and renewable sources will help to reduce gradually reliance on imported fuels.
We expect legislation to encourage private-sector oil and gas exploration to lead to an intensification of offshore activity in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean to intensify. The government has begun to explore the possibility of exploiting shale gas potential in the south-east and other parts of Turkey. Plans to construct two nuclear plants are highly controversial and, even if built, they will not come on stream until the early 2020s.
Intense competition in the mobile telecoms sector should ensure that infrastructure remains adequate and up-to-date, although there may be delays in adopting the latest technology or it may initially be expensive or concentrated in major cities. Fixed-line broadband Internet access has expanded rapidly, but at an estimated 12.7% in 2016 the penetration rate was still well below an average of 30-40% for most other European countries. Including large and rapidly rising numbers of mobile broadband subscriptions, the penetration rate is much higher. About 80% of all mobile subscriptions are now third-generation (3G), and fourth-generation (4G) technology began to be offered in 2016.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, its well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diver-sified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows to Turkey during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016 and early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy in November 2016 after a prolonged period of loosening. The lira has stabilised since January 2017, but it remains vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment, as illustrated by a short, sharp drop in value against the US dollar in the first week of July, probably prompted by expectations of balance-sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank). If the lira depreciates sharply again, an abrupt tightening of policy might be necessary, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery. However, this is not The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline scenario, as we currently expect US monetary policy to be tightened only gradually in the remainder of 2017-18.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges have blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.

Low budget deficit- and public debt-to-GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and prevent a surge in domestic demand from causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, to widen from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.2% of GDP per year in 2017-19, before narrowing to 1.7% in 2021. Although the government debt/GDP ratio has edged up slightly, to 29.4% in 2016, we expect it to remain around 30% in 2017-21. The risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out. The transfer of Turkey's major state assets to a sovereign wealth fund established in 2016 to help finance major infrastructure projects could bring privatisation to a halt, and the fund could become a vehicle to increase off-budget spending.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021
3-month money market rate (av) 10.4 11.1 9.2 10.6 10.0 9.5
Deposit rate (av) 11.2 12.0 11.5 11.0 10.0 9.0
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates to revive economic activity has eased as the government has switched its attention to Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates and Fed balance-sheet tapering. To do this, we expect the Turkish central bank to use a mix of interest rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank raised most of its main policy rates between November 2016 and April 2017, and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. In mid-August 2017 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system was about 12%, compared with 7.8% in November 2016.
The central bank is seeking to normalise gradually its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that this will happen until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases.
