Real GDP growth slowed from an annual average of 7.4% in 2010-15 to 3% in 2016, in part owing to the disruption to the economy from the failed coup last July but also faltering foreign capital inflows amid expectations of global liquidity tightening. A recovery got under way in the final quarter of last year, and we expect growth to accelerate to 4.5% in 2017 and an average of 4.1% in 2018-21. The rebound has been supported by government stimulus measures, political pressure on banks to extend credit and a pick-up in global demand. There are downside risks to this forecast, which is predicated on the assumption that the transition to a presidential system of government in the next few years does not lead to further political instability deterring foreign capital flows into the Turkish economy.
We expect a moderate improvement in confidence, a gradual recovery in employ-ment growth and government incentives for the purchase of certain household durable goods (in the short term, at least until September 2017) to support household spending. As a result, we forecast an acceleration in real private consumption growth, from 2.3% in 2016 to an annual average of 3.5% in 2017-21.
After expanding by 7.6% in 2016 we expect government spending to increase by nearly 8% per year on average in 2017-19 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to hold down fixed investment growth at about 3% per year in 2017-18, as a more cautious approach by businesses will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast an acceleration to average annual growth of 5%, assuming that domestic political tensions ease after the elections.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey since mid-2016, the positive impact of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in the main export markets, especially in Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-21. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter some visitors to Turkey and weigh on the tourism sector. Our expectation is that a slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2020 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
As in most developing countries, the share of agriculture in nominal GDP has declined steadily in Turkey in recent decades. But at 6.9% of gross value added in 2016 agriculture remains an important sector, especially considering the input that it makes to Turkey's food, beverages and tobacco manufacturing industry. In addition, agriculture still accounts for a substantial share of about 20% of total employment, although almost half of those employed in the sector are classified as unpaid family workers. We expect the share of output of the primary sector to shrink slightly during the forecast period, but it will remain large compared with most other European countries at just over 6% of GDP in 2021. In 2016 the sector was hit by Russian sanctions on agricultural imports from Turkey, but most have now been lifted following the rapprochement between the two countries in June 2016. The sector would benefit from investment in irrigation in the south-east of the country and in some other regions, but investment is likely to remain on hold in areas affected by the conflict with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). The importance of modern, large-scale agricultural enterprises will gradually spread, but the problems of traditional agriculture and unclear policymaking are likely to persist.
Manufacturing will continue to play a central role in the Turkish economy
Industry, including manufacturing, mining and construction, accounted for 32% of GDP in 2016. The collapse in investment and export demand during the 2008-09 global crisis hit the manufacturing and construction sectors hardest. Since then manufacturing and particularly construction have rebounded. In 2016 manufacturing accounted for about 22% of GDP, compared with about 25% at the end of the 1990s. Having fallen as low as 6.3% of GDP in 2009, the construction sector accounted for a very high 10% in 2016.
Construction has been a significant driver of economic growth in recent years. Following annual real growth of 8-9% in the first two quarters of 2016, however, activity has slowed gradually to growth of 4.6% in the first quarter of 2017 amid concern about a possible property market crash. The pace of housing construc-tion-which accounts for around 75% of total activity in volume terms-had outstripped demand for several years, even after allowing for strong demographically driven growth in the number of households and accelerated replacement of existing buildings. The slowdown is likely to continue in the remainder of 2017, given oversupply, weak household and business sentiment, and uncertain financial conditions.
Although several manufacturing subsectors, such as automotive, and textiles and clothing, are strongly export-oriented and will continue to generate trade surpluses, Turkey's manufactured exports are generally import intensive; that is, a large portion of the inputs, whether energy, intermediates or capital goods, are imported, adding to Turkey's external imbalances, especially when international commodity prices are high or the lira weak, as it has been since mid-2013. This situation is unlikely to change much during the forecast period, as reducing the import intensity of exports and moving up the value-added chain will take time, even though these were explicit goals in the government's investment-incentive system, introduced in 2012.
Vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe
Before the global crisis, the automotive industry, which is closely integrated with the European market, overtook clothing as Turkey's biggest export industry. However, as elsewhere, the industry was one of the worst hit by the credit squeeze. Turkish automotive output and export earnings have recovered since the crisis. In 2016 Turkish vehicle production reached just over 1.5m vehicles, making Turkey the fifth-largest producer in Europe and the 15th-largest in the world. About 70% of vehicles produced in Turkey are for export and the bulk of these go to the EU. As a result, vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe. Demand in Europe has picked up since mid-2013, probably reflecting the release of pent-up demand after several years of weakness. Over the forecast period as a whole, however, deleveraging in many markets and potential disruption to demand as a result of the UK's decision to leave the EU are likely to hold down growth in demand for new vehicles and therefore Turkish exports. Given the growth potential of the automotive market in Turkey and the wider region, manufacturers with production plants in Turkey may start to focus more on the Turkish, Middle Eastern and North African markets. At present, about 60% of all new vehicles sold, and just over 70% of new passenger-car registrations, are imported.
We believe that most manufacturers will maintain their production facilities in Turkey. These facilities are technologically advanced and labour costs are much lower in Turkey than in core European countries, and are probably below those in most central and east European countries, where wages have risen strongly following accession to the EU. However, if Turkey is to remain a major automotive production location in the medium to long term, manufacturers will have to move away from exporting low-end passenger cars, light commercial vehicles (LCVs) and components to north European markets, towards developing and producing alternative energy engines and vehicles. There are some signs that this transition is happening. Toyota began producing hybrid passenger cars in Turkey at the end of 2016.
Textiles and clothing industries are likely to shrink further
The basic textiles industry is likely to shrink further over the forecast period, but clothing will remain an important export industry. The industry has undergone restructuring under the intense pressure of competition from low-cost pro-ducers in Asia. The government has also been looking at ways to improve investment incentives and target higher value-added products.
Turkish consumer electronics companies will continue to be major exporters
Production of industrial machinery and of white goods and other household durables, including furniture, recovered strongly as a result of a pick-up in domestic demand and export opportunities in 2010-11. However, more moderate domestic and external demand dampened growth in output in 2012-15. We expect Turkish consumer electronics companies to continue to be major exporters, although they appear to have been slow to adopt technological innovations in some segments.
Investment in the iron and steel industries, which accounted for a declining share of the value of total exports-8.9% in 2016, down from 9.5% in 2015 and 11.5% in 2013-may result in the medium term in greater output of flat products and other items with higher value added. However, in the short term, the value of exports will be largely driven by global metals prices, which fell for a fifth consecutive year in 2016. We expect solid price growth in 2017 driven by recovering demand across emerging markets, but a contraction again in 2018, as weaker demand from China offsets demand growth elsewhere.
If security concerns diminish, growth potential in tourism is good
Tourism, one of the most important services sectors of the Turkish economy, has witnessed rapid growth in the past ten years, but it remains vulnerable to geopolitical developments and changes in the exchange rate. Having reached a new record of 37m in 2014, the number of foreign visitors (excluding Turkish citizens living abroad) dipped slightly in 2015, reflecting mainly the impact of EU/US trade sanctions on the Russian economy (visitors from Russia, Turkey's second largest tourist market, fell by 18.5%) and perceived security concerns following a spate of terrorist attacks in the second half of the year. Balance-of-payments data show that travel receipts from all visitors, including Turkish citizens living abroad, fell from US$29.6bn in 2014 to US$26.6bn. In 2016 tourism was hit hard by Russian sanctions, which have now been lifted, and by terrorist attacks. Ministry of Culture and Tourism figures put the total number of foreign visitor arrivals in 2016 at 25.4m, a year-on-year fall of 30%. In the first half of 2017 visitors from Russia rose to 1.7m, from just 184,000 in January-June 2016, exceeding the level in 2015, but visitors from west and central European countries fell by 12.8% year on year, to 4.8m, suggesting security concerns may still be deterring visitors from key markets such as Germany and the UK. If security concerns diminish, growth potential is good. Foreign interest in residential real estate and hotels has been strong, and the sector remains price-competitive compared with those of many other Mediterranean destinations, especially after the weakening of the lira against the euro, which is the currency of Turkey's main tourist markets and of competitors such as Greece, Cyprus and Malta.

Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disin-flationary effects of low global oil prices. We expect further currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank does not loosen monetary policy too soon, we expect inflation to ease gradually, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.

There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows as well as the impact on investor confidence of domestic political tensions and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.

We expect the current account to widen moderately and to remain sufficiently large-at a forecast average of 4.2% of GDP per year in 2017-21-making it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main export sectors, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. There has been a rebound in Russian tourist arrivals in 2017, but the tourism sector is likely to take several years to recover to its 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Turkey
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows rose dramatically in 2005-08, after averaging a modest 1% of GDP between 1990 and 2004. In the context of the global economic and financial crisis, they slowed again in 2009-10 and have remained below the level reached in 2006-08 of around US$20bn. According to balance-of-payments statistics, inflows of FDI, including sales of real estate to non-residents, declined to around US$13bn, or 1.4% of GDP, per year in 2012-14, before picking up to US$17.6bn, or 2% of GDP, in 2015. In 2016 FDI inflows fell back to US$12.3bn, or 1.4% of GDP. With FDI inflows amounting to just US$4.9 in the first half of 2017, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the full-year figure to be slightly below that in 2016. The stock of inward FDI stood at just 15.6% of GDP in 2016. This figure compares with 60% in Slovakia, 70% in the Czech Republic, and 48% in Poland. Following a fall from US$4.1bn in 2012 to US$3.6bn in 2013, Turkish outward FDI jumped to US$7bn in 2014, largely reflecting a small number of large transactions, notably the acquisition of the UK-based United Biscuits by Yildiz Holding. The figure eased to US$5.1bn in 2015, still a relatively large figure by historical standards, and to US$3.1bn in 2016.
Origin and distribution
The traditional sources of foreign capital in Turkey have been multinational companies based in major EU countries, especially the Netherlands, Germany, the UK and France, and in other OECD countries such as the US, Switzerland and Japan. Individual large investments from several smaller EU countries, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Saudi Arabia, Russia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and Brazil have amended this pattern in recent years, and there have also been some significant purchases by private equity funds. About 90% of foreign investment appears to go to Istanbul, where most national Turkish companies have their headquarters. Investment projects of foreign capital companies are overwhelmingly concentrated in the Marmara region (which includes Istanbul), the Aegean region, the Mediterranean and Ankara. Historically, manufacturing (particularly the chemicals, food and automotive industries) and financial services attracted the most FDI. In 2012 construction figured prominently, with about 13% of net FDI inflows, although this was the result of the inclusion in this category of a single investment by the French-based Aéroports de Paris, which bought a 38% stake in Turkey's airport operator, TAV Airports, and a 49% stake in its construction arm, TAV Construction. In 2015 the share of FDI of financial services rose sharply to 30% of the total, from about 17% in the previous year; this again reflected the impact of a single large investment in which a Spanish bank, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), increased its stake in Garanti Bank. Chemicals and pharmaceuticals was the second largest category in 2015, accounting for 15% of total FDI inflows. Problems in developed economies, and the euro zone crisis in particular, together with the more recent deterioration in economic prospects in Turkey, has led to divestments by foreign financial institutions, many of which entered the Turkish market in 2005-08. As part of a plan to shore up its capital base, the National Bank of Greece has sold its 99.8% stake in Finans Bank, but because the sale, which was completed in mid-2016, was to Qatar National Bank, it did not affect net inward FDI figures in 2016.
Foreign property purchases, which are included in balance-of-payments statistics for FDI, have been making a solid contribution to net inflows since 2005. In 2005-13 net inflows averaged a solid US$2.5bn per year, before picking up to US$4.3bn in 2014, US$4.2bn in 2015 and US$3.9bn in 2016. In the first half of 2017 net investment in real estate rose by 34.3% year on year, to US$2.4bn.
Determinants
Foreign investment is mostly motivated by the size and potential of the Turkish market, but also increasingly because it offers access to neighbouring markets. The sharp rise in FDI in 2005-07 was partly driven by favourable global financial conditions, which have since evaporated. However, the upsurge was also made possible by the conjunction of several country-specific factors. The 2001 financial crisis led to a new drive for reform and privatisation, and reforms in sectors such as energy, telecommunications and banking began to take hold. The Justice and Development Party (AKP), in power since 2002, was more willing than its predecessors to sell majority stakes in state-owned companies to foreigners, even in sectors previously considered "strategic". The economy was relatively stable and grew strongly, and EU accession talks, which were expected to lead to further reform of the business environment, got under way. The private sector was also more willing to seek foreign partners than in the past. This may have reflected the thinking of a new generation of management, strategies of specialisation in certain sectors, a desire to raise capital for privatisation bids, fear of increasing foreign competition, lost appetite for bank ownership and temptingly high company valuations. From 2008, although the government remained willing to privatise, market conditions deteriorated, resulting in less interest from foreign investors. Since 2013 potential deterrents have multiplied: less buoyant economic growth, mass anti-government protests, financial market volatility, government corruption allegations, the spillover of violence from the conflict in Syria and, most recently, the collapse of the peace negotiations with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and an attempted military coup in July 2016. Other significant structural deterrents, which vary by the sector, size and type of investment, include regulatory uncertainty, a slow and unpredictable judicial system, weak intellectual property (IP) protection and unfair competition from smuggled goods and the informal sector.
Impact
The FDI stock as a percentage of GDP is much lower than in most central and east European countries, Turkey's main competitors for FDI. However, FDI has accumulated over many decades and the outlook compared with several central and eastern European countries has improved. Several leading multinationals, such as Unilever and Ford, have had a long-standing presence in Turkey, and companies with foreign partners play a significant role in the economy, helping to spread modern management and business practice. In the automotive industry, foreign investment has ensured expansion, technology transfer and access to global markets, although some lament the lack of national technology or a national trademark and the focus on production of low-end vehicles. By contrast, much recent FDI has taken the form of acquisitions of existing assets in domestically oriented sectors, and has therefore had limited direct impact on fixed investment or exports. Foreign ownership of banks has not demonstrably improved either access to international funds or services and productivity, which were already advanced, and nor have fears been fulfilled that foreign-owned banks may attach a greater risk premium than local banks to lending to the Turkish government or Turkish companies. The arrival of Vodafone has gradually helped to increase competition and investment in telecoms, where Turkcell and Turk Telekom are dominant players. From a macroeconomic perspective, Turkey relies on capital inflows, including FDI, to cover its large external financing requirement. In the years prior to the 2008-09 crisis, a growing share of FDI in capital inflows comforted the financial markets by reducing the vulnerability of the lira to trends in short-term capital inflows. However, the low level of FDI inflows relative to Turkey's current-account deficit continues to raise concerns about the sustainability of its external financing needs. We expect the ratio to improve during the forecast period, rising to about 35-40% of the projected current-account deficit, although most of this improvement reflects the impact of low international oil prices on the current-account deficit.
Potential
Our baseline forecast is that, assuming security concerns will be addressed during the forecast period, there will be a moderate pick-up driven by further privatisation and other crossborder mergers and acquisitions, as well as foreign interest in residential and commercial property, following the easing of restrictions on foreign ownership of real estate in 2012. Although the surge in foreign acquisitions in telecoms and banking of 2006-07 is unrepeatable, private corporations in many sectors may still be open to foreign investment, and several major assets remain to be privatised. We assume that the government will make further progress in creating conditions for private-sector investment in infrastructure. The energy sector in particular has the potential to attract large amounts of foreign investment. Existing investors are likely to increase their investment through further acquisitions or projects, and some greenfield investment may take place. Subdued income growth may dampen foreign investors' earlier interest in retailing, but they may also become more active in other services, such as tourism, as well as in mining and agriculture. Accordingly, we expect FDI to average close to 2% of GDP a year in 2016-20. Investors from the Gulf region and Asia may play a larger role, in addition to Western multinationals and funds.
Market opportunities: Market outlook

Overall spending power will rise, but income distribution will remain uneven
The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local currency terms. In 2016 GDP per head was US$10,767 at market exchange rates and US$24,268 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates. These figures are well below those for all central and east European countries in the EU, except Bulgaria and Romania. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Turkey's GDP per head to be about US$30,500 at PPP exchange rates in 2021. At this level, GDP per head in Turkey will be about 65% of the EU28 average, an increase of about 7 percentage points in ten years. This reflects not only Turkey's growth performance, but also the lasting impact of the current euro zone crisis on the EU average.
Income distribution is uneven by European standards. According to the official 2015 (latest available) survey of incomes and living conditions, members of the highest earning 20% of households accounted for 46.5% of total income, up from 45.9% in 2014, and the members of the lowest earning 20% of households for 6.1%, down from 6.2% in the previous year. Geographical factors contributed to the discrepancies. In general, the regions with the highest and most rapidly growing concentrations of population were also the wealthiest regions-except in the south-east, where spending power is low. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), greater Istanbul, which accounts for about one-fifth of the population, represents about one-quarter of household consumption expenditure. By contrast, the statistical region of south-east Anatolia, with about 10% of the population, generated about only 6% of household consumption. Income and consumer expenditure also vary widely between urban and rural areas, and within cities. These patterns are unlikely to change significantly in 2017-21.
Households are expected to decline in size
The household will remain the main consumption unit during the forecast period. Households typically consist of an average 3.4 people and over 90% of households are made up of married couples. Although these patterns will change only gradually, the number of households will tend to increase faster than the population, sustaining strong demand for housing construction and household durables, including basics like furniture, washing machines and refrigerators.
A large majority of Turkish consumers aspire to "western style" consumer society, in so far as their incomes permit, although local factors affect lifestyle aspirations. Much of the population adheres to Islamic prohibitions, including on consumption of alcohol. The country has wide variations in geography and climate, which affect diet, leisure activities and demand for certain goods. Choices of entertainment vary between groups with different education levels.

Young population will encourage new products and services to be introduced
The proportion of total household spending allocated to food, beverages and tobacco is high and not expected to fall much during the forecast period. Housing and household fuel, goods and services will also remain major expenditure items. The wealthiest households, which enjoy standards of living close to those of west Europeans, spend significant amounts on entertainment, education and catering, as well as on transport, because of the high cost of running a car. These households will remain an important target market for environment-friendly and wellness products and services, which are relatively new. Other population segments are starting to provide additional demand for items that have been the prerogative of upper income groups. Rising car ownership will continue to encourage supermarket shopping, residence in suburban areas and related lifestyle trends. Demand for branded fashion items, fast food, air conditioning and holidays is also spreading. That half of the population is under the age of 30 will encourage the introduction of new products and services in communications, information and entertainment tech-nology. Tourists constitute a significant addition to the consumer market. About 50m, including foreigners and non-resident Turks, visited Turkey in 2014 and 2015. This figure fell to a still sizeable 39m in 2016. Domestic political instability and security concerns are likely to dampen near-term growth, but growth potential in the sector is good.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Some of the obstacles to solid and stable growth were removed in the decade to 2010, but in recent years the government has focused on domestic power struggles and the foreign-policy challenges arising from turmoil in the wider region, putting economic reforms designed to boost investment and employment on hold. Given the deterioration of Turkey's institutions of governance and the likelihood that the current domestic political tensions will continue for some time, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects only limited progress on reforms in the near term, damaging Turkey's longer-term growth potential. For similar reasons, we do not expect Turkey's EU membership bid to make significant progress, making accession a remote prospect. A relatively low level of skills and quality of the workforce compared with Turkey's main competitors for foreign direct investment (FDI) in central and eastern Europe will continue to act as a deterrent to FDI, although Turkey will enjoy substantially more favourable demographics. The quality of infrastructure is also likely to lag behind, especially in remote eastern areas of the country.
Working-age population growth turns negative in 2040
Demographic trends: On current projections, Turkey will have the second-largest national population in Europe, after Russia, by 2050; and unlike in most European economies Turkey's working-age population will continue to grow up to 2040. Nevertheless, Turkey's positive demographic dynamic is expected to start to deteriorate from about 2030. In 2031-50 the difference between growth in the population of working age and that of the total population will become negative, which will dampen economic growth. This trend could be delayed if the bulk of 3.1m Syrian refugees currently being hosted in Turkey are integrated into the population.
Throughout the long-term forecast period, we expect an upward trend in the labour force and employment because of rises in participation rates, given the low starting levels. With the workforce continuing to expand at a steady rate, it will be a challenge to produce sufficient jobs to keep the unemployment rate on a downward trend from a forecast 9.7% in 2021.
External conditions: Wider international developments-particularly in international financial markets, the EU (Turkey's main export market) and in global terms of trade-will continue to affect Turkey's long-term economic performance. With export-led industries playing an increasing role in growth, Turkey would benefit from greater global trade liberalisation, but the process of liberalisation is faltering and trade flows have slowed. As a supplier of the developed economies, Turkey will continue to face intense international competition, since low and medium value-added manufactured goods are likely to remain its main product lines. Its technology potential is relatively limited, and the country is not well placed to become a major supplier of services other than tourism and, to a lesser extent, construction, although improvements in (and diversification of) the domestic financial sector over the past decade may enable Turkey to develop as a provider of banking and insurance services in the wider region. Because of completed and planned pipeline construction, Turkey is expected to become a major energy hub between the Caspian region and western Europe. As Turkey shares borders with countries like Iran, Syria and Iraq, its immediate regional environment is challenging. We expect Turkey's foreign policy to remain broadly Western-oriented, although given recent developments in the domestic political sphere there is a considerable risk that under the current religiously conservative government Turkey's foreign relations will take a different path.
The EU's problems will dampen Turkey's interest in membership
We do not expect Turkey to join the EU and there is a high probability that the accession negotiations may even be abandoned by one or both sides during the long-term forecast period. Given the limited progress so far in Turkey's EU accession negotiations, the strength of public opposition in most EU member states to Turkish membership and the severity of the economic and political problems facing the EU, we believe that Turkey's commitment to the goal of full EU membership will diminish even further. This increases the risk that government commitment to political and economic reform will weaken further. Harmonisation of Turkey's domestic legislation with EU norms is significantly more important for Turkey's long-term economic stability than actual membership. If the EU were to loosen its structure-the UK's vote to leave the EU could prompt such a move-opposition in the EU to Turkish accession might ease, increasing Turkey's chances of joining.
Institutions and policy trends: Recep Tayyip Erdogan's victory in Turkey's first direct election of the president in August 2014 and the approval of his presidential reform plan in a referendum in April 2017 have potentially huge implications for the country's future institutional and policy-setting framework. The constitutional reform allows Mr Erdogan to run for president for two five-year terms, which means he is likely to be in power until 2029. Beyond that, assuming the constitution is not amended further to allow him to run for a third term, which cannot be ruled out, the issue of his succession as leader of the AKP and president of the country could become a source of instability during the long-term forecast period.
The broadly positive management of the economy by the AKP since coming to power in 2002 has been one of the main reasons for its electoral successes. But there is a considerable risk that economic policy will be increasingly tailored to political purposes rather than to maintain macroeconomic stability and further improvement of the business environment. Nevertheless, Turkey's public finances are structurally sounder following a decade of IMF-backed reforms in 1999-2008, which may allow the government more room to increase public investment in infrastructure and possibly to reduce tax rates further, if solid economic growth is sustained. Given the little progress that we expect to be made in Turkey's EU accession negotiations, the problems of unpredictability and inefficiency in Turkey's domestic legal and regulatory environment are expected to continue beyond 2021. Legislation is likely to remain under the scrutiny of the EU and other international bodies, such as the IMF, World Bank, the Council of Europe and the European Court of Human Rights, although Mr Erdogan's assertive and increasingly personalised approach to foreign relations is likely to limit their influence over the direction of policies.
The government's peace negotiations with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed following the June 2015 election, and neither the PKK nor Mr Erdogan has shown any indication that they are willing to revive it any time soon. If the situation continues on its current trajectory, there is a real risk that the PKK and its affiliates will spread the conflict from the predominantly Kurdish-inhabited south-east of the country to Turkey's main cities in central and western regions, where the Kurdish population has risen rapidly in recent years. The mounting death toll will probably encourage Mr Erdogan to resort to increasingly authoritarian means to retain control.
Income levels will remain well below the EU average
Long-term performance: Turkey's economic growth performance is expected to surpass that of the EU28 as a result of its more favourable demographic profile and larger productivity increases. But, at an average of 3% a year in 2017-50, GDP growth will be well below the performance recorded in 2004-07 and 2010-15. Average growth in GDP per head will be substantially lower, reflecting the expected rise in the total population. Income levels will remain well below the EU28 average, but catch-up is likely to continue. Improvements in the policy environment could produce substantially better results, but there is still uncertainty about Turkey's future political and institutional framework, and its commitment to the reforms required under the EU accession process.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Thailand--highlights: Political outlook
The military-led government will remain in complete control until the next general election, which The Economist Intelligence Unit expects to be held in 2019. The new constitution (approved by the public in a referendum in 2016), which will be adopted under a newly elected government, will allow the military to maintain significant influence over executive and legislative affairs throughout the forecast period (2017-21). The junta will also continue to enforce lese-majesty laws strongly as it manages the funeral of the former monarch, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, and the formal accession of the new king, Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, in late 2017. The military's stronghold will ensure political stability in 2017-21, albeit at the expense of many civil liberties. However, organised, but non-violent, challenges to govern-ment cannot be ruled out, particularly later in the forecast period.
Thailand--highlights: Demographic outlook

The rate of population growth will slow in the forecast period as a result of effective family-planning programmes, sex education and changing social norms, such as later marriages and smaller families. Continuing improvement in the prevention and treatment of infectious disease will contribute to a rising life expectancy and a growing share of the population over 65 years old. However, owing to a shortage of formal job opportunities in neigh-bouring countries, migrant labour from Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will continue to grow in absolute terms. In combination with an increase in the average retirement age, this will serve to boost the labour force in 2017-21.
Thailand--highlights: Business environment outlook

Thailand's business environment score rises in 2017-21, helping to improve its global ranking to 34th, from 38th in 2012-16. Its regional position remains at ninth out of 17 countries. The macroeconomic environment will remain stable and the Bank of Thailand (the central bank) will maintain its independence. We expect modest improvements in policies towards private enterprise and competition and towards foreign investment. The overall tax regime will remain stable and accommodative to business. Trade liberalisation will continue, with growing integration among Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) members and other countries in Asia. Long-overdue construction on a number of transport infrastructure projects will also get under way.

We forecast that Thailand's real GDP will expand by 3.3% on average in 2017, but growth will average 3% a year in 2018-21 owing to tepid external demand. Public investment in infrastructure development will lend considerable support to growth in the early part of the forecast period. Private consumption will remain under pressure owing to high household debt and weak wage growth. Nonetheless, a clearer political path, following the referendum on the constitution in 2016 and the accession of the new king, will reassure investors, helping to boost growth in the later years of the forecast period. The tourism sector will remain a key support for the economy throughout 2017-21.

Thailand is a sizeable market in its own right, with a population of more than 69m and nominal GDP equivalent to US$407.2bn at market exchange rates in 2016. The retail sector will create market opportunities, in large part owing to the continuing strength of the tourism sector. Populist govern-ments in the early 2000s ensured strong growth in income levels through fiscal handouts, high minimum wages and price controls. Although the current and next government will try to be more fiscally prudent, they will have to maintain supportive policies for key interest groups in order to ensure political stability. Household debt will remain a dampener on consumer sentiment for much of the forecast period, but a tax regime increasingly focused on wealth, rather than income and consumption, will avoid crimping private consumption growth further.
Thailand--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2017-30 2031-50 2017-50

The long-term outlook for Thailand's economy hinges heavily on the assumption that governments in the next ten years will possess greater political power than their predecessors to enact and continue structural reforms, as well as develop infrastructure. Such reforms will improve the business environment and raise productivity. However, there will be persistent delays, mainly owing to (partly self-imposed) financial constraints. Thailand's demographic profile will also start to have a significant, negative impact on GDP growth from the 2030s.

Background: Following a revolution in 1932, Thailand's absolute monarchy was replaced with a constitutional monarchy. Over the years, while the elected government gained prominence, democracy was turbulent and led to several coups (nearly 19 have been staged since 1932). The latest coup took place in May 2014, when the democratically elected government led by Yingluck Shinawatra was removed following months of protests and political turmoil. The Shinawatra family gained prominence in Thai politics in 2001 when Thaksin Shinawatra, a businessman-turned-politician and Yingluck's older brother, was elected prime minister. He remained in office until 2006, when he was removed by a coup. Thaksin was a populist leader and his political prominence created a divide between the rural population in the northern provinces and the urban rich of the south. This rift is a lasting consequence of Thai democracy and has emerged from income inequality between the rural and urban parts of the country. Although the junta remains firmly in control of government, a return to democracy is likely to give way to renewed rivalry between the two camps.
Political structure: The military officers who comprise the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO, the formal name for the junta), led by Prayuth Chan-ocha as prime minister, control an interim government made up of a 200-member National Legislative Assembly (parliament), a 35-member cabinet and a 250-member reform council. The members of these bodies were appointed by the NCPO and are mainly military officers. The king remains the symbolic head of state. Following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej in October 2016, the crown prince, Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, ascended the throne.
Policy issues: The military-led government will focus on improving the investment environment in Thailand and head a public-investment drive in infrastructure in an effort to boost the country's long-term economic performance. The junta's continuing grip on power will reassure many foreign investors deterred by potential instability, but growing regional competition will detract from Thailand's attractiveness as an investment destination.
Taxation: Corporate income tax stands at 20%. Tax concessions are available for firms that list on the stockmarket. Value-added tax (VAT) stands at 7%. Personal income tax rises to 35% on annual taxable earnings exceeding Bt5m (US$145,000).
Foreign trade: According to national-accounts data, Thailand recorded a merchandise trade surplus (fob-fob) of US$35.8bn in 2016, up from US$26.8bn in 2015. The current-account surplus stood at US$46.8bn in 2016, up from US$32.1bn in 2015.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The military rules the country via a junta known as the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO), led by the former army chief and current prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha. The military coup in May 2014 led to the dissolution of the House of Representatives (parliament) elected in 2011. The NCPO appointed an interim National Legislative Assembly in its place in August 2014, consisting mainly of security officers and civilians supportive of the military. A 250-member National Reform Council, which is tasked with recommending reforms and approving a new charter, was also appointed. A new constitution was approved in a public referendum in August 2016, paving the way for fresh elections but also sealing the considerable influence of the military on the next government. However, the NCPO's planned path back to elections has been delayed by the death in late 2016 and pending cremation in October 2017 of the previous king, Bhumibol Adulyadej, and the coronation of the new monarch, Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, that will follow. The accession process was not destabilising, partly owing to the military government's imperative to sustain the royal institution in order to legitimise its own political role. Nonetheless, the king's prominent place in Thai society will slowly diminish in coming years, as the new monarch fails to command the same level of reverence among the public that his father did.
Political outlook: Political stability
The NCPO will continue to control the legislature until elections are held, which The Economist Intelligence Unit expects to take place in 2019 at the earliest. The new constitution, approved in a public referendum in August 2016, cements the military's continued influence over government even after the next ballot. The accession of King Maha will have a minimal impact on political stability in the forecast period (2017-21); the formal coronation will take place after the cremation of his late father on October 25th.
The king's endorsement will remain important for the junta
The military establishment depends on endorsement by the king for much of its political legitimacy. It has therefore ensured the continuance of the monarchy in line with the wishes of the late king, who even in death will remain a figure of paramount reverence among the Thai public. King Maha has already sought to consolidate his position in the political sphere by tailoring rules concerning the delegation of the monarch's authority and control over the royal estate to his preference. Although some of these alterations indicate a slightly stronger foundational role in politics than in the previous charter, in practice royal intrusion into everyday politics will remain rare. The junta's dependence on the continuation of the monarchy in its traditional form has led to the proactive suppression of any criticism of the new king via lese-majesty laws. The wide-ranging enforcement of these laws will remain the norm until the king's coronation, in an attempt to minimise any reputational damage to the royal institution and its long-term role within the state.
The junta has also boosted oversight and censorship of mass media and public debate in an attempt to suppress dissent against the military government. For instance, the authorities have threatened to revoke the operating licences of some internet service providers unless they block certain pages on major social media and video-streaming platforms featuring politically sensitive content. This trend is likely to ensure political stability in the near term. However, a mounting clampdown on free speech and association risks aggravating public discontent with the current political situation, particularly if indications of abuse of power by officials come to light or the economy slows more sharply than we currently forecast.
A newly elected government will have less executive authority
The election of a new government will be accepted with little open resistance in the light of the 2016 constitution referendum result. However, if strict rules prohibiting criticism of the authorities are carried over under the next government, the risk of political instability will rise markedly. This risk would already be high given the military's likely continuing, overtly central role in the political system-the Senate (the upper house of parliament) is likely to be dominated by figures linked to the military. As such, challenges to the next government-in the form of political boycotts and protests-cannot be ruled out. Such challenges are more likely to occur towards the end of the forecast period, especially if the next government fails to preside over a robust and inclusive economic recovery. A significant economic downturn is not our core forecast, however. Moreover, the risk of an armed civil conflict remains negligible, and any major stands against the next government and its constitutionally dictated set-up are likely to be headed by non-military political factions.
The insurgency in the Muslim-dominated southern provinces of Yala, Pattani and Narathiwat will rage on; small-scale attacks targeting security forces and civilian-frequented religious sites have increased in frequency. Peace talks in February 2017 between the military and MARA Pattani, an umbrella group for six separatist movements in southern Thailand, yielded the establishment of "safe zones" in the region, but attacks outside these areas have continued unabated. There also remains a moderate risk of attacks within safe-zone areas owing to the proliferation of insurgent groups outside the MARA Pattani umbrella. Yet, the insurgency presents only a minimal threat to overall political stability. Furthermore, the possibility of the insurgency expanding significantly and spreading to other parts of the country remains low. As such, we do not expect the situation to threaten Thailand's vital tourism sector in 2017-21.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness is more certain in the wake of public approval of the junta-drafted constitution and the smooth accession of the new king. Unlike the previous government, which faced major street demonstrations and legal challenges in opposition to its policies, the junta possesses near-absolute power to implement its agenda as a transitional government until the next elections. Moreover, regardless of the subsequent poll results, the military establishment has in effect sealed overarching power over the next government via the new charter.
The constitution that will be adopted by the next elected government out-lines an administrative structure that is formed, in a larger proportion than previously, of appointed officials and allows such officials to join their publicly elected counterparts in selecting a prime minister. These provisions will make it much easier for the military to dominate government decision-making, while curtailing the power of democratically elected officials. Although such changes are likely to expedite the policymaking process, they bode ill for the public accountability of government.
The junta will ensure that technocrats remain in charge of economic policy
The NCPO has appointed technocrats to manage the economy and is determined to outline a long-term strategy for the country in addition to its short- to medium-term focus on reviving investment and private consumption. Its proposed 20-year "National Strategy" is currently being drafted and the next government will be constitutionally bound to follow it, under the explicit threat of impeachment. It is already clear that infrastructure development is likely to be a core supporting strategy within it, to sustain primary goals including rebalancing public- and private-sector development, and special economic zone development.
Nevertheless, in the near term the junta is likely still to devote significant resources to populist policies when needed to appease key interest groups, such as agricultural producers. Avoiding inflaming future political tensions will remain a key underlying priority. The deputy prime minister, overseeing economic affairs, Somkid Jatusripitak, was the finance minister under a former, populist prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra. Somkid is known for his populist policies that kept the economy strong on the back of fiscal handouts and increased rural income.
However, the military has not made any material progress in reconciling the political differences between the rural population of the north (who supported Thaksin) and the elite in southern Thailand (who are represented by his detractors, the Democrat Party). Therefore, although the military-appointed component of the next government will enjoy efficacy in policymaking, it will still find it difficult to satisfy the two major camps and may face rising opposition from one or both in the medium term-the same tensions that have plagued its predecessors.
Corruption will remain a significant problem in many of the country's institutions, including the military. Transparency International, an international organisation tracking levels of graft, published its benchmark Corruption Perceptions Index for 2016 in January 2017, which suggested that corruption has worsened under the junta's rule. Cases under the next government involving unelected officials, particularly those with explicit military links, may serve as a flashpoint for discontent over the new constitutional system and its lack of accountability. If open discontent does materialise it is more likely to be from a cumulative series of incidents and thus occur later in the forecast period. Continuing corruption in the local police force allows the capital, Bangkok, to host one of the world's largest shadow economies. The junta has made efforts to show a tougher stance against corruption, for instance by setting up a dedicated court to try relevant cases and proposing the death penalty for the involvement of high-level officials, as well as for foreigners, in graft. However, similar initiatives have been popular with past military governments and have only increased the remit of the sizeable shadow economy. There is little reason to believe that the junta and the next government will be any more successful in clamping down on corrupt activities.
Political outlook: Election watch
We believe that the next election will not take place before 2019. With public dissent against the military government's rule at manageable levels, the junta is content to postpone polls repeatedly in the short term. The king's intervention to seek changes to the draft constitution in January 2017 served as a legitimate justification to extend the election timeline without facing fierce criticism from opposition groups. Other pretexts for delays are likely to be found, such as concerns over the security situation relating to the insurgency. However, the public's approval of the draft charter in a referendum, preserving the substantial political influence of the military, has reduced the junta's motivation to delay the poll indefinitely.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Prayuth Chan-ocha
A former career military officer, Prayuth became commander-in-chief of the military in 2010. In May 2014 he imposed martial law and toppled Thailand's then-caretaker government in a coup, forming a junta known as the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO) with himself as leader. In August 2014 the NCPO appointed a military-dominated interim National Legislative Assembly (parliament) and chose Prayuth as interim prime minister. Although Prayuth has made statements in the past stressing the neutrality of the armed forces in Thailand's political struggles, he has made it clear since taking power that his core agenda is biased towards restoring and protecting the economic and political privileges of the country's traditional elite. He will continue to prioritise this group in the remaining period of the junta's pre-election rule in order to marshal support for the subsequent heavily military-influenced government.
King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun
King Maha, the heir to the revered late monarch, Bhumibol Adulyadej, ascended the throne in December 2016. The new king does not command the level of popularity that his father did, owing in part to well-publicised elements of his lifestyle and related scandals. However, the junta has supported the king's traditional role via heavy-handed enforcement of lese-majesty laws and the monarch has moved to consolidate his position, for instance by bringing the royal estate more directly under his control and reducing the opportunities in which power may be deferred to a nominated party. Although the king is likely to continue to take a background role in national politics, he may choose actively to mediate future political disputes involving unscheduled changes of government towards favouring the interests of particular demographics in order to boost his popularity. This means that he has great potential political influence.
Somchai Wongsawat
A Puea Thai party politician and former prime minister, Somchai was acquitted over the forced dispersal of protestors that resulted in two deaths while he was in office in 2008. The case, which was brought by the National Anti-Corruption Commission in 2015, cast a shadow over Somchai's political future. With its resolution he is likely to step back into the fray of national politics and there is a strong chance that he will run for Puea Thai's leadership in the absence of its de facto leaders, Thaksin and Yingluck Shinawatra, who are both barred from Thai politics. Somchai is an experienced and well-known politician and could therefore help to spearhead a significant challenge to the continued dominance of the military in politics via calls to Puea Thai supporters not to participate in the next election or, along with fellow "redshirt" politicians, obstruct actions in the next parliament to frustrate a military-aligned faction's policy agenda.
Yingluck Shinawatra
Yingluck had been a politician for only around two months before leading the Puea Thai party to victory at the 2011 general election, becoming Thailand's first female prime minister. Her political inexperience had been more conspicuous in her policymaking than in her negotiating: she had managed to bring a degree of calm to Thailand's explosive political environment, but some of her economic policies flirted with fiscal disaster and helped to precipitate her downfall. Although being a newcomer to politics, Yingluck struck up a strong rapport with voters and as prime minister she had partly vindicated criticism that she was a stooge for her brother. However, owing to fiscally imprudent economic policymaking, she lost the state coffers millions. This led to the junta filing criminal charges against her for negligence in office over an expensive rice-subsidy programme. She has also in effect been banned from returning to Thai politics as the court case against her continues. However, she retains a sizeable support base and her influence on-and support for-other politicians from her "redshirt" camp cannot be discounted.
Political outlook: International relations
The military's seizure of power initially cooled relations with Western countries. However, links are gradually being restored for the sake of economic ties, as well as wider concerns over political influence in the region, particularly with regard to China's growing presence. The US administration under the president, Donald Trump, indicated in April 2017 that at least a partial rapprochement between the two countries is set to occur before an election, following a telephone call between Mr Trump and Prayuth. Diplomatic and trade ties with the US and other Western countries will improve further following the next poll. The inclusion of a referendum in the charter-drafting process, coupled with the election itself, will be sufficient to fulfil many Western countries' prerequisite for democratic due process in the decision to re-establish ties.
Japan, which is wary of being superseded by China (with regard to large-scale investment projects), has demonstrated a willingness to continue all but top-tier diplomatic ties and bilateral agreement negotiations with Thailand during the junta's rule. This means that major economic co-operation deals between the two countries will go ahead regardless, including infrastructure projects to be built under Japanese contract.
Nonetheless, China's influence in Thailand will grow in the short term as the military-controlled administration looks to the Chinese government for political and economic support before the election. The countries have no conflicting territorial claims in the South China Sea and are important trading partners. Economic ties are set to strengthen further as Thailand focuses on forging bilateral deals between state-owned enterprises under its plan to spur GDP growth through public investment. However, this growing relationship will not be without its setbacks, as illustrated by the stop-start progress of the planned China-Laos-Thailand high-speed rail project. Such tussles will delay the economic benefits of greater regional integration.
Notably, increasing bilateral integration with China seems unlikely to obstruct Thailand's ongoing efforts to engage with its neighbours in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN). Tensions between other ASEAN members and China in relation to territorial disputes in the South China Sea have cooled, largely in deference to China's economic concessions to various countries in the region.

Infant mortality rate (per 1,000 live births)   9.9 8.8

 Male   70.6 71.6
 Female   77.4 78.3
 Average   73.9 74.9
Sources: International Labour Organisation (ILO), labour force projections; Economist Intelligence Unit estimates and forecasts; national statistics.
Effective family-planning programmes, sex education and changing social norms, such as later marriage and smaller families, will keep Thailand's average population growth rate relatively low, at 0.2% a year, in the forecast period. By 2021 the population is forecast to reach 69.5m, with females accounting for 50.8% of the total. Owing to continued improvements in healthcare and childbirth procedures, the infant mortality rate will drop to an average of 8.8 per 1,000 live births in the forecast period, from 9.9 per 1,000 in 2012-16. Life expectancy will also improve, with men expected to live for an average of 71.6 years in 2017-21, up from 70.6 in 2012-16, while female life expectancy will rise from an average of 77.4 to 78.3 years over the same period.
An ageing population will way on the productivity of the economy
Thailand's population is ageing, with the proportion of the population aged under 15 set to fall to 16.1% in 2021, from 18.8% in 2011, and the proportion aged over 65 rising steadily. This will mean that the young-age dependency ratio falls to 0.23 in 2021, from 0.26 in 2011, while the old-age dependency ratio rises from 0.13 to 0.19. This demographic trend will place further strains on healthcare provision. The country's health system is structured around a universal healthcare scheme introduced in 2001, which is coming under increasing strains from the growing old-age population. Under the initial programme, the "Bt30 scheme", which was implemented by the government led by Thaksin Shinawatra in 2001, all Thais were entitled to visit a doctor or hospital for a flat fee of Bt30 (around US$1). Following the coup in 2006 that ousted Thaksin, the military-installed government abolished the Bt30 fee, thus making public healthcare free. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this scheme to remain free in the forecast period.

The crude death rate is forecast at 8.2 per 1,000 in 2017-21. Age-related non-communicable illnesses such as heart disease, stroke and respiratory diseases are responsible for most deaths in Thailand, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). In its latest country profile for Thailand, road accidents were also a leading cause of death (based on 2012 data). Thailand continues to confront the challenge of preventing the spread of HIV/AIDS, which in the early 2000s emerged as the country's leading cause of death. Thailand was one of the first countries in Asia to launch a campaign to raise public awareness of HIV/AIDS, and recent figures confirm its effectiveness. The WHO estimates the death rate from the disease at around 23 per 100,000 people in 2016, although 450,000 people continued to live with the disease in that year. Other infectious diseases such as cholera, measles and mumps have become less common but have not been eradicated.
There will remain a high number of migrant workers in Thailand
The labour market will tighten owing to the ageing of Thailand's population, but the emergence of serious labour shortages is unlikely in the next five years. The labour force will expand by 1.7m in 2017-21, to reach 38.6m, reflecting in part a trend of increasing numbers of women choosing to work outside the home. Migrant labour will remain abundant, with often-unregistered workers from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos continuing to dominate unskilled jobs in the construction industry and as household employees. However, Thailand will gradually become a less attractive destination for unskilled migrants over the long term. In the near term this will partly reflect a less welcoming stance on the part of the authorities, who are keen to channel unskilled migrant labour into legitimate strategic industries in border-located special economic zones. In the longer term, job opportunities in Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will expand as the prospects for economic growth and reform in those countries improve.
Despite slow population growth, the number of households in Thailand is expected to rise strongly in the forecast period, mainly as a result of a reduction in average household size. Internal migration and changing social patterns mean that it is increasingly common for households to consist of nuclear, rather than extended, families. Steady economic expansion in recent years has encouraged this trend, as migrant workers from rural areas have been moving to the major cities, and particularly the metropolitan area centred on the capital, Bangkok. Although the former remains the epicentre for the urban population, other cities, including Surat Thani, Chiang Mai and Hat Yai, have also been growing rapidly. This will result in the urban population increasing to 58.9% of the total population in 2021, from 51.7% in 2016.
