Thailand's business environment score increases from 6.62 in 2012-16 to 6.84 in 2017-21. In The Economist Intelligence Unit's global rankings, Thailand improves from 38th to 34th place, but its position in the Asia-Pacific region remains at ninth out of 17 countries. The score for political environment will improve. Political stability will be maintained for much of the forecast period, including after the next government comes to power. This is in large part because the military's central role in the subsequent government will stifle any partisan conflicts and improve political effectiveness. Separatist violence in the south will continue and a new military-dominated government is unlikely to dissipate the long-running, smouldering conflict. The risk of unrest permanently spreading to other parts of the country is low, however.
The government will continue to encourage foreign investment
The macroeconomic environment will stabilise in the forecast period, although it will remain vulnerable to external conditions. An improvement in the scores for policy towards private enterprise and competition and policy towards foreign investment under an elected government will encourage a moderate uptick in investment. This will be aided by an open capital account and a relatively stable currency. However, lacklustre domestic demand will continue to be a major drag on business sentiment, with high household debt and stagnating wages weighing on private consumption prospects. The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) will remain independent and monetary policy will be fairly conservative. Ambitious transport infrastructure projects boost the score for infrastructure.
Business environment outlook: Thailand's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: The authorities reorganise the management of several state-owned enterprises but do not sell off significant assets. The government gradually reduces subsidies, especially on food and energy, but price controls remain on many goods.
2019-21: Thailand remains on the US Trade Representative's intellectual property watch list despite an improvement in enforcement.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: The government woos foreign investors with the launch of new special economic zones. The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) limits public short-term foreign debt issuance to ease upward pressure on the baht.
2019-21: Opposition to the sale of assets to foreigners persists, particularly in the utilities sector. The authorities introduce new incentives to promote inward investment in targeted industries while removing incentives in low-value-added sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: The Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Economic Community (AEC) improves regional trade flows.
2019-21: Administrative procedures for trade transactions are streamlined, reducing delays. In particular, improvements are made in ASEAN intra-regional trade facilitation, amid efforts to step up integration of the AEC.
Taxes
2017-18: Enforcement of new land, property and inheritance taxes remains uneven. The government maintains the rate of value-added tax (VAT) at 7%.
2019-21: The coverage of land, property and inheritance taxes is actively expanded in order to boost government revenue.
Financing
2017-18: The authorities continue to focus on strengthening the financial sector and increasing its competitiveness. The health of the banking sector improves, and foreign investors continue to enjoy good access to local markets.
2019-21: Banks strengthen their financial position, and the regulatory environment is improved further. The BOT tries to expand the local bond market, primarily by developing a more active secondary market.
The labour market
2017-18: Unemployment remains low and rising labour costs have a negative impact on small and medium-sized enterprises. Labour unrest remains relatively rare, but trade unions vigorously oppose any moves towards privatisation.
2019-21: Shortages of skilled labour become more acute, driving up costs in high-value-added industries. The government loosens immigration controls on foreign skilled workers.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The expansion of road and rail infrastructure moves ahead slowly, providing a boost to the construction sector.
2019-21: A number of transport infrastructure projects proceed to the construction phase but are blighted by delays. A new government continues to explore the potential to develop nuclear power plants domestically, with Chinese assistance.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.8 7.8 22 20 7 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
There will be no major changes in Thailand's macroeconomic environment during the forecast period. However, deteriorating conditions elsewhere will see the country's global ranking improve from 22nd in 2012-16 to 20th in 2017-21, while its regional ranking will rise from seventh position to fifth over the same period. Relatively low public debt, a firmly positive current-account balance and fairly stable fiscal, monetary and exchange-rate policies will underpin macroeconomic stability. After several years of volatility, economic growth has been relatively steady since 2015 and is expected to remain so during 2017-21. Yet a pick-up to above 3.5%-closer to the country's potential growth rate-will prove elusive. This will be mainly owing to the increasing competition from other Association of South-East Asian Neighbours (ASEAN) countries in key high-value merchandise export industries.
The junta's fast-tracking of project approvals will lift investment
The military's control of government has allowed for more decisive approval of budgets and major spending plans. In 2017-18 the junta will continue to use its unchecked powers to fast-track policymaking and the approval of projects, including intermittent populist policies to appease influential interest groups such as agricultural producers. Furthermore, through the constitutionally mandated powers that it has recently secured, it will be able to maintain an influence on policymaking following the next election, in 2019 at the earliest. This will ensure that business-oriented tax reform and investment incentives are maintained and expanded in 2017-21, and that major infrastructure investment projects continue beyond the end of the forecast period. Private investment will continue to struggle in the early part of the forecast period, but this will be counterbalanced by public investment in major infrastructure projects that will act as economic stimulus. The growing tourism sector will provide strong support to domestic demand, particularly in the services sector.
Unlike previous post-coup governments, the junta directly manages important economic portfolios (including the Board of Investment, or BOI, which provides investment incentives). It is expected to continue to exert considerable indirect influence on these following the next elections via its 20-year "National Strategy", which is likely to influence the nature of investment via its priori-tisation of certain industries. The governor of the BOT, Veerathai Santiprabhob, who took the reins in October 2015, is well respected and there is so far no indication that he will bend to political pressure. This should ensure that the BOT remains independent and credible in its regulation of the financial sector and its management of the economy (particularly in setting official interest rates and acting to reduce excess volatility of the baht). Nonetheless, we cannot rule out political influence on the central bank's policymaking should economic conditions worsen significantly. This is not our core forecast, however.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.3 6.5 36 34 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
We expect a slight improvement in policy towards private enterprise and competition as the government makes more aggressive efforts to attract investment. This will help Thailand's global ranking to improve from 36th in 2012-16 to 34th in 2017-21. However, the country's regional rank will remain unchanged owing to concurrent improvements in other Asian countries. The military government has launched an anti-graft campaign, including a new court dedicated to trying corruption cases, but any clear success in tackling the issue is yet to be demonstrated. The favouritism for politically connected businesses under the previous administration led by Yingluck Shinawatra may have been replaced by another patronage system that rewards those allied to the military and the traditional establishment. Proposed reforms to state-owned enterprises (SOEs) will bolster the operational efficiency of state companies. However, privatisation remains a sensitive issue, and it is unlikely that the military-led government or its successor will try to sell off state assets, as this would redistribute economic rents away from current holders and be opposed by the general public. A long-standing area of concern is the lack of protection of intellectual property (IP), but new legal provisions should help to control piracy of digital and online content. The government will continue to use price controls for some basic goods to keep them affordable; prices for goods on the "sensitive" list cannot be changed without the permission of the Ministry of Commerce.
Efforts to curb corruption in the public sector will continue gradually
The corporate governance reform of 56 SOEs controlling assets worth US$340bn will be completed during the forecast period. In 2014 the military-controlled government appointed a so-called super-board to oversee the reform. Another super-board, designed to oversee procurement processes, was esta-blished in 2017. The formation of these bodies may help to curb corruption in the public sector, although progress in this area is likely to be slow. Another new public procurement law will also probably be passed, expanding and improving procurement processes. This will similarly help to reduce corruption and boost competition in the public-private sphere. All of these initiatives are unlikely to be reversed following new elections, as they look likely to be included in the junta-developed, constitutionally binding 20-year National Strategy.
Despite the passage of a new Copyright Act in August 2015, designed to protect IP rights on the internet, the US authorities continue to view the country as one of the worst offenders in terms of protecting IP. In 2017 Thailand remained on the US Trade Representative's Priority Watch List for the tenth consecutive year. The still-prevalent occurrence of IP infringement will hinder the country's progress towards becoming a "digital economy" and act as a disincentive to international brands starting up operations in Thailand.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.4 6.9 50 43 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand will continue to encourage inward investment, especially in higher-value-added industries. Further incentives are almost certain to be rolled out in 2017-21 and investment approvals will continue to be fast-tracked by the BOI. The government will not revive proposals, first touted in 2007, to amend the Foreign Business Act, which would make it more difficult for foreign companies to control Thai entities unless they own a majority of shares.
The BOI's seven-year investment promotion strategy, launched in 2015, offers incentives and government support for foreign investors. This includes incentives for setting up a business in less developed parts of the country and the promotion of special economic zones (SEZs) in border provinces. The latter are in place to take advantage of easier labour flows following the establishment of the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) in late 2015.
Improved connection to the capital will lift usage of special economic zones
A central pillar of the BOI's new strategy is the creation of at least ten SEZs on Thailand's borders. A large coastal-situated economic zone in the form of the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) has also been designated, capitalising on an existing industrial belt along the eastern seaboard. Significant incentives will be provided for firms in the border SEZs, including double tax deductions on some utilities for a ten-year period, access to cheap credit and the permission to use unskilled foreign labour from neighbouring Myanmar, Laos and Cambodia. Meanwhile, the EEC will benefit from transport infrastructure upgrades better linking it to the capital, Bangkok, and major port areas, in addition to a range of tax and regulatory incentives.
The promotion strategy will also introduce industrial developments based around the notion of "super-clusters". These will be collective industry hubs (for instance targeting automotive, electrical appliances, chemicals, digital, food production and medical industries). The BOI and the Ministry of Finance will provide tax and other incentives. These efforts will be undermined slightly, however, by the below-par prospects for private consumption, which are low by the standards of other countries at Thailand's income level.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
8.2 8.2 34 39 7 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Given Thailand's reliance on international trade, the government will retain a favourable foreign-trade regime, trying to accommodate the demands of influential domestic groups inclined towards protectionism while avoiding provoking any retaliation from major export markets. Most import duties for goods from other ASEAN member states have been lifted, following the formation of the AEC at end-2015. Thailand is also party to multilateral trade agreements concluded by the regional grouping, such as those in place with China and India, and a combined agreement with Australia and New Zealand. However, Thailand's existing trade deals allow signatories to exclude a number of sensitive sectors, while also keeping some non-tariff barriers in place. Thailand will continue to adhere to its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organisation. The country has accepted the obligations laid down in the IMF's Article VIII, which stipulates that transactions on the current account should be free of restrictions. Foreign investors do not face restrictions on the repatriation of profits and dividends and the central bank has eased restrictions on outward capital flows. The BOT would reimpose temporary capital controls only if excessive speculative capital flows were judged to be threatening macro-economic stability.
The AEC will remain a leading driver of trade liberalisation
Thailand, along with the other members of ASEAN, will continue to liberalise its trade regime in line with its commitment to implementing the AEC. Freer movement of goods, services, investment and skilled labour (in eight selected sectors) between the ten member states came into effect at end-2015. ASEAN initiatives are often beset by delays and the AEC is likely to be no exception. Still, the liberalisation envisaged under the AEC will, eventually, create new opportunities for Thai firms, as well as increase the threat of competition from foreign companies, particularly in labour-intensive industries.
Free-trade agreements (FTAs) signed by ASEAN with China and India, as well as a combined agreement with Australia and New Zealand, are gradually being phased in. The deal with India eliminated duties on many products in 2016 and talks are under way to include services. The FTA with Australia and New Zealand will be expanded to include 96% of all product types by 2020. Formal talks on a bilateral FTA between Thailand and the EU began in 2013, but were put on hold after the 2014 coup. European and Thai businesses are keen to conclude a deal, which would compensate in part for Thailand's loss of the EU's Generalised System of Preferences status in 2015. Negotiations will resume after a general election takes place, in 2019 at the earliest. As a result, a Thai-EU deal is unlikely to be concluded before the end of the forecast period.
The baht has experienced large swings in its value in recent years as loose monetary policy in the US, Japan and other major economies led to large speculative flows into Thailand in search of higher yields. A rebound in inflows in the first half of 2017, owing in part to lowered investor expectations of stimulatory measures in US and the strengthening external sector, has led to significant appreciation of the local currency against the US dollar. A correction in the form of a strong depreciation will occur in 2018. The BOT will not reintroduce capital controls to stem this decline in the baht:US dollar exchange rate, partly in preference for a weaker currency to aid exporters. However, intermittent intervention in the foreign-exchange market to curb extreme volatility will remain an option.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.9 7.9 12 10 6 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score in the taxes category remains unchanged at 7.9 in 2017-21. Yet trends elsewhere mean that its global ranking improves from 12th place in 2012-16 to tenth in 2017-21, and by one place, to fifth, in the regional ranking. Thailand's tax regime is relatively simple and changes have been made in recent years to lower the overall burden. Successive governments have aimed to minimise the load on households and firms and lowering taxes has been an important part of this strategy. As a result, its ranking in this area has improved over time (although a relatively low tax-GDP ratio is a fiscal concern in the medium to long term). The standard rate of corporate tax was gradually reduced from 30% in 2011 to 20% in 2013. The government did this with the aim of boosting the country's competitiveness as a destination for foreign investors and to mitigate the impact of higher minimum-wage levels. Tax incentives are also widely available, and on the whole Thailand's fiscal regime continues to provide fairly strong encouragement for new investment. The personal income tax regime is relatively favourable, with the top marginal rate standing at 35% for both Thai and foreign workers on annual earnings over Bt5m (US$145,000).
Tax rates will remain favourable for businesses
The junta repeatedly postponed a hike in the standard value-added tax (VAT) rate in 2014-16. The next government is likely to maintain the rate at 7% until late in the forecast period, when the authorities will look to consolidate the public finances after private consumption returns to a stronger footing. This decision will also be influenced by calls from international organisations such as the IMF to push the rate back up.
With increases to unpopular consumption taxes off the agenda in the earlier part of the forecast period, the military government will push for other tax reforms to raise revenue and expand the tax base. An inheritance tax was approved in July 2015 and a property tax on land and building assets will come into effect in 2018. The latter will levy tax on commercial land and buildings with a ceiling of 2%, but most applicable tax rates will be much lower than this. As such, the impact on business will be minor.
The government will continue to look for opportunities to provide tax sops in a bid to support consumption. These sops will range from allowing individuals to deduct income tax on purchases of selected consumer goods to income tax deductions for domestic hotel and travel expenses in particular tax years. Similarly, the government will support the real-estate market through subsidised loans and other targeted incentives, such as income tax deductions for first-time buyers in lower-income brackets, during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.0 7.4 21 22 7 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score for financing will improve in 2017-21, as the banking sector will be in better health. Moreover, a deterioration in the financing environments of neighbouring countries will result in Thailand's regional ranking for the category rising by one place to sixth, although an improvement in countries outside the region will see its global ranking slip by one place to 22nd. A slow-down in domestic credit growth in 2013-14 reflected weak demand rather than a tightening of lending conditions. Increased due diligence and prudential measures among banks helped in reducing the ratio of non-performing loans to total loans from the mid-2000s until 2013, from which time they have crept up again slightly. However, this situation is expected to reverse, if only moderately, in 2017-21. This will bolster the overall health of the banking sector.
The BOT and the finance ministry will continue to focus on strengthening the financial sector and increasing its competitiveness by implementing a Financial Sector Master Plan, which has already resulted in the consolidation of a number of small and large private- and state-owned financial institutions. Foreign investors enjoy good access to local capital markets.
Capital markets will remain deep and well regulated
The local bond market will continue to expand under the guidance of the BOT. Thailand's bond market remains small compared with its equity market. Government bonds dominate, accounting for about 80% of all bonds issued, but large and medium debt-laden companies are increasingly using the bond market to refinance their bank loans and offshore borrowings. Strengthening demand in this market will continue in the early part of the forecast period, as investors and institutions seek high-yields amid a lack of opportunities in the Stock Exchange of Thailand.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.6 6.5 34 42 8 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The deterioration in the global and regional rankings for the labour market reflects Thailand's waning competitiveness. The country is a labour-scarce economy and unemployment is low. Labour market conditions will, in general, remain adequate in terms of supporting the operations of foreign-invested enterprises, but weaknesses, especially rising wage costs and skill shortages, will persist. The country's advantages as a cost-efficient base for labour-intensive production are diminishing, amid increasing competition from neighbouring economies such as Cambodia and Vietnam. In addition to rising relative costs for low-skilled workers, general labour shortages are a growing problem. In terms of skilled labour, problems stem in large part from Thailand's underperforming education system, which ranks poorly both globally and regionally and has long focused on rote learning. Although educational reforms have been promised, little practical progress has been made and there are currently no plans for a major overhaul of the system. The ability of the labour force to meet the needs of businesses (in terms of specialist skills) is likely to remain subpar by global standards. Hiring foreign workers will continue to be relatively difficult and expensive, except for labour from other ASEAN countries in designated sectors. In terms of the potential for industrial unrest, Thailand is comparatively attractive as an operating location, as strikes are rare.
Thailand's competitiveness will remain at risk owing to high wages
From January 2017 the nationwide daily minimum-wage schedule was replaced by minimum wages per province, set at or above Bt300 (around US$9). However, there has been no indication that any province has chosen to raise it substantially above the minimum. Moreover, significant future increases in the minimum wage are unlikely because this would further damage Thailand's competitiveness vis-à-vis regional competitors. The low average rate of con-sumer price inflation expected in 2017-21 should also ease the upward pressure on wages.
Thailand is facing the social and economic consequences of a rapidly ageing society, including a steadily declining workforce as a share of the total population. During the forecast period it will introduce steps to mitigate this crisis. It has announced an increase in the retirement age of civil servants from 60 to 65 years, a measure that will invariably put pressure on private employers to follow suit. Accordingly, we expect the average retirement age in the private sector to increase in 2017-21, but this will do little to counter the problems posed by skills shortages on the overall labour market.
Local labour will continue to decline in Thailand, with the country becoming more reliant on migrant workers, mostly from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos and often officially unregistered, who typically fill low-skilled vacancies. The government is in the process of opening SEZs on the country's borders, designed in part to capitalise on the supply of low-cost migrant labour sourced from its neighbours. International concerns for potential human rights abuses in Thailand, especially in the fishing industry, will result in tighter regulation and enforcement of protective measures for migrant workers. Ongoing co-ordination with the Burmese government to register migrants and issue identity documents will help to improve the situation, and will expand access to a (legal) low-cost labour pool.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
5.8 6.6 62 55 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's infrastructure will improve moderately in the next five years. The military government has prioritised long-pending "megaprojects", but they will still face significant delays. Improvements to telecommunications services have also been slow. Although the availability of 4G is widespread, average speeds remain slow by regional comparison. Electricity supplies have risen, but the potential for shortages remains. In 2015 67% of the country's electricity was generated using natural gas, according to the latest figures from Thailand's Energy Policy and Planning Office, and over 20% of natural gas is imported, making the country vulnerable to fluctuations in global gas prices. With gas supplies in the Gulf of Thailand in decline, the government's energy plans prioritise diversification of energy sources, including development of renewable energy. The government's Power Development Plan 2015 proposes to more than double the capacity of alternative energy sources by 2036, primarily in solar and biomass, and to import additional hydropower from neighbouring nations.
The junta will focus public investment on infrastructure development
The government has had difficulty securing funding for its ambitious plans to develop infrastructure "megaprojects". Although the junta has moved a number of projects nearer to the construction phase, including the building of dual-track railways, highways and port expansions, the medium-term prospects for a high-speed train linking Thailand and China, via Laos, which was originally agreed in 2010, are still unclear. Funding to build a section of the line between the Thai capital and the north-eastern province of Nakhon Ratchasima was approved in mid-2016, but further sections are yet to be greenlighted. This rail project and others have been slow to progress owing to doubts over their commercial viability and wrangling over financing with Chinese and Japanese investors. Delays also partly reflect the government's efforts to take advantage of the ongoing competition for geopolitical influence between China and Japan-the Thai government has both been seeking the best deal and has taken a cautious approach to shifting its alliances amid China's growing economic clout and Japan's historical investment links. However, we expect significant progress on priority projects in 2017-21. This will in large part be owing to the junta's use of unilateral executive powers, via Section 44 of the interim constitution, to bypass regulatory and political obstacles. Priority projects include road and rail upgrades on the eastern seaboard to link with Bangkok and the expansion of the U-Tapao International Airport, 140 km south-east of the capital.
The state-run Airports of Thailand authority will upgrade the country's six major airports, at an estimated cost of Bt194bn (US$5.7bn). The bulk of the money is earmarked for the expansion of Bangkok's second international airport, Don Mueang International Airport. Expansion works got under way at Suvarnabhumi Airport in 2016, while expansion of the airports in Chiang Mai, Chiang Rai, Phuket and Hat Yai is currently not a priority. The total capacity of the six major airports will rise significantly, from the current 75m passengers per year, by the end of the forecast period. This will mainly be aimed at accommodating surging arrivals from East Asia, especially China.
Further modernisation of telecoms networks can be expected
Thailand's telecoms networks have been slow to adopt the latest technology, exposing inefficiencies in the regulatory environment. Auctions of 4G bandwidth were completed in 2017. The regulator expects the commercial launch of 5G bandwidth in 2020, although we believe that those auctions will be completed at a similarly slow pace. Moreover, the new bandwidth is likely to lag behind equivalent offerings in most other Asian countries in terms of speed, as with 4G, owing to shortfalls in service provider technology.
The Power Development Plan 2015 lays out clear targets for energy production, consumption and imports in the period to 2036. Overall objectives include reducing reliance on natural gas, increasing imports of electricity from Thailand's neighbours, and ramping up alternative energy production, especially solar and biomass. Nuclear power options are still on the table, but have been subject to delays owing to public opposition, especially following Japan's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear incident in 2011. Thailand will remain reliant on natural gas for electricity production in 2017-21.
Economic forecast: Policy trends

Thailand's military-controlled government has declared economic revival to be its priority and is pursuing policies aimed at boosting consumption and investment, including ramping up public spending on infrastructure. The administration is increasingly utilising Section 44 of the interim constitution, which allows it to pass legislation unilaterally in order to expedite the develop-ment of big-ticket projects. This approach will propel public investment and thereby support economic growth in 2017-21. Although this is positive in the short term, it sets a dangerous precedent in impeding the rights of the local business community and fair competition. It also risks fast-tracking projects at the expense of proper public scrutiny.
Demand-side stimulatory measures have played a prominent role in the junta's policy agenda, and the government is likely to continue to enact minor stimulatory measures over 2017, focused on small and medium-sized enterprises and smallholders in the agricultural sector, which are still struggling following a prolonged period of lacklustre external demand and inclement weather conditions. Nonetheless, the impetus for further such disbursements will lessen in 2018-21 compared with 2014-17 as the authorities seek to consolidate the public finances.

Budget balance -2.7 -2.5 -2.5 -2.6 -2.2 -2.0
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to run a marginally wider fiscal deficit on average in 2017-21 compared with 2012-16. This will be mainly owing to the raft of fiscal reforms aimed at stimulating demand in the forecast period, combined with public spending on infrastructure construction. For instance, higher thresholds for personal income tax and increases to deductible allowances came into effect in early 2017. Other new recurring expenditure, primarily aimed at boosting the junta's popularity, such as the extension of free state education for those aged 12-15 years, will also act as a drag on the budget balance in 2017-21.
This pressure will be offset partially by some revenue-raising measures such as new or increased excise charges on goods like diesel, cigarettes and alcohol. A new inheritance tax, which came into force in February 2016, and the pending reform of property taxes, which should take effect from 2018, will also boost revenue later in the forecast period-but only modestly, owing to the watering-down of original proposals to avoid public objections. In addition, there is a significant possibility that the value-added tax (VAT) rate, currently set at 7%, will be raised slightly later in the forecast period. Although the government will be increasingly eager to expand the revenue base, this reform will be stalled by greater economic uncertainty in the middle of the forecast period as private consumption growth slows. Overall, we expect the fiscal deficit to average the equivalent of 2.4% of GDP in 2017-21, up from an average of 2.2% in 2012-16.

We expect the Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) to remain accom-modative, maintaining its policy rate, the one-day repurchase rate, at 1.5% until 2020. This forecast is based partly on the expectation that consumer price inflation will strengthen only modestly in 2017, averaging 0.8% for the year as a whole, below the BOT's target range of 1-4%. The BOT's modest expectations for the economy in 2017, heavily influenced by global uncertainties, will persist in the middle of the forecast period, as economic growth in China slows sharply in 2018 and the US economy experiences a cyclical downturn the year after. As such, the BOT will not feel confident in raising rates until 2020, when inflation accelerates again amid stronger conditions for domestic and external demand.

Real GDP will maintain a growth rate of 3.3% in 2017, the same as in 2016, as public-investment drives are expanded but import growth accelerates at a faster rate than exports. External demand will dip in 2018-19, tempering headline GDP growth in those years. We expect real GDP growth to average 3% a year in 2017-21, down from 3.4% in 2012-16.

Private consumption growth, which accounts for a significant share of GDP, will be supported in part by the still-strong tourism sector. However, we expect it to record a pronounced dip in the middle of the forecast period as weakening external demand in 2018-19 undermines domestic economic activity. It will pick up again after the economy sees a broader, sustained recovery in 2020-21.
We expect a modest recovery in external demand in 2017, after a pronounced dip in 2015-16. This will be heavily supported by rising demand from Asia. Growth in exports will then ease again in 2018-19 owing to a steep slowdown in growth in China in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019. However, this will be softened somewhat by the underlying trends of rising demand from Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states and the still-expanding tourism sector. These will also aid the economic rebound expected in 2020-21.
From the tepid levels seen in 2016, private domestic and foreign investment will stay firm in 2017-18 as business confidence grows on the back of optimism for the ASEAN region and the accelerating momentum of Thailand's public infrastructure investment drive. Overall investment will be weighed down by lower external demand in 2019, but burgeoning prospects in surrounding ASEAN countries will hasten the return of more robust investment growth in 2020-21. This uneven outlook notwithstanding, the government's public-investment drive will lend substantial support to total fixed investment in 2017-21. As a result, gross fixed investment will grow by an average of 3% a year in the forecast period, compared with 2.9% in 2012-16.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
On the supply side of the economy, we expect the industrial sector to grow the fastest, at an average annual rate of 4.2% in 2017-21. Thailand has been successful in taking the lead in certain industrial sectors relative to its neighbours, such as the automotive industry, in addition to some high-technology subsectors, most notably electronics and machinery components. However, its technical capabilities and competitiveness are slowly declining owing to a lack of investment in the sector. The industrial sector grew by a lacklustre 2.1% in 2016 as other regional manufacturing bases continued to rise in competitiveness and global demand dipped. Industrial growth will recover in 2017-21 amid increased public investment in infrastructure and a more stable and business-friendly policy environment. Stronger external demand in the early and latter parts of the forecast period will buoy investment sentiment in the largely export-oriented sector. Over the longer term, Thailand risks losing its role as a predominant producer of intermediate manufactured goods to fast-growing countries in the region that have cheaper labour.
The services sector will grow by an annual average of 2.6% in 2017-21. Despite a slowdown in growth in the sector in 2014, resulting from the coup in that year, growth averaged 4.8% a year in 2012-16 amid surging tourist arrivals from the wider Asian region, especially China. In the forecast period the growth rate will normalise somewhat owing in part to slowing growth in tourism expenditure. Nonetheless, the retail sector-the largest component of services-will continue to expand over the forecast period, albeit at a slower rate. In addition, the financial sector remains relatively healthy. The ratio of non-performing loans to total loans has risen slightly since 2014, but it still remains far below the levels seen prior to the 2008-09 financial crisis and banks are well capitalised. Growth in household debt slowed in 2015-16, although the already-elevated levels of debt here will crimp demand and dampen the expansion of the sector as a whole in 2017-21. The telecommunications segment will see strong growth with the development of 4G networks under licences awarded in 2016, which will allow firms to meet surging demand for mobile internet services. This will dovetail with the expansion of e-commerce platforms in the country.

The agricultural sector will remain vulnerable to extreme weather cycles, including droughts and floods. Productivity is also likely to suffer as tentative efforts to reform the sector are repeatedly set back by inclement weather events, which will also mean that producers are largely unable to upgrade from current basic technologies. Some subsectors, such as fishing, will struggle early in the forecast period as the industry adapts to the market-access requirements of Western countries regarding labour rights and the government clamps down on unregistered migrant labour. We expect the agricultural sector to grow by an annual average of 2.5% in 2017-21.

In 2017 a modest recovery in global commodity prices and firming domestic demand will lead to a gradual increase in inflationary pressures, resulting in consumer prices rising by an average of 0.8%, up from 0.2% in 2016. Despite a weakening exchange rate in 2018-19, inflationary pressures will remain subdued owing to stagnation in commodity prices and sluggish consumer demand. Stabilising domestic and external demand in the latter part of the forecast period will push consumer price inflation to an annual average of 1.7% by 2021.

The baht has strengthened considerably against the US dollar since the beginning of 2017. In part, this reflects investors' increasing confidence in Thailand and emerging-market Asian economies in general, particularly vis-à-vis the US, where uncertainty over government policy persists. However, like many emerging-market Asian currencies, we expect the baht to be affected by the steep slowdown in China's economy and associated instability in financial markets in 2018. In nominal terms, the baht will weaken by 2.2% a year on average against the US dollar over 2018-19. The latter part of the forecast period will see a restoration in the currency's value as macroeconomic fundamentals strengthen, with the baht appreciating by an annual average of 1.2% in 2020-21.

Since 2014 Thailand has enjoyed a substantial current-account surplus, primarily owing to weaker global commodity prices that led to weakness in imports. The current-account surplus rose to the equivalent of 11.7% of GDP. In 2017-19 the surplus will narrow from 11.9% of GDP to 10%, owing partly to stronger import growth in 2017 and weaker export demand in 2018-19, following a significant slowdown in China and a technical recession in the US. A slightly higher surplus will be seen in 2020-21 when external demand firms again. The surplus on the services account will continue to rise, owing to the robust tourism sector. However, we expect increasing competition from the rest of the region to temper growth in tourist arrivals, after strong gains in 2014-16. The primary income account will remain in deficit in 2017-21, reflecting the continued repatriation of profits and dividends by foreign-owned firms. However, this will be partly offset by the effect on the secondary income account of personal transfers, notably remittances.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Thailand
Stocks and flows
Net foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows (including earnings reinvested by companies already operating in Thailand) were volatile in 2012-16 owing to natural disasters and political instability that was disruptive for the business environment. Net flows struggled throughout 2012-15, registering a marginally positive annual average of US$1.4bn in that period, owing in part to political instability from 2014. In 2016 net FDI flows turned sharply negative, averaging US$12.6bn, owing in part to the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej as well low investor confidence in the Thai economy. In 2016 the stock of inward FDI stood at US$193.5bn, equivalent to 47.5% of GDP.
Origin and distribution
The privately owned manufacturing sector attracts the largest proportion of FDI inflows into Thailand. In particular, manufacturers of automotive parts and producers of electronics and electrical appliances have attracted significant foreign interest in recent years. The financial and real-estate sectors have also gained prominence. Historically, Japanese firms have been the main investors in Thailand. In 2016 the value of approved Japanese investment projects accounted for 57.2% of the total value of approved wholly owned foreign investment, according to the Board of Investment (BOI, a government agency). Investment from China has also greatly increased in the past few years. Chinese investors, even more so than their Japanese counterparts, are likely to gain from Thailand's infrastructure development plans, but these will essentially come in the form of services contracts in construction and logistics planning.
Determinants
Thailand has traditionally been an attractive investment destination, owing to its relatively competitive labour costs, flexible labour laws and advantageous location within the region. However, some of these advantages have been fading amid sporadic political uncertainty and increasing competition from later-developing regional neighbours. Incentives offered by the BOI generally take the form of exemptions from corporate income tax and reduced taxes on imported machinery. The BOI also offers non-tax incentives, including granting permission to bring in foreign workers, own land and take or remit foreign currency abroad. Thailand has generally been regarded as open to foreign investment. Although regulatory uncertainties do exist, the government has actively tried to address these quickly. Indeed, the large-scale Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) special economic zone, first proposed in 2016, includes fast-tracked environmental assessments as an incentive. The EEC fits within the BOI's seven-year investment promotion strategy launched in February 2015 that extended incentives to newer industries such as "alternative energy and environmental services" and "hospitality and wellness", while removing existing incentives in certain low-value, labour-intensive industries. The BOI has also been encouraging investment into infrastructure, through a small number of "big-ticket" projects. Although a backlog of proposals accumulated in the period leading up to the 2014 coup, the BOI subsequently expedited the investment application and approval process, and will continue to do so in an effort to stimulate economic activity prior to the next elections.
Impact
Inflows of FDI have been volatile over the past decade. The ratio of FDI inflows to GDP fell to 1.8% in 2009 owing to the global economic crisis. Following this, FDI inflows fluctuated in 2010-16 amid flood damage and repeated bouts of political uncertainty. Large FDI inflows have helped to support overall economic growth and have contributed to Thailand's development as a leading exporter to other countries in Asia in a number of sectors, including vehicles (particularly light pickup trucks), electronics (notably hard-disk drives) and electrical appliances.
Potential
Following the public approval of the junta-drafted constitution at a referendum in 2016 and the smooth accession of the new king, Thailand's political scene has gained a foothold of political stability. Challenges to the new political structure and next government are unlikely to materialise before late in the forecast period at the earliest, which bodes well for steadier FDI flows in the forecast period compared with 2012-16. However, a number of other challenges may limit the potential for strong growth in FDI in the next five years. Thailand's attractiveness as a location for investment has been diminishing owing to a rising relative cost base (particularly for labour) and sluggish domestic demand outside the tourism sector. Although the current administration is keen to show a commitment to liberalisation, mainly through the legally binding 20-year National Strategy, access to important sectors such as telecommunications and utilities in the medium term remains in question. Although the standard of infrastructure in the country has improved in recent years, it remains poorer than that in Malaysia, a rival manufacturing location. However, the junta is demonstrating renewed vigour in this regard with an ambitious infrastructure development programme. Although Thailand will continue to attract foreign investment by virtue of its leading position in the development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free-Trade Area, there is a risk that it may lose out to other countries in the region as they make improvements to their business environments at a faster rate.

Thailand constitutes a sizeable market in its own right, with a population of 69m and nominal GDP equivalent to around US$407.2bn at market exchange rates in 2016. Moreover, the development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free-Trade Area means that firms located in Thailand will continue to enjoy almost entirely duty-free access to ASEAN's population of 500m, including a burgeoning middle class with growing disposable incomes.
The retail sector will benefit from the strong tourism industry
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that aggregate personal disposable income will grow at a slightly slower rate in 2017-21 than it did in 2012-16, but at a more consistent pace owing to a generally more stable political environment. Even so, the very large tourism sector will lend support to the retail sector. The latter will expand by 1.6% a year on average in 2017-21.
National wealth distribution remains alarmingly disparate between the regions, according to the latest data from the Asian Development Bank. Of the 10.5% of the population defined as living in poverty (in 2015, living on US$1.90 or less per day at purchasing power parity), the majority reside in the rural north and north-eastern parts of the country. The capital, Bangkok, remains the wealthiest region by far: personal disposable incomes there are double the national average. Measures to narrow the wealth gap undertaken by governments have tended to be short term in nature and unsustainable. Thus, market oppor-tunities in the rural areas remain limited compared with urban centres.
A fairly small proportion of personal disposable income in Thailand is spent on accommodation, leaving a greater share available for spending on consumer goods. Demand for consumer goods is therefore high compared with that in many other countries in Asia. As the level of household debt subsides, the release of pent-up demand will boost retail sales towards the end of the forecast period. Nevertheless, debt burdens among those on lower incomes will put a dampener on overall consumer sentiment, and could limit the prospects for social mobility among this group.

Private consumption will grow by an annual average of 2.7% in 2017-21, slightly weaker than the rate of 2.8% in 2012-16. The next government will maintain policies aimed at supporting consumption through various subsidies and other support packages aimed at helping low-income citizens and occasional short-term measures to stimulate spending by higher-income groups. Given the still-frail state of private consumption, the value-added tax (VAT) rate is unlikely to be raised from the current level of 7% until later in the forecast period, despite previous discussion on doing so. The government will instead focusing on wealth taxes, such as the new inheritance and property taxes, which will avoid burdening lower-income households, although certain "sin taxes" on alcohol and tobacco will still have a minor impact on the population at large.
Expenditure on healthcare and leisure will rise as the population ages
Consumer expenditure on essential items, such as food, household goods and clothing, will fall slightly as a proportion of total expenditure as average incomes rise. The average individual outlay on hotels and restaurants is likely to increase as a result of several trends: a rise in the number of women who work (leading to a fall in the number of meals cooked at home); government efforts to promote domestic tourism; and cheaper domestic travel owing to the expansion of budget airlines and rail routes. Expenditure on leisure and education, which generally rises as economies become more developed, is not expected to grow significantly, as average incomes will remain relatively low. Growth in healthcare spending is forecast to moderate, owing to relatively comprehensive free state healthcare, which we do not expect to be rescinded in 2017-21. We expect healthcare spending in local-currency terms to rise by 4.8% a year on average in 2017-21, down from 7.4% in 2012-16. The projected increase in spending on transport and communications will largely reflect the expanding market for information technology products, which will be boosted by national upgrades to internet services.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: The past decade has been characterised by political turmoil in Thailand, with two coups between 2006 and 2014 and many (sometimes violent) anti-government protests and rallies. Economic growth has been volatile in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis owing to natural disasters and political crisis. Although the military-led government that ousted the populist administration of Yingluck Shinawatra in May 2014 has made economic recovery a priority, growth has remained relatively sedate. Political instability caused many reforms and development works to be neglected and interrupted. Physical infrastructure remains inadequate in many respects and under increasing strain, with little progress on this front in recent years. Reform of the education system, which is sorely needed, has long been promised, but successive governments have largely failed to modernise the curriculum. As a consequence, the workforce is characterised by a low level of technical skills.
Thailand will become increasingly more dependent on migrant workers
Demographic trends: Thailand's population will age over the long-term forecast period. Slower population growth and longer life expectancies will account for the demographic shift. The female labour force participation rate, which was strong in the early 2000s, is expected to rise only modestly in the 2030s and 2040s. This will lead to an average annual contraction of 1% in the labour force in 2031-50. Nevertheless, a gradual loosening of regulation con-cerning immigrants' right to work will preclude a steeper fall in the size of the workforce. Successive governments are likely to be forced to ease immigration policies further owing to the country's negative demographic profile.
External conditions: Thailand faces a challenging external environment in the period to 2050. Although many export-oriented, labour-intensive industries will shift away from China, Thailand will struggle to capitalise on this opportunity owing to a lack of competitiveness compared with lower-cost locations, such as Cambodia, Vietnam and Bangladesh. New regional rivals will also gain ground, including Laos and Myanmar. Closer integration with China could open up market opportunities for Thai businesses in more niche subsectors. One possibility is that Thailand may develop itself as a services centre for China, meeting that country's increasing demand for foreign holidays, regional-specific agricultural goods and other niche products. There already signs that this is under way in the tourism sector with the Tourism Authority of Thailand spearheading a move towards the luxury end of the Chinese market. However, Thailand still has a long way to go before it is in a position to welcome large numbers of high-end visitors-the ongoing expansion of transport infrastructure will go some way to addressing this. Similarly, economic and trade links will be strengthened by the development of overland transport routes between China and Thailand in the next decade or so. The development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Economic Community, formally established in 2015, will motivate business and technical innovation in Thailand such that it retains its prominence in the region.
The challenges to democracy will be addressed gradually
Institutions and policy trends: The power struggle between the established military and bureaucratic elites in the capital, Bangkok, who will continue to side with the palace to bolster their legitimacy, and the rural masses that form the majority of the Thai electorate may ease in the decades ahead. However, this will be conditional on successive governments finding a path to restruc-turing the agricultural economy, including moving a far greater proportion of the workforce into industry and services. Democratically elected governments might be successful in instigating such a shift with the introduction of appropriate electoral reforms as well as a focus on medium- to long-term rural development policies, rather than just short-term relief measures.
Long-term performance: The long-term outlook for Thailand's economy is heavily dependent on whether the next military-dominated government is able to sustain the political authority required to initiate appropriate structural reform that will continue into the medium to long term, in addition to upgrading infrastructure. Implementing comprehensive liberalisation in a number of important sectors, such as power and communications, will help Thailand to regain some of its competiveness relative to its regional neighbours. The effects of an ageing population could be offset by improving educational attainment on the part of the existing workforce or by measures to facilitate greater immigrant access to the labour market. However, progress is likely to be slow in both areas.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Domestic data
GDP growth: Bank of Thailand, Annual Report; Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS
Population: Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators; UN, World Development Report
GDP per head: nominal GDP divided by population
Inflation: consumer price index, Department of Business Economics, Ministry of Commerce
Budget: fiscal year (October-September)
Wages: local-currency wage data derived from minimum-wage data, inflated to correspond with occasional UNIDO data for US dollar manufacturing-sector wages
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime rate: Bank of Thailand, Quarterly Bulletin
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; OECD, External Debt Statistics (for data on short-term debt)
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
UNIDO: UN Industrial Development Organisation
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Although the regime of the president, Nicolás Maduro, will strengthen its grip on power following the installation of a Constituent Assembly, we do not expect Mr Maduro to remain in power beyond 2019. The most likely scenarios for a transition to an opposition-led government are through ad hoc elections after economic collapse (probably as foreign-exchange shortages culminate in debt default) or a military coup. There is a risk that the regime will cling on to power as either Chinese or Russian finance helps the sovereign to avoid debt default, or should Mr Maduro be replaced by another PSUV official to appease critics.
Inflation is likely to exceed 1,000% by 2018. The risk of hyperinflation will rise as the government increasingly prints money for spending. After an estimated recession of 14% in 2016, GDP is forecast to contract by a further 9% in 2017 and 6% in 2018. High inflation has led to a collapse in private consump-tion and difficult operating conditions have hurt investment. We forecast a weak recovery beginning only in 2020, by which time the current opposition is expected to be in government, leading to a combination of macroeconomic adjustments, and institutional and structural reforms.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the PSUV on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and triple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and the increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices and the economy will not return to growth until 2020. Our forecast for a weak recovery in 2020-21 rests on the assumption of a new government that implements macroeconomic adjustment alongside institutional and structural reform. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production in 2017, and only a minor increase from 2018 as economic conditions stabilise.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 79th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2017-21, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela moves ahead of Cuba to 11th place of the 12 countries covered, assuming improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Government's low approval ratings reduce the risk of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.
