Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature. In August 2017 the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) installed a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government and a remit to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$7bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. The current-account deficit is estimated to have fallen from 4.3% of GDP in 2015 to 1.8% of GDP in 2016.

Netherlands Antilles 7.9 Colombia 5.0
Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Political and social tension will remain high following a controversial vote on July 30th organised by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), to establish a Constituent Assembly with powers over all branches of government-including the opposition-controlled National Assembly-and a remit to write a new constitution. Although The Economist Intelligence Unit is maintaining its forecast for a change of government midway through the 2017-21 forecast period, we no longer believe that this is likely to happen via elections scheduled for December 2018, which the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) would be well-placed to win, given the govern-ment's unpopularity amid a growing economic and humanitarian crisis. Mr Maduro seems little concerned about the ever more damning criticism from the international community, with even the veiled threat of US economic sanctions proving no deterrent to the president's plans to consolidate power through increasingly authoritarian ways.
We now no longer believe that Mr Maduro will feel pressured into holding an election that he risks losing as scheduled in December 2018. But nor do we expect that he will manage to cling to power for the entire 2017-21 forecast period, on the basis that economic conditions seem set to deteriorate further, producing unsustainable pressure for a change of government. International oil prices are not expected to rise to such a level to provide the foreign-exchange proceeds needed to ease chronic consumer goods shortages (Venezuela depends heavily on imports) and allow the government to meet external debt obligations falling due over the next 12-15 months. We therefore believe that a transition involving the opposition is likely in the medium term.
Given the highly volatile political situation, accurately forecasting when and how a transition of power will occur is challenging. We believe that there are two main ways in which a transition of power might come about. The most likely scenario involves Mr Maduro muddling through for the remainder of 2017 and much of 2018, running down reserves to meet external debt repayments, but ultimately being unable to avoid a debt default, perhaps in the context of the imposition of sanctions by the US on Venezuela oil imports. This would be likely to bring about Mr Maduro's downfall, as his allies in government and the military would be hit financially, and remaining popular support from his constituents (chiefly the poor and public-sector workers) would fade owing to heightened economic hardship as hand-outs dry up. This would lead to a transition to a government led by the opposition.
Another potential transition scenario involves a military coup in late 2017 or 2018, triggered by dissent among the ranks of the armed forces. Although successive PSUV governments have given increasing power to the generals and trained lower-ranking soldiers ideologically so as to cultivate pro-PSUV sentiment, unease among other stakeholders in the armed forces appears to be growing, judging by sporadic episodes of rebellion in recent months. Under both transition scenarios we would expect free and fair elections to be held.
Although it is not our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is a high risk that the PSUV will cling on to power. If, for example, Russia or China were to provide sufficient financial assistance to allow Venezuela to avoid default and boost oil output, or if oil prices were to rise significantly beyond our expectations, there is a possibility that the government would manage to withstand political pressure for elections and regime change. In another possible scenario, Mr Maduro could leave office but be replaced by another high-ranking PSUV official in an attempt to appease critics. However, no likely successor to Mr Maduro would appease opposition demands for elections and political transition, and tension would remain high.
One challenge for the opposition will be to maintain the momentum of protests that began in April (over 120 people have died so far, mostly at the hands of the security forces), in order to try to achieve its objectives. The scale of protests is likely to wax and wane in response to government measures to stifle democratic procedures and those that are likely to persist will be from the more violent and hardline "resistencia".
Regardless when and how political transition occurs, the second half of our forecast period is likely to remain volatile and uncertain. The broad, diverse opposition coalition will have to contend with huge economic distortions and deep political differences that would test even a unified political party. Although we expect significant financial support from multilateral lending agencies, the risk of renewed political volatility will remain high, even under an opposition government.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
In both our transition scenarios we assume that elections will eventually be held and will be free and fair, ushering the MUD-led opposition into power. That said, and as part of its efforts to cling to power in the meantime, we expect that the Maduro regime and the Constituent Assembly will push back the schedule for the next presidential election, which is due in December 2018.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Following the installation of the Constituent Assembly, Venezuela has become much more isolated diplomatically and is coming under increasing regional and international pressure. To date this has done little to weaken the government's grip on power, but the growing threat of US sanctions could prove significant. The US president, Donald Trump, has threatened strong but unspecified economic measures against Venezuela. This probably would entail firstly a cut in US exports of distillates that Venezuela needs for its oil exports, lifting costs and hence reducing foreign-exchange proceeds, before ultimately cutting US purchases of Venezuelan oil, a move that would cripple the economy. Mr Trump recently suggested that he does not rule out unspecified military actions, although at this stage we assume that this is bluster. Mercosur, a regional bloc comprised of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay, has suspended Venezuela indefinitely owing to "violations to the constitutional order", and a group of major countries in the region have denounced the regime and say that they will not recognise laws passed by the new Constituent Assembly. The Vatican, which has in the past tried to mediate between the government and opposition, has also criticised the Constituent Assembly.
A return to negotiations, brokered perhaps by Cuba (its closest ally) and Colombia (its neighbour), could potentially provide a path to fresh elections and a political transition, but huge obstacles remain. Another key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with China (a key creditor) and Russia, whose state oil company, Rosneft, is active in Venezuela. It is possible that Russia will help Venezuela to muddle through for longer by providing much-needed external financing in exchange for lucrative oil contracts for Rosneft. Reflecting its external financing difficulties, Venezuela will continue to scale back-or possibly end-oil shipments to beneficiaries of PetroCaribe, an agreement providing cheap financing for oil exports to regional allies.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
It is unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without significant policy adjustments. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017-18 than it has done so far. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or technically incapable of adjusting policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy intervention-ism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA, the state-oil company. However, given the extremely thin reserves cushion (less than $10bn in August), we have now factored into our forecasts the likelihood of a debt default in 2018, which would have dramatic consequences in the form of lower oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and political turmoil.
In our baseline scenario, we expect the opposition to hold power by 2019, ushering in much-needed, market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of over US$16bn in 2019-21. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.5% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. A transition to a new government should help to ease the deficit to 4.2% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply (M2) rose by nearly 340% year on year in July, the highest rate on record. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability. There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. Our forecasts now assume that Venezuela will default on its external debt at some stage in 2018. This will be followed by a restructuring process with external creditors under an MUD-led opposition government.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. Our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government in 2019 also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that we project further contractions in real GDP in 2017-19. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a decline in real GDP of nearly 30% in 2014-19.
After dropping by over 20% in 2016, private consumption will continue to contract in 2017-18, reflecting the effect of soaring inflation on real wages, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in invest-ment in 2019-21 assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from recession. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep reces-sion. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation of 26% in July, bringing accumu-lated inflation for January---July to 249%. Assuming that price pressures remain high, we expect average inflation to exceed 850% in 2017 and reach 1,220% by the end of 2018 (this is an upwards revision of the forecast included in our previous monthly report for Venezuela). However, we continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, reflecting moderately higher oil prices, which will bring in the necessary foreign exchange to help to alleviate scarcity of goods, and the effect of persistent recession on demand. From 2019 fiscal and monetary policy adjustment will also be supportive of a gradual reduction in inflation towards double-digit levels (in year-on-year terms). However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2017-18, but the exchange rate will still be extremely overvalued. The dual exchange-rate system is composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom. On August 11th, at the twelfth auction since the government revamped the Dicom system in May, the BCV sold US$24.2m at BsF2,970:US$1, implying an annual 76% devaluation of the Dicom rate. However, the Dicom accounts for only 10% of all official transactions. In real terms, the average exchange rate (weighted by volume of transactions) has continued to appreciate, creating ever greater pressure for currency adjustment, the need for which is evident in the black-market rate; this was over BsF14,000:US$1 in mid-August.
The pegged Dipro rate appears increasingly unsustainable, and we assume that the government will devalue the rate later this year and again in 2018. We also expect the government to increase the share of Dicom in foreign-currency transactions-in effect a maxi-devaluation. We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued decline in oil output. A sharp fall in oil output in 2019 will lift the current-account deficit. In 2020-21 a recovery in oil output will help to offset a rise in imports after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021 reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP leader. An early election will be held on October 15th.
The popularity of the ÖVP new leader, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, means that the election has become a three-horse race between the SPÖ, the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) and the ÖVP, which will be rebranded on the ballot as the "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party". The most likely coalition to emerge is one that is led by the ÖVP and includes the FPÖ, although negotiations to form one could be fraught.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government would not lead to similar EU sanctions as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects any new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, low government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2017-21), as the fiscal consolidation process is likely to be restrained by limited government cohesion and effectiveness. The public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.6% in 2016 and 1.9% year on year in the first quarter of 2017. We forecast continued catch-up growth this year, at 2%, and that growth will moderate to 1.5% on average in 2018-21.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-21, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 1% in 2016, up from 0.8% in 2015, and we forecast an annual average of 2% in 2017-21.
In 2016 the current-account surplus decreased slightly, to 1.7% of GDP. We forecast that it will average about 2% in the coming years as a weakening trade balance is offset by strong tourism receipts.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21). As a result, the country remains in 12th place in the regional ranking but loses two places in the global ranking, dropping to 21st. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress likely to be limited.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. Little progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between the EU and the UK.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to the tax system, owing in part to a likely deterioration in government effectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely assuming a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power in 2017. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election will be held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.8bn and the goods import bill was US$143bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.3bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Following several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. The popular 30-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, has taken over the leadership of the ÖVP and will run as the party's lead candidate in the early general election on October 15th. However, probably owing to the party's recent poor performance in the polls (it has languished in third place over the past year) Mr Kurz decided to leverage his own popularity by demanding full control over the ÖVP and that the party appear on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party", which would also include a number of people not previously associated with the ÖVP. Following Mr Kurz's arrival as party leader the ÖVP shot to the top of the polls, pushing the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) to third place, from first. This "Kurz effect" could wane slightly in the coming months, as Mr Kurz has been forced to continue working in the dysfunctional coalition, will face increasing scrutiny of his policies and will need time to build new structures to lead a reformed ÖVP. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the election to be a three-horse race between the ÖVP, the SPÖ and the FPÖ, although we expect the ÖVP to be best placed to emerge as the largest party in the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house of parliament).
Nevertheless, the election will be a further step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP will have been replaced to a large extent by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the break-down of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz looks to be drawing voters away from the FPÖ, in large part based on his strong stance on immigration and border control.
The most likely coalition to emerge after the election is one led by the ÖVP, with the FPÖ as a junior coalition partner, as the other parties-including the Greens and NEOS, a liberal party-are unlikely to be large enough to help either the SPÖ or the ÖVP to reach a parliamentary majority. Risks to this outlook are high, as the election could turn and coalition negotiations could falter, because the FPÖ will probably demand significant concessions from Mr Kurz. Regard-less of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further. The government will struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, and the FPÖ is likely to struggle to translate its opposition on matters such as immigration and inte-gration into concrete policy proposals. As a result, we expect little progress on significant structural reforms and the risk of an early election in the next parliamentary term to be high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for October 15th 2017. The most likely scenario is that the rebranded ÖVP under Mr Kurz will win the largest share of the vote, although not an outright majority, and subsequently form a coalition with the FPÖ.
Elections for some state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the strong position of the FPÖ. All three of the large parties have hinted that they want to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
We expect a new government to continue along the same line. Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the election in 1999 led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should the party join the next governing coalition. Although at that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was a relatively unusual development, since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in parliament in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Norbert Hofer, the FPÖ candidate-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU did not reform or if Turkey joined. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term, in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, we expect little progress, as both parties will be focused on the election and, in the case of the ÖVP, on reforming the party itself.
The next government, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right and is likely to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.4% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1.1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.6%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2017-21), albeit safely within the EU mandated limit of 3% of GDP, as fiscal con-solidation will continue to be limited and growth solid, though unspectacular. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 84.6% in 2016, following a positive contribution from the Heta deal, to 75.9% in 2021. In the context of the quanti-tative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and a EUR60bn per month QE programme, which will run until the end of 2017. However, the economic recovery in the euro zone has maintained momentum-supported by an acceleration in credit growth-and looks to be more broad-based. We expect another healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 1.9%, after growth of 1.9% on average in 2015-16. Although commentary from the ECB's president, Mario Draghi, was cautious in tone following the policy meeting in July, Mr Draghi revealed that the bank's policy-setting governing council would be discussing the future of the QE programme in the autumn of this year. We maintain our view that the bank will begin gradually to wind down, or "taper", the programme in 2018. Nevertheless, underlying price pressure remains relatively subdued, and downside risks to wage growth and the global economy during that year could yet slow the pace at which the ECB reduces its monthly asset purchases. We forecast that the ECB will not raise policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany; this was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.6%, remained below Germany's 1.8% growth.
However, the economy has recently started to gain momentum again, with average quarterly growth of 0.6% between July 2016 and March 2017. Although the labour market had in previous years struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, when the unemployment rate started to fall. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 2% this year, and the upturn in growth throughout the region is supporting export growth, with exports to other EU economies up by 11.5% year on year in the first quarter. As a result, we expect real GDP growth to accelerate to an upwardly revised 2% this year, broadly in line with that of regional peers.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, when we forecast that the economy will expand by 1.7%. A worsening global economic environment in 2018-19, when we expect a policy-driven slowdown in China and a cyclical slowdown in the US, will weigh on growth in the second half of our forecast period, as will the continued lack of reform progress. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.4% in 2019-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone in both years. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 2%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has continued and political risk has waned. More recently, a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB has prompted a sharp appreciation in the euro against the dollar. Although the value of the euro may yet come under pressure from political risk-especially in relation to the election in Italy, which we expect to take place in early 2018-and monetary tightening in the US, we have revised up our forecast for the exchange rate, to US$1.12:EUR1 on average in 2017-18, from US$1.08:EUR1 previously. The euro derives structural support from a large current-account surplus, and we expect it to appreciate further in the final years of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and moved the trade balance back into a small deficit in 2016. We expect growth in domestic demand and a slight rise in oil prices to weigh on the trade balance in the coming years. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in our forecast period, of about 2%.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The struggle between an opposition-dominated legislature and a government with control of key institutions will keep tension high and sustain uncertainty regarding The Economist Intelligence Unit's political and economic forecasts. Despite the unpopularity of the administration led by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), and economic woes, we believe that the government will muddle through until the next elections are held in December 2018, after which we expect the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática coalition to take office. A risk exists that the PSUV will seek non-democratic ways to cling to power.
A fundamental rebalancing of the economy is needed to avoid default and economic collapse, but there has been no sign of significant economic reform. Policy mismanagement will persist while Mr Maduro remains in office. Key problems include extremely expansionary macroeconomic policy, soaring inflation and a business climate that discourages investment. A new government will begin a gradual process of adjustment from 2019.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the PSUV on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and triple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and the increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite a partial recovery in oil prices and the economy will not return to growth until 2020. Our forecast for a weak recovery in 2020-21 rests on the assumption of a new government that implements macroeconomic adjustment alongside institutional and structural reform. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, reinforcing our forecasts of only a weak recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production in 2017, and only a minor increase from 2018 as economic conditions stabilise.

Venezuela is in 79th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2017-21, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela moves ahead of Cuba to 11th place out of the 12 countries covered, assuming improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Government's low approval ratings reduce the risk of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature, but its powers have been usurped by other branches of government dominated by the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). In May Mr Maduro announced that he wanted to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$5.8bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. The current-account deficit is estimated to have fallen from 4.3% of GDP in 2015 to 2.1% of GDP in 2016.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
As the most severe economic crisis in the country's history continues, political uncertainty will remain extremely high in the context of huge social unrest. Since April the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has been organising demonstrations against attempts by the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) government to increase its grip on power through non-democratic means. In May the president, Nicolás Maduro, announced rules, heavily skewed in the regime's favour, for the selection of members to a constituent assembly charged with rewriting the constitution promulgated by his predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). The selection is due to take place on July 30th. Constitutional reform proposals seem designed to not only reduce the role of the elected National Assembly and to severely crimp the opposition's ability to compete in national elections due to be held in December 2018, but also possibly postpone the elections, perhaps indefinitely. The MUD won control of the National Assembly at the December 2015 elections, but the government has since effectively eliminated the National Assembly's legislative powers by circumventing the body via the PSUV-controlled Supreme Court.
The violent public protests that began in April have led to the deaths of nearly 100 civilians; these demonstrations show little sign of letting up, but, equally, seem to have done little in terms of weakening the Maduro government's hold on power. However, recent developments, including growing international uneasiness with events in Venezuela, may have put Mr Maduro on the back foot. A key opposition leader, Leopoldo López, was recently moved to house arrest after being controversially imprisoned on charges of public incitement to violence in 2014, and the opposition successfully organised an unofficial plebiscite on July 16th in which over 7.5m people voted, most against the government's efforts to redraft the constitution. The PSUV's grip on authority is largely based on the continuing support of the military, which will play a decisive role in future political developments. The govern-ment has, to date, secured military backing by eliminating dissent in its upper echelons and by including the military in a system of patronage that has given it significant policymaking powers. It is not certain to what extent the military would be willing to support the government if it were to attempt to hold onto power by non-democratic means.
The opposition is working to encourage defectors from within government and military ranks. It is possible that it may offer immunity from prosecution as an enticement to switch sides. On this basis, The Economist Intelligence Unit still bases its forecasts on the assumption that presidential and legislative elections will take place in December 2018. We expect the MUD, the clear favourite, to win these elections and take power in 2019. But there is a high risk that the PSUV, with the backing of the armed forces, will attempt to cling to power beyond this date. Given the scale of opposition to the government, and the increasingly limited means of addressing opposition concerns via institutional channels, there is also a strong risk of some sort of chaotic, violent political transition, particularly in the context of a crippling economic crisis that the government has shown little willingness or capacity to address. A short-term trigger for such a crisis could include sovereign default or the imposition of sanctions by the US. An interruption of dollar flows from oil sales stemming from either of these events would be deeply damaging to the government.
Assuming that an MUD-led government does take power, we expect it to implement economic adjustments to reduce the state's role in the economy, and unravel the many macroeconomic distortions that the PSUV has introduced since 1999. It will also begin the difficult task of reforming deeply politicised institutions. Given the scale of the economic distortion and institutional destruction that has taken place in Venezuela, as well as the heterogeneous nature of the MUD-which is aligned mainly in its desire to remove the current government from office-the process will not be a smooth one. Weak institutional capacity and high political tension will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
With the next presidential election due in December 2018, the electoral authorities are placing a host of obstacles in the MUD coalition's path, forcing most parties to re-register and banning a leading opposition figure and presidential frontrunner, Henrique Capriles, from running for election for 15 years, citing "administrative irregularities" in his tenure as governor of Miranda state. Nevertheless, assuming that open elections are held, we expect the MUD to win by a substantial margin (as it did in legislative elections in 2015). The timing of the elections and the capacity for the opposition to compete in them fairly is, however, increasingly uncertain. The contro-versial constitutional redrafting proposed by Mr Maduro entails a long rewriting process and will supposedly be put to a nationwide referendum, steps which would take time and could well be used as a pretext for delaying elections. The position of the military towards any such efforts, and to the election process itself, will be decisive, and the risks to our forecasts are unusually high.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Even though a handful of small Caribbean island members of the Organisation of American States (OAS, an institution promoting regional co-operation, and a frequent election observer) helped to scupper a forceful rebuke at the annual assembly in June, Venezuela is isolated diplomatically and coming under increasing regional and international criticism. To date this has done little to weaken the government's grip on power, but the growing threat of sanctions by the US could prove significant. The US president, Donald Trump, has threatened strong but unspecified economic measures against Venezuela (probably a cut in US purchases of Venezuelan oil) if the government goes ahead with the controversial July 30th constituent assembly vote. Other countries in the region and in Europe have also urged Venezuela to abandon the constituent assembly. A return to negotiations, brokered perhaps by Cuba (its closest ally) and Colombia (its neighbour), could potentially provide a path to fresh elections and a political transition, but huge obstacles remain. Another key priority for the Maduro administration will be the maintenance of good relations with China (a key creditor) and Russia, whose state oil company Rosneft is active in Venezuela. Reflecting its external financing difficulties, Venezuela will continue to scale back-or possibly end-oil shipments to beneficiaries of PetroCaribe, an agreement providing cheap financing for oil exports to regional allies.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
It is unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without some sort of policy adjustment between now and the presidential election. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017-18 than it did last year. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or unable to adjust policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy interventionism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Amid subdued oil prices, import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA, the state-oil company. However, given the extremely thin reserves cushion (under $10bn in July), the risk of a disorderly default remains extremely high; this would have dramatic economic and political consequences in the form of a sharp decrease in oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and political turmoil.
We expect the opposition to take power in 2019, ushering in much-needed, market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of over US$16bn in 2019-21. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.5% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. The election of a new government should help to ease the deficit to about 6% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply (M2) rose by nearly 340% year on year in July, the highest rate on record. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability.
There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. In 2016 the government undertook a bond swap that saw about US$2.8bn of PDVSA debt due in 2017 pushed out to 2020. Even after this deal, we continue to see an extremely high risk of default and that some form of debt restructuring-either distressed or otherwise-is increasingly likely in most scenarios.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. In the context of extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. Our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government from 2019 also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that, after a massive contraction in GDP in 2016 (estimated at 14%), we project a further contraction, of 7%, in 2017 (this represents a downward revision from last month, reflecting the effect on activity of ongoing widespread protests). We do not expect the government to make the necessary adjustments to bring about economic recovery, and expect recession to persist into 2019. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a decline in real GDP of nearly 30% in 2014-19.
After dropping by an estimated 20.2% in 2016, private consumption will contract further in 2017-18, reflecting the effect of soaring inflation on real wages, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in invest-ment in 2019-21 assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from recession. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep reces-sion. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation of 18.3% in May, bringing accumu-lated inflation for January---May to 127.8%. Assuming that price pressures remain high in the first half of 2017 at least, we expect average inflation to be higher this year, at nearly 570%, than in 2016. However, we continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, reflecting moderately higher oil prices, which will bring in the necessary foreign exchange to help to alleviate scarcity of goods, and the effect of persistent recession on demand. From 2019 fiscal and monetary policy adjustment will also be supportive of a gradual reduction in inflation towards double-digit levels (in year-on-year terms). However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2017-18, but the exchange rate will still be extremely overvalued. The dual exchange-rate system is composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom. On July 11th, at the seventh auction since the government revamped the Dicom system in May, the BCV sold US$29.4m at Bs2,700:US$1, implying an annual 76% devaluation of the Dicom rate. However, the Dicom accounts for only 10% of all official transactions. In real terms, the average exchange rate (weighted by volume of transactions) has continued to appreciate, creating ever greater pressure for currency adjustment, the need for which is evident in the black-market rate; this stood at BsF8,470:US$1 in mid-July.
The pegged Dipro rate appears increasingly unsustainable, and we assume that the government will devalue the rate later this year (to BsF20:US$1) and again in 2018 (to BsF400:US$1). We also expect the government to increase the share of Dicom in foreign-currency transactions-in effect a maxi-devaluation. We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. Until that occurs, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued gradual decline in oil output. The deficit will widen thereafter, on the assumption that economic recovery draws in imports on a large scale after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021, reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Country Forecast Greece July 2017 Updater

Abstract: The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. According to recent opinion polls, popular support for staying in the euro zone is waning, although a majority still supports membership. [...]as part of negotiations regarding the division of Cyprus, Turkey insists that its troops should be kept on the island, whereas Greece and Greek Cypriots are adamantly opposed. First-quarter data show that the budget is being kept under control by cutting expenditure.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Greece&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Greece+July+2017+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-07-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Greece&amp;rft.issn=0966954X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In September 2015 Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza)-the party of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras-won the snap election (the second in 2015) and formed a coalition government with the right-wing, nationalist Independent Greeks (AE). The Syriza-AE government has only a three-seat majority, which could evaporate as the coalition implements unpopular bail-out policies. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not think that the government will survive a full term.
Protests about labour market reforms, pension cuts, tax and social security increases, and privatisation are likely to intensify as the government strives to meet the ambitious primary surplus budget targets under the three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) bail-out programme. This will increase pressure on the coalition and is likely to result in an early election, which the main opposition, New Democracy (ND), would probably win.
We do not think that the policies contained in the third economic adjustment programme will generate sufficient economic growth to mitigate Greece's debt burden or reduce popular disaffection with austerity. Political stability and Greece's membership of the euro zone will therefore remain in question over the forecast period (2017-21).
We believe that Greece will leave the euro zone by the end of our forecast period, but it is impossible to pinpoint the timing of "Grexit" and build it into our forecast numbers. Grexit would be accompanied by a major debt default and would produce a severe recession for one or two years. After that the economy would grow at a rapid pace. Growth rates under this scenario would be faster than in our medium-term forecast.
We forecast annual real GDP growth in 2017 of 1%, following stagnant growth in 2016, as budget austerity holds back the economic recovery. We forecast average annual real GDP growth of 1.8% in 2018-21 (we have not built our medium-term Grexit forecast into these numbers). We expect that public debt will still equal almost 180% of GDP in 2021.
After zero inflation in 2016, we forecast average annual inflation of 1.4% in 2017-21, reflecting higher oil prices and a pick-up in domestic demand. These trends will result in widening current-account deficits in 2017-21, but these will remain moderate compared with the pre-crisis period.

Greece's score recovers modestly in 2017-21, from a low base, but its global ranking falls from 53rd to 59th and it remains at the bottom of the regional ranking. This is because of improvements in other countries' scores and despite improvement in the macroeconomic environment.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisation targets under the three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme have not been met and a series of processes are being relaunched. The new privatisation fund makes sluggish progress.
2019-21: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: The investment incentives law, passed in June 2016, offers more tax relief and fewer direct subsidies. Its focus is predominantly small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make little progress.
2019-21: "Fast track" legislation will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eased gradually. The risk of Greece leaving the euro area and re-introducing exchange controls and (possibly) restrictions on trade remains high.
2019-21: There is a 60% risk of Greece leaving the euro area; factors on which this will depend include Greece's economic performance, the political and social sustainability of the reform package and the continuation of EU and IMF support.
Taxes
2017-18: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is tough. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2019-21: Little progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up, independence of the tax authority remains in doubt.
Financing
2017-18: Liquidity is tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Steps to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) are painfully slow. The sale of NPL portfolios becomes a political bone of contention.
2019-21: Lending hampered by need to make provisions for still-high NPL portfolios. Moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for majority of debtors. Greece's main banks sell more of their overseas subsidiaries.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market reform remains contentious for Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left. Unemployment remains high.
2019-21: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for the young, raise employment but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Some projects under a development scheme co-financed by the EU for 2007-13 have shifted to the new 2014-20 period. First batch of projects concluded in 2017.
2019-21: Despite technical assistance from the EU, problems with absorption persist. Some privatisations are revived.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule, Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a demo-cracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but it was granted undue leniency in complying with public finance conditions. Greece's rising debt has proved unsustainable and has put its continued membership of EMU in question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. The parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-have been blamed by voters for causing the crisis and, subsequently, the painful consequences of being bailed out by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme. In 2012 public debt held by the private sector was restructured. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. We assume that Greece will have to accept another ESM-financed bail-out programme in 2019-21.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 29% and that on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) were worth US$27.1bn and imports (fob) came to US$45.4bn. The current account registered a deficit of US$1.2bn, equivalent to 0.6% of GDP.
