Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The coalition government of the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, is hanging on by a parliamentary majority of three. Following the September 2015 snap election, won by Mr Tsipras's party, Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), the prime minister formed another coalition with the right-wing, nationalist Independent Greeks (AE). The government obtained a five-seat majority in the 300-seat parliament, but this dropped to three after two members of parliament (MPs) resigned rather than support reforms under the three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM, an inter-governmental assistance fund for countries in the euro zone) agreed in August 2015. The government has tied its acceptance of painful bail-out reforms in 2015-17 to a debt-relief deal and faces a political backlash at home having failed to achieve this at the latest Eurogroup meeting of euro zone finance ministers, on June 15th. It is questionable whether the government has the political will and capacity to implement all the measures required to complete the three-year ESM programme over the next 12 months. The risk of a breakdown in relations between the Greek authorities and their euro zone creditors over the coming year is high.
At the June 15th Eurogroup meeting agreement was reached on a package of structural measures to complete the second programme review. The outcome removed market uncertainty about Greece's capacity to make large debt repayments in July, as it paved the way for the ESM to approve on July 7th disbursement of EUR7.7bn to Greece, including EUR6.9bn to meet debt-service obligations. However, the meeting failed to meet the government's objective of attaining debt relief and left many critical questions unresolved, which means that uncertainty about the country's growth and debt trajectory is likely to persist, increasing political pressure on the government.
Greece has been under a bail-out programme since 2010. The economy has been in almost permanent recession since then, and real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter. Unemployment is still at about 22% and youth unemploy-ment is near 50%. Despite undertaking the biggest post-crisis fiscal adjustment of any euro zone country, Greece's public finances remain parlous and its public debt is still close to 180% of GDP. The Economist Intelligence Unit thinks it more likely than not that Greece will leave the euro zone over the medium term. ESM fiscal and structural reform policies, to which Greece will remain subject after 2018, are unlikely to generate sufficient economic growth to mitigate Greece's debt burden or reduce popular disaffection. Doubts about the country's ability to stay in the euro zone will therefore persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
In the September 2015 election Syriza won 35.5% of the vote, slightly less than in January 2015, and secured 145 seats in Greece's 300-seat parliament (including the 50 bonus seats awarded to the winning party). The AE had ten MPs elected, and the two parties formed a coalition government with a slim majority. We do not think that the government will last a full term (to September 2019), given its fragile majority and the lack of political consensus on bail-out reforms. Syriza is trailing in the polls behind the opposition centre-right New Democracy (ND), but there is little popular enthusiasm for either party; many voters continue to blame ND for its role in leading Greece into the economic mess that led to the three bail-out programmes. However, ND is likely to win the next election and form a coalition government.
An amendment to the electoral law abolishes the 50-seat bonus for the party winning the most votes and lowers the voting age from 18 to 17. However, Syriza failed to secure the two-thirds majority required for the change to come into effect at the next election; therefore the law will take effect after the following election.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
We believe that Grexit is more likely than not by 2021, for several reasons.
Implementation risks. It will be difficult for the government to implement painful reforms in the face of opposition from vested interests and an austerity-weary population.
The growth/debt challenge. Even under a best-case reform scenario, it will be difficult for Greece to restore competitiveness and achieve significant growth while remaining inside the euro zone. The economy's lack of competitiveness, which is difficult to address without a currency devaluation, will continue to shackle growth. Structural reforms recommended in the bail-out programme are slow burners that are unlikely to deliver growth in the short term. Mean-while, spending cuts and tax increases will prolong the squeeze on domestic demand and hinder growth. Without a write-down, which Germany will not countenance, the debt burden will depress economic activity for decades.
Increasing Euroscepticism. According to recent opinion polls, popular support for staying in the euro zone is waning, although a majority still supports membership. In the coming years support for remaining in the euro zone at all costs is likely to diminish.
Greek-Turkish relations have deteriorated recently, with a rise in tensions owing mainly to two issues.
First, Turkey requested the extradition of eight Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the failed coup on July 15th 2016. Greece's Supreme Court rejected the request, saying that the soldiers could not be guaranteed a fair trial. In response, Turkey called the ruling "political" and sent two navy vessels to the disputed islands of Kardak in the Aegean Sea, prompting Greece to warn Turkey against violating its territorial waters.
Second, as part of negotiations regarding the division of Cyprus, Turkey insists that its troops should be kept on the island, whereas Greece and Greek Cypriots are adamantly opposed. Talks all but collapsed in July over this issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Greece's latest bail-out programme will shape economic policy to 2018 and beyond. The ESM is providing financial assistance to meet Greece's financing needs, which euro zone leaders have estimated at EUR86bn over three years (2015-18). In return Greece must implement fiscal and structural reforms, as well as large-scale asset sales. On July 7th the ESM authorised the disbursement of EUR7.7bn to Greece, bringing the total disbursement so far under the third economic adjustment programme to EUR39.4bn. It will be followed by another sub-tranche of EUR800m after September 1st, subject to the ESM being satisfied that the government has made progress in clearing its arrears to the private sector. That will be the concluding payment of the second programme review.
As we expected, there was no agreement on debt relief at the Eurogroup on June 15th, although there was further discussion of what type of measures might be considered at the end of the current ESM programme. The IMF is not convinced that the measures would be sufficient to make Greece's debt sustainable. The IMF says that it cannot officially support the programme by providing funding unless it is confident that the debt is sustainable. When a country's sovereign debt is assessed as being unsustain-able the IMF's legal framework prevents it from providing financial support, unless the programme includes specific measures-normally including debt restructuring-that can resolve the debt-sustainability problem within a medium-term timeframe.
In May 2016 the European institutions and the IMF agreed on a framework for assessing debt sustainability based on the view that Greece's gross financing needs should remain below 15% of GDP after the end of the programme in 2018 for the medium term and below 20% of GDP thereafter. On that occasion the Eurogroup said that it would "implement a possible second set of measures following the successful implementation of the ESM programme".
On July 27th the IMF executive board will decide whether to support Greece with a precautionary stand-by arrangement (SBA), withholding funding until after agreement is reached on measures to ensure long-term debt sustainability for Greece. Despite attempts to suggest that the IMF is on board, it seems fairly clear that it is not and that it is no longer prepared to pretend otherwise.
The European Central Bank (ECB) said that euro zone finance ministers had not provided enough clarity on debt relief to reassure the bank that Greece's debt was sustainable, so Greece will not be included in the ECB's bond-buying quantitative easing (QE) programme. There must therefore be some doubt about Greece's ability to return to the international capital markets and exit the drip-feed of bail-out programme financing after 2018.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Eurostat has confirmed budget data released by the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT, the national statistics office) showing that in 2016 Greece achieved a general government budget surplus of EUR1.3bn, equivalent to 0.7% of GDP (ESA 2010 measure). The budget recorded a primary surplus (budget balance minus interest payments) of EUR6.9bn, equivalent to 3.95% of GDP. The above-plan performance was primarily the result of expenditure cuts, which fell by 9.6% year on year, to 49.1%, from 54.3% of GDP in 2015. Revenue increased by 3.1% year on year, to EUR87.5bn.
In 2017 the primary surplus target under the third economic adjustment programme is 1.75% of GDP; this rises to 3.5% in 2018 and for four years until 2022 (after which Greece is expected to deliver a 2% of GDP budget primary surplus until 2060). The 2017 budget targets additional revenue of more than EUR1bn from new (mainly indirect) taxes and spending cuts of more than EUR1bn. The budget assumes real GDP growth of 2.7% in 2017, which is faster than our forecast of 1%. The government target seems optimistic given the likely dampening effect on domestic demand of further tax increases and austerity, and the negative effect on confidence resulting from the delay in finalising the second review. First-quarter data show that the budget is being kept under control by cutting expenditure. We do not see Greece meeting, from 2018 onwards, annual primary surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP for five years.
The restructuring of government debt to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.5% at end-2012, from 172% in 2011. However, the budget over-performance in 2016 was not sufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt, which rose to EUR314.9bn, equivalent to 179.4% of GDP (up from 177.7% in 2015). Government debt is now almost entirely owed to official creditors. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming weak nominal GDP growth rates over the medium term, the public debt/GDP ratio will remain close to 180% in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
The ECB is pursuing an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero; a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money; and a EUR60bn per month QE programme, which will run until the end of 2017. However, the economic recovery in the euro zone has maintained momentum-supported by an acceleration in credit growth-and looks to be more broad based. We expect another healthy expansion of real GDP in the euro zone in 2017, of 1.8%, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Commentary at the end of June from the ECB's president, Mario Draghi, that mentioned "reflationary" forces in the region's economy has reinforced our forecast that the bank will begin to wind down, or "taper", the programme in 2018. Nevertheless, underlying price pressure remains relatively subdued, and downside risks to wage growth and the global economy during that year could yet slow the pace at which the ECB reduces its monthly asset purchases. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not raise policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Real GDP data released by ELSTAT indicate that the economy stagnated in 2016. Broken down by expenditure, the only positive contribution for full-year 2016 came from final consumption, which rose by 0.6%. However, this headline figure masked significant differences in the underlying numbers. Household consumption rose by 1.4%, and general government spending fell by 2.1%. Exports of goods and services contracted, and fixed investment stagnated.
On June 2nd ELSTAT released its revised estimate for the first quarter of 2017. Real GDP (seasonally and calendar adjusted) grew by 0.4% compared with both the previous quarter and the year-earlier period. There appear to be contradictory trends at work in the Greek economy that make it difficult to forecast short-term growth prospects. Delays in finalising the second programme review had a negative effect on consumer and investor confidence in the first half of 2017. However, there was evidence of consumers stepping up discretionary spending as fears mounted about the outcome of the negotiations between Greece and its creditors, supporting retail sales. Meanwhile, working-day-adjusted industrial output averaged about 7% in the first five months of 2017, and export growth has been fairly brisk; investment also appears to have picked up, but this is also driving up imports. On the downside, a combination of more and higher taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts will put pressure on household disposable income. Credit growth has been sharply negative so far this year, and there is little prospect of a resumption of lending growth any time soon. We forecast real GDP growth of 1% in 2017.
As the threat of a bail-out breakdown and default recedes and the authorities make some progress in structural reform and privatisation, we expect investment growth to return and household consumption to increase modestly, by an average of 4% and 1.7% per year respectively in 2018-21. However, some of the headwinds discussed above will persist in 2018 and beyond, when the government is supposed to deliver an annual primary budget surplus of 3.5% of GDP. Given the bail-out programme's emphasis on fiscal restraint and meeting ambitious primary surplus targets, as well as still high unemployment and limited lending growth, we believe that annual real GDP growth in 2018-21 will average 1.8%. Government consumption growth will remain modest in 2018-21, given that Greece's international creditors will insist on continued fiscal consolidation.
We expect investment to recover in 2017-21, after almost a decade of contraction, but this will be from a low base (65% below 2007 levels in 2016). The decline in fixed investment since the start of the sovereign debt crisis will have a significant negative effect over the longer term, undermining the economy's ability to generate growth. Greece's external trade will be constrained by the continuation of the capital controls regime, as well as by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. After a strong second-half export performance in 2016 base effects will reverse this pattern in 2017. Over the medium term we expect tourism to support services export growth, but we forecast only modest growth of exports of goods and services, averaging 2.3% per year in 2017-21.
We forecast that Greece will leave the euro zone by 2021, but it is impossible to pinpoint the timing and build it into our forecast. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and a severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then begin to grow rapidly, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the need to achieve a primary surplus. Growth rates under this scenario would be faster than those in our medium-term forecast.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
In January-May Greece's harmonised index of consumer prices (HICP) rose by an average of 1.6% year on year. As in recent months, the main positive contribution came from transport prices, which rose by 4% year on year, adding 0.6 percentage points to headline price growth. Transport prices are heavily linked to energy costs, and with global energy prices having bottomed in early 2016, base effects will now become less supportive. We expect the energy-driven spike in inflation to fade, and, with core inflation still weak, we forecast an average increase in the HICP of 1.3% this year and average annual inflation of 1.4% in 2018-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has continued and political risk has waned. This, combined with a rise in expectations of QE tapering by the ECB, has raised the upside risks to our forecast for the exchange rate to average US$1.08:EUR1 in 2017-18. We expect the euro to appreciate gradually thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
In 2016 the current account recorded a deficit of US$1.2bn (0.6% of GDP) compared with a small surplus in 2015, as a result of a deterioration in the services surplus. After several years during which it contracted fairly sharply, the current-account deficit has started to expand modestly, according to recent data, reflecting primarily developments on the merchandise goods account and in particular higher prices for energy imports. We expect this trend to continue and expect the external deficit to widen moderately relative to GDP this year. We forecast that annual deficits will expand further as import prices continue to rise and import volumes gradually pick up in line with higher domestic demand, although they will be smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.5% of GDP since Greece joined the euro in 2001.

Country Forecast Turkey July 2017 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-july-2017-updater/docview/1955227747/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. The bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen, from 7.8% to about 12% in early July 2017. 2012a 2013a 2014a 2015a 2016b 2017c 2018c 2019c 2020c 2021c The labour market (av) Labour force (m) 26.1 27.0 28.8 29.7 30.5 31.5 32.2 32.7 33.5 34.2 Labour force (% change) 2.1 3.5 6.4 3.1 3.0 3.2 2.3 1.5 2.5 2.0 Employment (m) 23.9 24.6 25.9 26.6 27.2 27.9 28.6 29.1 29.8 30.6 Employment (% change) 2.9 2.8 5.4 2.7 2.2 2.5 2.4 2.0 2.3 2.5 Unemployment (m) 2.2 2.4 2.9 3.0 3.3 3.6 3.7 3.6 3.7 3.7 Unemployment rate (%) 8.5 9.1 10.0 10.3 10.9 11.5 11.4 11.0 11.1 10.7 Wage and price inflation (% except labour costs per hour) Consumer prices (av) 8.9 7.5 8.9 7.7 7.8a 10.3 7.8 6.3 5.7 5.2 Consumer prices (year-end) 6.3 7.5 8.3 8.9 8.5a 8.6 7.8 6.0 5.3 5.0 Producer prices (av) 6.1 4.5 10.2 5.3 4.3a 14.8 9.5 8.5 7.5 5.5 GDP deflator (av) 7.4 6.3 7.4 7.8 7.7a 8.8 8.2 6.1 6.1 5.7 Private consumption deflator (av) 7.8 6.1 7.7 7.7 6.7a 10.3 8.9 7.3 6.8 6.2 Government consumption deflator (av) 9.3 6.0 9.4 8.2 9.8a 9.4 7.8 6.3 5.7 5.2 Fixed investment deflator (av) 6.6 5.8 9.0 7.6 7.7a 6.0 5.5 5.0 5.0 5.0 Average nominal wages 15.6b 14.4b 15.5b 13.7b 15.9 11.5 10.0 9.0 8.3 7.7 Average real wages 6.1b 6.5b 6.1b 5.6b 7.5 1.1 2.0 2.6 2.4 2.4 Unit labour costs (TL-based; av)d 15.9b 10.9b 18.2b 12.7b 17.6 12.0 10.8 9.5 8.8 8.7 Unit labour costs (US$-based)d 8.1b 4.7b 2.8b -9.3b 5.9 -6.9 8.9 5.2 5.5 6.2 Labour costs per hour (TL)d 7.5b 8.6b 10.0b 11.3b 13.1 14.6 16.1 17.5 19.0 20.5 Labour costs per hour (US$) 4.2b 4.5b 4.5b 4.2b 4.3 4.0 4.3 4.6 4.8 5.0 a Actual.b Economist Intelligence Unit estimates.c Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts.d Manufacturing only: public and private sectors.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The political instability in Turkey that followed the failed coup in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, the presidential reform provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incumbent, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. This will further undermine Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures, exacerbate the deep social and political divisions in the country, damage the country's already fragile international relations, especially with the EU, and delay further economic reform efforts.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and the Justice and Development Party (AKP) will win the next presidential and parliamentary elections, completing the transfer of executive powers to Mr Erdogan. The elections are not due to be held until late 2019, but they could be called earlier-once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place-if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency. Emergency rule, which was introduced following the failed coup, will continue to be used to silence government critics and disable the pro-Kurdish opposition. We expect emergency rule to remain in place for the foreseeable future to allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and jihadi extremists affiliated with Islamic State (IS). Turkey risks be-coming mired in the Syrian conflict, following the deployment of Turkish troops to Syria to combat IS and halt the territorial expansion by Syrian Kurds.
The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses. Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to cut interest rates to boost the economy has eased. We expect the bank to keep monetary policy tight in order to lower inflation and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates.
We expect average annual real GDP growth to accelerate, from 3% in 2016 to an annual average rate of 4.1% in 2017-21. The current-account deficit has narrowed, but will still be large at an annual average of about 4% of GDP in 2017-21 and therefore difficult to fund, especially if global liquidity is tightened.

Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2017-21) and the country's global ranking falls by 12 places, reflecting the absence of reforms in recent years. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment. The main shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening-up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade following the lifting of Russian sanctions. Possible increase in protectionism under the new US administration.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. Political pressure on c0mmercial banks to reduce interest rates. Renewed pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey cannot be ruled out.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Wage moderation after 30% minimum wage rise in 2016. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup at-tempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019, and possibly earlier. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage remain widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.9bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The intense political instability that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit maintains its negative medium-term political outlook. The narrow referendum victory and allegations of vote fraud have deepened the social and political divisions. The "justice march" from the capital, Ankara, to Istanbul, led by Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the leader of the opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), ended peacefully on July 9th, but further protests are likely, keeping high the risk of clashes between protesters and pro-government supporters or a government clampdown. The presidential reform, which will take effect after the next presidential and parliamentary elections, both due in 2019, will further undermine Turkey's fragile democratic institutions and governance structures. It provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incum-bent president and leader of the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP), Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Mr Erdogan and the AKP have continued to tighten their grip on power. The state of emergency law introduced after the failed coup has been repeatedly extended on a three-month basis. We expect it remain in place for the foresee-able future because it will effectively allow Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place.
Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More than 100,000 people-mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media-have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk remains high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place. Given the popularity of the president and his party's ability to control the election process, we expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and currently appears to have no candidates capable of challenging him. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round with just over 50% of the vote against a joint candidate presented by the CHP and the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties will consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the MHP leadership's decision to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 elections and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for parliamentary representation, which would boost the AKP's seat share. Under the constitutional changes approved in the referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's inter-national relations with its traditional Western allies.
Having deployed armed forces to back rebel groups in Syria to fight IS and prevent the expansion of territory held by US-backed, PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds, Turkey risks becoming embroiled in the conflict. Tensions and the risk of confrontation between Turkey and US-backed forces could escalate once IS is defeated. The US administration appears unlikely to grant Turkey's request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey on charges of masterminding the failed coup. Even if the AKP government provides evidence of his role in the coup that would stand up in a US court, there would be a strong chance that his extradition would be rejected on the grounds that he might not get a fair trial in Turkey.
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc anymore. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU may not be able to avoid suspending the process. The sus-pension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Turkey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. A settlement of the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but talks collapsed in July 2017. We maintain our forecast that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but are pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances, well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector and its dynamic, diver-sified private business sector. However, the risk of an intensification of political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity could disrupt foreign capital inflows to Turkey during the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016 and early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy in November after a prolonged period of loosening. If the lira depreciates sharply again-after stabilising at about TL3.5:US$1 in June 2017, it fell by around 3% in the first week of July, to TL3.63:US$1, probably prompted by expectations of balance sheet tapering by the Federal Reserve (the Fed, the US central bank)-an abrupt tightening of policy may be necessary, which could strangle Turkey's economic recovery. However, this is not our baseline scenario, as we currently expect US monetary policy to be tightened only gradually in the remainder of 2017-18.
Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges have blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past and major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to support investor confidence and prevent a surge in domestic demand causing an unsustainable widening of the current-account deficit. Nevertheless, we expect the central government deficit, which captures most of the public sector, will widen from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.3% of GDP per year in 2017-19, before narrowing to 1.9% in 2021. Although the government debt/GDP ratio has edged up slightly, to 29.4% in 2016, we expect it to remain around 30% in 2017-21. The risk of a larger deterio-ration in the public finances cannot be ruled out. The transfer of Turkey's major state assets to a sovereign wealth fund established in 2016 to help finance major infrastructure projects could bring privatisation to a halt and the fund could become a vehicle to increase off-budget spending.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates to revive economic activity has eased, as the government has switched its attention to Turkey's profitable commercial banks. We expect that the central bank will have to keep its monetary policy tight in the remainder of 2017 and in 2018 in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates and Fed balance sheet tapering. To do this, we expect the Turkish central bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen, from 7.8% to about 12% in early July 2017.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, the one-week repurchase lending rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that the corridor will be eliminated until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases. From 2017 the bank will hold only eight regular Monetary Policy Committee meetings annually rather than 12.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
After slowing sharply in 2016, real GDP growth has rebounded. We expect it to accelerate from 3% in 2016 to 4.1% per year in 2017-18 (revised up from 3.3% previously), supported by government stimulus measures, an easing of domestic political uncertainty after the presidential reform referendum and a pick-up in global demand. We forecast annual average growth of 4% in 2019-21. This assumes that domestic political conditions do not deteriorate sharply in the next few years as the country transitions to a presidential system of government and that foreign investor confidence in Turkey holds up. The main risks to growth over the medium term are that further domestic political uncertainty and tighter global liquidity will negatively affect capital inflows, hampering bank lending and business confidence.
We expect real private consumption growth to accelerate from 2.3% in 2016 to an annual average of 3.5% in 2017-21 owing to a moderate improvement in con-fidence, an easing of lending conditions as a result of government pressure to lower interest rates, a gradual recovery in employment growth and government incentives for the purchase of certain household durable goods in the short term (at least until September 2017).
After expanding by 7.6% in 2016 we expect government spending to increase by nearly 8% per year on average in 2017-19 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to dampen fixed investment growth in 2017-18, as a more cautious approach by businesses will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast an acceleration to average annual growth of 5%, assuming a less volatile domestic and global environment.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey since mid-2016, the positive impact of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in the main export markets, especially in Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-21. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter some visitors to Turkey and weigh on the tourist sector. Our expectation is that a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. We expect further currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Amid further bouts of volatility, we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar to an annual average of TL3.63:US$1 in 2017-a fall of about 17% compared with 2016. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL4.06:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, and the impact on investor confidence of domestic political instability and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
After narrowing in recent years, we expect the current account to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large-at a forecast average of 4.1% of GDP per year in 2017-21-to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main export sectors, we expect this to be largely offset by the moderately higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. There has been a rebound in Russian tourist arrivals in early 2017, but the tour-ism sector is likely to take several years to recover to 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP. An early election will be held on October 15th.
The popularity of the new leader of the ÖVP, the young minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, means that the election has become a three-horse race between the SPÖ, the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The most likely coalition to emerge is one that is led by the ÖVP and includes the FPÖ, although negotiations to form one could be fraught.
The inclusion of the FPÖ in the government will not lead to similar EU sanctions as in 2000, when the party was last part of a coalition, owing largely to the normalisation of the far right in Europe since then.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects any new government to focus on integration and immigration policy, and to attempt to reduce the large tax wedge and introduce some additional flexibility in labour and product markets. However, limited government cohesion is likely to lead to limited progress.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2017-21) as the fiscal consolidation process suffers under limited government cohesion and effectiveness. Nevertheless, the public debt/GDP ratio will fall gradually.
After several years of underperformance compared with its regional peers, the economy has performed relatively strongly since the start of 2016, growing by 1.6% in 2016 and 1.9% year on year in the first quarter of 2017. We forecast continued catch-up growth this year, at 1.9%, and that growth will moderate to 1.4% on average in 2018-21. In line with the broader recovery in the euro zone, this will be driven mainly by domestic demand.
Consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) will continue to exceed the euro zone average in 2017-21, driven by structural domestic factors including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets. Annual inflation averaged 1% in 2016, up from 0.8% in 2015, and we forecast an annual average of 2% in 2017-21.
In 2016 the current-account surplus decreased slightly, to 1.7% of GDP. We forecast that it will average about 2% in the coming years as a weakening trade balance is offset by strong tourism receipts.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21). As a result, the country remains in 12th place in the regional ranking but loses two places in the global ranking, dropping to 19th. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress likely to be limited.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. Little progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between the EU and the UK.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to the tax system, owing in part to a likely deterioration in government effectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely assuming a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power in 2017. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform, and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

a Actual.
Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election will be held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.8bn and the goods import bill was US$143bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.3bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Following several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition and party in-fighting, the grand coalition of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister of economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. The popular 30-year-old minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz, has taken over the leadership of the ÖVP and will run as the party's lead candidate in the early general election on October 15th. However, probably owing to the party's recent poor performance in the polls (it has languished in third place over the past year) Mr Kurz decided to leverage his own popularity by demanding full control over the ÖVP and that the party appear on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party", which would also include people not previously associated with the ÖVP. Following Mr Kurz's arrival as party leader the ÖVP shot to the top of the polls, pushing the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) to third place, from first. This "Kurz effect" could wane slightly in the coming months, as Mr Kurz will be forced to continue working in the dysfunctional coalition, will face increasing scrutiny of his policies and will need time to build new structures to lead a reformed ÖVP. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the election to be a three-horse race between the ÖVP, the SPÖ and the FPÖ, with the ÖVP currently best placed to emerge as the largest party in the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house of parliament).
Nevertheless, the election will be a next step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the ÖVP will have been effectively replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns about immigration, although Mr Kurz looks to be drawing voters away from the FPÖ, in large part based on his strong stance on immigration and border control.
The most likely coalition to emerge after the election is one led by the ÖVP, with the FPÖ as a junior coalition partner, as the other parties-including the Greens and NEOS, a liberal party-are unlikely to be large enough to help either the SPÖ or the ÖVP to reach a parliamentary majority. Risks to this outlook are high, as the election could turn and the coalition negotiations could falter, because the FPÖ will probably demand significant concessions from Mr Kurz. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further. The government will struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, and the FPÖ is likely to struggle to translate its opposition on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for October 15th 2017. The most likely scenario is that the rebranded ÖVP under Mr Kurz will win the largest share of the vote, although not an outright majority, and subsequently form a coalition with the FPÖ.
Elections for some state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president will be in 2022.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the strong position of the FPÖ, and it seems to have driven the government to lower its annual cap on asylum applications. The government has repeatedly hinted that it wants to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
We expect a new government to continue along the same line, as most parties have supported such an approach. Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the election in 1999 led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should the party join the next governing coalition. Although at that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was a relatively unusual development, since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in parliament in several EU countries, including some Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Norbert Hofer, the FPÖ candidate-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU did not reform or if Turkey joined. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016, when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In the renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term, in 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, we expect little progress, as both parties will be focused on the election and, in the case of the ÖVP, on reforming the party itself.
The next government, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right and is likely to focus on improving the business environment, including by reducing the sizeable tax wedge, but we would expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.3% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, but widened again in 2016, to 1.5%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2017-21), albeit within 1% of GDP from 2018, as fiscal con-solidation will continue to be limited and growth solid, but unspectacular. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 84.6% in 2016, following a positive contribu-tion from the Heta deal, to more than 75% in 2021. In the context of the quanti-tative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
The euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum at present, and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and a EUR60bn per month QE programme, which will run until the end of 2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, stressed that the recent reduction in the pace of QE (from EUR80bn per month in March) was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany, which was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. A faltered reform process has contributed to higher inflation compared with regional peers and weakened productivity growth, admittedly from fairly high levels. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.6%, remained below Germany's 1.8% growth.
However, the economy has recently started to gain momentum again, with quarterly growth of 0.6% in the past three quarters. Although the labour market had in previous years struggled to integrate the significant increase in the labour force, it seemed to have turned a corner in late 2016 and early 2017, when the unemployment rate started to fall. This is supporting private consumption, which we expect to grow by 1.8% this year, and the uptick in growth throughout the region is supporting export growth, with exports to other EU economies up by 11.5% year on year in the first quarter. As a result, we expect growth to accelerate to an upwardly revised 1.9% this year, broadly in line with that of regional peers.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an under-performance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue next year, when we forecast that the economy will expand by 1.7%, broadly in line with regional peers. A worsening global economic environment in 2018-19, when we expect a policy-driven slowdown in China and a cyclical slowdown in the US, will weigh on growth in the second half of our five-year forecast period, as will the continued lack of reform progress. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in these years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.4% in 2018-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone in both years. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 2.2%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has continued and political risk has waned. However, the common currency's resilience may be tested again in forthcoming elections, and faster economic growth and tighter monetary policy in the US will lend support to the dollar. We expect the exchange rate to average US$1.08:EUR1 in 2017-18, before appreciating gradually in 2019-21. We do not expect the euro to return to its long-term average value against the dollar even by the end of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and moved the trade balance back into a small deficit in 2016. We expect growth in domestic demand and a slight rise in oil prices to weigh on the trade balance in the coming years. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in our forecast period, of about 2%.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana, is pressing ahead with a programme of economic policy adjustment in an effort to eliminate distortions and return the economy to sustainable growth. The adjustment process is proving difficult, involving politically unpopular austerity measures, and the risk of social unrest will therefore remain significant for much of the forecast period.
Given the president's minority position in Congress, and the priority given to urgent macroeconomic reforms, there is likely to be only limited progress on the pursuit of legislation that would successfully address longstanding institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Comprehensive reforms to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. Furthermore, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect meaningful advances-at least in the short term-on a structural reform agenda (incorporating tax and labour market reform) that could improve long-term potential growth rates.
After a contraction in real GDP in 2016, reflecting macroeconomic policy tightening and currency depreciation, we are forecasting a pick-up in exports, investment and private consumption in the medium term. There will be a boost in business confidence from policy tightening. Combined with macroeconomic adjustment, and a gradual removal of foreign-exchange and import controls, these policies should set the economy on a more solid long-term footing. However, some aspects of the policymaking environment will remain suboptimal, with labour-market reform and a comprehensive fiscal reform remaining low on the agenda.
Currency adjustment should gradually bolster the current account as a weaker peso starts to boost goods and services exports and rein in imports. On this basis, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow in 2017, but it will begin to widen again from 2019 to end the forecast period at 2.9% of GDP. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve over the forecast period, assuming that capital inflows pick up as investor confidence in the Macri administration grows.
Argentina's GDP per head is still among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

Argentina's global business environment score improves substantially in 2017-21, and the country jumps 17 places in our global ranking. A period of economic policy adjustment is under way as the centre-right government works to tighten macroeconomic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. However, in many areas improve-ments will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2019-21: Continued work to build confidence in legal and regulatory framework. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2017-18: Efforts to resolve any remaining disputes with international creditors and investors as the government seeks fresh sources of US dollar inflows.
2019-21: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Any remaining foreign-exchange controls likely to be removed. Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance.
2019-21: Possibility that free-trade agreements make better progress.
Taxes
2017-18: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax system remains complex and burdensome.
2019-21: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist.
Financing
2017-18: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2019-21: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2017-18: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of the unions will remain strong.
2019-21: Progress on labour reform unlikely. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The Macri administration works to address weak contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes, which keep private investment below potential. Financing constraints hamper public investment in the short term.
2019-21: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.

Background: Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983 after 50 years of instability and military regimes. A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances in the economy in the form of double-digit inflation, real peso appreciation and a deterioration of the balance of payments. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to foreign-exchange, import and capital controls, as well as ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to reduce economic distortions and set the economy on a more solid long-term footing are taking place under Mr Macri; these include peso devaluation, and fiscal and monetary tightening. Microeconomic reforms to boost domestic supply are also getting under way.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals). Taxes on exports were reintroduced in 2002, and have since been expanded to account for around 20% of total revenue.
Foreign trade: The current account shifted from surplus to deficit in 2010. Despite comprehensive controls, there was a current-account deficit of 2.7% of GDP in 2015.
