Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The political scene is becoming more complicated as voter fatigue with austerity increases and patience with adjustment measures wears thin. An increase in union obstructionism since March is unsurprising amid annual wage-bargaining negotiations that are taking place in the run-up to mid-term legislative elections on October 22nd. More of a concern for the president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is the continued perception among voters that adjustment is not bringing about obvious rapid improvements in the economy. Various economic indicators suggest that the economy is indeed emerging from recession, but consumers are not yet feeling the benefit in terms of higher real wages or increased employment.
The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Macri to abandon the adjustment process that he has pursued since taking office for a four-year term in late 2015. This process has involved devaluation, fiscal and monetary tightening, and sharp tariff adjustments. In this environment, voter weariness with auster-ity, combined with the approaching mid-terms, will in the short term complicate relations with Congress, where the president lacks a majority. The ruling Cambiemos alliance, which includes the Pro and the centre-left Unión Cívica Radical, has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda in both houses of Congress on an ad hoc basis with the various factions of the large Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party). So far this support has mainly been forthcoming, not least because the Peronists have had trouble regrouping under a clear leader-ship since losing the presidency in 2015. The largest faction of the party, the Frente para la Victoria, has been weakened by a series of corruption scandals, while moderate Peronists have frequently supported government legislation.
We expect obstructionism to increase amid election-related politicking surrounding the mid-terms in October, and as a presidential election in October 2019 approaches. But mutual interest will ensure some continuing co-operation between Cambiemos and moderate Peronists. On top of this, a strong executive branch (the president has substantial powers to rule by decree) should provide Mr Macri with room for manoeuvre, even assuming that Congress becomes less co-operative. The president will also retain influence with powerful provincial governors, who largely control the agenda of the Senate (the upper house) but who are in turn deeply reliant on central government transfers, some of which are discretionary. As a result, we expect some continued progress on the govern-ment agenda. However, there will be limited progress on legislation that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Compre-hensive efforts to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. We do not expect meaningful advances on a structural reform agenda.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
Mid-term elections are set for October 22nd. Open, nationwide primary elections will be held on August 13th, although in practice, Argentina's political parties continue to choose their candidates via internal selection processes, and the primaries will therefore serve as a sort of dress rehearsal for the main event. With the primaries now approaching, campaigning is beginning to dominate the political scene. The ruling Pro and its partners in the Cambiemos coalition are currently in a minority position in both houses of Congress, and we do not expect this to change in the mid-terms. For Cambiemos, a more important marker is whether it gains or loses seats, and how it performs on the Buenos Aires province congressional list (voters select party lists; this gauges both how popular the political parties are and how popular the leading candidates on each list are). On this measure, Cambiemos should do fairly well, partly because the dominant, heterogeneous Peronist party is deeply divided.
The former Peronist president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15) has created a new party altogether (to avoid primary elections) and announced her intention to run for Senate. Ms Fernández's presence in the race will not only divide the Peronist vote, but also give focus to the Cambiemos campaign, which currently lacks the strong economic recovery narrative that it was hoping for at the start of the year. Instead, Cambiemos can now frame the mid-terms as a fight between a modernising government and the cronyism of the past. (Ms Fernández is currently under investigation for corruption during her time as president, and a congressional seat would provide her with immunity from prosecution.) On this basis we expect Cambiemos to do well enough to retain good working relations with moderate Peronists in the legislature.
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and a return to single-digit inflation by then, we currently expect Mr Macri to win a second four-year term. There are substantial risks to this forecast, given the challenging external environment and the government's minority position in Congress. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. In this context, the emergence of a strong challenger from the moderate wing of the Peronist party is a major possibility, and the election will be closely fought.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Efforts by the Macri government to repair relations with trade and invest-ment partners have achieved rapid results, and we expect relations with key trade partners in the region and elsewhere to remain strong. The Argentinian govern-ment will remain keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended from the group in 2016). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, free trade has shifted off the political agenda not only in the US but also in Europe. Mr Macri recently visited Spain in an effort to drum up support for a deal, and negotiations are continuing. Our forecasts do not currently assume a successful conclusion of free-trade talks with the EU, but the workings of intra-Mercosur trade are likely to improve in the forecast period. Efforts at joining the Pacific Alliance, a regional trading bloc that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico, may also make progress, although this is not currently reflected in our five-year economic forecasts.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
The Macri administration has made good initial progress on a programme of adjustment intended to put the economy on a sounder footing, having devalued the peso, reduced agricultural export duties and energy subsidies, and secured a deal with holdout creditors (allowing Argentina to exit default and tap international capital markets again). However, macroeconomic adjustment remains incomplete, and policy efforts to reduce inflation will continue, in the form of tight fiscal and monetary policy, and restraint in nominal wage growth. The latter in particular is proving a difficult political challenge, and has encountered stiff union resistance. The government is extremely unlikely to meet its goal of limiting nominal wage growth to 20% this year, but we do continue to expect nominal wages to trend downwards steadily from levels of above 30% in recent years. All of these measures should gradually engender price stability and ultimately boost investor confidence, although we do not expect inflation to fall to single-digit levels until 2019.
With macroeconomic adjustment measures proceeding apace, the government is gradually turning its attention to the structural reform agenda and to reforms to improve the business environment, and we expect a growing policy emphasis on these areas. The government has already passed new public-private partnership framework legislation that should facilitate an increase in infrastructure investment, along with reforms to reduce red-tape financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. The development of longer-term finance and the deepening of Argentina's currently shallow capital markets will be a priority. However, other aspects of the policymaking environ-ment will remain suboptimal, with progress on labour-market reform (to improve flexibility) or comprehensive fiscal and tax reform (to reduce costs and complexity) unlikely in the medium term amid political obstruction.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Higher-than-expected revenue from a tax amnesty on undeclared foreign assets will bolster the fiscal accounts and allow the government to meet its target of narrowing the primary deficit to 4% of GDP in 2017, slightly below the 4.3% of GDP primary deficit registered in 2016. We expect the government's gradualist approach to fiscal tightening to continue in subsequent years, bringing the overall fiscal deficit down to a more manageable level of 3.3% of GDP by 2021, by which time the primary deficit will have dropped to about 1% of GDP. The govern-ment has taken some important steps in the past 18 months to try to narrow the deficit, particularly by reducing costly subsidies and the public-sector payroll. Even so, in the light of income-tax breaks and increased transfers (to expand the social safety net), deficit reduction will be slow.
In the aftermath of the holdout deal, and assuming that there is progress on deficit reduction, the government's ability to finance moderate deficits without resorting to inflationary money printing will be much improved. A moderate, though rising, public debt/GDP ratio (and low levels of external indebtedness), combined with the attractiveness of Argentina's still-high yields, should facilitate international bond issuance in 2017-21, following Argentina's exit from default in 2016. The sovereign's much-improved access to internal finance (and a clear search for yield) was evident in June, when the sovereign issued US$2.5bn in 100-year global bonds at a yield of 7.92%. As a percentage of GDP, the public debt will stabilise at slightly over 50% in 2017-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Notwithstanding a recent policy reversal, which saw the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) lift the policy rate from 24.75% to 26.25% in April (it has kept rates unchanged since then), we continue to expect fairly substantial rate cuts in the second half of 2017 and beyond. The BCRA responded to rising inflation expectations with what we expect to be a one-off rate rise in April to make its commitment to the newly implemented inflation-targeting framework clear. Assuming that monthly inflation starts to fall towards 1% on a consistent basis, we expect ample scope for renewed monetary easing in the third quarter of 2017.
The central bank has made it clear that it will prioritise monetary policy that is conducive to a reduction of inflation, and our forecasts assume moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term, consistent with a deepening of credit and the development of long-term lending. This forecast is supported by the shift to an inflation-targeting regime (with the target due to be lowered to 8-12% in 2018 and 5% in 2019), and by reduced political interference after a period of politicisation under the previous administration.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
After a contraction in real GDP of 22% in 2016, we expect a return to positive territory in 2017. But with Brazil's economic recovery likely to stall in 2017 amid an escalating political crisis, manufacturing activity in Argentina will recover only moderately, limiting GDP growth to 2.7%. We currently expect the recovery to peak in 2018, with growth of 3.4%. However, the growth rate for that year masks an expected sequential deceleration in the second half of 2018, resulting from a projected weakening of Chinese import demand. By 2019, when we project a cyclical downturn in the US economy, real GDP growth in Argentina will slide back below 3%, before a modest recovery takes hold in 2020-21.
Our forecast for a relatively robust recovery in the medium term is based on the assumption that a combination of macroeconomic adjustment and improve-ments to the business environment will eventually have some beneficial impact on both export activity and domestic demand. An easing of inflation, combined with efforts by the Macri government to address the problem of legal and regulatory uncertainty and reduce red tape, should set the stage for renewed strong growth in fixed investment and private consumption, support-ing an acceleration of GDP growth. On the supply side, growth should be bolstered in 2017 and into the medium term by a positive outlook for agriculture, and for investment in both infrastructure and energy, including renewables.
There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to reduce economic distortions and engineer a smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging. However, there is also some upside risk, as investment could overtake expectations from 2017 once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and depending on the success of efforts to improve the framework for doing business. However, even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform efforts than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than 4%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation will decline steadily but gradually in the forecast period, from a rate of 25.4% in May (according to the Buenos Aires city price index). Although high, the May result represents a steep fall from a peak of 47.2% in July 2016, which resulted from currency and tariff adjust-ments by the new administration. Assuming tight monetary and fiscal policy (spending growth will remain negative in real terms until 2018), we expect gradual disinflation in the medium term, provided that domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11 and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environ-ment for agricultural and other producers. The main risks to this forecast stem from possible failure to tighten fiscal policy as projected, a weaker than expected peso and the difficult process of reining in nominal wage growth. However, if the government is able to tackle the high level of wage indexation, there is also the potential for inflation to slow more quickly than we currently project.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The peso has weakened modestly since late May, reflecting some contagion effects from Brazil's political crisis, but at Ps16.1:US$1 in late June, the currency was only slightly weaker than the end-2016 level of Ps15.9:US$1. We expect further modest weakening of the peso in 2017-21, particularly in 2017-18, as domestic interest rates decline and the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) continues a monetary tightening cycle. However, the positive outlook for portfolio and foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will be supportive of the currency, which will dampen depreciation pressure and produce some periods of real currency appreciation (as occurred in early 2017). In nominal terms, we expect the peso to end 2017 at Ps17.6:US$1 and 2021 at Ps23.37:US$1.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
An improvement in the terms of trade will help to widen the trade surplus and narrow the current-account deficit in 2017, to 2.1% of GDP. However, the terms of trade will gradually deteriorate in the remainder of the forecast period, producing a renewed narrowing of the trade surplus. On top of this, a still-strong peso will contribute to a persistently large services deficit, and the income deficit will widen as interest payments on a growing stock of external debt, along with repatriation of profits by multinationals operating in the country, increase. As a result, the current-account deficit will widen again gradually, to a peak of 2.9% of GDP in 2021. The country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits of this size has improved, and assuming that portfolio and FDI inflows rise as investor confidence grows, the result will be a rise in foreign reserves in nominal terms. Our forecasts currently assume FDI inflows averaging just under 2% of GDP in 2017-21, with foreign reserves equivalent to an annual average of eight months of import cover in the same period. This represents a substantial increase on 2015 levels, and mainly represents extremely high portfolio inflows in the past 18 months.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The struggle between an opposition-dominated legislature and a government with control of key institutions will keep tension high and sustain uncertainty regarding The Economist Intelligence Unit's political and economic forecasts. Despite the unpopularity of the administration led by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), and the persistent risk of economic collapse, we believe that the government will muddle through until the next elections are held in December 2018, after which we expect the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática coalition to take office. A risk exists that the PSUV will seek non-democratic ways to cling to power.
A fundamental rebalancing of the economy is needed to avoid default and economic collapse, but there has been no sign of significant economic reform. Policy mismanagement will persist while Mr Maduro remains in office. Key problems include extremely expansionary macroeconomic policy, soaring inflation and a business climate that discourages investment. A new government will begin a gradual process of adjustment from 2019.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the PSUV on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and triple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, and the increasingly difficult operating environment will accentuate the fall in fixed investment. The recession that began in 2014 will continue to deepen despite the partial recovery in oil prices and the economy will not return to growth until 2020. Our forecast for a weak recovery in 2020-21 rests on the assumption of a new government that implements macroeconomic adjustment alongside institutional and structural reform. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, and our forecasts imply only a partial recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production in 2017, and only a minor increase from 2018 as economic conditions stabilise.

Country forecast overview: Business environment rankings
               
Value of index a     Global rank b     Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21   2012-16 2017-21   2012-16 2017-21
4.11 4.48   78 79   12 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 79th position globally in our business environment rankings for 2017-21, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela moves ahead of Cuba to 11th place of the 12 countries covered, assuming improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Government's low approval ratings reduce the risk of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.
Fact sheet

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature, but its powers have been usurped by other branches of government dominated by the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). In May Mr Maduro announced that he wanted to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$5.8bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. The current-account deficit is estimated to have fallen from 4.3% of GDP in 2015 to 2.1% of GDP in 2016.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Amid the most severe economic crisis in the country's history, Venezuela's political scene will remain dominated by a volatile power struggle between the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) government, led by the president, Nicolás Maduro, and the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD), which won a majority in the National Assembly in late 2015. Political tension has escalated amid growing signs that the government is seeking to cling to power through non-democratic means. In late May Mr Maduro announced rules, heavily skewed in the regime's favour, for the selection of members to a constituent assembly charged with rewriting the constitution promulgated by his predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). Constitutional reform proposals seem designed both to reduce the role of the elected National Assembly and to postpone, perhaps indefinitely, national elections due to be held in December 2018. Before this, the government used its control of key state institutions to scupper opposition efforts to hold a recall referendum (allowed under the constitution) this year to remove Mr Maduro. The government also effectively eliminated the National Assembly's legislative powers. Violent public protests have ensued in response (with over 60 civilians killed since April); these show little sign of letting up, but are unlikely to weaken the Maduro government's hold on power.
This grip on authority is largely based on the continuing support of the military, which will play a decisive role in future political developments. The govern-ment has, to date, secured military backing by eliminating dissent in its upper echelons and by including the military in a system of patronage that has given it significant policymaking powers. It is not certain to what extent the military would be willing to support the government if it were to attempt to hold onto power by non-democratic means.
There have been instances in the recent past in which the military and other political actors have been seen to intervene to force the government to respect democratic norms. After the legislative election in 2015, the defence minister, Vladimir Padrino López, affirmed publicly that the army would uphold the constitution. Earlier in 2017 the attorney-general, Luisa Ortega, criticised a Supreme Court attempt to take over the National Assembly's powers, which was subsequently abandoned. More recently, she disparaged plans to rewrite the constitution. All of this suggests that there are limits to support for the beleaguered Maduro administration from its allies in the military and elsewhere. The opposition is working to encourage defectors from within government and military ranks. It is possible that it may offer immunity from prosecution as an enticement to switch sides. On this basis, The Economist Intelligence Unit still expects the elections in December 2018 to take place, and for the MUD, which would be the clear favourite, to win, taking power in 2019. But there is a high risk that the PSUV, with the backing of the armed forces, will attempt to cling to power beyond this date. Given the scale of opposition to the government, and the increasingly limited means of addressing opposition concerns via institutional channels, there is also a strong risk of some sort of chaotic, violent political transition, particularly in the context of a crippling economic crisis that the government has shown little willingness or capacity to address.
Assuming that an MUD-led government does take power, it would implement economic adjustments to reduce the role of the state in the economy, and unravel the many macroeconomic and monetary distortions that the PSUV has implemented since it came to power in 1999. It will also begin the difficult task of reforming deeply politicised institutions. Given the scale of the economic distortion and institutional destruction that has taken place in Venezuela, as well as the heterogeneous nature of the MUD-which is aligned mainly in its desire to remove the current government from office-the process will not be a smooth one. Weak institutional capacity and high political tension will persist throughout the 2017-21 forecast period.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
With the next presidential election due in December 2018, the electoral authorities are placing a host of obstacles in the MUD coalition's path, forcing most parties to re-register and banning a leading opposition figure and presidential frontrunner, Henrique Capriles, from running for election for 15 years, citing "administrative irregularities" in his tenure as governor of Miranda state. Nevertheless, assuming that open elections are held, we expect the MUD to win by a substantial margin (as it did in legislative elections in 2015). The timing of the elections is, however, increasingly uncertain. The contro-versial constitutional redrafting proposed by Mr Maduro entails a long rewriting process and will be put to a nationwide referendum, all of which would take time and could be used as a pretext for delaying elections. The position of the military towards any such efforts, and to the election process itself, will be decisive, and the risks to our forecasts are unusually high.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Venezuela is isolated diplomatically amid growing regional and international censure of the Maduro regime, although this is doing little to weaken the government's grip on power. The government has announced its withdrawal from the Organisation of American States (OAS, an institution promoting regional co-operation, and a frequent election observer), pre-empting a probable suspension from the organisation. Venezuela was suspended from Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) in late 2016. Although relations with neighbouring countries such as Colombia will deteriorate in the short term, the Maduro administration appears to be more concerned with retaining good relations with China (a key creditor), and with not provoking the US administration, presumably to avoid economic measures by that country, such as a cut in oil imports, which would hit Venezuela extremely hard. US-Venezuela tension would escalate if the PSUV government were to attempt to cling to power by suspending the next elections. Reflecting its external financing difficulties, Venezuela will continue to scale back-and possibly end-oil shipments to beneficiaries of PetroCaribe, an agreement that provides cheap financing for oil exports to regional allies. Relations with Cuba, the closest of these allies, will become more distant as Venezuela's ability to provide assistance is eroded.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
It is unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without some sort of policy adjustment between now and the presidential election. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017-18 than it did last year. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or unable to adjust policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy interventionism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Slightly higher oil prices than in 2014-16 will bring some relief, but import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. International reserves totalled US$10.1bn in early May, far below historical levels, and down by about 20% year on year. Even after a 2016 restructuring of debt owed by PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, substantial external debt payments are falling due in 2017-18. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA (it made a US$2.1bn coupon payment in April). However, given the extremely thin reserves cushion, the risk of default remains high; this would have dramatic economic and political consequences in the form of a sharp decrease in oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and political turmoil.
We expect the opposition to take power in 2019, ushering in much-needed market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of over US$16bn in 2019-21. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.6% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. The election of a new government should help to ease the deficit to about 6% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply (M2) rose by 230% year on year in April, the highest rate on record. High inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability.
There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. In 2016 the government undertook a bond swap that saw about US$2.8bn of PDVSA debt due in 2017 pushed out to 2020. Even after this deal, we continue to see an extremely high risk of default, although the government has emphasised its commitment to pay, and we expect the next administration to follow through with its debt-servicing and repayment obligations.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. Amid extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. From 2019 our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that, after a massive contraction in GDP in 2016 (estimated at 14%), we project a further contraction, of 7%, in 2017 (this represents a downward revision from last month, reflecting the effect on activity of ongoing widespread protests). We do not expect the government to make the necessary adjustments to bring about economic recovery, and expect recession to persist into 2019. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a decline in real GDP of nearly 30% in 2014-19.
After dropping by an estimated 20.2% in 2016, private consumption will contract further in 2017-18, reflecting the effect of soaring inflation on real wages, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in invest-ment in 2019-21 assumes a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in energy and-later in the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting renewed investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from recession. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep reces-sion. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but since the start of the year the National Assembly has begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation at 16.5% in April, bringing accumu-lated inflation for January-April to 92.8%. Assuming that price pressures remain high in the first half of 2017 at least, we expect average inflation to be higher this year, at 591%, than in 2016. However, we continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, reflecting moderately higher oil prices, which will bring in the necessary foreign exchange to help to alleviate scarcity of goods, and the effect of persistent recession on demand. From 2019 fiscal and monetary policy adjustment will also be supportive of a gradual reduction in inflation towards double-digit levels (in year-on-year terms). However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2017-18, but the exchange rate will still be extremely overvalued. The dual exchange-rate system is composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom. The government revamped the Dicom system at end-May, and at its first auction (two per week are planned) sold US$24.1m at Bs2,010:US$1, implying a 65% devaluation of the Dicom rate. However, the Dicom accounts for only 10% of all official transactions. In real terms, the average exchange rate (weighted by volume of transactions) has continued to appreciate, creating ever greater pressure for currency adjustment, the need for which is evident in the black-market rate; this stood at BsF6,100:US$1 in late May.
The pegged Dipro rate appears increasingly unsustainable, and we assume that the government will devalue the rate to BsF20:US$1 later this year and again in 2018 (to BsF400:US$1). We also assume that the government will increase the share of Dicom in foreign-currency transactions-in effect a maxi-devaluation. We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. In the meantime, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued gradual decline in oil output. The deficit will widen thereafter, on the assumption that economic recovery draws in imports on a large scale after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021, reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is pressing ahead with a programme of economic policy adjustment in an effort to eliminate distortions and return the economy to sustainable growth. The adjustment process is proving difficult, involving politically unpopular austerity measures, and the risk of social unrest will therefore remain significant for much of the forecast period.
Given the president's minority position in Congress, and the priority given to urgent macroeconomic reforms, there is likely to be only limited progress on the pursuit of legislation that would successfully address longstanding institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Comprehensive reforms to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. Furthermore, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect meaningful advances-at least in the short term-on a structural reform agenda (incorporating tax and labour market reform) that could improve long-term potential growth rates.
After a contraction in real GDP in 2016, reflecting macroeconomic policy tightening and currency depreciation, we are forecasting a pick-up in exports, investment and private consumption in the medium term. There will be a boost in business confidence from policy tightening. Combined with macroeconomic adjustment, and a gradual removal of foreign-exchange and import controls, these policies should set the economy on a more solid long-term footing. However, some aspects of the policymaking environment will remain suboptimal, with labour-market reform and a comprehensive fiscal reform remaining low on the agenda.
Currency adjustment should gradually bolster the current account as a weaker peso starts to boost goods and services exports and rein in imports. On this basis, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow in 2017-21 from the 2016 peak. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve over the forecast period, assuming that capital inflows pick up as investor confidence in the Macri administration grows.
Argentina's GDP per head is still among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

Argentina's global business environment score improves substantially in 2017-21, and the country jumps 20 places in our global ranking. A period of economic policy adjustment is under way as the centre-right government works to tighten macroeconomic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. However, in many areas improve-ments will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2019-21: Continued work to build confidence in legal and regulatory framework. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2017-18: Efforts to resolve any remaining disputes with international creditors and investors as the government seeks fresh sources of US dollar inflows.
2019-21: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Any remaining foreign-exchange controls likely to be removed. Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance.
2019-21: Possibility that free-trade agreements make better progress.
Taxes
2017-18: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax system remains complex and burdensome.
2019-21: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist.
Financing
2017-18: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2019-21: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2017-18: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of the unions will remain strong.
2019-21: Progress on labour reform unlikely. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The Macri administration works to address weak contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes, which keep private investment below potential. Financing constraints hamper public investment in the short term.
2019-21: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.

Background: Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983 after 50 years of instability and military regimes. A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances in the economy in the form of double-digit inflation, real peso appreciation and a deterioration of the balance of payments. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to foreign-exchange, import and capital controls, as well as ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to reduce economic distortions and set the economy on a more solid long-term footing are taking place under Mr Macri; these include peso devaluation, and fiscal and monetary tightening. Microeconomic reforms to boost domestic supply are also getting under way.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals). Taxes on exports were reintroduced in 2002, and have since been expanded to account for around 20% of total revenue.
Foreign trade: The current account shifted from surplus to deficit in 2010. Despite comprehensive controls, there was a current-account deficit of 2.7% of GDP in 2015.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The political scene is becoming more complicated as voter fatigue with austerity measures increases and patience with adjustment measures wears thin. An increase in obstructionism on the part of public-sector unions since March is unsurprising amid annual wage-bargaining negotiations that are taking place in the run-up to mid-term legislative elections in October. More of a concern for the president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is the continued perception among voters that adjustment is not bringing about obvious rapid improvements in the economy. Various economic indicators suggest that the economy is indeed emerging from recession, but consumers are not yet feeling the benefit in terms of higher real wages or increased employment.
The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Macri to change course and abandon the adjustment process that he has pursued since taking office for a four-year term in late 2015. This process has involved devaluation, fiscal and monetary tightening, and sharp tariff adjustments. In this environment, voter weariness with austerity, combined with the approach of mid-term legislative elections on October 22nd, will in the short term complicate relations with Congress, where the president lacks a majority. The ruling Cambiemos alliance, which includes the Pro and the centre-left Unión Cívica Radical, has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda in both houses of Congress on an ad hoc basis with the various factions of the large Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party). So far this support has mainly been forthcoming, not least because the Peronist party has had trouble regrouping under a clear leadership since it lost the presidency in 2015. The largest faction of the party, known as the Frente para la Victoria, has been weakened by a series of damaging corruption scandals, while moderate Peronists have frequently supported government legislation.
We expect obstructionism to increase amid election-related politicking surrounding a mid-term election in October 2017, and as a presidential election in October 2019 approaches. But mutual interest will ensure some continuing co-operation between Cambiemos and moderate Peronists. On top of this, a strong executive branch (the president has substantial powers to rule by decree) should provide Mr Macri with room for manoeuvre, even assuming that Congress becomes less co-operative. The president will also retain influence with powerful provincial governors, who largely control the agenda of the Senate (the upper house) but who are in turn deeply reliant on central government transfers, some of which are discretionary. As a result, we expect some continued progress on the govern-ment agenda. However, with electoral considerations coming into play, there will be limited progress on legislation that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Compre-hensive efforts to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. We do not expect meaningful advances on a structural reform agenda.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
Mid-term elections are set for October 22nd. Open, nationwide primary elections will be held on August 13th, but, in practice, Argentina's political parties continue to choose their candidates via internal selection processes, and the primaries will therefore serve as a sort of dress rehearsal for the main event. With the primaries now approaching, campaigning is beginning to dominate the political scene. We expect the Peronists to remain the largest political force in Congress after the mid-terms, given their dominance of provincial politics and strong grassroots presence. The ruling Pro and its partners in the Cambiemos coalition are currently in a minority position in both houses of Congress, and we do not expect this to change in the mid-terms. For Cambiemos, a more important marker is whether it gains or loses seats, and how it performs on the Buenos Aires congressional list (voters select party lists; this gauges both how popular the political parties are and how popular the leading candidates on each list are). A good performance in Buenos Aires by the Pro, although mainly symbolic and not enough to provide a majority in Congress, would send a signal of the government's popularity. This is important because the dominant Peronist party would be much less likely to support the legislative agenda of an unpopular government.
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and a return to single-digit inflation by then, we currently expect Mr Macri to win a second four-year term. There are substantial risks to this forecast, given the challenging external environment and the government's minority position in Congress. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. In this context, the emergence of a strong challenger from the moderate wing of the Peronist party is a substantial possibility and the election will be closely fought.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Efforts by the Macri administration to repair relations with trade and investment partners have achieved rapid results, and we expect relations with key trade partners in the region and elsewhere to remain strong. The Argentinian government will remain keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended from the group in 2016). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, free trade has shifted off the political agenda not only in the US but also in Europe. Mr Macri recently visited Spain in an effort to drum up support for a deal, and negotiations are continuing. Our forecasts do not currently assume a successful conclusion of free-trade talks with the EU, but the workings of intra-Mercosur trade are likely to improve in the forecast period. Efforts at joining the Pacific Alliance, a regional trading bloc that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico, may also make progress, although this is not currently reflected in our five-year economic forecasts.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
The Macri administration has made good initial progress on a programme of adjustment intended to put the economy on a sounder footing, having devalued the peso, reduced agricultural export duties and energy subsidies, and secured a deal with holdout creditors (allowing Argentina to exit default). However, macroeconomic adjustment remains incomplete, and policy efforts to reduce inflation will continue, in the form of tight fiscal and monetary policy and restraint in nominal wage growth. The latter in particular is proving a difficult political challenge, and has encountered stiff union resistance. The government is extremely unlikely to meet its goal of limiting nominal wage growth to 20% this year, but we do continue to expect nominal wages to trend downwards steadily from levels of above 30% in recent years. All of these measures should gradually engender price stability and ultimately boost investor confidence, although we do not expect inflation to fall to single-digit levels until 2019.
With macroeconomic adjustment measures proceeding apace, the government is gradually turning its attention to the structural reform agenda and to reforms to improve the business environment, and we expect a growing policy emphasis on these areas. The government has already passed new public-private partnership framework legislation that should facilitate an increase in infrastructure investment, along with reforms to reduce red-tape financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. The development of longer-term finance and the deepening of Argentina's currently shallow capital markets will be a priority. However, other aspects of the policymaking environ-ment will remain suboptimal, with progress on labour-market reform (to improve flexibility) or comprehensive fiscal and tax reform (to reduce costs and complexity) unlikely in the medium term amid political obstruction.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Higher-than-expected revenue from a tax amnesty on undeclared foreign assets will bolster the fiscal accounts and allow the government to meet its target of narrowing the primary deficit to 3.9% of GDP in 2017, slightly below the 4.3% of GDP primary deficit registered in 2016. We expect the government's gradualist approach to fiscal tightening to continue in subsequent years, bringing the overall fiscal deficit down to a more manageable level of 3.4% of GDP by the end of the forecast period, by which time the primary deficit will have been brought to about 1% of GDP. The govern-ment has taken some important steps in the past 18 months to try to narrow the deficit, particularly by reducing costly subsidies and the public-sector payroll. Even so, in the light of recently announced income-tax breaks and increased transfers (to expand the social safety net), deficit reduction will be slow.
In the aftermath of the holdout deal, and assuming that there is progress on deficit reduction, the government's ability to finance moderate deficits without resorting to inflationary money printing will be much improved. A moderate public debt/GDP ratio (and low levels of external indebtedness), combined with the attractiveness of Argentina's still-high yields, should facilitate international bond issuance in 2017-21, following Argentina's exit from default earlier this year. In January the sovereign issued US$7bn in five- and ten-year global bonds. As a percentage of GDP, the public debt will stabilise at slightly under 50% in 2017-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Notwithstanding a recent policy reversal, which saw the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) lift the policy rate from 24.75% to 26.25% in April, we continue to expect fairly substantial rate cuts in the second half of 2017 and beyond. The policy rate is below the year-earlier peak of 38%, but inflation has been slow to come down amid a series of tariff increases, and inflation expectations have been rising as a result, to slightly over 21% at end-2017, well above the central bank's 12-17% target range for this year. The BCRA responded with what we expect to be a one-off rate rise to make its commitment to the newly implemented inflation-targeting framework clear. Assuming that monthly inflation starts to fall towards 1% on a consistent basis, we expect ample scope for renewed monetary easing from later this year.
The central bank has made it clear that it will prioritise monetary policy that is conducive to a reduction of inflation, and our forecasts assume moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term, consistent with a deepening of credit and the development of long-term lending. This forecast is supported by the shift to an inflation-targeting regime (with the target due to be lowered to 8-12% in 2018 and 5% in 2019), and by reduced political interference after a period of politicisation under the previous administration.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
After a contraction in real GDP of 2.3% in 2016, we expect a return to positive territory in 2017. But with Brazil likely to post barely positive growth in 2017 amid an escalating political crisis, manufacturing activity in Argentina will recover only moderately, limiting GDP growth to 2.5%. We currently expect the recovery to peak in 2018, with growth of 3.6%. However, the annual growth rate for that year masks an expected sequential deceleration in the second half of 2018, resulting from a projected weakening of Chinese import demand. By 2019, when we project a cyclical downturn in the US economy, real GDP growth in Argentina will slide back below 3%, before a modest recovery takes hold in 2020-21.
Our forecast for a relatively robust recovery in the medium term is based on the assumption that a combination of macroeconomic adjustment and improve-ments to the business environment will eventually have some beneficial impact on both export activity and domestic demand. An easing of inflation, combined with efforts by the Macri government to address the problem of legal and regulatory uncertainty and reduce red tape, should set the stage for renewed strong growth in fixed investment and private consumption, support-ing an acceleration of GDP growth. On the supply side, growth should be bolstered in 2017 and into the medium term by a positive outlook for agriculture, and for investment in both infrastructure (which should see construction activity accelerate rapidly) and energy, including renewables.
There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to reduce economic distortions and engineer a smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging, keeping both con-sump-tion and investment subdued for longer than we expect. However, there is also some upside risk, as investment could overtake expectations from 2017 once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and depending on the success of efforts to improve the framework for doing business. However, even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform efforts than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than 4%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation will decline steadily but gradually in the forecast period, from a rate of 29.4% in April (according to the Buenos Aires city price index). Although high, the April result does represent a steep fall from a peak of 44.4% in May 2016, which resulted from currency and tariff adjust-ments by the new administration. Assuming tight monetary and fiscal policy (spending will remain negative in real terms until 2018), the inflationary spike will prove transitory, and we expect gradual disinflation in the medium term, provided that domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11 and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environ-ment for agricultural producers. The main risks to this forecast stem from possible failure to tighten fiscal policy as projected, a weaker than expected peso and the difficult process of reining in nominal wage growth. However, if the government is able to tackle the high level of wage indexation, there is also the potential for inflation to slow more than we currently project.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The peso weakened modestly in late May and early June, reflecting modest contagion effects from Brazil's political crisis, but at Ps16.1:US$1 in early June, the currency was only slightly weaker than the end-2016 level of Ps15.9:US$1. We expect some further modest weakening of the peso in the rest of the five-year forecast period, particularly in 2017-18, as domestic interest rates decline and the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) continues a monetary tightening cycle. However, the positive outlook for portfolio and foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will be supportive of the currency, which will dampen depreciation pressure and produce some periods of real currency appreciation (as occurred in early 2017). In nominal terms, we expect the peso to end 2017 at Ps17.61:US$1 and 2021 at Ps23.38:US$1.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
As the terms of trade improve and a weaker peso gradually boosts goods and services exports, improvements in the trade and services accounts will cause the current-account deficit to narrow. From an estimated 2.6% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to fall to an annual average of 1.1% of GDP in 2017-21. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve, assuming that portfolio and FDI inflows pick up as investor confidence grows. The result will be a rise in foreign reserves in nominal terms. Our forecasts currently assume FDI inflows averaging 2% of GDP in 2017-21, with foreign reserves equivalent to an annual average of just over eight months of import cover in the same period.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text: Austria--highlights: Political outlook
An early election will take place in October 2017, called after the "grand coalition" government of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) and the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) fell apart in May. The election will be a three-horse race between the coalition parties and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). The Economist Intelligence Unit sees a coalition including the FPÖ emerging from the election as the most likely scenario, which will push policy on issues such as immigration and integration to the right. The system of social partnerships, which has for decades ensured political and policy stability, is likely to fray further during the forecast period (2017-21), weighing on the efficiency of the policymaking and implementation processes.
Austria--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2011 2016 2021
Total 8.4 8.6 8.7
 Male 4.1 4.2 4.3
 Female 4.3 4.4 4.4
Period averages (%)   2012-16 2017-21
Population growth   0.3 0.3
Working-age population growth   0.1 -0.1
Labour force growth   1.5 0.5
The population will grow at an annual average of 0.3% over the forecast period, supported above all by net migration. As in many other developed countries, the population will age. The share of the total population accounted for by people of working age is expected to decline slightly over the next five years. Immigration from eastern Europe will remain strong. The influx of migrants and refugees from Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq, which pushed up the population figure in 2015, is not expected to be repeated. All three leading parties have called for restrictions on freedom of movement within the EU, albeit to different degrees, and we expect such calls to become stronger in the likely case of the FPÖ achieving a place in a new governing coalition in late 2017.
Austria--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.62 7.76 19 18 12 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment will improve slightly in the forecast period, compared with the historical period (2012-16), helping it to rise by one place in both our global and regional rankings, to 18th and 11th respectively. The improvement is driven in large part by an improving financing environment and increased market opportunities as economic growth accelerates. The political environment, which is already less stable than many of its regional peers, will deteriorate further in the forecast period. However, the overall business environment remains relatively strong as infrastructure is of high quality, spending on research and development (R&D) is high, and the labour market continues to function relatively well.
Austria--highlights: Economic outlook
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021

3-month Treasury rate (av; %) -0.3 -0.2 0.0 0.1 0.2 0.3
Exchange rate [euro]:US$ (av) 0.90 0.93 0.92 0.90 0.89 0.87
After a relatively robust recovery from the global financial crisis in 2008-09, Austria has underperformed compared with its regional peers, notably Germany, with average growth of only 0.6% in 2012-15. Growth picked up in 2016, to 1.6%, and we expect another slight acceleration in 2017-18, to 1.7% on average, in part reflecting pent-up demand. Growth will moderate after that, to 1.4% on average in 2019-21. International competitiveness remains an issue and will continue to weigh on the outlook for export growth, as we expect little progress on reforms to address this. Nevertheless, a sizeable surplus on services exports, driven in large part by tourism, will keep the current account in surplus.
Austria--highlights: Market opportunities
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021

Household consumption (US$ bn) 203.2 204.4 212.0 223.9 234.8 247.1
Household consumption per head (US$) 23,680 23,760 24,570 25,900 27,090 28,450
Austria is a wealthy country by international standards, with GDP per head well above the regional average. Household consumption growth has been subdued in recent years, and negative labour market trends and high savings rates mean that the country did not benefit as much from oil price-related real income gains in recent years as other countries. Throughout the forecast period the outlook for household incomes and consumption is more positive as the labour market recovers. An ageing demographic profile and a rise in the number of single-person households will continue to drive demand for housing, healthcare and leisure services. Income inequalities will remain lower than the regional average.
Austria--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2017-30 2031-50 2017-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)
Growth of real GDP per head 1.2 1.2 1.2
Growth of real GDP 1.5 1.2 1.3
Labour productivity growth 1.1 1.2 1.2
Real GDP per head is forecast to grow by an annual average of 1.2% in 2017-50. An ageing demographic profile will act as a drag on long-term growth prospects, although Austria has more scope than some other EU countries to raise levels of participation in the labour force, particularly among older workers and women. There is also potential for an improvement in productivity growth, with the government encouraging greater R&D activity and investment in education. Austria's large trade and investment exposure to central and eastern Europe will be a net positive for growth in the long term.
