Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. An early general election will be held on October 15th 2017.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second-highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.8bn and the goods import bill was US$143bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.3bn. Along with a modest primary income deficit and significant secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.7% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The "grand coalition" of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) and the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), which had been renewed at the general election in September 2013, fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of the ÖVP vice-chancellor. The next election looks set to be a three-horse race between the SPÖ, the ÖVP and the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). Although the FPÖ has been on the political scene for decades, support for the party increased sharply during the European migrant crisis in 2015-16. Neverthe-less, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the ÖVP to become the largest party after the election, driven in large part by the popularity of its young leader, the foreign minister, Sebastian Kurz. Several smaller parties will contest the election but these generally do not attract enough support to play a major role or to be able to make up the numbers for a majority coalition, which is likely to consist of the ÖVP and the FPÖ.

Political outlook: Political stability
Following several years of little progress on reforms, and coalition and party infighting, the grand coalition fell apart in May 2017 following the resignation of Reinhold Mitterlehner from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister for the economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. The popular 30-year-old Mr Kurz has taken over the leadership of the ÖVP. However, probably owing to the party's recent poor performance in the polls-it has languished in third place over the past year-Mr Kurz decided to leverage his own popularity by demanding full control over the party and that it would appear on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party", which would also include people not previously associated with the ÖVP. Following Mr Kurz's arrival as party leader, the ÖVP shot to the top of the polls, pushing the opposition FPÖ to third place, from first. This "Kurz effect" could wane slightly in the coming months, as he will be forced to continue working in the dysfunctional coalition, will face increasing scrutiny of his policies and will need time to build new structures to lead a reformed ÖVP. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the election to be a three-horse race between the ÖVP, the SPÖ and the FPÖ, with the ÖVP currently best placed to emerge as the largest party in the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house of parliament).
Nevertheless, the election will be a next step in the fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP, as the latter will have been effectively replaced by Mr Kurz's new movement. The two parties have together ruled the country almost continuously since 1945, and a renewed grand coalition has become almost impossible following the breakdown of relations between the two parties and the gridlock in recent years. The FPÖ has profited from this and from concerns over immigration, although Mr Kurz looks to be drawing voters away from the FPÖ in large part based on his strong stance on immigration and border control.
The most likely coalition to emerge after the election is one led by the ÖVP, with the FPÖ as a junior coalition partner, as the other parties-including the Greens and NEOS, a liberal party-are unlikely to be large enough to help either the SPÖ or the ÖVP to reach a parliamentary majority. Risks to this outlook are high, as the election could turn and the coalition negotiations could falter because the FPÖ will probably demand significant concessions from Mr Kurz. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deter-iorate further. The government will struggle to implement its policies, as the coalition partners are likely to disagree on economic matters, and the FPÖ is likely to struggle to translate its opposition on matters such as immigration and integration into concrete policy proposals.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The state has a well-established division of power between its legislative, executive and judicial branches, all of which function well by international standards. The extent of interaction between the government and its social partners has varied over the past decade, but we expect this to become increasingly contentious during the forecast period (2017-21) as the post-war consensus continues to fray. Government decisions have occasionally bypassed the social partnership system (Sozialpartnerschaft), which establishes a co-operative relationship with trade unions and employers on aspects of economic policy-making. Membership of the Sozialpartnerschaft is compulsory and its role has been made explicit in law. On the whole, the social partners are encouraged by government to participate in drafting proposals and bills relating to specific issues. As a result, the social partners have been involved in negotiations on issues such as public healthcare reform, opening Austria's labour market to workers from new EU member states and improving education. The framework has tended to advantage the traditional main-stream parties and decreased in influence when the FPÖ was in government in 2000-05. As the chance of the FPÖ being included in government following the election in October 2017 is high, the influence of the Sozialpartnerschaft on shaping industrial relations is likely to diminish over the forecast period.
Austria's nine federal states (Länder) each have an elected legislature, a state government and a governor, but have fewer direct powers than states in some other federal countries, including Germany. A high proportion of tax revenue is collected at the federal level, although there is some pressure to increase fiscal federalism. Although spending is more decentralised, decision-making is largely concentrated at the federal level, with sub-national governments mainly tasked with the administration and implementation of programmes. The principle of finanzausgleich (fiscal equalisation) regulates the distribution of revenue at the federal level between the states. Co-ordination between the different layers of government is strong but also complex, and the lack of accountability and transparency contributes to inefficiencies in the fiscal framework and a high level of bureaucracy. In recent years several attempts have been made to reform this system but these have not led to noteworthy improvements and we do not expect a significant streamlining of policy-making and implementation processes.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for October 15th 2017. The most likely scenario is for the rebranded ÖVP under Mr Kurz to win the largest share of the vote, although not an outright majority, and subsequently to form a coalition with the FPÖ.
Elections for some state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president is in 2023.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Christian Kern (SPÖ)
Mr Kern shot into the spotlight in May 2016 when the then federal chancellor, Werner Faymann, resigned and Mr Kern was nominated by his party to replace him. Originally a business journalist, Mr Kern moved through a position as spokesman for the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) to become the chief of the Austrian railways in 2010, a position that he held until becoming the federal chancellor in May 2016. Despite some hope at the time that he would be able to reinvigorate the grand coalition between the SPÖ and the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP), especially after the parties presented a renewed agreement in early 2017, he was unable to hold the coalition together following the resignation of the ÖVP vice-chancellor, Reinhold Mitterlehner. Mr Kern will now run as the candidate for chancellor for the SPÖ in the election in October. He will emphasise his vision to modernise the country, which he set out in a plan presented earlier in 2017 called "Plan A". However, most opinion polls in May-June 2017 put Mr Kern and his party in second place, behind the ÖVP and Sebastian Kurz, the ÖVP leader.
Sebastian Kurz (ÖVP)
Mr Kurz is the charismatic leader of the ÖVP. He was appointed as foreign minister in 2013, becoming Europe's youngest at the age of 27. Although his appointment was initially met with scepticism in Austria, he quickly established a reputation as a competent and hard-working minister, building his profile by hosting high-level diplomatic talks in Vienna, the capital, for example on the Iran nuclear deal. His response to the European migrant crisis in 2015-16, when he co-ordinated the closure of the route through the Balkans for migrants entering Europe via Greece, cemented his position as the leader-in-waiting of the ÖVP, which itself struggled badly in competition with the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). He attached several conditions to taking over the leadership of the party, which included getting full control, rebranding it on the ballot as "List Sebastian Kurz-the New People's Party" and putting forward parliamentary candidates from outside the ÖVP. Polls conducted after he took over the leadership showed that his personal popularity pushed the party from third place to first. Mr Kurz will go into the election as the main candidate for the chancellorship.
Heinz-Christian Strache (FPÖ)
Mr Strache, the leader of the FPÖ, born in June 1969, has positioned his party as a more radical opposition force than it was before he took over the leadership in 2005. He has focused the party's agenda on a firm anti-EU, anti-immigration and law-and-order stance. The FPÖ is the largest opposition party in Austria and shot to first place in the polls in the wake of the European migrant crisis in 2015-16. Despite the FPÖ's often radical right-wing views, its strength in recent polls and elections, including in the presidential election in 2016 when its candidate made it to the second-round run-off, means that it is becoming increasingly difficult for the mainstream parties to ignore Mr Strache. The arrival of Mr Kurzwhom Mr Strache has accused of stealing the FPÖ's ideasas leader of the ÖVP has pushed the party down to third place in the polls. As another grand coalition looks almost impossible and the FPÖ remains relatively strong, it is highly likely that the FPÖ will be prominent in the coalition formation process after the next election. Mr Strache is therefore likely to remain at the forefront of the political scene in the coming years.
Political outlook: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its domestic politics and international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the rise of the FPÖ, and it seems to have driven the government to lower its annual cap on asylum applications. The government has repeatedly hinted that it wants to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens in the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
We expect a new government to continue along the same line, as most parties have supported such an approach. Although the previous inclusion of the FPÖ in government following the election in 1999 led to sanctions being imposed by other EU nations in 2000, we do not expect this to be repeated should it join the next governing coalition. Whereas at that time a far-right nationalist party entering government was a relatively unusual development, since then sister parties to the FPÖ have either entered government or supported minority governments in parliament in several EU countries, including several Nordic countries and the Netherlands.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Norbert Hofer, the FPÖ candidate-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU did not reform or if Turkey joined. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.

Austria's population was estimated at 8.6m in 2016, an increase of around 300,000, or 3.6%, over the past decade. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a further rise to 8.7m by the end of the forecast period, in 2021. However, these figures slightly understate population growth in the past two years, as the UN data that we use for comparability across countries is not updated as regularly as the national source data. Natural change (more births than deaths) has been a contributor to population growth since the mid-1980s, but the main driver in recent years has been net migration. According to Statistics Austria, annual net immigration increased from 3,880 people in 1996 to a record 113,067 people in 2015. This was driven in large part by the sizeable intake of refugees in the second half of the year. As this movement came to a halt in the first half of 2016, the figure for 2016 was more in line with the years before 2015, at 64,676. We expect this source of population growth to be less pronounced in the coming years.
The share of foreign nationals in the population is relatively high
The share of registered foreign nationals in the total population is one of the highest in Europe, at just above 13% at the start of 2017, up from 7.4% in 2001. The high proportion of foreign nationals is related to the naturalisation process being longer than in many other EU countries, although the number of people granted citizenship has been increasing fairly rapidly since 2011. Around two-thirds of foreign nationals are from non-EU countries, with the majority from former Yugoslavia and Turkey. Measures limiting access to the Austrian labour market for citizens from the ten EU member states that joined in May 2004 were removed in April 2011. Restrictions on immigration from Romania and Bulgaria were removed in 2014. The government has suggested European-wide measures to limit migration but has so far been rebuffed by its European part-ners. We therefore expect inward migration to continue in the forecast period, mostly from newer member states and non-EU member states in the region.
Austria's population will age as it continues to grow slowly
As elsewhere in the developed world, the population will age owing to a low, albeit slightly increasing, fertility rate (at 1.48 children born per woman in 2016 compared with 1.41 in 2005). Nevertheless, we expect the population to grow by 0.3% in 2017-21, the same growth rate as in 2012-16. The ageing population is reflected in our forecast for average life expectancy, which is projected to rise from 80.9 years in 2012-16 to 81.9 years in 2017-21. The number of people aged under 15 is forecast to be unchanged relative to the total population between 2016 and 2021, at 14%. Over the same period the population aged 65 or over will rise from 19.1% to 20.2% of the total population. Highlighting the demographic challenge for the economy, the size of the working-age population will stagnate at around 5.7m as it declines by 0.1% on average in 2017-21.
Focus is on boosting labour force participation among older workers
Faced with a declining pool of young, skilled employees, policymakers have acknowledged the need to boost employment among older workers. Reforms of the state-run pension system are an example of this shift in policy, with one of the main aims being to reverse the long-standing trend towards early retirement. The effective retirement age is currently several years below the statutory level, particularly for men. Currently, retirement is possible from the age of 62 for men and from the age of 60 for women (subject to 37.5 years of contributions or credits). However, the legal retirement age for women will be gradually brought into line with that for men between 2024 and 2033. For each year that retirement is taken early-before the age of 65-the pension is lowered by 4.2%. Additional measures have been introduced to improve labour market opportunities for older workers (where employment levels at present are below the EU average), including employer incentives to retain and hire older employees, increased funding for re-training schemes and efforts by the Public Employment Service Austria to promote the employability of older workers. However, changing the attitudes of employers and employees will take time, and existing opportunities for early retirement are still being used extensively, which results in the unemployment rate for those aged 55 years and older being relatively low.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21), owing largely to improvements in financing, market opportunities and the macroeconomic environment. The country gains one place in the regional ranking, to 11th place, and one place in the global ranking, to 18th. Austria's strengths as a business location include stable political institutions (although this will deteriorate modestly), a system of social partnership that has facilitated wage moderation and good labour relations, and comparatively high spending on research and development (R&D).
Little progress on reforms is expected in the coming years
Austria's attractiveness as a business location will be held back by high taxes, a less stable political environment and restrictive regulations. Other issues include a lack of competition and excessive red tape in some markets, some opposition to foreign takeovers of domestic companies, and high business costs. The Austrian banking sector's profitability continued to recover in 2016, although this was driven by non-structural factors, such as further reductions in risk provisioning. The banking sector's geographical exposure to central and eastern Europe was further reduced in 2016, but remains substantial. Tighter regulatory requirements will support financial stability but will also affect profitability. Austria's reliance on the resilient German market for exports (accounting for 28% of exports in 2016) provides a solid foundation for export and economic growth. Austria's tax burden on labour income is the sixth highest in the OECD and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects only modest change on this front. We remain sceptical that tangible progress will be achieved to boost Austria's competitiveness during the forecast period. The election in October 2017 has increased the risks to the policy outlook more broadly, as it is likely to lead to the inclusion in government of the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ).
Business environment outlook: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited. Barriers to entry to network industries are likely to persist.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of the competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal. Progress on liberalisation of trade in services.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate. Little progress on EU-US trade deal. Free-trade agreement between the EU and the UK.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to the tax system, owing in part to a likely deterioration in government effectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely assuming a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power in 2017. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements and a reduction in risk from exposure to central and eastern Europe. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage is introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.8 8.0 22 15 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The macroeconomic environment is improving
Austria's macroeconomic environment score increases slightly in 2017-21, to 8.0, up from 7.8 in 2012-16. Owing to relatively poorer economic conditions else-where in the world, Austria climbs in the global ranking from 22nd to 15th place. However, in the regional ranking it remains in 8th. The risk of a serious escalation of the euro zone debt crisis has fallen significantly since mid-2012 following decisive pro-euro rhetoric by the European Central Bank (ECB) and the easing of the prospect of an imminent return of crisis conditions, after Greece secured a third bail-out in August 2015.
However, over the past five years the economy grew by only 0.8% on average per year. Although 2016 possibly marked the start of a period of catch-up growth, it remained relatively weak, at 1.6%. We expect real GDP growth of 1.8% in 2017, easing to 1.7% in 2018 and an average of 1.4% in the remainder of our five-year forecast period. There are some downside risks, especially relating to the uncertainty over euro zone growth after the vote by the UK to leave the EU and the potential impact of economic slowdowns in China in 2018 and the US in 2019.
Export competitiveness weakened in recent years
Sluggish economic reform progress and relatively high inflation (compared with the country's euro zone peers) have weakened Austrian export competitiveness. Therefore, export growth is likely to be below the country's potential. Austrian exporters hope to benefit from the ongoing recovery of the German economy-Austria's main export market.
Meanwhile, households' preference for saving rather than spending meant that in 2014-16 household consumption levels did not benefit from low oil prices as much as in many of Austria's European peers. Income tax reform in 2016 provided a moderate boost to consumption. However, the government has struggled to deliver some of the commitments made under its work programme and the early election makes any significant further progress unlikely. We expect any new government to struggle to implement significant growth-friendly structural reforms.
Macroeconomic stability will continue to benefit from relatively prudent fiscal policy and relatively benign public debt levels, benefiting from the clean-up and debt restructuring in late 2016 of Heta Asset Resolution (Heta), a "bad bank" that had been created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA) in 2014. Austria will continue to record a current-account surplus, which will remain broadly stable in the coming years as a weakening trade balance is offset by strong tourism receipts.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
7.8 7.5 20 22 12 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Gradual simplification of regulations on the policy agenda
We expect the government to continue to attempt structural reform to raise the economy's potential growth rate, regardless of the composition of the new coalition from October 2017. Restrictive regulations and high admin-istrative costs continue to limit competition in some markets, particularly in the services sector (such as retail trade). Progress has been made in reducing barriers to the creation, and in supporting the growth, of small companies. A recent example is a reduction in the amount of capital needed to form a Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung (GmbH; a company with limited liability), from EUR35,000 to EUR5,000 for the first ten years of its existence, which is more in line with the requirements in other EU countries.
Services trades and professions remain highly regulated
However, there is still considerable scope to reduce statutory and other regulations of services trades and professions. According to the OECD, the legal, broadcasting and accounting professions in Austria face a particularly high level of services trade restrictiveness. There is a high degree of state ownership and regulation in electricity generation and transmission, contributing to high network access prices and regional market concentration.
Despite improvements to the competition framework in recent years, there is still scope to strengthen the enforcement powers of the independent Federal Competition Authority (BWB). However, we expect only slow progress over the forecast period. Positively, the third EU energy liberalisation programme, imple-mented in 2009, should gradually lead to greater price transparency and higher customer mobility in the fields of electricity and gas. As part of these reforms, Austria is working to improve internal market mechanisms by unbundling transmission system operators from generation, production and supply.
The risk of political interference in private enterprise remains relatively high. On April 1st 2015 a new entity, Österreichische Bundes- und Industriebeteiligungen (ÖBIB), assumed responsibility for managing the Austrian state's holdings in several private companies, such as Telekom Austria and OMV, an oil producer. The changes allow for greater government involvement in the management of the firms. Moreover, the political composition of the nomination committee creates the potential for the selection of board members to become the subject of intra-coalition wrangling.
The retail sector has long been subject to heavy regulation, restricting the number and type of outlets, and hours of business. Although over the years there has been a significant liberalisation of shop opening hours, further liberalisation has faced opposition from a strong alliance between the trade unions and the Catholic Church, which wants to prevent shops from opening on Sundays and Catholic holidays.
In recent years there have been few privatisations of state-owned companies. The sale in 2008 of Austrian Airlines to Lufthansa, a German airline, was the most recent notable privatisation. Public opinion is generally sceptical towards privatisation. Nevertheless, several assets of HGAA have been sold off in recent years as part of its restructuring process, which was boosted in late 2016 by a clean-up and debt restructuring deal for Heta.
Austria's expenditure on R&D stood at 3.1% of GDP in 2016, up from 2.4% in 2005; this was well above the EU average of 2% (in 2015) and also above the EU target of 3% under the Europe 2020 strategy. Despite tight financing conditions in the private and public sectors, during the forecast period we expect Austria to move closer to its R&D target for 2020 of 3.76%.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
8.2 8.2 19 20 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Foreign investment will continue to be welcome
We expect Austria to continue to have a broadly welcoming attitude towards foreign direct investment (FDI). There are few specific restrictions on foreign ownership of companies and property, and regulations do not tend to discriminate between domestic and foreign-owned companies. There are no sectoral or geographic restrictions on FDI, but prospective foreign investors should be aware of strict environmental regulations and widespread concerns about the environmental impact of industry, which create some resistance to investment in the industrial sector.
Overall, Austria is open and welcoming to foreign investment, although there have been instances of protectionism and state intervention when facing the threat of a foreign takeover of a "national champion". This is the consequence of some negative experiences in the past. After Semperit, a tyre company, was taken over by Continental, a German group, the new owners moved the highly innovative R&D department to Germany, the machinery-paid for by the Austrian state-to the Czech Republic and closed down the Austrian factory. Only the brand name was kept. When a UK private equity group, CVC, raised a bid for a steelmaker, Böhler-Uddeholm in 2007, the government feared a loss of jobs through possible restructuring and engineered a takeover of Böhler by Voestalpine, an Austrian steel giant.
We expect Austria to maintain its close economic ties with central and east European countries, as opportunities in west European economies are limited owing to saturated markets. Austria will also retain its attractive position as a link between western, central and eastern Europe, which will continue to offer investment opportunities. Many Austrian firms distribute to central and east European countries at the wholesale level (although there remains significant room for improvement on transport links to the region). Many Austrian banks continue to operate significant networks in the region-despite some retrench-ment since the global financial crisis-and so can offer access to trade and investment financing for companies that want to do business in the area. However, exposure to central and eastern Europe entails risks, highlighted by ongoing concerns about political and security risks in Ukraine and tensions between the EU and Russia. Austria is among those countries with most to lose from a long-term decline in political re-lations with Russia, for example via finance, tourism, investment and construction channels.
The government has stated strong reservations about several of the EU's trade agreements that have been negotiated recently-including the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada-or are still under negotiation. Following the European migrant crisis in 2015-16 and struggles within the labour market to integrate the new migrant labour, the three largest political parties voiced reservations about the free movement of labour within the EU, and we expect Austria to remain an advocate for stricter rules surrounding this in the coming years.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
9.6 9.6 6 6 2 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's foreign trade and exchange policy will be that of the EU
We expect Austria to remain a member of the EU (and the euro area) over the forecast period. The country's foreign trade and exchange policy will be that of the EU. There will be no exchange controls, and trade policy will be determined by the EU's commitments to the World Trade Organisation (WTO). National political pressures to prevent job losses through state aid may at times conflict with EU rules, but the EU is unlikely to attempt to reverse the market opening to most types of merchandise trade that has taken place under WTO auspices. We expect the EU to abide by WTO dispute arbitration. However, no progress has been made in the Doha round of world trade negotiations since 2008 and prospects for the round look poor. A less comprehensive agreement focusing on "trade facilitation"-particularly expediting the movement, release and clearance of goods-was reached at a WTO meeting in December 2013 and entered into force in February 2017 following its ratification by two-thirds of WTO members. Within the EU, no tariffs or quotas are permitted, and the EU has succeeded in abolishing most other non-tariff trade restrictions, such as health regulations that favour domestically produced goods.
In the absence of an international agreement, the EU will continue to sign bilateral trade agreements, such as CETA. However, potentially the biggest agreement could be with the US. Talks between the EU and the US on a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) stalled in 2016 and we do not expect this agreement to go into effect during our five-year forecast period. The Austrian government generally supports free-trade agreements, but the government's programme for 2013-18 also states that Austria will continue to insist on the inclusion of social and ecological minimum standards in future EU trade and investment agreements.
The EU has a customs union with Turkey, includes Norway and Iceland in the European Economic Area (EEA), and has a range of bilateral agreements enabling free trade and other economic exchange with Switzerland. Agriculture is excluded from these arrangements. Outside agriculture, trade with non-EU countries is mostly subject to only moderate customs duties. The EU takes a liberal approach to trade in industrial goods. Average unweighted tariffs on these goods from "most-favoured nations", which cover most countries, are just below 4%. Although the EU occasionally takes controversial measures against alleged dumping, these have not undermined the broadly open regime and are unlikely to do so. A range of bilateral and regional agreements also provide for lower or zero tariffs and co-operation on non-tariff barriers.
The UK has decided to leave the EU in the forecast period. We expect the EU and the UK to reach at least a framework deal on the new trading relation-ship by the close of the two-year negotiating period, in March 2019. At that stage the UK will formally leave the single market, although the terms of the new relationship will be phased in gradually in order to minimise disruption. We expect the short- to medium-term impact of the Brexit vote to be an economic slowdown in the UK, weighing on exports and sentiment throughout the euro zone, and also affecting Austria, depressing GDP growth slightly.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.2 5.5 35 65 8 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Since 2001 successive governments have made little progress in lowering Austria's relatively high tax burden (total tax and social security contributions). Personal tax rates in Austria are relatively high by international standards, with income taxes and social security contributions combining to produce high marginal tax rates, particularly among middle-income earners. In 2016 Austria had the sixth-highest tax wedge (a measure of the tax on labour income) among the 35 OECD member countries, with the average single worker in Austria facing a tax wedge of 47.1%, compared with the OECD average of 36%. The tax regime for companies is more favourable than that for individuals, with the standard rate of corporation tax at 25%. The actual (effective) tax burden faced by companies in Austria-after taking into account differences in countries' tax base definitions and varying levels of tax relief-compares favourably with the EU's east European members, despite many having lower standard corporation tax rates.
Progress on tax reform but the tax burden remains high
In July 2015 Austria's parliament enacted a major reform of the country's tax system (Steuerreformgesetz 2015/2016), which expands the progressive income tax scale for individuals to six brackets, ranging from 25% to 55% (previously 50%); the reform took effect from January 1st 2016. Social security contribution tax credits and the tax-exempt allowance for children have been raised. These changes and the restructuring of the tax brackets mean that the overall effect will be mild tax relief for most individuals. The reform package also raises the with-holding tax on dividends (profit distributions) paid to a foreign parent company from 25% to 27.5%, but this increase does not apply to withholding tax on savings interest. Real estate capital gains tax has also been raised. Despite the recent tax reform, Austria still has one of the highest bottom statutory tax rates in the OECD, at 25% in 2016, down from 36.5% previously.
Despite these reforms, there is scope for further simplification, with tax laws still subject to numerous special rules and exceptions that reduce their transparency and distort economic activity. The government wants environ-mental and health considerations to play a stronger role in taxation, including a higher vehicle insurance tax, a vehicle tax on polluting cars, and higher taxes on alcohol and tobacco. The 2015/16 tax reform reduces tax incentives for carbon dioxide (CO2) emitting company cars from 2016 onwards, and other tax incentives are available for non-CO2 emitting company cars.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
6.6 8.1 26 15 9 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Credit conditions are set to improve significantly compared with 2012-16. The banking sector's exposure in central, east and south-east Europe (CESEE) remains significant, having caused large write-downs in the wake of the global financial crisis. The transfer of ownership in UniCredit Bank Austria's CESEE subsidiaries to its Italian parent bank in the second half of 2016 has significantly reduced the Austrian banking system's foreign risk exposure. Nevertheless, exposure to CESEE remains a systemic risk.
Positively, the CESEE region's macrofinancial conditions and economic dynamics have improved significantly. The asset quality in the banking sectors in CESEE have strengthened markedly amid progress on the resolution of non-performing loans (NPLs) and increases in profitability. However, uncertainty about the duration and effects of economic sanctions by and against Russia in the wake of the Ukraine crisis will continue to weigh on the short-term pro-spects for the Austrian banking sector. Raiffeisen Bank International and Bank Austria have sizeable Russian units that are exposed to the risk of intensifying sanctions and recession in Russia.
Austrian banks' capital ratios have continued to improve, but remain slightly below regional peers. Tighter regulatory requirements will continue to support financial stability, but will also maintain downward pressure on profitability. In a comprehensive stress test conducted by the European Banking Authority (EBA) in 2014 only one bank-Österreichische Volksbanken-failed. The EBA stress tests performed in 2016, which only included the two largest Austrian banks (Erste Group Bank and Raiffeisen Zentralbank Österreich), showed that even in the adverse scenario, the two banks' capital positions remained above the supervisory benchmark.
Recovery in profitability, but some risks persist
According to the December 2016 financial stability report by the Austrian Nationalbank (the central bank), the Austrian banking sector's profitability continued to recover in 2016, although this was driven by non-structural factors, such as further reductions in risk provisioning. The restructuring of UniCredit Bank Austria has reduced the total size of the Austrian banking system's NPL portfolio. However, major NPL volumes persist at some remaining subsidiaries and remain a burden for their new lending and profitability.
Financial-sector supervision lies with the Financial Market Authority (FMA), the Austrian Nationalbank and the ECB. To rein in banking-sector risk, in 2011 the central bank announced new capital rules and lending curbs for banks. Banks are required to adhere to tighter capital requirements given full implementation of Basel III rules from 2013. The FMA recently introduced a systemic risk buffer of up to 2% of risk-weighted assets to be phased in over 2016-19, in addition to earlier macroprudential measures that focus on stronger local funding of Austrian banks' subsidiaries abroad and fewer foreign-currency loans. Banks are subject to a loan/deposit ratio ceiling of 110% for lending in CESEE, and are required to write "living wills" to prepare for potential crises.
Domestically, the clean-up of the troubled HGAA bank was boosted in late 2016 by a debt restructuring deal for Heta. In October 2016 creditors holding almost all of the outstanding bonds of Heta accepted a debt restructuring deal, reducing Heta's debt load and moving its ultimate liabilities from the province of Carinthia to the federal government.
Despite a shift towards greater reliance on equity capital since Austria's entry into the EU, the stockmarket plays a smaller role in financing domestic companies than in many EU countries, with the bulk of financing still obtained through bank loans. However, corporates have increasingly been able to issue bonds, thus reducing their dependence on bank financing. According to the Austrian Nationalbank, in 2016 corporate bond issuance (volumes outstanding) rose by 3.8% in nominal terms, after a 3.6% rise in 2015. This trend is likely to continue.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The labour market has turned a corner after years of rising unemployment
The labour market continues to function relatively well. With few restrictions on hiring and firing, it remains more flexible than the labour markets of many other EU countries. Labour participation levels exceed euro area and OECD averages, the workforce is well qualified and productivity is similar to that in Germany. This is partly attributable to a consensual system of social partnership, which continues to offer unions and employers a co-operative role in policymaking and has contributed to traditionally strong labour relations, although this system is coming under increasing pressure.
However, low labour market participation by older workers, women and migrants remains an issue. In recent years the labour market has not been able to integrate an increased labour supply caused partly by the influx of migrants; this pushed up the unemployment rate, even though employment had been growing. However, the unemployment rate never reached any-where near the levels seen in many peripheral European economies and the labour market seems to have turned a corner in early 2017, with the unemployment rate falling again as labour supply growth moderated.
Because of its ageing workforce, Austria will become increasingly dependent on immigration to avoid shortages of skilled labour. However, ensuring that skilled immigrants are employed in jobs suited to their qualifications will remain a challenge given large numbers of highly skilled immigrants in low-skilled work. To this end, the government is seeking to improve the process whereby migrants' foreign qualifications are recognised in Austria. This has become an even bigger challenge following the influx of a large number of migrants and refugees, peaking in 2015 with net immigration of 113,067, according to Statistics Austria-the highest level since at least 1961. In 2016 net immigration eased slightly, but remained substantial, at 64,676. The number of job-seekers among those with migration backgrounds has risen significantly, according to the Public Employment Service Austria. Net inward movement is likely to continue in coming years, albeit at lower levels than in 2015-16.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21 2012-16 2017-21
9.2 9.3 5 5 5 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Transport links with southern and eastern neighbours need improvement
Austria benefits from excellent healthcare, telecommunications, transport and energy infrastructure. An extensive transport network provides good access to west European industrial centres. However, many aspects of Austria's transport links to its eastern and southern neighbours-although they have improved in recent years-require upgrades after years of underinvestment. This is particularly important in the light of the continuing rise in transit traffic (both east-west and north-south) through Austria, which is creating bottle-necks and raising environmental concerns about vehicle emissions. The co-alition government initially continued to implement the infrastructure projects announced by the previous government in its General Transport Plan for the period to 2025, but these have since been held back by financing difficulties given the substantial debt faced by the national road and rail authorities.
The infrastructure section in the government's programme for 2013-18 emphasises improving the interfaces between transport modes, in particular through the further development of freight terminals, stations, and park and ride facilities. Over the next 15 years investment to complete three large tunnels is estimated to total EUR50m-200m. In 2017 the government's infrastructure company, ASFiNAG, is investing EUR1.2bn in highways and expressways, with EUR530m going into new construction projects and EUR470m into renewal of existing roads and tunnels, and a further EUR200m is reserved for the construction of a state-of-the-art truck toll system.
Austria has a sophisticated telecoms network. Mobile telecommunications prices have fallen in recent years owing to increased competition, prompted by the entry of several new providers to the market. Internet services are well established and widespread, and fixed and mobile broadband subscriptions have grown strongly in recent years but remain above the levels seen in west and north European economies. Austria ranks highly for the range and sophistication of its online government services.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution (Heta), a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016 when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In its renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term, originally scheduled for October 2018. These included a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, although the coalition parties agreed to implement a number of these measures before the election in October, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects little progress, as both parties will be focused on the election and in the case of the Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) on reforming the party itself.
The next government, which is likely to include the Freedom Party (FPÖ), will move integration and immigration policy further to the right, but we would expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.3% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015 but widened again in 2016, to 1.5%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2017-21), albeit within 1% of GDP from 2018, as fiscal con-solidation will continue to be limited and growth solid but unspectacular. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 84.6% in 2016, following a positive contribu-tion from the Heta deal, to about 77% in 2021. In the context of the quanti-tative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021
Short-term interest rate (av) -0.3 -0.2 0.0 0.1 0.2 0.3
Long-term interest rate (av) 0.4 0.7 1.0 1.2 1.8 2.6
The euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum at present, and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and a EUR60bn per month QE programme, which will run until the end of 2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, stressed that the recent reduction in the pace of QE (from EUR80bn per month in March) was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.

Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany, which was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.6%, this remained below growth of 1.8% in Germany.
The economy's relatively lacklustre performance in recent years reflects a number of factors. Austria's domestic reform process has faltered and, along with higher inflation compared with its regional peers, this has weakened pro-ductivity and competitiveness, admittedly from fairly high levels, in relation to countries such as Germany and the Netherlands, hindering export performance. This has depressed labour market prospects. In recent years the labour market has not been able to integrate the increased labour supply, caused in part by the influx of migrants last year, and this has pushed up the unemployment rate, even though employment has been growing. This in turn has weighed on consumer sentiment, meaning that much of the windfall for consumers from low oil prices since late 2014 has been saved instead of consumed. Although inflation has picked up recently following increasing global energy prices and positive base effects, we expect continued moderate consumption growth owing to a modestly improving labour market.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an underperformance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue, and we expect real GDP growth of 1.8% in 2017, broadly in line with regional peers. The lack of reform progress is likely to continue to weigh on growth throughout the forecast period. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in the coming years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.5% in 2018-21.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Although its size has shrunk, industry still accounts for around 28% of GDP and remains an important driver of economic growth. After a steep contraction in 2009, the industrial sector bounced back fairly strongly as global trade volumes picked up, growing by an average of 3.2% per year in real terms in 2010-12. However, Austria's industrial sector could not escape the subsequent downturn in euro zone growth. Industrial growth averaged just 0.7% in 2013-15. The weaker performance of recent years has brought into sharp focus a relative decline in competitiveness compared with some euro zone peers, and Austrian exports have lost market share. Growth of value added in industry picked up to 1.7% in 2016 as Austrian industry profited from the uptick in fortunes in the euro zone and strong growth in central Europe. We expect industry to continue growing robustly in 2017-18 but for growth to moderate to around 1% in the second half of our forecast period.
Services dominate the Austrian economy, accounting for over 70% of GDP. Austria's two largest services sectors are financial services and tourism. Austrian banks' early move to establish a strong position in central and eastern Europe initially gave them a strategic advantage over other European competitors, although in the post-crisis years many of these investments have caused problems. These have now largely passed and the sector is looking increasingly healthy and able to contribute to growth in the coming years.
Austria's tourism sector is highly developed and large by international standards. In terms of international tourism receipts, the country ranks tenth in the world, accounting for over 1% of the global market, a huge share relative to the country's size (just over 0.1% of the world's population). Tourism has held up well in recent years, despite the euro zone crisis. The weakness of the Russian economy and the rouble have already seen the number of Russian visitors (who are often among the higher-spending tourists) drop, but overall we expect the Austrian tourism sector to remain strong during the forecast period, owing in part to other destinations, such as Turkey and Egypt, having become less attractive for European and Russian tourists. The government has made efforts to develop the tourism industry and has sought to diversify away from its traditional heavy reliance on Alpine summer and winter holidays. One area of growth in recent years has been "wellness tourism", with Austria's clean air, attractive environment and top-class facilities being strongly promoted as a favoured destination for health-related holidays. We expect growth of the services sector to continue closely tracking headline GDP growth, at 1.7% on average in 2017-21.
Agriculture will remain small as a percentage of GDP, but unlike in some other parts of western Europe it is not expected to shrink during the forecast period. Nevertheless, stronger growth in other sectors means that its share of GDP is set to fall slightly further in the coming years, to 1.2% by 2021, as we expect it to grow only by an average of 1.4% per year in 2017-21.

Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone in both years. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 2.2%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.

The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015. The annual average exchange rate was US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, although a sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following the presidential election in the US led to a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1. The euro has since rallied as the region's economic recovery has continued and political risk has waned. However, the common currency's resilience may be tested again in forthcoming elections, and faster economic growth and tighter monetary policy in the US will lend support to the dollar. We expect the exchange rate to average US$1.08:EUR1 in 2017-18, before appreciating gradually in 2019-21. We do not expect the euro to return to its long-term average value against the dollar even by the end of the forecast period.

Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and moved the trade balance back into a small deficit in 2016. We expect growth in domestic demand and a slight rise in oil prices to weigh on the trade balance in the coming years. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in our forecast period of just below 2% on average.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Austria
Stocks and flows
Inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) have risen steadily since Austria joined the EU. Although it remains one of the smaller hosts in western Europe in absolute terms, it has made substantial progress relative to the size of its economy. The stock of FDI increased significantly from the equivalent of 6.6% of GDP in 1994 (the year before Austria joined the EU) to 69.1% in 2016. FDI inflows posted a record of US$81.3bn in 2005, but have since dropped significantly, to -US$1.3bn on average in 2011-16. FDI outflows followed a similar pattern: after peaking at US$81.5bn in 2005 they stood at US$14.3bn (divestment) in 2010, before averaging US$8.3bn in 2011-16. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the stock of Austrian FDI abroad to rise gradually in the coming years, from US$316.2bn in 2016 (equivalent to 81.7% of GDP) to US$400.5bn (85.1% of GDP) at the end of the forecast period in 2021, and the stock of FDI in Austria is expected to rise gradually from US$267.3bn in 2015 (69.1% of GDP) to US$300bn (63.8% of GDP) at the end of the forecast period.
Origin and distribution
Companies in other EU member states have traditionally been the largest inward direct investors, accounting for over half of the inward FDI stock in 2016. Historically, most FDI comes from the EU15, in particular Germany, and Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands have also been important sources of inflows. In terms of stock, Germany remains comfortably the biggest holder, with EUR41.7bn in 2015 (28.2% of the total), followed by Russia (EUR21.8bn; 14.7%) and Italy (EUR11.2bn; 7.6%). Central and south-eastern Europe remains an important destination for Austrian FDI outflows, although net outflows to this region were negative in 2016 as companies repatriated capital. This also led to a drop in the stock of outstanding investment in the region, to EUR56bn, from EUR61.7bn in 2015. The region now represents around 29% of the total stock of Austrian FDI, compared with 50% in 2008. Professional scientific and technical services activities, financial intermediation and trade were the sectors in Austria in which foreign investors had the most invested in 2016. The same was true for Austrian investors abroad, although financial intermediation was by some margin the largest sector for outward foreign investment.
Determinants
Austria's main strengths as a location for FDI are its central location within the EU's single market, its proximity to and historical ties with eastern Europe, its competitive corporation tax rate (25%), an educated and flexible workforce, an excellent labour relations record, advanced IT and telecommunications infrastructure, a growing emphasis on research and development (R&D), and a high quality of life. However, Austria receives low marks for its employers' high social security contributions, considerable levels of red tape, and delays in expanding road and rail infrastructure towards eastern Europe. Outward direct investment has been driven in large part by integration with other euro zone economies and by the opportunities provided by the opening up of eastern neighbours' economies, although growth in investment into the former has been stronger in recent years.
Impact
FDI has increased competitiveness by providing a boost to fixed capital formation and assisting in the diffusion of new technologies and best practice developed in multinational companies. Outward investment, particularly in the financial sector, has helped to promote growth in the banking sector and has diversified risks away from the euro zone, although there have been other problems associated with economies in central and eastern Europe, especially Hungary, Ukraine and Russia. Public opinion remains ambivalent towards inward investment, with some lingering opposition among Austrians to the sale of "national champions"-particularly in the manufacturing and energy sectors-to foreign investors.
Potential
Austria's strong links with Germany and central and eastern Europe have historically been viewed as a strength. During the economic crisis of 2008-09 these links were temporarily deemed a weakness, but as the German economy has become the main driver of economic growth in Europe in recent years Austrian firms have benefited. However, the exposure to central and eastern Europe has been much less beneficial since 2008-09, particularly given the widespread problems in the banking sectors in some countries. Exposure to Ukraine and Russia has also become problematic recently. Nevertheless, over the longer term growth in much of the region is expected comfortably to outpace that of western Europe, and Austrian companies' early move into the region gave them the advantage of establishing themselves as large and respected organisations. They are expected to benefit from this over the forecast period. Austria will be well positioned to remain an attractive bridge to central and eastern Europe. The government will continue to seek to attract companies to establish their regional headquarters in Austria, and the country's favourable corporate tax environment and advantages in terms of quality of life serve as a magnet to high-technology companies in the IT sector. However, a lack of competition in some service markets and the need to expand transport links to Austria's eastern neighbours will remain challenges over the forecast period.

Austria is a wealthy country by international standards. GDP per head measured on a purchasing power parity (PPP) basis was US$51,105 in 2016, well above the EU average. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Austria's relative position to remain broadly unchanged over our forecast period (2017-21), owing to a slight pick-up in real GDP growth compared with the previous five years, at 1.6% on average in 2017-21, compared with 1.5% on average for the EU as a whole. As a result, at US$59,905 in 2021, its GDP per head on a PPP basis means that it will remain one of the continent's wealthiest countries.
Consumption growth will accelerate but remain modest
Private consumption growth will stay subdued in 2017-21, at 1.4% on average. However, this represents a strong acceleration compared with the previous five years, when it averaged just 0.3%. The improving labour market will help to push up incomes, and income tax reforms introduced at the start of 2016 are supporting after-tax incomes.
Austria is among the most advanced countries in the world in terms of its telecommunications and internet infrastructure. Total spending on IT should grow more than overall demand over the forecast period, reflecting the increased take-up of internet telephony, broadband and wireless services. The slight acceleration of economic growth and incomes will help to support demand for the latest innovative products, something on which Austria has at times slightly lagged some of its regional peers.
Robust consumption growth and high per head incomes are reflected in Austria's score in the market opportunities category of our business environ-ment rankings. Driven in large part by the improved economic outlook, its score improves sharply, from 4.9 to 5.8 over the forecast period. As a result, its global ranking improves from 42nd to 25th and the local ranking from 14th to 8th.

Population ageing will have an impact on spending patterns in 2017-21
Austria is a mature consumer market, but demographic trends will have a large influence on spending patterns over the forecast period. With a high (and rising) life expectancy and declining fertility rate, Austria's population is ageing. Although the total population is set to grow over the next decade and beyond, the proportion of those between 15 and 64 will drop slightly, and the share of the population over the age of 65 will rise. Austria's changing demographic profile, allied to sociological trends (such as the increase in single-person households), will continue to drive demand for housing, transport, communications, healthcare and leisure services. In general, income inequalities across Austria are lower than the west European average, which helps to support private consumption.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Total factor productivity growth 0.6 0.9 0.8
Initial conditions: Austria is a wealthy country. Compared with some other high-income countries, it saw fairly good productivity growth in the period up to 2008, owing to reforms enacted at the beginning of the 2000s. These reforms helped to strengthen the long-term sustainability of the state pension system, lower the tax burden and improve the competitiveness of Austrian companies. However, progress on reform has stalled in recent years, and trends in productivity have been fairly negative since 2010. A number of areas still require attention if Austria is to raise its long-term growth potential. These include increasing product and labour market flexibility, boosting labour force participation rates, raising education standards, reducing high drop-out rates in tertiary education, lowering the tax on labour, continued reform of the banking sector, and improving infrastructure links with the country's eastern neigh-bours. The Economist Intelligence Unit's core forecast assumes only limited progress in these areas in the coming years.
The working age population will shrink in 2017-50
Demographic trends: The total population should grow moderately, at an average of 0.1% per year until 2050, owing to immigration and higher life expectancy. However, as in other European economies, the population will age over the long-term forecast period. As a result, the working-age population will decline by an average of 0.4% per year over 2017-50, meaning that the share of the working-age population will decline from a 66.9% in 2016 to around 56% by 2050, thereby significantly increasing the old-age dependency ratio. To avoid a sizeable contraction in the workforce, Austria must raise its labour force participation rate, especially of older workers. This to some extent is being addressed by pension reforms that came into force at the beginning of 2014.
External conditions: Austria stands to benefit from the faster expected growth rates of the EU's newer member states in central and eastern Europe over the coming decades, given its strong trade links in the region. Trade relations are expected to be further enhanced as the new member states become more fully integrated. However, Austria will remain dependent on the older member states of the EU for its exports. Many of these countries share the same challenges that Austria faces, including a negative demographic outlook (albeit not as negative in most cases as in many of the new member states) and tepid productivity growth, and we expect growth this also to remain moderate.
Institutions and policy trends: Austria is a stable democracy with well-entrenched rule of law that has underpinned macroeconomic stability over recent decades. Since the second world war, politics has largely been conducted as a system of grand bargains between the centre right and the centre left, which led to a stable political environment and few sharp changes in policy. The system of social partnership, offering trade unions and employers co-operative roles in aspects of economic policymaking, plays an important part in ensuring political and social stability. Although this system is likely to decline in importance as the traditional mainstream parties remain under pressure, we expect the political system to remain relatively stable and institutions con-ducive to growth. Significant reforms in the early 2000s saw Austria attempt to liberalise sheltered sectors of the economy, privatise and slim down the public sector, and spur entrepreneurship. Liberalisation of the telecommunications sector has gone fairly well, but a high degree of state ownership and regulation remains in the electricity sector, and reforms of competition in the services sector have also been slow. The increasingly fluid political landscape has the potential to lead to limited reform in some areas, although some of this could be counterproductive, especially with regard to the free movement of labour and goods.
Economic performance will mirror that in much of the rest of the euro zone
Long-term performance: Overall, long-term prospects for the Austrian economy are broadly in line with much of the rest of the euro zone. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects real GDP per head to grow at an average of 1.2% in 2017-50. The demographic profile is not as challenging as for some other euro zone countries (notably Germany), but will nevertheless be a drag on long-term growth prospects. Continued progress on pensions, labour market and healthcare reform will be crucial in this regard. Greater competition in services would boost long-term growth prospects. Faced with global competition, increasing investment in education and improving the outcomes of research and development (R&D) activity will be crucial. There is now a stronger emphasis on R&D (Austria is third in the EU in terms of R&D spending as a percentage of GDP, at 3.1% in 2016), and education reform is aimed at accelerating the transition to a knowledge-based economy. A particular challenge will be raising the educational standards of second- and third-generation immigrants, and integrating the large numbers of recently arrived asylum-seekers into the labour market. An increase in the number of older workers should stimulate growth and employment in traditional sectors of the economy, but there may be a shortage of skilled labour in areas such as information and communications technology (ICT) and bio-technology.
