Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported.
Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. Our long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also the key to understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. The Economist Intelligence Unit is well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions (based on cross-section, panel data for 86 countries for the 1970-2000 period) that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The sample is split into three decades: 1971-80, 1981-90 and 1991-2000. This gives a maximum of 258 observations (86 countries for each decade); given missing values for some countries and variables, the actual number of observations is 246. The estimation of the pooled, cross-section, panel data is conducted on the basis of a statistical technique called Seemingly Unrelated Regressions.
The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade in the 1970-2000 period.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
Control variables include PRIMARY: Share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: Percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: History of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in the 1970-2000 period.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income.
Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Formal political opposition to the regime will remain marginal. Vladimir Putin, the president, is likely to run again for president in March 2018 and win with a large majority in the first round. The principal concern for the authorities will be to maintain a high turnout in the absence of a meaningful contest.
Donald Trump, the US president, has expressed a desire to improve relations with Russia, but the likelihood of a significant rapprochement has declined given the intense scrutiny of Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 presidential election campaign and of the Trump team's alleged links with Russian officials.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects US and EU sectoral sanctions on the Russian defence, energy and financial sectors to remain in place in the medium term. Russian counter sanctions on Western food imports will also remain in place indefinitely, but relations with Turkey have improved from a recent low and Russia has lifted its sanctions on Turkey.
Despite a reduction in fighting in Ukraine, we do not expect the Minsk II deal to lead to a comprehensive political settlement. Ukraine will not regain full control of its border with Russia.
Russia is likely to remain a mobilisation economy, characterised by high spending on the defence sector, a cautious approach to foreign investment in many sectors, protectionism and a large role for the state in the economy.
The government is unlikely to implement disruptive market reforms. Minority stakes in some major state enterprises will be sold off. Chinese companies are likely to take a bigger role in the economy, including in the extractive sector.
Despite pressure to maintain defence and welfare spending, the government will cut public expenditure in 2017-19 to keep the budget deficit under control. The budget deficit will narrow to less than 1% of GDP by 2021, from 3.4% of GDP in 2016.
The economy contracted by 0.2% in 2016. We forecast that the economy will grow by 1.6% in 2017, supported by higher oil prices and improving consumer confidence. Investment will remain relatively weak, and public spending will be tightened further.
The medium-term growth outlook will be constrained by structural weaknesses, including a lack of competition, high state involvement in the economy, an ageing and declining workforce, and weak rule of law. We forecast average annual GDP growth of 1.6% per year in 2017-21.

Russia falls by one place in our regional ranking in the forecast period (2017-21), to 14th out of 16 countries. This reflects manifold institutional weaknesses, poor rule of law, high levels of corruption and extensive state involve-ment in the economy. It falls to 68th out of 82 countries in our global ranking.
Country forecast overview: Russia's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisation plans will proceed slowly, despite the announcement in 2016 of a new privatisation drive.
2019-21: Overall state involvement in the economy remains high. Government interference in private companies remains arbitrary. Rent-seeking officials remain a burden on business. Protection of intellectual property rights could weaken.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: International sanctions and low energy prices discourage major new investment in the oil and gas sectors.
2019-21: The "pivot to the east" will lead to further moderate growth in investment from Asia.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Western sanctions remain in place. Membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is effectively suspended. The Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) internal market is undermined by exemptions and weak enforcement.
2019-21: The difficulty of trading across borders continues to be a weakness. The Russian ban on Western agricultural imports is likely to remain in force.
Taxes
2017-18: The resources tax on gas and the tax on tobacco rise. The freeze on the tax on vodka is extended. Direct taxes on in-dividuals and value-added tax (VAT) will not be raised, and the government may issue VAT concessions to selected sectors.
2019-21: A progressive consumption tax might be introduced. Tax inspections remain a burden on business. The time that it takes to pay taxes is close to international norms. There are some specific improvements in the corporate tax regime.
Financing
2017-18: International sanctions limit access to external capital markets, significantly raising the cost of financing.
2019-21: International financial integration proceeds slowly. The banking system remains weak and state dominated. The government maintains its commitment to bail out systemically important institutions.
The labour market
2017-18: Spending on education is cut further. The incidence of strikes increases slightly, although the labour movement remains weak.
2019-21: The indigenous labour force will steadily decline; however, the impact will be offset in some sectors by continued substantial immigration from the Commonwealth of Independent States, much of it unskilled.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Budget constraints curb investment in infrastructure. Politically important projects are prioritised, but even here cuts are made. Russia struggles to obtain international funding for its infrastructure projects. Roads are starved of funding.
2019-21: It remains difficult to secure foreign finance. China provides only a limited alternative to Western funding.

Background: The transition to a market economy in the early 1990s was accompanied by a collapse in industrial production and a sharp drop in living standards. A contested privatisation process led to a highly concentrated ownership structure. Executive weakness and bureaucratic dysfunction contributed to a sharp decentralisation of power. After becoming president in 2000, Vladimir Putin sought to restore central control over the regions and tame independent corporate interests. Mr Putin presided over a period of strong economic growth in his first two terms. His re-election as president in 2012 has heralded the development of a more authoritarian domestic environment.
Political structure: Boris Yeltsin won the first democratic presidential election in June 1991 and was re-elected in July 1996. Repeated confrontations with the legislature culminated in the dissolution of parliament in September 1993 and a violent showdown the following month. The powers of the executive were greatly increased by a new constitution, adopted in 1993. Mr Putin was elected in March 2000 and re-elected for a second term in March 2004. Mr Putin's second term in office was characterised by increasing centralisation of the state. A loyal ally, Dmitry Medvedev, won the presidential election in March 2008 and took over in May of that year. Mr Putin returned to the presidency for a third term in May 2012. Following a constitutional change, his term will last six years, to 2018.
Policy issues: Mr Putin's third term as president has seen a greater emphasis on "conservative cultural values", anti-Westernism and great-power nationalism. The stand-off with the West is leading to a rollback of Russia's integration into the world economy. This is likely to strengthen further the state's role in the economy. Tit-for-tat sanctions have encouraged the government to focus on import substitution. The focus on curbing "foreign influence" on domestic politics is likely to endure, along with close controls on civil society, the internet and the media.
Taxation: Reforms since 2000 have aimed to rationalise the tax system and cut the number of taxes and the corporate tax burden. Changes to the tax regime in January 2001 included the introduction of a flat rate of personal income tax of 13% and a simplification of the administration of social security contributions. In 2004 the basic rate of value-added tax (VAT) was reduced from 20% to 18% and a regional 5% sales tax was abolished. The corporate tax rate was cut from 24% to 20% at the beginning of 2009. The government has pledged not to raise personal or consumption taxes before 2018.
Foreign trade: Mainly because of high international oil prices, export revenue has soared since 2000. Import growth picked up over the same period as a result of rising real incomes and real rouble appreciation. Merchandise exports totalled just over US$280bn in 2016 and imports were just over US$190bn. Oil and gas account for around two-thirds of Russia's exports, with metals contributing around one-tenth.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Vladimir Putin's third presidential term, which began in 2012, has seen a shift towards "conservative cultural values", a more authoritarian political culture and more overt anti­Westernism. This has been further consolidated by Russia's confrontation with the West over Ukraine. Despite some pro-market rhetoric, economic policy has grown more statist and protectionist. The leadership will remain preoccupied by the need to insulate the economy and society from foreign-in particular Western-influence and the perceived threat of externally sponsored regime change. However, the regime is characterised by ideological flexibility and is more adaptable than many observers acknowledge. If the external environment allows (a major caveat), it is possible that the leadership will devote greater attention to domestic issues and welfare after the 2018 presidential election and attempt to implement a slightly more liberal economic agenda. Concern about political stability is likely to hold the government back from pursuing radical reform.
The forecast period (2017-21) is likely to be characterised by relatively slow growth in living standards, following a major decline in 2015-16 and further cuts in public expenditure in many areas. This contrasts sharply with the rapid growth achieved in Mr Putin's first decade in power and could have unpredict-able effects on stability in the medium term. However, there currently seems to be little desire for disruptive reform among the broader population, and the potential for mass protest or major political change from below appears to be low. Social controls have been tightened since 2012, and the opposition has been marginalised and demoralised. Protests regularly occur across the country, but these tend to be focused on single issues such as plans to clear Soviet-era housing blocks in the capital, Moscow; the cost for individuals and activists of collective action focused on broader political change is high. The government tends to respond constructively when confronted with specific economic grievances. A mixture of state support and administrative pressure will keep major enterprises operating in provincial industrial towns.
The regime is actively engaged in cadre renewal at many levels. Nevertheless, the political system leans heavily on the charismatic leadership and popularity of Mr Putin. There is therefore a risk of a rupture when he departs the political scene. The weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the person-alised, opaque governance system around Mr Putin, could present difficulties in managing an eventual presidential transition. Any successor is likely to come from the team around Mr Putin and will not herald a sharp change in the policy agenda. However, it could be difficult for any successor to build popular legitimacy given the weak economic outlook. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a political transition in the forecast period. Speculation about an eventual succession strategy is likely to intensify soon after the 2018 presidential election, however, and this will further depress business confidence and raise political uncertainty.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next presidential election will take place in March 2018. We expect Mr Putin to contest the election and win by a wide margin in the first round. Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption blogger and nationalist opposition politician, will be barred from participating in the presidential election following a second conviction for defrauding Kirovles, a timber company. This suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, offering voters no meaningful alternatives to Mr Putin. The main challenge for the authorities will be to prevent a sharp fall in turnout, which would throw doubt on the legitimacy of Mr Putin's popular mandate. This is one of the reasons behind the efforts to revitalise the regional leadership with the replacement of poorly performing governors.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
The Ukraine conflict has led to a sharp deterioration in Russia's relations with the West since 2014. In response to the conflict in Ukraine, the US and the EU have imposed sanctions on senior Russian officials and the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors. Russia has responded with a ban on almost all Western food imports.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a comprehensive political resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. The constitutional reform mandated by the agreement, which could formally embed Russia's proxies within Ukraine's political system, is politically toxic in Ukraine. In the highly unlikely event that it is passed, there is little chance that Russia will allow Ukraine to re-establish control of its side of the international border. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests. Russia will not step back from its long-term objective of preventing a pro-Western govern-ment from consolidating in Ukraine. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, appears likely to endure for several years.
It appears unlikely that relations with the US will improve under the presidency of Donald Trump. Allegations of Russian interference in the US presidential election are the subject of FBI and congressional investigations. Links between senior figures close to Mr Trump and Russian officials have been intensely scrutinised in the media, making it difficult for the administration to take measures perceived as offering concessions to Russia. Moreover, Mr Trump's decision to launch a strike on a Syrian airbase in early April has again set Russian and US policy on Syria-an area where Mr Trump's advisers had hoped to build co-operation-on divergent paths. We believe it likely that US and EU sanctions will be retained in the medium term. Russian counter sanctions on Western food imports are also likely to remain in place indefinitely.
Regardless of Mr Trump's stance, Russia's broader foreign policy will remain vehemently opposed to Western integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. This also applies to former communist countries in Europe, such as Montenegro, whose NATO accession on June 5th was heavily criticised by Russia. Russia's policy towards its neighbours, and towards Ukraine in particular, will be an enduring source of tension with the West. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via popular uprising, would probably trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Economic reform will be subordinated to the imperatives of political stability and regime survival. We do not expect the government to move substantively towards liberalisation of the economy, and certainly not before the presidential election in March 2018, although some reform is possible thereafter.
A more likely scenario is that the government will seek incrementally to improve the efficiency of the system by replacing failing officials and bureau-crats and cracking down selectively on corruption. Following the presidential election the government is likely to extend the pension age and conduct a limited tax reform. Progress on strengthening the rule of law and protecting property rights is likely to be limited. The government will continue to sell minority stakes in some major state-controlled assets. However, as with the sale in December 2016 of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a Russian oil giant, the govern-ment's priority is to raise budget revenue rather than increasing the level of competition in the economy or reducing state influence over it.
Russia's stand-off with the West has strengthened statist and protectionist trends within the government. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a strategic priority. The main elements of this strategy include a large positive sovereign external asset position (low public debt combined with substantial foreign-exchange reserves), protectionist measures to encourage import substitution and support domestic manufacturing, and a cautious approach to globalisation and foreign investment (which in "strategic sectors" such as the extractive sector is likely to be permitted only in partnership with state-controlled companies).
Some policymakers have urged a further increase in state intervention in the economy, along with capital controls, expansionist monetary policy and a return to a fixed exchange rate. We believe that the government will continue to pursue a mixed approach, observing the broad tenets of a market economy and avoiding disruptive reforms and excessive market-distorting behaviour (such as exchange or capital controls) while maintaining a large state role in the economy. We expect formal and informal barriers to external trade to remain significant.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The government faces tight budget constraints as a result of international sanctions, low commodity prices and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances (although Russia succeeded in placing two Eurobonds in 2016). In 2016 the deficit was the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP; however, this included extraordinary income from the sale of a stake in Rosneft in December last year. Without this, the deficit would have exceeded 4% of GDP.
Under the government's initial budget for 2017, spending will fall from Rb16.4trn (US$276bn) in 2016 to Rb16.2trn, broadly in line with the Ministry of Finance's proposal that nominal spending be frozen for the next three years. Based on an average oil price of US$40/barrel in 2017, the govern-ment expects revenue to rise by 1.8%.
As anticipated, the government is now planning revisions in the light of higher average oil prices. Anton Siluanov, the minister of finance, has suggested that expenditure could rise by Rb200bn (US$3.6bn) compared with the original budget, and that the budget deficit target could be reduced to 2% of GDP, from 3.2% previously. We forecast a significantly higher oil price than set out in the original budget, of US$54/b, and a budget deficit of 2.2% of GDP this year, allowing for slightly higher additional spending than currently proposed by the finance ministry.
We expect the finance ministry to continue to trim the deficit in 2018-21, but the adjustment to expenditure is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly given the forthcoming presidential election. We believe that the government is unlikely to hold expenditure fixed in nominal terms in 2018-19 as planned, although spending will still decline in real terms. We forecast that the deficit will narrow to less than 1% of GDP by 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
At its meeting in April the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) cut its policy rate by 50 basis points, to 9.25%. This was the central bank's second cut in as many months. The strong rouble, driven by higher oil prices and the carry trade, has helped to push disinflation ahead of the CBR's expectations. We expect the CBR to reduce its policy rate to 8-8.5% by the end of the year. We expect further loosening of monetary policy in 2018. With inflation now almost at the CBR's 4% target, the central bank governor, Elvira Nabiullina, has suggested that an appropriate level for the real interest rate would be about 2.5-3%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Russia's growth was decelerating even before 2014, as it ran into structural constraints. The economy experienced a sharp recession in 2015 as a result of the fall in the oil price, and real household incomes declined by almost 20%. The Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat) now estimates that the economy contracted by 2.8% in 2015 and 0.2% in 2016.
The outlook for 2017 will depend on the path of household consumption. We expect real wage growth to pick up this year, to about 3%. Following a sharp decline in US dollar incomes in 2015-16, however, household consumption is likely to remain subdued. Retail sales volumes grew by 2.4% quarter on quarter in January-March (seasonally adjusted), but continued to contract in year-on-year terms. Leading indicators for manufacturing fell back in April, but the services sector purchasing managers' index remained strong.
Fiscal consolidation will continue to constrain public consumption and infrastructure spending. We expect a weak recovery in investment, after three years of contraction. Corporate deleveraging will slow and external financing conditions are likely to improve marginally. A relaxation of Western sanctions-not our core forecast-would provide a modest boost to investment. However, perceptions of political risk would remain high, limiting foreign direct investment (FDI) outside the commodities sector. An upswing in regional growth should lead to continued export growth, but at a slower pace than in 2016, as oil production is forecast to be flat. We forecast real GDP growth of 1.6% this year, with risks oriented to the downside, as household consumption might be weaker than currently projected.
The stabilisation of the economy should allow continued growth in investment in 2018, although it will remain relatively weak. We forecast a slowdown in China in 2018, which will hit Russia's terms of trade, and we expect Russia's growth rate to moderate slightly, to 1.5%. The public sector will remain a drag on domestic demand.
In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low investment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that real GDP growth will average about 1.6% per year in 2018-21, in line with CBR estimates of Russia's trend growth under the current institutional and macroeconomic framework. There currently seems to be little prospect of far-reaching domestic institutional reform. High political risk and the poor business environment will continue to depress investment below the level needed to develop a higher trend growth rate. The declining workforce will also be a constraint on headline growth, although in some sectors this will be offset by continued high immigration from the Commonwealth of Independent States.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Inflation stood at 5.4% year on year in December 2016, but fell to 4.1% in April 2017, and remained at this level in May, meaning that the CBR has almost achieved its inflation target more than six months ahead of schedule. Disinflation has been assisted by a strong harvest last year and the appreciation of the rouble. Both factors could prove to be temporary, given that the strong rouble is in part due to the carry trade, which will unwind as the CBR continues to loosen monetary policy. We forecast that consumer price inflation will average 4.1% in 2017. The slowdown in China will lead to a modest depreciation of the rouble in 2018, but external inflationary pressures are likely to be relatively low. Tax changes in 2019 are expected to push up inflation to 4.9% in that year. Overall, we expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-target in the medium term.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Higher oil prices and relatively tight monetary policy, which has boosted the carry trade, has led to a significant appreciation of the rouble against the US dollar. In early June the rouble stood at Rb56.7:US$1. We expect the rouble to depreciate moderately from this level in the second half of 2017 as the CBR gradually loosens monetary policy. The rouble is highly correlated with the oil price, and any rapid fall in the oil price could lead to renewed exchange-rate volatility. We forecast an average exchange rate of Rb59.1:US$1 in 2017. Our forecast growth slowdown in China in 2018 will hit Russia's terms of trade, and we have reduced our 2018 oil price forecast to US$55/b, from US$60/b previously, further reinforcing our expectation that the rouble will depreciate slightly in that year. Oil prices are forecast to be broadly stable around US$60/b in 2019-21, and therefore we do not anticipate significant movements in the rouble-dollar exchange rate.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
We forecast an increased current-account surplus in 2017 as higher oil prices boost the value of exports. This will be tempered by higher imports as domestic demand and investment pick up, alongside increased outflows on the primary and secondary accounts. We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, but a further recovery in imports and investment will gradually reduce the size as a share of GDP. International sanctions and political uncertainty will depress FDI and portfolio inflows, although we expect these to recover in 2018-21.

Country Forecast Turkey June 2017 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-june-2017-updater/docview/1952372819/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. The central bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen, from 7.8% to about 12% at end-May 2017. 2012a 2013a 2014a 2015a 2016b 2017c 2018c 2019c 2020c 2021c The labour market (av) Labour force (m) 26.1 27.0 28.8 29.7 30.5 31.2 31.7 32.3 33.1 33.8 Labour force (% change) 2.1 3.5 6.4 3.1 3.0 2.2 1.7 1.7 2.4 2.4 Employment (m) 23.9 24.6 25.9 26.6 27.2 27.6 28.1 28.7 29.4 30.2 Employment (% change) 2.9 2.8 5.4 2.7 2.2 1.4 2.0 2.0 2.5 2.8 Unemployment (m) 2.2 2.4 2.9 3.0 3.3 3.6 3.6 3.6 3.6 3.6 Unemployment rate (%) 8.5 9.1 10.0 10.3 10.9 11.6 11.3 11.1 11.0 10.6 Wage and price inflation (% except labour costs per hour) Consumer prices (av) 8.9 7.5 8.9 7.7 7.8a 10.1 7.8 6.4 5.7 5.2 Consumer prices (year-end) 6.3 7.5 8.3 8.9 8.5a 8.6 7.6 6.0 5.3 5.0 Producer prices (av) 6.1 4.5 10.2 5.3 4.3a 13.9 9.7 8.5 7.5 5.5 GDP deflator (av) 7.4 6.3 7.4 7.8 7.7a 9.1 8.0 6.5 6.0 5.6 Private consumption deflator (av) 7.8 6.1 7.7 7.7 6.8a 10.3 8.3 7.1 6.2 5.7 Government consumption deflator (av) 9.3 6.0 9.4 8.1 9.8a 10.1 7.8 6.4 5.7 5.2 Fixed investment deflator (av) 6.6 5.8 9.0 7.6 7.7a 6.0 5.5 5.0 5.0 5.0 Average nominal wages 15.6b 14.4b 15.5b 13.7b 15.9 11.5 10.0 9.0 8.3 7.7 Average real wages 6.1b 6.5b 6.1b 5.6b 7.5 1.3 2.1 2.5 2.4 2.4 Unit labour costs (TL-based; av)d 15.9b 10.9b 18.2b 12.7b 17.6 12.0 11.3 10.0 9.1 9.0 Unit labour costs (US$-based)d 8.1b 4.7b 2.8b -9.4b 5.9 -6.7 9.3 7.1 7.6 8.1 Labour costs per hour (TL)d 7.5b 8.6b 10.0b 11.3b 13.1 14.6 16.1 17.5 19.0 20.5 Labour costs per hour (US$) 4.2b 4.5b 4.5b 4.2b 4.3 4.0 4.4 4.6 4.9 5.3 a Actual.b Economist Intelligence Unit estimates.c Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts.d Manufacturing only: public and private sectors.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The intense political instability in Turkey that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. However, the presidential reform provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incumbent, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. This will further undermine Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures; exacerbate the deep social and political polarisation of the country; damage the country's already fragile international relations, especially with the EU; and delay further economic reform efforts.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and the Justice and Development Party (AKP) will win the next presidential and parliamentary elections, completing the transfer of executive powers to Mr Erdogan. The elections are not due to be held until late 2019, but they could be called earlier-once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place-if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency. Emergency rule, which was introduced following the failed coup, will continue to be used to silence government critics and disable the pro-Kurdish opposition. Emergency rule will remain in place until at least late July 2017, and probably beyond.
Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and jihadi extremists affiliated with Islamic State (IS). Turkey risks be-coming mired in the Syrian conflict, following the deployment of Turkish troops to Syria to combat IS and to halt the territorial expansion by Syrian Kurds.
The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses. Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to cut interest rates to boost the economy has eased, but we expect that it will have to keep monetary policy tight in order to lower inflation and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates.
We expect average annual real GDP growth to accelerate slightly, from 3% in 2016 to 3.2% in 2017-18 and a still moderate 3.7% annual average in 2019-21. The current-account deficit has narrowed, but will still be difficult to fund, especially if global liquidity is tightened.

Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period and the country's global ranking deteriorates by 12 places, reflecting the absence of reforms in recent years. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment. The main shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening-up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade following the lifting of Russian sanctions. Possible increase in protectionism under the new US administration.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU could be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements might come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. The Central Bank of Turkey and commercial banks remain under political pressure to keep interest rates low.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. A 30% minimum wage rise in 2016 could damage competitiveness. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks could persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened under the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has remained prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage remain widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.8bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The intense political instability in Turkey that followed the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 has eased partially since the approval in a referendum in April 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency. Household, business and investor sentiment has improved and the economy has continued to recover. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit maintains its negative medium-term political outlook for Turkey. The presidential reform provides few checks and balances on the powers of the president and moves the country closer to one-man rule by the incumbent, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. This will further undermine Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures; exacerbate the deep social and political polarisation of the country; damage the country's already fragile international relations, especially with the EU; and delay further economic reform efforts.
The narrow margin of victory in the referendum, allegations of vote fraud and bids to nullify the referendum have prompted Mr Erdogan and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) to tighten their grip on power. Following the referendum the government extended the state of emergency law until late July 2017. Emergency rule, which has been repeatedly extended on a three-month basis since its introduction in response to the failed coup, effectively allows Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is fully in place, after the presidential and parliamentary elections, scheduled for 2019.
Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More than 100,000 people-mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media-have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held in 2019, but they could be called earlier, once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place, if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency. We expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and to remain in office with enhanced powers for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and lacks candidates capable of challenging him. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round with just over 50% of the vote, well ahead of a joint candidate presented by the two main opposition parties, the Republican People's Party (CHP) and the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the AKP's presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties would consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the MHP leadership's decision to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 elections and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for representation in parliament, which would help to boost the AKP's share of seats. Under the constitutional changes approved in the presidential reform referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's inter-national relations with its traditional Western allies. Having deployed armed forces to back rebel groups in Syria to fight IS and prevent the expansion of territory held by US-backed PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurds, Turkey risks becoming embroiled in the conflict. Tensions and the risk of confrontation between Turkey and US-backed forces could escalate once IS is defeated.
Despite talk of agreeing a new roadmap to ease tensions and improve co-operation in the main areas of interest such as security, trade and investment, neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc any more. However, neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. Our baseline forecast has been that the death penalty is unlikely to be reinstated, but this cannot be ruled out given the government's increasingly hardline nationalist stance. The suspension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Tukey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. An agreement on a solution to end the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but we believe that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
The administration of the US president, Donald Trump, is less concerned about Mr Erdogan's autocratic tendencies than its Democrat predecessor was, but is equally unresponsive to Turkey's domestic and regional security concerns. Vague US reassurances about support for Turkey's fight against terrorism avoided a full-blown crisis in May 2017, when, as expected, Mr Trump author-ised the supply of arms to the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) for the offensive against IS in its stronghold in Raqqa, Syria. As yet there has also been no response to Turkey's request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey on charges of masterminding the failed coup.
Since mid-2016 relations between Turkey and Russia have improved. Russia has lifted almost all sanctions, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both are militarily involved but are pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional, and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Turkey's economy has shown considerable resilience during past bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing largely to the country's solid public finances and well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector. However, the recent stabilisation of the lira and a recovery in Turkish financial assets remain vulnerable to a return of global risk aversion, which could be triggered by tighter than currently expected US monetary policy in the coming months, although this is not our central forecast and we consider the probability of it happening to be low. Uncertainty about the direction of Turkey's economic policy also continues to cloud the country's medium-term economic outlook. The AKP government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges have blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
We expect political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity to pose an ongoing risk to foreign capital inflows to Turkey, especially in the first half of the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016-early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy after a prolonged period of loosening. An abrupt tightening of policy could strangle Turkey's already fragile economic growth.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past but also major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the AKP government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight, but that the central government deficit will widen, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.1% of GDP per year in 2017-21. The government debt/GDP ratio is low, but it edged up slightly, to 29.4%, in 2016, from 29.1% in 2015. We expect a further moderate increase in 2017-19, before it declines to about 30% in 2021. However, the risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out. The government's decision to transfer Turkey's major state assets to a sovereign wealth fund set up in 2016 to help to finance major infrastructure projects could bring privatisation to a halt and increase political control over state companies, and the fund could become a vehicle for increased off-budget spending.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
In recent months political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates to revive economic activity has eased, but we expect that the central bank will have to keep monetary policy tight in the coming months in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates. We expect the bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The central bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was gradually raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25%, in late April. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen, from 7.8% to about 12% at end-May 2017.
The central bank is seeking to normalise gradually its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, the one-week repurchase lending rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that the corridor will be eliminated until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases. From 2017 the bank will hold only eight regular Monetary Policy Committee meetings annually rather than 12.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Domestic political instability, perceived security risks from terrorist attacks in 2015-16 and uncertainty about the global economic outlook will have negative but diminishing effects on the economy in the short and medium term. We expect real GDP growth to pick up only modestly, from 3% in 2016 to 3.2% per year in 2017-18. In 2019-21 we expect real GDP growth to average 3.8% per year, assuming that domestic conditions stabilise.
We expect real private consumption growth to accelerate from 2.3% in 2016 to an annual average of 2.4% in 2017-18 and 3% in 2019-21. A moderate improve-ment in confidence, recent stabilisation of the lira, government pressure on banks to ease lending conditions for households, and government incentives for the purchase of certain household durable goods should support growth in the short term. However, the risk over the medium term is that further domestic political uncertainty and tighter global liquidity will negatively affect capital inflows, hampering bank lending.
After expanding by 7.7% in 2016 we expect government spending to increase by nearly 8% per year on average in 2017-19 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to dampen fixed investment growth in 2017-18, as weakened business sentiment and a more cautious approach by foreign investors will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast an acceleration to average annual growth of 4.9%, assuming a less volatile domestic and global environment.
We expect the lifting of Russian sanctions on Turkey since mid-2016, the positive impact of a weaker lira on export competitiveness and stronger growth in the main export markets, especially in Europe, to drive a return to growth of exports of goods and services in 2017-21. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter visitors to Turkey and weigh on the tourist sector. Our expectation is also that a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. We expect further currency weakness and a moderate recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile, plunging in value against all major currencies in late 2016-early 2017 and then recovering partially in recent months. Amid further bouts of volatility we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar to an annual average of TL3.63:US$1 in 2017-a fall of about 17%. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL3.88:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, and the impact on investor confidence of domestic political instability and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
GDP revisions, moderate domestic demand growth, sharply lower global oil prices and a weaker lira have helped to reduce Turkey's current-account deficit in recent years. However, we expect it to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large-at a forecast average of 4.2% of GDP per year in 2017-21-to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and investor confidence deteriorates. Although a weaker lira and the lifting of Russian sanctions will boost Turkey's main export sectors, we expect this to be largely offset by the higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. In addition, the tourism sector is likely to take several years to recover to 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat

Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; Turkstat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS
External trade and balance of payments: IMF, IFS; Central Bank of Turkey; Turkstat
Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury

Country Forecast Argentina May 2017

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-argentina-may-2017/docview/1902041251/se-2?accountid=14357

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Argentina&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Argentina+May+2017&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-05-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Argentina&amp;rft.issn=09668977&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Argentina--highlights: Political outlook
The president, Mauricio Macri, will persist with economic rebalancing measures to return the economy to sustainable growth. The adjustment process involves some politically unpopular austerity measures that will sustain the risk of social unrest and strikes by powerful unions in the short term. On top of this, Mr Macri is in a minority position in both houses of Congress. To Mr Macri's benefit, however, a moderate faction of the dominant Peronist faction has proved co-operative in Congress to date, and strong presidential powers provide Mr Macri with some room for manoeuvre. On this basis, and based on an assumption of economic recovery, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects governability to remain relatively good. Nonetheless, given his party's minority position in Congress, and the priority that will be given to urgent macroeconomic reforms, progress in the pursuit of reforms that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth is expected to be limited.

Population growth has slowed in recent decades and is expected to remain below the Latin American average, although it will be outpaced by growth in the labour force in the outlook period. An ageing population will place a heavy demand on healthcare services, which have deteriorated in recent years. The effects of this decline will be lasting, but relatively high skills levels mean that the stock of human capital will, nonetheless, remain a source of compara-tive advantage, although improvements in some other Latin American countries will narrow the gap between Argentina and much of the rest of the region.

Argentina's position in our business environment ranking improves substantially between the historical and forecast periods. The weak historical ranking reflects the legacy of expansionary and distortionary macroeconomic policies, and a deterioration in the legal and regulatory framework. The Macri administration will continue to iron out distortions, which although contributing to still-high inflation in the short term, will improve the business environment. However, depending on the extent of public opposition, there is a risk that the government may be forced to backpedal, implying that implementation would be less successful than we currently assume.

The economy is emerging slowly from recession, amid deep macro-economic adjustments and continuing efforts to address the problem of legal and regulatory uncertainty. That said, we still expect the economy to pick up over the forecast period. There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to reduce economic distortions and engineer a relatively smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging, keeping both consumption and investment subdued for longer than we expect. There is also some upside risk, however, as investment could take off beyond expectations from 2017 once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and assuming that efforts to restore confidence in the rule of law make progress. But even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than to 4%.

Argentina's wealth of natural resources, a large domestic market with high per-head incomes relative to much of the rest of the region, and proximity and preferential access to the large Brazilian market represent attractive long-term opportunities for foreign investors (assuming that the Brazilian economy recovers gradually). However, economic adjustments to rein in inflation will deter investment in the very short term, at least as businesses wait on the sidelines while Mr Macri pushes through all the necessary politically and socially difficult adjustments.

We forecast that average annual GDP will grow by 2.8% in 2017-50, with the growth rate peaking at 3.1% in 2021-30 before slowing to 2.5% by 2041-50. Our forecasts assume that the contribution of capital to growth will be firm initially, before tapering off somewhat over the latter part of the outlook period. We also assume that as growth in the working-age population slows, the increase in the availability of labour will slow; as a result of this, growth will become more dependent on productivity gains.

Background: Economic liberalisation in the 1990s drove firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and fail-ure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party) began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanage-ment drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983 after 50 years of instability and military regimes. A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances in the economy in the form of double-digit inflation, real peso appreciation and a deterioration of the balance of payments. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to foreign-exchange, import and capital controls, as well as ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to reduce economic distortions and set the economy on a more solid long-term footing are taking place under Mr Macri; these include peso devaluation, and fiscal and monetary tightening. Microeconomic reforms to boost domestic supply are also getting under way.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals). Taxes on exports were reintroduced in 2002, and have since been expanded to account for around 20% of total revenue.
Foreign trade: The current account shifted from surplus to deficit in 2010. Despite comprehensive controls, there was a current-account deficit of 2.7% of GDP in 2015.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The president, Mauricio Macri, took office on December 10th 2015 for a four-year term ending in December 2019. Mr Macri was elected on the ticket of the Cambiemos electoral alliance. This alliance includes Mr Macri's own party, the centre-right Propuesta Repúblicana (Pro), along with the centrist Unión Cívica Radical and the smaller left-wing Coalición Cívica. Mr Macri's party is in a minority in the Senate (the upper house of Congress), where the opposition Frente para la Victoria (FV, a faction of the Peronist party) holds a majority. In the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house), the FV has the largest number of seats of any single party but does not have a simple majority.
