Political outlook: Political stability
The political scene is becoming more complicated as voter fatigue with austerity measures increases and patience with adjustment measures wears thin. An increase in obstructionism on the part of public-sector unions in recent weeks is unsurprising amid annual wage-bargaining negotiations that are taking place in the run-up to mid-term legislative elections in October. More of a concern for the president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is the continued perception among voters that adjustment is not bringing about obvious rapid improvements in the economy. Various economic indicators suggest that the economy is indeed emerging from recession, but consumers are not yet feeling the benefit in terms of higher real wages or increased employment.
The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect Mr Macri to change course and abandon the adjustment process that he has pursued since taking office for a four-year term in late 2015. This process has involved devaluation, fiscal and monetary tightening, and sharp tariff adjustments. In this environment, voter weariness with austerity, combined with the approach of mid-term legislative elections on October 22nd, will in the short term complicate relations with Congress, where the president lacks a majority. The ruling Cambiemos alliance, which includes the Pro and the centre-left Unión Cívica Radical, has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda in both houses of Congress on an ad hoc basis with the various factions of the large Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party). So far this support has mainly been forthcoming, not least because the largest opposition force, the leftist-populist faction of the Peronist party, known as the Frente para la Victoria, has been weakened by a series of damaging corruption scandals.
We expect obstructionism to increase amid election-related politicking surrounding a mid-term election in October 2017, and as a presidential election in October 2019 approaches. But mutual interest will ensure some continuing co-operation between Cambiemos and moderate Peronists. On top of this, a strong executive branch (the president has substantial powers to rule by decree) should provide Mr Macri with room for manoeuvre, even assuming that Congress becomes less co-operative. The president will also retain influence with powerful provincial governors, who largely control the agenda of the Senate (the upper house) but who are in turn deeply reliant on central government transfers, some of which are discretionary. As a result, we expect some continued progress on the govern-ment agenda.
However, we assume that, with electoral considerations coming into play, there will be limited progress on legislation that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Compre-hensive efforts to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. We do not expect meaningful advances on a structural reform agenda.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
A concentration of power in the executive helps to speed progress with the government agenda, but results in a lack of transparency in decision-making. The trend towards a concentration of power in the executive has occurred ever since the 2001-02 economic crisis, at which point extraordinary powers were given to the president to expedite policymaking. More than a decade on, these extraordinary powers have become entrenched; Mr Macri has for example periodically used decree powers to push through policy measures or political appointments, particularly when Congress is in recess. Although Mr Macri may be more likely to pursue them than his predecessor, reforms that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and strengthen the bureaucracy will prove politically difficult. The permanent state bureaucracy is made up mainly of low-paid clerical jobs. The professionals responsible for designing and implementing policy are appointed on short-term contracts, which are renewed with each change of government (or even minister).
Reforms to improve the legal system are required
Reforms are required to improve the legal system, which has for decades been plagued by corruption and inefficiency. Under the presidency of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), the courts resisted pressure to side with the government; the Supreme Court ultimately declared that a legal reform threatening judicial independence was unconstitutional, ensuring that the law (which had been passed by a razor-thin margin in Congress) did not come into effect. The presence of a non-Peronist executive provides some opportunity for a new judicial reform proposal that addresses the problems of corruption and inefficiency in the judiciary (there has been a historic tendency for executive-branch overreach among Peronists). Significantly, upon taking office Mr Macri quickly filled two vacant seats on the Supreme Court with candidates viewed as highly qualified and unbiased. However, we are not optimistic about significant reform measures being taken in the short term, given Mr Macri's minority position in Congress. Without a strengthening of the legal system, it will be difficult to address the problem of corruption in government. A number of investigations into members of the Fernández government are under way, but voters have complained of a lack of convictions.
Political outlook: Election watch
Mid-term elections are set for October 22nd. Open, nationwide primary elections will be held on August 13th, but, in practice, Argentina's political parties continue to choose their candidates via internal selection processes, and the primaries will therefore serve as a sort of dress rehearsal for the main event. With the primaries now less than three months away, campaigning is beginning to dominate the political scene. We expect the Peronists to remain the largest political force in Congress after the mid-terms, given their dominance of provincial politics and strong grassroots presence. The ruling Pro and its partners in the Cambiemos coalition are currently in a minority position in both houses of Congress, and we do not expect this to change in the mid-terms. For Cambiemos, a more important marker is whether it gains or loses seats, and how it performs on the Buenos Aires congressional list (voters select party lists; this gauges both how popular the political parties are and how popular the leading candidates on each list are). A good performance in Buenos Aires by the Pro, although mainly symbolic and not enough to provide a majority in Congress, would send a signal of the government's popularity. This is important because the dominant Peronist party would be much less likely to support the legislative agenda of an unpopular government.
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and a return to single-digit inflation by then, we currently expect Mr Macri to win a second four-year term. There are substantial risks to this forecast, given the challenging external environment and the government's minority position in Congress. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has ever won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. In this context, the emergence of a strong challenger from the moderate wing of the Peronist party is a substantial possibility and the election will be closely fought.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Mauricio Macri
Mr Macri is one of the very few non-Peronist politicians to translate popularity at the local level into a presidential victory. Previously the popular right-wing mayor of the capital, Buenos Aires, a centre of opposition to the then-president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), Mr Macri was able to secure an electoral alliance with the centrist Unión Cívica Radical that gave him the nationwide political structure that he needed for a successful presidential campaign. Mr Macri's biggest political challenge to date has been in seeking consensus for difficult economic adjustments. So far, he has been successful; although his opinion poll ratings have slipped, they remain relatively high (above 50%). His negotiating skills (and those of key cabinet members) have been put to the test and have also proved successful so far, with major reforms including legislative approval for a deal with holdout creditors approved early on in his term.
Marcos Peña
Mr Peña, a close ally of the president, was appointed cabinet chief after serving in the same post in the Buenos Aires city government under Mr Macri. Mr Peña was elected to the Buenos Aires city government when he was just 26 years old, and was, with Mr Macri, one of the founders of the centre-right Propuesta Repúblicana (Pro) party. He plays a key role in the Macri administration as chief negotiator, both in Congress and in cabinet, and is at the centre of the most important government decisions.
Nicolás Dujovne
The finance minister, Mr Dujovne succeeded Arturo Prat-Gay in a cabinet reshuffle at the end of 2016, apparently in response to internal dispute between Mr Prat-Gay and the president of the Banco Central de la República Argentina (the central bank), Federico Sturzenegger, over the direction of fiscal and monetary policy. Mr Dujovne is a fiscal hawk and has emphasised transparency in fiscal reporting, introducing quarterly as well as three-year fiscal targets. In the coming year he hopes to enact fiscal responsibility legislation with the provinces. He has also mooted a broad payroll tax reform, but this is unlikely to be contemplated until after mid-term elections in October 2017, and is likely to face difficult passage through Congress, although it could be pushed through in a watered-down form, assuming that the ruling coalition fares moderately well in the mid-term elections.
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner
Although she holds no public post, the former president has been a thorn in Mr Macri's side and a fierce critic of economic adjustment measures under the new government. However, her influence appears to be waning as her political movement (the Frente para la Victoria, a left-wing faction of the Partido Justicialista-the Peronist Party) struggles with allegations of corruption during her presidency. Before corruption allegations against members of her government surfaced, Ms Fernández was thought likely to run for Congress in 2017, in an effort to position herself for another run at the presidency in 2019. However, the public mood seems to be shifting away from Ms Fernández, leading to a battle for control of the Peronist party among more moderate factions of the party.
Juan Manuel Urtubey
Mr Urtubey, the governor of Salta province, has been outspoken in recent years against Ms Fernández, and could prove a unifying figure for key Peronist politicians, including a number of governors who did not identify with Ms Fernández's lunge to the left of recent years and who represent more traditional Peronist views, closer to its trade-unionist roots. Mr Urtubey will face stiff competition for the leadership from other Peronist figures who are thought to also harbour presidential ambitions, such as José Manuel de la Sota, the governor of Córdoba
Political outlook: International relations
Efforts by the Macri administration to repair relations with trade and investment partners have achieved rapid results, and we expect relations with key trade partners in the region and elsewhere to remain strong, with the possible exception of the US. Like most other governments in Latin America, the Macri administration was wrong-footed by the victory of Donald Trump in the US presidential election in November 2016. After cultivating strong ties with the previous US administration led by Barack Obama (2009-17), Mr Macri is likely to abandon recent efforts to secure preferential trade ties with the US with a view to an eventual free-trade agreement. The Argentinian government will remain keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended from the group in 2016). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, free trade has shifted off the political agenda not only in the US but also in Europe. Mr Macri recently visited Spain in an effort to drum up support for a deal, and negotiations are continuing. Our forecasts do not currently assume a successful conclusion of free-trade talks with the EU, but the workings of intra-Mercosur trade are likely to improve in the forecast period. Efforts at joining the Pacific Alliance, a regional trading bloc that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico, may also make progress, although this is not currently reflected in our five-year economic forecasts.

Population growth will remain slow
Population growth has slowed in recent decades and is expected to remain below the Latin American average. Owing to a relatively low birth rate, the percentage of the population aged 14 or under is low by Latin American standards, and is falling. A declining gross birth rate and longer life expectancy also account for the high and rising share of the population aged 65 years and over, although, at just over 11% this is still below that of OECD countries, where shares above 15% are the norm. Even so, the ageing population places increasing demand on Argentina's healthcare services, which have deteriorated significantly in recent years.
The forecast rise in the economically active portion of the population is chiefly the result of an expected increase in the female participation rate. The latter has increased gradually to 48.5% in 2016, up from 40% in 1990. This is still below a total labour force participation rate of over 60% (and below the OECD average female participation rate of 51%) and can be expected to rise towards 50% in the forecast period. Although the gross birth rate is forecast to fall over the next decade, the gross mortality rate is expected to stay broadly constant as the ageing of the population offsets improvements in healthcare conditions. Argentina has in the past been the recipient of much inward migration (an estimated 85% of the population is of European descent) and has established quite a flexible approach to immigration. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects policy in this area to remain relatively flexible in the forecast period, enabling economic sectors such as agriculture and construction to continue to benefit from immigrant labour. Our positive medium-term economic forecasts for Argentina suggest that inward migration could pick up in the forecast period, following a period of substantial outward migration in recent decades. Partly owing to strong ties to Europe, 600,000 Argentinians are estimated to live abroad. Around one-third of these emigrated in the years immediately follow-ing the 2001-02 economic crisis. These newer emigrants are mainly middle-class young people who have moved to Spain, Italy and the US, many of whom benefit from dual Italian or Spanish citizenship.
An urban population with marked regional disparities
The population is highly urbanised. More than 90% of the country's population is concentrated in urban centres-one of the highest ratios in the world. The Buenos Aires metropolitan area contains almost one-third of the national population; when the hinterland of Buenos Aires (the pampas) is included, the proportion rises to two-thirds. Overall, population density is low, at 13 inhabitants per sq km (around one-third of the Latin American average), although this aggregate figure masks wide regional disparities: in the capital there are 13,679 inhabitants per sq km, whereas in the southern provinces of Santa Cruz and Chubut, population density is just 0.8 and 1.8 inhabitants per sq km respectively. Most measures of social and economic development show marked disparities between rural and urban areas, with per-head incomes and healthcare and education indicators much better in the Buenos Aires area than elsewhere.
Argentina's lead in regional healthcare and education standards will erode
Although Argentina's healthcare indicators still compare favourably with those of most of its neighbours, social conditions worsened markedly during the 1998-2002 recession, and in many areas problems have persisted despite firm growth for most of the following decade, suggesting that expenditure has become inefficient. The healthcare and education systems are in urgent need of reform. Even so, a high level of educational attainment by regional standards mean that the stock of human capital will remain a source of comparative strength, although improvements in some other Latin American countries will close the gap within the region.

Improvement of investment environment under new government
The Economist Intelligence Unit's global business rankings measure the quality and attractiveness of the investment environment in 82 of the world's largest economies, including 12 in Latin America. Argentina's 20-place jump in the overall rankings is the most significant improvement globally, by some distance. Partly, Argentina's improvement reflects a particularly poor 2012-16, charac-terised by the then-government's expansionary and distortionary macro-economic policies, a weak legal and regulatory framework as a result of ad hoc government interventionism, and policies that deterred trade and investment. Although the more market-friendly government of Mauricio Macri took office at the end of 2015, the average score for the 2012-16 historical period remains weak. Mr Macri's administration has made significant strides in rolling back the distortions that characterised the previous administration's tenure, resulting in a noticeable improvement in the investment climate and prompting an improvement in the component scores across virtually every area of the business environment.
Our forecasts currently assume that there will continue to be relatively rapid, large improvements in a number of key areas of the business environment, including the macroeconomic environment, policy towards private enterprise and competition, foreign trade and exchange controls, and financing. To Argentina's benefit, it already scores highly in a number of categories in which improvements are generally difficult and take longer to bear fruit, such as infrastructure, market opportunities and the labour market. Argentina's worst-scoring category will remain tax, as making improvements to the burdensome, unwieldy tax system will prove extremely difficult politically.
Business environment outlook: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2019-21: Continued work to build confidence in legal and regulatory framework. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2017-18: Efforts to resolve any remaining disputes with international creditors and investors as the government seeks fresh sources of US dollar inflows. Government makes concessions to oil investors in attempt to bolster foreign investment.
2019-21: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Remaining foreign-exchange controls likely to be removed. Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance.
2019-21: Possibility that FTA talks make better progress, but EU-Mercosur talks are unlikely to have reached completion.
Taxes
2017-18: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax system remains complex and burdensome.
2019-21: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist.
Financing
2017-18: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2019-21: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2017-18: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of the unions will remain strong.
2019-21: Progress on labour reform unlikely. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The Macri administration works to address weak contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes, which keep private investment below potential. Financing constraints hamper public investment in the short term.
2019-21: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.

Macroeconomic environment will improve sharply during the forecast period
Argentina's global and regional ranking for the macroeconomic environment improves substantially between the historical and forecast period. The weak score in 2012-16-one of the worst in our global model-reflected the highly distortionary policy environment under Mr Macri's predecessor, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15). The institutional underpinnings of macroeconomic stability were poor, with a politicised central bank taking monetary policy decisions based on the government's fiscal demands and highly questionable official statistics, following a change of methodology and staffing at the the official statistics institute (Indec). The weak quality of policymaking also undermined the macroeconomic environment.
We expect significant improvements in all of these areas in 2017-21. Mr Macri's policy stance is much more investor-friendly, which has led to an improvement in the quality of policymaking and reasonable progress in addressing the distortions put in place by the previous administration, even though the consequences (most notably in high levels of inflation) will continue to hamper economic performance, at least in the short term. The government is also working to improve the quality of information and to restore operational independence to the Banco Central de la República Argentina (the central bank). Assuming that these efforts continue, Mr Macri should lay the found-ations for firmer medium-term economic performance.
The fact that Argentina's overall score and ranking in this area improves in 2017-21 is based on the assumption that the negative effects of the policy adjustment-which contributed to a recession in 2016-pass rapidly, with the economy returning to fairly solid rates of growth from 2017. Inflation will remain high but trend downwards, returning to single-digits from 2019. Fiscal consolidation efforts should reduce the deficit. Meanwhile, improved terms of trade are expected to reduce the current-account deficit.
There are downside risks attached to these projections. The assumption of a smooth transition out of recession and towards a (relatively) low-inflation environment with a more sustainable external position may be overly optimistic, given Argentina's track record (the country has a history of economic instability and disorderly swings from one economic model to another). Given the scale of distortions that Mr Macri inherited, as well as constraints to the achievement of a low-inflation environment such as wage indexation and growing public frustration with the short-term knock-on effects of policy tightening, it will take time to engender confidence in the central bank's capacity to contain inflation.

The economy will benefit from the return to a market-friendly policy stance
Argentina's score and ranking for private enterprise and competition improves substantially for the 2017-21 forecast period under our assumption that the Macri government continues to introduce measures that actively encourage private investment and promote competition. The Fernández government had a track record of arbitrary decision-making that was often detrimental to the private sector and eroded confidence in the legal framework. It also persistently focused its efforts on managing the economy at the company level (rather than adopting sounder fiscal or monetary policies), hampering the freedom of businesses to compete and giving rise to allegations of crony capitalism. Under Mr Macri, we expect a revamped competition commission to focus on amendments to anti-trust legislation. Across the public sector, a reduction in red tape is likely; legislation reducing red tape for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) was approved earlier this year. The government will also remain committed to scaling back price controls and subsidies, although an official acknowledgement that measures are needed to cushion the impact on consumers of what are significant adjustments indicates that the process will be subject to delay. Although these efforts will be hampered by lobbying by special interest groups in the context of Argentina's long tradition of political clientelism, we expect significant improvements in all of these areas. Meanwhile, state participation in key sectors, including energy, utilities and banking, is expected to continue.
Under Ms Fernández, the Comisión Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia (CNDC, the competition authority) was a weak and ineffective body, doing little to prevent monopolistic practices or protect consumer rights. This is changing under Mr Macri. He appointed a new head of the CNDC in February 2016, Esteban Greco, who immediately performed an internal audit and made significant staff changes. He focused immediately on crafting a reform to the current anti-trust law, which was submitted to the legislature in late 2016. The reform would make the CNDC an independent body, tighten penalties for companies found guilty of competition-related offences and create an undersecretariat responsible for investigation, training and education. Closer co-operation with US competition authorities to train staff on mergers and acquisitions will also raise standards in this area. The reform legislation is still awaiting final approval, but we expect it to be passed in the coming months.
Agricultural export taxes and quotas are continuing to be scaled back, but the process will be subject to delays. Immediately upon taking office, Mr Macri eliminated export taxes on wheat, beef and corn. He also reduced the tax on soybeans-the most important export crop-from 35% to 30% in early 2016 and had indicated that the tax would continue to be cut by 5 percentage points each year. However, fiscal difficulties have prompted the government to delay the process. In October 2016 Mr Macri announced that the soybean export tax would be kept on hold until the beginning of 2018, when the rate will be progressively reduced by half a percentage point each month until the end of 2019 (implying an end-2019 level of 18%). We currently expect the scaling back to continue from 2018, but there could be renewed delays if economic performance is weaker than we are forecasting.
The process of scaling back price controls on consumer goods will progress very slowly in the short term. Upon taking office, the government kept a price control programme, Precios Cuidados, in place, as it sought to curb the pass-through effect on inflation of currency devaluation, but it reduced the number of basic consumer items covered from 500 to 317. But since then a number of new products has been added to the list, with over 450 products now covered, in response to stubbornly-high inflation. Renewed efforts to reduce price controls on consumer goods are unlikely until inflation begins to subside.
There has been more progress on efforts to raise electricity and natural gas tariffs. Following a removal of subsidies and an increase in wholesale prices in early 2016, in June the government introduced hefty price increases for end-users, with gas bills quadrupling for most consumers and electricity bills rising by around six-fold, in spite of considerable domestic opposition. In early 2017 the government announced new increases to utility rates in the Buenos Aires metropolitan area of 60-148%. Even with the increases, the government will still be shouldering a fiscal burden of around 1.5% of GDP in terms of gas and utility subsidies. The authorities will continue to scale back subsidies in 2018-19, entailing further raises in utility rates, with the aim of aligning domestic rates with market rates by the end of 2019. However, this timetable may slip if inflation fails to fall as expected.

Foreign investment to pick up
Argentina's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment improves significantly between the historical and forecast period. This reflects Mr Macri's much more welcoming stance towards foreign capital and his efforts to make government policy towards foreign investment more transparent, clear and predictable. Progress on lifting energy tariffs will make foreign participation more attractive, while the sovereign's exit from default in April lifts a major constraint on foreign investment by reopening access to investment protection schemes (a key factor driving the increase in Argentina's score in this category for 2017-21). The government's more market-friendly approach means that the risk of expropriations is much lower, while government favouritism of domestic firms will be less marked. Despite the new government's more welcoming stance to foreign investment, we expect outright privatisation to remain off the agenda. The public still places much of the blame for the 2001-02 crisis on the privatisation process of the 1990s, in which foreign firms featured heavily.
Argentina's exit from default has facilitated access to capital markets, but the government's ambitious plans for infrastructure and housing development will still necessitate foreign participation in the context of fiscal expenditure constraints. With this in mind, a bill establishing a public-private partnership (PPP) framework for investment was signed into law in December 2016. Official estimates that it could raise potential capital inflows by US$90bn are likely to prove extremely optimistic, but the legislation will boost foreign participation in the country's infrastructure drive.
Energy policy reforms to liberalise tariffs and promote investment are likely to boost multinational interest in deals to commercialise Argentina's vast shale oil and gas reserves (the world's second-largest). Even though the government is likely to continue to align energy prices with market levels, the process is expected to be gradual, and recent pledges to foreign energy companies to offer labour flexibility and price subsidies in exchange for firmer commitments to move pilot projects (of which there are currently 18) into the development stage (in which there are only two projects) will lift inward investment.

An easing of controls is well under way
Mr Macri's rapid moves to dismantle currency controls upon taking office are the main factor driving the improvement in Argentina's score and ranking in this area. Rather than a steady and gradual process, the government opted for an immediate lifting of controls and simultaneous devaluation of the peso, on the basis that this would provide clarity, transparency and a strong signal of the government's commitment to change. Most export duties were removed and the requirement for official authorisation from the tax bureau for all US dollar purchases and profit remittances was lifted. The move has essentially eliminated the black-market exchange rate, and fears of an uncontrolled unravelling of the peso have been unfounded (although the peso has weakened moderately).
Mr Macri's close relations with the Brazilian president, Michel Temer, are facilitating trade liberalisation efforts by Mercosur, the Southern Cone customs union. There has been recent progress on a long-mooted free-trade agreement (FTA) between Mercosur and the EU, with a week of negotiations in late April in Buenos Aires between both sides. However, significant obstacles remain-particularly over the treatment of agricultural products, with several EU countries (including France) concerned about exposing their own agricultural sectors to greater external competition-and we do not expect both sides to sign a final FTA within the forecast period. But an increase in intra-regional trade is possible, particularly if efforts to join the Pacific Alliance, an integration project that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico, and on which Argentina has observer status, are successful.

Despite improvements, the tax system will remain complex
Although we expect some improvements in 2017-21, Argentina's tax system will remain the weakest area of the business environment. Tax policy is becoming more predictable under the Macri government, but it will take time to address the system's complexity (over 35 different types of tax are collected), high costs and inefficiency. According to the World Bank's 2017 Doing Business report, in Argentina a medium-sized company takes 359 hours per year to prepare, file and pay its taxes, compared with an OECD average of 163 hours, and pays a total tax rate (including labour contributions) of 106% of profits (the OECD average is 41%). At 35%, the corporate tax rate is one of the highest in the region. Under Mr Macri, a reduction and eventual elimination of the most distortionary taxes, such as agricultural export taxes, will be likely. But a broad-and politically difficult-reform to increase the consistency and equity of the system has long been put off and remains extremely unlikely to be addressed in the forecast period. Although we expect both tax evasion and labour informality to moderate somewhat, significant improvements in these areas are unlikely.
Reforms to the system of revenue-sharing with the provinces are badly needed to secure the stability of the tax system. Although there have been some efforts to reduce discretionary transfers to provinces, continued delays on a comprehensive reform can be expected, given Mr Macri's focus on boosting macroeconomic performance. In the absence of a reform package, the executive will continue to roll over provincial debt, as it has done several times since 2010. Until the problems in the system of revenue-sharing with the provinces are addressed, weaknesses in the provincial finances will sustain the need for further central government bailouts and therefore raise the risk of periodic ad hoc measures at the national level to increase tax revenue.
The Macri government has passed several tax measures to improve conditions for SMEs that have been particularly badly hit by deteriorating economic conditions. From the start of 2017, SMEs have been exempt from the minimum notional income tax levied on companies' assets. This tax accounts for a very small share of total tax revenue (0.2% in 2015), but is burdensome for SMEs (particularly for manufacturing companies who generally have more assets in the form of equipment than service providers), as it must be paid even in the event of losses. In addition, SMEs are now able to offset bank debit and credit tax against income tax. SMEs are also able to pay value-added tax (VAT) on sales every three months rather than monthly, which will assist with cashflow. Finally, to encourage investment, the law offsets up to 10% of new investments in capital goods and infrastructure against income tax.

Argentina's score and ranking for financing improve sharply for the forecast period, reflecting an easing in corporate financing constraints now that Argentina has exited default. Yet although we envisage an improvement in conditions for foreign companies operating in Argentina, long-term credit lines will still be restricted-particularly for SMEs-by structural constraints, including the banking sector's weak deposit base (a legacy of the 2001-02 crisis). Medium- and long-term credit for domestic business is therefore likely to remain scarce until late in the forecast period. Large foreign companies will continue to meet most of their financing needs through external sources. Banking sector regulation and supervision are expected to be reasonable, while financial soundness and profitability indicators will remain solid. However, some weaknesses in the system persist, including shallow financial markets and low levels of banking penetration.
Domestic capital markets will remain underdeveloped by regional and particularly global comparison. The nationalisation of private pension funds in 2008 was a serious blow to their growth and has had a lasting impact. Argentina's private pension-fund administrators were the country's most important institutional investors and were a growing source of finance in the local capital markets. Under current regulations, the Administración Nacional de Seguridad Social (Anses, the social security agency, which took over the nationalised pension fund assets) is able to allocate up to 50% of assets in local private companies' shares and up to 10% of assets in foreign government securities. Although reforms are likely and the Macri government is unlikely to use the Anses funds to finance government investment, the changes will take time to bear fruit, and growth with be from a very low base: stockmarket capitalisation stood at less than 15% of GDP in March 2017. The stockmarket is currently shallow and undiversified, with ten companies accounting for around 95% of total market capitalisation.
Business environment outlook: The labour market

Labour market reforms are unlikely
Although we do not expect a sharp improvement in the labour market in 2017-21, the relatively well-educated, productive and flexible labour force has long been an asset to the country's business environment (and made the labour market one of Argentina's highest-ranking categories in the historical period). That we do not expect significant improvements (indeed, Argentina's global ranking is expected to fall in 2017-21) reflects the political difficulty of securing support for reforms to simplify labour regulations and addressing the highly unionised labour market that produces a high incidence of strikes. In the short term, difficult economic adjustments that are contributing to a decline in real wages and a cut in purchasing power will translate into a high level of strikes, particularly as the government continues to rein in wage increases against the backdrop of high levels of inflation. Mr Macri faces a tough task in tackling union power, and we expect little progress on reducing the extent of wage and other labour-market regulation.
Although we expect labour reform to be slow and piecemeal, it should gradually help to boost business sentiment. A first step approved in Congress in early 2017 was a reform of the Labour Insurance Law. The law allows workers who have suffered accidents or work-related illnesses to seek compensation in the courts. Because so many do so (claims are reported to have multiplied by a factor of 40 since 2003), insurance premiums paid by employers against such claims are very high. The reform seeks to reduce premiums by establishing new medical commissions that will weed out unreasonable or bogus compensation claims before they reach the industrial tribunal stage. Changes are also being proposed to make it easier for employers to "formalise" informal workers, bringing them in to the tax and benefits system, and to centralise training schemes to be run by a single national agency. For political reasons, further reforms are likely to be pursued in a piecemeal fashion and may be put on the backburner at sensitive times during wage negotiations. In the meantime, sector-by-sector negotiations could continue. An outline deal with unions and employers in the oil industry reached in January 2017 cuts overtime and allows multitasking for workers in the Vaca Muerta shale oil and gas field in Patagonia.
Skills shortages and mismatches have become more of a problem for business in the past decade, compounded by a lack of effective training pro-grammes in both the public and private sectors. Secondary and tertiary enrollment are very high by regional standards, but educational outcomes are not as strong as would be expected given these rates, and vary widely by province. At the same time, access to job training tends to be unequal and informal.

More private investment will help to upgrade infrastructure
Infrastructure remains Argentina's highest-scoring area of the business environment, although its global ranking slips as other similarly-scoring countries make more progress. The country boasts a well-developed telecoms network, as well as relatively low property rental costs. However, physical infrastructure has suffered over the past decade from a lack of investment. We currently assume that Argentina's exit from default, the passage of PPP legislation and improvements in contract rights will help to boost investment both in transport infrastructure and energy. However, such projects will take time to come on stream, explaining Argentina's unchanged score in 2017-21, raising the risk that infrastructure bottlenecks will continue to hamper growth in the meantime.
The risk of energy shortages will persist in the short term at least, given long project completion times. Demand for electricity and gas has soared in the past decade, but as tariffs for residential and business consumers are lifted, demand growth is expected to slow. Argentina is expected to sign a final agreement with China in the coming weeks to construct a fourth and fifth nuclear reactor in Argentina, with construction expected to begin in 2018. Aside from this, prospects are less certain. Despite Argentina's vast hydroelectric potential, no further large projects are under way. The government is preparing several auctions in both the conventional and renewable sector over the course of 2017, but successful bids are unlikely to translate into new capacity until late in the forecast period (or even after). In the short term at least, the lack of new energy capacity coming on stream will maintain dependence on imports, and increase exposure to weather-related problems at existing hydropower facilities.
Economic forecast: Policy trends

The Macri administration has made good initial progress on a programme of adjustment intended to put the economy on a sounder footing, having devalued the peso, reduced agricultural export duties and energy subsidies, and secured a deal with holdout creditors (allowing Argentina to exit default). However, macroeconomic adjustment remains incomplete, and policy efforts to reduce inflation will continue, in the form of tight fiscal and monetary policy and restraint in nominal wage growth. The latter in particular is proving a difficult political challenge, and has encountered stiff union resistance. The government is extremely unlikely to meet its goal of limiting nominal wage growth to 20% this year, but we do continue to expect nominal wages to trend downwards steadily from levels of above 30% in recent years. All of these measures should gradually engender price stability and ultimately boost investor confidence, although we do not expect inflation to fall to single-digit levels until 2019.
With macroeconomic adjustment measures proceeding apace, the government is gradually turning its attention to the structural reform agenda and to reforms to improve the business environment, and we expect a growing policy emphasis on these areas. The government has already passed new public-private partnership framework legislation that should facilitate an increase in infrastructure investment, along with reforms to reduce red-tape financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. The development of longer-term finance and the deepening of Argentina's currently shallow capital markets will be a priority. However, other aspects of the policymaking environ-ment will remain suboptimal, with progress on labour-market reform (to improve flexibility) or comprehensive fiscal and tax reform (to reduce costs and complexity) unlikely in the medium term amid political obstruction.

The government has changed the methodology of its fiscal reporting, and because it now presents profits from the Banco Central de la Repùblica (BCRA, the central bank) below the line as financing rather than above the line as revenue, the outturn on the non-financial public-sector deficit is substantially higher than previously reported, at 5.9% of GDP in 2016 (versus 4.5% of GDP previously). Our forecasts have been revised upwards as a result, although the trend remains the same. In the short term, higher than expected revenue from a tax amnesty on undeclared foreign assets will bolster the fiscal accounts and allow the government to meet its target of narrowing the fiscal deficit to 4.2% of GDP in 2017, slightly below the 4.5% of GDP registered in 2016. We expect the government's gradualist approach to fiscal tightening to continue in subsequent years, bringing the fiscal deficit down to a more manageable level of about 3% of GDP by the end of the forecast period, and bringing the primary deficit down to about 1% of GDP by 2021. To date, the govern-ment has taken some important steps to try to narrow the deficit, particularly by reducing costly subsidies and the public-sector payroll. Even so, in the light of recently announced income-tax breaks and increased transfers (to expand the social safety net), deficit reduction will be slow.
In the aftermath of the holdout deal, and assuming that there is progress on deficit reduction, the government's ability to finance moderate deficits without resorting to inflationary money printing will be much improved. A moderate public debt/GDP ratio (and low levels of external indebtedness), combined with the attractiveness of Argentina's still-high yields, should facilitate international bond issuance in 2017-21, following Argentina's exit from default earlier this year. In January the sovereign issued US$7bn in five- and ten-year global bonds. As a percentage of GDP, the public debt will stabilise at slightly under 50% in 2017-21.

Notwithstanding a recent policy reversal, which saw the BCRA lift the policy rate from 24.75% to 26.25% in April, we continue to expect fairly substantial rate cuts in the second half of 2017 and beyond. The policy rate is below the year-earlier peak of 38%, but inflation has been slow to come down amid a series of tariff increases, and inflation expectations have been rising as a result, to slightly over 21% at end-2017, well above the central bank's 12-17% target range for this year. The BCRA has responded with what we expect to be a one-off rate rise to make its commitment to the newly implemented inflation-targeting framework clear. Assuming that monthly inflation starts to fall towards 1% on a consistent basis, we expect ample scope for renewed monetary easing from later this year.
The central bank has made it clear that it will prioritise monetary policy that is conducive to a reduction of inflation, and our forecasts assume moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term, consistent with a deepening of credit and the development of long-term lending. This forecast is supported by the shift to an inflation-targeting regime (with the target due to be lowered to 8-12% in 2018 and 5% in 2019), and assumes reduced political interference after a period of politicisation under the previous administration.

After a contraction in real GDP of 2.3% in 2016, we expect a return to positive territory in 2017. But with Brazil likely to post barely positive growth in 2017, manufacturing activity in Argentina will recover only moderately, limiting GDP growth to 2.6%. We currently expect the recovery to peak in 2018, with growth of 3.6%. However, the annual growth rate for that year masks an expected sequential deceleration in the second half of 2018, resulting from a projected weakening of Chinese import demand. By 2019, when we project a cyclical downturn in the US economy, real GDP growth in Argentina will slide back below 3%, before a modest recovery takes hold again in 2020-21.
Our forecast for a relatively robust recovery in the medium term is based on the assumption that a combination of macroeconomic adjustment and improvements to the business environment will eventually have some beneficial impact on both export activity and domestic demand. An easing of inflation, combined with efforts by the Macri government to address the problem of legal and regulatory uncertainty and reduce red tape, should set the stage for renewed strong growth in fixed investment and private consumption, supporting an acceleration of GDP growth.
There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to reduce economic distortions and engineer a smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging, keeping both con-sump-tion and investment subdued for longer than we expect. However, there is also some upside risk, as investment could overtake expectations from 2017 once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and depending on the success of efforts to improve the framework for doing business. However, even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform efforts than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than 4%.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Agriculture will continue to be a key contributor to the Argentinian economy. Although it has accounted for around 10% of GDP over the past decade, and for around 20% of private employment, these figures underestimate its contribution, as they do not include agro-industry. Weak soft commodity prices relative to the boom years of the commodities supercycle will have some dampening impact on agriculture. However, we believe that a more important factor in the sector's growth prospects will be the easing of export taxes and quotas by the Macri administration. This follows a period of ever-tightening controls implemented by the administration of the former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), to keep domestic prices low, which ultimately restricted profitability and hence output. A more stable, clear and attractive environment for agriculture producers will boost output. It will also support agro-industry (including the processing of Argentina's key crop, soybean) and bolster a manufacturing sector that is currently struggling amid still-weak demand both at home and in Brazil. We expect a mild economic recovery in Brazil in 2017-21, which will also help to produce a moderate pick-up in Argentinian manufacturing in 2017-21.
Better incentives should boost key sectors
Mining and energy are two sectors with great potential. Argentina has vast shale and gas resources, but, to date, commercialising them has proven difficult, particularly in the wake of the nationalisation of the country's largest energy company, YPF, in 2012. The Macri administration has started to tackle some of the main problems constraining investment, which, apart from a lack of confidence in the rule of law, include price controls that keep gas prices well below the international market price. In early 2017 the government announced a series of measures to boost investment and domestic production, thereby reducing reliance on imports. The measures include the "flexibilisation" of labour conditions in Vaca Muerta, a 30,000-sq-km oil field located in southern Argentina that is the world's second-largest shale gas reservoir and fourth-largest shale oil reservoir. The government is also hoping gradually to eliminate price distortions, but will retain high gas prices as an incentive to investment in the medium term. In exchange, oil companies including YPF, Total (France), Pan American Energy (Argentina), Chevron (US), Shell (Netherlands) and Dow (US) have agreed to invest US$5bn in Vaca Muerta in 2017. These increases in investment should see exploration and production activity in the sector rise steadily this year and in the remainder of the forecast period.
The mining sector also has substantial potential. It shares the mineral-rich southern Andes mountains with Chile, long recognised as one of the world's mining powerhouses. However, a longstanding combination of national neglect and provincial restrictions has slowed the pace of development. The latest available data show that Argentinian mining accounts for around 0.3% of GDP, and it is estimated that only around 15% of Argentina's mineral deposits are currently being exploited. A succession of governments in 2002-15 were seen as hostile to foreign mining companies, while being supportive of restrictive local content rules and in dispute with foreign creditors. The Macri administration has shifted government policies in a much more sector-friendly direction, and several projects are being developed. With global metal prices continuing to recover moderately, solid mining growth is still viable. But much will depend on the details of provincial-level regulations. The constitution grants ownership of sub-soil minerals to the provinces, and local regulations vary.
In an effort to standardise the regulatory environment for mining, a preliminary national mining accord was signed among the provinces in February. This agreement seeks, among other things, to augment public- and private-sector oversight of environmental matters; regulate public mining ventures along the same lines as private-sector operations; create a lithium board (with a view to formulating a comprehensive development plan for this rapidly developing subsector); and standardise the mining tax and royalty regime. The next step will be approval from the president to send the accord to the national legislature and to the provincial legislatures for their approval. The plan therefore has some way to go before it takes effect.

Consumer price inflation will decline steadily but gradually in the forecast period, from a rate of 29.4% in April (according to the Buenos Aires city index). Although high, the April result does represent a steep fall from a peak of 44.4% in May 2016, which resulted from currency and tariff adjust-ments by the new administration. Assuming tight monetary and fiscal policy (spending will remain negative in real terms until 2018), the inflationary spike will prove transitory, and we expect gradual disinflation in the medium term, provided that domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11 and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environ-ment for agricultural producers. The main risks to this forecast stem from possible failure to tighten fiscal policy as projected, a weaker than expected peso and the difficult process of reining in nominal wage growth. However, if the government is able to tackle the high level of wage indexation, there is also the potential for inflation to slow more than we currently project.

The peso stood at Ps15.7:US$1 in late May, having strengthened modestly from Ps15.9:US$1 at end-2016 on the back of increased portfolio flows. We expect renewed modest weakening in 2017-21, particularly in the first half of the forecast period as domestic interest rates decline and the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) continues a monetary tightening cycle. However, the positive outlook for portfolio and foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will be supportive of the currency, which will dampen depreciation pressure and produce some periods of real currency appreciation (as has occurred in recent months). In nominal terms, we expect the peso to end 2017 at Ps17.78US$1 and 2021 at Ps23.61US$1.

As the terms of trade improve and a weaker peso gradually boosts goods and services exports, improvements in the trade and services accounts will cause the current-account deficit to narrow. From 2.6% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to fall to an annual average of 1.2% of GDP in 2017-21. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve, assuming that portfolio and FDI inflows pick up as investor confidence grows. The result will be a rise in foreign reserves in nominal terms. Our forecasts currently assume FDI inflows averaging 2% of GDP in 2017-21, with foreign reserves equivalent to an annual average 8.1 months of import cover in the same period.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Argentina
Stocks and flows
The inward foreign direct investment (FDI) stock was US$92bn (15% of GDP) in 2015 and the outward stock of FDI was US$38bn (6% of GDP). Inflows of FDI to Argentina have been volatile in recent decades and have followed economic cycles of boom and bust. In the 1990s inflows to Argentina increased substantially, reaching 3.7% of GDP in the second half of the decade, reflecting a privatisation programme and acquisitions of domestic private firms. This was followed by a collapse in inward FDI to 1.4% of GDP in 2001-03, reflecting Argentina's default and subsequent deep recession. Devaluation stimulated a rapid recovery of inward FDI in subsequent years, with inflows averaging 3.7% of GDP in 2003-08. Since then, however, FDI inflows have weakened, from 3% of GDP in 2008 to an annual average 1.8% of GDP in 2009-15. Since Mauricio Macri took office in December 2015, the government has worked to address concerns about the strength and predictability of the legal and regulatory environment. For now, however, inward FDI remains subdued by weak economic activity and tight macroeconomic policy.
Origin and distribution
US firms account for one-quarter of the stock of FDI, followed by Spanish firms with 16%, and Dutch firms with 11%. Chilean, Brazilian and Uruguayan companies account for around 5% each. Spanish firms have invested in privatised utilities, banking and energy. European firms in the utilities and banking sectors were hit hard by the 2001-02 crisis. As many companies disinvested after the crisis, firms from Brazil, Mexico and Chile bought up cheap assets. In 2015 the largest foreign direct investor in Argentina, by some distance, was the US, followed by Spain. The potential for an influx of Chinese FDI, focused in particular in agri-business, is thought to be substantial. However, the latest local-source data on FDI inflows into Argentina by country show that, of US$13.3bn in total inflows in 2015, less than US$100m came from China.
Determinants
FDI into Argentina is quite broadly spread; oil accounts for 20% of the stock, followed by chemicals, the automotive sector, metal minerals, the financial sector and telecommunications, although in the past decade almost half of FDI inflows have gone into manufacturing. Historically, Argentina has attracted investors hoping to take advantage of a relatively affluent and protected domestic market. During the 1990s, and as a result of rapid trade liberalisation, domestic market-seeking investment focused on sectors that showed comparative (or even absolute) advantages or were naturally protected from foreign competition (non-tradeable services, such as utilities). Efficiency-seeking investments have been less common, and have been mainly limited to the automotive industry, where government incentives have been in place for over a decade. Recent FDI in services (including information technology-IT) has been attracted by Argentina's skilled workforce and relatively low wages.
Impact
The presence of foreign subsidiaries has brought positive spillovers (both within and across industries) in manufacturing, but only in sectors where domestic firms have proven sufficiently adaptable. In other cases, increased competition from foreign investors, or a preference on the part of the latter for foreign suppliers, has damaged local firms. Telecoms is one example of a sector where the quality of service and technology has been transformed by foreign investment. Foreign investors own most of the privatised utilities. After the 2001-02 maxi-devaluation, which in effect broke the terms of foreign inverstors' contracts (and after the government declined to renegotiate), investment declined. The contribution of foreign firms to local research and development activities has been limited, as technical progress has been mainly embodied by imported capital goods and turnkey plants. Foreign firms account for a large share of Argentina's exports.
Potential
The major attractions for FDI will be a growing and relatively high-income domestic market, strong natural-resource endowments and, to a lesser extent, Argentina's potential as a manufacturing base. A relatively large pool of skilled human capital and a large stock of natural resources constitute Argentina's long-term advantages. Argentina's exit from default in 2016 will also act as a spur to FDI inflows, by facilitating investor access to investment guarantees and trade finance, which has until recently been lacking.

Argentina's wealth of natural resources, large domestic market (with high per-head incomes relative to much of the rest of the region), and proximity and preferential access to the large Brazilian market represent attractive long-term opportunities for foreign investors. On top of this, The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast of a shift to moderate GDP growth rates of an annual average 3.2% in 2017-21, and an improvement in the environment for business, suggests an increase in domestic market opportunities in the medium term.
Some improvement in purchasing power expected
Argentina is a middle-income country with one of the highest levels of GDP per head in the region-US$21,258 at purchasing power parity (PPP) exchange rates in 2016. Demographics are generally supportive of growth: the population is estimated at around 44m (the fourth-largest in Latin America), and is relatively young, albeit not as young as that of most other countries in the region. Moreover, urbanisation is high, at more than 90% of the population. However, as in much of the region, income inequality and poverty remain high. According to recently released data from INDEC, the national statistics institute, the poverty rate came in at 30.3% in the second half of 2016. The extreme poverty rate was 6.1%. Although this represents a gradual improvement on early 2016, the poverty rate is clearly still high, and the gap between the cost of the basic consumption basket (used to measure the poverty line) and the average income of poor households is considerable: the former came in at Ps13,945 (US$870), while the latter was only Ps8,789. However, there are significant geographical disparities, with poverty rates highest outside of the capital, Buenos Aires. By national comparison, the poverty rate was highest in Santiago del Estero, in the north-west, at 44%. In Greater Buenos Aires province, which encircles but does not include the capital city, the poverty rate was also high, at 34.6%, probably reflecting the impact of a steep decline in manufacturing in the province. By contrast, the poverty rate was just 9.5% in the capital itself.
A full analysis of the poverty data over time is complicated by a lack of historical data. A deterioration of statistical quality during the previous administration led to unreliable poverty statistics; in the latter years of the previous administration, INDEC stopped publishing poverty statistics altogether. Under new leadership, INDEC began publishing poverty data in mid-2016, using new methodology that is not comparable with the discredited historical data. However, the latest INDEC data are similar to figures published by the Centro de Estudios Distributivos Laborales y Sociales (Cedlas), a social policy research institute at the Universidad Nacional de La Plata. According to Cedlas, the poverty rate is roughly similar to data from the first half of 2011, implying that there has been no progress on poverty reduction since then. In the medium term, lower inflation rates and steady economic growth should help to reduce poverty through spillover effects. In the meantime, however, poor social conditions will drive insecurity and social unrest.

A long-term shift in consumer attitudes was brought about by the economic crisis of 2001-02, which changed patterns of goods consumption markedly. A shift towards cheaper brands and lower-cost, high-volume outlets was not reversed even during the boom years of 2004-07. However, we expect the proportion of income spent on food, beverages and tobacco to fall gradually in the forecast period, and for the proportion of consumer spending on hotels and restaurants, healthcare, leisure and education to grow. This assumes growth in purchasing power as real disposable incomes rise over the course of the forecast period, driven by growth in employment, income redistribution via Argentina's relatively new conditional cash transfer schemes, and greater efforts at financial inclusion, which suggest a steady increase in access to bank credit during the forecast period. One difference between Argentina and the rest of the region will be the age of the population. Argentina's population will remain markedly older; just over 11% were aged 65 years and over in 2015. This will affect consumption patterns, notably pushing up overall expenditure on healthcare.

Abundant natural resources and a skilled labour force underpin potential
Argentina has historically been susceptible to cycles of boom and bust, reflecting both a vulnerability to external conditions and domestic policy challenges. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecast rests on the assumption that Argentina will adopt a more sustainable economic model that reduces fiscal and external imbalances, allowing the economy to grow by an average of 2.8% in 2017-50.
Initial conditions: Argentina's GDP per head of US$12,445 in 2016 (US$21,258 at purchasing power parity) is one of the highest in the region. However, as it is still only one-third of the US figure, there is clearly potential for Argentina to catch up to developed-country levels. The internal market is relatively large and, although the territory is extensive, there are few internal geographical obstacles, although Argentina is distant from developed-country markets and high transport costs will place an extra burden on exporters. For a decade after the 2001 maxi-devaluation, labour was cheaper than during the 1990s, but the gains from devaluation had been eliminated by 2012 amid high inflation and sustained real wage growth. Despite two decades of gradual de-industrial-isation, Argentina retains a solid skilled labour base and some capacity to carry out high-level research and development. It will attract manufacturing invest-ment, but its competitiveness as a global manufacturing centre will lag behind Asian rivals. Argentina has strong comparative advantages in agriculture, although, as a commodity producer, it will face more volatile terms of trade than Asian competitors. This means that growth is likely to be uneven.
Demographic trends: Argentina shares demographic as well as cultural features with Europe. The average age of the population is higher than in most of the rest of the region and population growth both in percentage and absolute terms is expected to be slightly lower. We expect population growth of 0.7% per year in 2017-50, less than half the average recorded in 1980-2000. At present, the working-age population is still growing faster than the overall population, but we expect this trend to change from around 2030. Although labour force participation rates will continue to rise gradually towards OECD levels, from an estimated 64% in 2020, growth in the labour force will slow as a result. Particularly towards the end of the long-term forecast period, the contribution of labour to GDP will therefore be weaker.
The population is more urbanised and better provided with healthcare than in other Latin American countries, leading to a life expectancy of around 76 years, similar to that of many developed countries. Given the existence of the welfare state and the severe weakening of the finances of the state and private pensions systems in the past two decades, the growing elderly population will increasingly generate strains on the public finances.
External conditions: Growth-determining factors exogenous to Argentina will include the level of developed-country interest rates (in the past this has been strongly correlated with the volume of capital flows into Latin America and has had a major impact on growth) and commodity prices. Argentina will remain highly dependent on income from exports of agricultural commodities to provide an investible surplus for deployment elsewhere in the economy. Restricted access to finance since the 2001 default has raised the cost of capital in the past decade by forcing reliance on financing from the shallow, more expensive domestic market. However, Argentina's exit from default in April 2016 implies improved access to international capital markets to facilitate stronger growth in investment, particularly in agriculture, energy and infrastructure.
Institutional weaknesses will constrain growth
Institutions and policy trends: Disappointing economic outcomes have been the indirect result of shortcomings in policymaking and institutions. Argentina scores moderately to poorly on measures of corruption, security and the rule of law. Our analysis suggests that an improvement in the overall institutional climate would have a significant impact on long-term growth, but institutional reforms will take a long time to bear fruit. The quality of policymaking is likely to improve more rapidly. The government of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15) clashed with foreign investors over the terms of contracts, and oversaw a phase of ad hoc intervention in the economy. A more market-friendly administration led by Mauricio Macri is seeking to address these problems, and we assume that the government will succeed early on in the long-term forecast period in establishing a new framework for foreign investors in sectors such as utilities.
GDP will grow by an annual average of 2.8% in 2017-50
Long-term performance: We forecast that average annual GDP will grow by 2.8% in 2017-50, with the growth rate peaking at 3.1% in 2021-30, before slowing to 3% in 2031-40 and 2.5% by 2041-50. Our forecasts assume that the contribution of capital to growth will be firm in the first part of the forecast period, before tapering off somewhat over the latter part of the period. We also assume that as growth in the working-age population slows, the increase in the availability of labour will slow, meaning that growth will become more dependent on productivity gains. To the extent that they are achieved, these gains are likely to be made via technology transfer and higher foreign invest-ment. Firms will increasingly look beyond national borders in order to achieve economies of scale, and this will stimulate efficiency gains. Having said this, and although Argentina's abundant natural resources and relatively strong skills base represent solid economic potential, the country will struggle to achieve the productivity gains needed to converge with developed-market income levels. This is particularly the case in the light of low levels of domestic investment in research and development, and we expect limited progress in catching up with developed country incomes even in the long-term forecast period.
