Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text:   Venezuela--highlights: Political outlook
Politics will be dominated by a volatile power struggle between the unpopular Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) government and the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD). Risks are growing that the PSUV will seek to cling to power beyond the next elections (scheduled for December 2018) by non-democratic means, with support of the military. Given the scale of opposition to the government, and limited means of addressing opposition concerns via institutional channels, there is also a high risk of a chaotic, violent transition, particularly in a context of a crippling economic crisis that the government has shown little willingness or capacity to address. Even under our current, benign assumption (which is subject to unusually high levels of uncertainty) of a transition to a MUD-led government in 2019, Venezuela will remain plagued by weak institutions, endemic corruption and poor security conditions, but we expect the MUD to undo many of the macroeconomic distortions imposed by successive PSUV governments since 1999.

Venezuela will enjoy a structural demographic bonus in 2017-21, as it will experience a more rapid increase in its working-age population than in its overall population. But amid deep recession, the country will struggle to deal with new entrants to the labour market, and the already-large informal economy will expand. The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards, but population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily indebted social security system in a context of volatile public finances.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela's position in our business environment ranking falls in 2017-21 to 79th place globally, making it one of the least attractive locations of the 82 countries covered in our rankings. This reflects unpredictable state inter-ventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and difficulties in accessing foreign exchange. Weak and politicised institutions, an unpredictable tax regime, a rigid labour market, and deteriorating infrastructure will also impair the business outlook. Assuming a political transition later in the forecast period, improvements will emerge. But these will take time, given the damage done by heterodox policymaking. There will also be only modest advances in addressing the country's structural constraints, and curbing corruption and bureaucratic inefficiency.

A combination of highly distortionary economic policies and still-low global oil prices will prolong Venezuela's recession in 2017-19. Inflation will remain in triple-digits until 2020 and the currency will remain highly overvalued. As a result, the black market for foreign exchange will remain rampant. A weak revenue base and falling oil output will sustain an extremely wide fiscal deficit in the first half of the forecast period, and the government will remain at a high risk of failing to meet its external obligations. Overall, the risk of economic collapse is high, with hyperinflation likely to be triggered in the event of debt default. Our forecasts for 2020-21 are more positive, based on the benign assumption that substantial international financial assistance will help an MUD-led administration stabilise the economy.

US-dollar measurements of Venezuela's market size provide an overly positive picture of the economy, given the marked overvaluation of the fixed exchange rate. In reality, the recession and extremely high inflation (driven by a scarcity of key consumer goods) will continue to restrict purchasing power. Although Venezuela is generously endowed with natural resources (it has the largest oil reserves in the world, estimated at 300bn barrels), extremely challeng-ing conditions will keep private-sector investment well below potential.

Assuming a political transition in 2019 that will lift economic distortions and improve the business environment, we expect that Venezuela's economy will begin to recover. But the damage inflicted to the economy in recent years (with a 30% decline in real GDP in 2013-19) will prove difficult to reverse. As such, recovery will be gradual, with GDP growth averaging 1.8% annually in 2017-30. In 2031-50 we forecast that Venezuela's real GDP growth will pick up to 2.4% as rising investment in human capital boosts labour productivity growth, helping to offset deteriorating demographics. Persistent oil dependency will be difficult to undo, and a weak productive base will limit overall economic output.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed 1992 coup. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the legislature, but its powers have been usurped by other branches of government dominated by the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). In May Mr Maduro announced that he wanted to rewrite the 1999 Constitution-apparently a ploy to entrench the PSUV in power.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$5.9bn in 2016 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. The current-account deficit is estimated to have fallen from 4.3% of GDP to 2.1% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Venezuela is a multiparty democracy. However, the independence of its institutions has deteriorated sharply in the past decade, as has its system of checks and balances. Power is concentrated in the executive, currently headed by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), who took office in April 2013 after a snap election. This followed the death from cancer of his predecessor, the highly charismatic Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), who built a cult of personality around himself and ushered in a brand of nationalistic populism known as chavismo. In the September 2010 legislative election, the PSUV and its allies lost their two-thirds majority in the National Assembly. Five years later, in legislative elections in December 2015, the PSUV lost its simple majority altogether, gaining just 55 seats, against 112 claimed by the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD), a broad coalition of parties from across the political spectrum that was formed in 2008 to present a united front against the PSUV government. The main parties comprising the MUD are Primero Justicia, Acción Democrática, Un Nuevo Tiempo, and Voluntad Popular, which together hold 109 seats.
Despite its technical majority, the MUD has not been able to do anything to alter government policy, as sustained efforts by the government (as well as the government-controlled Supreme Court) have eroded the power of the legislature and restricted the rights of the opposition. This culminated in a Supreme Court ruling in late 2016 (citing alleged irregularities in the 2015 election) that all legislation passed by the National Assembly would be null and void, which has essentially neutralised the legislature as a political actor. Decision-making is therefore concentrated entirely in the hands of the executive and judicial branches. Mr Maduro has given policymaking powers to the PSUV's allies in the military as he seeks to cement their support for his regime.

Political outlook: Political stability
Amid the most severe economic crisis in its history, Venezuela's political scene will remain dominated by a volatile power struggle between the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) government, led by the president, Nicolás Maduro, and the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD), which won a majority in the National Assembly in late 2015. Political tension has escalated recently amid growing signs that the government is seeking to cling to power through non-democratic means. Mr Maduro announced at the start of May that he would seek to convene a constituent assembly to rewrite the constitution promulgated by his predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). Constitutional reform proposals seem designed both to reduce the role of the elected National Assembly and to postpone, perhaps indefinitely, national elections due to be held in December 2018. The govern-ment used its control of key state institutions to scupper opposition efforts to hold a recall referendum (allowed under the constitution) to remove Mr Maduro. The government also effectively eliminated the National Assembly's legislative powers. Violent public protests have ensued in response; these show little sign of letting up, but also show little sign of weakening the Maduro government's hold on power.
This grip on power is largely based on the continuing support of the military, which will play a decisive role in future political developments. The govern-ment has to date secured military both by eliminating dissent in its upper echelons and by including the military in a system of patronage that has given it significant policymaking powers. It is not certain, however, to what extent the military would be willing to support the government if it were to attempt to hold onto power by non-democratic means, for instance by declaring an economic emergency as a justification for calling off the presidential election.
There have been instances in the recent past in which the military and other political actors have been seen to intervene to force the government to respect democratic norms. After the legislative election in 2015, the defence minister, Vladimir Padrino López, affirmed publicly that the army would uphold the constitution. Earlier this year, the attorney-general, Luisa Ortega, publicly criticised a Supreme Court attempt to take over the National Assembly's powers, which was subsequently abandoned. All of this suggests that there are limits to support for the beleaguered Maduro administration from its allies in the military and elsewhere. On this basis, The Economist Intelligence Unit still expects the December 2018 election to take place, and for the MUD (which would be the clear favourite) to win, taking power in 2019. But there is a high risk that the PSUV, with the backing of the armed forces, will attempt to cling to power beyond this date. Given the scale of opposition to the government, and the increasingly limited means of addressing opposition concerns via institutional channels, there is also a strong risk of some sort of chaotic, violent political transition, particularly in the context of a crippling economic crisis that the government has shown little willingness or capacity to address.
Assuming that an MUD-led government does take power, it would implement economic adjustments to reduce the role of the state in the economy, and unravel the many macroeconomic and monetary distortions that the PSUV has implemented since it came to power in 1999. It will also begin the difficult task of reforming deeply politicised institutions. Given the scale of the economic distortion and institutional destruction that has taken place in Venezuela, as well as the heterogeneous nature of the MUD-which is aligned mainly in its desire to remove the current government from office-the process will not be a smooth one. Weak institutional capacity and high political tension will persist throughout the 2017-21 forecast period.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
In 2017-21 Venezuela will continue to suffer from one of the weakest political and institutional frameworks in the region. Under Mr Chávez, the decision-making process was characterised by arbitrary decisions, often subject to reversals, and the Maduro government has proved little different in this respect. There is little discussion of policy proposals among the wider public, and the technical quality of the laws passed is extremely patchy. Institutional effectiveness will remain very poor, undermined by a politicised judiciary and high levels of corruption. Moreover, the credibility of the country's institutions will continue to decline, with particular concerns about an increasing lack of accountability and transparency, including in the use of public finances and the management of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The government's aggressive stance towards some foreign multinationals (while granting more favourable treatment to other companies from countries with politically sympathetic governments) is expected to continue.
Facing mounting opposition protests and growing unpopularity, Mr Maduro announced in May 2017 that he intends to re-write the Constitution. Details of the process are scarce, but the PSUV will seek to entrench its power and, quite possibly, delay calling the December 2018 elections. Our baseline forecast assumes that the elections will be held and that there will be a political transition in 2019 to the MUD. At the same, we recognise the risk of demonstrations turning more violent and eventually dislodging the Maduro government. Any post-transition period would be turbulent, as it would inevitably result in the dismantling of the PSUV's influence in key state institutions and its politics of patronage, which had, until recently, given it an overwhelming degree of support from certain segments of the population. Undoing nearly two decades of gradually tighter state control over the economy will not be easy, as the country will remain vulnerable to macroeconomic risks, either from domestic adjustment or external shocks. Although we believe that an opposition govern-ment will seek to rebuild the country's institutional capacity, this will take considerable time; in the meantime, violence and corruption will be endemic, especially while economic conditions remain weak.
One of the legacies of the Chávez era will be the persistence of special interest groups such as public-sector unions, regional party bosses and high-ranking members of the military, who are likely to continue to enjoy considerable power. The poor quality of bureaucracy will also constrain the effectiveness of policymaking. A new administration is likely to bring many of the social programmes introduced during the Chávez era back under the control of the relevant ministries rather than retaining them as off-budget misiones, social programmes that are funded by oil proceeds and prone to clientelism. Assistance from multilateral lenders will ease the transition.
Violent crime is expected to remain a major problem, fuelled by impunity, shortcomings in law enforcement and the growing problem of crossborder drug-trafficking. The homicide rate has risen sharply over the past 15 years. According to official figures, Venezuela recorded a homicide rate of 58 per 100,000 people in 2015, although private sources claim that the rate was much higher. Some sources also put the capital, Caracas, at the top of its list of most violent cities in the world, with a homicide rate of over 100 per 100,000 people. Aside from homicides, there have been numerous high-profile kidnappings for ransom in urban areas, a development that has increased concern over police corruption and mismanagement. Express kidnappings, in which people are held for a short period of time until they have withdrawn money from their bank accounts, are also rampant. This increase in criminality will not be halted unless measures are adopted to improve the competence and effectiveness of law enforcement agencies and the criminal justice system, reduce rates of impunity, and boost youth employment.
Political outlook: Election watch
With the next presidential election due in December 2018, the electoral authorities are placing a host of obstacles in the MUD coalition's path, forcing most parties to re-register and banning a leading opposition figure and presidential frontrunner, Henrique Capriles, from running for election for 15 years, citing "administrative irregularities" in his tenure as governor of Miranda state. Assuming that open elections are held, we expect the MUD to win by a large margin (as it did in legislative elections in 2015). The timing of the elections is increasingly uncertain. A contro-versial constitutional redrafting proposal put forward by Mr Maduro would entail a long rewriting process and would also, in theory, need to be put to a nationwide referendum, all of which would take time and could be used as a pretext for delaying elections. The position of the military towards any such efforts, and to the election process itself, will be decisive, and the risks to our forecasts are unusually high.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Nicolás Maduro
A former union leader and co-founder of the party that brought Hugo Chávez to power in 1999-the Movimiento V República-Mr Maduro is a radical leftist. In 1999 he was elected to the assembly that rewrote the constitution. He was elected to the National Assembly in 2000 and was its president in 2005-06. He was minister of foreign affairs in 2006-12. After the 2012 presidential election, Mr Chávez appointed him vice-president and announced that Mr Maduro should succeed him. Following Mr Chávez´s death from cancer in March 2013, Mr Maduro took over the presidency, and then stood for the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) in the 2013 presidential election, winning by less than 1.5 percentage points against Henrique Capriles of the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD). The sharp deterioration of the economy since then has weakened Mr Maduro's standing dramatically. In response, he has attempted to entrench his power via emergency decree powers. He has found it more difficult to engage with the masses with the ease that Mr Chávez did, hurting his popularity. With other senior PSUV politicians and military representatives being granted increasing powers, Mr Maduro is now somewhat of a figurehead, faced with the task of managing the competing factions within his party.
Tareck El Aissami
A minister under Mr Chávez in 2008-12, Mr El Aissami subsequently served as governor of the state of Aragua until his appointment as vice-president in January 2017. Since replacing Aristóbulo Istúriz, he has quickly accumulated far more sweeping powers than his predecessor. Three weeks after his appointment, Mr Maduro devolved important new powers to Mr El Aissami, including direct budgetary control over all ministries, hiring responsibilities for senior management at state-owned companies, the ability to make decisions over expropriation, responsibilities for allocating foreign exchange to different ministries and decision-making powers over tax rates (both sales and income taxes). Mr El Aissami now has control over areas that have always been the responsibility of the president, suggesting that he may be being lined up as the PSUV's preferred successor. His firm ties with the army substantiate this interpretation. He is a controversial figure internationally: the US placed sanctions against him in early 2017 on the grounds that he helped drug-trafficking to the US.
Diosdado Cabello
A former military officer and veteran of the 1992 coup movement led by Mr Chávez, Mr Cabello remains a highly influential member of the PSUV, although representing a different faction to Mr El Aissami. In the past, Mr Cabello has held the posts of minister of the interior and justice, vice-president (during an abortive 2002 coup) and minister of public works-the latter after he was defeated by Mr Capriles in his bid to win re-election as governor of Miranda state in November 2008. He is also vice-president of the PSUV. Mr Cabello is said to wield effective influence over large sectors of the economy, including both nationalised companies and private industries. His brother, José David Cabello, is minister of industry and head of Seniat, the tax and customs agency. A master of behind-the-scenes chavista factional politics, Mr Cabello is regarded as a right-winger by the left of the movement and is reportedly distrusted by Mr Maduro's allies. However, he has significant support among the upper ranks of the armed forces.
Henrique Capriles
The 44-year-old governor of Miranda state, which includes much of the Metropolitan District of Caracas, Mr Capriles has twice stood for president (in 2012 and 2013) as the candidate of the opposition MUD coalition. Representing the centrist Primero Justicia (PJ) party, Mr Capriles entered the political scene at the same time as Mr Chávez in 1998 and is untainted by association with the widely discredited pre-Chávez regime. Two energetic campaigns brought him close to winning the presidency and Mr Capriles is still perceived as the de facto leader of the opposition, particularly as another senior figure-Leopoldo López-remains in prison. However, hopes that he might contest a third presidential election in December 2018 have apparently been dashed by an April 2017 ruling that bans him from running for elected office for 15 years. This was the result of a decision by the comptroller general (who is responsible for overseeing fiscal revenue and expenditure) that Mr Capriles was guilty of "administrative irregularities" in 2011-13. Fears that the government is seeking to disqualify anyone with a reasonable chance of winning the 2018 election have fuelled anti-government demonstrations in the capital, Caracas. The government is unlikely to reverse this ruling, so it is unlikely that Mr Capriles will be permitted to stand.
Leopoldo López
Leader of the more radical wing of the MUD, Mr López was jailed in February 2014 and has remained imprisoned since then, for his alleged involvement in violence that followed an opposition march. A founder member of PJ and later a member of Un Nuevo Tiempo, he founded his own party, Voluntad Popular in 2009. The previous year he had been banned from holding elected office for six years, a move that frustrated his bid to become mayor of metropolitan Caracas. He pulled out of the primaries to select the MUD's 2012 presidential candidate and became Mr Capriles's campaign manager. In early 2014 he was one of the main proponents of the "la salida" movement that promoted street demonstrations as a way of forcing political change. His decision to turn himself in to the authorities helped to boost his popularity, making him the clearest rival to Mr Capriles as opposition leader, should he be released from prison. Mr López's wife, Lilian Tintori, continues to wage a highly publicised campaign calling for her husband's release and has met with many high-profile leaders (including the US president, Donald Trump) in support of these efforts.
Political outlook: International relations
Venezuela is becoming increasingly isolated amid growing regional and global censure of the Maduro regime, although this is doing little to weaken the government's grip on power. The government has announced its withdrawal from the Organisation of American States, which promotes regional co-operation and is a frequent election observer, pre-empting probable suspen-sion from the organisation. Venezuela had already been suspended from Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) in late 2016. Although relations with neighbouring countries such as Colombia are likely to deteriorate, the government appears concerned with retaining good relations with China (a key creditor), and with not provoking the US administration, presumably to avoid sanctions such as a cut in oil imports, which would hit Venezuela hard. However, US-Venezuela tension would escalate if the government were to attempt to cling to power by suspending the December 2018 elections. Reflecting its external financing diffi-culties, Venezuela will continue to scale back-and possibly end-oil shipments to beneficiaries of PetroCaribe, an agreement that provides cheap financing for oil exports to regional allies. Relations with Cuba, the closest such ally, will become more distant as Venezuela's ability to provide economic assistance is eroded.

A demographic bonus will be wasted as a result of economic woes
Although population growth will remain weak because of a falling birth rate, Venezuela will enjoy a demographic bonus in 2017-21, but this will be largely squandered as a result of the poor economic policies and a resulting deep recession that has left a greater proportion of the population outside the labour force. The annual population growth rate slowed from 2.8% in the 1980s to 2.3% in the 1990s and 1.8% in 2000-10, before decelerating steadily to 1.2% in 2016. We expect the annual rate of population growth to continue to slow, averaging 1.4% in 2017-21. Contributing to the slowdown is emigration by Venezuelans, which is anecdotally estimated at around 1.5m people since 2000, with the rate speeding up since 2014 as crisis in the country has deepened (there are no official data). Assuming a recovery later in the forecast period, this will lead to a rise in the participation rate and a faster growth rate in the labour force compared to that of the working age population. The total population is expected to reach 33m by 2021, with just under two-thirds between 15 and 65 years old. Population density is low, at 34.5 people/sq km, but rising. Distribution between urban and rural areas is highly uneven, with around 90% of the total population living in urban centres. Underdeveloped rural infrastructure, limited job opportunities in the countryside and fixed agricultural prices (in many cases, below the cost of production) will result in a continuing trend of urbanisation in 2017-21, creating problems in the main cities.
The labour participation rate declined in 2004-12 (owing to an increased uptake of education linked to the government's social programmes), but ticked up marginally in 2013 and 2014, before falling again in 2015 as economic conditions worsened. In the light of continued economic recession, we believe that the participation rate fell further in 2016. Although we are forecasting some improvement later in the forecast period, we expect the participation rate to remain below 70% throughout the forecast period. A very poor business environment, severe macroeconomic distortions and some of the highest labour costs in the region-exacerbated by the approval in 2012 of a labour reform that creates extra costs for employers-will continue to limit job creation, forcing more people to seek work in the informal sector, which is already estimated to account for around half of employment. According to the authorities, the official unemployment rate fell from 8.5% in 2010 to 6.8% in 2015. However, given that this coincided with a sharp deterioration in local economic conditions, it is likely that it reflects inflexible labour laws (which make it virtually impossible to lay off workers) rather than any significant job creation. It is also possible that the data are unreliable, as it is highly implausible that unemployment has remained low in the midst of a deep economic recession, with a growing number of companies folding.
Poverty indicators improved during the tenure of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but these data are no longer published by the authorities. Independent academic sources estimate that poverty rates are rising rapidly and that many people are forced to skip meals owing to chronic food shortages. A study by two public universities found that in 2016, 78% of Venezuelans lost weight because of food shortages, with the average per head weight loss coming in at around 9 kg. Shortages of medicines and surgical supplies are creating huge problems in the healthcare system, while insufficient vaccines are resulting in the re-emergence of diseases that had previously been practically eradicated.
Public services will remain under strain from a lack of resources
The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards but, in the context of volatile public finances, population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily indebted social security system. The Instituto Venezolano de los Seguros Sociales (IVSS, the social security system) will remain under significant strain, with corruption exacerbating inefficiencies. IVSS hospitals will continue to suffer from crumbling infrastructure, and lack of supplies (including medicines) and equipment. The latter are mainly imported, or assembled from imported parts, and supplies have fallen victim to a lack of US dollars. Hospital building and rebuilding programmes have been a failure, owing to mismanagement of funds and shortages of building materials. Even a parallel welfare system, the Sistema Nacional de Misiones, is struggling to function as the government makes cuts and inflation erodes purchasing power. Overall, the provision and quality of public healthcare and education services is therefore expected to deteriorate further. This will also reflect long-running problems including a pronounced deficit of technical and basic skills, and the continued emigration of professionals, particularly doctors and nurses.

The investment climate has deteriorated under Nicolás Maduro
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings place Venezuela among the world's least attractive investment locations during the historical period (2012-16). However, the country slides further in the ranking for the current forecast period (2017-21), to 79th place (down from 78th) of the 82 countries covered in the business environment rankings model, above only three countries (Cuba, Angola and Libya). Venezuela's operating environment has long been a challenge for investors, owing to weak institutions and persistent cycles of boom and bust. Conditions deteriorated under the presidency of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013) as a result of political conflict, erosion of the legal framework for investors, and promotion of a state-led model that hampers private enterprise and competition. These conditions have worsened since Mr Chávez's successor, Nicolás Maduro, took office in 2013, and critical economic problems are paralysing the investment climate. Even though foreign investment is desperately needed to reverse a deep and protracted recession, there is little prospect of a shift in the government's policy stance as long as Mr Maduro remains in office.
Improvement later in the forecast period assumes a political transition
Despite the fact that Venezuela's overall ranking remains very poor, it does register a slight improvement in its overall score in the forecast period, reflecting expected improvements in several categories relating to government policy. This in turn reflects our assumption that a political transition to an opposition-led administration in 2019 will result in a change in official policy towards investors. This affects the "policy towards foreign investors" category most noticeably (where Venezuela's global ranking improves from 78th to 63rd), but it also prompts improvements in the political effectiveness and market opportunities categories.
The envisaged improvements in policy stance will take time to filter through to actual performance, as tackling the deep distortions that have built up over so many years will prove highly destabilising. The macroeconomic environment is therefore likely to deteriorate further, with Venezuela's ranking set to fall to the world's lowest in 2017-21. The ranking for foreign trade and exchange controls will also deteriorate, based on the assumption that capital and exchange controls will be eased only gradually. The huge gap between the current fixed exchange rate and the black-market rate underlines the difficulty in moving towards a floating exchange rate and we expect only gradual progress in this area by the end of the forecast period. The other main area in which we expect deterioration is political stability. Not only is the Maduro government's survival increasingly reliant on an erosion of democratic institutions and military support, but an opposition-led administration will also struggle to cement its position, as high public expectations for an immediate improvement in the economic situation will be difficult to meet. Divisions within the heterogeneous opposition coalition will also prove a barrier to long-term political stability.
Business environment outlook: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, although actual investment flows remain fairly low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Government's low approval ratings reduce the risk of tax increases, despite the huge fiscal deficit. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The macroeconomic environment will weaken further
The macroeconomic environment is the weakest area of Venezuela's business environment. During the forecast period, Venezuela's macroeconomic environment will rank as the least attractive of the 82 countries covered in our index, with the underlying score deteriorating even further. This reflects several factors, including our forecast of an ongoing recession in 2017-19, after three years of steep contraction in 2014-16. A combination of price and exchange controls-and a persistently hefty fiscal deficit financed largely by money printing-has pushed up inflation and eroded real incomes, while fuelling shortages of basic goods and a rampant black market. In the context of triple-digit inflation and the concurrent risk of a bout of uncontrolled hyperinflation, the authorities have lost the ability to address massive overvaluation of the official exchange rate. Moreover, the huge premium at which foreign currency trades on the black market engenders widespread corruption among official bodies with access to fixed-rate US dollars.
Even though we expect the opposition to gain power later on in the forecast period, the process of dismantling currency and price controls and moving towards a more orthodox macroeconomic policy stance will be difficult, given the depth of economic distortions that have built up over a prolonged period. If mismanaged, the short-term impact of any adjustments could be very substantial, with inflation and interest rates likely to rise even more sharply than forecast. Even assuming external support from the IMF and the World Bank, the economic adjustment process is likely to be highly disruptive (although extremely beneficial in the long term).
Our baseline forecast is that the Maduro government will continue to service its external debt, even though reserves levels remain very low and there are very few sources of external finance willing to extend credit to such a high-risk sovereign. In the light of these factors, there are significant risks to our forecast that Venezuela will avoid default, particularly given a rising current-account deficit and capital flight. We assume that a new opposition-led administration will have to negotiate a significant restructuring of liabilities in order to ease pressure on the economy and create space for an adjustment of the policy stance.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
Value of index a

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition will improve from a low base in 2017-21, reflecting some gradual improvements towards the end of the forecast period under an opposition-led government, but Venezuela's ranking in this category will still be among the least business-friendly among the 82 countries. Operating conditions have long been challenging, but the current government will refuse to alter its stance-characterised by bias against free markets, weak, politicised and inefficient institutions, and widespread price-fixing-despite supply constraints amid a deepening economic crisis. Hopes that greater currency and debt pressures will force Mr Maduro to adopt a more pragmatic approach are likely to be dashed. Uncertainty over contract and property rights, distortionary price and exchange controls, and the cumbersome burden of government regulation will continue to restrict businesses' freedom to compete under Mr Maduro.
Competition policy will remain problematic under the current administration. Under Mr Chávez, contracts in energy and heavy industries were revised to give the government greater autonomy and a larger share of the tax take. The government resorted to outright nationalisation in some cases, affecting a number of sectors (communications, cement, steel production, food distribution, financial services and retail). Under Mr Maduro, there have been fewer takeovers of private companies. This reflects the fact that the authorities are already over-stretched and performance in nationalised firms has slipped since the government's intervention. However, the president will continue to blame the private sector for the country's weak economic conditions, and may use this as a pretext for further erosion of companies' freedom to operate.
The government is nominally seeking private investment in the oil sector, but foreign partners will be allowed to hold only minority stakes in joint projects with PDVSA, the state oil monopoly. Private-sector enterprises have scope to operate with relative freedom in less politicised sectors, but those engaged in food production and distribution, as well as the financial services sector, are at greater risk of state interference. The government will take a firm line against companies that they believe are raising retail prices too aggressively, in a futile effort to rein in triple-digit inflation.
The improvement in the score and ranking for policy towards private investment reflects expected improvements in policy stance under a new opposition-led administration later in the forecast period. This will be most evident in greater protection of property rights, a scaling back of the dominance of state-owned businesses across several sectors, as well as the start of a process of gradually scaling back price controls. However, none of these goals will be achievable immediately, as the dire economic situation precludes a blanket lifting of price controls, and improving competition policy would require a strengthening of competition and regulatory bodies. In the context of the institutional decay that has occurred in recent years and deep political polarisation, boosting Venezuela's ranking substantially in this area will be difficult, even under an opposition administration.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Policy under a successor government is likely to be much friendlier for investors
Venezuela's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment improves between the historical and forecast period, reflecting anticipated changes in policy stance under a new opposition-led government. Until then, a very weak policy environment will undermine the score in this area. Although the 1999 constitution establishes national treatment for foreign capital, in practice Mr Maduro will prioritise investment from firms tied to, or owned by, friendly governments, thereby diminishing opportunities for other firms. The fact that the World Bank's International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes is currently considering dozens of cases lodged by companies affected by the nationalisation drive under Mr Chávez will prove a further disincentive to foreign companies, particularly as there is little indication that the Maduro regime has either the will or the ability to make compensation payments. With the fiscal accounts extremely weak in 2017-21-and with the government gradually withdrawing from international arbitration treaties-there is a possibility of outright confiscation under the Maduro government.
We expect an opposition-led administration to adopt a much friendlier approach towards foreign investment. The improvement in the score and ranking reflects our expectation that the risk of nationalisation and/or expropriation would be much lower under the next government, while government favouritism towards certain domestic firms, as well state firms from foreign allies, would decline. This would start to create a more level playing field for foreign investors.
Given the dominance of the oil sector, the next government is likely to focus on developing the vast, heavy-oil resources located in the Orinoco tar belt in order to reverse the recent slide in production. PDVSA lacks the capacity to boost production, so terms for foreign oil investors are likely to be reformed in order to increase the scope for private-sector participation.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Easing currency controls will prove difficult and will progress only slowly
We do not expect any improvement in conditions in this category between 2012-16 and 2017-21, as a result of which Venezuela falls slightly further in the global ranking. Although official policy towards foreign investors will improve under an opposition-led administration expected later in the forecast period, easing exchange controls will prove extremely challenging, with the process likely to be gradual. Even by the end of the forecast period, access to foreign currency is likely to be restricted, hampering foreign trade.
As long as Mr Maduro remains in power, he will retain stringent controls on foreign currency, with problems relating to the exchange regime representing a major barrier to foreign trade. Exchange controls (introduced in 2003) have been progressively tightened to strengthen the balance-of-payments position. In practice, the private sector has no access to the official rate, which was last devalued from BsF6.3:US$1 to BsF10:US$1 in March 2016. In theory, US dollars are available to purchase via a system known as Dicom at a rate of over BsF720:US$1, but demand massively outstrips supply, forcing many firms to either turn to the black market (on which the exchange rate is now over BsF5,000:US$1), or pare back or mothball operations in Venezuela. The result is a highly opaque multi-tier system that creates serious problems for private-sector importers. There is little sign that this convoluted foreign-exchange regime will ease until after a new government comes to power. Given the depth of distortions, there is a possibility that the country may be forced to dollarise or adopt a new domestic currency.
Difficulty in remitting profits earned in Venezuela will remain one of the most significant challenges of doing business for foreign companies operating in the country. Capital controls mean that official permission is required for such transactions, but with the government facing growing demand for US dollars, delays have accumulated in the system. Many foreign-owned companies have not been able to remit their profits for several years, which has had an impact on their overall financial performance, particularly as firms must now use the Dicom rate to value profits, which has weakened sharply in recent years. This has affected foreign companies across a variety of sectors, including airlines, auto manufacturers and retailers. Companies are increasingly choosing to mothball operations or wind down their presence in the Venezuelan market as a result. Given that we expect further devaluations of the Dicom rate, any eventual release of profits will mean that the foreign-currency value of these profits will be a fraction of their original value.
The government-already an inconsistent trade partner-is becoming increasingly isolated in terms of international trade. Venezuela was suspended from Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) in December 2016 for violating the body's democratic principles. The move will have little impact on current foreign trade flows, as Venezuela hardly exports anything to member countries, but it highlights a growing antipathy towards foreign trade agreements (the government made little effort to respond to the concerns of other member states, in fact criticising the body prior to Venezuela's suspension). Meanwhile, bilateral trade partners will continue to struggle in their relations with the Maduro government. Many have complained that Venezuela has not paid their suppliers; given shortages of foreign exchange, this trend is likely to continue. Red tape, corruption and inefficiency will also hinder trade, and corruption in the customs service will remain endemic.
Given severe fiscal constraints, there is a significant risk that Mr Maduro will revoke preferential trading and finance deals during the forecast period. During the 2004-08 oil boom, the Venezuelan government made a host of offers to other countries in the region, mainly in the form of cheap oil-financing deals, but also financial support for refinery and infrastructure construction projects. Little of this support is likely to materialise in 2017-21. Demand for domestic spending is likely to remain high-and oil output is falling as a result of years of underinvestment-so money for such international projects will be in short supply. Countries governed by radical left-wing administrations are less likely to have their trading preferences revoked; the oil-for-doctors swap with Cuba is expected to continue. PetroCaribe (an agreement with Caribbean and some Central American governments, allowing them to pay a fraction of the market oil price up front, spreading the remainder over a 25-year term at extremely low interest rates) is expected to remain in place at least in the short term, but, given that most of the signatory countries do not share the government's political stance, volumes will continue to decline. There is a substantial risk that the programme could be abandoned altogether.
Business environment outlook: Taxes

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Improvements in the tax regime are likely under an opposition government
The tax regime will remain a constraint to investment, but will undergo some minor improvements under an opposition-led government expected later in the forecast period. Rates of direct corporate taxation are currently moderate, with a top corporate income tax rate of 34% (excluding oil companies), but tax laws, regulations and procedures are complicated, inconsistent and subject to frequent arbitrary adjustments. A series of new taxes introduced in 2009 in many cases doubled the effective tax rate on earnings. These taxes formed part of wider reforms such as a sports law, a new science and technology law, a worker training law, and a municipal law, but included new fiscal charges on businesses, some of which are levied on gross revenue rather than net earnings. The measures are unlikely to be rolled back under the Maduro government, although a successor, opposition administration would be likely to reverse these changes.
The tax base is narrow: according to the latest official data, tax income accounted for just 13% of GDP in 2012. The failure to publish fiscal data since then suggests that tax income is likely to have shrunk in recent years. Despite the recent deterioration in the public finances, we do not believe that tax rises are likely under the current administration. Mr Maduro has shown little interest in raising revenue to offset massive increases in public spending and appears content with financing the huge fiscal deficit through public debt issuance, which is monetised, contributing to inflation. In addition, the president will be reluctant to pass measures that would further alienate his already-dwindling support base.
Based on our assumption that an opposition-led government will take over and begin enacting policy adjustments later in the forecast period, we expect it to seek a widening of the tax base to promote the development of a more stable system, but efforts would be focused at least initially on improving compliance-a difficult task, given the deterioration of state institutions over the course of the past 15 years.
Business environment outlook: Financing

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Financing conditions will remain difficult
Venezuela's financing score remains unchanged, on the assumption that improvements in access to medium-term finance for the private sector, and in eliminating distortions, will occur only beyond the forecast period. Financial sector distortions are severe. The government has continued its policy of directed lending, which requires private banks to channel credit to specific sectors at preferential rates (including agriculture, mortgages and tourism). Bank credit has grown, but this reflects a lack of other investment alternatives in the context of captive domestic liquidity and triple-digit inflation. Nevertheless, the credit market remains comparatively shallow. For companies borrowing from local banks, credit remains predominantly short term. As only a small percentage of the population has sufficient funds to purchase investment and savings products, the capital market also remains shallow. Following a political transition, we expect interest rates to be gradually rationalised, but sector-specific measures will also be required and financing will remain a major weakness of the business environment throughout the forecast period.
The soundness of the financial system and the quality of regulation will remain key concerns. A bout of instability in 2009 prompted the government to take control of a number of small banks and brokerage houses. Although balance-sheet irregularities appeared to be the main motive, the problems stem-med from inadequate supervision by the Superintendencia de las Instituciones del Sector Bancario (the banking superintendency), which could have intervened at a much earlier stage to enforce existing regulations. The government passed new legislation in 2010, but this has not resulted in a tighter regulatory framework. In line with reform legislation passed in other sectors, the government has simply established a new layer of bureaucracy (in this case, a new regulatory oversight body), rather than trying to tackle the patchy enforce-ment of existing regulations. Weak skills in regulatory agencies and political meddling in oversight decision-making will remain problems, and will continue to undermine efforts to identify and support ailing banks at an early stage.
A removal of the many price, export, capital and foreign-exchange controls after an expected political transition would be particularly risky to the stability of the financial system, given the shocks that would result from sharp policy adjustments. Under this scenario, reforms would instead have to be introduced gradually in order to avoid creating systemic risks to the financial sector. This would require careful co-ordination with the country's banks to reduce pressures on the financial system when currency exchange controls are liberalised (which would involve rises in interest rates). The gradual lifting of the directed lending system would also allow for better allocation of resources and the medium-term stabilisation of interest rates.
Business environment outlook: The labour market

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Labour market rigidities will persist under the Maduro regime
Venezuela's labour market will remain among the least flexible in the world in 2017-21. Although a marginal improvement in the underlying score is expected, as a new government begins to take steps to ease the highly-regulated labour market, the process will be gradual and come only at the end of the forecast period, meaning that the impact on the overall score in 2017-21 will be very limited. The highly distorted exchange-rate system makes it virtually impossible to assess wage costs in US-dollar terms in comparison with the rest of the region. However, a 2012 labour reform increased non-wage costs considerably: obligatory non-wage costs, employers' social security contributions, mandatory profit sharing, and childcare and food allowances added more than 70% to the basic wage costs for large and medium-sized companies, and 30% for smaller companies. Owing to the accumulated real appreciation of the local currency over recent years, the relative cost of living is also rising. Under the assumption of a political transition, we expect some of the most egregiously restrictive regulations to be reformed later in the forecast period.
Wage and non-wage costs come on top of a long-standing firing freeze, under which staffing levels (excluding managers, short-term workers and high-income earners) can be reduced only via collective agreement. In practice, companies looking to shed staff are forced to negotiate "voluntary redundancy" agreements with workers; these typically centre on extremely generous severance payments, further adding to employment costs. Employment tribunals are generally hostile to private-sector employers, a factor used by workers and union representatives to their advantage. Moreover, companies that make recourse to voluntary redundancies have at times been targeted for nationalisation, representing a further disincentive for the private sector.
Finding skilled labour is likely to remain problematic even under an opposition-led government, as the results of decades of underinvestment in education will take time to reverse, meaning that even basic skills will remain scarce in much of the workforce. Chronic underinvestment in scientific and technical skills, as well as political interference in universities and technical colleges, has damaged the quality of the country's tertiary education system. Professionals with good employment prospects abroad, in particular in the energy sector, as well as software engineers, doctors and other medical staff, university lecturers, and teachers, have fled the country en masse, leaving behind an acute skills shortage. Although some are more likely to return to the country under an opposition-led government, this is unlikely during the 2017-21 forecast period, as they are likely to wait until the political and economic situation stabilises before returning.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
