a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Underinvestment will cause many services to deteriorate
Relatively speaking, infrastructure was one of the strongest areas of Venezuela's overall business environment during the historical period. The country was a comparatively early adopter of a national electricity grid and modern ports, airports and telecommunications (which account for half of the infrastructure score). However, years of underinvestment are causing the quality of most services to deteriorate and both the score and ranking are forecast to fall during the 2017-21 forecast period. Overall, capital expenditure will remain significantly lower in the forecast period than during the historical period, reflecting fiscal constraints. Given the long-term horizon of investment in most infrastructure projects, the highly uncertain policy outlook will dissuade private investors. Despite repeated pledges by the government to implement ambitious infrastructure projects, state-led investment under Mr Maduro will be erratic, and most plans are unlikely to advance. A post-transition government will be keen on making up the shortfalls but fiscal constraints will make it extremely difficult to raise infra-structure spending, although some multilateral assistance should be provided.
The power network accounts for only a small share of the infrastructure score, but reliable access to electricity will be one of the main causes for concern for businesses operating in Venezuela in 2017-21. Frozen nominal electricity tariffs have led to rapid growth in demand in recent years. Water levels at the Guri dam-which generates most of the country's hydropower (which, in turn, accounts for 60% of total electricity generation)-have recovered from critically low levels a year ago, but with little new capacity coming on stream, the country will remain highly exposed to drought. The government's repeated pledges to invest in the power sector are unlikely to materialise, so the long-standing standing problem of a weak transmission and distribution network will remain unaddressed during the forecast period, meaning that electricity rationing and unscheduled blackouts will remain a risk.
Although the physical airport infrastructure remains reasonable-the capital's Maiquetia airport is relatively modern-government policies complicate air travel. Long delays in authorising the remittance of international air carriers' profits outs of Venezuela have prompted several carriers to reduce or suspend services. The reduced service coupled with firm demand (as Venezuelans have sought to travel overseas in order to bring US dollars back into the country, where they can sell them on the black market) has sent airfare prices soaring.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
It is unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without some sort of policy adjustment between now and the presidential election. We assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017-18 than it did last year. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or unable to adjust policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policies will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy interventionism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Slightly higher oil prices than in 2014-16 will bring some relief, but import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. International reserves totalled US$10.1bn in early May, far below historical levels, and down by about 20% year on year. Even after a 2016 restructuring of debt owed by PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, substantial external debt payments are falling due in 2017-18. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA (it made a US$2.1bn coupon payment in April). However, given the extremely thin reserves cushion, the risk of default remains high; this would have dramatic economic and political consequences in the form of a sharp decrease in oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and political turmoil.
We expect the opposition to take power in 2019, ushering in much-needed market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of over US$16bn in 2019-21. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.

The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.6% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. The election of a new government should help to ease the deficit to 6% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply (M2) rose by 230% year on year in April, the highest rate on record. Meanwhile, high inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability.

There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. In 2016 the government undertook a bond swap that saw around US$2.8bn of PDVSA debt due in 2017 pushed out to 2020. Even after this deal, we continue to see an extremely high risk of default, although the government has emphasised its commitment to pay, and we expect the next administration to follow through with its debt-servicing and repayment obligations.

Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. Amid extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. From 2019 our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.

Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that, after a massive contraction in GDP in 2016 (estimated at 14%), we project a further contraction, of 6.4%, in 2017 (this represents a downward revision from last month, reflecting a slight downward revision to our oil production forecast and the impact on activity of ongoing widespread protests). We do not expect the government to make the necessary adjustments to bring about economic recovery, and expect recession to persist into 2019. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment (supported by IMF financial assistance), and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound, after a decline in real GDP of nearly 30% in 2014-19.
After dropping by an estimated 20.2% in 2016, private consumption will contract further in 2017-18, reflecting the impact of soaring inflation on real wages and disposable incomes, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in invest-ment in 2019-21 is based on expectations of a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in the energy sector and-towards the end of the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting increased investment under a new government and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from the recession years. Even after the change in govern-ment, however, dependence on oil will persist.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Oil sector: With proven levels approaching 300m barrels, Venezuela has the largest reserves in the world, making it a major oil producer and exporter. However, the energy sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanage-ment owing to political interference. The state is accorded exclusive ownership of PDVSA and its subsidiaries. Since 2007 oil exploration, extraction and storage activities have been reserved for state-owned enterprises or companies in which the state holds a stake of at least 51%. The level of oil output in Venezuela in recent years has been the subject of debate by national and international sources, with the latter reporting production levels significantly below PDVSA's estimates. PDVSA has long insisted that oil production stands at around 3m barrels/day (b/d). This figure is higher than its own reports to OPEC, and well above independent estimates, including the 2.03m b/d calculated by the International Energy Agency (IEA) in March 2017, (we use the IEA's series in our forecasts). Under an OPEC quota deal in late 2016, which we expect to be renewed in May 2017, Venezuela is expected to reduce output to close to 2m b/d, thus still not complying entirely with its quota of 1.97m b/d. In March the authorities announced that production would be reduced in several extra-heavy fields, including joint-ventures with Rosneft, the Russian state oil firm, in order to abide by the OPEC quota. This suggests that OPEC is putting more pressure on Venezuela to improve compliance.
The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee continued low levels, before production begins to rise again in 2019, although this is subject to the considerable risk of a steeper than forecast fall and a slower recovery. In recent years, PDVSA has signed agreements with a Russian consortium, including Gazprom and Lukoil, and with the China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC, the Chinese state oil company) to develop various blocks in the Orinoco tar belt (where the majority of Venezuela's untapped reserves are located). It has also established a US$2bn financing deal with Chevron (US) and a joint venture with Eni (Italy) for a refinery. However, these plans are likely to progress very slowly, owing to financing and regulatory hurdles, which will limit any significant rise in production.
In the light of significant fiscal restraints, PDVSA investment in new exploration and production has been very limited, and the company will struggle to meet production targets, as it continues to act as a major financier of the government's social programmes. PDVSA's investment budget will continue to be compromised by large compensation payments to foreign oil companies and by repayments on the company's increasingly large debt stock (which represents a considerable share of the public sector's total obligations). As a result of its chronic payments difficulties, PDVSA's relations with its foreign partners have been turbulent over the past year. For example, Schlumberger, a US-based oil services firm, announced in 2016 that it would curtail its activities in Venezuela owing to lack of payments. Other foreign suppliers could follow suit in the light of PDVSA's financial constraints, although the company will try and avoid this, in order to maintain its good standing and demonstrate its commitment to pay.
Overall, the Venezuelan oil sector will remain very challenging for foreign companies under a PSUV-led government, with the possibility of repeated contract revisions and the very weak legal framework acting as major constraints. Moreover, most private firms are likely to face unfair competition, stemming from the government's ideological preference for PDVSA to work with state-owned companies from friendly governments. Although the great potential for growth in the Orinoco tar belt and the massive investment and expertise needed to develop these reserves will provide some opportunities for private participation, this is unlikely to materialise while global oil prices stay low, the country's economic crisis deepens and the risk of domestic turbulence remains high ahead of an expected political transition.

A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years, and in the short term there is little sign that the situation will improve, despite deep reces-sion. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015, but the National Assembly has since the start of the year begun producing a consumer price index. This showed monthly inflation at 16.2% in March, bringing accumu-lated inflation for January-March to 65.5%. Assuming that price pressures remain high in the first half of 2017 at least, we expect average inflation to be higher this year, at 562%, than in 2016. However, we continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, reflecting moderately higher oil prices-which will bring in the necessary foreign exchange to help to alleviate scarcity of goods-and the impact of persistent recession on demand. From 2019 fiscal and monetary policy adjustment will also be supportive of a gradual reduction in inflation towards double-digit levels (in year-on-year terms). However, for now, a lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (monthly inflation of over 50%) will remain substantial.

Amid huge pressures on the dual-currency exchange-rate system, our forecasts assume substantial devaluations in 2017-18, but the exchange rate will still be extremely overvalued. The dual exchange-rate system is composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom. The Dicom rate weakened by 70% in nominal terms in 2016 and stands at BsF720:US$1 currently, but it accounts for less than 10% of all official transactions. In real terms, the average exchange rate (weighted by volume of transactions) continued to appreciate substantially in 2016, creating ever greater pressure for currency adjustment, the need for which is evident in the black-market rate; this stood at BsF5,100:US$1 in early May.
The pegged Dipro rate appears increasingly unsustainable, and we assume that the government will devalue the rate to BsF25:US$1 later this year and again in 2018 (to BsF500:US$1). We also assume that the government will increase the share of Dicom in foreign-currency transactions to 50% by 2018, up from a current level of about 8% (in effect a maxi-devaluation). We assume that further major currency adjustment under a new, MUD-led government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. In the meantime, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.

The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017-18, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued gradual decline in oil output. The deficit will widen thereafter on the assumption that economic recovery draws in imports on a large scale after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. Together with IMF loans, this should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021, reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Venezuela
Stocks and flows
According to the IMF (whose figures differ somewhat from local sources), the stock of foreign direct investment (FDI) stood at US$32.2bn in 2015, the last year in which actual data has been provided. This is around one-third less than a peak of US$48.9bn in 2007 and is primarily the result of significant disinvestment, notwithstanding the government's strict capital controls. The stock of FDI has also plummeted as a share of GDP terms, dropping from a peak of nearly 50% of GDP in 2003 to just 6.8% in 2015. Overall, FDI inflows have been very volatile in the past 15 years, affected by both political and macroeconomic factors. During the oil opening of 1996-98, inward FDI peaked at an annual average of US$4bn a year (5% of GDP). By historical standards, inward FDI held up well in the first three years of the presidency of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), averaging US$3.8bn per year in 1999-2001. As political conflict intensified, FDI inflows began to decline in 2002-08 (averaging US$1.6bn per year), and in 2009-a year of great volatility in the world economy and adverse domestic developments in Venezuela-the country registered disinvestment of US$1bn (some negative inflows were also the result of compensation for nationalisations). Inward FDI has recovered since then, averaging an estimated US$4.5bn per year in 2011-13, as a result of greater investment from China in energy and housing. It declined considerably in 2014, to just US$390m, as the economy entered recession, but picked up again in 2015 to US$3.8bn. Outbound FDI in Venezuela is considerable, reaching a stock of US$28.9bn in 2014. However, this tally is dominated almost entirely by investments abroad by PDVSA, the state oil company.
Origin and distribution
The energy sector, and oil in particular, remains the main magnet for FDI. US and European oil companies have major investments in the country, even after forced changes to the ownership structure of most contracts. After oil, banking and communications have been the main recipients of FDI. Spanish banks have the largest foreign presence in the financial sector, although the Venezuelan state has bought back some operations. Other notable FDI inflows come from Chile (in forestry activities) and Canada (in the mining industry). In recent years Venezuela has courted new investment partners in Brazil, China, Russia and Iran, with limited success. Domestic economic problems in most of these countries mean that short-term efforts will be focused on seeking investment from China and Russia (PDVSA has joint-ventures with Rosneft, the Russian state oil firm).
Determinants
Following a period of booming FDI inflows in the 1990s, driven by oil and telecommunications openings, an uncertain political and policy environment-including threats of nationalisation-and a volatile macroeconomic climate have served to keep FDI well below potential, particularly in the non-extractive sectors. In the extractive sector, FDI inflows have been affected by the government's restrictive hydrocarbons investment regime. This partly reverses the oil opening of the 1990s by mandating that PDVSA must hold a minimum 51% stake in most activities, and raises the national take from taxes and royalties in the sector. Further investment in this sector has been hampered by the generally unfavourable outlook for global oil prices in the short term. Although Venezuela's oil production costs are among the lowest in the world, extra heavy crude from larger fields like the Orinoco tar belt (which holds the bulk of reserves) are far more expensive, averaging around US$60-100/barrel. The sharp contraction of non-energy economic activity and severe weaknesses in the business environment have hampered inward FDI outside of the oil sector.
Impact
Foreign investment in oil brought accelerated growth in output, from 2.4m barrels/day (b/d) in 1994 to a peak of 3.4m b/d in 1999. Foreign investment in the extractive sector has fallen since then, contributing to a decline in oil output, reinforced by PDVSA's inability to drive production. Foreign involvement has had a less dramatic impact in other sectors, such as domestic manufacturing or services, but this in turn has resulted in high levels of import dependence. As FDI has flowed mostly into capital-intensive industries, its impact on employment and skills levels has been limited.
Potential
Potentially attractive opportunities for FDI exist in an array of sectors, such as oil and gas (of which Venezuela possesses the largest reserves in the world), petrochemicals, coal, aluminium, gold, forestry, power, tourism and telecoms. There is additional potential in some manufacturing and agricultural niches (for example, leather goods, cocoa and rum). Further comparative attractions are Venezuela's transport infrastructure, which is still fairly good by regional standards, and the country's strategic geographic location. However, FDI inflows will be severely curtailed by concerns over the government's policy stance, difficulties in accessing foreign exchange, the weak macroeconomic environment and the fragility of the legal framework. Nonetheless, some investment from non-traditional sources, particularly China, is set to continue in the short and medium term. A more noticeable upturn in FDI inflows will have to wait until after a political transition takes place, insofar as the new government undertakes a commitment to improve the business environment, address exchange-rate distortions and bring down inflation from current triple-digit levels.

Although Venezuela appears to be a middle-income country, a sharply overvalued exchange rate artificially inflates US-dollar income measurements. In dollar terms, and using a weighted average of the country's official exchange rates, we estimate that GDP per head stood at US$18,360 in 2016, well above the average for the Latin American region. Estimates using purchasing power parity (PPP) give a lower figure of US$14,625. Using the black-market exchange rate (over BsF5,000:US$1 in early May 2017) as a basis for these calculations would result in a significantly lower GDP per head figure, however. Given the country's ongoing recession, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects GDP per head and disposable incomes to fall in the medium term, before beginning to pick up in PPP terms from 2020. These forecasts are based on the benign assumption that a forecast political transition materialises without severe economic disruption, and that growth recovers thereafter.
Several factors will restrict purchasing power, including triple-digit consumer price inflation, and persistently high levels of poverty and income inequality. Although national statistics show a dramatic improvement in social indicators in recent years, the data have been disputed, and independent studies have suggested that inequality has not fallen as quickly as the government indicates, and that the middle-income class has shrunk. According to the UN Human Development Programme, 6.6% of the population survived on less than US$1.25/day (in purchasing-power terms) in 2012, a higher proportion than in almost any other country in the region.
Investment potential will only be tapped after a political transition
Venezuela is a reasonably-sized consumer market and has the potential to become an attractive investment location, although this will have to wait until a more market-friendly administration takes over from the PSUV. The country has vast reserves of natural resources (including oil, gas, coal and precious metals), an array of spectacular natural tourist attractions, relatively good physical infrastructure and a fairly favourable geographical location given its proximity to the US. However, poor economic policies have contributed to a volatile GDP profile and a deterioration of public services and human capital over the past two decades. The unattractiveness of the business environment is compounded by inadequate contract and property rights. Moreover, continued high poverty levels and a deterioration in health-care and education provision in the past three decades have contributed to an erosion of skills and productivity, which has also been exacerbated by the exodus of talented individuals to work abroad.

A weakened productive base will sustain demand for imported goods
In common with the rest of the Latin American region, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure, and this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. Sharp growth in mobile-telephone usage and an underdeveloped urban public transport system (which has boosted car ownership) are the main factors behind the relatively heavy weighting of expenditure on transport and communications. Most consumer goods industries will remain under-developed, a legacy of "Dutch disease", whereby dependence on energy exports leads to currency appreciation and therefore a lack of competitiveness in manufacturing exports, with a consequent decline of the latter sector. Furthermore, shortages of foreign exchange have led to import controls, resulting in a scarcity of consumer goods that are not produced domestically.
The scale of the country's ongoing recession will lead to major contraction in retail sales volumes throughout most of the forecast period, and only a modest improvement from 2020. Despite a forecast maxi-devaluation in 2018-29, the bolivar will still be overvalued, so sales in US dollar terms are not an accurate indicator of consumer demand.

Political transition will help to boost growth, but only in the long term
The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term outlook is based upon a transition to a government (in 2019) that pursues sounder policies and improves the business environment. However, despite the prospects of a more market-friendly government and the gradual elimination of the country's economic distortions, long-term growth will remain under-whelming, and will continue to be subject to boom and bust cycles linked to the oil market. We therefore project that Venezuela's real GDP will grow by an average of just 2.1% in 2017-50 (this figure is influenced by a contraction in 2017-18); growth will average 2.4% in 2031-50). Among the factors comprising long-term GDP growth, human capital will expand the most firmly, by a forecast 1.8% per year in 2015-50, mainly reflecting a fairly healthy demographic profile. However, very weak institutions, oil dependency and a weak productive base (made worse by severe mismanagement during the era of Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela-PSUV-government) will remain significant barriers to growth.
Initial conditions: After averaging growth of 10% in 2004-08, real GDP fell sharply in 2009-10. Although the economy recovered in 2011-12 on the back of aggressive fiscal spending, growth slowed sharply again in 2013, with the economy slipping into a deepening recession in late 2014. We estimate that by the time the economy returns to growth in 2020, it will have lost around 30% of real GDP, making the recession the country's most severe in recent history (technically a depression). The heterodox policy framework that has been in place for over a decade has been a major factor in hampering GDP growth, while an opaque and distorted exchange-rate system has provided opportunities for corruption on a large scale, further undermining the institutional framework and maintaining income inequality. Given the sharp deterioration in conditions in recent years, there is potential for improvement in the policy and political environment in the long term under an opposition administration, but there is significant risk of an outright economic collapse before then (or afterwards, if the transition is particularly chaotic). In addition, institutional deterioration is very deep-rooted and will prove harder to reverse.
On a more positive note, a higher skills base and reasonably good infrastructure by regional standards provide scope for faster overall growth and a rise in personal incomes. Nevertheless, underinvestment in human capital and infrastructure is eroding these advantages and, given growing fiscal difficulties, this trend will take time to reverse. Successive governments have failed to take advantage of Venezuela's proximity to developed US and European markets relative to its South American neighbours, as internal geography and a lack of investment in infrastructure in the interior have limited Venezuela's chances of becoming a regional hub for transport and commerce.
Demographic trends: As in most other emerging-market countries, growth in the working-age population will slow in the long term, while rising partici-pation rates will ensure that the labour force will grow at an even brisker pace. The dependency ratio of old to young will remain low by comparison to OECD levels in 2050. Even with life expectancy growing steadily, the share of the population aged 65 and over will be only around 16% in 2050 (although rising from 6.8% in 2016), while the proportion of the population at working age will remain high, at just under 65%. A particular risk to productivity is the brain-drain seen in recent years as many experienced professionals have left the country to work abroad with no guarantee of returning, even after economic conditions stabilise following a change in government.
Diversifying away from oil will be one of the key long-term challenges
External conditions: Oil, which currently accounts for almost 90% of export revenue and around one-quarter of GDP, will continue to dominate the Venezuelan economy. However, there will be an effort to diversify the productive base in the long term, given the severe consequences of the economy's dependency on oil (particularly on the external and fiscal balances). During the Hugo Chávez (1999-2013) and Nicolás Maduro eras Venezuela and its allies have taken a confrontational stance against US policy and US-led efforts at economic integration. This will end once a new government is in power, which will result in an economic rapprochement with some of its faster growing neighbours, such as Colombia and Peru. It will also signal the end of programmes such as PetroCaribe, which was largely used to boost the country's regional influence and was financially viable only as a result of historically high oil prices. A gradual real devaluation of the exchange rate will be necessary for Venezuela to be competitive in non-commodity sectors, as will be the need to remove state control over key productive sectors that have export potential. Capital control, trade restrictions and other barriers currently designed to keep foreign currency from leaking out will gradually be pared down as well, although further liberalisation of trade is unlikely to be a priority for the next government until well into the next decade. In the meantime, links with Asia will be strengthened, and the country's close relationship with China is not likely to be compromised, given that country's significant investment potential.
Institutions and policy trends: Under the assumption of an end to PSUV rule in 2019, our long-term forecast assumes that there will be a gradual improvement to the policy environment. We assume that some of the most distortionary elements of the current policy framework, including price and exchange controls, will be scaled back gradually, reducing the large black-market exchange-rate premium and increasing economic openness by the end of the long-term forecast period. However, the prospects for improvements in other aspects of the business environment are less encouraging, given that they will take far longer to address. For example, strengthening of the non-oil public finances will prove unfeasible until the economy is sufficiently diversified. Given that the economy will still be highly vulnerable to the fluctuations of the price of oil, the fiscal position will remain highly pro-cyclical. An overhaul of the overstaffed and inefficient bureaucracy will be difficult to achieve, even if the opposition comes to power, owing to the political costs of redundancies. Within the context of a deficient administrative framework, progress in reforming social security and labour legislation will be slow at best, as the new government will want to retain some of its powers of patronage in order to avoid a loss of support from the withdrawal of Chávez-era benefits. Endemic corruption and politicisation will be difficult to root out, even assuming other improvements in the policy environment.
The economy will remain vulnerable to external shocks and cycles
Long-term performance: Even once the most distortionary elements of current economic policy are abandoned, the deterioration of the skills base over the past decade will mean that Venezuela's potential GDP growth will have been eroded, although there is still some scope for recovery in 2021-30, when growth will average a respectable 3.3%. It will then slow down to an average of 2.4% in 2031-50. A higher trend rate of GDP growth would be possible in the event that a significant change in the policy direction is coupled with more favourable external conditions (mainly oil prices) than currently forecast, thereby allowing for rapid and thorough implementation of much-needed structural reforms. Under our baseline scenario, however, achieving reforms beyond those necessary for a post-transition adjustment will prove very complicated. As it is, the overall economy will remain vulnerable to continuing cycles of boom and bust, with negative consequences for macroeconomic stability and growth, as well as constraining the prospects for catch-up with more developed economies, despite some solid projected growth late in the forecast period. The key variables to a successful turnaround will be the degree to which the economy is diversified from oil and whether the business environment improves to the point that domestic and external investment become key drivers of growth.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
Domestic data
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsF:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the Central Bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
Formal political opposition to the regime will remain marginal. Vladimir Putin, the president, is likely to run again for president in March 2018 and win with a large majority in the first round. The principal concern for the authorities will be to maintain a high turnout in the absence of a meaningful contest.
Donald Trump, the new US president, has expressed a desire to improve relations with Russia. However, the likelihood of a significant rapprochement has declined following a US strike on a Syrian airbase in early April.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects US and EU sectoral sanctions on the Russian defence, energy and financial sectors to remain in place in the medium term. Russian counter sanctions on Western food imports will also remain in place indefinitely.
Despite a reduction in fighting in Ukraine, we do not expect the Minsk II deal to lead to a comprehensive political settlement. Ukraine will not regain full control of its border with Russia.
Russia is likely to remain a mobilisation economy, characterised by high spending on the defence sector, a cautious approach to foreign investment in many sectors, protectionism and a large role for the state in the economy.
The government is unlikely to implement disruptive market reforms. Minority stakes in some major state enterprises will be sold off. Chinese companies are likely to take a bigger role in the economy, including in the extractive sector.
Despite pressure to maintain defence and welfare spending, the government will cut public expenditure in 2017-19 to keep the budget deficit under control. The budget deficit will narrow to less than 1% of GDP by 2021, from 3.4% of GDP in 2016.
The economy contracted by 0.2% in 2016. We forecast that the economy will grow by 1.6% in 2017, supported by higher oil prices and improving consumer confidence. Investment will remain relatively weak, and public spending will be tightened further.
The medium-term growth outlook will be constrained by structural weaknesses, including a lack of competition, high state involvement in the economy, an ageing and declining workforce, and weak rule of law. We forecast average annual GDP growth of 1.6% per year in 2017-21.

Russia falls by two places in our regional ranking in the forecast period (2017-21), to 15th out of 16 countries. This reflects manifold institutional weaknesses, poor rule of law, high levels of corruption and extensive state involve-ment in the economy. It falls to 69th out of 82 countries in our global ranking.
Country forecast overview: Russia's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisation plans will proceed slowly, despite the announcement in 2016 of a new privatisation drive.
2019-21: Overall state involvement in the economy remains high. Government interference in private companies remains arbitrary. Rent-seeking officials remain a burden on business. Protection of intellectual property rights could weaken.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: International sanctions and low energy prices discourage major new investment in the oil and gas sectors.
2019-21: The "pivot to the east" will lead to further moderate growth in investment from Asia.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Western sanctions remain in place. Membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is effectively suspended. The Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) internal market is undermined by exemptions and weak enforcement.
2019-21: The difficulty of trading across borders continues to be a weakness. The Russian ban on Western agricultural imports is likely to remain in force.
Taxes
2017-18: The resources tax on gas and the tax on tobacco rise. The freeze on the tax on vodka is extended. Direct taxes on in-dividuals and value-added tax (VAT) will not be raised, and the government may issue VAT concessions to selected sectors.
2019-21: A progressive consumption tax might be introduced. Tax inspections remain a burden on business. The time that it takes to pay taxes is close to international norms. There are some specific improvements in the corporate tax regime.
Financing
2017-18: International sanctions limit access to external capital markets, significantly raising the cost of financing.
2019-21: International financial integration proceeds slowly. The banking system remains weak and state dominated. The government maintains its commitment to bail out systemically important institutions.
The labour market
2017-18: Spending on education is cut further. The incidence of strikes increases slightly, although the labour movement remains weak.
2019-21: The indigenous labour force will steadily decline; however, the impact will be offset in some sectors by continued substantial immigration from the Commonwealth of Independent States, much of it unskilled.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Budget constraints curb investment in infrastructure. Politically important projects are prioritised, but even here cuts are made. Russia struggles to obtain international funding for its infrastructure projects. Roads are starved of funding.
2019-21: It remains difficult to secure foreign finance. China provides only a limited alternative to Western funding.

Background: The transition to a market economy in the early 1990s was accompanied by a collapse in industrial production and a sharp drop in living standards. A contested privatisation process led to a highly concentrated ownership structure. Executive weakness and bureaucratic dysfunction contributed to a sharp decentralisation of power. After becoming president in 2000, Vladimir Putin sought to restore central control over the regions and tame independent corporate interests. Mr Putin presided over a period of strong economic growth in his first two terms. His re-election as president in 2012 has heralded the development of a more authoritarian domestic environment.
Political structure: Boris Yeltsin won the first democratic presidential election in June 1991 and was re-elected in July 1996. Repeated confrontations with the legislature culminated in the dissolution of parliament in September 1993 and a violent showdown the following month. The powers of the executive were greatly increased by a new constitution, adopted in 1993. Mr Putin was elected in March 2000 and re-elected for a second term in March 2004. Mr Putin's second term in office was characterised by increasing centralisation of the state. A loyal ally, Dmitry Medvedev, won the presidential election in March 2008 and took over in May of that year. Mr Putin returned to the presidency for a third term in May 2012. Following a constitutional change, his term will last six years, to 2018.
Policy issues: Mr Putin's third term as president has seen a greater emphasis on "conservative cultural values", anti-Westernism and great-power nationalism. The stand-off with the West is leading to a rollback of Russia's integration into the world economy. This is likely to strengthen further the state's role in the economy. Tit-for-tat sanctions have encouraged the government to focus on import substitution. The focus on curbing "foreign influence" on domestic politics is likely to endure, along with close controls on civil society, the internet and media.
Taxation: Reforms since 2000 have aimed to rationalise the tax system and cut the number of taxes and the corporate tax burden. Changes to the tax regime in January 2001 included the introduction of a flat rate of personal income tax of 13% and a simplification of the administration of social security contributions. In 2004 the basic rate of value-added tax (VAT) was reduced from 20% to 18% and a regional 5% sales tax was abolished. The corporate tax rate was cut from 24% to 20% at the beginning of 2009. The government has pledged not to raise personal or consumption taxes before 2018.
Foreign trade: Mainly because of high international oil prices, export revenue has soared since 2000. Import growth picked up over the same period as a result of rising real incomes and real rouble appreciation. Merchandise exports totalled just over US$280bn in 2016 and imports were just over US$190bn. Oil and gas account for around two-thirds of Russia's exports, with metals contributing around one-tenth.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Vladimir Putin's third presidential term, which began in 2012, has seen a shift towards "conservative cultural values", a more authoritarian political culture and more overt anti­Westernism. This has been further consolidated by Russia's confrontation with the West over Ukraine. Despite some pro-market rhetoric, economic policy has grown more statist and protectionist. The leadership will remain preoccupied by the need to insulate the economy and society from foreign-in particular Western-influence and the perceived threat of externally sponsored regime change. However, the regime is characterised by ideological flexibility and is more adaptable than many observers acknowledge. If the external environment allows (a major caveat), it is possible that the leadership will devote greater attention to domestic issues and welfare after the 2018 presidential election and attempt to implement a slightly more liberal economic agenda. Concern about political stability is likely to hold the government back from pursuing radical reform.
The forecast period (2017-21) is likely to be characterised by relatively slow growth in living standards, following a major decline in 2015-16 and further cuts in public expenditure in many areas. This contrasts sharply with the rapid growth achieved in Mr Putin's first decade in power and could have unpredict-able effects on stability in the medium term. However, there currently seems to be little desire for disruptive reform among the broader population, and the potential for mass protest or major political change from below appears to be low. Social controls have been tightened since 2012, and the opposition has been marginalised and demoralised. Protests regularly occur across the country, but these tend to be focused on single issues; the cost for individuals and activists of collective action focused on broader political change is high. The government tends to respond constructively when confronted with specific economic grievances. A mixture of state support and administrative pressure will keep major enterprises operating in provincial industrial towns.
The regime is actively engaged in cadre renewal at many levels. Nevertheless, the political system leans heavily on the charismatic leadership and popularity of Mr Putin. There is therefore a risk of a rupture when he departs the political scene. The weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the person-alised, opaque governance system around Mr Putin, could present difficulties in managing an eventual presidential transition. Any successor is likely to come from the team around Mr Putin and will not herald a sharp change in the policy agenda. However, it may be difficult for any successor to build popular legitimacy given the weak economic outlook. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a political transition in the forecast period. Speculation about an eventual succession strategy is likely to intensify soon after the 2018 presidential election, however, and this will further depress business confidence and raise political uncertainty.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next presidential election will take place in March 2018. We expect Mr Putin to contest the election and win by a wide margin in the first round. Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption blogger and nationalist opposition politician, will be barred from participating in the presidential election following a second conviction for defrauding Kirovles, a timber company. This suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, offering voters no meaningful alternatives to Mr Putin. The main challenge for the authorities will be to prevent a sharp fall in turnout, which would throw doubt on the legitimacy of Mr Putin's popular mandate. This is one of the reasons behind the efforts to revitalise the regional leadership with the replacement of poorly performing governors.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
The Ukraine conflict has led to a sharp deterioration in Russia's relations with the West since 2014. In response to the conflict in Ukraine, the US and the EU have imposed sanctions on senior Russian officials and the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors. Russia has responded with a ban on almost all Western food imports.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a comprehensive political resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. The constitutional reform mandated by the agreement, which could formally embed Russia's proxies within Ukraine's political system, is politically toxic in Ukraine. In the highly unlikely event that it is passed, there is little chance that Russia will allow Ukraine to re-establish control of its side of the international border. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests. Russia will not step back from its long-term objective of preventing a pro-Western govern-ment from consolidating in Ukraine. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, appears likely to endure for several years.
It appears unlikely that the plans of the US president, Donald Trump, to reconfigure relations with Russia will be realised, given strong resistance from the US security establishment. Allegations of Russian interference in the US presidential election are the subject of FBI and congressional investigations. Links between senior figures close to Mr Trump and Russian officials have been intensely scrutinised in the media, making it difficult for the administration to take measures perceived as offering concessions to Russia. Moreover, Mr Trump's decision to launch a strike on a Syrian airbase in early April has again set Russian and US policy on Syria-an area where Mr Trump's advisers had hoped to build co-operation-on divergent paths. We believe it likely that US and EU sanctions will be retained in the medium term. Russian counter sanctions on Western food imports are also likely to remain in place indefinitely.
Regardless of Mr Trump's stance, Russia's broader foreign policy will remain vehemently opposed to Western integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. Russia's policy towards its neighbours, and towards Ukraine in particular, will be an enduring source of tension with the West. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via popular uprising, would be likely to trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Economic reform will be subordinated to the imperatives of political stability and regime survival. We do not expect the government to move substantively towards liberalisation of the economy, and certainly not before the presidential election in March 2018, although some reform is possible thereafter.
A more likely scenario is that the government will seek incrementally to improve the efficiency of the system by replacing failing officials and bureau-crats and cracking down selectively on corruption. Following the presidential election the government is likely to extend the pension age and conduct a limited tax reform. Progress on strengthening the rule of law and protecting property rights is likely to be limited. The government will continue to sell minority stakes in some major state-controlled assets. However, as with the sale in December 2016 of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a Russian oil giant, the govern-ment's priority is to raise budget revenue rather than increasing the level of competition in the economy or reducing state influence over it.
Russia's stand-off with the West has strengthened statist and protectionist trends within the government. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a strategic priority. The main elements of this strategy include a large positive sovereign external asset position (low public debt combined with substantial foreign-exchange reserves), protectionist measures to encourage import substitution and support domestic manufacturing, and a cautious approach to globalisation and foreign investment (which in "strategic sectors", such as the extractive sector, is likely to be permitted only in partnership with state-controlled companies).
Some policymakers have urged a further increase in state intervention in the economy, along with capital controls, expansionist monetary policy and a return to a fixed exchange rate. We believe that the government will continue to pursue a mixed approach, observing the broad tenets of a market economy and avoiding disruptive reforms and excessive market-distorting behaviour (such as exchange or capital controls) while maintaining a large state role in the economy.
We expect the government to remain committed to its import substitution policy, and formal and informal barriers to external trade will remain significant.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The government faces tight budget constraints as a result of international sanctions, low commodity prices and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances (although Russia succeeded in placing two Eurobonds in 2016). The deficit in 2016 was the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP; however, this included extraordinary income from the sale of a stake in Rosneft in December last year. Without this, the deficit would have exceeded 4% of GDP.
Under the government's initial budget for 2017, spending will fall from Rb16.4trn (US$276bn) in 2016 to Rb16.2trn. This is broadly in line with the Ministry of Finance's proposal in July that spending be frozen for the next three years in nominal terms (which was based on the original expenditure target for 2016 of Rb16.1trn). Based on an average oil price of US$40/barrel in 2017, the govern-ment expects revenue to rise by 1.8%.
As anticipated, the government is now planning revisions in the light of higher average oil price. Anton Siluanov, the minister of finance, has suggested that expenditure could rise by Rb200bn (US$3.6bn) compared with the original budget, and that the budget deficit target could be reduced to 2% of GDP, from 3.2% previously. We forecast a significantly higher oil price than set out in the original budget, of US$56/b. We forecast a budget deficit of 2.2% of GDP this year, allowing for slightly higher additional spending than currently proposed by the finance ministry.
We expect the finance ministry to continue to trim the deficit in 2018-21, but the adjustment to expenditure is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly given the forthcoming presidential election. We believe that the government is unlikely to hold expenditure fixed in nominal terms in 2018-19 as planned, although spending will still decline in real terms. We forecast that the deficit will narrow to within 1% of GDP by 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
At its meeting in April the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) cut its policy rate by 50 basis points, to 9.25%. This was the central bank's second cut in as many months, after it had held the rate unchanged since September last year. The strong rouble, driven by higher oil prices and the carry trade, has helped to push disinflation ahead of the CBR's expectations. We expect the CBR to reduce its policy rate to 8-8.5% by the end of the year. We expect further loosening of monetary policy in 2018. With inflation now at the CBR's 4% target, the central bank governor, Elvira Nabiullina, has suggested that an appropriate level for the real interest rate would be about 2.5-3%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Russia's growth was decelerating even before 2014, as it ran into structural constraints. The economy experienced a sharp recession in 2015 as a result of the fall in the oil price, and real household incomes declined by almost 20%. The Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat) now estimates that the economy contracted by 2.8% in 2015 and 0.2% in 2016.
The outlook for 2017 will depend on the path of household consumption. We expect real wage growth to pick up this year, to more than 2%. Following a sharp decline in US dollar incomes in 2015-16, however, household consumption is likely to remain subdued. Retail sales volumes grew by 2.4% quarter on quarter in January-March (seasonally adjusted), but continued to contract in year-on-year terms. Leading indicators for manufacturing fell back in April, but the service sector purchasing managers' index remained strong.
Fiscal consolidation will continue to constrain public consumption and infrastructure spending. We expect a weak recovery in investment, after three years of contraction. Corporate deleveraging will slow and external financing conditions are likely to improve marginally. A relaxation of Western sanctions-not our core forecast-would provide a modest boost to investment. However, perceptions of political risk would remain high, limiting foreign direct investment (FDI) outside the commodities sector. An upswing in regional growth should lead to continued export growth, but at a slower pace than in 2016, as oil production is forecast to be flat. We forecast real GDP growth of 1.6% this year, with risks oriented to the downside, as household consumption might be weaker than currently projected.
The stabilisation of the economy should allow continued growth in investment in 2018, although it will remain relatively weak. A forecast slowdown in China will hit Russia's terms of trade, and we expect Russia's growth rate to moderate slightly, to 1.4%. The public sector will remain a drag on domestic demand.
In the medium term, outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low investment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that real GDP growth will average about 1.6% per year in 2018-21, in line with CBR estimates of Russia's trend growth under the current institutional and macroeconomic framework. There currently seems to be little prospect of far-reaching domestic institutional reform. High political risk and the poor business environment will continue to depress investment below the level needed to develop a higher trend growth rate. The declining workforce will also be a constraint on headline growth, although in some sectors this will be offset by continued high immigration from the Commonwealth of Independent States.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Inflation stood at 5.4% year on year in December 2016, but had slowed to 4.1% by April 2017 and 4% in mid-May, according to the Ministry of Economy, meaning that the CBR has achieved its inflation target more than six months ahead of schedule. Disinflation has been assisted by a strong harvest last year and the appreciation of the rouble. Both factors could prove to be temporary, given that the strong rouble is in part due to the carry trade, which will unwind as the CBR continues to loosen monetary policy. We forecast that consumer price inflation will average 4% in 2017. The slowdown in China will lead to a modest depre-ciation of the rouble in 2018, but external inflationary pressures are likely to be relatively low. Tax changes in 2019 are expected to push up inflation slightly in that year. Overall, we expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-target in the medium term.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Higher oil prices and relatively tight monetary policy, which has boosted the carry trade, has led to a significant appreciation of the rouble against the US dollar. In mid-May the rouble stood at Rb56:US$1. We expect the rouble to depreciate moderately from this level in the second half of 2017 as the CBR gradually loosens monetary policy. The rouble is highly correlated with the oil price, and any rapid fall in the oil price could lead to renewed exchange-rate volatility. We forecast an average full-year rate of just over Rb60:US$1. Our forecast growth slowdown in China in 2018 will hit Russia's terms of trade, and we expect the rouble to depreciate slightly in that year. Oil prices are forecast to be broadly stable around US$60/b in 2018-21, and therefore we do not anticipate significant movements in the rouble-dollar exchange rate.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
We forecast an increased current-account surplus in 2017 as higher oil prices boost the value of exports. This will be tempered by higher imports as domestic demand and investment pick up, alongside increased outflows on the primary and secondary accounts. We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, but a further recovery in imports and investment will gradually reduce the size as a share of GDP. International sanctions and political uncertainty will depress FDI and portfolio inflows, although we expect these to recover in 2018-21.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
Since the failed coup by parts of the military on July 15th 2016 there has been a rapid deterioration in Turkey's political outlook, and it looks set to continue. The president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) are steadily tightening their grip on power. This process is undermining Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures, and exacerbating the already deep social and political polarisation of the country. The approval in a referendum on April 16th 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency with few checks and balances moves the country one step closer to one-man rule by Mr Erdogan.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and the AKP will win the next presidential and parliamentary elections, completing the transfer of executive powers to Mr Erdogan. The elections are not due to be held until late 2019, but they could be called earlier-once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place-if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency. Emergency rule, which was introduced following the failed coup, will continue to be used to silence government critics and disable the pro-Kurdish opposition. Emergency rule will remain in place until at least late July 2017, and probably beyond.
Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and jihadi extremists affiliated with Islamic State (IS). Turkey risks be-coming mired in the Syrian conflict, following the deployment of Turkish troops to Syria to combat IS and to halt the territorial expansion by Syrian Kurds.
With the government focused with domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges, we expect little progress on economic reforms to improve the business and investor climate. Fiscal policy will be loosened to try to boost the economy, but we expect it to be relatively tight in the forecast period (2017-21).
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to cut interest rates to boost the economy has eased, but we expect that it will have to tighten monetary policy further in the coming months in order to lower inflation and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates.
We expect average annual real GDP growth to accelerate slightly, from 3% in 2016 to 3.2% in 2017-18 and a still moderate 3.7% annual average in 2019-21. The current-account deficit has narrowed, but will still be difficult to fund, especially if global liquidity is tightened.
