Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period and the country's global ranking deteriorates by 12 places, reflecting the absence of reforms in recent years. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment. The main shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening-up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade following the lifting of Russian sanctions. Possible increase in protectionism under the new US administration.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU may be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements may come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. The Central Bank of Turkey and commercial banks remain under political pressure to keep interest rates low.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. A 30% minimum wage rise in 2016 could damage competitiveness. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks may persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then, Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened under the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP, Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has remained prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which, with the AKP's consent until 2013, allowed the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage remain widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150.2bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.8bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Since the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 there has been a rapid deterioration in Turkey's political outlook, and this looks set to continue. The president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) are steadily tightening their grip on power. This is undermining Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures, and exacer-bating the already deep social and political polarisation of the country. In a referendum on April 16th, a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency were approved. This moves the country one step closer to one-man rule by Mr Erdogan. The president will not be deterred by the narrow margin of victory in the referendum, allegations of vote fraud or bids to nullify the referendum. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and the AKP will win the next presidential and parliamentary elections, completing the transfer of executive powers to Mr Erdogan with few checks and balances. These elections are not due to be held until 2019, but they could be called earlier, once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place, if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency.
Given the close referendum result and the allegations of vote fraud we expect political instability to persist in Turkey, which is likely to delay further economic reform efforts, hamper economic recovery and damage the country's already fragile relations with the EU. Immediately after the referendum the government announced the extension for another three months, to late July 2017, of the state of emergency law that was introduced in response to the failed coup. Emergency rule allows the president and the cabinet to pass laws without the approval of parliament and without recourse to the Constitutional Court, effectively allowing Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is in place. Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a US-based Islamic cleric, who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More than 100,000 people, mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media, have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held in November 2019 at the latest. We expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and to remain in office, with enhanced powers, for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, and the opposition is fragmented and lacks candidates capable of challenging him. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round with just over 50% of the vote, well ahead of a joint candidate presented by the two main opposition parties, the Republican People's Party (CHP) and the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the AKP's presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties would consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the MHP leadership's decision to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 elections and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for representation in parliament, which would help to boost the AKP's share of seats. Under the constitutional changes approved in the presidential reform referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's international relations with its traditional Western allies.
Tensions with the EU escalated to new highs during the presidential reform referendum campaign and are unlikely to ease in the near future, given Mr Erdogan's narrow win and allegations of vote fraud. Neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc any more, but neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested since the failed coup, the EU may not be able to avoid suspending the process. Our baseline forecast has been that the death penalty is unlikely to be reinstated, but this cannot be ruled out given the government's increasingly hardline nationalist stance. The suspension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Tukey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the movement of migrants and refugees into Europe. An agreement on a solution to end the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but we believe that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
The Trump administration is less concerned about Mr Erdogan's autocratic tendencies than its Democrat predecessor, but is equally unresponsive to Turkey's domestic and regional security concerns. Vague US reassurances about support for Turkey's fight against terrorism avoided a full-blown crisis in May 2017, when as expected Mr Trump authorised the supply of arms to the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) for the offensive against IS in its stronghold in Raqqa in Syria. This ignored Turkey's objection that, in its view, the YPG is affiliated with the outlawed PKK in Turkey. As yet there has also been no response to Turkey's request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey on charges of masterminding the failed coup.
Since mid-2016 Turkey has improved its ties with Russia, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both countries are militarily involved but are pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
We expect political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity as a result of anticipated shifts in US monetary policy to pose an ongoing risk to foreign capital inflows to Turkey, especially in the first half of the forecast period. These inflows are needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, but tend to be short-term and highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows put the lira under intense pressure in late 2016-early 2017, fuelling an acceleration in inflation that prompted the Central Bank of Turkey to start tightening monetary policy after a prolonged period of loosening. An abrupt tightening of policy could strangle Turkey's already fragile economic growth.
Turkey's economy has shown considerable resilience during past bouts of volatility in global liquidity, owing largely to the country's solid public finances and well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector. However, uncertainty about the direction of economic policy in recent years has clouded Turkey's medium-term economic policy outlook. Although the AKP government has focused on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges, the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate have been blocked. The biggest policy challenge in the short term will be to support the recovery of Turkey's flagging economy while also controlling inflationary pressures and stabilising the lira. The current direction of policy appears to be towards a difficult balancing act between fiscal loosening and tight monetary policy while encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios-reflecting the impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past but also major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts-give the AKP government some leeway to loosen fiscal policy to support the economy. Our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight, but that the central government deficit will widen, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.1% of GDP per year in 2017-21. The government debt/GDP ratio is low, but it edged up slightly, to 29.4% in 2016, from 29.1% in 2015. We expect a further moderate increase in 2017-19, before it declines to about 30% in 2021. However, the risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out. The government's decision to transfer Turkey's major state assets to a sovereign wealth fund set up in 2016 to help to finance major infrastructure projects could bring to a halt the government's privatisation programme and increase political control over state companies, and the fund could become a vehicle for increased off-budget spending.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Political pressure on the Central Bank of Turkey to lower interest rates to revive economic activity has eased in recent months, but we expect that it will have to tighten monetary policy further in the coming months in order to dampen inflationary pressures and prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates. We expect the bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. The central bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which has gradually been raised by a total of 250 basis points, to 12.25% in late-April. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen from 7.8% to about 11.9% in mid-May 2017.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, the one-week repurchase lending rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that the corridor will be eliminated until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases. From 2017 the bank will hold only eight regular Monetary Policy Committee meetings annually rather than 12.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Domestic political instability, perceived security risks from terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook will have negative effects on the economy in the short and medium term. We expect real GDP growth to pick up only modestly, from 3% in 2016 to 3.2% per year in 2017-18. In 2019-21 we expect real GDP growth to average 3.7% per year, assuming that there is a stabilisation of domestic conditions. By far the biggest risk to our growth forecast is the possibility of a severe disruption to capital inflows to Turkey.
We expect moderate private consumption growth in 2017-21 as domestic political uncertainty, a weaker lira and high unemployment will partially offset the impact of the 30% minimum wage rise in 2016, government pressure on banks to ease lending conditions for households and government incentives to support demand for certain household durable goods.
After expanding by 7.7% in 2016, we expect government spending to increase by just under 8% per year on average in 2017-19 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect growth to be more moderate but still solid.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to dampen fixed investment growth in 2017-18, as weakened business sentiment and a more cautious approach by foreign investors will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast an acceleration to average annual growth of 4.9%, assuming a less volatile domestic and global environment.
After contracting by 1.9% in 2016 as a result of the impact of Russian sanctions and domestic security concerns, especially on the tourism sector, we expect exports of goods and services gradually to return to growth, reflecting the lifting of sanctions and the impact of a weaker lira on export competitiveness. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter visitors to Turkey. Our expectation is that a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. We expect further currency weakness and a partial recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank keeps monetary policy tight and does not loosen it too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile, plunging in value against all major currencies in late 2016-early 2017 and then recovering partially in recent months. Amid further bouts of volatility we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar to an annual average of TL3.67:US$1 in 2017, a fall of 18%. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL3.97:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, and the impact on investor confidence of domestic political instability and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
GDP revisions, moderate domestic demand growth, sharply lower global oil prices and a weaker lira have helped to reduce Turkey's current-account deficit in recent years. However, we expect it to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large-at a forecast average of 4.2% of GDP per year in 2017-21-to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and the loss of investor confidence since the failed coup persists. Although a weaker lira will boost Turkey's main export sectors, we expect this to be largely offset by the higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. In addition, the tourism sector is likely to take several years to recover to 2015 pre-crisis levels, before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Full text:   Italy--highlights: Political outlook
The resounding rejection of the flagship constitutional reform package of the government led by Matteo Renzi in a referendum on December 4th 2016 has increased political instability, which will hinder prospects for political and economic reform in Italy. The government formed in December 2016 by Paolo Gentiloni, previously the minister of foreign affairs under Mr Renzi and also a member of the Partito Democratico (PD), is weak and especially vulnerable to political manoeuvrings within the PD and the wider coalition ahead of the next parliamentary election. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the election will be held at or close to term in early 2018 and that the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) to emerge as the largest party but will not obtain a majority of parliamentary seats. Given the considerable obstacles to M5S form-ing a coalition with other parties, we expect a broad coalition of established centre-left/centre right parties to be formed, but it will be unstable and ineffective. Frustration with such a government would probably fuel further anti-establishment resentment, boosting M5S's chances of entering government after the subsequent election.

Having increased at an annual average rate of 0.4% in 2000-09, total population growth slowed in 2010-16, coming to a halt at 59.8m. We expect population to continue to stagnate during the forecast period, falling slightly to 59.7m in 2021, reflecting lower immigrant inflows and emigration of young Italians.

Italy's business environment score improves slightly during the forecast period (2017-21), but falls by two places in the global rankings, reflecting the slow pace of reform and weak implementation. Its regional ranking is unchanged, at 16th out of 18 west European countries, ahead of only Greece and Turkey. Italy's macro-economic environment score remains unchanged. However, owing to improve-ments in other countries, Italy slips 11 places in our global ranking and by three places in the regional ranking. The scores for policy towards foreign investment, financing and the labour market all improve, reflecting the impact of economic reforms taken by successive governments since late 2011. Italy's tax system remains one of the biggest hindrances to businesses and foreign invest-ment. Compliance is costly and tax evasion remains widespread.

The biggest challenge facing the government will be to balance measures to cut the public debt burden of close to 132.5% of GDP in 2016 with measures designed to promote economic growth, reverse a rise in unemployment and ease social tensions. Repairing the weaknesses in Italy's banking system is also likely to prove challenging. We expect the budget deficit to remain within the 3% of GDP limit for EU countries, but the debt/GDP ratio will remain high and economic reforms to boost growth will only have a gradual effect. After a prolonged recession, Italy's economy has returned to growth, but the recovery remains fragile and the pace of expansion is modest. Driven mainly by domestic demand growth, we expect real GDP to expand at an annual average rate of about 1% in 2017-21. We expect the current account to remain in surplus over the forecast period, although it will decline as domestic demand growth stabilises.

Italy is one of the largest and richest markets in Europe, with a population of about 6om. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth pros-pects. Income levels differ greatly between the north and the south of Italy, with GDP per head in the south less than 55% of that in the centre and north. Past policies have done little to close the gap, so no significant change is expected during the forecast period. Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns, with population ageing driving healthcare expenditure.

Our baseline forecast is that Italy's weak demographic profile will act as a substantial brake on real GDP growth, which we expect to average just 0.5% per year in 2017-50, which is considerably weaker than what was until recently considered to be Italy's trend rate of growth (1.5%). A more favourable political environment could produce a better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improvements in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is limited.

Background: Post-war Italy has been characterised by a weak political structure and, since the 1970s, a declining economic base. Between 1996 and 2011 Italy had a bipolar political system, dominated by a centre-right alliance and a centre-left coalition. Since 2011 the political landscape has become more fragmented, with the break-up of the centre right and the emergence of Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), an anti-establishment movement. Since the 2013 general election Italy has had two broad centre-left/centre-right governments. The resignation of Matteo Renzi as prime minister after his flagship constitutional reform was rejected in a referendum on December 4th 2016 triggered a crisis and the formation of another government led by Paolo Gentiloni, a close ally of Mr Renzi.
Political structure: Parliament, which comprises two houses with equal powers, is elected for a maximum of five years. The president, who is elected by parliament for a seven-year term, decides, in the event of a political crisis, whether to call an election or nominate a prime minister to try to form a government. The president also promulgates laws and may return a law to parliament for reconsideration, but has no power of veto. Executive power lies with the cabinet, which is nominated by the prime minister and approved by parliament. The prime minister cannot dismiss ministers without forming a new government. The legislative system remains unchanged following the rejection in the December referendum of a reform to reduce the powers of the Senate (the upper house).
Policy issues: The main issues are the management of, and attempts to reduce, Italy's large public debt (which reached an estimated 132.5% of GDP in 2016), safeguarding the banking system and keeping Italy in the euro zone. In 2012 the government, led by Mario Monti, carried out a number of structural economic reforms to improve competitiveness. The process stalled in 2013, but it was revived under the Renzi government.
Taxation: The top rate of personal income tax is 43% and social security contributions are high, especially for employers. The corporation tax rate is 24%, reduced from 27.5% in 2017, but additional regional and municipal taxes are levied, including the regional business tax (IRAP) to fund health services. The basic rate of IRAP is 3.5%, reduced from 3.9% in 2014. Income earned from most types of financial investment is taxed at 26%. The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 22%.
Foreign trade: The value of exports of goods (fob) stood at US$449.3bn in 2015, and imports (fob) were worth US$391.4bn. In the same year the current account recorded a surplus of US$29.3bn, or 1.6% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Matteo Renzi, the leader of the Partito Democratico (PD), resigned as prime minister in December 2016 after his flagship constitutional reform package was resoundingly rejected in a referendum. He was replaced by Paolo Gentiloni, previously the minister of foreign affairs under Mr Renzi and also a member of the PD. Mr Gentiloni's government is backed in parliament by the PD, the centre-right Nuovo Centro Destra (NCD)-a splinter party formed when the Popolo della Libertà (PDL) leader, Silvio Berlusconi, withdrew his party from the Letta government coalition and renamed it Forza Italia (FI)-and by two small centrist parties. The main opposition parties are the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), FI, Lega Nord and Fratelli d'Italia. In addition, the defection from the PD of groups of critics of Mr Renzi's leadership style has added to an array of small parties and movements to the left of the PD, including Sinistra Italiana (SI), combining leftist PD defectors and the left-wing, environmentalist Sinistra Ecologia Libertà (SEL), and Articolo 1-Movimento Democratico e Progressista (MDP), another group of PD defectors.

Political outlook: Political stability
The coalition government, led by Paolo Gentiloni of the dominant centre-left PD, was formed in December 2016 following Mr Renzi's resignation. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the Gentiloni government will remain in place until the end of the current parliamentary term, in early 2018. However, another government crisis and a snap general election in the final months of this year cannot be ruled out. The government is weak and especially vulnerable to political manoeuvrings within the PD and the wider coalition ahead of the next election.
Having also resigned as secretary of the PD in February 2017 to confront his critics in the party, Mr Renzi was re-elected with about 69% of the vote in a leadership contest that concluded with a public vote on April 30th. The margin of victory has helped to tighten Mr Renzi's grip on a divided party, which ahead of the leadership contest saw a large group of leftists break away under the MDP banner. Nevertheless, Mr Renzi faces a huge challenge to rebuild popular support and credibility after the failure of the constitutional reform referendum and to fend off the growing challenge of M5S, a Eurosceptic, anti-establishment movement led by Beppe Grillo. To do this Mr Renzi may adopt a tougher line with the Gentiloni government and the EU, which has pressured Italy to take additional corrective measures to meet agreed budget targets.
Against this backdrop, Mr Gentiloni has a difficult policy remit, including trying to keep the economic recovery on track while controlling the public finances, managing problems in Italy's banking sector, dealing with a renewed influx of migrants and tackling the aftermath of a series of deadly earthquakes, as well as the imminent collapse of the former national carrier, Alitalia. At the same time the government will have little say over the main issue driving the political debate, namely the need to align the electoral laws of the two houses of parliament after elements of both were declared unconstitutional by the Constitutional Court in separate rulings for the Senate (the upper house) in 2013 and the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) in January 2017. The task of reforming the electoral laws will fall to the leaders of the main parties in parliament-Mr Renzi for the PD, Angelino Alfano for NCD, Mr Grillo for M5S and Silvio Berlusconi for the centre-right FI. Their views differ significantly on the issue. Failure to reach an agreement could destabilise the government and trigger an early election to be held under the electoral laws as they stand, which are essentially strongly proportional for both houses. A majoritarian element (bonus seats) left intact in the Chamber of Deputies would only be triggered if a party exceeded 40% of the vote, but based on current opinion polls no party is likely to reach this threshold. Assuming, as we do, that the next election will be held under strongly proportional electoral laws, we expect the next government to be unstable and ineffective, unable to pass long overdue political and economic reforms.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Italy is governed by weak, divided executives, generally comprising multiparty coalitions, in which small parties wield disproportionate power over policy decisions. Under the bicameral parliamentary system all bills have to be passed in the same form by both houses of parliament in order to be enacted, often resulting in delays and the dilution of measures. This is unlikely to change following the rejection of the Renzi government's constitutional reform package, which sought drastically to reduce the legislative powers of the Senate and would have effectively made the parliament quasi-unicameral.
Efficiency may improve in the public administration, but not in the judiciary
Red tape and Italy's inefficient judicial system are likely to continue to pose problems for businesses. However, measures being introduced to increase public-sector accountability and efficiency should help to speed up gradually some bureaucratic procedures, although given entrenched resistance to change within the public administration, the implementation of the reforms approved in 2015 is likely to be slow. A partial reform of the judicial system was under-taken in 2014-16. However, many of the problems facing Italy's judicial system have not been addressed, including a fee system for lawyers that acts as a disin-centive to concluding cases swiftly, a lack of specialisation among judges and a highly fragmented court system. The average number of days to resolve a contractual dispute in Italy is more than double that in some other EU member states.
Corruption is still rife in business, judging by the number of corruption scandals revealed in recent years. A bill presented in March 2010 containing measures intended to combat corruption among public officials took almost three years to become law. Since then, government action appears to have intensified. In June 2014 the powers of the anti-corruption authority were strengthened, and less than a year later parliament approved another anti-corruption law, including provisions eliminating the minimum threshold for the prosecution of accounting fraud and introducing harsher prison sentences for this offense, as well as corruption of public officials, embezzlement and mafia association.
Criminal organisations will continue to pose problems for businesses and deter investment, despite the authorities' efforts to combat extortion and usury and the arrests of several mafia bosses in recent years.
Political outlook: Election watch
The December 2016 referendum outcome and the subsequent increase in political instability have considerable implications for our forecasts for the next parliamentary election, which we expect to take place in early 2018. We expect that the political parties will harmonise the two electoral laws, instituting a strongly proportional electoral system for both houses of parliament. In the less likely scenario that the laws are left unchanged, we would expect no single party to reach the 40% threshold for bonus seats in the lower house. As a result, we expect that the next election will produce consistent results in the two houses, but also that the fragmentation of the political system into three main blocs-centre left, M5S and centre right-will prevent any bloc from emerging as the clear winner.
The main contest is likely to be between the PD and M5S. Support for the two parties remains broadly similar, at about 30% of the vote, according to opinion polls. Although M5S's credibility has been dented by recent political blunders and local-level scandals, most notably in Rome's city government, we expect it to emerge as the largest party at the next election, boosted by Mr Renzi's defeat in the referendum, the split in the PD and an increase in anti-politics sentiment. However, under a strongly proportional voting system, we expect that M5S will not obtain a majority of parliamentary seats. This would require it to enter a coalition with other parties to form a government. Given M5S's hardline stance towards the established parties across the political spectrum and these parties' concerns about M5S's policies and administrative capability, we believe that M5S would be unlikely to succeed. It is more likely that the established parties will be persuaded to join forces to keep M5S out of government, leading to the establishment between the centre left and the centre right of an unstable coalition. Frustration with such a government would probably fuel further anti-establishment resentment, boosting M5S's chances of winning the subsequent election and possibly entering government.
The president is elected for a seven-year term by an electoral college of the Senate, the Chamber of Deputies and regional representatives. The next presi-dential election is not due until 2022. The next local elections in several large towns and cities, notably Genoa and Palermo, will take place in June 2017.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Matteo Renzi
A former mayor of Florence, Mr Renzi first became leader of the Partito Democratico (PD) in December 2013 with almost 68% of the 2.8m votes cast in the primary elections. After resigning as prime minister in December 2016 he also stepped down as PD leader to confront his critics in a leadership contest, which he won convincingly again with 69.2% of the vote on April 30th 2017. Turnout was lower than in 2013, however, at about 1.8m. As leader of the PD, Mr Renzi has shifted the party to the right, loosening the PD's ties with its traditional trade union supporter base and antagonising the party's large leftist minority. Mr Renzi's popular appeal declined steadily after the PD won an unprecedented 40% of the vote in the May 2014 European Parliament elections. This helped to galvanise opponents of his reform plans within his party and on the opposition benches, culminating in the resounding rejection of his flagship constitutional reform package in a referendum in December 2016. As prime minister from February 2014-December 2016 Mr Renzi's performance was mixed. He succeeded in introducing some economic reforms that had eluded Italian governments over the previous 20 years, but his abrasive and at times autocratic leadership style became increasingly polarising. Having won a fresh mandate to lead the PD, his goal is to be elected to parliament for the first time at the next general election, due to be held in early 2018, and become prime minister again. Mr Renzi's bid to return to the prime minister's office will be more difficult than his ascent in 2014, when he effectively ousted Enrico Letta, also of the PD, from the post. He needs to rebuild his popular support after the referendum defeat and counter the rise of the anti-establishment, Eurosceptic Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S).
Sergio Mattarella
Mr Mattarella, a former Constitutional Court judge and government minister, was elected president by the parliament and electoral college in January 2015 following the retirement of his predecessor, Giorgio Napolitano. Although Mr Napolitano gave explicit support to Mr Renzi and his reform agenda in his last year in office, Mr Mattarella has been more circumspect. Since the Constitutional Court ruling in January 2017 declaring aspects of the electoral law for the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house of parliament) unconstitutional, Mr Mattarella has used his non-partisan position to pressure the political parties to agree on changes to the electoral laws before the next election. He will play a vital role in the government formation process after the next election. It is the president's prerogative to decide whether and when to call a parliamentary election. He also designates the prime minister, after consultation with the parties in parliament and former presidents.
Beppe Grillo
Mr Grillo founded M5S, a protest movement, in 2009. At its first general election in 2013 M5S shocked the political establishment by obtaining about 25% of the vote. Amid internal wrangling, M5S lost ground in the May 2014 European Parliament elections, but it was still the second-largest party by vote share, with just over 20%. In opinion polls support for M5S has recovered to close to 30% of the vote, on a par with the PD. In 2016 Mr Grillo adopted a lower profile, which allowed Luigi Di Maio, the deputy speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, to emerge as the party's leader in parliament and potentially its prime ministerial candidate at the next general election. However, following a series of party blunders and local-level scandals, notably in Rome, he has reasserted his control. Although he will not stand in the general election he is likely to dominate the M5S's electoral campaign. TheM5S's Eurosceptic, anti-establishment rhetoric resonates strongly with voters disillusioned with the mainstream parties on both the centre left and centre right, virtually all of which have been embroiled in corruption scandals at national or local level.
Silvio Berlusconi
Mr Berlusconi's personal wealth, dominance of the media and tendency to confuse the public good and his own interests made him a controversial prime minister during the 20 years that he dominated Italian politics. He is a much diminished political figure since his expulsion from parliament in 2013 as a consequence of his definitive conviction for tax fraud. However, Mr Berlusconi is still the leader of the main centre-right party in parliament, Forza Italia, and he is seeking to determine who will emerge as his successor as the leader of a broader centre-right alliance to challenge Mr Renzi and the PD. In a highly fragmented parliament his position on planned changes to the electoral laws could be decisive, as could be his stance in the process of government formation after the next general election.
Matteo Salvini
Under Mr Salvini's leadership since December 2013, the Lega Nord has enjoyed a rise in popular support in opinion polls. However, with the general election approaching in early 2018, support for the Lega Nord appears to have plateaued at 13-14%, putting it on a par with the once dominant Forza Italia. Following the presidential election defeat of the Front national leader, Marine Le Pen, in France in May 2017, the Lega Nord's old guard and founders, whom Mr Salvini has sought to sideline, have revived their criticism of his leadership, which has transformed the party from what was originally a regionalist protest movement from the north into a populist party of national appeal with a strong anti-immigrant, Eurosceptic message. From 1994 until late 2011 Lega Nord propped up several centre-right governments led by Mr Berlusconi, gradually abandoning its original goal of secession of the north from the rest of Italy. By 2011 the party and its leadership had become mired in allegations of abuse of party funds.
Political outlook: International relations
We expect the mainstays of Italy's foreign relations to remain in place during the forecast period (2017-21): membership of the EU and the euro zone, a close relationship with the US and membership of NATO and the UN. We expect the government led by Mr Gentiloni to maintain broadly positive EU relations, as would a broad coalition government if, as we expect, one were to be formed after the next general election. Nevertheless, the rise of anti-establishment parties in Italy and elsewhere in Europe has led voters to question Italy's hitherto strong commitment to European integration. M5S has proposed a referendum on Italy's membership of the euro area and recently flirted with the idea of a NATO referendum as well. Although referendums on international treaties are not permitted by the Italian constitution, there would be a risk of at least a non-binding vote on the euro if an M5S-led government were to come to power, although this is not our baseline forecast. Such action could unnerve financial markets and Italy's European partners if it were to go ahead. Regardless of who is in government, Italy's high public debt burden and political instability will continue to be a cause for concern for some time for the core euro zone creditor countries, as well as a risk to the survival of the bloc and to the stability of its financial sector.
The Italian government has supported the sanctions that the EU has imposed on Russia since July 2014 as a result of Russia's intervention in Ukraine. We expect them to remain in place during most of the forecast period.
We expect Italy to maintain its commitment to the US-led campaign against Islamic State (IS) in Iraq and Syria, although without participating in air strikes. Italy and the US have worked closely together to support the Government of National Accord (GNA) in Libya, but the future direction of US policy is uncertain following the change of administration in the US.

Population growth is projected to come to a virtual halt
Having declined for several years in the late 1990s, Italy's total population increased moderately in 2000-09, rising by an average of 0.4% per year. Since 2010 population growth has slowed gradually, coming to a halt at 59.8m in 2016. The increase was mainly driven by immigration and births to foreign residents. More recently, the stagnation reflects the failure of births to keep pace with deaths, as well as lower net immigration, as the expectation of scarce job oppor-tunities due to the weakness of the economy has probably reduced the influx of immigrants and driven further emigration of young Italians. There is some uncertainty about future levels of immigration to Italy from outside Europe. Since the EU's March 2016 agreement with Turkey, the flow of migrants from Turkey to Greece and on to northern Europe has more or less ceased, but it has coincided with a sharp increase in migrant flows to Italy. In the past most migrants arriving in Italy moved on to other EU countries, notably Germany. However, this has become more difficult, as other EU member states have tightened their border controls with Italy.
According to Istat (the national statistics office), the proportion of foreign residents in the total population has increased steadily in recent years, rising from 4.5% in 2005 to 8% at end-2013 and 8.3% at end-2016, unchanged from the previous year. The majority of immigrants live in the north and the centre of Italy, where foreign residents accounted for 10.7% of the population at end-2015 (latest available data), up from about 10% in 2013. However, growth in the number of foreign nationals residing in the south has begun to outpace that in the north and centre in recent years. The three largest national groups are Romanians, Albanians and Moroccans, who together account for about 40% of the total number of foreign residents. Even during periods of modest economic growth, shortages of skilled and even unskilled workers are likely to re-emerge in areas of high employment such as the north-east, owing to deficiencies in the labour market. This is likely to result in employers calling for immigrant worker quotas to be raised.
Although almost 70% of Italians live in urban areas, the population is widely dispersed among numerous small cities and towns. As a result, local markets tend to be diffused and relatively small scale. The combined population of Italy's three largest cities-Rome (the capital), Milan and Naples-accounts for less than 10% of the country's total population, although if the outer suburbs are included, the three main urban areas account for about 20% of the total population.
Reforms seek to increase labour mobility
The steady rise in the employment rate (the percentage of people aged 20-64 in employment) since the mid-1990s came to a halt in 2008. At 61.6% in 2016, down from 62.9% in 2008, according to Eurostat, it was about 10 percentage points lower than the EU28 average and the third-lowest rate in the EU, ahead of only Greece and Croatia, and slightly below Spain. The reasons for this include cultural factors, but also the low effective retirement age and limited mobility from areas of high unemployment in the south to those of high employment in the north. Low labour mobility has been perpetuated to a large extent by the greater use of temporary employment contracts, especially for young workers, poor active labour market policies and an inadequate system of unemployment benefits. The labour market reforms approved since 2012 aim to gradually address some of these issues during the forecast period. In spite of the projected decline in the working-age population during the forecast period, the labour force will increase moderately. This will be attributable to greater female participation as well as pension reforms, which have reduced the incentive for early retirement, and measures to improve jobseeking services.
Rise in proportion of elderly will put pressure on pensions and healthcare
During the forecast period the number of people of working age will be considerably lower than the number of people reaching 65. As a result, Italy's old-age dependency ratio (the ratio of people aged over 65 to those of working age) will rise further. At an estimated 33% in 2016, it is already one of the highest in the EU. By the end of the forecast period it is expected to reach 35%, compared with 37% in Germany, 34% in France and 29% in the UK.
This trend, combined with the continued rise in life expectancy, will continue to put upward pressure on public expenditure on pensions and care for the elderly. Italy's public pension spending has been on a steadily rising trend and is among the highest in the EU as a share of GDP. According to figures from the Ministry of the Economy, public pension spending is projected to decline gradually over the next ten years, from a peak of about 16% in 2013-14, owing to a series of reforms introduced since the beginning of the 1990s.

Although Italy's business environment score has improved slightly during the forecast period (2017-21), it has fallen by two places in the global rankings compared with the historical period (2011-16), reflecting the slow pace of reform and weak implementation. Its regional ranking is unchanged, at 16th out of 18 west European countries, ahead of only Greece and Turkey.
Institutional reform to improve government effectiveness is unlikely
Italy scores poorly for government effectiveness because of its slow legislative and judicial systems. Following the rejection of Matteo Renzi's constitutional reforms, institutional reform will be off the political agenda for the foreseeable future. The parliamentary election, due to be held in early 2018, is likely to produce another unstable coalition government. A partial reform of the judicial system in 2014-16 is unlikely to be sufficient to resolve the problems facing Italy's judicial system. The economic recovery remains on track, but is modest. Promoting economic growth and employment, as well as reducing Italy's elevated public debt burden and repairing weaknesses in the banking sector, will remain the biggest policy challenge facing the government in 2017-21.
The scores for policy towards foreign investment, financing and the labour market all improve, reflecting the impact of economic reforms taken by successive governments since late 2011. Recent governments have also taken steps to reduce political opposition to foreign takeovers, and public receptiveness to overseas investment has also improved.
Despite moderate cuts to income and business levies since 2014, Italy's tax system remains one of the biggest hindrances to businesses and foreign investment. Compliance is costly and tax evasion remains widespread. The government has taken some steps to encourage mergers in the banking sector and support banks' efforts to reduce the level of non-performing loans (NPLs) on their balance sheets, but progress has been slow.
Business environment outlook: Italy's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Significant reforms to improve competition are unlikely ahead of the 2018 election.
2019-21: Further improvements in competition policy are dependent on political stability.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Recent administrative reform has brought about modest reductions in red tape. Some streamlining of the judicial system is likely, but lengthy delays persist.
2019-21: Organised crime, legal complexity and shortcomings in the judicial system remain deterrents, with further reform progress dependent on political stability.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Quotas and tariffs are in line with EU practice. EU-UK trade deal to dominate Brexit negotiations. The risk of euro area break-up, which could lead to capital controls, is moderate, although we expect Greece to have left the bloc by 2021.
2019-21: Trade barriers remain low, but agricultural protection continues. The EU focuses on further bilateral free-trade deals. However, EU-US agreement will probably remain elusive.
Taxes
2017-18: Despite a tax cut for businesses, levies remain elevated to curb the budget deficit.
2019-21: Overall tax rates stay high, but the burden of future fiscal tightening is likely to fall on public expenditure.
Financing
2017-18: Despite new legislation, bank mergers, further recapitalisation and non-performing loan sales are slow. Overall profitability and credit provision are still weak.
2019-21: Banking sector exposure to the Italian sovereign will persist. Mergers of smaller co-operative banks and possible foreign takeovers should accelerate, as will the gradual sale of securitised bad loans.
The labour market
2017-18: Despite reforms, Italy's weak economic recovery will see firms remain reluctant to increase open-ended contract payrolls. Universal unemployment benefit is gradually introduced.
2019-21: Decentralisation of productivity-related pay deals is likely to be slow. Pressure to improve competitiveness leads to more flexible work organisation at company level. Changes to public employment contracts are likely to be resisted.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Infrastructure continues to exhibit deficiencies. Lack of political appetite for drastic current-expenditure cuts limits room for public investment.
2019-21: Infrastructure still lags that of other euro area countries, despite some new investment.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's assessment of the macroeconomic environment focuses not on headline real GDP growth (measured in the market opportunities category) but on economic stability and the underlying policy framework, which influence business planning, hiring and investment. Italy's macroeconomic environment score is unchanged in the forecast period. However, owing to improvements in other countries, Italy slips 11 places in our global ranking, and by three places in the regional ranking. Despite some progress, economic reforms were introduced with a lag relative to most other struggling euro zone economies, and further measures to reverse more than a decade of stagnant productivity growth are unlikely in the current political environment. We expect Italy to keep its budget deficit within the EU's 3% of GDP limit and to continue to generate primary surpluses (the budget balance excluding interest payments), but the public debt burden will remain about 130% of GDP during the forecast period.
The budget deficit will remain under control, but debt reduction will be slow
After a protracted period of stagnation, consumer prices have increased, largely owing to rising global energy costs. Demand-side inflationary pressures will remain subdued, owing to continued weak household consumption, labour market slack and high unemployment, as well as constrained wage growth.
Export growth and low global energy prices will keep Italy's current account in surplus during the forecast period. Nevertheless, concerns remain surrounding the erosion of the country's export competitiveness and stagnant productivity.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
Value of index a
 
Global rank b
 
Regional rank c
 

2012-16
2017-21
2012-16
2017-21
2012-16
2017-21

5.8
5.8
43

18

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition remains an area in which Italy scores poorly compared with its EU peers, reflecting weak implementation and enforcement of competition rules. Generally, EU directives have been the main drivers of liberalisation in Italy, forcing successive governments-which, regardless of their political leaning, have not instinctively favoured compe-tition-to open up markets in several sectors, notably telecommuni-cations, energy and professional services. The powers of Italy's national Competition Authority were strengthened and its remit extended to cover the provision of public services in 2010, but political pressure has generally limited effectiveness. This is also true of other watchdogs, including the Commissione Nazionale per le Società e la Borsa (Consob), the public authority responsible for regulating the Italian securities market, and the telecoms watchdog, Autorità per le Garanzie nelle Comunicazioni (AGCOM).
External constraints will continue to be the main drivers of liberalisation
In 2012 the then technocratic government led by Mario Monti, which came to power in late 2011 when Italy was threatened with losing financial market access at the height of the euro zone crisis, introduced a range of measures, including provisions to increase competition in retailing, taxi services, the sale of pharmaceuticals and utilities. The government also abolished minimum tariffs for several professions, including lawyers. In 2014-16 the Renzi govern-ment continued earlier progress in cutting red tape affecting businesses, stream-lining the complex tax system and, in particular, simplifying and reducing regulation of the Italian labour market. The introduction of reforms following the stress tests of the European Central Bank (ECB) in 2014 has reduced the influence of minority shareholder local charitable foundations in Italy's co-operative banks (banche popolari), paving the way for greater competition, consolidation and mergers. However, consolidation has been slow, owing to reticence to write down bad loans and new EU bail-in rules that require losses to be imposed on shareholders and junior bondholders, who are often retail investors, in return for government support.
Weak contract enforcement, few convictions for white-collar crime, and notoriously long court case backlogs will remain a prominent deterrent of foreign direct investment (FDI) and domestic business investment. A reform package passed by parliament included provisions extending prison sentences for some white-collar crimes such as bribery, and setting up support offices to reduce the backlog in Italy's Supreme Court. However, resistance to change is strong in the judiciary, which for example has found ways round a reduction in the number of days' holiday for judges from 45 to 32. Other important law reform proposals, such as extending the statute of limitations for serious crimes, have also been delayed owing to divisions in the governing coalition and resistance from the judiciary. With the next election due in early 2018 and political instability likely to continue after the vote, further major reforms are unlikely.
Further privatisations likely to be delayed until after the general election
Privatisation plans are likely to face continued delays partly for political reasons but also because market conditions will not always be favourable. In mid-2015 the Renzi government re-launched its privatisation plans to highlight Italy's openness to foreign investment and reduce the public debt. It resulted in the largest auction of a state asset in a decade-the sale of a 35% stake in the national post office and financial services group, Poste Italiane, for EUR3.4bn in October 2015-and the transfer of another 35% to the state investment fund, the Cassa Depositi e Prestiti (CDP). The sale of the remaining 30% has been subject to repeated delays, however, as has the mooted sale of a 40% stake in Ferrovie dello Stato, Italy's state-owned railway utility group. In 2016 revenue from privatisation amounted to 0.1% of GDP, well short of the government's target of 0.5% of GDP. Little progress is expected in 2017 ahead of the next general election, although the sale to the CDP of stakes in state-controlled firms such as the energy conglomerates, Eni and Enel, might go ahead to boost revenue.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The positive impact of economic reforms will only be felt incrementally
FDI inflows into Italy have generally been low compared with other similarly sized countries, including those such as France that have traditionally been seen as no more open than Italy. The main deterrents to FDI in Italy relate to complex bureaucratic and legal procedures, barriers to entry in areas of the services sector, inadequate infrastructure, high levels of taxation and energy costs, and labour market rigidities. Labour market reforms, modest business tax cuts and streamlining of Italy's complex tax system have begun to address some of these issues, resulting in an improvement in Italy's score and rankings in this category. However, given the economy's long-standing structural deficiencies, and the likelihood that the impact of recent reforms will be felt incrementally, inward FDI in Italy will continue to lag that in other large EU member states.
The collapse of the former state airline, Alitalia, in May 2017 highlights the difficulty of operating in Italy, even for major overseas investors such as Etihad, a UAE-based airline that bought a 49% stake in Alitalia in 2014. In April 2017 workers rejected a restructuring plan, causing much-needed financing from the airline's investors to fall through. The airline is now in the hands of three special administrators who have six months to sell the airline or liquidate it. A bridge loan from the government is keeping the carrier afloat in the meantime.
Judicial reforms introduced during 2014-16 should gradually improve contract enforcement, with signs that they are already reducing civil case backlogs. Legislation passed in 2015 should also encourage further financial sector consolidation, which could eventually attract FDI in the banking sector, although there has been no visible progress so far. The sale of banks' securitized bad loans to foreign investors has also been dogged by bureaucratic complexity. Although less ambitious than hoped for, anti-corruption legislation introduced since 2013 represents a further sign of intent to improve the operating environment for domestic and overseas investors.
Foreign takeovers, especially of Italian luxury goods brands likely to continue
Corporate balance sheets and the ability to raise capital were severely damaged by the 2011-14 economic downturn. As a result, a rising number of inter-nationally renowned Italian corporate brands such as Bulgari, Valentino and Loro Piana have been acquired by foreign companies in recent years, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors. An almost EUR50bn merger between an Italian luxury eyewear company, Luxottica, and a French lens manufacturer, Essilor, also took place in January 2017, with the merged firm to be listed in Paris, the French capital. Despite signs of concerns among some law-makers regarding foreign takeovers, the trend is likely to continue during the forecast period. As illustrated by the Fiat takeover of Chrysler in 2014 and the recent bid by the Italian road toll company, Atlantia, for its Spanish partner, Abertis, large Italian firms are seeking opportunities to invest abroad.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's EU membership determines the country's foreign trade and exchange policy. Full freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons exists within the EU (subject to transitional restrictions for newer member states), and we do not expect any exchange controls. Bilateral trade disputes between EU countries are resolved by the European Commission or, in extremis, the European Court of Justice (ECJ), the jurisprudence of which has played a major role in developing the single market. Compliance with judicial or other rulings within the EU is higher than in other regional trading blocs or the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Trade with Nordic neighbours Norway and Iceland is unrestricted under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). The EU has a customs union with Turkey and a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland. All these arrangements exclude agriculture.
In other sectors trade with non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. The EU takes a liberal approach to trade in industrial goods, with average unweighted most favoured nation tariffs, which cover most countries, at about 4%. Trade between member states and third countries has been largely gov-erned by multilateral agreements administered by the WTO. In 2015 the WTO reached an agreement on trade facilitation (reducing red tape at borders, and setting binding standards for customs and movement of goods internationally), but the Doha trade talks have stalled since 2008 and are unlikely to be revived.
The EU is increasingly looking to bilateral agreements to boost trade, such as the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) signed with Canada. However, the stalled EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) is unlikely to reach conclusion following the election of Donald Trump as US president.
Brexit to dominate EU trade agenda during 2017-19
The EU's trade agenda over the coming years is set to be dominated by negotiations with the UK, ahead of Britain's formal departure from the EU in 2019. Early signs suggest these Brexit negotiations could become acrimonious, which will decrease prospects for a satisfactory final agreement. As its third most important EU export market, Italy would be a major loser from failure to secure a satisfactory EU-UK free trade agreement.
Business environment outlook: Taxes

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's tax system remains highly complex so compliance is costly
Italy ranks second from last of our global ranking for taxation and bottom in our regional ranking during the forecast period. Notwithstanding some recent simplifications and streamlining, the tax system is highly complex, making compliance costly and time consuming for private-sector companies. Also, despite some modest tax cuts since 2014, the tax burden has remained high and is unlikely to decline much, owing to a substantial public debt burden and EU sovereign debt reduction requirements. According to Istat (the national statistics office), total tax revenue/GDP (including social security contributions) stood at 42.9% in 2016, only slightly lower than the previous year, but higher than the regional aggregates of about 40% for the EU and euro area.
According to Eurostat data, Italy has the highest implicit tax rate on labour in the EU (aggregate tax revenue from labour as a percentage of the potential tax base). This was 43.9% in 2014, more than six percentage points above the EU average, and more than 4 points higher than the euro area aggregate. However, at 18.1%, Italy's implicit tax rate on consumption in 2014 was about 2 percentage points lower than the regional average, highlighting this as an area to which fiscal tightening could be shifted from the excessive reliance on labour levies.
Despite promises to reduce levies in 2016-18, labour taxes will remain high
In addition to a corporate tax rate of 24%, businesses also pay a regional business tax (IRAP), which is levied at a standard rate of 3.9%, and a slightly higher rate for most financial institutions. However, the central government can raise the regional business tax rate as high as 4.4% in regions running budget deficits. Regions and municipalities also apply personal income surtaxes at varying rates to offset the impact of cuts in transfers from the central government, which have been an almost constant feature of budget adjustments in recent years. Despite the high tax burden, fiscal adjustment plans during the height of the euro zone crisis in 2010-13 tended to focus mainly on raising additional revenue rather than more politically sensitive spending cuts. The Renzi government introduced some tax cuts, but with government debt at more than 130% of GDP, the room for fiscal loosening was limited.
In July 2015 Mr Renzi announced plans for a programme of tax cuts of about EUR35bn in 2016-18. A reduction in levies on primary residences, affecting 80% of households, was included in the 2016 budget. A planned cut in the rate of corporate tax for non-financial corporations-by 3.5 percentage points, from 27.5% to 24%-was delayed by one year but has taken affect in 2017. Banks and most other financial sector firms, however, were excluded from the new tax cut and continue to pay the 27.5% rate. Although another reduction in personal income tax is scheduled to follow in the 2018 budget, this might be dependent on economic growth in 2017, and any changes in future fiscal policy will be dependent on the composition of Italy's post-election government in 2018.
Efforts to reduce tax evasion have had some success and are likely to continue
The determination with which tax evasion and avoidance has been tackled since 2006 appears to have had at least a temporarily positive effect on compliance. Tackling evasion was a priority of Mr Monti's government, and has remained so for subsequent administrations. A tough stance towards tax evasion will remain a priority for the current government, which has extended deadlines through 2017 for the voluntary submission of undeclared incomes and assets held abroad.
Business environment outlook: Financing

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's position in this category has slipped in both our global and regional rankings in the forecast period, largely reflecting the fact that reforms to address the Italian banking sector's weaknesses were delayed compared with other countries. Although the sector has begun a belated process of capital-raising, consolidation and restructuring, it continues to be weighed down by an exceptionally large stock of non-performing loans (NPLs), low levels of profitability and uncertainty about the quality of past supervision. However, bad loans declined in 2016 for the first year since the global financial crisis. Although financing conditions for banks and the sovereign have been stable for several years, partially owing to the ECB's bond purchasing programme (quantitative easing), benchmark ten-year government bond yields have widened since mid-2016. After several years of contraction or stagnation, bank credit to the private sector has expanded modestly since the beginning of 2016. The stabilisation in lending marks an important development for Italy's large number of small and medium-sized enterprises that rely largely on bank borrowing for financing.
Tighter monetary policy by the US Federal Reserve (the US central bank) and a gradual tapering of the ECB's quantitative easing (QE) programme from 2018 are likely to put upward pressure on government borrowing costs, which could also increase the cost of bank credit. Financial market volatility could also increase if, as we expect, political instability rises after the parliamentary election in early 2018.
The 2014 asset quality review highlighted the long-standing structural weaknesses associated with Italy's banking system, including the excessive influence of politically affiliated local charitable organisations within co-operative banks, which have restricted the banks' ability to raise capital and expand activities. In April 2016 new legislation took affect forcing the ten largest co-operative banks, with combined assets of about EUR500bn, to change their ownership structures and establish joint-stock companies by the end of 2016. By reducing the voting rights of minority local charitable foundations, whose interests are not purely commercial, the legislation enhanced the prospects for future banking consolidation. The merger of Banca Popolare di Milano (BPM) and Banco Popolare (BP) in January 2017 was the first major bank merger in Italy in a decade, creating the country's third-largest banking group by assets.
Despite the BPM-BP merger and recent reforms, efforts to repair Italy's banking system have been beset with difficulties, largely relating to new EU bail-in rules, which require losses to be imposed on shareholders and junior bondholders before government support can be granted. Although the state is ultimately likely to compensate small investors' losses, the bail-in rules have provided political capital for anti-establishment political parties and restricted government willingness to speed up bank resolutions.
UniCredit, Italy's largest bank by assets, held a successful EUR13bn rights issue in February 2017 following an earlier write-down of bad loans. Further capital-raising by Italian banks is expected in 2017-18, representing a major test of investor appetite in the Italian financial sector. Some banks, however, have been unable to raise sufficient funds, notably Monte dei Paschi di Siena (MPS), which is awaiting the approval of the European Commission and the ECB of its restructuring plans before it can receive support from the Italian state. The government has set aside EUR20bn to rescue banks such as MPS that are unable to raise sufficient funds on capital markets. The smaller Banca Popolare di Vicenza (BpVi) and Veneto Banca will also require state support.
Sale of NPLs will continue to lag other euro area economies
Gross NPLs totalling about EUR349bn at the end of 2016, largely consisting of non-financial corporation loans, remain one of the main challenges facing the Italian banking sector and wider economy. The introduction of a partial government guarantee on the sale of securities to third parties, and the purchase of riskier bad loan tranches by Atlante, a private equity fund financed mainly by domestic banks, but also by the state investment fund, CDP, to recapitalise weak lenders and purchase NPLs was designed to kick start the sale of NPLs. However, the complexity of the guarantee arrangement, Atlante's limited funds, difficulty pricing corporate bad loans and Italy's slow judicial system have resulted in no significant sales of securitised NPLs as of mid-2017. The sale of bad loans will continue to lag that in other euro area economies, which also have large stocks of legacy NPLs, such as Ireland and Spain.
Atlante has arguably increased systemic risk through purchases of distressed bank equity by stronger institutions, and it might also have delayed more radical but necessary banking sector reform.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
