Recent reforms have contributed to improving the labour market score in the forecast period, but Italy's positions in the global and regional rankings are unchanged. Although the Renzi government's Jobs Act legislative package passed in 2014-15 was a welcome development, long-standing rigidities are only set to decline gradually, as the main reforms only apply to new private-sector hires. The reforms have significantly weakened employment protection for long-term contracts. At the same time they have created a much simplified contract system for labour market entrants by introduc-ing a standard open-ended employment contract with gradually increasing protection. The reform also reduces restrictions on the use of easily terminated fixed-term contracts, which can now be used for up to 36 months rather than the previous 12 months and account for up to 20% of the workforce of an individual firm. The reform has increased the availability of unemployment benefits, streamlined the use of wage guarantee funds for temporary lay-offs or firm restructuring, and established a new national agency to monitor and co-ordinate the activities of all employment services providers.
Positive effect of the Jobs Act is only likely to be felt over the medium term
Reflecting the impact of a protracted recession, delayed reforms and weak economic recovery since late 2014, Italy's headline jobless rate remains high, at 11.7% in March 2017, compared with the euro area average of 9.5%. The youth unemployment rate was 34.1%-the third-highest in the euro area and well above the 19.4% euro area average. Despite some recent improvement, Italian labour market participation remains low, particularly among women and young people. According to Eurostat, Italy's employment rate was 57.4% in the fourth quarter of 2016, compared with the euro area average of 65.8%. The female employment rate was 48.3%, compared with 60.7% in the euro area.
Unions and employers appear to be no closer to agreeing on the compre-hensive implementation of a wage bargaining system that puts greater emphasis on firm-level negotiations to ensure that wage increases are tied to productivity gains. Greater use of second-level (plant) agreements would allow Italy to regain some of its lost export competitiveness, which has accompanied a decade of flat productivity growth and moderately rising wages. Such measures would also address regional disparities in productivity, and boost job-creation prospects in poorer southern regions where structural unemployment is most prevalent.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure quality in the south will continue to lag the rest of the country
As reflected in its unchanged score and the decline in its regional and global rankings, the quality of Italy's infrastructure is set to remain below the average of other developed countries during the forecast period. A significant disparity between the north and the south of the country will also continue. Budgetary constraints have limited public investment in the past 25-30 years, and local interest groups have succeeded in blocking or delaying several major projects in the transport and energy sectors. Corruption investigations are another relatively common reason for delays. Telecoms costs have fallen and device ownership has risen, along with internet use and broadband penetration, but Italy continues to lag most other developed countries in these markets.
Budgetary constraints will remain a major stumbling block to future government capital spending projects over the forecast period. In 2014-16 the Renzi government was a vocal proponent of relaxing EU fiscal rules to boost public capital investment projects. However, Italy used the limited room for fiscal manoeuvre mainly for tax cuts rather than infrastructure investment.
Infrastructure projects were expected to benefit greatly from the EUR315bn invest-ment plan put forward by the European Commission and the European Invest--ment Bank in late 2014. However, two years since it became operational, little funding has found its way to the EU or Italian infrastructure projects, and a large number of projects that have formally had funding approved have yet to start.
Fiscal consolidation will hold back public investment in infrastructure
Investment is likely to be mainly focused on improving the current rail, ports, motorway and other transport networks across the country. However, as resources are limited, few major improvements are likely to materialise during the forecast period. The 2017 budget law extended modest cuts in regional business taxes for some public construction projects and a new tax credit for research and development (R&D) investment. Resources are available for earthquake-hit areas, which will include infrastructure reconstruction projects, although similar schemes have proven disappointing in the past.
Limited domestic energy sources and popular opposition to the development of nuclear-power generation will continue to cause uncertainty about security and diversification of supply. Poor infrastructure in energy distribution is likely to keep upward pressure on costs. Investment will also continue to face strong local resistance.
In 2016 fixed-line broadband penetration reached an estimated 55% of house-holds, compared with an EU average of 74%. However, above-average mobile-phone penetration rates and the rapid take-up of smartphones and high-speed mobile contracts could explain some, or even all, of the gap. We expect the fixed-line broadband penetration rate to rise to about 30% by 2021, by which time almost all subscriptions are likely to be broadband connections.
Government efforts to accelerate investment in fibre-to-the-home (FTTH) networks providing high-speed internet access will make gradual progress. Central to the government's plans has been the metropolitan fibre-optic operator, Metroweb, which in December 2016 merged with a subsidiary of Enel, the state controlled energy utility, to form Open Fiber. Open Fiber, which is now jointly owned by Enel and CDP, plans to build FTTH networks in 250 cities in Italy by 2030, investing EUR3.7bn in the development of the network, 85% of this by 2021.
Economic forecast: Policy trends

The political uncertainty that has taken hold since the referendum in December 2016 has increased the potential for financial volatility, and could disrupt the current fragile economic recovery and further delay structural reforms, at least in the short term. We believe that the European Central Bank (ECB) will have sufficient tools at its disposal to contain any financial market turmoil. However, weakened investor confidence could disrupt efforts to repair the weaknesses in Italy's banking system-high operating costs, low profitability, a EUR349bn burden of non-performing loans at end-2016 and uncertainty about the quality of supervision-and cause already depressed bank shares to slide further. The referendum vote derailed the government-endorsed private-sector rescue plan for Italy's third-largest bank, Monte dei Paschi di Siena (MPS). The government and the bank are now engaged in talks with the European Commission and the ECB regarding plans for a precautionary recapitalisation of MPS, which requires about EUR8.8bn in fresh funding, according to the ECB. The uncertainty about MPS has had negative knock-on effects for several smaller beleaguered lenders that also need to attract private capital to increase their capital buffers. In contrast, UniCredit, Italy's largest bank, which completed a massive capital raising operation in March 2017 on the back of an ambitious restructuring plan, will not require assistance from the state.
Reforms to the labour market, the judicial system and the public administration that have been introduced in recent years are likely to have a positive effect on growth performance, but only over the medium term. However, there is a risk that some aspects of these reforms will be diluted or reversed in the next parliament.

The Renzi government used the little room for manoeuvre that it had, arising from low interest rates on government debt and some "fiscal flexibility" granted by the EU for structural reforms, to try to support economic growth without breaching the EU-wide deficit limit of 3% of GDP. Following a shortfall of 2.4% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to remain broadly unchanged in 2017-18, as political constraints and an impending general election make any bolder efforts at fiscal consolidation difficult. From 2019 we forecast that the deficit will widen gradually to close to 3% by 2021 as interest payments rise once again, offsetting solid primary surpluses of 2% of GDP per year. We expect that the government debt/GDP ratio peaked in 2016, at 132.5%, and that it will decline only marginally to around 130% at end-2021.

Despite heightened political risk, the euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and a EUR60bn per month quantitative easing (QE) programme, which will run until the end of 2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, stressed that the reduction in the pace of QE (from EUR80bn per month in March) was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period, and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.

Despite our expectation that political instability will persist beyond the end of the current parliamentary term, we expect that domestic demand growth will continue to sustain the moderate economic recovery that began in 2014. Following real GDP growth of 1% in 2016, we expect that the economy will expand by 0.9% in 2017 (revised up from 0.8% previously), as weak consumer sentiment, concerns about instability in the banking sector and uncertainty about external conditions dampen economic activity. In 2018-21 we forecast that real GDP growth will average 0.9% per year.
We expect the boost to household disposable income and consumption from modest tax cuts and low oil prices to diminish in 2017, slowing private consump-tion growth this year. Fragile consumer sentiment, reflecting political instability, concern about the impact on savings of protracted difficulties in the banking sector and modest employment growth will continue to hold back private consumption growth, which we forecast to average 0.8% per year in 2017-21.

We expect that the return to public consumption growth in 2016 after five consecutive years of contraction will be sustained in 2017-21. We expect the pace of expansion to remain modest, however, driven by the need to control the budget deficit.
Owing to public investment cuts, weak business sentiment and difficulty accessing bank credit, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, fixed investment at end-2015 was almost 30% below its level prior to the 2008-09 global crisis. Fixed investment returned to growth in 2015-16, but we expect growth to be moderate in 2017-21, held back by domestic demand constraints and risks to external demand. The need to replace ageing machinery and equipment, the extension of tax incentives, post-earthquake reconstruction and a gradual easing of access to credit should prevent further contractions during the forecast period.
We expect the slowdown in exports of goods and services growth in 2016 to continue in 2017-19, reflecting uncertainty in the EU and emerging markets in 2017, a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019. A modest acceleration should get under way in 2020-21. Reflecting moderate domestic demand growth and external demand constraints, we expect import growth to outpace that of exports during most of the forecast period.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Reflecting the severe impact on the industrial sector of the 2008-o9 global crisis and the subsequent ongoing euro area crisis, industry (excluding construction) accounted for about 20% of employment in 2016, down from 22.1% in 2007, and 19.3% of nominal gross value added, compared with 20.5% of gross value added in 2007. The manufacturing sector has long been the main strength of the Italian economy, especially Italy's family-owned, small and medium-sized export-oriented companies specialising in products that require high-quality design and engineering. However, the sector faces major challenges owing to Italy's structural problems, the uncertainties arising from the euro zone crisis and uncertainty about the global economic outlook caused by the UK's decision to leave EU and our expectation of a sharp slowdown in China in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019.
Italian industry faces major challenges owing to structural deficiencies
In 2016 manufacturing accounted for 16.3% of gross value added, down from 17.8% in 2007 and 20.3% in 1997. The sector's decline has largely been driven by the prolonged weakness of domestic demand, but also by the difficulties that Italian exporters face in remaining competitive within the European single currency area. Unit labour costs have remained well above the euro area average since 2005 and have continued to rise in Italy since 2010, whereas they have fallen in other peripheral euro area economies such as Spain, Greece, Ireland and Portugal. Weak competitiveness and further transfers of low-value-added production out of Italy are likely to lead to a further decline in manufacturing's contribution to the economy during the forecast period.
The automotive industry is one of the flagship sectors of Italian industry. It accounts for about 8% of GDP, almost one-quarter of the contribution from all manufacturing industries and about 10% of the total value of Italian exports. Fiat (Fabbrica Italiana Automobili Torino), which was renamed Fiat-Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) in 2014 after merging with a US-based producer, is the dominant producer in Italy, but the sector also comprises hundreds of firms that manufacture components or provide related services.
After declining in 2008-13, vehicle production in Italy picked up by 6% in 2014, 45% in 2015 and 8.8% in 2016, to reach 1.1m units, approaching 2007 levels. The fall in 2008-13 reflected the impact of the global economic crisis on demand in Italy and in export markets, as well as the transfer of production to lower-cost countries. A recovery in domestic and external demand drove the rise in output in 2014, whereas the double-digit increase in 2015 was largely driven by the addition of two new models to the FCA's production line at the Melfi factory in southern Italy. The drop in Italian production affected passenger-car output disproportionately. In 2013 passenger-car output was more than 70% lower than in 2000. Following a modest increase of 3% in 2014, Italian passenger-car production rose by 65% in 2015 and 7.5% in 2016.
We expect car registrations in Italy to decline by 4.5% in 2017 as political and economic uncertainty in Italy continue and rising inflation starts to eat into real wages. The decline in sales will also be driven by higher year-on-year comparisons. We forecast that growth will return only gradually, averaging about 3% in 2018-21. Commercial vehicle sales are also forecast to decline in 2017, by about 4%, and rise by 5.5% on average in 2018-21.
Fiat's strategy to become a major global producer through mergers, acquisitions and alliances abroad is proving challenging and will probably not boost production in Italy, even if it is successful. Given Italy's high labour costs and other difficulties of doing business in the country, the recent trend of shifting automotive production out of Italy is likely to continue, despite FCA's repeated promise to increase domestic production. Fiat now produces about two-thirds of its vehicles abroad, in China, Brazil, Turkey, Russia, Serbia, Poland and elsewhere. It closed its Termini Imerese plant in Sicily at the end of 2011 and began producing cars at a new plant in Serbia in the first half of 2012. Integration with Chrysler could also result in more production being transferred to plants outside Italy. Following an agreement with the trade unions to introduce more flexible working practices and boost productivity and output at its plant at Pomigliano d'Arco, near Naples, the company transferred production of one of its models from Poland at the beginning of 2012. However, production at the plant was interrupted or reduced at various times during the economic crisis, when demand in the Italian and wider European car markets contracted.
Manufacturing sector performance will depend on the speed of the reforms
In the medium term, the performance of the manufacturing sector will depend largely on the implementation of reforms to tackle Italy's structural deficiencies. These include issues such as a lack of competition, particularly in the non­tradeable services sectors and utilities, which has meant that companies in Italy pay high prices for domestically produced inputs, such as electricity, compared with competitors elsewhere. The predominance of small companies and their lack of investment in areas such as innovation and research and development (R&D) has prevented them from moving up the value-added chain. There are about 450,000 manufacturing companies in Italy, about 98% of which employ fewer than 50 people. Firms with fewer than ten employees account for about 8o% of the total.
Italian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are often aggregated within sector-specific industrial districts, which, through a combination of co-operation and competition, help to mitigate the impact of the difficulties arising from a lack of expansion. According to the Edison Foundation, a think-tank that monitors 99 industrial districts, exports from the industrial districts fell sharply in euro terms in 2009, but have risen strongly since the beginning of 2010, and previously marginal hi-tech districts have increased their weighting in the index as they have outperformed the overall index and Italy's traditional low-tech manufacturing sectors such as clothing and textiles, and home furniture.
Italian SMEs have begun to consolidate under the pressure of intense competition and the global crisis. However, the availability of domestic funds to support mergers or recapitalisations to start new projects is likely to be curtailed by the need to reduce the government debt burden. This has contributed to a rising number of internationally renowned Italian corporate brands being acquired by foreign companies in recent years, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors. Global designer brands such as Bulgari, Valentino and Lora Piana have been sold to foreign groups, and as of mid­2014 Indesit, Italy's main manufacturer of white goods, is no longer majority Italian owned. This trend is likely to continue during the forecast period.
Construction sector activity is likely to remain subdued in 2016-20
Activity in the construction sector accounted for 4.8% of gross value added in 2016, unchanged from 2015, but down from an annual average of 6% of gross value added in 2006-09, and 6.2% of employment in 2016, compared with 8.6% in 2007. After nine full-year contractions, which left output in the sector about a third below its 2006 peak in real terms, the decline appeared to bottom out in the final quarter of 2014, but activity is likely to remain subdued during the forecast period, reflecting the impact of an eight-year decline in property prices up to 2016. Ongoing corruption investigations involving public works contracts and large government spending cuts are also likely to dampen activity. Various governments have sought to accelerate EU co-financed infrastructure invest-ment plans to provide some support to the sector, but little progress is likely to be made, largely owing to delays at the regional and ministerial levels.
Already accounting for almost 74% of gross value added, the services sector is expected to expand broadly in line with subdued average real GDP growth during the forecast period. Those subsectors that are exposed to foreign competition, such as tourism, are likely to struggle, although a weaker euro during the first half of the forecast period and security concerns in several competitor markets could help. Sectors that serve mainly the domestic market and have so far enjoyed a high level of protection from competition, such as the professions and retailing, will come under pressure as a result of reforms to reduce barriers to entry, but this is likely to be only gradual. High-value­added services sectors, such as design, which are closely tied to clothing, textiles and automotives, Italy's main export sectors, should continue to perform well, even though in some sectors production is increasingly being moved abroad to countries where labour costs are lower.

We expect the markedly improved current-account balance since 2012 to persist in 2017-21, driven mainly by continued low international energy prices and moderate domestic demand growth. We forecast that slightly higher commodity prices and moderate external demand growth will gradually reduce the surplus, from an average of 2.5% of GDP per year in 2017-18 to 1.8% in 2021.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Italy
Stocks and flows
Net inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows are low compared with most other EU countries, and Italy has generally been a net exporter of FDI. Net inflows to Italy picked up to US$34.4bn in 2011 (1.5% of GDP), from about US$10bn (0.5% of GDP) in 2010, but declined again to close to zero in 2012, owing to large disinvestments. Net inflows recovered moderately in 2013-15, averaging US$16.5bn per year (0.8% of GDP). We estimate that inward FDI rose to US$26.5bn in 2016, the equivalent of 1.4% of GDP. Italy attracts less green-field foreign investment than other large European economies. The total stock of FDI was US$457bn in 2015, compared with about US$800bn in France and about one-third of that in the UK and Germany. In relation to GDP, the stock of FDI was 25% in 2015, compared with 22.9% in 2014, lower than in any other EU country apart from Greece. FDI outflows have also generally been quite small, mainly reflecting the prevalence of small and medium-sized companies in Italy. In 2005-09 Italy recorded substantial outward FDI flows as a result of several major investments abroad in the banking and energy sectors. A similarly large outflow, of about US$52bn, was recorded in 2011, the year that Italian car manufacturer Fiat (Fabbrica Italiana Automobili Torino) bought the US Treasury's remaining stake in Chrysler.
Origin and distribution
FDI from Europe accounts for about 60-65% of company revenue and employment generated by foreign companies with operations in Italy. Companies from North America represent about 25-30% of revenue and employment, and those from Japan for about 3-4%. The manufacturing sector contributed about 40% of the total revenue and value added of foreign­owned firms, but this has generally been on a downward path and dropped sharply in 2005, when General Motors (US) sold its stake in Fiat. The utilities and telecommunications sectors have registered the most rapid expansion.
Determinants
The main attraction for foreign companies to set up operations in Italy is the size of the domestic market, which offers a population of about 6om and average GDP per head of US$38,5oo, at purchasing power parity (PPP). Deterrents include the complexity of Italy's legal system, inefficiencies in public administration, inadequate infrastructure-particularly in the south of the country-and often high regulatory barriers to entry, especially in services sectors. In addition, studies of the determinants of FDI in southern Italy have highlighted classical deterrents to investment, such as distance from major European markets, low presence of other foreign companies and a high level of organised crime. Such studies seem to indicate that fiscal incentives and the presence of specialised producer service providers have a low impact on foreign entrants' decisions, but that human capital is an important positive variable. Italy has an abundant workforce in the south, which has attracted a few high-technology investments to areas such as Catania in Sicily, where a Franco-Italian joint venture, ST Microelectronics, has a production plant and several research centres.
Impact
According to the industry association, Confindustria, foreign-controlled companies employ more than 1m people in Italy and generate revenue of about EUR5oobn per year. Foreign companies invest on average three and half times more in research and development (R&D) than Italian companies. However, because of the comparatively low level of inflows and their concentration in the north of Italy, the impact of FDI on the Italian economy as a whole has been limited. The depressed areas of the south, which attract limited Italian private-sector investment, would benefit substantially in terms of employment and through the spillover effect of advanced technology, management practices and production processes. However, almost all of the inward FDI stock is located in the north and centre of the country. Despite massive state investment in 1950-84, the south has continued to lag central Italy and the north in GDP per head terms (less than 55% of the average in the centre and north). The unemployment rate in the south is almost double the national average and about two and a half times higher than that in the north.
Potential
The possibility of higher FDI inflows in the forecast period will be hampered by the uncertainty caused by the euro zone crisis and the fact that most of the factors that have deterred FDI in the past will remain in place. A slight improvement is expected in the efficiency of the public administration, as a result of recent and ongoing reforms. The performance of the state body responsible for attracting foreign investors may also improve. Given Italy's need to reduce its dependence on imported energy, there could be potential for investment in the still state-dominated energy sector as liberalisation continues to make progress and the authorities are forced to focus on investment in renewable energy sources, following the decision in mid-2011 to abandon plans to return to nuclear-power generation. Despite the current government's openness to foreign investors, political opposition to foreign interest in ownership of utility networks and possibly even some companies in the manufacturing sector is likely to continue, as such companies are deemed to be of a "strategic" nature. Banking sector reforms may increase opportunities for foreign investment in smaller Italian banks, but there appears to be limited interest at present.

Italy is a major market, but growth potential remains limited
Italy is one of the largest markets in Europe, with a population of just under 60m, and is one of its most affluent nations. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth prospects.
In 2015 the economy began to emerge from a protracted recession. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the recovery to continue during the forecast period (2017-21) but domestic demand growth will remain subdued, given high unemployment, weak business investment, the ongoing need for fiscal consolidation in Italy and elsewhere in the developed world, high taxation and moderate wage growth.
In terms of private consumption per head, Italy is more or less on a par with the euro area average, but well below Finland, Sweden, France and Germany. However, the relative weakness of Italian economic growth for much of the past 15-20 years means that GDP per head-at purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion rates that explicitly adjust for differences in price levels between countries-has fallen steadily as a percentage of the EU28 average, remaining below 100% since 2013. GDP per head at PPP rates stood at US$38,504 in 2015.
Income levels differ greatly on a regional basis, with GDP per head in the south less than 55% of that in the centre and the north. Development policies in the past 50 years have done little to close the gap, and no significant change is expected.

Despite relatively high income levels, spending on food, beverages and tobacco is still high as a share of total consumer spending, at about 18%-similar to the level in France but above that in Germany and the Netherlands (about 15%), and the UK (just under 13%). We expect it to decline only gradually during the forecast period, largely because of subdued spending on other categories of goods and services.
Consumer credit demand has begun to rise, after several years of stagnation and/or contraction. Household indebtedness is relatively low and interest rates on consumer loans have declined and are expected to rise only moderately in 2017-21, containing the proportion of disposable income spent on debt servicing. Still, we expect only moderately stronger demand for big-ticket items and branded goods, as consumers are likely to postpone purchases until sen-timent improves further and risks to the recovery diminish. Rates of ownership of traditional consumer durable goods, such as white goods and passenger cars, are generally high, so demand will be driven by technological change and the need to replace ageing stock.
Demand for electronic goods, such as computers (especially laptops and tablets) and smartphones, has shown a tendency to outperform the rest of the consumer goods market. Growth will be driven by innovations such as smartphones, tablet computers and, more recently, wearable technology. However, weak income growth will dampen demand. Personal computer (PC) ownership lags well behind countries such as the UK, Germany and France, where the penetration rate is about 90%, compared with about 65% in Italy; however, much of the gap is expected to have been closed by the end of the forecast period.
The ageing population will drive growth in healthcare spending
Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns. The ageing population will continue to drive overall healthcare spending, but we expect efforts to curb public healthcare expenditure to meet budgetary targets.
Italians tend to live at home with their parents, often until their mid-thirties. Thus, a larger portion of the disposable income of those aged 18-35 has tended to be spent on leisure and consumer goods than in other countries, although this trend is likely to be offset by low salaries for many young people who have work and one of the highest youth unemployment rates (among the 15-24 age group) in Europe, despite declining gradually in recent years. In March 2017 it was 34.1%, down from a peak of 44% in March 2014-almost double pre-crisis levels in 2007-08.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Initial conditions: Italy's economic growth performance has been poor in the past two decades, even in comparison with the sluggish average rate of growth achieved by core countries within the EU. Besides undergoing severe fiscal consolidation during the 1990s in order to join the euro area, which dampened growth in that decade, the Italian economy has suffered from a steady loss of competitiveness owing to low productivity growth and rising unit labour costs (reflecting falling output, despite wage moderation since 1993)-in contrast to the situation in its main trading partners.
The weakness of Italy's political and institutional framework policy hinders policy formulation, as reforms are frequently delayed or watered down under pressure from a wide range of interest groups. Italy's public finances also remain weak, limiting the scope to reduce taxation or stimulate demand during cyclical downturns. Major brakes on Italy's long-term growth will be the country's unfavourable demographic profile, low labour participation rates, a collapse in fixed investment during the recent recession, and low levels of investment in research and development (R&D).
Italy's demographic profile will be the main brake on long-term growth
Demographic trends: Italy's demographic profile is particularly unfavourable. Projected net immigration is expected to be insufficient to halt the continued decline in the population of working age in the long-term forecast period up to 2050. Italy's labour market participation rate is expected to rise from current low levels of about 65%, but only moderately, reflecting an increase in the number of women joining the workforce and a gradual rise in the minimum retirement age, but it will remain well below the OECD average (about 71% in 2015) and will be insufficient to prevent an annual average decline in the labour force of 0.5% in 2017-50.
External conditions: The effects of the global crisis of 2008-09 and the height of the euro area crisis in 2010-13 will be felt for years. The risk that the sovereign debt crisis in financially stressed peripheral countries in the euro area, including Italy, could lead to a partial or even complete break-up of the single currency area, which would have severe negative consequences for Italy's long-term economic prospects, has eased, but The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that it is more likely than not (6o%) that Greece will leave the euro area by 2020. Even without Greece in the euro area, the euro zone member states are still a long way from resolving the structural shortcomings of the single currency area.
Italian companies have generally been slow to adapt to the rigours of fixed exchange rates in the euro area and the increase in competition from goods produced in low-cost developing countries, although some traditional manufacturing sectors have undergone restructuring in recent years, notably textiles and clothing, and also automotive. This difficulty seems unlikely to change in the medium to long term. In the past, clusters of family-owned small and medium-sized export-oriented manufacturing companies located in the so­called industrial districts in the north and centre of the country showed greater flexibility and ability to adapt to changing external conditions than Italy's few large companies. However, more recently they have struggled to compete in some low- to medium-technology sectors. This is attributed variously to the lack of investment in R&D and innovation and marketing, as well as to difficulties in protecting and promoting the generic ''Made in Italy" brand, which has long been considered synonymous with good quality and style. To survive, Italian companies will have to expand in size and increasingly outsource low-value-added production to locations in central and eastern Europe and Asia, where costs-especially labour costs-are lower. The reluctance to relinquish control will hinder the expansion of family-owned businesses, which also often face difficult choices in terms of management succession.
With institutional change off the agenda, economic reform will be slow
Institutions and policy trends: Italy's poor growth performance has raised concerns among policymakers about the country's future economic prospects. Policy responses triggered by such debates in the past have generally been short lived. Some reforms have been introduced since the financial turmoil of late 2011. However, popular and political resistance to reform halted the Renzi government's attempt to overhaul Italy's institutional framework in 2014-16, taking institutional change off the political agenda for the foreseeable future. Without a substantial improvement in its political and institutional framework, Italy's efforts to carry out reforms will continue to lag the rapid pace of change in the world economy and the increase in competition.
In particular, Italy will need further liberalisation of its product and services markets, although recent reforms, if they are not reversed-a possibility that cannot be ruled out-should help to reduce labour market rigidities over the medium to long term. A more comprehensive system of unemployment protection envisaged under the 2012 and 2014 reforms could help to enhance labour mobility, but there may be a lack of resources without more drastic cuts in public spending on pensions, which is projected to ease from a peak of about 16% of GDP in 2013-14 to about 15.5% in 2030, according to the Treasury (before rising again over the subsequent decade and falling again more sharply in the decade to 2050). To raise long-term productivity growth, the country will also have to improve the quality of human capital. Recent education reforms have sought to address shortcomings in the education system, including high drop-out rates and mismatches between the skills needed by employers and qualifications held by potential employees.
A more favourable policy environment would boost long-term growth
Long-term performance: Our baseline forecast is that Italian GDP growth will average 0.5% per year in 2017-50, which is considerably weaker than what was until recently considered to be Italy's trend rate of growth (1.5%). The main brake on long-term growth will be an unfavourable demographic profile, which will be offset only partly by expected moderate improvements in labour productivity and technological infrastructure. Other industrialised countries will continue to grow faster than Italy, and so it will fall further behind in terms of GDP per head, which in the decade to 2015 fell from 109% of the EU28 average to 96%. In addition, decades of massive public-sector spending have done little to narrow the large income gap between the more developed centre and north of Italy and the south of the country. This imbalance is expected to continue to weigh on Italy's overall growth performance in the long term. A more favourable political environment could produce a better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improvements in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is limited.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text:   Nigeria--highlights: Political outlook
The government will largely fail to achieve its promises of tackling corruption, improving stability and boosting living standards. A period of significantly lower oil revenue will hinder the government's ability to boost development, particularly of infrastructure. As a result, high levels of poverty and unemployment will combine with the country's ethnic and religious divisions to create a potent mixture that will spill over into outbreaks of violence. Nevertheless, Nigeria has a high tolerance for political instability and so there is little significant threat to the government's position outside of the election cycle, even if the president were forced to leave office early owing to his ill health-a growing likelihood.

The population growth rate will remain high enough to retain a relatively stable age profile. However, the formal economy will not grow quickly enough to provide the employment needed to absorb the estimated 2m Nigerians entering the jobs market each year. This will jeopardise attempts to reduce poverty. Furthermore, high numbers of poor young unemployed will be a fertile recruiting ground for militant groups, thus prolonging violent instability in large parts of the country.
Nigeria--highlights: Business environment outlook

The business environment in Nigeria is unlikely to improve significantly over the forecast period. Even if progress is made, it will often be at a slower rate than in the country's peers. Systemic problems in infrastructure and the labour market mean that Nigeria remains towards the bottom of The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment global rankings for the forecast period, at 78th out of 82 countries. On a regional basis, Nigeria is ranked 15th out of 17 countries for the forecast period. Efforts to create a more attractive business environment are likely to produce only modest results owing to the slow pace of structural reform, the ongoing problem of corruption, the absence of effective government institutions and the weak capacity of the civil service to implement changes. Some improvements in infrastructure are expected over the forecast period, albeit from a very low base, as telecommunications infrastructure and ports (both benefiting from private-sector involvement) improve. However, power and much transport infrastructure will remain weak.

While Nigeria will escape the recession of 2016, economic growth will remain well below historic averages in 2017-21. Trends in the oil sector and elections in 2019 will have a negative impact on the economy. Inflation will spike in 2017, amid currency depreciation, but will then subside gradually amid tight monetary policy and weaker commodity prices. Economic policymakers will struggle to counter strong demand for increases in spending from the legis-lature and state-level governments, given pressing development needs. Set against this, oil sector revenue is likely to underperform, and so a fiscal deficit of around 2.5% of GDP will persist. The current account will be close to balance after decades of large surpluses, amid weak oil export revenue and strong import demand to fuel infrastructure development and growing consumer spending.

Nigeria remains an important market for many multinationals because of its abundant natural resources and the size of its population-the largest in Africa-despite the very low level of income among the majority of the population. However, the relatively large wealthy elite and growing middle class make up important submarkets. Nigeria is potentially a profitable market for multinational companies that know how to operate in its complex and chaotic regulatory environment and can overcome the logistical difficulties posed by the almost non-existent infrastructure, for example by providing their own power and water supplies.

Nigeria's long-term economic performance will pick up moderately, driven by gradual improvements in infrastructure provision. Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960 and the army soon became the dominant political player. Multiparty democracy was restored in 1999. That presidential poll and the next one, in 2003, were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in the 2015 presidential election-the first time an incumbent had been defeated at the ballot box and an important step forward for the country's democracy.
Political structure: Under the constitution, adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties dominate the political process. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the only political party to attract nationwide support, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015. Although the 36 state governments enjoy significant autonomy, almost all remain dependent on the federal government for funding.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. Meanwhile, the government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, as efforts to promote exchange-rate stability worsen hard-currency shortages.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. Tax compliance is a time-consuming process.
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 has wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by an overvalued exchange rate and massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Muhammadu Buhari-a former military dictator turned civilian politician-became president at the 2015 presidential election, while his All Progressives Congress (APC) swept to power at the concurrent legislative election. The ascension to power of Mr Buhari and the APC ended the 16-year rule of the People's Democratic Party (PDP). The APC also won power in the majority of state-level governments. Furthermore, the APC retained its hold on Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital, which meant that for the first time since 1999 the administrator of this important state was from the same party as the president. The cabinet must contain representatives from each of Nigeria's 36 states, although very few are elected politicians. Mr Buhari and his ministers are scrutinised by an elected, two-chamber National Assembly. State governments enjoy considerable autonomy under governors and elected state assemblies.

The APC is far from a united entity, however. It is an amalgamation of the three largest former opposition parties and a faction of a fourth (all with separate geographic and ethnic power bases, as well as varying ideologies), along with PDP defectors. Political appointments in numerous instances have, therefore, been based on distributing the vestiges of power among the APC's constituent elements rather than merit. This has been relatively successful in maintaining party backing for Mr Buhari, but large cracks are appearing-and are expected to widen-as the administration struggles to turn around Nigeria's struggling economy.
Political outlook: Political stability
Slow progress on tackling the various security and societal challenges at a time of economic difficulty means that The Economist Intelligence Unit expects repeated outbreaks of instability throughout the forecast period. Risks are heightened by the ongoing uncertainty over the health of the president, Muhammadu Buhari, who has spent much of early 2017 in the UK on medical grounds. Were Mr Buhari to suddenly leave office, we would expect him to be replaced by his vice-president, Yemi Osinbajo, for the remainder of his term (which expires in 2019). This is stipulated in the constitution and would replicate the situation in 2010 when the then vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, was promoted following the death of the then president, Umaru Yar'Adua. However, the transfer of power would bring with it a tense period as lines of patronage are broken and re-established, not least because of the move from a northern president to a southern one, an important and often fraught geopolitical divide in Nigeria. Such a period would distract policymakers at a time of significant economic and security challenges in Nigeria. Indeed, public resentment at the administration's failure to improve the economy or tackle corruption has already led to street protests in 2017. Nevertheless, democracy is entrenched in Nigeria to such a degree that a rise in political acrimony or public protests during the forecast period would not be likely to topple the government-or prompt the army to attempt to step in and take power. However, it would further disrupt business activity, negatively affect investor perceptions and hinder the economy.
Meanwhile, it will prove impossible to bring a permanent peace to large parts of Nigeria hit variously by Islamist insurgency in the north (which is increasing the risk of a major famine there with agricultural production decimated), ethno-nationalism in the main oil-producing region, secessionism in the region known as Biafra and inter-religious tensions across the centre of the country. The Nigerian authorities will periodically publicise advances made against insurgents, but we expect sporadic violent outbreaks to continue over the forecast period. The challenge facing the government remains that of building a more effective counterterrorism infrastructure while also repairing the damage to infrastructure and economic productivity that has devastated economic opportunities in many parts of the country and pushed some Nigerians towards militancy. However, efforts to improve military capacity or local infrastructure will take years, so the government will continue to look for shorter-term solutions. The solutions it is able to offer (including pay-offs, training or jobs for those renouncing violence) will be undermined by the authorities' difficult financial predicament. Furthermore, even if the government is able to direct more resources towards steering Nigerians away from militancy, this is only likely to encourage others to take up violence as a way to access official largesse.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Institutional effectiveness will remain poor in Nigeria. The National Assembly is very slow at moving through new legislation, owing both to inefficiency and to tensions between the executive and legislative branches of government. With the APC largely a coalition of convenience, competing ideologies and priorities will continue to hinder the legislative process, as will tensions over how to handle Mr Buahri's ill health, policy direction and spending priorities between the federal government and powerful state governors. Finally, vested political interests, inefficiency and corruption have slowed reform in Nigeria for decades, and these issues are unlikely to change in the forecast period.
Corruption will prove impossible to tackle comprehensively
Nigeria traditionally boasts a relatively strong economic team, led by able technocrats generally in favour of structural reform. Mr Buhari and the APC have maintained this practice, given the need to bolster confidence among international investors and lenders. However, as always, the team's capacity to translate good intentions into action will be hampered by Nigeria's complex political environment, entrenched rent-seeking interest groups and weak administrative system. Despite some reforms of the civil service-including the removal of so-called ghost workers by the new administration-the public sector will remain overstaffed, highly bureaucratic and largely ineffective, given internal resistance to reform and a lack of desire among the leadership to upset deep-seated patronage networks and finely balanced factions within the APC. Although considerable progress has been made in strengthening institutional capacity to check more blatant forms of corruption, rent-seeking officials and politicians have found more subtle ways to defraud the Treasury, with continued corrosive effects on politics and economic management. Nigeria was ranked 136th out of 198 countries in Transparency International's 2016 Corruption Perceptions Index, and is expected to remain towards the bottom of the rankings throughout the forecast period.
Fighting corruption has long been a government priority-and is a key priority for Mr Buhari-but the administration's efforts are likely to yield limited results. In a nation where many members of the ruling elite, including politicians and senior military officers, display wealth that is beyond what could be acquired on their official salaries, structural deficiencies (including inadequate checks and balances) mean that graft will remain a problem despite the periodic headline-grabbing arrests. In addition, allegations of political score-settling are often levelled at the authorities in their anti-corruption efforts-something that will stoke acrimony and prevent greater co-operation across the political, legal and social spheres. Meanwhile, the judicial system is still deeply undermined by corruption and hugely underfunded. This has resulted in poor administration of justice, including long delays in the hearing of cases.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next national elections are due in 2019. The ruling All Progressives Congress (APC)-an awkward amalgamation of former opposition parties-will enter the next election period riven by factional in-fighting. We expect the party to remain just about intact for the elections, given that access to power is a strong unifying factor, but a split ahead of the polls is a distinct risk. An additional risk is that Mr Buhari will either decide not to stand for re-election given health concerns, or face an internal challenge for the APC's candidacy. Were Mr Buhari to leave office sooner, leaving Mr Osinbajo serving as president in 2019, there would also probably be a divisive struggle within the APC to agree on a single presidential candidate; Mr Osinbajo would not be the automatic choice, especially in the party's influential northern caucus.
The former ruling party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP), also suffers from serious internal ructions and will struggle to be a unified force in 2019. Nevertheless, the PDP still has strong grass-roots support and experienced campaigners. The outcome of the 2019 elections will therefore largely depend on which of the main parties can present the most united face, with a close result likely. Voters will probably be just about prepared to give Mr Buhari (or whoever replaces him) and the APC another term, given the relatively fresh memory of the largely ineffective period of PDP rule, but this is far from certain.
Political outlook: Key players to watch
Muhammadu Buhari
A former military head of state (1983-85), Mr Buhari subsequently made the transition into civilian politics. He had contested the civilian presidency unsuccessfully three times prior to his victory in March 2015. He is a founding member of the All Progressives Congress (APC), but has struggled to get on with some of the other big personalities in a governing coalition whose only single unifying objective was to win power. As a northern Muslim, Mr Buhari is not universally popular in the mainly Christian south of Nigeria, in particular in the key oil-producing region, the Niger Delta. There are major doubts over Mr Buhari's state of health, with the president spending much of early 2017 in the UK for unspecified medical treatment. A lack of clarity on his health has led to much local speculation that he could be forced to stand down.
Yemi Osinbajo
The vice-president hails from the commercial capital, Lagos, with his appointment giving geopolitical balance to Mr Buhari's northern power base. Since assuming office, Mr Osinbajo has taken a lead role in economic reform, including improving the business environment. In early 2017 he became acting president during Mr Buhari's medical leave, and an increased pace of economic reform in this period was notable. Were Mr Buhari forced to stand down before the next elections (due in 2019), Mr Osinbajo would serve the remainder of the term as president.
Bola Tinubu
A former Lagos state governor and founding member of the APC, Mr Tinubu is a powerful political figure in the south-west of Nigeria. His relationship with Mr Buhari will be key in deciding the effectiveness of the APC administration in the coming years. The two worked well together to secure victory in the 2015 elections, but since then the relationship has become strained. Mr Tinubu has made thinly veiled criticisms of Mr Buhari's management of fuel supply and has also clashed with Buhari loyalists within the APC over political appointments.
Babatunde Fashola
Another former Lagos state governor and APC member, Mr Fashola won plaudits both locally and internationally for his efforts to develop one of the world's largest and most chaotic cities. Given his successes in Lagos, he was appointed as power, works and housing minister by Mr Buhari. He is a potential vice-presidential or presidential candidate for the future, but will have to negotiate a fractious relationship with his one-time mentor, Mr Tinubu.
Olusegun Obasanjo
A former military ruler (1976-79) before being elected president (1999-2007), Mr Obasanjo's relationship with the former ruling party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP), broke down prior to the 2015 elections, culminating in his leaving the party. He has since adopted the approach of an elder statesman, vocal on issues such as governance. Although his impact in day-to-day politics is waning, he will remain influential behind the scenes.
Goodluck Jonathan
Mr Jonathan was the defeated incumbent in the 2015 presidential elections. He was the first person from the Niger Delta to lead the country. His time in office yielded little in the way of progress on many of the challenges faced by Nigeria, but he will be favourably remembered for his gracious acceptance of electoral defeat-something that significantly reduced post-electoral tensions. Although no longer in power, Mr Jonathan is still very active within the PDP as it suffers from major ructions in the wake of its ejection from power. He could yet return to frontline politics.
Lamido Sanusi
Mr Sanusi was a respected governor of the Central Bank of Nigeria before he was dismissed by Mr Jonathan because of a dispute over what Mr Sanusi claimed were billions of dollars of fraudulently missing oil revenue. Mr Sanusi subsequently became the emir of Kano (an important religious position), but remains vocal on political and economic matters. His criticism of the Buhari administration's foreign-exchange policy is likely to prevent any quick rapprochement with the political elite, however.
Emmanuel Ibe Kachikwu
As the head of the state-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) and junior petroleum minister (Mr Buhari named himself as the petroleum minister), Mr Kachikwu has the task of reforming Nigeria's moribund oil sector. He has shown reforming zeal so far, attempting to push through major changes to the functioning of the NNPC. However, he faces a massive task given the scale of the issues faced and strong vested interests in maintaining a corruption-blighted status quo.
Kemi Adeosun
The finance minister is a former finance commissioner of Ogun state who also has private-sector experience, at PricewaterhouseCoopers and Chapel Hill Denham, a local investment bank. Although well qualified for her current post, she does not have a particularly high profile or a significant support base.
Political outlook: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories, but regional co-operation will improve. The West will provide some assistance, but will remain wary given concerns over human rights abuses perpetrated by the Nigerian armed forces. Relations with the US will be mixed; the Trump administration has appeared more willing than its predecessor to sell Nigeria military hardware, but the US's clampdown on immigration has ensnared some Nigerians (even though they are not on the travel ban list of countries drawn up by the Trump administration), straining bilateral relations.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil (although demand from the US has started to rise again after slumping in 2014-15 amid the shale oil boom) and will become a bigger source of foreign investment. However, this will come as weakening Chinese domestic prospects limit Chinese appetite for large-scale involvement in Nigeria's challenging business environment.
Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges will tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Relations with South Africa, meanwhile, will remain strained. Africa's two largest economies will continue to compete for political, economic and cultural influence.

Nigeria will have a population of well over 200m in 2021, ensuring that it will remain by far the most populous nation in Africa; it accounts for almost half of the population of the West Africa region and around 20% of the Sub-Saharan region. Nigeria has a very young population, with over 40% under 15 years of age and almost 2m entering the jobs market each year.
Underemployment is more of an issue than unemployment
The population growth rate will be high enough to retain a relatively stable age profile. Such a youthful population will have difficulty in finding suitable employment within the formal economy. However, it is not unemployment that is the main issue; few Nigerians in the labour force can afford not to work in a country with no government social security support for the unemployed. Instead, the main challenges are underemployment and low pay. This suggests that the task facing the government is not so much job creation as the implementation of reforms to help to raise productivity and enable employers and employees to upskill existing jobs. Indeed, the country's ability to capitalise on this demographic opportunity will depend on raising health, employment and educational standards, on which only gradual progress can be expected. With the participation rate increasing gradually, largely as a result of more women entering the workforce, the pressure on the job market will be keenly felt throughout the forecast period.
Much will depend on the manufacturing and services sectors, but the prospects are mixed. Meanwhile, the oil and gas sector will remain capital- rather than labour-intensive, and a gradual switch from subsistence to commercial farming is likely to result in less employment in agriculture rather than more, as hoped by the government. Many young Nigerians will have to resort to low-paid work in the informal sector, but others are likely to turn to crime or militancy-another challenge for policymakers.
Rapid urbanisation will present a challenge
A further problem will be to provide enough housing for young Nigerians leaving home. Given that the government's efforts to boost house-building are expected to make only limited progress, owing to inefficiency and capacity bottlenecks, slums are likely to increase in number and resentment to grow. This issue will be intensified by ongoing urbanisation. The share of the urban population will surpass 50% in the forecast period, up from 36% in the 1991 census. This will strain the capacity of municipal authorities to provide adequate services. Nevertheless, competition for the best agricultural and grazing grounds will continue in some parts of the country. Access to land has been a key source of violence in the country's "middle belt", and this is set to continue.
Weak infrastructure compounds health challenges
Although the reported incidence of HIV/AIDS is relatively low in Nigeria, with UNAIDS putting the prevalence rate in 2015 at 3.1%, the country's large population means that Nigeria has one of the highest numbers of sufferers of the disease in the world. Furthermore, there are geographical pockets of infection where the level is above 20% of the sexually active population, and there are major differences in the prevalence rate between states. Other health concerns include the high incidence of malaria, tuberculosis and Guinea worm disease. Furthermore, there was a significant outbreak of measles during 2016 across parts of northern Nigeria that have seen local health infrastructure decimated by insecurity. A mass vaccination programme began in early 2017, but it will take time to bring the outbreak under control. More positively, the measles vaccination push has been able to leverage some of the networks built by a big push in recent years to eradicate polio. In mid-2015 Nigeria celebrated one year without a case of polio, prompting the World Health Organisation to remove the country from the handful of endemic countries in September of the same year. However, a few isolated cases were reported during mid-2016, showing that the fight is not yet over-especially as insecurity will remain a persistent threat where these diseases are most prevalent. Meanwhile, in other, more prosperous areas of the country, diseases associated with improving living standards are also a growing issue; for example, 1.56m Nigerians suffer from diabetes-a figure that looks likely to increase, given weak healthcare provision.
