a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria's business environment will remain among the more challenging in the world over the next five years. Small improvements in the political environment, economy and infrastructure will be largely offset by ongoing major deficiencies in the authorities' handling of the foreign-exchange markets and a more complex tax regime. This mixed picture, coupled with other countries moving ahead at a faster rate with their own business environment reform processes, will mean that in our global rankings Nigeria falls from 73rd to 78th place out of 82 countries. In the regional rankings Nigeria deteriorates from 12th to 15th out of 17 countries.
Efforts to create a significantly more attractive business environment in the country will continue to be hindered by the slow pace of market-oriented structural reforms, the ongoing problem of corruption, the absence of effective government institutions, the weak capacity of the civil service to implement changes and extremely poor infrastructure. It will remain largely beyond the capacity of Nigeria's policymakers, even in the medium term, to push through the much-needed and comprehensive reforms.
Efforts to diversify economy away from oil will require pro-business reforms
While Nigeria will emerge from the economic recession of 2016 during the forecast period, prices for its economic mainstay, oil, will remain well below the peaks seen in the early 2010s. This will place ongoing strain on the economy. However, there is good to come from this, as it will force the administration to do more to improve the business environment for the non-oil sector. Furthermore, with the oil-revenue-dependent government unable to afford a sustained large-scale public spending spree to try to boost growth, it will instead edge towards sanctioning the greater role of private companies in the provision of public services, including health, education and infrastructure building, although the benefits of this will only be felt after the end of the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Progress on market-oriented reforms is positive but slow moving, given various vested interests and inefficiencies.
2019-21: The administration formed after the 2019 elections makes more assertive steps towards improving the environment for the non-oil private sector, although the reform process remains beset by inefficiency.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Confusion over oil sector reform creates ongoing uncertainty for investors. The government favours local companies in oil sector deals.
2019-21: Clearer policy lines help to stem the trend of lower investment in the oil and gas sectors, but low prices prevent any major upturn in foreign direct investment. Meanwhile, liberalisation opens up greater non-oil opportunities.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Ongoing restrictions on end-users of hard currency mean that a large premium between the official and black- market rates persists.
2019-21: Political upheaval around the 2019 elections and ongoing nationalistic sentiment delays reforms to make trading across borders easier.
Taxes
2017-18: Focus on boosting tax compliance grows, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Retroactive measures become a possibility, although the business community will fight this.
2019-21: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation. Efforts to increase VAT and move more of the informal economy into the formal sector see non-oil collection also improve.
Financing
2017-18: Risk premiums on Nigerian foreign borrowing increase in line with difficult economic prospects, while the weak health of the domestic banking sector (given connections to the troubled oil industry) restricts local availability of financing.
2019-21: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically once the 2019 elections are concluded, as local capital markets deepen and the banking sector develops.
The labour market
2017-18: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers and poor health indicators among the workforce.
2019-21: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2019-21: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but project implementation is slow and beset by corruption.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The economy will perform less badly than in 2016, but not by much
Nigeria's macroeconomic environment will improve a little in the forecast period, which translates to improvements in the score and rankings. However, this mainly results from the low base for comparison set by the economy's disastrous performance in 2016, when it lurched into recession and the currency's dollar peg broke. A return to (low) economic growth from 2017 and a slightly less volatile currency will provide some respite for the macroeconomic environment, but that is a long way from saying that Nigeria has a strong economy. Indeed, its position for this category, while improving considerably, is still only in the middle of the global and regional rankings. Although this category remains the country's highest-scoring by some margin, this mainly reflects how poorly the country scores in other categories.
Nigeria's macroeconomic environment will remain constrained by insecure property rights, a weak civil service, confusion caused by overlaps and contradictions between local, state and federal government actions, and deeply entrenched vested interests opposed to free-market competition. Macro-economic policy will continue to espouse the promotion of market-led growth and poverty reduction, but action is unlikely to match rhetoric.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Positive (but only limited) progress on structural reform results in a small improvement in the score but a deterioration in the rankings as other countries improve more quickly. Furthermore, this improvement is from a low base and the local business environment will remain difficult, with Nigeria towards the bottom of the global and regional rankings. The government will continue to send out mixed signals regarding its commitment to promoting a more market-oriented and competitive economy, protecting property rights and reducing government interference in the economy. During his time as military leader in the 1980s, Mr Buhari demonstrated a penchant for heavy state intervention at the expense of private-sector endeavour, and his policy statements while in power since 2015 imply that he still sees a large role for the state. However, he has included pro-business reformers with private-sector experience in his cabinet.
Despite the rhetoric of the government's Economic Recovery and Growth Plan (ERGP), which was released in early 2017, it is highly unlikely that Nigeria will embark on major market-oriented structural reforms during the forecast period. The ERGP offers a vision of an economy that is largely private-sector-driven, recognising the power of free markets. However, vested interests will hinder such an agenda, including politicians wanting to protect patronage networks across geopolitical faultlines, consumers used to price controls and large subsidies, and, in particular, powerful business interests.
Given the small number of politically connected companies operating in many formal sectors-and the existing barriers to entry into many sectors-competition is expected to remain limited. Companies in the formal sector have been dependent on state subsidies and have been shielded by protectionist policies for so long that many are unlikely to respond favourably to government implementation of fundamental free-market reforms and will continue to champion state intervention, both openly and discreetly, particularly with regard to foreign trade and domestic infrastructure subsidies.
A rapid improvement in the ease of doing business is unlikely
An official goal of achieving a top-100 ranking in the World Bank's Doing Business index in the next three years (from 169th in 2016) is unlikely to be met. It is positive that Mr Buhari recognises the need to improve the business environment, and he was relatively quick to set up a Presidential Enabling Business Environment Council (PEBEC) on coming to power. The reformist vice-president, Yemi Osinbajo, chairs the PEBEC and has instigated some positive reforms aimed at reducing red tape. However, a rapid improvement in the business environment will almost certainly require deeper reforms than have so far been announced. Although eliminating unnecessary bureaucratic constraints is vital to reducing the high cost of doing business, increasing private investment also requires changes in policy direction, including liberalisation of the foreign-exchange system. However, there is still strong opposition to liberalisation in general, not least from Mr Buhari himself, and this will get in the way of reform efforts.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Little change is expected in the government's policy towards foreign investment over the forecast period, as evidenced by the unchanged score for this section. With other countries showing improvement, Nigeria's position will deteriorate closer to the bottom of both the global and regional rankings. A lower oil price environment compared with previous boom years will limit investor interest in that sector, and despite government efforts to drum up higher levels of non-oil investment, this will be limited by the complexities of the local business environment, along with the bureaucracy, corruption, low productivity, poor infrastructure and low income levels that restrict the potential market. Ongoing foreign-exchange restrictions will remain an off-putting factor for investors.
As well as the weaker price environment, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) into the hydrocarbons sector will also remain constrained until the regulatory and tax environments become clearer. The Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) was designed to do this; it was first submitted to the National Assembly in 2008 and presented again in a modified form in 2012, but got bogged down in the legislature. The Buhari administration is expected to push for the passage of the PIB, but it will continue to face resistance given the conflicting demands of the various stake-holders. These include ethnic nationalists demanding a greater share of oil revenue for impoverished communities in oil-producing areas (so-called host communities); federal officials wanting to maximise Nigeria's share of oil profits; and multinational oil companies seeking to hold on to their profits, while also demanding improvement in the local operating environment. Indeed, even assuming that the PIB is passed during the forecast period, its fiscal terms may well be at a level that continues to put off investors, given that we expect oil prices to remain well below recent historical levels. Given all of this, it is difficult to envisage any rapid improvement in the investment environment in the hydrocarbons sector.
Public mistrust of foreign investment will remain high
While outright expropriation of foreign-owned assets is unlikely, legal disputes and accusations of corruption can easily ensnare investors. For example, in early 2017 the Nigerian high court ordered Royal Dutch Shell (UK/Netherlands) and Eni (Italy) to temporarily cede control of a jointly owned oil licence to the federal government, pending an investigation into claims that bribes were paid in an earlier sale of the block. Controversy such as this highlights the problems of opacity and cronyism that have long under-mined public confidence in the government's management of Nigeria's mineral resources and fuelled local resentment towards foreign participation in the local economy.
Nigeria will attract a greater share of FDI into non-oil industries. Investors will be pulled in by the economy's strong growth potential and expanding middle class, which are driving growth in consumer markets in Africa's most populous nation. Mining, agriculture, retail, communications and infrastructure will all be growing recipients of FDI in the forecast period, albeit from a very low base.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria will remain one of the worst-ranked countries for foreign trade and exchange controls during the forecast period. We expect the administration to continue to struggle with the management of the foreign-exchange system in an economy prone to fluctuations in supplies of hard currencies, largely owing to reliance on volatile crude oil sales. This has seen the Buhari administration oversee the implementation of a number of capital controls aimed at supporting a dollar peg in a low oil price environment. The result has been a multiple exchange-rate environment that further complicates the already challenging business environment. While we expect some devaluation of the naira to be allowed over the forecast period, ongoing attempts to manage the currency's value will prevent the naira from reaching market-clearing levels, and a large premium with black market rates will persist.
Protectionist sentiments will persist
Protectionist sentiment will remain strong in Nigeria, and it is unlikely that the Buhari administration will have either the political will or the ideological orientation to promote free trade. It will take a long time to remove the barriers to the movement of capital, labour and goods, both within the West Africa region and between the region and its international markets. Crossborder smuggling is likely to remain an important feature of the Nigerian economy and to exert additional pressure on locally based businesses.
Although Nigeria's complicated tariff structure has been simplified over the past decade, the scope and range of import restrictions will also change according to the policy priorities of the government and the relative strength of local interest groups. The authorities will persist with varying bans on access to foreign exchange for the import of goods they deem non-essential, or will try to foster local production.
The capacity and efficiency of Nigerian ports have improved following the implementation of an ambitious concession programme in the mid-2000s that transferred management of terminals to private operators. However, although the reforms have improved port operations and ship turnaround times, there remains the problem of corruption in the customs service, which can complicate and delay the clearance of goods.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
Value of index a

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The government will attempt to increase tax rates and broaden the coverage of collection during the forecast period; an expected increase in the rate of value-added tax (VAT) in particular sees the score for this category worsen for 2017-21 and Nigeria's global and regional rankings deteriorate. The need to increase tax collection has been intensified by the slump in oil prices in recent years that slashed revenue for a sector that historically provided around 70% of Nigeria's fiscal revenue. However, while the tax burden is set to increase, it will be from a low base. With the total tax-to-GDP ratio at only 6% across all tiers of government, Nigeria has one of the lowest tax intakes in the world.
Increasing tax compliance will get the government only so far
The government has embarked upon a data-gathering programme that will enable it to pursue tax avoiders more aggressively, both at home and abroad. It also intends to boost tax revenue and compliance through an asset and income declaration scheme. Although there is plenty of scope to improve tax collection in a country where tax evasion is rampant, it is highly doubtful whether administrative measures to boost compliance and broaden the tax base will be sufficient to restore government finances. Tax rises will be needed at some point, but are not on the agenda in the near term given already high public dissatis-faction with the government. Indeed, the government has indicated that it does not intend to raise tax rates within the next 18 months, but thereafter is likely to increase VAT and consider changes to corporation and personal income taxes.
Many companies would be able to absorb moderate tax rises as long as they were accompanied by major improvements in the whole tax payment system. Companies in the formal sector complain of being subjected to multiple taxes as a result of tax authorities at the different tiers of government imposing a variety of levies, sometimes illegally. The fiscal rivalry between federal and subnational administrations makes it difficult for the central government to establish any new tax body with significant autonomy and the power to impose tax harmonisation. The efficacy of tax administration varies considerably by state. It is most sophisticated in the commercial capital, Lagos.
Business environment outlook: Financing

Nigeria's banking sector will continue to face a number of severe challenges, with the score for this category unchanged as a result. The lack of any improve-ment sees Nigeria's ranking for financing deteriorate on a global and regional basis. The country's recession of 2016 (and prospects for only a weak recovery) and banks' large exposure to the depressed oil and power sectors will continue to challenge banks' financial soundness. Non-performing loans grew past 10% of total loans during 2016 and seem likely to remain high in the coming years as the oil sector continues to underperform and the wider economy posts weak growth. A weakening exchange rate adds to this gloomy picture. Lending denominated in dollars accounts for almost half of banks' loan books, and lending to the oil and gas sector makes up around one-third of gross loans.
Some improvements to the financial sector are in prospect, but not many
Although the restructuring of the banking sector that took place after a major crisis in 2009 means that Nigerian banks are better placed to develop the domestic financial sector further, large challenges remain in raising standards to international levels, and crossborder supervision needs improving. Bank lending to private businesses-especially small and medium-sized firms-has been subdued in a high interest-rate environment. Nevertheless, as the forecast period progresses, greater competition in the banking sector should drive down the cost of banking and improve the availability of lending in the longer term, especially for corporate clients. Moreover, the government's efforts to create a long-term government bond market may allow the development of a more active corporate bond market in the future. Coupled with the development of the Nigerian Stock Exchange, this should make it easier to raise funds as the forecast period progresses.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
Value of index a
 
Global rank b
 
Regional rank c

5.3

13

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The government of Mr Buhari has made reducing unemployment and boosting job creation one of its top priorities, particularly with respect to youths. However, there is a notable risk that rather than attempting to make liberalising changes to the economy as a means to improve job creation, the administration will instead adopt a more nationalistic approach, attempting to boost local employment by restricting that of foreigners. This prospect sees the score for this category deteriorate slightly in the forecast period, with Nigeria's rankings suffering as a consequence.
Poor education system will continue to generate skills deficiency
The dire state of the education system, notably the vocational system and apprenticeship schemes, means that skilled manual labour-from bricklayers to mechanics and electricians-will remain in short supply. Poor education, health and transport mean that, in terms of unskilled labour, productivity levels are very low. Nigeria's university system will continue to churn out large numbers of graduates, with a bias towards the arts and social sciences, but the economy will still suffer from a large deficit of skilled personnel, particularly in the fields of science and technology, as well as business management. Expatriates will continue to find the procedure to secure work permits-and sometimes even simple entry visas-complex and costly.
More and more Nigerians, particularly the younger generation, are no longer reconciled to a life toiling in traditional occupations or earning poverty wages; they aspire to modern standards of living, but there are not enough of the jobs that would bring them to this level. The dilemma facing the authorities is that the supply of workers seeking decent jobs is likely to continue to outstrip demand. This imbalance has both economic and political conse-quences in a nation that is susceptible to sectarian conflicts, often fuelled by competition for scarce resources. This suggests that the priority of policymakers should be to foster an economic environment that encourages private invest-ment in activities that have the potential to improve the productive and employment capacity of the economy. However, given past precedents, there can be little confidence that this will actually happen. High unemployment is set to remain a worrying feature of the Nigerian economy, and could well become a source of greater social and political instability.
Productivity will remain below that of Nigeria's developing-world peers
Although labour law reform in 2005 weakened the capacity of the unions to organise political or sympathy strikes, the labour movement remains powerful, capable of organising paralysing national strikes. Partly as a result of union pressure, the government has been forced to increase the minimum wage significantly in recent years. Although such increases have been required to offset the rising cost of living over the past decade, and should not affect the more skilled jobs in much of the private sector, where pay is already above this level, it is a move likely to diminish any prospects of rapid growth in the formal sector for lower-skilled and labour-intensive sectors such as manufacturing. Furthermore, given deficiencies in infrastructure, as well as health and education provision, productivity in Nigeria will remain a long way below that in other developing-world countries.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
Value of index a
 
Global rank b
 
Regional rank c
 

2012-16

3.1

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Improving Nigeria's dire infrastructure is a central part of the government's policy agenda. Lower oil revenue will constrain investment, but increased public borrowing and greater private-sector involvement will lead to some improvement in infrastructure. These likely improvements explain the rise in Nigeria's score for infrastructure for 2017-21. However, given the scale of the problems and the fact that progress will not match rhetoric, Nigeria remains near the bottom of the rankings. Nigeria's poor infrastructure has been a major constraint on growth since the mid-1970s. Successive governments have failed to deliver on promises to improve and expand basic services in key areas such as power, water, telecommunications, healthcare and education. Gains will be made where the private sector becomes more involved, although significantly furthering private-sector investment in many sectors will require politically difficult changes, such as establishing pricing systems that adequately allow for profit.
Funding issues will be a major barrier to development
Official efforts to boost infrastructure spending will yield mixed results. The administration's Economic Recovery and Growth Plan (ERGP) contains ambitious projects that would require substantial private-sector investments, which are unlikely to materialise without stronger reforms to inspire investor confidence. For example, the ERGP states that Nigeria needs to invest US$3trn in infrastructure over the next 30 years. This equates to US$100bn a year, which is around 25% of the nation's current GDP and several times its savings rate. Given that government revenue (across federal, state and local levels) accounts for less than 10% of GDP and public finances are likely to remain tight in the medium term, the quest for grand-scale infrastructure development is only feasible with large injections of private capital, much of it from overseas lenders and investors. However, past experience in Nigeria has shown that investors are reluctant to put money into businesses where the government controls prices and other market variables.
Energy policy is backwards
Nigeria will probably remain beset by inadequate power supply. A lack of private investment in the development of power infrastructure and the failure of privatised electricity companies to invest more in upgrading and expanding their deficient facilities are largely due to the government imposing energy price ceilings that do not allow for cost recovery. Similarly, the main reason that thermal power-generating stations have been hampered for years by shortages of gas supplies in a country with abundant natural gas reserves is that official gas prices for domestic power plants have been too low to entice oil companies to invest in developing the costly infrastructure needed to harness gas for domestic use. The ERGP has said that the gas pricing structure will be reviewed to recover all prudent costs as services improve, but govern-ment officials and investors will invariably have different views on what constitute prudent costs. Policymakers also seem to have got the relationship between pricing and service improvement backwards. To begin providing a better service, companies often need to generate more revenue to invest in the physical and human resources required to achieve the desired improvements.
It is difficult to see how the administration will attain its infrastructure objectives without first putting in place independent and flexible pricing systems that can gain the long-term confidence of profit-seeking investors. As it is, the government's current concept of cost-reflective pricing amounts to occasional price increases, which at the time of setting may be cost-reflective but soon become unviable in a high inflation environment. This arrangement not only fails to assure investors of the future profitability of their endeavour, but also often results in the government periodically implementing large price adjustments that invariably fuel public discontent and protests.
A recent revival in Nigeria's railways will prove short-lived unless greater private-sector participation is encouraged. After decades of decline in the network, the revival at the start of 2013 of the 1,126-km Lagos-Kano line, after a ten-year closure, marked the first significant result of multiple government plans aimed at improving rail transport. However, Nigeria's railway revival has not been fast or cheap. Indeed, in April 2017 Mr Buhari asked parliament for approval to borrow US$5.85bn from China to continue the modernisation of the nation's rail network. An additional issue is that while infrastructure funding from China has potential, precedent shows that the announcement of large Chinese funding lines does not match up to actual disbursements as projects become bogged down in Nigeria's difficult operating environment. The expected Chinese economic slowdown over the forecast period will be a further constraint on its outbound investment.
Mismanagement and corruption will hinder road development
Large amounts of public money will continue to be spent on improving Nigeria's road network, but around half of the national roads are still in poor condition, exacting a considerable toll on the economy. The government will need to address mismanagement and corruption in the handling of road projects. In addition, the cumbersome process under which funds are released for public works causes delay in the execution of contracts, particularly with respect to road maintenance.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government released its medium-term Economic Recovery and Growth Plan (ERGP) in March 2017. The ERGP is mainly aimed at addressing the country's huge infrastructure deficit, attaining food security and promoting industrialisation driven by small and medium-sized enterprises. The programme also seeks to secure macroeconomic stability, create 15m jobs and increase real annual GDP growth to 7% by 2020. It offers a vision of an economy that is largely private-sector-driven, recognising the power of free markets. However, the professed preference for markets is not backed by commitments to scrap many of the existing policies and practices that clearly hinder unfettered exchange, including capital controls, energy pricing regulations and international trade restrictions. Indeed, despite the rhetoric, there is little in the ERGP's details to suggest that Nigeria's rulers are about to embark on market-oriented structural reforms.
Successive Nigerian governments since the restoration of civilian rule in 1999 have paid lip service to the idea of market reforms, but progress has been slow and we expect this to remain the case. State management of scarce resources enables politicians and other members of the political elite to direct the flow of these resources not only for personal gain but also to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies. Policymakers also fear that market reforms will push up consumer prices, thereby stoking wider unrest at a time when the government is already struggling to maintain political stability. There is also opposition to reforms from members of the middle classes whose living standards are dependent on government-subsidised goods, such as petrol and electricity. Sections of the private sector that rely on state handouts and protectionist policies are also not keen on structural reforms. Policy development and implementation will also continue to suffer from a lack of co-ordination and poor relations between the various tiers of government.
The restructuring of the oil sector will also remain on the policy agenda but will move at a similarly slow pace to the ERGP. Many contentious issues have still to be resolved, including fiscal terms and revenue management. The oil companies, workers and local politicians (not to mention the various militant groups) will all pull in different directions. Nevertheless, some modest progress is likely given the important role that a stronger oil sector could play in supporting the wider economy.

The Buhari administration will attempt to continue its expansionary fiscal stance into 2017-18, in an attempt to drag Nigeria out of the recession it entered during 2016 and with the 2019 elections firmly in mind. However, expenditure growth will be hindered by capacity constraints and an inefficient bureaucracy. Indeed, as is now common, the budget for the 2017 calendar year had still not been passed into law by late April.
Revenue collection in 2017 will increase strongly in nominal terms as exchange-rate depreciation boosts the value of Nigeria's oil exports in local-currency terms. However, as a proportion of GDP, revenue will barely creep back past 3%, reflecting the narrow revenue base. Oil revenue will continue to grow in 2018 in line with stronger prices and moderate production gains. The non-oil tax take in 2017-18 will increase in tandem with the recovering non-oil economy and government efforts to widen the tax base, but will do so from a miniscule base, and oil will remain the dominant revenue source. Overall, we expect the budget deficit to come in a little below 2.5% of GDP in 2017-18.
We expect 2019 to be more challenging, given our forecast of stronger global headwinds, which will sap confidence. Spending will remain high around the elections (although it will be reined in a little afterwards), and revenue will be constrained by stagnating oil prices. We forecast that the fiscal deficit will increase to 2.8% of GDP in 2019 before edging down to 2.3% of GDP in 2021, amid a tentative global and local economic recovery.
Deficits in the range of 2-3% of GDP appear relatively low by emerging-market standards. However, given such low revenue collection in Nigeria, debt servicing will become more challenging in the coming years. Indeed, debt servicing is already equivalent to about one-third of federal government revenue. Without more action to widen the tax base the proportion will increase, raising questions over longer-term debt sustainability. Furthermore, the situation at state and local government level is similarly precarious.

Monetary policy will concentrate on attempts to support economic recovery while limiting inflation and supporting the flagging currency. However, this will yield contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period, with the private sector desperate for cheaper credit to spur growth, but inflation running high following currency devaluation in 2016 and 2017. On balance, interest rates will not move much, staying high as pressure on the naira continues and inflation remains high. The monetary situation should stabilise a little in 2018 as oil prices recover. However, with oil prices remaining well below their 2012-13 highs, interest rates will have to remain at around double-digit levels, under the assumption that the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will return to its, and Mr Buhari's, preference for currency stability. Rates are likely to fall in 2019-20 as the global economy slows and the monetary authorities attempt to stimulate activity, with Nigeria following suit, before a small increase in 2021 as economic activity picks up.

Nigeria will post only a weak economic recovery in 2017 from the recession it experienced in 2016. Oil production will pick up a little following the massive disruption caused by militancy in 2016-Nigeria was exempted from a production cut by OPEC at the cartel's recent meetings. However, we expect that the government will be unable to secure a permanent end to rebel activity and that lower-level disruption will continue. Much of the non-oil sector will continue to be hindered by the central bank's monetary stance and ongoing interference in the exchange-rate system. Power provision should improve a little, in line with reduced disruption to feedstock from the oil and gas sector, although energy supplies will remain woefully insufficient overall. We therefore forecast that real GDP growth in 2017 will reach just 0.9%.
No significant rise in oil production is expected in the medium term, given the magnitude of the issues faced. Elsewhere in the economy, some pro-business policy reforms and a gradual improvement in infrastructure provision will support the non-oil sector. Overall, real GDP growth should pick up to 2.1% in 2018. We then expect growth to slip back to 1.7% in 2019, given election-related uncertainty, compounded by an expected recession in the US and an ongoing slowdown in China that will spook global markets and lead to a moderation in oil prices. We forecast a moderate rebound in growth, to 3.2%, in 2021 as local and global markets strengthen. The average growth rate of 2.1% in 2017-21 is weak for a country with a young and expanding population, and will hit living standards and job creation-issues that will feed back into threats to political and social stability.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Even amid a lower price environment compared with the boom years of the early 2010's, Nigeria's oil and gas sector will continue to be crucial to the prospects of the wider economy, dominating the export profile and accounting for the majority of government revenue. Nevertheless, despite the best intentions of reformists in government, oil production is unlikely to stage a rapid recovery following a slump in investment in recent years, amid policy uncertainty and rising militancy by local groups seeking greater control of oil revenue. This lack of investment means that in spite of the oil sector being a source of great financial windfall for Nigeria, the infrastructure that supports it is old and rickety.
Achieving a workable consensus among the various political and economic interest groups that depend on the oil industry will probably continue to confound policymakers. In 2008 the Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB), a complex piece of legislation to overhaul the oil sector radically, was unveiled. It included provisions to create a national oil company that is self-financing and profit-driven; to enshrine greater transparency and openness in the management of oil resources; to protect the environment; and to alter revenue-sharing. However, successive governments have failed to implement the legislation and will continue to struggle to do so. The ongoing failure to pass the PIB stems largely from the rival claims of the stakeholders who lobbied hard to push their interests, which invariably relate to the share-out of the gains from Nigeria's considerable oil and gas endowment. The multinational petroleum companies responsible for most of Nigeria's hydrocarbon output oppose the PIB's proposed increase in the government's take of oil profits, claiming that it would deter investment in the industry. However, Nigerian officials and civil groups have long complained that their nation has been under-rewarded for its oil production, particularly from offshore deposits. With global oil prices now substantially lower than they were when the PIB was initially brought before parliament, the government is under even greater pressure to maximise its share of oil profits.
The PIB contains a provision for 10% of the net profit of upstream oil firms to be paid into a fund for the development of oil-producing areas. This would go some way to placating the oil-region militants. However, politicians from non-oil states, especially in the north, oppose this provision. Opponents argue that increasing the slice of oil revenue allocated to oil-producing states, which are already entitled to a 13% oil-derivation payment, will disadvantage non-oil parts of the country by reducing the amount of federal revenue available for them. Some of these areas are as needy (if not more so) and susceptible to political instability as is the oil-producing Niger Delta, they argue.

Delay in key legislation deters billions of dollars of investment
The uncertainty that continues to be generated by the delay in enacting new petroleum industry legislation has led to the loss or deferment of billions of dollars of investment, as prospective investors are unsure what fiscal terms and regulatory conditions will be in force if or when the law is changed. The good news is that the current administration has taken steps to address the issue of government underfunding in the joint-venture oil companies (in which it holds an average stake of 57.5%). It has agreed to pay US$5.1bn of the US$6.8bn it owes in cash call payments for the five years up to December 2015 in the form of incremental oil production-something that will go some way towards narrowing the infrastructure deficit. It is unclear what will happen to the balance and the arrears accumulated in 2016. From January 2017 the admini-stration has also stopped making budgetary allocations for cash call payments and instead allowed the joint-venture operators to deduct the share of production costs payable by the state at source before handing the government its share of profits. This will help to avoid future arrears, but at the cost of lower oil revenue for the government.
Gas production could be scaled up if pricing issues are resolved
Nigeria's proven gas reserves, both oil- and non-oil-associated, are among the largest in the world. In the gas sector the key issue is still flaring; a succession of deadlines to end the practice has been missed in recent years. There is therefore intense competition to find commercial outlets for gas. The government hopes to use much of the new gas production coming on stream to fuel domestic power stations, thus easing the electricity crisis. However, pricing remains an issue, as, despite government pledges to increase the price that it pays for gas, prices on the export market remain more attractive for companies in the sector.

The effects of currency devaluation and efforts by the authorities to rein in the subsidy bill and boost power tariffs to cost-reflective levels will see inflation remain high in 2017, at an average rate of 17%. Currency stability will improve as 2017-18 progresses, but global commodity prices will pick up and so average inflation will ease only moderately, to 13.4% in 2018. Pre-election spending and a further drop in the naira on the back of weaker oil prices mean that inflationary pressures will stay high in 2019, with inflation averaging above 12%, before it falls back slightly in 2020-21, to an annual average of 10.8%, as tighter fiscal and monetary policy takes effect.

We expect misguided interference by the authorities to continue to undermine the functioning of foreign-exchange markets in Nigeria during the forecast period. Despite the interbank market being notionally liberalised in mid-2016, ad hoc restrictions to try to head off depreciatory pressure are likely to be implemented. Import bans will come and go, as will directed foreign-exchange allocations. The current multiple-exchange-rate environment that results from this will therefore continue. Investors will be loath to enter Nigeria amid such uncertainty.
Nevertheless, despite the CBN's reluctance to give up its management of the foreign-exchange markets, it is not in a position to maintain a hard peg, given pressure on external reserves and strong dollar demand. We therefore expect periods of questionable stability in the official rate punctuated by notable, but sporadic, devaluations. Overall, we forecast that the official, interbank, value of the naira will average N329:US$1 in 2017, down from N196.6:US$1 as recently as January 2016. Slightly stronger oil prices will give the CBN more firepower to intervene in 2018, but a slight moderation in oil prices accompanying global jitters on the back of a US slowdown, coupled with elections in Nigeria, will lead to larger falls in the naira during 2019. By end-2021 we expect the naira to be trading not far away from N500:US$1.

Forecasting the naira
For the purpose of The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts, the naira exchange rate is that of the official market. This rate is then used for all calculations where the local-currency value is converted into US dollars, a prime example being GDP. However, given the current exchange-rate regime, the official exchange rate is not a good measure of the rates at which most businesses and individuals in Nigeria can access hard currency. An alternative would be for us to use the black-market rate for the forecasts. However, although this might be more reflective of the situation on the ground, obtaining credible historical data is difficult and the rate varies significantly across Nigeria, which would make forecasting challenging. Another option would be to use the average bureau de change rate, which acts as a sort of semi-official rate in Nigeria, with operators licensed by the Central Bank of Nigeria but operating outside the interbank market. However, here too central bank interference is a major issue, complicating data collection and forecasting. Therefore, for the time being we will continue to use the official rate, but with the caveat that this rate does not give a true reflection of the health of the local economy in dollar terms.

Although oil prices will post a moderate recovery in 2017-18, boosting exports, we expect Nigeria's current account to record only small surpluses, a stark contrast to the enormous surpluses witnessed during the last commodity boom. Oil production will remain prone to disruption, and there will be little short-term progress in terms of diversifying the country's hydrocarbons-dominated export base. Import growth will start to pick up from 2017, in line with subdued, albeit improving, economic prospects, and an ambitious government spending agenda, but the import bill in 2017 will still be more than 25% below the average value recorded in 2011-14, when the oil boom and stronger naira allowed a spending splurge. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation will pick up in 2017-18, but-as with goods imports-will remain below the peaks seen during the last oil boom. Meanwhile, workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency. We then expect the current account to post a small deficit in 2019, equivalent to 0.4% of GDP, as the global slowdown negatively affects workers' remittances, before a modest improvement to a surplus of 0.4% of GDP in 2021 as oil prices increase slightly.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Nigeria
Stocks and flows
Flows of foreign direct investment (FDI) into Nigeria in 2016 totalled US$4.4bn. This was the first year-on-year increase in five years. However, despite this increase, FDI inflows remained weak in an historic context; inflows in 2016 were still less than half their peak level in 2011. As well as lower oil prices, one of the main reasons for lower foreign investment in Nigeria's oil sector is the continued uncertainty about the future fiscal terms for the industry resulting from the delay in the passage of the controversial Petroleum Industry Bill. The bill, which was initially submitted to parliament in 2008, remains stuck. The stock of FDI was an estimated US$95.9bn, or 23.6% of GDP, in 2016. However, this share of GDP was magnified by the fall in Nigeria's total US dollar GDP as the local currency plummeted in value.
Origin and distribution
Most FDI inflows into Nigeria are from the oil multinationals. There has been a modest surge in non-oil sector foreign investment in recent years, after it became clear that civilian democracy and macroeconomic stability had become established. Although much of the investment was by large multinational companies that were already operating in the country, South African companies strongly increased their presence, with Asian companies leading the next wave. However, the challenging market has seen some prominent withdrawals by South African firms, and the economic slowdown in China is also likely to have an impact on Asian inflows.
Determinants
The main factors attracting investment by oil firms are low production costs and high-quality crude oil, both of which offset economic problems and political instability. A number of gas projects have moved ahead, stimulated by abundant supplies, growing demand and the government's policy goal of eliminating gas flaring. So far, privatisation has been a stop-start process. However, the opening-up of the mobile-phone market has been a success. Otherwise, the main rationale for investment by multinationals is to establish a presence in Africa's largest market, which could be highly profitable despite the difficult operating environment.
Impact
The energy sector, which has received most foreign investment to date, provides the majority of government revenue and the vast majority of foreign-exchange earnings. However, it is also a capital-intensive sector with limited linkages to the rest of the economy and little effect on employment. One area in which FDI has had a high-profile impact is mobile-phone networks, led by MTN of South Africa. However, MTN fell foul of regulators over its failure to register SIM card users during 2015 and has had a large fine imposed. This is likely to make investors more wary.
Potential
With the largest economy and population in Africa, Nigeria is an important market, although the awkward business environment-characterised by impenetrable bureaucracy and idiosyncratic regulation-is likely to keep FDI inflows below potential. Established multinationals that have mastered operating in the complex and chaotic regulatory environment make substantial profits, despite the country's low income levels and the logistical difficulties caused by the almost non-existent infrastructure, which obliges companies to provide their own power and water supplies and to distribute goods on a road system that is in poor repair. The government will continue to promote Nigeria as a rewarding target for foreign investment, especially for the commercial exploitation of a range of minerals. The privatisation programme will have a relatively high profile over the next few years, but progress is likely to remain erratic. Parastatals are an important source of patronage, and privatisation faces considerable political opposition, as it is often associated with large-scale job losses. However, the failure of public enterprises to provide an adequate level of service, notably in the electricity and water sectors, and the success of the liberalisation of the telephone market make privatisation almost inevitable, even if this proves to be a protracted and convoluted process. There is considerable potential in the agricultural sector, especially in the production of food for domestic consumption.

Market potential is high, but the operating context will be unfavourable
With Africa's largest economy (or second largest, depending on the exchange rate) and highest population (the country accounts for 20% of the population of Sub-Saharan Africa), Nigeria will grow in importance as a market for many multinationals. Yet its attractiveness over the next five years should not be overstated. Extremely low income levels for the majority of the population will continue to mean that most people have little to spend on goods other than basic necessities. Furthermore, GDP per head in US dollar terms (at market exchange rates) will remain well below the peak reached in 2014 throughout the forecast period. This is due to the weaker context for the vital oil sector and expected further falls in the value of the currency, the naira. Never-theless, Nigeria's growing middle class and wealthy elite-the sizes of which dwarf those in most other African countries-will remain important markets. Nigeria is potentially a profitable market for multinational companies that know how to operate in its complex and chaotic regulatory environment and have over-come the logistical difficulties posed by the almost non-existent infrastructure, for example by providing their own (expensive) power and water supplies.
As the problems associated with working in Nigeria substantially push up the cost of operations, particularly given low productivity, competition from low-cost imports will remain an issue. Providing goods through imports may seem a more attractive option for many companies seeking to exploit the market. However, given the authorities' desire for control over the exchange rate, capital controls and import restrictions will continue to impede business operations.

There will be little shift in spending patterns amid economic hardship
Given the country's low level of income, consumer expenditure is dominated by the purchase of foodstuffs. Food, beverages and tobacco account for more than half of household expenditure. When spending on fuel, clothing and footwear is taken into account (and given that households also face emergency outlays, for example on healthcare), little disposable income is left for expenditure on other consumer goods, leisure or eating out. These trends will broadly continue into the forecast period. There will be some increase in spending on consumer goods, driven largely by the burgeoning middle class, but the poor will remain in the vast majority. The middle classes are almost exclusively located in urban areas, with a geographic concentration in the south-west of the country, around the commercial capital, Lagos.

Initial conditions: Although the oil sector of the economy accounts for less than 10% of GDP (and did so even before the end of the oil price boom), its performance has a major bearing on overall economic conditions given its domination of government and export revenue. Consequently, the lower price environment since late 2014 has severely weakened the local economy. The government's ability to spend what oil revenue it does still earn in a way that would benefit the majority of Nigerians is hugely constrained by the extremely weak civil service, high levels of corruption and the requirement that a large proportion of revenue be allocated to states, which are even less accountable than the federal government. Although there is more dynamism in certain parts of the non-oil private sector, such as trade, entertainment, banking and communications, a background of weak infrastructure and decades of under-investment in healthcare and education means that the initial conditions for the country to enter sustainable and diversified growth are poor.
Population changes bring opportunities, but also threats
Demographic trends: Despite the poor initial conditions, one factor in Nigeria's favour is its large and young population. However, most indicators of the health of the population are low, reflecting decades of underinvestment in healthcare facilities, which will take years to turn around even if the commitment is found. Increasing urbanisation will also put strain on service provision in the cities, as well as housing. An additional problem for the government is provision of education and training facilities for the rapidly growing population, as well as long-term employment opportunities. It is difficult to be optimistic about the outlook without a substantial improvement in economic governance and policy implementation. Over the time horizon to 2050, there is time to turn the situation around, but the precedent is not positive.
External conditions: There has been a structural shift in Nigeria's export markets in recent years, away from the US, which is steadily reducing its oil imports, and towards Asia, particularly India. Oil reserves will not be exhausted by 2050 but are likely to have peaked by then, which will present the additional challenge of finding external markets for the growing non-oil economy. The importance of Nigeria due to its size and influence on the African continent means that the international community will retain an interest in political developments in the country and will try to address the issues of insecurity, corruption and poverty, although Nigeria's oil and gas revenue means that any influence they have will be limited. Without a real commitment by the domestic leadership, Western countries will promote largely cosmetic changes rather than more fundamental reforms.
Institutions and policy trends: The real challenge for successive governments is to raise average incomes and living standards through a sustained period of economic reform and to deliver a real improvement in governance. However, the omens are not good. Nigeria remains one of the most corrupt and poorly governed countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, and given how engrained these problems are, they will be hard to resolve, even in a long-term timeframe. The gap between economic policy rhetoric and implementation will remain huge, and improvements will continue to be slow, given that the vast range of vested interests that benefit from the chaotic status quo remain opposed to change. In addition, policy formulation will continue to be hampered by the country's federal structure; even if a positive reform agenda is promoted at the national level, it is often not implemented or is openly contradicted at the state level.
Largely unsuccessful attempts to diversify economy will hinder prospects
Long-term performance: Nigeria's long-term economic performance will pick up during 2020-50, albeit at a slower pace in 2017-30 than in 2031-50, given the long-term nature of many of the challenges restricting the country's economic potential. Indeed, growth in real GDP per head will remain negative up until 2020, given the weak medium-term context. Although some non-oil sectors will perform well (agriculture has enormous potential, as do retail and communi-cations), others, such as manufacturing, are likely to struggle to become internationally competitive. Income levels will remain low. Moreover, Nigeria's exports and government revenue will continue to be dominated by the hydrocarbons sector. Once the next wave of new developments in the offshore oil and gas sector has run its course, Nigeria will face difficult choices in terms of economic development, and it remains unclear whether fundamental policy decisions can be made and implemented to ensure that the country is able to enter a longer period of sustained and more diversified growth.

Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit assigns a high risk to the grand coalition government of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) and the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) not serving its full parliamentary term to 2018, despite the coalition parties' recent renewal of their agreement.
Political risks have risen since mid-2015, as public unease about the influx of migrants and dissatisfaction with the mainstream ruling parties has boosted support for the anti-immigration Freedom Party (FPÖ) and heightened intra-coalition tensions amid still weak economic growth. Since late 2015 opinion polls have shown support for the FPÖ at about 32%-above both coalition parties.
The risk of an early election increased on May 10th, when Reinhold Mitterlehner, the vice-chancellor, minister of the economy and leader of the ÖVP, announced that he would be resigning from all his positions. This is likely to mean that the popular 30-year-old foreign affairs minister, Sebastian Kurz, will take over as ÖVP leader and could lead to an early election later this year.
Even if the government survives the latest upheaval, we expect little progress in most areas of its reform agenda. This policy paralysis will hamper efforts to improve competitiveness, which over recent years has deteriorated relative to Austria's regional peers. We expect this to be the case under any new government as well.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2017-21) as the fiscal consolidation process suffers under limited government cohesion and effectiveness. However, we expect the public debt/GDP ratio to fall gradually.
Economic growth in recent years has been tepid, as productivity has weakened and export market shares have declined. Real GDP grew by 0.8% in 2015 but accelerated to 1.6% in 2016, driven by domestic consumption and invest-ment demand. We expect a slight acceleration of growth in 2017, to 1.7%, reflecting mainly catch-up growth, and forecast average annual growth of 1.5% in 2018-21.
Structural factors, including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets, will keep inflation higher than in regional peers; after 1% in 2016, we forecast 2.1% inflation in 2017 and 2% on average in 2018-21.
