a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21). As a result, the country rises to 11th place in the regional ranking and to 18th in the global ranking. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited. Barriers to entry to network industries are likely to persist.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of the competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal, but further liberalisation unlikely.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to the tax system, owing in part to government ineffectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely if a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers. Downside risks from financial, legislative and macroeconomic risks in central and eastern Europe.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage is introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

a Actual.
Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. The last general election was held in 2013; the next is due in 2018.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best, as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second-highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2016 the value of exported goods was US$142.8bn and the goods import bill was US$143bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.3bn. Along with a significant primary income deficit and modest secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.7% of GDP.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit assigns a high risk to the grand coalition government of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) calling an early election before the end of its term in October 2018.
The outlook for the coalition surviving seemed to improve slightly after the two parties presented a new coalition agreement in late January 2017, which included a number of policy measures, including a new minimum wage and enhanced security measures. However, relations between the two parties remain tense, and there are serious questions as to whether it will be possible for the coalition to implement the announced reforms. Furthermore, even within the parties relations are tense, as demonstrated on May 10th by Reinhold Mitterlehner announcing his resignation from the positions of vice-chancellor, minister for the economy and leader of the ÖVP, citing frustration within his own party. Mr Mitterlehner was seen as a placeholder for the popular 30-year-old foreign affairs minister, Sebastian Kurz, who is now likely to take over the leadership of the party. On the closing date for this report it remained unclear whether he would trigger an early election to capitalise on his popularity and win a personal mandate, or take up the offer from the SPÖ chancellor, Christian Kern, to work on a reform programme together until the scheduled election in 2018.
A clear trend in recent state elections and in the presidential election in 2016 has been gains for the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) at the expense of the SPÖ and the ÖVP. Opinion polls continue to show support for the FPÖ at about 32%, ahead of the SPÖ (at 29%) and the ÖVP (at 21%)-although when the same question is asked assuming that Mr Kurz leads the ÖVP, it becomes a three-horse race. The FPÖ is the well-established party of protest, attracting support from voters who are dissatisfied with the current government. It is therefore not surprising that support for the FPÖ has increased at a time when there is a widespread perception of stalemate within the current coalition, along with concerns about immigration, stagnant economic growth and relatively high unemployment. The fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP will weigh heavily on political stability in the years ahead. The FPÖ candidate eventually lost the presidential election in December 2016, and by a larger margin the second time round when it was rerun following irregularities in the vote counting process. However, the fact that the FPÖ candidate, Norbert Hofer, managed to gain almost half of the vote both times, and on a high turnout, backs our view that support for the FPÖ has become entrenched to a significant degree.
The FPÖ is likely to win an early election or the next scheduled one, and subsequently to attempt to form a government, although it remains unclear which party it will choose to do this with. Even if the FPÖ only manages to come second, the difficult relationship between the SPÖ and the ÖVP means that they are unlikely to enter another grand coalition. Thus the FPÖ is likely to form part of any new government, as the other parties-including the Greens and the liberal NEOS-are unlikely to be large enough to help any of the three large parties to reach a majority. The FPÖ's proximity to power means that it tends to moderate its views slightly compared with far-right, populist parties in other European countries, such as France and the Netherlands. Mr Kern has been vocal in his disapproval of the FPÖ, but has been moving towards the party in terms of policy, for instance by pushing for curbs on intra-EU labour migration and by stating that his own party and the FPÖ were the only parties in Austria that wanted change. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further in the second half of our forecast period (2017-21). Relations with fellow EU member states will worsen in the event that the FPÖ enters government, putting pressure on the FPÖ's coalition partner, and we expect a government led by the party to be unstable, as it would struggle to implement its policies.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for September or October 2018. Whether it takes place then or earlier, we forecast that the FPÖ will become either the largest or the second-largest party and will then probably form a coalition with either the SPÖ or the ÖVP.
Elections for some state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president is in 2023.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the rise of the FPÖ, and it seems to have driven the government to lower its annual cap on asylum applications. The government has repeatedly hinted that it wants to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens on the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Mr Hofer-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU does not reform or if Turkey joins. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution, a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016 when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In its renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017 the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term, in 2018. These include a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, we are sceptical that tangible progress will be achieved in most of these areas, owing to a lack of cohesion within the grand coalition and within the parties themselves at the different levels of government. The next government, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right, but we would expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.3% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015 but widened again in 2016, to 1.5%, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending.
We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period, albeit within 1% of GDP from 2018, as fiscal con-solidation will continue to be limited and growth relatively slow. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from 84.6% in 2016, following a positive contribu-tion from the Heta deal, to about 77% in 2021. In the context of the quanti-tative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Amid heightened political risk the euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum, and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and a EUR60bn per month quantitative easing (QE) programme, which will run until the end of 2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, stressed that the reduction in the pace of QE (from EUR80bn per month in March) was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably Germany, which was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.6%, this remained below growth of 1.8% in Germany.
The economy's relatively lacklustre performance in recent years reflects a number of factors. Austria's domestic reform process has faltered and, along with higher inflation compared with its regional peers, this has weakened productivity and competitiveness, admittedly from fairly high levels, in relation to countries such as Germany and the Netherlands, hindering export performance. This has depressed labour market prospects. In recent years the labour market has not been able to integrate the increased labour supply, caused in part by the influx of migrants last year, and this has pushed up the unemployment rate, even though employment has been growing. This in turn has weighed on consumer sentiment, meaning that much of the windfall for consumers from low oil prices since late 2014 has been saved instead of consumed. Although inflation has picked up recently following increasing global energy prices and positive base effects, we expect continued moderate consumption growth owing to a modestly improving labour market.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth-following an underperformance even compared with fundamentals in recent years-to continue, and we expect real GDP growth of 1.7% in 2017. This still compares negatively with, for instance, the Netherlands, where catch-up growth in recent years has been about 2%. The lack of reform progress is likely to continue to weigh on growth throughout the forecast period. Domestic demand will be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in the coming years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.5% in 2018-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016-well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone in both years. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation from October 2016, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 2.1%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015 and averaged US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, with a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1, reflecting the sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following Donald Trump's election victory in the US. We now forecast an annual average rate of US$1.06:EUR1 in 2017 and US$1.07:EUR1 in 2018, reflecting heightened political risk in Europe and strong growth in the US, with the euro then appreciating gradually in 2019-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and pushed the trade balance back into a small deficit in 2016. We expect further growth and higher oil prices to continue to weigh on the trade balance in the coming years. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in our forecast period of just below 2% on average.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data are for historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: EIU aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent

3-month Euribor: IFS
Domestic data
GDP: Eurostat
Population: Statistics Austria
Consumer prices: Eurostat
Average hourly earnings: MEI
Industrial production: MEI
Exchange rates and interest rates: IFS
External trade: IFS
Unemployment rate: Statistics Austria
General government budget balance: Eurostat
Foreign direct investment: IFS
Abbreviations
EIU: Economist Intelligence Unit
IFS: IMF, International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
MEI: OECD, Main Economic Indicators

Country Forecast Turkey April 2017 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-turkey-april-2017-updater/docview/1892154970/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Turkey+April+2017+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-04-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Turkey&amp;rft.issn=09668632&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
Since the failed coup by parts of the military on July 15th 2016 there has been a rapid deterioration in Turkey's political outlook, and it looks set to continue. The president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) are steadily tightening their grip on power. This process is undermining Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures and exacerbating the already deep social and political polarisation of the country. The approval in a referendum on April 16th 2017 of a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency with few checks and balances moves the country one step closer to one-man rule by Mr Erdogan.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and the AKP will win the next presidential and parliamentary elections, completing the transfer of executive powers to Mr Erdogan. The elections are not due to be held until late 2019, but they could be called earlier-once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place-if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency. Emergency rule, which was introduced following the failed coup, will continue to be used to silence government critics and disable the pro-Kurdish opposition. Emergency rule will remain in place until at least late July 2017, and probably beyond.
Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and jihadi extremists affiliated with Islamic State (IS). Turkey risks be-coming mired in the Syrian conflict, following the deployment of Turkish troops to Syria to combat IS and to halt the territorial expansion by Syrian Kurds.
With the government preoccupied with domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges, we expect little progress on economic reforms to improve the business and investor climate. Fiscal policy will be loosened to try to boost the economy, but we expect it to remain relatively tight during the forecast period.
We expect the Central Bank of Turkey to tighten monetary policy further in the short to medium term in order to re-assert its independence from political pressure to lower interest rates, and at the same time to prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates.
We expect real GDP growth to accelerate slightly, from 3% in 2016 to 3.2% in 2017 and a still moderate 3.6% annual average in 2018-21. The current-account deficit has narrowed, but will still be difficult to fund, especially if global liquidity is tightened.

Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2017-21), but the country's global ranking deteriorates by 12 places. There is now uncertainty regarding the future direction of economic policies. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment. The main shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening-up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in key sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade following the lifting of Russian sanctions. Possible increase in protectionism under the new US administration.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU might be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements might come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Monetary policy remains cautious amid concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality. The Central Bank of Turkey and commercial banks remain under political pressure to keep interest rates low.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. A 30% minimum-wage rise in 2016 could damage competitiveness. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Gaps and bottlenecks might, nevertheless, persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then, Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western/EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened under the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government, which will come into effect by late 2019. Since the failed coup power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has remained prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup has highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which allowed, with the AKP's consent until 2013, the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage remain widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2016 goods exports (fob) came to US$150bn and imports (fob) to US$191bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$40.8bn-a contraction from US$48.1bn in 2015. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Since the failed coup by parts of the military in July 2016 there has been a rapid deterioration in Turkey's political outlook, and this looks set to continue. The president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) are steadily tightening their grip on power. This is undermining Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures and exacerbating the already deep social and political polarisation of the country. In a referendum on April 16th a set of constitutional changes designed to replace Turkey's parliamentary system of government with an executive presidency were approved. This moves the country one step closer to one-man rule by Mr Erdogan. The president will not be deterred by the narrow margin of victory in the referendum or allegations of vote fraud by individuals close to the "yes" camp. Given the control that Mr Erdogan and his ruling AKP have over Turkey's institutions, it is highly unlikely that bids to nullify the referendum result will succeed. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that Mr Erdogan and the AKP will win the next presidential and parliamentary elections, completing the transfer of executive powers with few checks and balances to Mr Erdogan. These elections are not due to be held until 2019, but they could be called earlier, once the institutions and instruments of the new presidential system are in place, if Mr Erdogan decides to accelerate the transfer of executive powers to the presidency.
Given the close referendum result and the allegations of vote fraud we expect political instability to persist in Turkey, which is likely to delay further economic reform efforts, hamper economic recovery and damage the country's already fragile relations with the EU. Immediately after the referendum the government announced the extension for another three months, to late July 2017, of the state of emergency law that was introduced in response to the failed coup. Emergency rule allows the president and the cabinet to pass laws without the approval of parliament and without recourse to the Constitutional Court, effectively allowing Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers until the new system of government is in place. Emergency rule was initially introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of a US-based Islamic cleric, Fethullah Gulen, who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More than 100,000 people, mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media, have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to end an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections will be held in early November 2019 at the latest. We expect Mr Erdogan to win the presidential election and to remain in office, with enhanced powers, for at least one more five-year term, if not two (the maximum allowed), up to 2029. His popularity is unrivalled, while the opposition is fragmented and lacks candidates capable of challenging him. In 2014 Mr Erdogan won the presidential election in the first round with just over 50% of the vote, well ahead of a joint candidate presented by the two main opposition parties, the Republican People's Party (CHP) and the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The MHP's support in parliament for the AKP's presidential reform makes it unlikely that either of the two parties would consider fielding a joint candidate at the next election.
The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) since mid-2015, the MHP leadership's decision to back the presidential reform, and the hardline nationalist stance adopted by Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have a considerable effect on voting patterns at the next parliamentary election. Both the MHP and the HDP have been weakened since the 2015 elections and run the risk of falling below the high 10% national vote threshold for representation in parliament, which would help to boost the AKP's share of seats. As a result of the constitutional changes approved in the presidential reform referendum, there will be 600 seats in a much weakened parliament from the next election, up from 550 currently.
The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, Turkey's traditional Western allies, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's international relations.
Tensions with the EU escalated to new highs during the presidential reform referendum campaign and are unlikely to ease in the near future given Mr Erdogan's narrow win and allegations of vote fraud. Neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the bloc any more, but neither has yet been willing to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested since the failed coup, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. Our baseline forecast has been that the death penalty is unlikely to be reinstated, but this cannot be ruled out given the government's increasingly hardline nationalist stance. The suspension of accession negotiations would almost certainly prompt Tukey to end its collaboration with the EU to stem the inflow of migrants and refugees into Europe. An agreement on a solution to end the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but we believe that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
The Turkish government's expectations of a reset of ties with the US under the administration of the new US president, Donald Trump, have so far proven unrealistic, causing growing frustration in the Turkish government. Although Mr Trump's administration is less concerned about Mr Erdogan's autocratic tendencies than its Democrat predecessor was, Mr Trump is unlikely to do much to address the two issues that are of most concern to Turkey: its request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey for his alleged responsibility for the failed coup; and an end to US support for the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG), which is fighting IS in Syria and is affiliated with the PKK.
Since mid-2016 Turkey has improved its ties with Russia, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both countries are militarily involved but are pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional and the risk of new tensions emerging will remain high.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
We expect political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity as a result of anticipated shifts in US monetary policy to pose an ongoing risk to foreign capital inflows to Turkey, especially in the first half of the forecast period. These are predominantly portfolio investments and short-term loans needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, so tend to be highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows since November 2016 have put the lira under intense pressure, fuelling inflation expectations and highlighting the need for the Central Bank of Turkey to tighten monetary policy after a prolonged period of loosening. An abrupt tightening of policy could strangle Turkey's already fragile economic growth.
The economy has shown considerable resilience during past bouts of volatility in global liquidity, owing largely to the country's solid public finances and well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector. However, Turkey's medium-term economic policy outlook remains a cause for concern. The AKP government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts in December 2016 have helped to improve the country's budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios. The public finances are in good shape and our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to maintain a low level of public debt, and to try to avoid fuelling another surge in domestic demand and a further expansion of the still large current-account deficit. Reflecting the impact of the economy's weakness and increased public spending since the failed coup, we expect the central government deficit to widen moderately, from 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 1.9% of GDP per year in 2017-21. The government debt/GDP ratio is low, but it edged up slightly, to 29.4% in 2016, from 29.1% in 2015. We expect a further moderate increase in 2017-19, before it declines to about 30% in 2021. However, the risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out. The government's decision to transfer Turkey's major state assets to a sovereign wealth fund set up in 2016 to help to finance major infrastructure projects could bring to a halt the government's privatisation programme and increase political control over state companies, and the fund could become a vehicle for increased off-budget spending.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
We expect that in the coming months the central bank will have to tighten monetary policy further in order to re-assert its independence from political pressure to lower interest rates to revive economic activity, and at the same time to prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates. We expect the bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. Having steadily lowered interest rates in May-September 2016, the central bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little-used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was raised by a total of 200 basis points, to 11.75%, in mid-March. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen from 7.8% to about 11.5% in the first half of April 2017.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, the one-week repurchase lending rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy de-cisions. However, it is unlikely that the corridor will be eliminated until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases. From 2017 the bank will hold only eight regular Monetary Policy Committee meetings annually rather than 12.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Domestic political instability, perceived security risks from terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook will have negative effects on the economy in the short and medium term. We expect real GDP growth to pick up only modestly, from 3% in 2016 to 3.2% in 2017. In 2018-21 we expect real GDP growth to average 3.6% per year, assuming that there is a gradual stabilisation of domestic conditions. By far the biggest risk to our growth forecast is the possibility of a severe disruption to capital inflows to Turkey.
We expect moderate private consumption growth in 2017-21 as domestic political uncertainty, a weaker lira and high unemployment will partially offset the impact of the 30% minimum wage rise in 2016, government pressure on banks to ease lending conditions for households and government incentives to support demand for certain household durable goods.
After expanding by 7.7% in 2016, we expect government spending to increase by just under 8% per year on average in 2017-19 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support ahead of the 2019 elections. From 2020 we expect more moderate-but still solid-growth.
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to dampen fixed investment growth in 2017-18, as weakened business sentiment and a more cautious approach by foreign investors will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast an acceleration to average annual growth of 4.9%, assuming a less volatile domestic and global environment.
After contracting by 1.9% in 2016 as a result of the impact of Russian sanctions and domestic security concerns, especially on the tourism sector, we expect exports of goods and services gradually to return to growth, reflecting the lifting of sanctions and the impact of a weaker lira on export competitiveness. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter visitors to Turkey. Our expectation is that a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. We expect further currency weakness and a partial recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank tightens monetary policy and does not loosen it too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile and generally on a depreciating path against all major currencies since September 2016. Amid further bouts of volatility we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar to an annual average of TL3.73:US$1 in 2017, a fall of 19%. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL4.07:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, and the impact on investor confidence of domestic political instability and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
GDP revisions, moderate domestic demand growth, sharply lower global oil prices and a weaker lira have helped to reduce Turkey's current-account deficit in recent years. However, we expect it to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large-at a forecast average of 5% of GDP per year in 2017-21-to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and the loss of investor confidence since the failed coup persists. Although a weaker lira will boost Turkey's main export sectors, we expect this to be largely offset by the higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. In addition, the tourism sector is likely to take several years to recover to 2015 pre-crisis levels-before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
Donald Trump, the new US president, has expressed a desire to improve relations with Russia. However, the likelihood of a significant rapprochement has declined following a US strike on a Syrian airbase in early April.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects US and EU sectoral sanctions on the Russian defence, energy and financial sectors to remain in place in the medium term. Russian counter sanctions on Western food imports will also remain in place indefinitely.
Despite a reduction in fighting in Ukraine, we do not expect the Minsk II deal to lead to a comprehensive political settlement. Ukraine will not regain full control of its border with Russia.
Russia is likely to remain a mobilisation economy, characterised by high spending on the defence sector, a cautious approach to foreign investment in many sectors, protectionism and a large role for the state in the economy.
Formal political opposition to the regime will remain marginal. Vladimir Putin, the president, is likely to run again for president in March 2018 and win with a large majority in the first round. The principal concern for the authorities will be to maintain a high turnout in the absence of a meaningful contest.
The government is unlikely to implement disruptive market reforms. Minority stakes in some major state enterprises will be sold off. Chinese companies are likely to take a bigger role in the economy, including in the extractive sector.
Despite pressure to maintain defence and welfare spending, the government will cut public expenditure in 2017-19 to keep the budget deficit under control. The budget deficit will narrow to under 2% of GDP by 2019, from 3.5% of GDP in 2016.
The economy contracted by 0.2% in 2016. We have revised up our forecast for growth in 2017, and now project it will expand by 1.8%, supported by higher oil prices and improving consumer confidence. Investment will remain relatively weak, and public spending will be tightened further.
The medium-term growth outlook will be constrained by structural weaknesses, including a lack of competition, high state involvement in the economy, an ageing and declining workforce, and weak rule of law. We forecast average annual GDP growth of 1.7% per year in 2017-21.

Russia falls by two places in our regional ranking in the forecast period (2017-21), to 15th out of 16 countries. This reflects manifold institutional weaknesses, poor rule of law, high levels of corruption and extensive state involvement in the economy. It falls to 69th out of 82 countries in our global ranking.
Country forecast overview: Russia's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisation plans will proceed slowly, despite the announcement in 2016 of a new privatisation drive.
2019-21: Overall state involvement in the economy remains high. Government interference in private companies remains arbitrary. Rent-seeking officials remain a burden on business. Protection of intellectual property rights may weaken.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: International sanctions and low energy prices discourage major new investment in the oil and gas sectors.
2019-21: The "pivot to the east" will lead to further moderate growth in investment from Asia.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Some US sanctions may be relaxed. Membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is effectively suspended. The Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) internal market is undermined by exemptions and weak enforcement.
2019-21: The difficulty of trading across borders continues to be a weakness. The Russian ban on Western agricultural imports is likely to remain in force.
Taxes
2017-18: The resources tax on gas and the tax on tobacco rise. The freeze on the tax on vodka is extended. Direct taxes on in-dividuals and value-added tax (VAT) will not be raised, and the government may issue VAT concessions to selected sectors.
2019-21: A progressive consumption tax may be introduced. Tax inspections remain a burden on business. The time that it takes to pay taxes approximates to international norms. There are some specific improvements in the corporate tax regime.
Financing
2017-18: International sanctions limit access to external capital markets, significantly raising the cost of financing.
2019-21: International financial integration proceeds slowly. The banking system remains weak and state dominated. The government maintains its commitment to bail out systemically important institutions.
The labour market
2017-18: Spending on education is cut further. The incidence of strikes increases slightly, although the labour movement remains weak.
2019-21: The indigenous labour force will steadily decline, however the impact will be offset in some sectors by continued substantial immigration from the Commonwealth of Independent States, much of it unskilled.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Budget constraints curb investment in infrastructure. Politically important projects are prioritised, but even here cuts are made. Russia struggles to obtain international funding for its infrastructure projects. Roads are starved of funding.
2019-21: It remains difficult to secure foreign finance. China provides only a limited alternative to Western funding.

Background: The transition to a market economy in the early 1990s was accompanied by a collapse in industrial production and a sharp drop in living standards. A contested privatisation process led to a highly concentrated ownership structure. Executive weakness and bureaucratic dysfunction contributed to a sharp decentralisation of power. After becoming president in 2000, Vladimir Putin sought to restore central control over the regions and tame independent corporate interests. Mr Putin presided over a period of strong economic growth in his first two terms. His re-election as president in 2012 has heralded the development of a more authoritarian domestic environment.
Political structure: Boris Yeltsin won the first democratic presidential election in June 1991 and was re-elected in July 1996. Repeated confrontations with the legislature culminated in the dissolution of parliament in September 1993 and a violent showdown the following month. The powers of the executive were greatly increased by a new constitution, adopted in 1993. Mr Putin was elected in March 2000 and re-elected for a second term in March 2004. Mr Putin's second term in office was characterised by increasing centralisation of the state. A loyal ally, Dmitry Medvedev, won the presidential election in March 2008 and took over in May of that year. Mr Putin returned to the presidency for a third term in May 2012. Following a constitutional change, his term will last six years, to 2018.
Policy issues: Mr Putin's third term as president has seen a greater emphasis on "conservative cultural values", anti-Westernism and great-power nationalism. The stand-off with the West is leading to a rollback of Russia's integration into the world economy. This is likely to strengthen further the state's role in the economy. Tit-for-tat sanctions have encouraged the government to focus on import substitution. The focus on curbing "foreign influence" on domestic politics is likely to endure, along with close controls on civil society, the internet and media.
Taxation: Reforms since 2000 have aimed to rationalise the tax system and cut the number of taxes and the corporate tax burden. Changes to the tax regime in January 2001 included the introduction of a flat rate of personal income tax of 13% and a simplification of the administration of social security contributions. In 2004 the basic rate of value-added tax (VAT) was reduced from 20% to 18% and a regional 5% sales tax was abolished. The corporate tax rate was cut from 24% to 20% at the beginning of 2009. The government has pledged not to raise personal or consumption taxes before 2018.
Foreign trade: Mainly because of high international oil prices, export revenue has soared since 2000. Import growth picked up over the same period as a result of rising real incomes and real rouble appreciation. Merchandise exports totalled just over US$280bn in 2016 and imports were just over US$190bn. Oil and gas account for over two-thirds of Russia's exports, with metals contributing around one-tenth.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Vladimir Putin's third presidential term, which began in 2012, has seen a shift towards "conservative cultural values", a more authoritarian political culture and more overt anti­Westernism. This has been further consolidated by Russia's confrontation with the West over Ukraine. Despite some pro-market rhetoric, economic policy has grown more statist and protectionist. The leadership is preoccupied by the need to insulate the economy and society from foreign-in particular Western-influence and the perceived threat of externally sponsored regime change. However, the regime is characterised by ideological flexibility and is more adaptable than many observers acknowledge. If the external environment allows (a major caveat), it is possible that the leadership will devote greater attention to domestic issues and welfare after the 2018 presidential election and attempt to implement a more liberal economic agenda. Concern about political stability is likely to hold the government back from pursuing radical reform.
The forecast period (2017-21) is likely to be characterised by relatively slow growth in living standards, following a major decline in 2015-16, and further cuts in public expenditure in many areas. This contrasts sharply with the rapid growth achieved in Mr Putin's first decade in power and could have unpredict-able effects on stability in the medium term. However, there currently seems to be little desire for disruptive reform among the broader population, and the potential for mass protest or major political change from below appears to be low. Social controls have been tightened since 2012, and the opposition has been marginalised and demoralised. Protests regularly occur across the country, but these tend to be focused on single issues; the cost for individuals and activists of collective action focused on broader political change remains high. The government tends to respond constructively when confronted with specific economic grievances. A mixture of state support and administrative pressure will keep major enterprises operating in provincial industrial towns.
The political system leans heavily on the charismatic leadership and popularity of Mr Putin. The weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the personalised, opaque governance system around Mr Putin, could present difficulties in managing an eventual presidential transition. Any successor is likely to come from the team around Mr Putin and will not herald a sharp change in the policy agenda. However, it may be difficult for any successor to build popular legitimacy given the weak economic outlook. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a political transition in the forecast period. Speculation about an eventual succession strategy is likely to intensify soon after the 2018 presidential election, however, and this will further depress business confidence and raise political uncertainty.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next presidential election will take place in March 2018. We expect Mr Putin to contest the election and win by a wide margin in the first round. Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption blogger and nationalist opposition politician, will be barred from participating in the presidential election following a second conviction for defrauding Kirovles, a timber company. This suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, offering voters no meaningful alternatives to Mr Putin. The main challenge for the authorities will be to prevent a sharp fall in turnout, which would throw doubt on the legitimacy of Mr Putin's popular mandate. This is one of the reasons behind the efforts to revitalise the regional leadership with the replacement of poorly performing governors.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
The Ukraine conflict has led to a sharp deterioration in Russia's relations with the West since 2014. In response to the conflict in Ukraine, the US and the EU have imposed sanctions on senior Russian officials and the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors. Russia has responded with a ban on almost all Western food imports.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a comprehensive political resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. The constitutional reform mandated by the agreement, which could formally embed Russia's proxies within Ukraine's political system, is politically toxic in Ukraine. In the highly unlikely event that it is passed, there is little chance that Russia will allow Ukraine to re-establish control of its side of the international border. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests, even though the second of these remains unlikely. Russia will not step back from its long-term objective of preventing a pro-Western govern-ment from consolidating in Ukraine. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, appears likely to endure for several years.
Donald Trump, the new US president, has voiced scepticism about US alliances in Europe, expressed his admiration for Mr Putin and appears more amenable to forming an anti-terrorist coalition with Russia. However, it now appears unlikely that Mr Trump's plans to reconfigure relations with Russia will be realised. As anticipated, Mr Trump's stated desire for rapprochement with Russia has encountered strong resistance from the US security establishment. The links between senior figures close to Mr Trump and Russian officials have been the subject of intense media scrutiny, making it difficult for the administration to take measures perceived as offering concessions to Russia. Moreover, Mr Trump's decision to launch a strike on a Syrian airbase in early April has again set Russian and US policy on Syria-an area where Mr Trump's advisers had hoped to build co-operation-on divergent paths. We now believe it likely that US and EU sanctions will be retained in the medium term, throughout most, if not all, of the forecast period. Russian counter sanctions on Western food imports are also likely to remain in place indefinitely.
Regardless of Mr Trump's stance, Russia's broader foreign policy will remain vehemently opposed to Western integration with the countries of the former Soviet Union. Russia's policy towards its neighbours, and towards Ukraine in particular, will be an enduring source of tension with the West. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via popular uprising, would be likely to trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
With the economy set to return to growth in 2017, the constraints on macro-economic policy will ease. However, the fiscal position remains precarious. We expect the government to remain committed to a relatively tight fiscal and monetary policy to keep borrowing and inflation in check.
Economic reform will be subordinated to the imperatives of political stability and regime survival. We do not expect the government to move substantively towards liberalisation of the economy, and certainly not before the presidential election in March 2018, although some reform is possible.
A more likely scenario is that the government will seek incrementally to improve the efficiency of the system by replacing failing officials and bureau-crats, and cracking down selectively on corruption. Following the presidential election, the government is likely to extend the pension age and conduct a limited tax reform. Progress in strengthening the rule of law and protecting property rights is likely to be limited. The government will continue to sell minority stakes in some major state-controlled assets. However, as with the sale in December 2016 of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a Russian oil giant, the govern-ment's focus is on raising short-term budget revenue rather than increasing the level of competition in the economy or reducing state influence over it.
Russia's stand-off with the West has strengthened statist and protectionist trends within the government. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a strategic priority. The main elements of this strategy include a large positive sovereign external asset position (low public debt combined with substantial foreign-exchange reserves), protectionist measures to encourage import substitution and support domestic manufacturing, and a cautious approach to globalisation and foreign investment (which in "strategic sectors", such as the extractive sector, is likely to be permitted only in partnership with state-controlled companies).
Some policymakers have urged a further increase in state intervention in the economy, along with capital controls, expansionist monetary policy and a return to a fixed exchange rate. We believe that the government will continue to pursue a mixed approach, observing the broad tenets of a market economy and avoiding disruptive reforms and excessive market-distorting behaviour (such as capital controls) while maintaining a large state role in the economy.
We expect the government to remain committed to its import substitution policy, and formal and informal barriers to external trade will remain significant.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The government faces tight budget constraints as a result of international sanctions, low commodity prices and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances (although Russia succeeded in placing two Eurobonds in 2016). The deficit in 2016 was the equivalent of 3.5% of GDP; however, this included extraordinary income from the sale of a stake in Rosneft in December last year. Without this, the deficit would have been 4.4% of GDP.
Under the government's budget for 2017, spending will fall from Rb16.4trn (US$276bn) in 2016 to Rb16.2trn. This is broadly in line with the Ministry of Finance's proposal in July that spending be frozen for the next three years in nominal terms (which was based on the original expenditure target for 2016 of Rb16.1trn). Based on an average oil price of US$40/barrel in 2017, the govern-ment expects revenue to rise by 1.8%.
We forecast a higher oil price than set out in the budget, of US$56/b. This should boost revenue from the hydrocarbon sector. However, in early February the finance ministry announced that it intended to accumulate the extra tax revenue as foreign-exchange reserves, rather than transferring it directly to the budget. Overall, we forecast a deficit of 2.8% of GDP. We expect the finance ministry to continue to trim the deficit in 2018-19, but the fiscal adjustment is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly given the forthcoming presidential election. We believe that the government is unlikely to hold expenditure fixed in nominal terms in 2018-19 as planned. We forecast that the deficit will narrow to 1% of GDP by 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
At its meeting in March the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) cut its policy rate by 25 basis points, to 9.75%, having held the rate unchanged since September last year. The strong rouble, driven by higher oil prices and the carry trade, has helped to push disinflation ahead of the CBR's expectations. At its mid-April meeting, the central bank indicated that a further cut in its policy rate was possible on April 28th. We expect the CBR to reduce its policy rate to 8-8.5% by the end of the year. We expect further loosening of monetary policy in 2018. Once inflation reaches the 4% target-a goal that we expect to be achieved before the end of this year-the CBR governor, Elvira Nabiullina, has suggested that an appropriate level for the real interest rate would be about 2.5-3%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Russia's growth was decelerating even before 2014, as it ran into structural constraints. The economy experienced a sharp recession in 2015 as result of the fall in the oil price. The impact of this was masked in the headline numbers by sharp import contraction, but real household incomes declined by almost 20%. The Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat) now estimates that the economy contracted by 2.8% in 2015 and 0.2% in 2016.
We have revised up our forecast for 2017 growth to 1.8%, from 0.9% previously. Surveys suggest that consumer confidence is at its highest level since the second half of 2014, helped by the appreciation of the rouble and slowing inflation. Retail sales volumes grew by 2.4% quarter on quarter in January-March-the first quarterly increase since October-December 2014. Leading indicators for services and manufacturing have also reached levels last recorded prior to the 2015-16 recession.
Fiscal consolidation will continue to constrain public consumption and infrastructure spending. We expect a weak recovery in investment, after three years of contraction. Corporate deleveraging will slow and external financing conditions are likely to improve marginally. A relaxation of Western sanctions-not our core forecast-would provide a modest boost to investment. However, perceptions of political risk would remain high, limiting foreign direct investment (FDI) outside the commodities sector.
The stabilisation of the economy should see continued growth in investment in 2018, although it will remain relatively weak. A forecast slowdown in China will hit Russia's terms of trade, and we expect Russia's growth rate to moderate to 1.6%. The public sector will remain a drag on domestic demand.
In the medium term, outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low investment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that real GDP growth will average about 1.7% per year in 2018-21, in line with CBR estimates of Russia's trend growth under the current institutional and macroeconomic framework. There currently seems to be little prospect of far-reaching domestic institutional reform. High political risk and the poor business environment will continue to depress investment below the level needed to develop a higher trend growth rate. The declining work force will also be a constraint on headline growth, although in some sectors this will be offset by continued high immigration from the Commonwealth of Independent States.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
The CBR is aiming to reach its inflation target of 4% by the end of the year. It has a firm commitment to a relatively tight monetary policy as it aims to reach this inflation target. Inflation stood at 5.4% year on year in December 2016, but had slowed to 4.3% by March 2017. Disinflation has been assisted by a strong harvest last year and by the appreciation of the rouble. Both factors could prove to be temporary, and inflation expectations remain elevated. We forecast that consumer price inflation will average 4% in 2017 and that the CBR will more than meet its year-end target. The slowdown in China will lead to a depre-ciation of the rouble in 2018, but external inflationary pressures are likely to be relatively low. Tax changes in 2019 are expected to push up inflation slightly in that year. Overall we expect inflation to remain close to-but slightly above-target in the medium term.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Higher oil prices and relatively tight monetary policy, which has boosted the carry trade, has led to a significant appreciation of the rouble against the US dollar. It reached Rb55:8:US$1 in late April-the strongest level for almost two years. We expect the rouble to depreciate from this level in 2017 as the CBR gradually loosens monetary policy. The rouble is highly correlated with the oil price, and any rapid fall in the oil price could lead to renewed exchange-rate volatility. We forecast an average full-year rate of just under Rb60:US$1. Our forecast growth slowdown in China in 2018 will hit Russia's terms of trade, and we expect the rouble to depreciate by about 6% against the dollar on average in that year. Oil prices are forecast to be stable in 2019-21, and we therefore do not expect significant movements in the rouble-dollar rate.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
We forecast an increased current-account surplus in 2017 as higher oil prices boost the value of exports. This will be tempered by higher imports as domestic demand and investment pick up, alongside increased outflows on the primary and secondary account. We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, but a further recovery in imports will gradually reduce the size as a share of GDP. International sanctions and political uncertainty will depress FDI and portfolio inflows, although we expect these to recover in 2018-21.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is pressing ahead with a programme of economic policy adjustment in an effort to eliminate distortions and return the economy to sustainable growth. The adjustment process is proving difficult, involving politically unpopular austerity measures, and the risk of social unrest will therefore remain significant for much of the forecast period.
Given the president's minority position in Congress, and the priority given to urgent macroeconomic reforms, there is likely to be only limited progress on the pursuit of legislation that would successfully address longstanding institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Comprehensive reforms to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. Furthermore, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect meaningful advances-at least in the short term-on a structural reform agenda (incorporating tax and labour market reform) that could improve long-term potential growth rates.
After a contraction in real GDP in 2016, reflecting macroeconomic policy tightening and currency depreciation, we are forecasting a pick-up in exports, investment and private consumption in the medium term. There will be a boost in business confidence from policy tightening. Combined with macroeconomic adjustment, and a gradual removal of foreign-exchange and import controls, these policies should set the economy on a more solid long-term footing. However, some aspects of the policymaking environment will remain suboptimal, with labour-market reform and a comprehensive fiscal reform remaining low on the agenda.
Currency adjustment should gradually bolster the current account as a weaker peso starts to boost goods and services exports and rein in imports. On this basis, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow in 2017-21 from the 2016 peak. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve over the forecast period, assuming that capital inflows pick up as investor confidence in the Macri administration grows.
Argentina's GDP per head is still among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Argentina's global business environment score improves substantially in 2017-21, and the country jumps 20 places in our global ranking. A period of economic policy adjustment is under way as the centre-right government works to tighten macroeconomic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. However, in many areas improve-ments will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2019-21: Continued work to build confidence in legal and regulatory framework. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2017-18: Efforts to resolve any remaining disputes with international creditors and investors as the government seeks fresh sources of US dollar inflows.
2019-21: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Any remaining foreign-exchange controls likely to be removed. Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance.
2019-21: Possibility that free-trade agreements make better progress.
Taxes
2017-18: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax system remains complex and burdensome.
2019-21: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist.
Financing
2017-18: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2019-21: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2017-18: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of the unions will remain strong.
2019-21: Progress on labour reform unlikely. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The Macri administration works to address weak contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes, which keep private investment below potential. Financing constraints hamper public investment in the short term.
2019-21: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
