a Economist Intelligence Unit estimates. b Actual.
Background: Economic liberalisation in the 1990s resulted in firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and failure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Peronist party began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanagement drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983 after 50 years of instability and military regimes. A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances in the economy in the form of double-digit inflation, real peso appreciation and a deterioration of the balance of payments. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to foreign-exchange, import and capital controls, as well as ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to reduce economic distortions and set the economy on a more solid long-term footing are taking place under Mr Macri; these include peso devaluation, and fiscal and monetary tightening. Microeconomic reforms to boost domestic supply are also getting under way.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals). Taxes on exports were reintroduced in 2002, and have since been expanded to account for around 20% of total revenue.
Foreign trade: The current account shifted from surplus to deficit in 2010. Despite comprehensive controls, there was a current-account deficit of 2.7% of GDP in 2015.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The political scene is becoming more complicated as voter fatigue with austerity measures increases and patience with adjustment measures wears thin. Increase obstructionism on the part of public-sector unions in recent weeks is unsur-prising amid annual wage bargaining negotiations that are taking place in the run-up to mid-term legislative elections in October. More of a concern for the president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is the continued perception of voters that adjustment is not bringing about obvious rapid improvements in the economy. Various economic indicat-ors suggest that the economy is indeed emerging from recession, but consumers are not yet feeling the benefit in terms of higher real wages or increased employment.
We do not expect Mr Macri to change course and abandon the adjustment process that he has pursued since taking office for a four-year term in late 2015. This process has involved devaluation, fiscal and monetary tightening, and sharp tariff adjustments. In this environment, voter weariness with austerity, combined with the approach of mid-term legislative elections in October, will in the short term complicate relations with Congress, where the president lacks a majority. The ruling Cambiemos alliance, which includes the Pro and the centre-left Unión Cívica Radical, has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda in both houses of Congress on an ad hoc basis with the various factions of the large Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party). So far this support has mainly been forthcoming, not least because the largest opposition force, the leftist-populist faction of the Peronist party, known as the Frente para la Victoria (FV), has been weakened by a series of damaging corruption scandals.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects obstructionism to increase amid election-related politicking ahead of the October 2017 mid-terms, and as the October 2019 presidential election approaches. But mutual interest will ensure some co-operation between Cambiemos and moderate Peronists. A strong executive branch (the president has substantial powers to rule by decree) should also provide Mr Macri with room for manoeuvre, even assuming that Congress becomes less co-operative. The president will retain influence with powerful provincial governors, who largely control the Senate agenda but are in turn deeply reliant on central government transfers, some of which are discretionary. As a result, we expect some continued progress on the govern-ment agenda.
However, we assume that with electoral considerations coming into play, there will be limited progress on legislation that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Compre-hensive efforts to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption, or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. We do not expect meaningful advances on a structural reform agenda.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
Mr Macri's Pro party is small but increasingly influential. Apart from the presidency, it now controls the governments of Buenos Aires city and province, which together account for almost half of the population. However, the Pro is in a minority position in both houses of Congress, and although it may make some gains in mid-term legislative elections in October 2017, it is likely to remain in a minority position throughout the forecast period, given the dominance of the Peronist party in national politics and its strong grassroots presence. However, the Peronist party is split into various competing factions. Having lost the powers of patronage bestowed on it by the presidency, and amid its struggles with corruption allegations, the leftist-populist FV wing of the party will lose influence and the position of the traditional Peronist wing will improve, leaving it well placed to make gains at the expense of the FV in the 2017 mid-term elections.
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and a return to single-digit inflation by then, we currently expect Mr Macri to win a second four-year term. There are substantial risks to this forecast, given the challenging external environment and the government's minority position in Congress. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has ever won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. In this context, the emergence of a strong challenger from the moderate wing of the Peronist party is a strong possibility and the election will be closely fought.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Efforts by the Macri administration to repair relations with trade and investment partners have achieved rapid results, and we expect relations with key trade partners in the region and elsewhere to remain strong, with the possible exception of the US. Like most other governments in Latin America, the Macri administration was wrong-footed by the victory of Donald Trump in the US presidential election in November 2016. After cultivating increasingly strong ties with the previous US administration, led by Barack Obama, Mr Macri is likely to abandon recent efforts to secure preferential trade ties with the US with a view to an eventual free-trade agreement. The Argentinian government will remain keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended from the group in 2016). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, free trade has shifted off the political agenda not only in the US but also in Europe. Mr Macri recently visited Spain in an effort to drum up support for the deal, and negotiations are continuing. Our forecasts do not currently assume a successful conclusion of free-trade talks with the EU, but the workings of intra-Mercosur trade are, at least, likely to improve in the forecast period. Efforts at joining the Pacific Alliance, a regional trading bloc that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico, may also make progress, although this is not currently reflected in our five-year economic forecasts.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
The Macri administration has made good initial progress on a pro-gramme of adjustment intended to put the economy on a sounder footing, having devalued the peso, reduced agricultural export duties and energy subsidies, and secured a deal with holdout creditors (allowing Argentina to exit default). However, macroeconomic adjustment remains incomplete, and policy efforts to reduce inflation, which remained substantially over 30% in March, will continue, in the form of tight fiscal and monetary policy and restraint in nominal wage growth. The latter in particular is proving a difficult political challenge, and has encountered stiff union resistance. Some slippage on the government's goal of limiting nominal wage growth to 20% this year appears likely, but we do continue to expect nominal wages to trend downward steadily from levels of above 30% in recent years. All these measures should gradually engender price stability and ultimately boost investor confidence, although we do not expect inflation to fall to single-digit levels until 2019.
With macroeconomic adjustment measures proceeding apace, the government is gradually turning its attention to the structural reform agenda and to reforms to improve the business environment, and we expect a growing policy emphasis on these areas. The government has already passed new public-private partnership framework legislation that should facilitate an increase in infrastructure investment, along with reforms to reduce red tape financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. The development of longer-term finance and the deepening of Argentina's currently shallow capital markets will be a priority going forward. However, other aspects of the policymaking environ-ment will remain suboptimal, with progress on labour market reform (to improve flexibility) or comprehensive fiscal and tax reform (to reduce costs and complexity) unlikely in the medium term amid political obstruction.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Higher-than-expected revenue from a tax amnesty on undeclared foreign assets will bolster the fiscal accounts and bring the government closer to meeting its fiscal targets. We expect the overall fiscal deficit to come in at 4.2% of GDP in 2017, slightly below the 4.5% of GDP registered in 2016. We expect the government's gradualist approach to fiscal tightening to continue in subsequent years, bringing the fiscal deficit down to a more manageable level of around 2% of GDP by the end of the forecast period, and eliminating the primary deficit by 2021. To date, the govern-ment has taken some important steps to try to narrow the deficit, particularly by reducing costly subsidies and the public-sector payroll. Even so, in the light of recently announced income-tax breaks and increased transfers (to expand the social safety net), deficit reduction will be slow. There are also downside risks to our forecasts, which rest on two key assumptions: that expenditure as a share of GDP will fall by slightly over 1 percentage point (reflecting a smaller public-sector workforce, a further drop in subsidies and a reduction in the deficits of state companies); and that revenue will increase by around 1 percentage point in the same period (assuming that recent tax cuts are more than offset by a pick-up in revenue from trade and increased economic activity).
In the aftermath of the holdout deal, and assuming that there is progress on deficit reduction, the government's ability to finance moderate deficits without resorting to inflationary money printing will be much improved. A moderate public debt/GDP ratio (and low levels of external indebtedness), combined with the attractiveness of Argentina's still-high yields, should facilitate international bond issuance in 2017-21, following Argentina's exit from default earlier this year. In January the sovereign issued US$7bn in five- and ten-year global bonds. As a percentage of GDP, the public debt will stabilise at slightly under 50% in 2017-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Notwithstanding a recent policy reversal, which saw the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) lift the policy rate from 24.75% to 26.25% in April, we continue to expect fairly substantial rate cuts in the second half of 2017 and beyond. The policy rate is well down on the year-earlier peak of 38%, but inflation has been slow to come down amid a series of tariff increases, and inflation expectations have been rising as a result, to slightly over 21% at end-2017, well above the central bank's 12-17% target range for this year. The BCRA has responded with what we expect to be a one-off rate rise to make its commitment to the newly implemented inflation-targeting framework clear. Assuming that monthly inflation starts to fall towards 1% on a consistent basis, we expect ample scope for renewed monetary easing from later this year.
The Bank has made clear that it will prioritise monetary policy that is consistent with a reduction of inflation, and our forecasts assume moderately positive real interest rates in the medium term, consistent with a deepening of credit and the development of long-term lending. This forecast is supported by the shift to an inflation-targeting regime (with the target due to be lowered to 8-12% in 2018 and to 5% in 2019), and assumes reduced political interference after a period of politicisation under the previous administration.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
After a contraction in real GDP of 2.3% in 2016, we expect real GDP to return to positive territory in 2017. But with Brazil likely to post barely positive growth in 2017, manufacturing activity in Argentina will recover only moderately, limiting GDP growth to 2.7%. We currently expect the recovery to peak in 2018, with growth of 3.6%. However, the annual growth rate for that year masks an expected sequential deceleration in the second half of 2018, resulting from a projected weakening of Chinese import demand. By 2019, when we project a cyclical downturn in the US economy, real GDP growth in Argentina will slide back below 3%, before a modest recovery takes hold again in 2020-21.
Our forecast for a still relatively robust recovery in the medium term is based on the assumption that a combination of macroeconomic adjustment and improvements to the business environment will eventually have some beneficial impact on both export activity and domestic demand. An easing of inflation, combined with efforts by the Macri government to address the problem of legal and regulatory uncertainty and reduce red tape, should set the stage for renewed strong growth in fixed investment and private consumption, supporting an acceleration of GDP growth.
There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to reduce economic distortions and engineer a smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging, keeping both con-sump-tion and investment subdued for longer than we expect. However, there is also some upside risk, as investment could overtake expectations from 2017 once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and depending on the success of efforts to improve the framework for doing business. However, even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform efforts than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than 4%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
The Macri administration introduced a new consumer price index in May 2016 to address widespread concerns about the quality of official data. However, because of a lack of historical data to provide a full picture of 12-month inflation trends, for the time being we are continuing to use the Buenos Aires city consumer price index as a proxy for inflation at the national level. This showed 12-month inflation of 35% in March 2017. Although high, this does represent a steep fall from a peak of 44.4% in May 2016, which resulted from currency and tariff adjust-ments by the new administration. Assuming tight monetary and fiscal policy (spending will remain negative in real terms until 2018), the inflationary spike will prove transitory, and we expect gradual disinflation in the medium term, provided domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11 and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environ-ment for agricultural producers. The main risks to this forecast stem from possible failure to tighten fiscal policy as projected, a weaker than expected peso and the difficult process of reining in nominal wage growth. However, if the government is able to tackle the high level of wage indexation (a key obstacle to the reduction of inflation towards OECD levels), there is also the potential for inflation to slow more than we currently project.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Owing mainly to increased portfolio inflows, the peso has appreciated in 2017, standing at around Ps15.2:US$1 in late April. We expect renewed modest weakening in 2017-21, particularly in the first half of the forecast period as domestic interest rates continue to decline and the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) continues a monetary tightening cycle. However, the positive outlook for portfolio and foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will be supportive of the currency, which will dampen depreciation pressure and produce some periods of real currency appreciation (as has occurred in recent months). In nominal terms, we expect the peso to end 2017 at Ps17.78US$1 and 2021 at Ps23.61US$1.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
As the terms of trade improve and a weaker peso gradually boosts goods and services exports, improvements in the trade and services accounts will cause the current-account deficit to narrow. From 2.6% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to fall to an annual average 1.2% of GDP in 2017-21. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve, assuming that portfolio and FDI inflows pick up as investor confidence in the Macri administration grows. The result will be a rise in foreign reserves in nominal terms. Our forecasts currently assume FDI inflows averaging 2% of GDP in 2017-21, with foreign reserves equivalent to an annual average 8.1 months of import cover in the same period.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The struggle between an opposition-dominated legislature and a government with control of key institutions will keep tension high and sustain uncertainty regarding The Economist Intelligence Unit's political and economic forecasts. Despite the unpopularity of the administration led by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), and the persistent risk of economic collapse, we believe that the government will muddle through until the next elections are held in December 2018, after which we expect the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática coalition to take office. That said, a risk exists that the PSUV will seek non-democratic ways to cling to power.
A fundamental rebalancing of the economy is needed to avoid default and economic collapse, but there has been no sign of significant economic reform. Policy mismanagement will persist while Mr Maduro remains in office. Key problems include extremely expansionary macroeconomic policy, soaring inflation and a business climate that discourages investment. A new government will begin a gradual process of adjustment from 2019.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the PSUV on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and triple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, while the increasingly difficult operating environment will deepen the fall in fixed investment. After a deep recession in 2016, GDP will contract further in 2017 and will not return to growth until 2020. Our forecast for a weak recovery in 2020-21 rests on the assumption of an increase in oil prices and a new government that implements macroeconomic adjustment alongside institutional and structural reform. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, and our forecasts imply only a partial recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production in 2017, and only a very minor increase from 2018 as economic conditions stabilise.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 79th position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2017-21, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela moves ahead of Cuba to 11th place of the 12 countries covered, assuming improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under a new government, but actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection remains weak.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves gradually, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Risk of tax increases diminishes, given the depressed state of public consumption. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance is in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed 1992 coup. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática took control of the legislature, but has since met fierce opposition from other branches of government dominated by the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus fell from US$27.2bn in 2014 to US$768m in 2015. The current-account balance is estimated to have turned negative in 2015, posting a 4.3% of GDP deficit. The deficit is estimated to have narrowed to 2% of GDP in 2016, owing to import compression.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Amid the most severe economic crisis in the country's history, Venezuela's political scene will remain dominated by a volatile power struggle between the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) government, led by the president, Nicolás Maduro, and the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD), which won a majority in the National Assembly in late 2015. Opposition efforts to unseat Mr Maduro by legal means and through negotiations mediated by the Vatican before the next elections, which are due to be held in December 2018, have floundered amid tight government control of key institutions, including the government-controlled judiciary, which has effectively eliminated the National Assembly's powers. In addition, an increased role for the military in economic policymaking will bolster Mr Maduro's position, even if it comes at the expense of his own influence in government. Mr Maduro has handed substantial policymaking powers to the vice-president, Tareck El Aissami, a PSUV hardliner who is seen as being close to the army.
There remains a risk of an early (and chaotic) transition, which would be triggered if default occurs and/or hyperinflation takes hold, and intensifying social unrest causes military support for the PSUV to wane. But The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to muddle through until the December 2018 elections, in which the opposition MUD would be the clear favourite. However, there is a high risk that the PSUV, with the backing of the allied armed forces, will cling to power by non-democratic means, for instance by declaring an economic emergency as a justification for preventing the holding of presidential elections. Recent developments suggest this risk is growing-the Supreme Court recently issued a ruling that formally took over the powers of the National Assembly. Although it partially backtracked, this episode and others indicate that the government has little regard for democratic procedures. However, our current forecasts are based on the assumption that the December 2018 elections will go ahead, and that the MUD will win, taking power in 2019. A MUD-led government will implement economic adjustments to reduce the role of the state in the economy, and unravel the many macroeconomic and monetary distortions that the PSUV has implemented since it came to power in 1999. It will also begin the difficult task of reforming deeply politicised institutions. Given the scale of the economic distortion and institutional destruction that have taken place in Venezuela, there is a risk that this process will go less smoothly than we are currently forecasting.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The electoral authorities are obligating political parties that secured less than 1% of the popular vote in at least 12 states in the December 2015 legislative election to re-register-in effect, all parties (59) aside from the ruling PSUV will have to do so. To remain in existence, opposition parties are required to secure the signatures of at least 0.5% of the electoral roll in at least 12 states, a criterion that is likely to force many small parties to fold. Some members and politicians will join other parties in the opposition MUD coalition, which is a broad church of anti-PSUV parties. But the process will cause some tension and the MUD may well emerge as a weakened political force. The opposition Primero Justicia has announced that Henrique Capriles-twice a defeated presidential candidate and the current governor of Miranda state-will seek to contest the December 2018 presidential election. Given that the MUD coalition is likely to select its candidate through a primary election, Mr Capriles's candidacy is not assured, but he currently is the frontrunner. The PSUV is unlikely to be re-elected, but there is a risk that it will use non-democratic means (requiring the backing of the military) to remain in power. We assume that the MUD will form the next government and retain control of the legislature, allowing it to pass its agenda, although weak institutional capacity and high political tension will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Venezuela's relations with its neighbours will remain strained while the PSUV is in office, and the election of Donald Trump as US president will sustain underlying bilateral tensions. PSUV governments have periodically stoked animosity towards the US in order to drum up nationalist support, but the Trump administration is more likely than any of its recent predecessors to react to this with economic measures such as a cut in oil imports, which would hit Venezuela hard. This appears to have encouraged Mr Maduro to tone down his anti-US rhetoric so far, but tension would escalate if the PSUV government were to cling to power by suspending the December 2018 elections, which is a risk. Mr Maduro will seek closer ties with China, but further financial support is unlikely to be forthcoming in the short term. Reflecting its external financing difficulties, Venezuela will continue to scale back-and possibly end-oil shipments to beneficiaries of PetroCaribe, an agreement that provides cheap financing for oil exports to regional allies. Relations with Cuba, the closest of these allies, will become more distant as Venezuela's ability to provide economic assistance is eroded. Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) suspended Venezuela in December 2016 and members of the Organisation of American States are likely to suspend Venezuela too, highlighting a growing international consensus over the need to reprimand the government. Nevertheless, relations with Colombia have improved; Venezuela has recently permitted passage through some border crossings to allow its citizens to buy food and medicine in Colombia.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
It seems increasingly unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without some sort of policy adjustment between now and the presidential election. In the absence of other alternatives, we assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017 and 2018 than it did last year. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or unable to adjust policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policy will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy interventionism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Slightly higher oil prices will bring some relief, but import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. At US$10.4bn in early April, international reserves remain far below historical levels, and are only about two-thirds of their end-2015 total. Even after a 2016 restructuring of debt owed by PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, substantial external debt payments are falling due in 2017-the next one being a US$2.1bn coupon payment on April 12th. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA. However, given the extremely thin reserves cushion, the risk of default remains high, and would have dramatic economic and political consequences in the form of a sharp decrease in oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and probable political turmoil.
We expect the opposition to take power in 2019, ushering in much-needed market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process; we have factored in accumulated lending of over US$16bn in 2019-21. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.6% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. The election of a new government should help to ease the deficit to 5.9% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits of the present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply, as measured by M2, rose by 198% year on year in March, the highest rate on record. Meanwhile, high inflation and an overvalued currency are eroding the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability.
There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. In October 2016 the government undertook a bond swap that sees around US$2.8bn of PDVSA debt due in 2017 (of US$10bn in total PDVSA and sovereign debt) pushed out to 2020. This will alleviate some pressure, but does not resolve the country's external financing difficulties; we continue to see an extremely high risk of default. Despite this, the government has emphasised its commitment to pay, and we expect the next administration to follow through with its debt-servicing and repayment obligations.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. Amid extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. From 2019 our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that, after a massive contraction in GDP in 2016 (estimated at 14%), we project a further contraction, of 5.5%, in 2017. We do not expect the government to make the necessary adjustments to bring about a proper economic recovery, and we thus forecast that recession will persist into 2019. Even after this, recovery will be relatively weak, given the depth and length of the downturn. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of slightly higher oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macroeconomic adjustment, and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound; overall we expect real GDP to have declined by nearly 30% in 2014-19.
After dropping by an estimated 20% in 2016, private consumption will contract further in 2017-18, reflecting the impact of soaring inflation on real wages and disposable incomes, as well as government compression of imports. Imports account for a large share of consumer goods, owing to Venezuela's weak manufacturing base, which has been further eroded by currency distortions. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment in 2019-21 is based on expectations of a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in the energy sector and-towards the end of the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017-18 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting increased investment under a new government, and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from the recession years. Even after the change in government, however, dependence on oil will persist, and the next government will have to begin a process of economic diversification to produce a more robust domestic economy and promote non-oil exports.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years. It will remain very high in the medium term, but we expect a disinflation process later in the forecast period, assuming a change of government. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015. However, according to unofficial data from Cenda, a local think-tank, the price of a basic basket of goods increased by 9.9% month on month in January, bringing 12-month inflation to an estimated 508%. Money supply (M2) growth accelerated to 198% in late March, up from 159% in December. Assuming that price pressures remain high in the first half of 2017 at least, we expect average inflation to be higher this year, at 555%, than in 2016. However, we continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, reflecting moderately higher oil prices, which will bring in the necessary foreign exchange to help to alleviate scarcity of goods and the impact of persistent recession on demand. From 2019 fiscal and monetary policy adjustment will also be supportive of a gradual reduction in inflation towards double-digit levels (in year-on-year terms). However, before this happens, the lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (which we define as monthly inflation of more than 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The authorities manage a dual exchange-rate system composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom. The Dicom rate weakened by 70% in nominal terms in 2016 and stands at BsF710:US$1 currently, but it accounts for less than 10% of all official transactions. In real terms, the average exchange rate (weighted by volume of transactions) continued to appreciate substantially in 2016, creating ever greater pressure for currency adjustment, the need for which is evident in the black-market rate (BsF4,100:US$1 in early April).
In March the government announced that it was planning changes to the Dicom but gave few details. The pegged Dipro rate appears increasingly unsustainable, and we assume that the government will devalue the rate to BsF25:US$1 this year and again in 2018 (to BsF500:US$1). We currently assume that the government will increase the share of Dicom in foreign-currency transactions to 50% by 2018, up from a current level of about 8%. This would effectively constitute a maxi-devaluation, as distortions to the exchange rate would otherwise become unsustainable. Further major currency adjustment under a new government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. In the meantime, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017-18, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued gradual decline in oil output. The deficit will widen thereafter on the assumption that economic recovery draws in imports on a large scale after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Nevertheless, risks to the balance of payments will persist, although our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. This should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021, reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
Domestic data
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsF:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the Central Bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit assigns a high risk to the grand coalition government of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) and the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) not serving its full parliamentary term to 2018, despite the coalition parties' recent renewal of their agreement.
Political risks have risen since mid-2015, as public unease about the influx of migrants and dissatisfaction with the mainstream ruling parties has boosted support for the anti-immigration Freedom Party (FPÖ) and heightened intra-coalition tensions amid still weak economic growth. Since late 2015 opinion polls have shown support for the FPÖ at about 32%, above both coalition parties.
Following several years of policy paralysis, in January 2017 the coalition parties announced a renewed coalition agreement. However, we expect im-plementation of the announced measures to be troublesome. If the government faces significant difficulties in delivery, we would expect the federal chancellor, Christian Kern (SPÖ), to push for early elections. He already seemed to be doing so during the recent negotiations and he may want to cash in on his continued popularity before a failed reform attempt sullies this.
Little progress is expected in most areas of the government's reform agenda. This policy paralysis will hamper efforts to improve competitiveness, which over recent years has deteriorated relative to Austria's regional peers.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit well within the EU-mandated limit of 3% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2017-21) as the fiscal consolidation process suffers under limited government cohesion and effectiveness. However, we expect the public debt/GDP ratio to fall gradually.
Economic growth in recent years has been tepid as productivity has weakened and export market shares have declined. Real GDP grew by 0.8% in 2015 but accelerated to 1.5% in 2016, driven by domestic consumption and invest-ment demand. We expect a slight acceleration of growth in 2017, to 1.8%, reflecting mainly catch-up growth, and forecast average annual growth of 1.5% in 2018-21.
Structural factors, including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets, will keep inflation higher than in regional peers; after 1% in 2016, we forecast 2.1% inflation in 2017 and 2% on average in 2018-21.

Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21). As a result, the country rises to 11th place in the regional ranking and to 18th in the global ranking. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited. Barriers to entry to network industries are likely to persist.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of the competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal, but further liberalisation unlikely.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to the tax system, owing in part to government ineffectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely if a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers. Downside risks from financial, legislative and macroeconomic risks in central and eastern Europe.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage is introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Labour market slowly improves as increase in labour supply moderates and unemployment starts to drop.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.

a Actual.
Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. The last general election was held in 2013; the next is due in 2018.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second-highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2015 the value of exported goods was US$142.1bn and the goods import bill was US$140.4bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.2bn. Along with a significant primary income deficit and modest secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit assigns a high risk to the grand coalition government of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) calling an early election before the end of its term in October 2018. In May 2016 Werner Faymann (SPÖ), the then chancellor, resigned and was succeeded by Christian Kern (also SPÖ), then the head of the state railway firm.
A clear trend in recent state elections and in the presidential election in 2016 has been gains for the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) at the expense of the SPÖ and the ÖVP. Opinion polls continue to show support for the FPÖ at about 32%, well ahead of the SPÖ (at 29%) and the ÖVP (at 19%). The FPÖ is the well-established party of protest, attracting support from voters who are dissatisfied with the current government. It is therefore not surprising that support for the FPÖ has increased at a time when there is a widespread perception of stalemate within the current coalition, along with concerns about immigration, stagnant economic growth and rising unemployment. The fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP will weigh heavily on political stability in the years ahead. The FPÖ candidate eventually lost the presidential election, and by a larger margin the second time round, after it was rerun following irregularities in the vote counting process. However, that the FPÖ candidate, Norbert Hofer, twice managed to gain almost half of the vote, and on a high turnout, endorses our view that support for the FPÖ has become entrenched.
Recently, the outlook for the coalition surviving has improved slightly, after the two parties presented a new coalition agreement in late January 2017. In this they presented a number of measures, including a new minimum wage and en-hanced security measures. However, relations between the two parties remain tense, and there are serious questions over whether it will be possible for the coalition to implement the announced reforms. In particular, it is uncertain whether Mr Kern and Reinhold Mitterlehner, the leader of the ÖVP, have a sufficient hold over their parties (and over the social partners and provincial governments, both of which are vital to implementation) to deliver the agree-ment in full and to the agreed timetable. If the government does face significant difficulties in delivery, we would expect Mr Kern to push for early elections. He already seemed to be doing so during the recent negotiations, and may want to cash in on his continued popularity before a failed reform attempt sullies this. The same is likely to be the case for the ÖVP, which will want to profit from the popularity of Sebastian Kurz, the minister of foreign affairs and most likely candidate to lead the party in the next election; some polls suggest that the ÖVP would win the election should Mr Kurz lead it instead of Mr Mitterlehner. We continue to believe that an early election is a likely scenario.
The FPÖ is likely to win either an early election or the next scheduled one and subsequently to attempt to form a government, although it remains unclear with which party it will choose to do so. The FPÖ's proximity to power means that it tends to moderate its views slightly compared with far-right, populist parties in other European countries, such as France and the Netherlands. Mr Kern has been vocal in his disapproval of the FPÖ, but has been moving towards the party in terms of policy, including by pushing for curbs on intra-EU labour migration and by recently stating that his own party and the FPÖ were the only parties in Austria that wanted change. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further in the second half of our forecast period (2017-21). Relations with fellow EU member states will worsen in the event that the FPÖ enters government, putting pressure on the FPÖ's coalition partner, and we expect a government led by the party to be unstable, as it would struggle to implement its policies.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next general election is scheduled for September or October 2018. Whether it takes place then or earlier, we forecast that the FPÖ will become either the largest or the second-largest party and will then probably form a coalition with either the SPÖ or the ÖVP.
Elections for some state parliaments are planned for the first half of 2018. The next election for the primarily ceremonial post of federal president is in 2023.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the rise of the FPÖ, and it seems to have driven the government to lower its annual cap on asylum applications. The government has repeatedly hinted that it wants to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens on the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Alexander Van der Bellen-the independent candidate running against Mr Hofer-suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU did not reform or if Turkey joined. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution (Heta), a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016 when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In its renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017, the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term, in 2018. These include a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, we are sceptical that tangible progress will be achieved in most of these areas, owing to a lack of cohesion within the grand coalition and within the parties themselves at the different levels of government. The same is true for a coherent policy response to relatively high unemployment, despite continued (albeit weak) growth, and the sustainability of the pension system, despite a widely shared belief in the need for reform. The next government, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right, but we would expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.3% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, although the public debt/GDP ratio increased further, to 85.6%.
We estimate that the deficit widened in 2016, to 1.4% of GDP, owing in part to fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending. We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period, albeit within 1% of GDP from 2018, as fiscal con-solidation will continue to be limited and growth relatively slow. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 84.6% in 2016, following a positive contribution from the Heta deal, to just above 76% in 2021. In the context of the quantitative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Amid heightened political risk the euro zone economy is showing increasing growth momentum and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and an EUR80bn per month QE programme, which will fall to EUR60bn per month from April until the end of 2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, has emphasised that the reduction in the pace of QE was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period than if purchases continued at the current rate, and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled and under-performed in comparison with regional peers, notably with Germany, which was particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.5%, this remained below growth of 1.8% in Germany.
The economy's relatively lacklustre performance in recent years reflects a number of factors. Austria's domestic reform process has faltered, and along with higher inflation compared with its regional peers this has weakened productivity and competitiveness, admittedly from fairly high levels, in relation to countries such as France, Germany and the Netherlands, hindering export performance. This has depressed labour market prospects. In recent years the labour market has not been able to integrate the increased labour supply, caused in part by the influx of migrants last year, and this has pushed up the unemployment rate, even though employment has been growing. This, in turn, has weighed on consumer sentiment, meaning that much of the windfall for consumers from low oil prices since late 2014 has been saved instead of consumed. Although inflation has picked up recently following increasing global energy prices and positive base effects, we expect continued moderate consumption growth owing to a modestly improving labour market.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth, following an underperformance even compared with fundamentals in recent years, to continue and we have made an upward adjustment to our real GDP growth forecast for 2017, to 1.8%. This still compares negatively with, for instance, the Netherlands, where catch-up growth in recent years has been around 2%. We expect the lack of reform progress to continue to weigh on growth throughout the forecast period and expect domestic demand to be the main driver of growth, which is likely to converge towards potential growth in the coming years. We therefore expect average real GDP growth of just 1.5% in 2018-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016, well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone in both years. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation in the final months of 2016 and January-February 2017, and will con-tinue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 2.1%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015 and averaged US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, with a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1, reflecting the sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following Donald Trump's election victory in the US. We now forecast an annual average rate of US$1.06:EUR1 in 2017 and US$1.07:EUR1 in 2018, reflecting heightened political risk in Europe and strong growth in the US, with the euro then appreciating gradually in 2019-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and is estimated to have pushed the trade balance back into deficit in 2016. We expect further growth and higher oil prices to continue to weigh on the trade balance in the coming years. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. We therefore expect continued current-account surpluses in our forecast period of just below 2% on average.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+European+Union&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Europe+March+2017&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2017-03-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+European+Union&amp;rft.issn=17468760&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text:   Fact sheet

Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars and the legacy of the cold war, during which Europe was divided into two blocs. The ending of Soviet control over central and eastern Europe from 1989, followed by the collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union, provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than that of other east European countries. The effects of war in former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-east Europe.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and healthy levels of political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-in particular those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at the level of the EU. Nineteen EU member states share the euro as their currency. These countries are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank (ECB). They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have often been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) ceded varying degrees of policy control to the EU and the IMF in exchange for receiving financial support. Although the euro zone crisis has passed its peak, normalisation remains a long way off. The Economist Intelligence Unit continues to attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during its medium-term forecast period. Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and of institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster and more successfully with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. Around 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary
Political stability
It is a time of increasing political fragmentation across much of the region. This makes it more difficult to form stable governments and implement policy.
The UK got a new prime minister and cabinet in swift succession following the EU referendum in June 2016, helping to bolster stability at a time of uncertainty.
The rejection of constitutional reforms in a referendum in Italy in December 2016 has resulted in the formation of an interim government. It is vulnerable to party manoeuvring ahead of the next general election, due in early 2018.
Electoral risk remains high in the EU, as populist forces will challenge mainstream parties in elections in several major countries in 2017.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects EU sanctions on Russia to be extended again in mid-2017, but there is a risk they will be eased over the medium term.
Economic policy
We forecast big changes in the UK's economic policy mix following the Brexit vote. Monetary policy has already been loosened and the government is prioritising long-term investment, as fiscal projections have worsened.
We expect the monetary stance to remain exceptionally loose across much of the rest of the region. We do not expect the European Central Bank (ECB) or the Bank of England (BoE, the UK's central bank) to increase policy rates by 2021.
We expect some rebalancing of the mix between monetary and fiscal policy in the euro zone as governments seek to respond to voter dissatisfaction. However, the bloc's rigid fiscal rules could make this a contentious process.
Economic reform has progressed well in certain countries, notably the Baltics, Spain and Ireland, but for most the main challenges lie ahead. With political fragmentation on the rise, policymaking is becoming more difficult.
Economic growth
We expect a growth slowdown in the UK in 2017-18 as the start of Brexit negotiations heightens uncertainty, hitting investment and private consumption.
The short-term economic fallout from Brexit will be modest for Europe, but the UK's departure will exacerbate weaknesses that have been holding back the region's economic recovery in recent years.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries as they have eased into a weak recovery phase. However, fragilities remain.
