Political outlook: Political stability
The UK has returned to a situation of relative political stability following an initial period of chaos triggered by the country's referendum vote on June 23rd 2016 to leave the EU. Nevertheless, the outcome of the referendum will on occasion test stability and will be decisive in shaping politics in The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast period (2017-21). The Conservative Party prime minister, Theresa May, will trigger Article 50 of the Lisbon treaty on March 29th 2017, beginning the formal, two-year process of the country's withdrawal from the EU. In a speech on January 17th Mrs May confirmed that the UK would leave the EU's single market, in line with the government's intention to honour the Brexit vote by establishing control over EU migration and ending the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice in the UK.
Given the government's intention to negotiate trade deals with other countries outside the EU, the UK might also have to leave the EU customs union (which allows goods to move freely without customs checks). Mrs May has said that she would like the UK to have tariff-free access to EU markets, but full customs union membership would mean a common external tariff and, crucially, would prevent the UK from negotiating trade deals with other countries. An alternative option would be a customs agreement with the EU, implying partial or associate membership. If the UK does leave the customs union, the govern-ment is likely to pursue a free-trade agreement. Whether or not the UK stays in the customs union, UK-EU trade ties are likely to remain close. The government will aim to reach a deal on the new UK-EU trading relationship by the close of the two-year negotiating period, in March 2019. At that stage the UK will formally leave the single market, and the terms of the new relationship, which could contain sector-specific arrangements, will be phased in gradually. There are risks to this forecast. If negotiations fail and no extension of the deadline is agreed by all 27 EU members, the UK will leave the EU in 2019 without any deal in place and revert to World Trade Organisation (WTO) trade rules.
Depending on how successfully Mrs May can navigate the Brexit process and implement her domestic policy agenda, she could potentially remain in power beyond the next general election, due in 2020. However, the possibility of an early election cannot be ruled out, especially if the government encounters significant obstacles in parliament to the terms of its Brexit deal. Either way, with the main centre-left opposition Labour Party likely to struggle to prove itself to be a credible alternative government, we forecast that the Conservative Party will enjoy an extended period in government. The Brexit vote and its aftermath have confirmed that the mainstream political parties are out of touch with large swathes of the electorate, but the UK's first-past-the-post electoral system makes it difficult for smaller parties to translate an increased national vote share into parliamentary seats.
The UK's decision marks another phase of Europe's institutional crisis
The UK's vote to leave the EU represents a further stage in a rolling regional political and economic crisis that began in 2010. This crisis has been defined by a failure of the region's institutions to provide effective governance and leadership in response to political and economic challenges. The early stages of the crisis were characterised by challenges to the survival of the single currency. We believe that the threat to stability in the region is much wider-this has been demonstrated by the events of the past two years. The euro crisis has not gone away, and the intra-bloc tensions that it has engendered have been compounded by the 2014-15 migration crisis, the rise of anti-establishment and anti-EU political parties, and now by the first-ever decision by a member state to break away from the bloc.
In managing its multiple crises since 2010, the region has had to resort to "muddling through". This policy approach has been moderately successful so far, certainly when compared with some of the disastrous outcomes that could have transpired. However, muddling through, by definition, does not offer a long-term strategy for addressing the region's problems and it has eroded the political capital of the policymakers involved. The region faces major unanswered questions-not least about its dire economic growth performance and whether further integration in the euro zone is (i) economically necessary and (ii) politically feasible. The resistance of policymakers to confronting these questions head on should not be underestimated. However, if Europe's leaders continue with this muddle-through policy, the political and economic costs may prove to be their undoing-as the tumultuous events of the past year illustrate.
We expect Mr Macron, an independent, to win the French presidential election
The 2012-17 presidency of François Hollande, of the centre-left Parti socialiste (PS), has been widely seen as a disaster. Mr Hollande will leave office in a few months as the most unpopular president in France's recent history and will not run for a second term. The slump in his ratings reflects his failure to deliver solid economic growth, to prevent a series of fatal terrorist attacks and even, at times, to act in a sufficiently presidential way. Public disappointment and frustration has spilled over from Mr Hollande to the political class in general, with polls and primary election results in 2016-17 indicating a keen desire to break with the status quo and force a change of political personnel. Polls suggest that the country is now in the unprecedented position, six weeks before the first round of the presidential election on April 23rd, of seeing both of the mainstream party candidates-from the PS and from the centre-right Les Républicains-eliminated before the second-round run-off, on May 7th. Fragmentation on the left has reduced the chances of the PS's presidential candidate, Benoît Hamon, who is a rebel from the far left of the party, getting into the second round, while François Fillon-who was chosen as Les Républicains' candidate in November-is mired in a public-funding scandal that emerged in late January.
Our core forecast is that Emmanuel Macron, a centrist independent and political newcomer, who started his own movement, En Marche!, in April 2016, will face Marine Le Pen, of the far-right Front national (FN), in the second round. We expect Mr Macron to win the presidency; however, his movement is unlikely to gain a majority in parliament in the legislative elections on July 11th and 18th. This means that gaining parliamentary support for his proposals will be unusually difficult, requiring far more inter-party negotiation than is typical in the highly presidential French political system. Political instability is therefore likely to be higher over our forecast period than in the recent past.
We expect Angela Merkel to remain in power after the 2017 election
Despite a marked increase in political volatility in Germany since 2015-largely as a result of the unprecedented surge of migrants entering the country-the country is likely to remain, in comparative terms, a source of political stability in Europe. Nevertheless, we expect the German political scene to be less stable over the forecast period than it has been over the past decade. Germany's current government-comprising a grand coalition of the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD)-is led by Angela Merkel, who is in her third term as chancellor. Our baseline forecast is that the CDU/CSU will win the largest share of the vote in the September election and that Ms Merkel will continue as chancellor. However, a recent rise in support for the SPD, led by the former president of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, since late January 2017, means that we now expect the election to be a close race between the mainstream parties.
Germany is not completely immune to the appeal of populism, as illustrated by the sharp rise in support for the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) over the past two years. In the 2013 election the AfD, running at the time on a mainly anti-euro platform, did not manage to breach the 5% threshold to gain representation in parliament. Its rise since then has been driven mainly by the inflow of migrants in 2015 and early 2016. The party managed to attract 24.2% of the vote in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt in state elections in March 2016, at the height of the outcry in Europe over the migration issue. Its support has waned in recent months, seemingly in part owing to support moving back to the SPD following the arrival of Mr Schulz; however, the AfD looks all but certain to win seats in parliament. This would be a significant moment for German politics, in which a party to the right of the CSU has long been taboo.
Germany remains an outlier, as, mainly for historical reasons, there is deep antipathy towards populist movements, especially those on the right. At the same time, this antipathy is far stronger in the west of the country than in the east, which remained under communist rule in the post-war period, until the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. The legacy of fascism will continue to shape German attitudes for years to come, but the recent rise in support for the AfD suggests that the country might merely be lagging behind others in the development of a populist movement. With the uncontrolled inflow of migrants having ended, we do not expect the AfD to make significant further inroads ahead of the election in September 2017, although our base case is that it will become the third-largest party. There is, however, no chance of any party forming a coalition with the AfD.
Election result puts to rest speculation about a Dutch exit from the euro or EU
The parliamentary election in the Netherlands on March 15th 2017 led to a fragmented result, with the centre-right People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) winning the most seats in the 150-seat parliament, with 33, down from 41 in 2012. The right-wing, populist Party for Freedom (PVV), led by Geert Wilders, which is the main outlet for public frustration with much of the traditional political mainstream, came second, albeit with 13 seats fewer than the VVD. Given the fragmented result and the peculiarities of the Dutch political system the formation of the next government might take anywhere from a few weeks to several months, or even longer. The PVV will not be part of the government, which we expect to include the VVD, the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA) and Democrats 66 (D66), with GreenLeft (GL) or the Christian Union (CU). The main political uncertainty over the longer term is whether populist parties-such as 50Plus, which represents older voters, and the PVV-will encounter limits to their support or not, and therefore whether they will ever be able to form a government. For now we do not expect this to happen, but if the next government struggles there is a small risk that disenchantment will grow to a level high enough to elevate someone like Mr Wilders into government.
Italy remains a particular pressure point within the euro zone. The overwhelming rejection of the flagship constitutional reform of the then prime minister and leader of the Partito Democratico (PD), Matteo Renzi, in a referendum in December 2016 has increased political instability, which will hinder prospects for political and economic reform in Italy. The government crisis triggered by Mr Renzi's resignation as premier was short-lived, but the government formed by Paolo Gentiloni, previously the minister of foreign affairs under Mr Renzi and a member of the PD, is weak and especially vulnerable to the political manoeuvrings within the divided PD and the wider coalition. In February 2017 Mr Renzi resigned as PD secretary to confront his critics in a leadership election due to take place on April 30th; however, this failed to prevent the breakaway of a large group of leftists. We expect Mr Renzi to be re-elected as PD leader, but given his abrasive leadership style this is unlikely to put an end to the party's internal turmoil. The PD leadership contest and the need to harmonise the electoral laws for the two houses of parliament before the next election have now all but ruled out the possibility of a snap general election in the coming months. We continue to expect the next election to be held at, or close to, the end of the current parliamentary term, in early 2018. We expect the next election to take place using a highly proportional voting system, which will increase political fragmentation further, complicating government formation after the election.
Against this unstable backdrop Mr Gentiloni's government has a difficult policy remit, including trying to keep the economic recovery on track while controlling the public finances, managing mounting problems in Italy's banking sector, dealing with a renewed inflow of migrants and tackling the aftermath of a series of deadly earthquakes.
In recent months the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) has ridden the wave of global populist sentiment. Even though its credibility has been dented by a series of political blunders and local-level scandals, most notably in Rome's city government, M5S is still likely to emerge as the largest party at the next election given very low levels of public satisfaction with the government and the political establishment. Nevertheless, we expect that M5S will fail to obtain a majority of parliamentary seats and that mainstream parties will coalesce to keep it out of office after the election. This is likely to exacerbate public frustration with the political process and further boost support for M5S.
Following the attempted coup in Turkey by parts of the military on July 15th 2016, there has been a sharp deterioration in the country's political outlook, which we expect to have lasting negative effects on its social stability as well as its international relations and economic prospects. Under the state of emergency rule that was introduced in late July 2016, there has been a government clampdown on suspected coup-plotters, political opponents and critics that has seen over 100,000 people, mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media, suspended, dismissed or detained. The political scene will continue to be dominated by the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP). Mr Erdogan's plan to establish a presidential system of government with few checks and balances on the executive powers of the presidency faces its final hurdle in a divisive national referendum, to be held on April 16th 2017. Most opinion polls, including polls commissioned by the AKP, suggest that the "no" camp has a narrow lead. However, we expect that a majority of voters will approve the reforms. The vote will take place under the state of emergency rule, which has created a climate of fear that could deter people from supporting the "no" campaign and from voting against the reforms. Nevertheless, the risk of the reforms being rejected cannot be overlooked, as Turkey's security and economic outlook has deteriorated. The reforms would not come into effect until after the parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled to take place in late 2019. Beyond the referendum, it is unclear what strategy Mr Erdogan and the AKP will adopt. We believe it is unlikely that there will be a rapid return to stability, regardless of the result.
Tensions between Russia and the West will persist during the forecast period
The conflict between Russia and the West will continue to shape the politics and economics of much of the region. NATO members placed the security threat posed by Russia at the heart of a landmark summit in July 2016, agreeing to deploy troops permanently in the Baltic States and Poland as an explicit deterrence to Russian aggression. However, the summit belied signifi-cant divisions within both NATO and the EU on Russia policy. These have become more pronounced following the election of Donald Trump as US president. Mr Trump has made clear his desire for an improvement in bilateral relations with Russia, and has cast doubt on US security guarantees to Europe. Eastern Europe has become the arena in which East-West tensions are being expressed. The expansion of the NATO alliance to include Montenegro has put the tiny western Balkan country in the eye of a political storm. Russia, which was accused by the Montenegrin authorities of being behind an alleged coup attempt on election day in October 2016, regards NATO expansion in the region as a provocation and a security threat. NATO meanwhile views Montenegro's accession as a way of countering Russian meddling and influence in the Balkans. The US is the only NATO member not to have approved Montenegro's NATO membership, agreed in principle in May 2016, after a vote on the matter was twice blocked by US senators opposed to further NATO expansion. The matter has the potential to inflame tensions between Russia and the West and between the US and its European allies. We expect a number of European NATO members to increase spending on defence in 2017-21.
Despite Mr Trump's election, we expect the tensions between the West and Russia, which have been exacerbated by the Ukraine crisis, to persist throughout the forecast period. The situation on the ground in eastern Ukraine is now broadly stable, but the "line of contact" between territory controlled by the Ukrainian government and Russian-backed separatists is highly militarised. Ceasefire breaches and fatalities are a regular occurrence. The ceasefire agreement signed in February 2015 in Minsk, the Belarusian capital, is unlikely to lead to a comprehensive political settlement. The constitutional reforms mandated by the agreement are politically toxic in Ukraine, and, as popular support for the government is low, the reforms are unlikely to be brought to a vote. Even if Ukraine passes the relevant laws, it is highly unlikely that Russia will allow the country to regain control of its international border and therefore re-establish full sovereignty over the territories that are currently controlled by Russian-backed militias. As a result, we expect the conflict between the Ukrainian state and the Russian-backed forces to remain effectively frozen. However, the status quo is unstable. The risk of a return to all-out war appears low, but cannot be entirely ruled out.
A thaw in Russia-US relations could exacerbate splits within the EU
The election in November 2016 of Mr Trump as US president has the potential to lead to an improvement in US-Russia relations. However, any rapprochement may be short-lived. Like Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, Mr Trump's leadership style depends on projecting an image of machismo and uncompromising strength. The two men could quickly come into conflict when the next international crisis emerges. Much of the political and security establishment in the US remains highly opposed to a rapprochement, and Russian officialdom will also remain strongly anti-American. A thaw in relations between Russia and the US could exacerbate splits within the EU on Russia policy. Senior figures in a number of countries, notably Italy, Greece and Hungary, have publicly attacked the EU's sanctions regime on Russia.
Recent developments in Kazakhstan suggest that planning for a transition of power is firmly under way. Nursultan Nazarbayev, who turns 77 in July, has ruled Kazakhstan since before independence in 1991. The political system concentrates a high degree of power within the presidential system; this has prevented the emergence of strong institutions, an independent media, and other checks and balances. In January Mr Nazarbayev announced a range of constitutional reforms that will notionally shift power from the presidency to the government and parliament. In practice, the impact on the political system is likely to be limited. Party politics is not competitive in Kazakhstan, and the parliament is dominated by Nur Otan, the "party of power" that supports the president. Political decision-making is therefore likely to remain highly non-transparent and informal.
We expect that Mr Nazarbayev will serve out his full term to 2020
Nevertheless, the announcement of the constitutional reform is a clear signal that succession planning is under way. At the same time, the frequency of reshuffles and purges of senior figures within the elite has risen. This is also likely to be linked to the succession process. Our core forecast is that Mr Nazarbayev will serve out his full term to 2020; however, the likelihood that he will depart sooner, as part of a managed transition, has risen. There is currently no clear successor, and any future leader may struggle to maintain elite coherence. There is a risk that the transition could lead to increased and more public conflict between the elite, which could prove destabilising. However, we believe all parties will have an interest in a managed process. Intense political uncertainty is likely to depress investment in the coming years and may reduce government effectiveness, as officials become more risk averse.
Political outlook: Le Pen win remains a risk in France
Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right Front national (FN) and its candidate in the presidential election, has substantial popular support. She claims to speak to, and for, the "France of the forgotten", in particular former industrial workers in the rust belt north of the country who feel left behind by globalisation, as well as those in the south of the country concerned by questions of immigration and assimilation. She promises to "bring back the nation-state" by reclaiming sovereignty from the EU and putting a stop to uncontrolled immigration and the alleged Islamification of French society. Ms Le Pen has made significant progress in the "de-demonisation" of her party, which under the previous leadership of her father (Jean-Marie) was beyond the political pale, in the light of the pro-Vichy, pro-Nazi and anti-Semitic proclivities of its founders.
However, the FN nevertheless remains anathema to many voters because of these roots, as well as its anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant views. Ms Le Pen's desire to take France out of the euro zone also prompts significant concern among savers and pensioners. In addition, the structure of the electoral system works against her: the two-round vote means that she would have to gain more than 50% of the vote to win (almost double her current share of support). Moreover, centre-left and centre-right voters typically unite around the non-FN candidate in the second round to keep the far right out of power, and polls suggest that this will happen again this year, with Ms Le Pen losing by a large margin to whoever she faces.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a closer race than the polls imply, with a high rate of abstention posing the most serious risk, as this could boost Ms Le Pen's share of the vote. Our core forecast is that she will face Mr Macron in the second round; should his support drop sharply before the first-round vote, then François Fillon, the candidate for the centre-right party, Les Républicains, could face Ms Le Pen in the second round, and we would expect him to win instead. In the event that Ms Le Pen did win the presidency, she would struggle to implement legislation, especially on issues where her party holds a minority view, as she would have to work with a hostile parliament. For this reason, even if she were elected, we would not expect France to leave the EU or the euro zone.
Political outlook: Election watch
We expect political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period. In the euro zone, in particular, the negative political fallout from the financial crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the post-war political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. Moreover, recent evidence suggests that fragmentation and difficulties forming a government occur even in countries that are registering solid rates of growth, such as Spain and Ireland.
In Ireland, a government was formed following the February 2016 election, but it is a precarious minority coalition administration and we expect it to fall in 2017. In Spain, the political dysfunction has been more pronounced. Following two inconclusive general elections and ten months of political gridlock, in early November 2016 the conservative Popular Party (PP) formed a minority coalition government led by the incumbent prime minister, Mariano Rajoy. It will be one of the weakest in Spain's democratic history. It can rely on just 170 votes-those of the PP (137 seats), Ciudadanos (Citizens; 32 seats) and the Canary Island Coalition (CC; one seat)-in the 350-seat Congress of Deputies (the lower house of parliament). The abstention of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) was necessary to unblock the political impasse. However, the PSOE will remain in opposition and will not support the PP government's legislation or its 2017 budget proposal. Mr Rajoy will therefore have to seek an ad hoc majority for each bill, with few options but to build coalitions with smaller, regional nationalist parties, like the Basque Nationalist Party (PNV; five seats). We do not expect the Spanish government to serve a full four-year term in office, with another early election being the most likely scenario. The political scene will remain fluid and fragmented.
We expect a more stable government in Croatia under Andrej Plenkovic
The Croatian parliamentary election on September 11th 2016 produced a more stable outcome than the previous election. The centre-right Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) and its partners won a plurality of the vote, defeating the Social Democratic Party (SDP)-led coalition. The HDZ re-entered a coalition with Most (Bridge). The new government received the votes of 91 parliamentarians, a clear majority in the 151-seat parliament. We expect a more stable government under the leadership of Andrej Plenkovic, the new centrist leader of the HDZ and prime minister-the government has already passed a large tax reform package. However, there are signs that Mr Plenkovic will struggle to appease the vocal right wing of his party while maintaining a centrist policy orientation, and progress on reform in other areas, such as the public administration, and the pension and healthcare systems, will probably be slow in the face of powerful interest groups. Although Mr Plenkovic faces pressure from the HDZ's right wing, we do not expect him to be as aggressive in his nationalist stance as his predecessor as HDZ leader, Tomislav Karamarko. It is unlikely that Croatia's relations with Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Serbia will improve significantly over the forecast period. Relations between these countries typically fluctuate between hostile at worst and correct at best, and will continue to do so. We do not expect relations to break down completely, nor do we expect a return to violent conflict.
In the parliamentary election in Georgia on October 8th 2016 the ruling Georgian Dream-Democratic Georgia (GD-DG) won 48.68% of the proportional vote. The United National Movement (UNM) came a distant second, with 27.11%. On October 30th GD-DG won run-off elections in 47 out of 49 constituencies, bringing its total seats in parliament to 115 out of 150, a constitutional majority. Only three other parties secured seats in parliament: the UNM won 27 seats, the pro-Russian Alliance of Patriots of Georgia secured six seats and Industry Will Save Georgia just one. However, in a row over the continuing influence of the former president, Mikheil Saakashvili, in January 2017 the UNM split, with the bulk of the party's leadership, or 21 of its 27 members of parliament (MPs), forming a new parliamentary faction, European Georgia. Mr Saakashvili retains control of the rump UNM, now represented by just six MPs. GD-DG now controls most local governments, and with its overwhelming majority in parliament it can determine judicial appointments and amend the powers of the presidency. GD-DG has mentioned a plan to abolish direct presidential elections, with the president instead appointed by parliament. This would ensure a GD-DG president. Giorgi Kvirikashvili, the returning prime minister, has said that constitutional reform will be enacted, but has promised not to amend the constitution without engagement from a full range of stakeholders. We expect that GD-DG will undertake some moves to consolidate power, as was also the case when the UNM swept to a constitutional majority after the 2008 parliamentary election. However, close ties with the West remain important for much of the Georgian establishment, and international criticism may act as a moderating influence on any potential anti-democratic tendencies of the new government.
A presidential election will take place in Russia in March 2018. Suggestions that Mr Putin, who has dominated the political scene since 2000, was contemplating withdrawing from politics appear to have been misplaced. We expect Mr Putin to run for a fourth term (until 2024) and to win with a large majority in the first round. In January Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption campaigner and one of the most dynamic of the "non-systemic" opposition leaders, was found guilty for a second time of defrauding Kirovles, a timber company. His previous conviction was overturned by the Supreme Court following a judgment by the European Court of Human Rights. Mr Navalny's conviction prevents him from standing in the presidential election, and suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, with little meaningful competition. The main challenge for the regime will be to secure a respectable turnout in the context of a relatively weak recovery in household incomes following two years of recession.
Populist forces will challenge main-stream parties in elections in 2017
There is a growing populist challenge to mainstream parties that is evident across Europe. The populists have shown themselves to be more prepared than the mainstream parties to debate the big political issues of the day, such as the impact of globalisation on income equality and national identity, and they are mobilising people to become engaged in the political process and to vote. In some cases the ruling elite has responded by dismissing the insurgent parties and their voters as deluded, manipulated or simply beyond the pale, and in other cases by shifting on to similar ground.
Important parliamentary elections are scheduled to take place in France in April/May and in Germany in September. In both of these contests anti-establishment movements and parties will be challenging mainstream political forces, albeit to differing degrees. Our core forecast is not for a surge of populist parties getting into power this year (although this is undoubtedly a risk). However, we expect strong support for these parties to give them an increasing influence on the topics of domestic political debate. We also anticipate growing difficulties with coalition-building as increasingly disparate mainstream parties try to find common ground to work together in order to keep the populists out.
SPD leadership change alters dynamic of the German election
Our baseline forecast for Germany is that Ms Merkel will remain in office until the 2017 election, will lead the centre-right CDU to victory, and will still be chancellor following the election, at the head of another grand coalition between the CDU, the CSU and the centre-left SPD. However, the SPD's change of leadership in late January 2017, with the former president of the European Parliament, Mr Schulz, replacing Sigmar Gabriel as party chairman, has significantly altered the political dynamic. Support for the SPD had hovered mostly around 2% in the polls since the 2013 federal election, well below that for the CDU/CSU. Mr Schulz, who benefits from a "novelty effect", has seemingly been able to tap into long-simmering frustrations over issues such as the flexible labour market by taking a traditional social-democratic stance in his first weeks as SPD leader, pledging to fight for social justice and combat inequality. As a consequence, the party's support has risen by about 10 percentage points since the start of the year, to just over 30%-neck and neck with the CDU/CSU. Ms Merkel remains a formidable opponent, however, with a reputation as a steady hand and a thoughtful decision-maker. After shooting up sharply, support for the SPD now seems to have stabilised. Ms Merkel's popularity was damaged in 2015-16 by her reaction to the migrant crisis, with her broadly welcoming response to a surge of migrant arrivals proving out of step with majority public opinion. However, a sharp drop in the number of arrivals last year-to 280,000, from 900,000 (equivalent to 1% of the population) in 2015-combined with a hardening of the government's stance on the issue, has reduced the political salience of the topic and eased the pressure on Ms Merkel. Together with the rise of Mr Schulz, this has caused the far-right, populist AfD to lose some of its support, which had picked up in the polls in 2015-16, as the party's anti-immigration message chimed with voters' concerns during the migrant crisis. The recent rise in support for the SPD has encouraged talk of a "red-red-green" coalition-comprising the SPD, the Left Party and The Greens-potentially unseating Ms Merkel and the CDU/CSU in September. However, we consider this fairly unlikely. Our view is instead that the improvement in the SPD's support makes another grand coalition with the CDU more likely-in part because it narrows both parties' options. Over the medium term, questions about who might succeed Ms Merkel as the dominant figure on the centre right will become more pressing, and the threat posed by the AfD will remain present.

Political outlook: Czech Republic: Andrej Babis set to dominate next government
The ANO movement led by Andrej Babis, a billionaire businessman and the current finance minister, has opened up a large lead in the polls over its coalition partner, the Czech Social Democratic Party (CSSD). This supports The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast that Mr Babis will become the next Czech prime minister after the October 2017 parliamentary election, and that ANO could emerge as the dominant force in the next government. Mr Babis has been compared to populist nationalists such the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, and businessmen-turned-politicians such as the US president, Donald Trump. However, we see important differences here, as well as similarities. We would expect an ANO-led administration to focus on pro-business and anti-corruption reforms, with the Czech Republic unlikely to follow Hungary and Poland in the direction of illiberal democracy.
Since early 2014 ANO has consistently topped Czech opinion polls. Its nearest rival is its senior partner in government, the CSSD, which is led by the prime minister, Bohuslav Sobotka. The CSSD narrowly won the 2013 general election, but has since seen its support soften. Opinion polls now suggest that ANO opened up a decisive lead over the CSSD in the wake of the October 2016 regional elections, in which Mr Babis's movement performed unexpectedly well. A poll released on January 26th by STEM, a polling agency, projected a 29.9% vote for ANO in the October 2017 election, compared with 14.6% for the second-placed CSSD, in an electoral model assuming a turnout of just under 60%. Polling by another research institute, CVVM, published a day later, projected 32% of the vote for ANO and 19% for the CSSD.
If reproduced in the general election, this vote share would mean that ANO could potentially govern with the support of just one smaller party, such as the current junior coalition partner, the Christian Democratic Union (KDU-CSL). A less likely alternative is that the CSSD will revive its electoral support sufficiently to close the gap that has opened up with ANO, and force a continuation of the current three-party ANO-CSSD-KDU coalition, albeit with ANO taking over as senior partner and Mr Babis becoming prime minister.
A Czech Trump?
Some commentators have seen Mr Babis as a central European strongman with similarities to Hungary's populist prime minister, Mr Orban, or Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the leader of the ruling Law and Justice (PiS) party in Poland. Others have compared him to former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi, or Mr Trump.
There are parallels. Like Mr Trump, Mr Babis is a very wealthy business insider, who rebranded himself as a political outsider and successfully ran against the establishment. Mr Babis owns the Agrofert agro-food conglomerate, the fourth-largest firm in the Czech Republic by revenue, and has a net personal worth of around US$3.3bn. Like Mr Berlusconi, he has used his private wealth and company infrastructures to develop his own party. ANO was launched as an anti-corruption initiative in 2011 and rose from obscurity in the 2013 election to become the second-largest party in parliament. Mr Babis has also supported his political ambitions through media holdings, acquiring the MAFRA group, which publishes two of the five big Czech national daily newspapers, in 2013.
Although he presents himself as a non-ideological results-oriented reformer, some of Mr Babis's public pronouncements have had authoritarian overtones. He has suggested on several occasions that the Czech Republic should be run like a company or a family firm, and has shown an obvious impatience with democratic procedures, repeatedly expressing frustration at the slowness of cabinet and parliamentary debates. In an accidentally recorded conversation, he told the Hungarian ambassador that he envied Mr Orban's freedom to make rapid, unchallenged decisions.
Mr Babis's position has led to a unique concentration of political, economic and media power-already evident in numerous conflict of interest scandals during his tenure as finance minister, which political opponents have sought to capitalise on. Mr Babis appears for now to have side-stepped the conflict of interest law passed in November by an ad hoc alliance of government and opposition parties, in the teeth of ANO opposition. The legislation, which bars ministers from holding a stake of over 40% in a company or any stake in a media outlet, has forced Mr Babis to transfer his assets into a trust fund. The lesson that he is likely to draw from this is that he needs to take a tougher stance against the established parties to pre-empt further measures being taken against him. In a future government ANO might therefore seek to exert stronger party-political control over key ministries, including the Ministry of the Interior, and sponsor counter-reforms targeting, for example, the financing of established parties (which tend to be more reliant on donations and public funding than ANO).
Limits to Babis
Mr Babis is, however, no populist nationalist, and even if the election in October delivers him a big win, there will be limits to his power. Born in Slovakia, and with a family and professional background that include close ties to the former communist regime, Mr Babis would be implausible in the role of a Czech nationalist. His politics, and those of his movement-although ill-defined-are broadly centrist, technocratic and pro-business. Mr Babis's picks for the cabinet posts held by ANO in the current government have consisted of middle-of-the-road technocrats and businesspeople (sometime recruited from Agrofert), not figures from the political fringes.
Moreover, ANO draws its support from a broad swathe of Czech society with surprisingly little differentiation by income, region or age. Research suggests that such middling voters are not particularly poor, angry or frustrated, but see ANO pragmatically as the "least bad" option, preferable to the older, established parties, which have had a patchy record in government and eventually succumbed to behind-the-scenes corruption scandals. Such voters value the buoyant economy that Mr Babis can claim to have delivered as finance minister. Many seem prepared to overlook Mr Babis's conflicts of interest on the grounds that he is a what-you-see-is-what-you-get politician, whose vast business empire is at least largely in plain sight. However, it is questionable whether such voters would continue to support Mr Babis-or the other ANO parliamentarians-if they launched a direct assault on the Czech Republic's liberal institutions.
ANO is also likely to find its power restricted in practice by its coalition partner or partners; its weak position in the Senate (which will remain controlled by other parties); and, if Milos Zeman loses (or does not contest) the presidential election in January 2018, the possibility of a new head of state who is less favourably disposed towards Mr Babis and ANO than the incumbent.
Policy outlook
The policy outlook for an ANO-led government remains for the moment unclear, with the movement planning to publish an electoral programme mid-year. As ANO's policymaking structures are comparatively weak, this programme is likely to reflect Mr Babis's own personal preferences.
The indications so far are that, as in 2013, Mr Babis will present ANO as a competent team of non-politicians focused on improving the public administration and fighting corruption-although, as at present, reforms will focus only on sectors that do not affect his political or business interests, and will ignore his own conflicts of interest. Czech media commentary suggest that ANO is likely to offer personal tax cuts and measures to support middle-income earners, especially in the public sector.
Both ANO and its leader have traditionally had a low profile in foreign and European affairs, preferring to focus on domestic reform. In the past Mr Babis has made inconsistent on-the-hoof pronouncements on issues such as euro adoption and EU refugee policy, designed primarily to play to Czech public opinion. An ANO-led government would be likely to follow a foreign policy focusing on Czech (economic) interests within the EU, but without developing any broader vision of Europe.
Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
Political tensions in the region are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. In March 2014 Russia annexed Crimea and has since been providing military support to pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine. In July 2014 the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, killing hundreds of EU citizens on board, was a decisive factor in the EU's decision to impose sector-wide sanctions on Russia's financial, defence and energy sectors. These sanctions may have discouraged Russia from significantly expanding the scope of the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The Minsk ceasefire agreement has led to a decline in the intensity of the conflict, but the line of contact between the government forces and Russian-backed military remains militarised. We think that EU sanctions against Russia will be renewed again in July 2017, but they may be eased over the medium term.
Russia is steadfastly opposed to EU and NATO expansion in the post-Soviet space (although the prospects for further enlargement of either bloc currently look very low). Unexpected political change in any country of the former Soviet Union has the potential to lead to an international crisis.
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk of their prompting a breakdown in inter-governmental relations has fallen sharply over the past year, as economic growth has picked up across the bloc. The European Central Bank (ECB) has successfully overcome objections in a number of countries-notably in Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing is not being used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform. This has led to a potentially destabilising escalation of anti-establishment political sentiment across much of the bloc. This trend is generating increased pressure for economic policymaking that is focused on national considerations rather than on the integrity of the euro zone, creating new centrifugal forces at a time when policymakers are already struggling to remedy the institutional shortcomings of the single currency. Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. This should ensure its survival in the short term, but the risk of a partial break-up in the medium term remains significant. We attach a 60% probability to Greece leaving the euro zone during our five-year forecast period.
Tension between Turkey and the EU will remain high
Just weeks before the failed military coup in Turkey the AKP government had initiated efforts to mend badly damaged relations with Israel and Russia, as part of what appeared to be a broader push to reduce Turkey's growing international isolation brought on by years of assertive partisan foreign policy. But the failed military coup and the government's uncompromising response have further complicated Turkey's relations with other countries in the region, especially the EU. Following the failed coup, tensions erupted with the EU over the bloc's perceived lack of solidarity with Turkey and its rush to criticise the measures taken by the Turkish government to restore stability. Relations have deteriorated even further in recent months.
Since January 2017 tensions with Greece have escalated over Cyprus, disputed islands in the Aegean and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's application for the extradition of Turkish military officers who fled to Greece after the July 2016 coup attempt. In the first half of March 2017 a war of words erupted with the Netherlands and Germany over their refusal to allow Turkish government ministers to hold rallies in their countries in favour of Turkey's presidential reform referendum. The deterioration could eventually lead to the formal suspension of Turkey's EU accession negotiations and an end to Turkey's collab-oration with the EU to stem the inflow of migrants and refugees into Europe.
Neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the EU anymore, but we believe that Turkey is unlikely to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested since the failed coup, it may become unavoidable for the EU to suspend the process. Our baseline forecast has been that the death penalty is unlikely to be reinstated, but this cannot be ruled out given the government's increasingly hardline nationalist stance. An agreement on a solution to end the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but we believe that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period. The EU needs to continue working with Turkey, albeit on a transactional basis, to prevent the country from walking away from the migrant deal signed in March 2016. For his part, Mr Erdogan will continue to benefit domestically by demonising the EU. Condemnation of the bloc helps to stir up nationalist sentiment and increase his political standing with voters.
Turkey's hopes of a reset of relations with the US are misplaced
Under the administration of Mr Trump, we expect that US-Turkey ties will be strained and typified by numerous breakdowns, disappointing the Turkish government's expectations of closer collaboration. Mr Trump's relationship with Mr Erdogan will be largely transactional, with a weakly defined approach to achieving the shared goal of defeating Islamic State (IS). Mr Trump is unlikely to prioritise Turkey's two main concerns: opposition to US support for Syrian Kurdish groups also fighting IS and Turkey's request for the extradition from the US of Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric whose supporters are accused of masterminding the failed military coup in July 2016. Anti-US sentiment remains strong in Turkey but has been kept at bay by the silence of the Turkish government and media, in spite of Mr Trump's so-called Muslim ban and his use of terminology such as "radical Islamist terrorists" as a justification for the ban. This restraint is unlikely to last long if Mr Erdogan feels that Turkey's concerns are not being addressed adequately.
Political outlook: Will the US relax sanctions on Russia?
Donald Trump, the newly inaugurated president of the US, has spoken on several occasions of his desire to improve relations with Russia. This has raised the prospect that he might relax the sectoral sanctions imposed on Russia in response to its annexation of Crimea and military intervention in eastern Ukraine. Mr Trump does not require congressional approval to lift sanctions; however, there are significant impediments to such a move. The security and political establishment is overwhelmingly against the relaxation of sanctions on Russia, and some cabinet appointees have taken a hawkish line in their congressional confirmation hearings. However, Mr Trump's early days in office suggest that the president might be willing to make radical and controversial foreign policy moves.
The final months of Barack Obama's presidency were marked by a further deterioration in relations with Russia. In late December 2016 the US intelligence agencies released a report suggesting that Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, had directed Russian hacking of the US presidential election, reportedly initially to discredit the process and subsequently to help Mr Trump. On December 29th, in the wake of the intelligence report, Mr Obama ordered wide-ranging measures against Russian diplomats and intelligence officers in the US. He ordered the expulsion of 35 Russian diplomatic personnel based in Washington DC and San Francisco, as well as the closure of two compounds used by the Russian embassy, in New York state and Maryland, and he put sanctions on Russian foreign military intelligence (GRU) and the Federal Security Service (FSB), as well as four GRU officers and three companies suspected of supporting the GRU's cyber operations.
Russia hopes for improved relations
Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs drew up a list of reciprocal sanctions that envisaged expelling 35 US diplomats and closing two facilities used by the US embassy; however, on December 30th Mr Putin declined to follow the recommendation in the hope that relations could improve under Mr Trump. Mr Trump's "America First" approach to international affairs could imply a major shift in US policy vis-à-vis Russia and eastern Europe. Mr Trump has expressed scepticism about the value of US alliances in Europe, described NATO as an "obsolete" organisation, and appeared to downplay Russia's military intervention in Ukraine and its annexation of Crimea.
Mr Trump's isolationist rhetoric has been welcomed by the Russian government. The Russian president has done little to discourage hopes of a fundamentally new relationship with the US under Mr Trump. In his customary year-end press conference Mr Putin expressed confidence that the two men could put bilateral relations on a more positive footing and noted that many Americans saw the world in similar terms to Russians, which was why (he claimed) Mr Trump had won the election. Senior parliamentarians have expressed similar expectations, although the president's spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, said on December 21st that Russia did not expect any rapid change of US position on NATO's push eastward or sanctions on Russia. On January 22nd Dmitry Medvedev, the prime minister, said that he did not expect sanctions to be lifted soon.
Can a deal be done?
Mr Trump's desire to improve relations with Russia has raised the prospect that he might relax sanctions on the country. He has the option of eradicating most of the Ukraine-related sanctions at the stroke of a pen, because they were established by executive order. However, the new president likes to characterise himself as a deal-maker and to project an image of uncompromising strength. It therefore appears unlikely that he will relax sanctions unless he can present it as part of a broader bilateral deal that offers clear benefits to the US.
On January 15th Mr Trump suggested that he would consider relaxing sanctions on Russia in exchange for co-operation in fighting terrorism and achieving other goals. However, he also stated that the sanctions would remain in place "at least for a period of time". Mr Trump held his first telephone call as president with Mr Putin on January 28th. The readout from these calls did not directly refer to sanctions, but the Russian statement noted that both parties "stressed the importance of rebuilding mutually beneficial trade".
Mr Trump has signalled the possibility of a broad-ranging deal with Russia to end the dispute over Ukraine, scale back NATO and abandon US efforts to oust the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, in order to focus jointly with Russia on exterminating Islamic State (IS) in Syria and Iraq. However, the impediments to such a grand bilateral deal remain substantial. Although the two leaders seem to be in broad agreement on Syria, they are at odds regarding the Iran nuclear deal and North Korea's efforts to extend its nuclear-strike capability. It is also unclear whether closer co-operation between the US and Russia would be sufficient to secure a resolution of the intractable conflict in Syria or to deliver meaningful additional progress in tackling international terrorism.
Constraining factors?
Any move to undermine NATO or reduce US security engagement in Europe-two of the biggest concerns for Russia-will be strongly opposed by large parts of the US security establishment and Congress. There also appears to be no unity of opinion on Russia within Mr Trump's team. Rex Tillerson, Mr Trump's secretary of state, and James Mattis, the new secretary of defence, were both critical of Russia in their congressional confirmation hearings. Shortly after his appointment Mr Mattis told other members of the alliance that the US had an "unshakeable commitment to NATO".
The publication on January 10th of an uncorroborated dossier compiled by a former British intelligence agent has drawn attention to allegations of close ties between Mr Trump and some of his advisers and Russian officials. Mr Trump has strongly refuted the claims set out in the dossier, but at a press conference on January 11th he conceded that Russia was probably responsible for the hacking of the Democratic National Committee during the election campaign. In February Mr Trump's national security adviser, Michael Flynn, was forced to resign after revelations emerged that he had lied about discussions he held with the Russian ambassador before being appointed to the national security post. The heads of the US security services are due to testify to Congress over links between Russia and Mr Trump's election campaign. The controversy surrounding the issue may limit Mr Trump's room for manoeuvre and make it more difficult for him to improve relations with Russia-in the light of the controversy, any concession on sanctions could be viewed as being driven by personal rather than national interests.
Outlook
The likelihood of a relaxation of US sectoral sanctions on Russia has undoubtedly risen since Mr Trump's election. The outlook is now finely balanced and complicated by the contradictory policy views held by various members of Mr Trump's team. We now believe that Mr Trump is likely to relax some sanctions on Russia over the course of his presidency, although in the first instance this might be limited to a lifting of measures on some individuals or a reversal of the measures taken against the GRU and FSB by Mr Obama in the final days of his presidency.
We continue to believe there remains a significant risk that, following a brief period of thaw, bilateral relations could again worsen. The institutional basis for an improvement in relations is shaky and the countries share few common interests. Mr Trump is not the first president to seek to improve ties with Russia-Mr Obama and George Bush, another former US president, also tried to reset relations at the start of their administrations. In both cases relations had deteriorated significantly by the end of their terms in office. If the new president were to lift sanctions, it cannot be entirely excluded that the legislature might impose its own.
Political outlook: Economic policy
With a conservative fiscal bias prevailing across most of the region, policy-makers continue to rely on interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. This creates a significant degree of exposure to the impact of the monetary policy cycle in the US, where The Economist Intelligence Unit expects further tightening over the forecast period (2017-21). The current reliance on monetary policy will also continue to exacerbate strains between monetary and fiscal policymakers, with the European Central Bank (ECB) in particular continuing to express concerns about the lack of heavy lifting in fiscal policy.
The UK has begun to alter its policy framework following its EU referendum
The UK faces particularly stark economic policy challenges following its decision in a referendum on June 23rd to withdraw from the EU. Leaving the EU will represent a break with decades of settled policy and, depending on how negotiations with the remaining member states proceed, may require a major reconfiguration of the country's regional and global trade, investment and migration ties. Monetary policy in the UK has already been loosened in response to the referendum result, and the government has taken some steps to address structural weaknesses, such as poor productivity growth, which have held the UK economy back in recent years. Such policy action seeks to pre-empt the risk that the UK's structural deficiencies might worsen either as a result of the economic fallout from the Brexit vote, or as a result of its implications for future trade and immigration.
Another country in which the overall economic policy framework is clouded by uncertainty is Turkey, where long-standing concerns about the policy-making implications of political instability have deepened following the failed coup attempt on July 15th and subsequent government crackdown. Structural reforms needed to improve Turkey's competitiveness have been on the government agenda but have yet to materialise. The failed coup has increased uncertainty further, leaving the Central Bank of Turkey-led by the governor, Murat Cetinkaya-and the deputy prime minister with responsibility for economic affairs, Mehmet Simsek, to try to reassure investors that macro-economic stability will be maintained. Domestic political instability and the prospect of tighter global liquidity as a result of expectations of higher US interest rates following the election of Donald Trump as US president has put the Turkish lira under severe pressure. A modest interest-rate rise by the Central Bank of Turkey in November, followed by the government's announcement of a package of measures to boost flagging economic growth, has had a limited impact on the Turkish currency. If it continues to depreciate at its current pace, the Central Bank may have to raise rates much more sharply. An abrupt tightening of policy could strangle Turkey's already fragile economic growth.
In Russia, the fall in oil prices, which led to a significant contraction in real GDP and household consumption, has underlined the imperative for reforms to encourage investment and diversification away from commodity exports. Two competing centres of expertise, one under Aleksei Kudrin, a former minister of finance, and the other centred around the Stolypin Group, headed by Boris Titov, the business ombudsman, have put forward contrasting proposals for structural reforms. We do not expect significant reforms to be undertaken before the presidential election in 2018. Following the re-election of Vladimir Putin, the incumbent, economic policy will continue to prioritise social and political stability, and we expect state involvement in the economy to remain substantial. Reform of the tax system and a gradual rise in the pension age appear likely. Institutional reform to strengthen the rule of law and protection for businesses looks much more difficult to achieve.
Political outlook: Fiscal policy

We expect fiscal consolidation to exert a much less powerful drag on growth over the forecast period compared with the preceding five years. Most governments in the region have completed the majority of the fiscal repair that they embarked upon in response to the financial crisis. Almost all European countries improved their fiscal positions in 2009-15, with the star performers being Ireland (+11.9 percentage points of GDP), Iceland and Lithuania (+8.9), and Greece (+7.6). However, significant fiscal loosening remains off the cards for most, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis. Although fiscal retrenchment has been painful and severe in much of the continent, many countries have little to show for it. Years of gaping deficits, weak or negative nominal GDP growth and (in some cases) expensive bank bail-outs have seen public debt/GDP ratios spike in a large number of states. Hefty public debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the euro zone for many years, although the cost of debt servicing has fallen owing to the exceptionally low interest rates that currently prevail across the bloc.
The UK's vote to leave the EU has transformed the fiscal outlook
Downward revisions to economic growth forecasts since the Brexit vote have made the UK government's previous target of achieving a budget surplus by the end of the current parliament (2020) even less feasible than before. Official projections released in March 2017 show the general government deficit widening marginally in the current fiscal year (2017/18) before narrowing throughout the forecast period, but remaining in deficit in 2021/22. The chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, aims to return the budget to balance "as early as possible" in the next parliament. This new target leaves some fiscal room for manoeuvre, although this will be undermined in the event that the economic fallout from Brexit is more severe than expected. We forecast that the deficit will widen to 4% of GDP in 2017, from an estimated 3.7% in 2016, as automatic stabilisers push up spending on social transfers as unemployment increases. However, revenue will still be rising, and in 2018-21 the government will aim to nudge down discretionary spending as a proportion of GDP. We expect the deficit to have narrowed to about 2% of GDP by 2021. We estimate that the public debt burden reached 91% of GDP in 2016, and will peak at about 95% by 2019, before falling thereafter.
Within the EU, over the past year a number of national governments have shown signs of pushing back against centralised fiscal constraints, which have become significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis. Renewed tension between member states and the European Commission, which enforces the EU's budgetary rules, are now coming to a head. In early July 2016 the Commission proposed that Spain and Portugal should be fined for their failure to meet deficit targets in 2015. Although the Commission ultimately stepped back from this position, the episode highlighted the growing tension between the strict fiscal rules agreed at the height of the crisis and the mounting political and economic arguments within member states for a greater degree of fiscal flexibility.
The fiscal position has deteriorated across the former Soviet Union
The steep fall in commodity prices and the sharp reduction in export demand and remittance inflows from Russia caused a significant deterioration in economic conditions across the former Soviet Union in 2015-16. This has contributed to a general deterioration in the fiscal picture across the region. The three major former Soviet Union oil exporters-Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Russia-were particularly hard hit and drew down on reserves in their sovereign wealth funds to cover wider budget deficits and/or maintain investment as bank lending fell. All three countries have announced privatisation programmes to plug funding gaps, but we remain sceptical about the scope and pace of these plans. Russia completed the sale of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a major oil producer, in December 2016; however, the terms of the deal remain unclear and the state retains control of the company. Russia's financing challenges are acute, as international sanctions make it difficult for the country to increase foreign borrowing. The Russian Ministry of Finance has put forward ambitious austerity measures that, if implemented in full, would decrease spending by the equivalent of 2-3% of GDP in three years. We do not expect the ministry to succeed in holding expenditure steady in nominal terms in 2017-19, as it intends, in part owing to the presidential election in 2018. However, revenue planning has been set on the basis of a conservative oil price, and we therefore expect the budget deficit to gradually narrow to less than 2% of GDP by 2020.
Weak institutional structures, high inflation and rapid currency depreciation have limited the ability of many countries in the region to respond to the economic slowdown with an expansive fiscal policy. Tajikistan, which has experienced a serious banking crisis, is likely either to seek funding from the IMF or further bilateral support from China or Russia (the Russian-backed Eurasian Bank released the first of two US$20m tranches of financial support in August 2016, with the second due in the fourth quarter of this year). The most notable exception in Central Asia is Kazakhstan, which is drawing on its substantial reserves to implement an ambitious counter-cyclical spending programme to offset the impact of falling household demand. The country avoided recession in 2016, recording real GDP growth of 1.3%. This is nevertheless significantly below the average growth rate of the past ten years.
Political outlook: The spring budget: the chancellor's U-turn
In the UK's final spring budget, delivered by the chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond, on March 8th the government restated its aim of preparing the country for its future outside the EU. Addressing weak productivity and promoting "fairness" are major objectives, to which end there will be a new effort to improve vocational skills.
As expected, additional funding was allocated to social care and there was targeted relief for businesses facing higher business rates. However, the chancellor was forced to make a swift U-turn on his proposal to fund these measures through an increase in national insurance contributions (NICs) from the self-employed, after this met with staunch opposition.
Compared with its previous forecast, in November, the UK's independent fiscal watchdog, the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), expects real GDP to grow at a faster pace in 2017, but at a slower pace in 2018-20.
Fiscal projections from the OBR see lower public-sector net borrowing in fiscal year 2016/17, but as this is down to one-off factors the public borrowing profile is broadly the same thereafter. Public-sector net debt will begin to fall as a share of GDP from 2018/19.
The budget was short of ground-breaking measures, with the chancellor likely to wait until the autumn budget-now the centrepiece of the fiscal year-to deliver bigger reforms, particularly as some uncertainty related to the Brexit process should have receded by then.
Mr Hammond's rhetoric was more forceful than the measures that he announced in the budget, partly because the government had already made more sizeable spending commitments in the autumn statement last November, as part of its strategy to boost the economy's resilience to Brexit. The chancellor reiterated that the government was aiming to build a "stronger, fairer and more global Britain" in order to prepare the country for "a global future" outside the EU. This strategy begins with tackling the causes of low productivity growth, which have held back the UK's economic recovery since the global financial crisis.
Renewed focus on vocational skills, but no big surprises
Having announced a National Productivity Investment Fund worth £23bn (US$28bn) last November, which was mainly directed at greater spending on infrastructure and innovation, there was a renewed focus on the need for investment in skills and education in this budget, with the chancellor noting that too many young people lack the skills that they need for the modern labour market. This will be addressed with a £260m (US$316m) investment in existing schools over the next three years, an extension of the free schools programme, the introduction of "T-Levels", which will provide focused routes to technical careers (as compared with "A-levels" in academia), and free transport for children travelling far to attend selective schools. Mr Hammond said that changes in this area were designed not only to boost productivity but also to promote fairness.
Most of the remaining measures announced in the budget were widely anticipated. Over the next three years, £2.4bn of additional funding will be provided for social care and £510m for the National Health Service (NHS). Mr Hammond responded to pressure from businesses and backbench members of parliament (MPs) to provide targeted relief for those facing an increase in business rates when these are revalued in April: a £305m fund will be provided for local councils to offer discretionary relief for hard-hit cases, there will be additional support for those in receipt of small business rate relief and in 2017/18 small pubs will get a £1,000 (US$1,216) discount on the business rates bill.
A forced U-turn on rise in self-employed NICs
In order to fund these measures, Mr Hammond proposed to level the playing field across different forms of employment, by reducing the "unfair discrepancy" between the total tax paid by an employed worker and that paid by those who set up their own companies. However, by proposing to raise NICs for the self-employed, by 1% in both 2018/19 and 2019/20, taking the rate to 11% (still below the employee rate of 12%), he broke a Conservative Party manifesto promise, causing uproar among Conservative MPs and supporters. Forced to make a swift U-turn, Mr Hammond will have to find alternative revenue of £2bn for social spending increases through to 2021/22. Headline tax increases are not politically feasible, but the sum is rather modest, and a combination of a spending squeeze and stealth tax rises would probably suffice.
Mr Hammond plans to raise £820m over this period through new measures to tackle tax non-compliance and a further £2.6bn through a reduction in the tax-free dividend allowance for directors and shareholders, to £2,000, from £5,000, in 2018/19-another measure aimed at promoting fairness. Mr Hammond announced that the government's "sugar tax" was raising less than expected in revenue because producers had responded by reducing the amount of sugar in their drinks, so a new minimum excise duty will be placed on cigarettes.
For consumers, set to see real incomes eroded by rising inflation in 2017-18, Mr Hammond noted that in April the personal allowance would be rising for the seventh consecutive year, to £11,500, with the higher-rate threshold rising to £45,000, and said that the government would meet its manifesto promise to increase these thresholds to £12,500 and £50,000 respectively by the end of the current parliament. The government will be publishing a green paper on consumer protection to help "ordinary working people".
Finally, Mr Hammond said that he had reached a deal with the mayor of London on further devolution, and announced £350m in additional funds for the Scottish government, £200m for the Welsh government and almost £120m for an incoming Northern Ireland executive, adding that the country was "stronger together".
Lower borrowing, briefly
The economy gathered momentum in the second half of 2016, and in response the OBR revised up its forecast for real GDP growth in 2017, to 2%, from 1.4% forecast after the autumn statement in November. Mr Hammond said that the resilience in the economy last year had been reflected in the labour market, and that the positive employment trend was set to continue over the OBR's forecast period. However, the OBR's new growth profile sags from 2018 onwards, when the pace of real GDP growth is forecast to slow to 1.6%, before picking up to 1.7% in 2019 and 1.9% in 2020. This compares with a previous OBR forecast of 1.7% real GDP growth in 2018 and 2.1% on average in 2019-20.
Stronger than expected growth in tax receipts in 2016 mean that the government is on course to undershoot its fiscal target for 2016/17, set in November, and so it has been revised down by £16.4bn, to £51.7bn. However, the OBR assessed that this revision reflected short-term factors that would not lead to a fundamental improvement in the public finances, and as a result the borrowing profile returns to its previous projection in 2017/18, with a slightly faster decline forecast in 2018/19 and 2019/20. This occurs despite the downward revision to growth in these years, owing to the net impact of measures announced in the budget. As before, however, big spending cuts in the final two fiscal years of the forecast period-largely reflecting departmental spending limits but also lower spending on welfare-pull the borrowing total down to just below £19bn on average.
The OBR still forecasts that public-sector net debt will begin to fall as a share of GDP from 2018/19, after peaking at 88.8% in 2017/18, although this is slightly lower than the 90.2% peak forecast in November. The debt/GDP ratio also ends the forecast period at just below 80% in 2021/22, a downward revision from 81.6% previously. This largely reflects lower cumulative borrowing during the forecast period, but also changes to the way that the OBR has modelled the accounting effect of future asset purchases made under the Asset Purchase Facility of the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank), because as maturing government bonds are rolled over the new purchases tend to have lower coupons than the ones that they replace.
Small steps in the right direction
The budget was unsurprisingly cautious. The government will trigger Article 50 of the Lisbon treaty on March 29th-giving formal notification of the UK's intention to withdraw from the EU-and so is taking a cautious approach to the public finances, making only small tweaks to taxes and spending plans that are broadly fiscally neutral. The chancellor may be holding back on announcing big reforms until late 2017, when the autumn statement will be replaced by a full autumn budget, which will serve as the big fiscal event of the year. Some uncertainty about the UK's future relationship with the EU may have receded by then, encouraging the chancellor to make bolder changes.
Nevertheless, further steps were taken to address the root causes of weak productivity in this budget, with the government switching its focus to the UK's vocational skills deficit. However, as with the National Productivity Investment Fund, although the measures represent steps in the right direction they are probably too modest in size and scope to invigorate the weak recovery in productivity and close the UK's productivity gap with its peers. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), in 2014 output per hour in the UK was 18 percentage points below the average for the rest of the G7 economies. The risk also remains that a deterioration in the public finances as the UK withdraws from the EU will constrain the government's ability to extend this plan in the future, although Mr Hammond's aim to reach a budget surplus "as early as possible" after the next election will provide some flexibility.
Political outlook: Monetary policy and exchange rates
