In most of Europe monetary policy remains exceptionally accommodative and will continue to do so throughout the forecast period. This is particularly the case in the EU, where the bloc's bias towards tight fiscal policy puts an unusual degree of pressure on the monetary authorities. We do not expect either the ECB or the Bank of England (BoE, the UK central bank) to increase rates in 2017-21.
We expect tapering of the ECB's QE programme to begin in 2018
Amid heightened political risk, the euro zone economy is showing increasing momentum, and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and an EUR80bn (US$85bn) per month quantitative easing (QE) programme, which will fall to EUR60bn per month from April until end-2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, emphasised that the reduction in the pace of QE was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period than if purchases continued at the current rate, and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our five-year forecast period, in 2021.
The Bank of England has loosened policy following the EU referendum
The BoE took several steps in 2016 to limit the financial and economic fallout from the Brexit vote. First, the bank's financial policy committee reduced the countercyclical buffer rate from 0.5% of banks' UK exposures to zero and made additional funds available to support market functioning. In August 2016 the bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) announced a package of stimulus measures designed to forestall a deterioration in economic conditions. The package of measures included four main changes:
a 25-basis-point cut to the policy rate, from 0.5% to 0.25%;
a £60bn (US$75bn) increase in the BoE's holding of government bonds under its QE programme, which will now total £435bn;
a £10bn purchase of corporate bonds; and
a new Term Funding Scheme (TFS), which is designed to boost commercial banks' lending.
A rapid depreciation of the pound has exacerbated inflationary pressure, and inflation is likely to overshoot its 2% target in 2017. At its meeting on March 16th 2017 the BoE's MPC kept policy unchanged, with the main interest rate at 0.25% and the stock of government bond purchases at £435bn. One member of the eight-member MPC voted to increase the policy rate by 25 basis points. Some MPC members said that "it would take relatively little further upside news" to prompt them to support a rate increase. However, with the economy set to lose some momentum in the second half of this year, unanimous support for a rate rise is still likely to be some way off.
Amid bouts of volatility, sterling has been on a generally depreciating trend since the Brexit vote in June 2016, reflecting investor unease about the implications of the vote. Financial market uncertainty is likely to persist, and we forecast that sterling will depreciate further against the US dollar and the euro this year. The depreciation against the dollar will be larger than against the euro (at about 11% and 8% respectively), as the dollar is supported by rapid economic growth in the US and monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank). However, we expect the pound to make a gradual recovery against the dollar in the final years of the forecast period, owing to our forecast of a recession in the US and monetary easing by the Fed in 2019.
Policy to be kept tight to support the Turkish lira and lower inflation
We expect that in the coming months the Central Bank of Turkey will have to tighten monetary policy further to re-assert its independence from political pressure to lower interest rates to revive economic activity, and at the same time to prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates. We expect the bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macro-prudential measures and other policies. Having steadily lowered interest rates in May-September 2016, the Central Bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little-used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which has been raised by a total of 200 basis points, to 11.75% in mid-March. Since November 2016, the weighted average cost of the Central Bank's funds to the banking system has risen from 7.8%, to 11.3% in mid-March 2017.
The Central Bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, the one-week repurchase lending rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that the corridor of interest rates that the bank has been using to vary the cost of funds to the banking system will be eliminated until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases. From 2017 the bank will hold only eight regular MPC meetings annually rather than 12.
The Turkish lira has been highly volatile and on a sharply depreciating path against all major currencies since September 2016. Amid further bouts of volatility, we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar to an annual average of TL3.84:US$1 in 2017, a fall of 21%. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL4.08:US$1 in 2021.
Inflationary pressures have weakened in Russia in early 2016
In Russia, inflation averaged 15.5% in 2015, as the sharp depreciation of the rouble in the final quarter of 2014 fed through into high import prices. A combination of weak demand and relatively tight monetary policy by the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) led to significant disinflation in 2016; over the year as a whole, inflation averaged 7%.
The CBR has been relatively successful in overcoming the impact of cost-push inflation linked to depreciation of the rouble, helped by a strong harvest in 2016 and rouble appreciation in the second half of the year. In the medium term, however, the major role played by the oil price in determining the terms of trade and inflation expectations will continue to complicate monetary policy. In addition, the CBR's job is made more difficult by rigidities in the labour market, low competition in some sectors and the limited size of the financial sector. These factors may make it harder to maintain stable and low inflation (particularly in the case of a poor domestic harvest, given the restrictions on food imports from many Western states). Administratively-controlled prices for many services and the rate of indexation of transfers play a large role in shaping inflation expectations, and lie beyond the control of the CBR. The CBR may resume monetary loosening as early as June 2017, but real interest rates are likely to remain positive throughout the forecast period. We forecast that the policy rate will be cut to 8.5-9% by end-2017. The CBR governor, Elvira Nabiullina, has suggested that an appropriate level for the real interest rate would be about 2.5-3% when inflation moves close to the CBR's 4% target. Although the CBR is under pressure from some policymakers to loosen monetary policy, the bank's management appears to have the support of the presidential administration in maintaining a relatively tight policy.
For those central and east European countries with currencies that are pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of Fed tightening. However, we do not see significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina or Bulgaria, or to the peg in Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of the record tourism season, have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue, to an average of HRK7.48:EUR1 this year.
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices (which has hit commodity exporters). Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan both officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, the commitment of both countries to a free float would be seriously tested in the event of further oil volatility. We would expect the central banks of both countries to intervene, at least temporarily, in such a scenario to prevent sharp fluctuations in the currency and maintain financial and monetary stability.
The Central Bank of Azerbaijan (CBA) had to grapple with a serious banking crisis in 2016 and struggled to restore confidence in the currency, the manat, following the devaluation in December 2015. Ten banks failed in 2016, which further undermined confidence in the banking system and encouraged a flight to the US dollar. In early 20177 the CBA made substantial foreign-exchange reserves from the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ, the sovereign wealth fund) available to the central bank in an effort to restore confidence in the currency. This appears to have had a positive impact on sentiment. The manat stabilised and then appreciated against the dollar in the first quarter of 2017. We do not believe that the manat is overvalued, and with oil prices likely to average significantly higher than in 2016, the CBA may be able to escape the cycle of currency weakening, high inflation and financial instability that it experienced in 2016.
Non-commodity exporters' currencies should stabilise in 2017
The currencies of most non-commodity exporters should stabilise in 2017, as the main price adjustment from lower remittances from Russia and the weaker regional growth outlook has now taken place. However, the outlook remains uncertain-weaker than forecast commodity prices or a return to fighting in eastern Ukraine could trigger another bout of currency volatility in Russia, which will be transmitted to most of the regional economies. Currency volatility over the past year has led to the increased dollarisation of many economies in the region, which will hamper the effectiveness of monetary policy, and the ability of the central banks to stabilise inflation and output.

The UK economy has been resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote. However, rising cost pressures stemming from a weaker pound, combined with uncertainty about the Brexit negotiations and the UK's future relationship with the EU, are likely to weigh more heavily on economic activity later this year, and on investment spending in particular. The Economist Intelligence Unit therefore expects a slowdown in the pace of economic growth, from 1.8% in 2016 to 1.7% in 2017 and 1% per year in 2018-19. A deal on the UK's new trading relationship with the EU is likely to be phased in from 2019. We expect the pace of real GDP growth to rise to 2% by 2021.
The economic impact of the UK's vote to leave the EU on the wider regional economy could be substantial. In addition to the direct impact via trade and investment channels, over time the referendum result is also likely to compound centrifugal political and institutional dynamics in the EU and euro zone, which already militate against effective policymaking and which have contributed to the region's weak economic performance in recent years. That said, in the nine months since the UK voted to leave the EU, the impact on Europe's economy has been barely noticeable. A small dip in economy-wide confidence in July and August quickly reversed, and a modest recovery across the region has continued uninterrupted. Economic and political risks are likely to intensify in the course of 2017, once the UK government formally begins the process of withdrawing from the EU. The short-term economic fallout from Brexit will be modest for Europe, but the UK's departure will exacerbate weaknesses that have been holding back the region's economic recovery in recent years, particularly as EU leaders turn their attention away from domestic issues, such as reform efforts, and focus on negotiations with the UK.
The region's economic prospects are unusually affected at present by several external factors that have been dominating the global economic landscape. Two important such factors are the pace of monetary tightening in the US and the nature of the slowdown that is under way in China. On the first of these, we now expect the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) to increase rates three times in 2017 (in line with the Fed's forward guidance) and twice in 2018. The election in November of Donald Trump as US president raised upside risks to economic growth in the country, and therefore increased the chance of a faster pace of monetary tightening by the Fed. However, we remain sceptical that the new administration will drive significantly faster US growth. In our view therefore, the path of Fed tightening is likely to remain gradual. This should ease pressure on a number of countries in the region-notably Turkey, Russia, Poland, Hungary, Georgia and Croatia-that are more exposed than others to the effects of Fed tightening. Although our central forecast is that the US business cycle will end in 2019, an external shock could bring it to a halt sooner. Unprecedented Fed policies have inflated asset prices, and a turn in investor sentiment could harm consumer and business confidence.
The Chinese economy has continued to defy gravity, with official data showing growth slowing smoothly, despite persistent inefficiencies in the state sector and recessionary conditions in the industrial north-east. However, we think that a hard landing is on the cards, and forecast that growth will lurch down from 6.4% in 2017 to 4.2% in 2018. This kind of shift is unprecedented in modern China and will come at a time when the global economy is uniquely unprepared to react. Consequently, 2018 will be a year of anxiety around the world, characterised by volatility in real economies and financial markets.

Outlook for the euro zone will remain challenging
Over the longer term the outlook for the single currency area will remain challenging, as demographic factors will begin to exert a more powerful drag on an increasing number of countries in the bloc. During the forecast period (2017-21) we expect policymakers to continue to try to remedy some of the euro zone's institutional shortcomings, but we do not expect them to find a game-changing solution. In particular, they are unlikely to reform the bloc's fiscal policy frame-work. This means that tensions will persist between member states over targets for budget deficits, and it is almost inconceivable that the bloc's fiscal authorities will significantly ease the pressure on their monetary counterparts by pursuing an actively expansionary policy.
We expect much of central and eastern Europe to face a slightly more challenging environment in the forecast period, particularly countries that have benefited from EU funding. A deadline at the end of 2015 for fund drawdowns from the EU's 2007-13 fiscal period brought an end to a surge in investment spending. Funding inflows for projects under the EU's 2014-20 funding period have not gained the same kind of momentum. Growth in Germany-a key market for these countries-will remain relatively solid, although the slowdown in China in 2018 will dampen external demand. Nonetheless, the German economy's changing structure, with investment and private consumption rising, will provide a boost to central and east European countries with strong trade links to their larger neighbour.
Within central and eastern Europe, there are significant divergences, and we expect these to persist. The Visegrad states-the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary and Poland-will see slower but still healthy growth rates in 2017-21, with low oil prices, significant trade integration with Germany, generally weighty and competitive external sectors (measured as exports relative to GDP), and a much smaller fiscal drag than previously supporting growth rates. Lower EU fund inflows as projects financed under the 2014-20 fiscal period get started will, however, weigh on growth this year. Growth in the Czech Republic-the star performer in 2015, with 4.6% growth-slowed to 2.3% in 2016 and is forecast at an average of 2.3% in 2017-21. In Slovakia, average growth will slow from 3.8% in 2015, but remain above 3% on average in 2017-21. In Hungary, growth slowed to 1.7% in 2016, from 3.1% in 2015, but is expected to pick up to an annual average of 2.4% in 2017-21. In Poland, we estimate that real GDP expansion slowed from 3.9% in 2015 to 2.8% in 2016, reflecting a deterioration in policy and a rise in political risk. We expect real GDP to expand at an average annual rate of 3.2% in 2017-21.
Economic activity is picking up in south-east Europe
In south-east Europe, the situation is generally improving after a protracted and difficult post-crisis recovery, with growth rates in the region set to overtake those of the Visegrad states and the Baltics in 2016-17. We expect continued strong real GDP growth in the region's biggest economy, Romania, which grew by 4.8% in 2016. We expect growth to average 3.4% per year in 2017-21. However, rapid wage growth is driving a consumer boom that is sucking in imports and inflating the current-account deficit, and a raft of tax cuts have widened the fiscal deficit. Bulgaria will also maintain the momentum established in 2015, with growth in 2017 expected to be 3.1%, after an expansion of 3.4% in 2016. This sustained pick-up is driven by improved performance in the euro zone, robust export performance and increased expenditure on infrastructure projects, which received a boost from a surge in the inflow of EU funds.
Growth in the western Balkans and Baltics to accelerate; Visegrad to slow
We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans (Albania, Bosnia and Hercegovina, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) of 3.3% per year in 2017-18, up from an annual average of around 3% in 2015-16. This compares with our forecast of average real GDP growth of 3% per year in the Visegrad countries in 2017-18, which represents a slowdown from the 3.4% average real GDP growth recorded in 2015-16. Growth in the three Baltic states is forecast to increase from an average of 1.9% per year in 2015-16 to 2.8% per year on average in 2017-18.
Economic activity in the western Balkans has picked up in the past two years, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors such as low oil prices. In 2015 private investment and exports were the main drivers of growth in Albania, Montengero and Serbia, with private consumption remaining weak, pointing to a more balanced growth trajectory. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the global economic crisis in 2007-09, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some notable exceptions, such as Montengero). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the region should benefit from the structural reforms that are now under way in most countries. On the downside, slow progress on structural reforms, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) a continued large fiscal drag remain impediments to faster growth. We do not think that the fallout from the Brexit vote will be unduly negative for the Balkans, the slow progress of which towards EU membership is set to continue.
Croatia had been the worst-performing economy in the former communist region, averaging annual real GDP growth of -1.6% in 2009-15. It emerged from six years of recession in 2015 with growth of 1.6%. Growth accelerated to 2.9% in 2016, driven by private consumption and investment, and benefiting from favourable base effects and cyclical factors, including low international oil prices and a record tourism season. We forecast real GDP growth of 3.2% this year, as the negative effect on private consumption of lower real income growth will be offset by a slew of tax cuts and increases in minimum and public-sector wages. In 2018-21 we expect the economy to grow by an annual average of 2.6%-a reasonable rate of expansion compared with the rest of the region. Nevertheless, the economy will only reach its 2008 level towards the end of the forecast period. Croatia is still at a relatively early stage in the reform process and is working off the excesses of the pre-crisis years. The need to pay down large public- and private-sector debt, a deteriorating demographic picture, poor competitiveness and a subdued external outlook will all contribute to the weak trend growth rate.
Greece's economic recovery stalled in 2015 as a result of the negative effect of political uncertainty on business and consumer confidence, but the recession was not as bad as might have been expected, owing to another strong tourism sector performance, low oil prices, consumers' readiness to spend their savings rather than risk a haircut on household deposits, and a rise in electronic payments (reducing the shadow economy). Real GDP growth contracted by 0.3% (seasonally adjusted) and by 0.2% in unadjusted terms in 2015, and remained flat in 2016. We forecast modest real GDP growth of 1.2% this year. The prospects for the economy are gloomy, partly because of continued investor uncertainty and partly because of the negative effect on consumption of bail-out reforms. A triple combination of higher taxes, higher social security payments and debt repayments will put further pressure on disposable income.
Russia's economy will move into a recovery phase next year
Although low energy prices contributed to a modest recovery in EU growth in 2015, they triggered a deep recession across most of the former Soviet Union. Russia's real GDP, which remains an important driver of the regional economy, contracted by 2.8% in 2015. The recession persisted in 2016, as oil prices remained low and households and companies continued to deleverage. Household incomes declined in real terms for a second successive year. This was compounded by a contractionary fiscal policy. The weak banking sector and high political risk continued to depress investment. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan likewise faced the combined impact of contracting household and government expenditure and corporate deleveraging in 2016. Russian GDP fell by 0.2% in 2016. Kazakhstan's economy posted low growth of just 1.3%, and real GDP in Azerbaijan declined by 3.8%. The weakness of the Russian economy held down growth across the rest of the region, largely through low remittances and export demand.
Growth in Russia is expected to rebound moderately from 2017, driven by a recovery in commodity prices, which should encourage a strengthening of the rouble and household spending power. We expect the banking sector to start to stabilise, allowing for a modest recovery in investment. We forecast real GDP growth of 0.9%. Risks are broadly to the upside, given that the oil price is projected to be around 25% higher than in 2016. At the same time, there are a number of possible headwinds. The external political environment remains uncertain, and a further upsurge in tensions with the West cannot be excluded. Moreover, oil prices may remain lower than currently forecast. In the medium term, structural constraints-the weak institutional environment, poor demo-graphics and weak competition-will hold trend growth below 2% per year.
After the shocks of revolution and war, real GDP contracted by 9.9% in Ukraine in 2015. GDP grew by 2.2% in 2016, driven by a recovery in private consumption and investment. Subdued growth in Russia and restrictions on trade will limit the prospects for an export-led recovery. We forecast average annual growth of 2.6% in the medium term; however, there are significant downside risks. Our forecast assumes that there is slow but steady progress in reforming the economy and stabilising the political system, and that there is not a return to all-out war in eastern Ukraine. None of these are guaranteed. Ukraine's fiscal position remains precarious, and the potential for political instability to trigger an economic crisis is high.
In Turkey, domestic political instability, perceived security risks from terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook will have negative effects on the economy in the short and medium term. We expect real GDP growth to pick up only modestly, from an estimated 2.2% in 2016 to 2.4% in 2017. In 2018-21 we expect real GDP growth to average 3.4% per year, assuming that there is a gradual stabilisation of domestic conditions. By far the biggest risk to our growth forecast is the possibility of a severe disruption to capital inflows to Turkey.

Disinflationary pressures are beginning to unwind across the region
The slump in global oil prices in late 2014 exacerbated a marked disinflationary trend in Europe. Although demand conditions remain fragile in much of the region, we do not expect recent downward pressures on prices to lead to a damaging deflationary spiral. On the contrary, disinflationary trends provided a welcome boost to the region's real economy in 2015, and to a limited extent in 2016, as households benefited from higher real earnings and businesses from lower input costs. In aggregate terms, we expect price pressures to become firmer from 2017 and to remain below 2% by the end of the forecast period in much of the region. Base effects-notably those related to energy prices-will provide much of the initial impetus behind rising rates of inflation, as domestic demand will recover only slowly in many countries.
In a number of specific instances across the region, very different inflationary patterns will be recorded-Turkey, for example, will struggle throughout the forecast period to bring its inflation rate down to its 5% target. The stubbornness of price pressures in Turkey will largely reflect downward pressure on the lira, but in 2016 policy moves such as a sharp increase in the minimum wage will also contribute. Sharp devaluations of many former Soviet Union currencies pushed up prices significantly across the region in 2015, through imports. Price pressures eased in most countries of the region in 2016, and in 2017 we expect annual price inflation gradually to fall, on the back of weak demand, relative currency stability and subdued external price pressures. Inflation averaged 7% in Russia in 2016, down from 15.5% in 2015.
Economic forecast: Outlook for inflation in the euro zone
In February 2017, according to a flash estimate from Eurostat, EU harmonised inflation in the euro zone reached 2% year on year-its highest level since January 2013. This compares with a zero inflation rate on average across the region in 2015 and 0.2% in 2016.
Unwinding energy price base effects have pushed inflation higher, but core price pressures have remained relatively stable, reaching 0.9% in February 2017, compared with annual average rates of 0.8% in both 2015 and 2016.
These price dynamics will persist in 2017, producing a temporary spike in inflation early in the year. Thereafter, external factors such as a recent strong increase in global commodity prices and a weak euro are likely to feed into supply-chain cost pressures.
However, weak domestic demand will continue to constrain inflationary pressure, even as monetary policy becomes more accommodative. When the supply-side boost fades after 2017, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the upturn to flatten, with annual inflation averaging 1.6% in 2017 and 1.4% in 2018.
Given this outlook for inflation, we reaffirm our view that the European Central Bank (ECB) will not tighten policy rates before the end of our five-year forecast period, in 2021.
Annual inflation in the euro zone has risen consistently since April 2016, when it dipped to -0.2%. Trends in inflation across the region mainly reflect price changes in Germany, France and Italy-the countries with the three highest weightings in the aggregate inflation measure, collectively accounting for 66% of the total. Inflation rose particularly sharply in December 2016-February 2017 owing to annual inflation in Germany, which jumped by 1.5 percentage points, to 2.2%. In Italy, where price pressures have been particularly subdued, annual inflation rose by 1.5 percentage points, to 1.6%, in February. In France inflation edged higher by 0.7 percentage points, to 1.4%, weighing on the regional average increase.
In February (the latest available data for most member states) Belgium had the highest inflation rate, at 3.3%, followed by the Baltic states, where inflation was 3.2-3.3%, and Austria, at 2.4%. More modest inflation was recorded in the Netherlands, Portugal and Greece, at 1.6-1.7%, whereas inflation in Ireland was just 0.3%, reflecting the impact of euro appreciation on the cost of the country's imports from the UK, Ireland's main supplier.
Upturn in inflation driven by energy prices
Unwinding energy price base effects were largely responsible for the pick-up in inflation in the euro zone at the turn of 2016-17, and underlying price pressures have remained weak. Global oil prices fell rapidly in the second half of 2015, with the result that energy prices were 30% lower in year-on-year terms on average in the first seven months of 2016. However, this effect diminished around mid-year as global oil prices recovered, and the annual change in energy prices turned positive in October. Excluding the price of energy and unprocessed food, core inflation in the euro zone has been broadly stable in 2016 and the first two months of 2017. Further evidence of subdued underlying price pressure is found in a measure of average services inflation, which tends to be driven more by domestic factors: this was estimated at 1.3% in February, only marginally above its year-earlier level of 0.9%.
Supply-chain cost pressures will continue to build
The acceleration in annual inflation at the turn of the year largely reflected a low base of comparison after global oil prices plunged in late 2015-early 2016. As a result, the rise in annual inflation in the euro zone in the first quarter of 2017 is likely to fall back from the second quarter. Nevertheless, external price pressure will be building as global commodity prices continue their upward trend. We forecast that the price of non-oil commodities will rise by 8% this year, after a 3% decline in 2016, and oil prices will rebound by about 27% year on year, after falling by 16% last year. Alongside a recent spike in Chinese producer price inflation, this should boost average import prices in the euro zone, a net importer of oil and commodities.
Exchange-rate dynamics are also likely to contribute to upward pressure on imported price inflation in 2017. Having exhibited resilience to shocks for most of 2016 (including the UK's vote to leave the EU), the euro depreciated sharply against the US dollar following the election of Donald Trump as US president in early November, and stood at about US$1.04:EUR1 by the end of 2016, from US$1.11:EUR1 on average during the first ten months of the year. This resilience will be tested again in 2017 amid heightened political risk and a continuation of the ECB's programme of quantitative easing (QE) to end-2017. We expect this to maintain downward pressure on the euro this year.
Underlying price pressure is likely to remain weak
However, a subdued domestic demand environment in some of the euro zone's largest economies will continue to constrain the pick-up in inflation across the region. In France and Italy substantial labour market slack persists. The unemployment rate is falling in both countries but will remain at an elevated level this year, at about 9% and 12% respectively-more than double the rate in Germany, at about 4%. High unemployment will weigh on the recovery in domestic demand, feeding into strong price competition in the private sector as both French and Italian businesses remain reluctant to pass on the full rise in input costs to consumers. A decline in the unemployment rate in Spain, which has the fourth-highest weighting in the aggregate inflation measure, from 22% in 2015 to just under 20% in 2016, released pent-up demand last year, but core inflation has remained remarkably stable.
After 2017 the upturn in inflation will flatten
These dynamics will make it difficult for the ECB to keep the inflation rate at its target of "below, but close to, 2%" over the medium term. Reaching this target would require stronger-performing economies, such as Germany, to record a sustained period of above-target inflation in order to boost the euro zone average. However, although base effects from low oil prices have caused inflation in Germany to surpass 2% in early 2017, this influence will pass. Domestic demand is relatively firmer in Germany, and core inflation (excluding for energy and unprocessed food) was running higher than the headline inflation rate during most of 2016. But even in Germany there is little scope for a surge in domestically driven price pressure in 2017, as-despite low unemployment-wage growth remains modest: negotiated earnings growth in Germany averaged 2.3% in 2016.
With no inflation overshoot on the horizon, monetary policy will remain loose
For this reason monetary policy in the euro zone is likely to remain extremely accommodative throughout our five-year forecast period. From April 2017 the ECB will slow the pace at which it purchases assets under its QE programme, to EUR60bn (US$64bn) each month, from EUR80bn currently. However, Mario Draghi, the ECB governor, has been keen to emphasise that this was designed to ensure the bank's "sustained presence" in the market for a longer period than if purchases continued at the current monthly rate. After this, practical and political constraints of a further expansion of QE will mean that the ECB will begin "tapering" the monthly purchases at a rapid pace in 2018, signifying a winding down of the programme. In particular, there will be pressure from Germany to begin tightening monetary policy after inflation in the country hits 2%.
However, we do not expect an announcement on tapering to represent the beginning of monetary policy tightening in the region: interest rates are likely to stay low as inflation struggles to reach its target over the medium term. Even if inflation rises to its target level by the end of the forecast period, we expect the ECB to refrain from increasing policy rates until it anticipates a sustained target overshoot on the three-year policy horizon. We therefore do not expect euro zone interest rates to increase before the end of 2021.

a Qualitative grades are assigned according to the following scale: very good: score more than 8; good: 6.5 to 8; moderate: 5.5 to 6.4; poor: 5 to 5.4; very poor: less than 5.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its key components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of ten categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into ten categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair, although patchy, have in most countries been under way for some time. Western Europe's score remains broadly stable, rising from 7.5 in the historical period to 7.6 in the forecast period, and eastern Europe's score moves up from 6.1 to 6.5 over the same timeframe. Across the region as a whole, the strongest ranking improvements are recorded by Romania, Croatia, Cyprus, Spain and Denmark. By contrast, Turkey dropped by seven places, Poland by five and Germany by four.
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets, and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we are not forecasting a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Recent years have brought considerable improvement to the investment climate of central and eastern Europe. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even here. Factors such as a low-cost but well-qualified labour force, proximity to developed markets and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region during the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. In Russia, the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. Low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to attempt to open up and diversify their economies. Ukraine has committed itself to an ambitious reform programme; however, its economic prospects will be harmed by disruption of trade and financial ties with Russia. In all the countries of the region the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.
Sources
GDP/GNP: IMF, IFS (line 99 b/c) for local currency data, converted into dollars by the relevant year average exchange rate, also available in IFS
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS (line rf)
Population: national statistical offices and IMF, IFS (line 99z)
GDP growth and inflation: relevant central banks or national statistical offices, also available in OECD, National Accounts
Abbreviations
CEECs: Central and east European countries (excludes Russia and other members of the Commonwealth of Independent States)
ECB: European Central Bank
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines ten separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, and infrastructure. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 16 (infrastructure), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2012-16) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2017-21). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2012-16. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2017-21 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
The main sources used in the business rankings model include CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce; Freedom House, Annual Survey of Political Rights and Civil Liberties; Heritage Foundation, Index of Economic Freedom; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; UN, Human Development Report; US Social Security Administration, Social Security Programs Throughout the World; World Bank, World Development Report; World Development Indicators; Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Report.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2012-16 ranges are then used to derive 2017-21 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2017-21, not to the likely situation in 2021 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2014 or 2019). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, will succeed in establishing a presidential system of government with few checks and balances on the powers of the presidency. We expect a majority of voters to approve the necessary constitutional reforms in a referendum on April 16th 2017, with the reforms coming into effect after the parliamentary and presidential elections to be held in late 2019. The risk of the reforms being rejected is high, owing to Turkey's deteriorating security and economic outlook. Regardless of the result, Mr Erdogan and his Justice and Development Party (AKP) will continue to dominate the political scene during the forecast period (2017-21).
The failed coup in July 2016 will have lasting negative implications for the domestic political outlook, as well as destabilising effects on foreign relations and the economy. Emergency rule, which was introduced in July to purge the state of the followers of the US-based imam, Fethullah Gulen, who is accused by the government of masterminding the putsch, will continue to be used to silence government critics and disable the pro-Kurdish opposition. Emergency rule will remain in place until at least late July 2017, and probably beyond.
Turkey is vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and jihadi extremists affiliated with Islamic State (IS). Turkey risks be-coming mired in the Syrian conflict, following the deployment of Turkish troops to Syria to combat IS and to halt the territorial expansion by Syrian Kurds.
With the government preoccupied with domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges, we expect little progress on economic reforms to improve the business and investor climate. Fiscal policy will be loosened to try to boost the economy, but we expect it to remain relatively tight during the forecast period.
We expect the Central Bank of Turkey to tighten monetary policy further in the short to medium term in order to re-assert its independence from political pressure to lower interest rates, and at the same time to prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates. An abrupt tightening could choke Turkey's already fragile economic growth.
We expect real GDP growth to accelerate slightly, from an estimated 2.2% in 2016 to 2.4% in 2017 and a still moderate 3.4% annual average in 2018-21. The current-account deficit has narrowed, but will still be difficult to fund, especially if global liquidity is tightened.

Our business environment score for Turkey remains broadly unchanged in the forecast period (2017-21), but the country's global ranking deteriorates by seven places. Uncertainty has developed regarding the future direction of economic policies. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment. The main shortcomings are a politicised and inefficient judicial system, labour market rigidities and widespread tax evasion.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisations are likely to be delayed amid the post-coup upheaval in the state institutions. Some companies, notably those with media holdings or ties with the Gulenist movement, remain subject to heavy-handed state intervention.
2019-21: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in a wide range of sectors, although the opening-up of the energy market makes progress.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2019-21: FDI inflows are boosted by further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in key sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Capital controls are not considered. There is a boost to trade following the lifting of Russian sanctions. Possible increase in protectionism under the new US administration.
2019-21: Customs union with the EU might be extended, but negotiations are likely to be protracted given the deterioration in Turkish-EU relations. More free-trade agreements might come into force with the EU's trading partners.
Taxes
2017-18: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make some progress. Tax rates are largely unchanged.
2019-21: A broader income tax base as exemptions and exceptions are reduced. Possible tax cuts and increased incentives.
Financing
2017-18: Cautious monetary policy and concern about a possible deterioration in credit quality constrain lending growth. The Central Bank of Turkey remains under political pressure to keep interest rates low.
2019-21: The banking system remains stable, despite some weaknesses. Heavy reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2017-18: Labour market remains rigid, with relatively high costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. A 30% minimum-wage rise in 2016 could damage competitiveness. Obstacles to employing foreigners ease.
2019-21: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Progress, albeit slow, continues on investment plans in energy, transport and communications.
2019-21: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. The construction of major airport and urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Gaps and bottlenecks might, nevertheless, persist.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal (Ataturk) defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then, Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West, becoming a member of the Council of Europe (1949) and NATO (1952), and signing an association agreement with the then European Community (1963). A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western/EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state governed under the 1982 constitution, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened under the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but the coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey has a unicameral parliamentary system of government with parliament elected for a four-year term. To win seats parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Under the AKP Turkey is moving towards a presidential system of government. The AKP's response to the failed coup is likely to strengthen the powers of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability is Turkey's biggest policy challenge. Fiscal policy has remained prudent, but large external financing needs and changing global liquidity conditions will require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy relatively tight to attract adequate capital inflows. The Kurdish problem, which has blocked economic development in the south-east, is one of Turkey's most pressing political issues, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015 and there has been a resurgence in violence. The failed coup has highlighted long-standing institutional weaknesses, which allowed, with the AKP's consent until 2013, the secretive Gulenist movement to infiltrate the state. Further politicisation of the judiciary is likely after the coup attempt. Corruption and patronage remain widespread.
Taxation: The basic rate of corporation tax is 20%. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Tax reform to reduce evasion was one of the main elements of previous IMF reform programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2015 goods exports (fob) came to US$152bn and imports (fob) to US$200bn, leaving a trade deficit of US$48bn-a contraction from US$64bn in 2014. The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Following the attempted coup by parts of the military on July 15th 2016 there has been a sharp deterioration in Turkey's political outlook, which The Economist Intelligence Unit expects to have lasting negative effects on Turkey's social and economic stability as well as on the country's international relations. We expect the severe clampdown by the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) on suspected coup plotters, political opponents and critics to continue under the state of emergency rule that was introduced in late July 2016 and will remain in place until at least late July 2017. More than 100,000 people, mainly in the judiciary, the military, the police, academic institutions and the media, have so far been suspended, dismissed or detained. Emergency rule was introduced to purge the state of Mr Erdogan's former allies, the followers of the US-based Islamic cleric, Fethullah Gulen, who is accused by the government of masterminding the coup attempt. However, the use of these powers has been extended to eliminate the pro-Kurdish political opposition, which the government accuses of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). The attempted coup, the resurgence of political violence and the imposition of emergency rule have undermined Turkey's already fragile democratic institutions and governance structures.
The political scene will continue to be dominated by Mr Erdogan, whose plan to establish a presidential system of government with few checks and balances on the executive powers of the presidency faces its final hurdle in a divisive national referendum, to be held on April 16th 2017. Even though most opinion polls, including those commissioned by the AKP, suggest that the "no" camp has a narrow lead, we expect that a majority of voters will approve the reforms, which would come into effect after the parliamentary and presidential elections, scheduled to take place in late 2019. Mr Erdogan is popular and is a formidable campaigner; the "no" camp is divided, and the state of emergency has created a climate of fear that could deter people from voting against the reforms. A low turnout in such an atmosphere would probably favour the "yes" camp. However, the risk of the reforms being rejected cannot be overlooked and has in fact increased, as Turkey's security and economic outlook has deteriorated.
Regardless of the result, we believe it unlikely that there will be a rapid return to stability. In the event of a "yes" vote, there would be a two-year transition period before the reforms come into effect. In this period we expect that Mr Erdogan would continue to exercise his dominance through his control over the AKP and the cabinet. There appears to be no threat of a challenge or resistance to Mr Erdogan's leadership. An important question will be whether or when the government will decide to end the period of emergency rule. Emergency rule allows the president and the cabinet to pass laws without the approval of parliament and without recourse to the Constitutional Court, effectively allowing Mr Erdogan to govern as a president with executive powers. In practical terms, he is likely to use this transition period to create the new institutions and instruments of the new presidential system, staff them and, over time, complete the process of transferring policy determination and implementation from the present ministers and ministries to the presidential palace.
In the event of a "no" vote we expect that Mr Erdogan would continue to bypass the constitutional constraints on the presidency through his dominance of the AKP and the cabinet. He could also decide to call an early parliamentary election. The clampdown on the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) and the AKP's hardline nationalist stance on the Kurdish issue could cause the hard-right Nationalist Action Party (MHP) and/or the HDP to lose further support and fall below the 10% national vote threshold for party representation in parliament. This would boost the AKP's share of seats, possibly giving the party a two-thirds majority, which would eliminate the need for a referendum to change the constitution.
Security risk will remain high, with negative implications for the economy. The state is seeking to appease an insurgency by the PKK in the south-east of Turkey, address the domestic security risk posed by terrorist attacks by Kurdish militants and Islamic State (IS) in cities across the country, and implement military operations in Syria and Iraq against both IS and the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds. The purge of the Turkish armed forces and the police since the attempted coup has created operational capacity problems and contributed to intelligence failures that have exacerbated Turkey's domestic security issues. In the short to medium term neither the government nor the PKK appears to be interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will intensify.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next parliamentary and presidential elections are scheduled for early November 2019. We expect the current AKP government to last a full parliamentary term, although an early election cannot be discounted if the government's constitutional reform plan fails. We expect Mr Erdogan to stand again in the next presidential election and to remain in office, with enhanced powers, for at least one more five-year term. The next local elections are scheduled to take place by March 2019.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Since the failed coup Turkish foreign policy has been heavily conditioned by Mr Erdogan's domestic political goals, notably his push to establish a presidential system of government in Turkey. This approach, combined with ongoing political upheaval in Europe and the US, Turkey's traditional western allies, has resulted in a marked deterioration in Turkey's international relations.
Relations with the EU, and especially Greece, the Netherlands and Germany, have deteriorated sharply in recent months. This could eventually lead to the formal suspension of Turkey's EU accession negotiations and an end to Turkey's collaboration with the EU to stem the inflow of migrants and refugees into Europe. Neither Turkey nor the EU is genuinely interested in Turkish membership of the EU anymore, but we believe that Turkey is unlikely to suspend negotiations unilaterally. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, as Mr Erdogan has suggested since the failed coup, the EU might not be able to avoid suspending the process. Our baseline forecast has been that the death penalty is unlikely to be reinstated, but this cannot be ruled out given the government's increasingly hardline nationalist stance. An agreement on a solution to end the de facto division of Cyprus between the Greek Cypriot south and the Turkish Cypriot north could help to improve Turkey's relations with the EU, but we believe that a settlement is unlikely during the forecast period (2017-21).
The Turkish government's expectations of a reset of ties with the US under the administration of the new US president, Donald Trump, have so far proven unrealistic, causing growing frustration in the Turkish government. Although Mr Trump's administration is likely to be less concerned about Mr Erdogan's autocratic tendencies than its Democrat predecessor was, Mr Trump is unlikely to do much to address the two issues that are of most concern to Turkey: its request for Mr Gulen to be extradited from the US to face trial in Turkey for his alleged responsibility for the failed coup; and an end to US support for the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG), which is fighting IS in Syria and is affiliated with the PKK.
Since mid-2016Turkey has improved its ties with Russia, but the level of trust between the two countries is still low, particularly in relation to the conflict in Syria, where both countries are militarily involved but are pursuing contrasting goals. We expect relations to remain largely transactional.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
We expect political instability and fluctuations in global liquidity as a result of anticipated shifts in US monetary policy to pose an ongoing risk to foreign capital inflows to Turkey, especially in the first half of the forecast period. These are predominantly portfolio investments and short-term loans needed to meet the country's large external financing requirements, so tend to be highly volatile. Faltering capital inflows since November 2016 have put the lira under intense pressure, fuelling inflation expectations and highlighting the need for the Central Bank of Turkey to tighten monetary policy after a prolonged period of loosening. An abrupt tightening of policy could strangle Turkey's already fragile economic growth.
The economy has shown considerable resilience during past bouts of volatility in global liquidity, owing largely to the country's solid public finances and well-capitalised, well-regulated banking sector. However, Turkey's medium-term economic policy outlook remains a cause for concern. The AKP government's focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Major upward revisions to Turkey's national accounts in December 2016 have helped to improve the country's budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios. Nevertheless, the public finances are in good shape and our baseline forecast remains that fiscal policy will be kept relatively tight to maintain a low level of public debt, and to try to avoid fuelling another surge in domestic demand and a further expansion of the still large current-account deficit. Reflecting the impact of the economy's weakness, we expect the central government deficit to widen moderately, from an estimated 1.1% of GDP in 2016 to an average of 2.1% of GDP per year in 2017-21. The government debt/GDP ratio is low, but we estimate that it edged up slightly to 29.3% in 2016, from 29.1% in 2015. We expect a further moderate increase in 2017-18, before it declines to about 30% in 2021. However, the risk of a larger deterioration in the public finances cannot be ruled out. The government's decision to transfer Turkey's major state assets to a sovereign wealth fund set up in 2016 to help to finance major infrastructure projects could bring to a halt the government's privatisation programme and increase political control over state companies, and the fund could become a vehicle for increased off-budget spending.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
We expect that in the coming months the Central Bank of Turkey will have to tighten monetary policy further in order to re-assert its independence from political pressure to lower interest rates to revive economic activity, and at the same time to prevent a further depreciation of the lira amid expectations of higher US interest rates. We expect the bank to use a mix of interest-rate rises, macroprudential measures and other policies. Having steadily lowered interest rates in May-September 2016, the central bank has raised most of its main policy rates since November 2016 and has increasingly provided funding to the banking sector at its previously little-used "late liquidity window" overnight lending rate, which was raised by a total of 200 basis points, to 11.75%, in mid-March. Since November 2016 the weighted average cost of the central bank's funds to the banking system has risen from 7.8% to 11.3% in mid-March 2017.
The central bank is seeking gradually to normalise its monetary policy frame-work to establish a single policy interest rate, the one-week repo lending rate, which would help to improve transparency regarding monetary policy decisions. However, it is unlikely that the corridor will be eliminated until inflation is more firmly on a downward path towards its medium-term target of 5% and domestic political uncertainty eases. From 2017 the bank will hold only eight regular Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meetings annually rather than 12.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Domestic political instability, perceived security risks from terrorist attacks and uncertainty about the global economic outlook will have negative effects on the economy in the short and medium terms. We expect real GDP growth to pick up only modestly, from an estimated 2.2% in 2016 to 2.4% in 2017. In 2018-21 we expect real GDP growth to average about 3.4% per year, assuming that there is a gradual stabilisation of domestic conditions. By far the biggest risk to our growth forecast is the possibility of a severe disruption to capital inflows to Turkey.
After contracting in 2016 by an estimated 0.4%, we expect private consumption to recover, but only modestly, in 2017, as domestic political uncertainty and a weaker lira will dampen household spending. An expected acceleration in 2018-21 will depend on the stabilisation of the lira and consumer confidence over the medium term.
After expanding by an estimated 15% in 2016, we expect government spending to increase by a further 12% in 2017 as the government seeks to revive the economy and boost support for the presidential reform referendum in April. From 2018 we expect more moderate-but still solid-growth (presidential and parliamentary elections are due in 2019).
The deterioration in the business environment since the attempted coup will continue to dampen fixed investment growth in 2017-18, as weakened business sentiment will offset government plans to invest heavily in infrastructure projects. In 2019-21 we forecast 4.9% average annual growth.
After contracting by an estimated 1.8% in 2016 as a result of the impact of Russian sanctions and domestic security concerns, especially on the tourism sector, we expect exports of goods and services gradually to return to growth, reflecting the lifting of sanctions and the impact of a weaker lira on export competitiveness. However, we expect the perception of security risks to persist for some time, which will continue to deter visitors to Turkey. Our expectation is that a sharp slowdown in the Chinese economy in 2018 and a cyclical downturn in the US in 2019 will dampen external demand growth in those years.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Consumer price inflation has remained stubbornly high-well above the official 5% medium-term target-as a weaker lira has, for the most part, offset the disinflationary effects of plunging global oil prices since mid-2014. We expect further currency weakness and a partial recovery in oil and other commodity prices from 2017 to keep consumer price inflation well above the official target during the first half of the forecast period. Assuming that the central bank tightens monetary policy and does not loosen it too soon, we see inflation gradually easing, achieving the 5% target by end-2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The Turkish lira exchange rate has been highly volatile and on a sharply depreciating path against all major currencies since September 2016. Amid further bouts of volatility we expect the lira to depreciate against the US dollar, to an annual average of TL3.84:US$1, in 2017-a fall of 21%. In 2018-21 we forecast that the exchange rate will remain broadly stable in real terms, depreciating in nominal terms to an average of TL4.08:US$1 in 2021. The lira will also depreciate sharply against the euro in 2017-21. There are substantial risks to our exchange-rate forecast, arising from uncertainty about the outlook for global financial flows, and the impact on investor confidence of domestic political instability and geopolitical turmoil in the region surrounding Turkey.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
GDP revisions, moderate domestic demand growth, sharply lower global oil prices and a weaker lira have helped to reduce Turkey's current-account deficit in recent years. However, we expect it to widen moderately and remain sufficiently large-at a forecast average of 4.8% of GDP per year in 2017-21-to make it difficult for Turkey to meet its external financing needs if global liquidity is constrained and the loss of investor confidence since the failed coup persists. Although a weaker lira will boost Turkey's main export sectors, we expect this to be largely offset by the higher cost of imported energy and inputs for manufactured import-intensive exports. In addition, the tourism sector is likely to take several years to recover to 2015 pre-crisis levels, that is before the resurgence of terrorist attacks and the imposition of Russian sanctions.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The battle between an opposition-dominated legislature and a government with control of key state institutions will heighten tension, introducing considerable uncertainty into The Economist Intelligence Unit's political and economic forecasts. Despite the unpopularity of the government led by the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), and the persistent risk of economic collapse, we believe that the government will muddle through until the next elections are held in December 2018, after which we expect the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática coalition to take office.
A fundamental rebalancing of the economy is needed to avoid default and economic collapse, but there has been no sign of significant economic reform. Policy mismanagement will persist while Mr Maduro remains in office. Key problems include extremely expansionary macroeconomic policy, soaring inflation and a business climate that discourages investment. A new government will begin a gradual process of adjustment from 2019.
Sweeping reforms are required to restore confidence in contract and property rights, and thereby promote a recovery in investment. The business environment is among the weakest in the world, reflecting outright hostility from the government towards the private sector as well as critical shortages of inputs needed to maintain productive capacity. From 2019 a new government will encourage private investment, re-establish market mechanisms for price stability and attempt to undo the constraints imposed by the PSUV on private firms.
Worsening shortages of consumer goods and triple-digit inflation will hit private consumption, while the increasingly difficult operating environment will deepen the fall in fixed investment. After a deep recession in 2016, GDP will contract further in 2017 and will not return to growth until 2020. Our forecast for a weak recovery in 2020-21 rests on the assumption of an increase in oil prices and a new government that implements macroeconomic adjustment alongside institutional and structural reform. However, these reforms will take time to bear fruit, and our forecasts imply only a partial recovery.
At almost 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the world's largest proven oil reserves, but its oil sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The government claims that rising investment in the energy sector will lift oil production significantly in the medium term, but we foresee a continued fall in production in 2017, and only a very minor increase from 2018 as economic conditions stabilise.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is in 80th position globally in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for 2017-21, out of 82 countries covered. It is therefore one of the least attractive investment locations. This reflects state interventionism, highly heterodox macroeconomic policies, a lack of legal security and weak institutions. Regionally, Venezuela remains in last place of the 12 countries covered. However, we expect improvements after 2019.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government persists with bias against free markets and ad hoc recourse to heterodox measures. Nationalisation poses a diminished threat, given fiscal weaknesses. Property rights remain weak. Price fixing undermines profitability.
2019-21: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Access to project financing is difficult and uncertainty over contractual rights persists.
2019-21: Efforts to attract foreign investment gather pace under an opposition-led government, but actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection remains weak.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2017-18: Frequent ad hoc adjustments to the unorthodox exchange-rate policy framework add to uncertainty. The state continues to exercise tight control over access to official-rate US dollars. Private firms must use a much weaker rate.
2019-21: Efforts to remove trade and exchange controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves gradually, after a political transition takes place.
Taxes
2017-18: Risk of tax increases diminishes, given the depressed state of public consumption. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2019-21: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2017-18: Credit growth remains firm, but sectoral allocation is distorted by administrative interventions. Banks remain highly profitable, although unpredictable enforcement and a weak regulatory framework heighten instability.
2019-21: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance is in short supply.
Labour market
2017-18: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage labour costs. An ongoing freeze on redundancies, combined with a large informal sector and skill shortages, makes the labour market exceptionally rigid.
2019-21: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Access to water and electricity supplies remains precarious. Underinvestment in power transmission ensures that rationing and unpredictable blackouts remain a cause for concern.
2019-21: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued electricity rationing.
