Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed 1992 coup. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 but, after declaring in July 2012 that he had fully recovered, won a fourth presidential term in October 2012. However, his health quickly deteriorated and he died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has since plummeted.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is a federal republic, successive administrations have proven reluctant to devolve political authority, with the transfer of financial resources from federal to local level highly dependent on the central government. The legislature is unicameral, and elections for the National Assembly take place every five years. In December 2015 the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática took control of the legislature, but has since met fierce opposition from other branches of government dominated by the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela.
Policy issues: Political radicalisation has been reflected in increasingly heterodox economic policymaking, with massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, and the nationalisation of industries deemed strategically important. Distortions created by this approach have become evident, with inflation rising sharply in spite of price controls, and with capital controls spawning a rampant black market for foreign exchange. Failure to invest part of the oil windfall has led to a startling decline in physical infrastructure. Non-oil production has in effect ground to a halt, leaving the economy entirely dependent on the energy sector. With large oil shipments going to China to repay loans, and (on subsidised terms) to regional neighbours via the PetroCaribe oil-financing scheme, the country is running very short of US dollars, forcing cuts in import spending.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 60% for oil firms. Since 2011 a maximum royalty of 95% has applied to oil extraction. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Official data are unavailable, but The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus fell from US$27.2bn in 2014 to US$768m in 2015. The current-account balance is estimated to have turned negative in 2015, posting a 4.3% of GDP deficit. The deficit is estimated to have narrowed to 2% of GDP in 2016 owing to import compression.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Amid the most severe economic crisis in the country's history, Venezuela's political scene will remain dominated by opposition efforts to unseat the president, Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), before the next elections, which are due to be held in December 2018. But The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect these efforts to succeed. Despite gaining a majority in Congress in late 2015, the opposition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) has been unable to force a negotiated political transition amid tight government control of key institutions, including the judiciary, which has effectively eliminated the National Assembly's powers. In addition, an increased role for the military in economic policymaking will bolster Mr Maduro's position, even if it comes at the expense of his own influence in government. Most recently, Mr Maduro has handed substantial policymaking powers to the new vice-president, Tareck El Aissami, a PSUV hardliner who is seen as being close to the army.
The main risk to our political forecast is of an early (and chaotic) transition, which would be triggered if default occurs and/or hyperinflation takes hold, and intensifying social unrest causes military support for the PSUV government to wane. Risks to the maintenance of the Maduro regime persist, as shown by looting and protests in the wake of the government's botched attempts in December 2016 to withdraw the highest denomination currency notes and replace them with new, higher denomination notes. Even so, the Venezuelan population has demonstrated an extraordinary tolerance for economic hardship, while wealthier citizens seek to source their needs through the black market. Barring outright economic collapse-which admittedly remains a substantial risk-social unrest is unlikely to be significant enough to weaken military support for the Mr Maduro government and force it from power.
On this basis, we expect the government to muddle through until the elections, in which the opposition MUD would be the clear favourite. Although we cannot discount the possibility that the government or military will intervene and prevent the holding of a free and fair presidential election in 2018, our forecasts are currently based on the assumption that they will go ahead, and that the MUD will win, taking power in 2019. An MUD-led government will implement economic adjustments to reduce the role of the state in the economy, and unravel the many macroeconomic and monetary distortions that the PSUV has implemented since it came to power in 1999. It will also begin the difficult task of reforming deeply politicised institutions. Given the scale of the economic distortion and institutional destruction that have taken place in Venezuela, there is a risk that this process will go less smoothly than we are currently forecasting.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The electoral authorities are obligating political parties that secured less than 1% of the popular vote in at least 12 states in the December 2015 legislative election to re-register-in effect, all parties (59) aside from the ruling PSUV will have to do so. To remain in existence, opposition parties are required to secure the signatures of at least 0.5% of the electoral roll in at least 12 states, a criterion that is likely to force many small parties to fold. Some members and politicians will join other parties in the opposition MUD, which is a broad church of anti-PSUV parties. But the process will cause some tension and the MUD may well emerge as a weakened political force. After a controversial decision by the electoral authorities ruling out a recall referendum on Mr Maduro's presidency (eliminating the MUD's hopes to dislodge the incumbent from office early by constitutional means), opposition parties have been frustrated again by the postponement of regional elections, which were due to be held in December 2016. If the government does manage to serve out its term to the end of 2018, as we expect, the PSUV is unlikely to be re-elected, barring the use of non-democratic means (requiring the backing of the military) to remain in power. An MUD-led government would also retain control of the legislature, allowing it to pass its agenda, although weak institutional capacity and high political tension will persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Venezuela's relations with neighbours will remain strained while Mr Maduro is in office, and the election of Donald Trump as US president will probably result in greater tension with the US. PSUV governments have periodically stoked animosity towards the US in order to drum up nationalist support, but the Trump administration is more likely than any of its recent predecessors to react to this with economic measures such as a cut in oil imports, which would hit Venezuela very hard. Therefore, it is conceivable that Mr Maduro will tone down his anti-US rhetoric. Mr Maduro will seek closer ties with China, but further financial support is unlikely to be forthcoming in the short term. Reflecting its external financing difficulties, Venezuela will continue to scale back-and possibly end-oil shipments to beneficiaries of PetroCaribe, an agreement that provides cheap financing for oil exports to regional allies. Relations with Cuba, the closest of these allies, will become more distant as Venezuela's ability to provide economic assistance is eroded. In December 2016 Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) suspended Venezuela, which had been a member since 2012, highlighting a growing international consensus over the need to reprimand the Venezuelan government. Nevertheless, relations with Colombia have improved; Venezuela has recently permitted passage through some border crossings to allow its citizens to buy food and medicine in Colombia.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
It seems increasingly unlikely that the government will be able to manage the build-up of inflationary and currency depreciation pressures without some sort of policy adjustment between now and the next presidential election. In the absence of other alternatives, we assume that the Maduro government will be forced to weaken the currency more substantially in 2017 and 2018 than it did last year. However, other much-needed reforms are unlikely to be addressed by a government that has proved unwilling or unable to adjust policy sufficiently to move Venezuela's economy away from the brink of collapse. Fiscal and monetary policy will remain expansionary, and ad hoc policy interventionism and heavy state control of the economy will persist. Slightly higher oil prices will bring some relief, but import compression will remain necessary, as other sources of foreign exchange will be hard to find. At US$10.7bn in early March, international reserves remain far below historical levels, and are only about two-thirds of their end-2015 total. Even after a 2016 restructuring of debt owed by PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, substantial external debt payments are falling due in 2017. We currently expect Venezuela to meet its 2017 obligations, which are mostly owed by PDVSA. However, given the extremely thin reserves cushion, the risk of default remains high, and would have dramatic economic and political consequences in the form of a sharp decrease in oil production, reduced import capacity, hyperinflation and probable political turmoil.
We expect the opposition to take power in 2019, ushering in much-needed market-driven adjustments designed to correct currency distortions, alleviate shortages of basic goods, tighten expansionary fiscal policy and rebuild institutional capacity after years of deterioration under PSUV rule. It is probable, given the scale of the challenge, that the new government will seek a financing agreement with the IMF to support the adjustment process. Efforts to secure increased inflows of foreign direct investment would also be likely under a new government, and would help to improve the balance-of-payments dynamics, although we expect direct investors to remain cautious for some time with regards to Venezuela, with the possible exception of the oil sector.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The authorities' failure to publish data on the non-financial public sector since 2012 demonstrates the opacity of the public finances and complicates accurate forecasting of the size of the deficit. After ballooning to an estimated 24.3% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to stand at a still-large 19.6% of GDP in 2017 and remain in double digits in 2018. The election of a new government should help to ease the deficit to 5.9% of GDP by 2021. The large deficits at present are mostly being financed by printing money; the money supply, as measured by M2, rose by 159% year on year in December, the highest rate on record. Meanwhile, high inflation and an overvalued currency erode the relative value of domestic and external debt, making debt/GDP ratios unreliable indicators of fiscal stability.
There is considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing, mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA. As these items are excluded from the public debt statistics, the true size of total public liabilities is understated. In October 2016 the government undertook a bond swap that will see around US$2.8bn of PDVSA debt due in 2017 (of US$10bn in PDVSA and sovereign debt in total) pushed out to 2020. This will alleviate some pressure next year, but does not resolve the country's external financing difficulties; we continue to see an extremely high risk of default. Despite this, the government has emphasised its commitment to pay, and we expect the next administration to follow through with its debt-servicing and repayment obligations.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Monetary policy under the Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank) will continue to be driven by the government's desire to keep real interest rates negative and to print money to finance large fiscal deficits. Amid extremely high inflation, we expect real rates to remain deeply negative in 2017-18. From 2019 our forecast of substantial currency and fiscal adjustment under a new government also implies a substantial tightening of monetary policy. We expect interest rates to rise sharply that year, declining only moderately thereafter.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Ongoing disruption to Venezuela's productive base and a collapse in consumer spending mean that, after a massive contraction in GDP in 2016 (estimated at 14%), we project a further contraction, of 5.5%, in 2017. We do not expect the PSUV to make the necessary adjustments to bring about a proper economic recovery and we thus forecast that recession will persist into 2019. Even after this, recovery will be relatively weak, given the depth and length of the downturn. Our forecast for a recovery in 2020-21 rests on our assumption of a rise in oil prices, alongside a political transition that produces a combination of macro-economic adjustment, and institutional and structural reform. However, reform will take time to bear fruit given the scale of the recession, and our forecasts therefore imply only a partial rebound; overall we expect real GDP to have declined by nearly 30% in 2014-19.
After dropping by an estimated 20.2% in 2016, private consumption will contract further in 2017-18, reflecting the impact of soaring inflation on real wages and disposable incomes, as well as government compression of imports. Imports account for a large share of consumer goods, owing to Venezuela's weak manufacturing base, which has been further eroded by currency distortions. Fixed investment will continue to contract sharply, reflecting the difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange, and remitting profits. Our forecast for a recovery in investment in 2019-21 is based on expectations of a political transition, progress on long­delayed joint projects with Chinese firms in the energy sector and-towards the end of the forecast period-a pick-up in public-sector investment. Exports will continue to shrink in 2017-18 as oil production falls further, but will pick up in 2019-21, reflecting increased investment under a new government, and a removal of constraints to domestic production. Import demand will rise faster than exports, in line with an alleviation of basic goods shortages and the release of pent-up demand from the recession years. Even after the change in government, however, dependence on oil will persist, and the next government will have to begin a process of economic diversification to produce a more robust domestic economy and promote non-oil exports.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
A decimation of domestic supply and severe shortages of foreign-exchange reserves have caused inflation to soar for much of the past two years. It will remain very high in the medium term but we expect a disinflation process later in the forecast period, assuming a change of government. No new official inflation data have been released since end-2015. However, according to unofficial data from Cenda, a local think-tank, the price of a basic basket of goods increased by 13.9% month on month in December, bringing 12-month inflation to an estimated 522%. Money supply (M2) growth accelerated to 174% in early February, up from 159% in December. Assuming that price pressures remain high in the first half of 2017 at least, we expect average inflation to be higher this year, at 562%, than in 2016. However, we continue to forecast a decline in inflation over time, reflecting moderately higher oil prices, which will bring in the necessary foreign exchange to help to alleviate scarcity of goods and the impact of persistent recession on demand. From 2019 fiscal and monetary policy adjustment will also be supportive of a gradual reduction in inflation towards double-digit levels (in year-on-year terms). However, before this happens, the lack of funds available for importing basic goods suggests that shortages will be rife, and the risk of hyperinflation (which we define as monthly inflation of more than 50%) will remain substantial.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The authorities manage a dual exchange-rate system composed of an official peg, known as the Dipro, which is limited to priority public-sector imports and set at BsF10:US$1, and a heavily managed rate known as the Dicom. The Dicom rate weakened by 70% in nominal terms in 2016, but it accounts for less than 10% of all official transactions. In real terms, the average exchange rate (weighted by volume of transactions) continued to appreciate substantially in 2016, creating ever greater pressure for currency adjustment, the need for which is evident in the black-market rate, which was just over BsF4,000:US$1 in early March.
The pegged Dipro rate appears increasingly unsustainable-we assume that the government will devalue this rate shortly (to BsF25:US$1) and again in 2018 (to BsF500:US$1), as well as gradually increasing the share of Dicom in foreign-currency transactions, to 50% by 2018, up from a current level of about 8%. This effectively constitutes a maxi-devaluation, as distortions to the exchange rate would otherwise become unsustainable. Further major currency adjustment under a new government in 2019 will involve immediate exchange-rate unification. In the meantime, given existing distortions in the foreign-exchange market, there is an extremely high risk of a debilitating currency crisis in the short term. If confidence in the bolívar collapses amid hyperinflation, there is a possibility that dollarisation-or the launch of a new domestic currency-could occur.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
The current-account deficit will narrow further in 2017-18, reflecting severe import compression and a moderate recovery in oil prices, which will outweigh a continued gradual decline in oil output. The deficit will widen thereafter on the assumption that economic recovery draws in imports on a large scale after years of pent-up demand and in line with an easing of external financing constraints. Nevertheless, risks to the balance of payments will persist, although our assumption of economic adjustment in the medium term suggests some recovery in capital inflows, particularly into the oil sector. This should help to rebuild reserves coverage, although our forecasts assume that even by the end of the forecast period in 2021, reserves will cover only slightly more than three months of goods and services imports.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
Domestic data
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsF:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the Central Bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The new US administration led by Donald Trump has the potential to significantly shift Russia-US relations. However, any attempt to step back from US engagement with NATO will be strongly resisted by the US security establishment. Russian official and public discourse will remain anti-Western.
The likelihood that the US will ease sanctions on Russia has risen significantly since Mr Trump came to office; however, a great deal of uncertainty regarding the sanctions outlook remains.
Despite a reduction in fighting in Ukraine, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect the Minsk II deal to lead to a comprehensive political settlement. Ukraine will not regain full control of its border with Russia.
Russia will remain a mobilisation economy, characterised by high spending on the defence sector, a cautious approach to foreign investment in many sectors, protectionism and a large role for the state in the economy.
Formal political opposition to the regime will remain marginal. Vladimir Putin, the president, is likely to run again for president in March 2018 and win with a large majority in the first round. The principal concern for the authorities will be to maintain a high turnout in the absence of a meaningful contest.
The government is unlikely to implement disruptive market reforms. Minority stakes in some major state enterprises will be sold off. Chinese companies are likely to take a bigger role in the economy, including in the extractive sector.
Despite pressure to maintain defence and welfare spending, the government will cut public expenditure in 2017-19 to keep the budget deficit under control. The budget deficit will narrow to around 2% of GDP by 2019, from 3.5% of GDP in 2016.
The economy contracted by 0.2% in 2016. It will return to growth in 2017, but household demand will remain weak. International sanctions will weigh on investment and public spending will be tightened further.
The medium-term growth outlook will be constrained by structural weak-nesses, including a lack of competition, high state involvement in the economy, an ageing and declining workforce, and weak rule of law. We forecast average annual GDP growth of 1.4% per year in 2017-21.

Russia falls two places in our regional ranking in the forecast period (2017-21), to 15th of 16 countries. This reflects manifold institutional weaknesses, poor rule of law, high levels of corruption and extensive state involvement in the economy. It falls to 70th out of 82 countries in our global ranking.
Country forecast overview: Russia's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Privatisation plans will proceed slowly, despite the announcement in 2016 of a new privatisation drive.
2019-21: Overall state involvement in the economy remains high. Government interference in private companies remains arbitrary. Rent-seeking officials remain a burden on business. Protection of intellectual property rights may weaken.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: International sanctions and low energy prices discourage major new investment in the oil and gas sectors.
2019-21: The "pivot to the east" will lead to further moderate growth in investment from Asia.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Some US sanctions may be relaxed. Membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) is effectively suspended. The Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) internal market is undermined by exemptions and weak enforcement.
2019-21: The difficulty of trading across borders continues to be a weakness. The Russian ban on Western agricultural imports is likely to remain in force.
Taxes
2017-18: The resources tax on gas and the tax on tobacco rise. The freeze on the tax on vodka is extended. Direct taxes on in-dividuals and value-added tax (VAT) will not be raised, and the government may issue VAT concessions to selected sectors.
2019-21: A progressive consumption tax may be introduced. Tax inspections remain a burden on business. The time it takes to pay taxes approximates to international norms. There are some specific improvements in the corporate tax regime.
Financing
2017-18: International sanctions limit access to external capital markets, significantly raising the cost of financing.
2019-21: International financial integration proceeds slowly. The banking system remains weak and state-dominated. The government maintains its commitment to bail out systemically important institutions.
The labour market
2017-18: Spending on education is cut further. The incidence of strikes increases slightly, although the labour movement remains weak.
2019-21: Excepting skilled migration from Central Asia, labour mobility remains low. Highly skilled Russian managers command internationally competitive remuneration.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Budget constraints curb investment in infrastructure. Politically important projects are prioritised, but even here cuts are made. Russia struggles to obtain international funding for its infrastructure projects. Roads are starved of funding.
2019-21: It remains difficult to secure foreign finance. China provides only a limited alternative to Western funding.

Background: The transition to a market economy in the early 1990s was accompanied by a collapse in industrial production and a sharp drop in living standards. A contested privatisation process led to a highly concentrated ownership structure. Executive weakness and bureaucratic dysfunction contributed to a sharp decentralisation of power. After becoming president in 2000, Vladimir Putin sought to restore central control over the regions and tame independent corporate interests. Mr Putin presided over a period of strong economic growth in his first two terms. His re-election as president in 2012 has heralded the development of a more authoritarian domestic environment.
Political structure: Boris Yeltsin won the first democratic presidential election in June 1991 and was re-elected in July 1996. Repeated confrontations with the legislature culminated in the dissolution of parliament in September 1993 and a violent showdown the following month. The powers of the executive were greatly increased by a new constitution, adopted in 1993. Mr Putin was elected in March 2000 and re-elected for a second term in March 2004. Mr Putin's second term in office was characterised by increasing centralisation of the state. A loyal ally, Dmitry Medvedev, won the presidential election in March 2008 and took over in May of that year. Mr Putin returned to the presidency for a third term in May 2012. Following a constitutional change, his term will last six years, to 2018.
Policy issues: Mr Putin's third term as president has seen a greater emphasis on "conservative cultural values", anti-Westernism and great-power nationalism. The stand-off with the West is leading to a rollback of Russia's integration into the world economy. This is likely to strengthen further the state's role in the economy. Tit-for-tat sanctions have encouraged the government to focus on import substitution. The focus on curbing "foreign influence" on domestic politics is likely to endure, along with close controls on civil society, the internet and media.
Taxation: Reforms since 2000 have aimed to rationalise the tax system and cut the number of taxes and the corporate tax burden. Changes to the tax regime in January 2001 included the introduction of a flat rate of personal income tax of 13% and a simplification of the administration of social security contributions. In 2004 the basic rate of value-added tax (VAT) was reduced from 20% to 18% and a regional 5% sales tax was abolished. The corporate tax rate was cut from 24% to 20% at the beginning of 2009. The government has pledged not to raise personal or consumption taxes before 2018.
Foreign trade: Mainly because of high international oil prices, export revenue has soared since 2000. Import growth picked up over the same period as a result of rising real incomes and real rouble appreciation. Merchandise exports totalled just over US$340bn in 2015 and imports were just over US$190bn. Oil and gas account for about 70% of Russia's exports, with metals contributing a further 11%.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
Vladimir Putin's third presidential term, which began in 2012, has seen a shift towards "conservative cultural values", a more authoritarian political culture and more overt anti­Westernism. This has been further consolidated by Russia's confrontation with the West over Ukraine. Hardline figures, many with backgrounds in the security services, have increased their influence over policy areas outside the traditional security domain. Despite some pro-market rhetoric, economic policy has grown more statist and protectionist. The leadership will remain preoccupied by the need to insulate the economy and society from foreign, and in particular Western, influences and the perceived threat of externally sponsored regime change. These policy trends are likely to endure even with Donald Trump, the new US president, having stated his desire to improve relations with Russia.
The forecast period (2017-21) is likely to be characterised by slow growth in living standards, following a major decline in 2015-16, and further cuts in public expenditure in many areas. This contrasts sharply with the rapid growth achieved in Mr Putin's first decade in power and could have unpredictable effects on stability in the medium term. However, there currently seems to be little desire for disruptive reform among the broader population, and the potential for mass protest or major political change from below appears to be low. Social controls have been tightened since 2012, and the opposition has been marginalised and demoralised. Political engagement for much of the population appears to be limited to single-issue campaigns, and the cost of collective action remains high. The government tends to respond constructively when confronted with specific economic grievances. A mixture of state support and administrative pressure will keep major enterprises operating in provincial industrial towns. Concern over political stability is likely to hold the government back from pursuing radical reform.
The weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the person-alised, opaque governance system around Mr Putin, could present difficulties in managing an eventual presidential transition. Any successor is likely to come from the team around Mr Putin and will not herald a sharp change in the policy agenda. However, it may be difficult for any successor to build popular legitimacy, given the weak economic outlook. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a political transition in the forecast period. Speculation about an eventual succession strategy is likely to intensify soon after the 2018 presidential election, however, and this will further depress business confidence and raise political uncertainty.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
The next presidential election will take place in March 2018. We expect Mr Putin to contest the election and win by a wide margin in the first round. Aleksei Navalny, an anti-corruption blogger and nationalist opposition politician, will be barred from participating in the presidential election, following a second conviction for defrauding Kirovles, a timber company. This suggests that the authorities intend to run a tightly controlled contest, offering voters no meaningful alternatives to Mr Putin. The main challenge for the authorities will be to prevent a sharp fall in turnout, which would throw doubt on the legitimacy of Mr Putin's popular mandate. This is one of the reasons behind the efforts to revitalise the regional leadership with the replacement of poorly performing governors.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
The Ukraine conflict has led to a sharp deterioration in Russia's relations with the West since 2014. In response to the conflict in Ukraine, the US and the EU have imposed sanctions on senior Russian officials and the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors. Russia has responded with a ban on almost all Western food imports.
The Minsk II ceasefire agreement, signed in February 2015, is highly unlikely to lead to a comprehensive political resolution of the conflict in Ukraine. The constitutional reform mandated by the agreement, which could formally embed Russia's proxies within Ukraine's political system, is politically toxic in Ukraine. In the highly unlikely event that it is passed, there is little chance that Russia will allow Ukraine to re-establish control of its side of the international border. Russia sees Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO as a direct threat to its national interests, even though the second of these remains unlikely. Russia will not step back from its long-term objective of preventing a pro-Western government from consolidating in Ukraine. The current status quo, of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting, appears likely to endure for several years.
Mr Trump's presidency could have profound implications for bilateral relations and European security. Mr Trump has voiced scepticism about US alliances in Europe, expressed his admiration for Mr Putin and appears more amenable to forming an anti-terrorist coalition with Russia. However, it remains unclear to what extent Mr Trump's plans to reconfigure relations with Russia will be realised. As anticipated, Mr Trump's stated desire for rapprochement with Russia appears to be encountering strong resistance from the US security establishment. The links between senior figures close to Mr Trump and Russian officials have been the subject of intense media scrutiny, making it difficult for the administration to take measures perceived as offering concessions to Russia. In mid-February the leak of conversations between Michael Flynn, who had been appointed as national security adviser, and the Russian ambassador to the US led to Mr Flynn's resignation.
Regardless of Mr Trump's stance, Russia's broader foreign policy will remain nationalistic and anti-Western throughout the forecast period. Russia's policy towards its neighbours, and towards Ukraine in particular, will be an enduring source of tension with the West. Regime change in any country in Russia's immediate neighbourhood, particularly via popular uprising, would be likely to trigger a crisis in relations between Russia and the West. Without an institutional or strategic basis to Russian-US co-operation, the two presidents could quickly come into conflict when the next international crisis emerges.
The likelihood of a relaxation of US sectoral sanctions on Russia has risen since Mr Trump's election. The outlook is now finely balanced and complicated by the contradictory policy views held by various members of his team. However, given the high level of uncertainty, at this stage we do not assume a relaxation of sectoral sanctions in our macroeconomic forecast for Russia.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
With the economy set to return to growth in 2017, the constraints on macro-economic policy will ease somewhat. However, the fiscal position remains precarious. We expect the government to remain committed to a relatively tight fiscal and monetary policy to keep borrowing and inflation in check.
Economic reform will be subordinated to the imperatives of political stability and regime survival. We do not expect the government to move substantively towards liberalisation of the economy, and certainly not before the presidential election in March 2018.
A more likely scenario is that the government will seek incrementally to improve the efficiency of the system by replacing failing officials and bureau-crats, and cracking down selectively on corruption. Following the presidential election, the government is likely to extend the pension age and conduct a limited tax reform. Progress in strengthening the rule of law and protecting property rights is likely to be limited. The government will continue to sell minority stakes in some major state-controlled assets. However, as with the sale in December 2016 of a 19.5% stake in Rosneft, a Russian oil giant, the govern-ment's focus is on raising short-term budget revenue rather than increasing the level of competition in the economy or reducing state influence over it.
Russia's stand-off with the West has strengthened statist and protectionist trends within the government. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a strategic priority. The main elements of this strategy include a large positive sovereign external asset position (low public debt combined with substantial foreign-exchange reserves); protectionist measures to encourage import substitution and support domestic manufacturing; and a cautious approach to globalisation and foreign investment (which in "strategic sectors", such as the extractive sector, is likely to be permitted only in partnership with state-controlled companies).
Some policymakers have urged a further increase in state intervention in the economy, along with capital controls, expansionist monetary policy and a return to a fixed exchange rate. We believe that the government will continue to pursue a mixed approach, observing the broad tenets of a market economy, avoiding disruptive reforms and excessive market-distorting behaviour (such as capital controls), while maintaining a large state role in the economy.
We expect the government to remain committed to its import substitution policy, and formal and informal barriers to external trade will continue to be significant in some sectors.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
The government faces tight budget constraints as a result of international sanctions, low commodity prices and the reluctance of Western banks to handle international bond issuances (although Russia succeeded in placing two Eurobonds in 2016). The deficit in 2016 was the equivalent of 3.5% of GDP; however, this included extraordinary income from the sale of a stake in Rosneft in December last year. Without this, the deficit would have been 4.4% of GDP.
Under the government's budget for 2017, spending will fall from Rb16.4trn (US$276bn) in 2016 to Rb16.2trn. This is broadly in line with the Ministry of Finance's proposal in July that spending should be frozen for the next three years in nominal terms (which was based on the original expenditure target for 2016 of Rb16.1trn). Based on an average oil price of US$40/barrel in 2017, the government expects revenue to rise by 1.8%.
We forecast a higher oil price than set out in the budget, of US$56/b. This should boost revenue from the hydrocarbon sector. However, the finance ministry announced in early February that it intended to accumulate the extra tax revenue as foreign-exchange reserves, rather than transferring it directly to the budget. Overall, we forecast a deficit of around 3% of GDP. We expect the finance ministry to continue to trim the deficit in 2018-19, but the fiscal adjustment is likely to be less radical than planned, particularly given the forthcoming presidential election. We believe that the government is unlikely to hold expenditure fixed in nominal terms, as planned, in 2018-19. We forecast that the deficit will narrow to 1.2% of GDP by 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
The Central Bank of Russia (CBR) cut its policy rate by 50 basis points, to 10%, at its meeting in mid-September 2016. It kept the rate unchanged at its meetings in October and December 2016, and in February 2017. The most recent guidance from the CBR stated that the potential remains for a loosening of monetary policy in the second quarter, as disinflation has moved ahead of the bank's expectations. However, the CBR also noted that some of the factors holding down inflation may have a temporary character. It is now possible that the CBR will cut its policy rate by 50 basis points at its meeting on June 16th. We expect the policy rate to be cut by 1-1.5 percentage points this year (either two or three cuts of 50 basis points), to 8-8.5% by the end of 2017. The bias is now towards a faster rate of easing.
Real interest rates are likely to remain positive throughout the forecast period. The CBR governor, Elvira Nabiullina, has suggested that an appropriate level for the real interest rate would be about 2.5-3% when inflation moves close to the CBR's 4% target.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Russia's economic growth was decelerating even before 2014, as it ran into structural constraints, but the short-term growth outlook has been impaired significantly by weak oil prices and the fall in the rouble. The Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat) now estimates that the economy contracted by 2.8% in 2015, and by 0.2% in 2016. Rosstat has not yet updated the quarterly GDP data for 2015-16 in line with its latest annual revisions. We have therefore suppressed all quarterly national accounts data and will reinstate these when Rosstat completes its revisions to the quarterly national accounts data.
Leading indicators point to growth in manufacturing and services output in the first quarter of 2017. We expect a modest rebound this year, led by a recovery in commodity prices and lower inflation, which should assist the gradual recovery in household consumption after two years of contraction. We expect a weak recovery in investment, after three years of contraction. Corporate deleveraging will slow and external financing conditions are likely to improve marginally. A relaxation of Western sanctions-not currently our core forecast-would provide a modest boost to investment. However, perceptions of political risk would remain high, limiting foreign direct investment (FDI) outside the commodities sector. Fiscal consolidation will continue to drag on public consumption and infrastructure spending. We expect only a modest pick-up in growth in 2018, as we forecast a significant slowdown in the Chinese economy in that year, which will weigh on some commodity prices.
In the medium term, outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low investment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth. We forecast that growth will average around 1.5% per year in 2018-21, in line with CBR estimates of Russia's trend growth under the current institutional and macroeconomic framework. There currently seems to be little prospect of domestic institutional reform. High political risk and the poor business environment will continue to depress investment below the level needed to develop a higher trend growth rate, and the poor demographic outlook will remain a significant constraint.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
The CBR is aiming to reach its inflation target of 4% by the end of the year. It has a firm commitment to a relatively tight monetary policy as it aims to reach this inflation target. Inflation stood at 5.4% year on year in December 2016, but fell to 5% in January and to 4.6% in February. Disinflation has been assisted by a strong harvest last year and by the appreciation of the rouble. However, both factors could prove to be temporary and inflation expectations remain elevated. We forecast that consumer price inflation will average 4.4% in 2017, and that the CBR will miss its year-end target. The slowdown in China will lead to a depreciation of the rouble in 2018, but external inflationary pressures are likely to be low. We expect inflation to remain close to, but slightly above, target in the medium term, given low competition and trade barriers.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Public confidence in the rouble has strengthened, but further falls in commodity prices could lead to renewed volatility. The rouble appreciated in January-February 2017 against the US dollar owing to higher average oil prices, and seasonal factors linked to the sale of foreign currency by commodity exporters. We expect the rouble to depreciate modestly from its current level over the course of 2017, leading to an average full-year rate of Rb60.5:US$1, against Rb67.1:US$1 in 2016. The slowdown in China in 2018 will hit Russia's terms of trade and we expect the rouble to depreciate by around 8-9% against the dollar on average in that year. The continuing underperformance and low productivity of the Russian economy will lead to further mild depreciation against the dollar on average in 2019-20.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
We have updated our external debt figures to incorporate new World Bank data for 2012-15. The World Bank debt figures are about 10% lower than local-source data, but show the same trend. We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout 2017-21. The rise in oil prices forecast from 2017 will be partly offset by a recovery in imports as investment and household consumption pick up. International sanctions and political uncertainty will de-press FDI and portfolio inflows, although we expect these to recover in 2018-21.

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The president, Mauricio Macri of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro), is pressing ahead with a programme of economic policy adjustment in an effort to eliminate distortions and return the economy to sustainable growth. The adjustment process is proving difficult, involving politically unpopular austerity measures, and the risk of social unrest will therefore remain significant for much of the forecast period.
Given the president's minority position in Congress, and the priority given to urgent macroeconomic reforms, there is likely to be limited progress on the pursuit of legislation that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Comprehensive reforms to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. Furthermore, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect meaningful advances-at least in the short term-on a structural reform agenda (incorporating tax and labour market reform) that could improve long-term potential growth rates.
After a contraction in real GDP in 2016, reflecting macroeconomic policy tightening and currency depreciation, we are forecasting a pick-up in exports, investment and private consumption in the medium term. There will be a boost in business confidence from policy tightening. Combined with macroeconomic adjustment, and a gradual removal of foreign-exchange and import controls, these policies should set the economy on a more solid long-term footing. However, some aspects of the policymaking environment will remain suboptimal, with labour-market reform and a comprehensive fiscal reform remaining low on the agenda.
Currency adjustment should gradually bolster the current account as a weaker peso starts to boost goods and services exports and rein in imports. On this basis, we expect the current-account deficit to narrow in 2017-21 from the 2016 peak. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve over the forecast period, assuming that capital inflows pick up as investor confidence in the Macri administration grows.
Argentina's GDP per head is still among the highest in the region and, combined with improved access to credit, moderate rates of economic growth in the medium term will boost purchasing power and create market opportunities. Still-high poverty rates and income inequality will restrict the pool of consumers, but to a lesser extent than in many other countries in the region.

Argentina's global business environment score improves substantially in 2017-21, and the country jumps 20 places in our global ranking. A period of economic policy adjustment is under way as the centre-right government works to tighten macroeconomic policy, reduce state intervention in the private sector and encourage private investment. However, in many areas improve-ments will take time to materialise.
Country forecast overview: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2019-21: Continued work to build confidence in legal and regulatory framework. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy toward foreign investment
2017-18: Efforts to resolve any remaining disputes with international creditors and investors as the government seeks fresh sources of US dollar inflows.
2019-21: Foreign direct investment is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: Any remaining foreign-exchange controls likely to be removed. Continued efforts to improve the workings of the Mercado Común del Sur (Mercosur) and develop closer relations with the Alianza del Pacifico (the Pacific Alliance).
2019-21: Possibility that free-trade agreements make better progress.
Taxes
2017-18: Further gradual reductions of export taxes to encourage domestic supply. Tax system remains complex and burdensome.
2019-21: Comprehensive tax reform to improve federal-provincial revenue a possibility, but obstacles to reform persist.
Financing
2017-18: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2019-21: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by a relatively small pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2017-18: Tension with unions, owing to inflation. Political and bargaining power of the unions will remain strong.
2019-21: Progress on labour reform unlikely. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Some skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2017-18: The Macri administration works to address weak contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes, which keep private investment below potential. Financing constraints hamper public investment in the short term.
2019-21: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.

Background: Economic liberalisation in the 1990s resulted in firm growth, but an inflexible exchange-rate mechanism and failure to deepen structural reform left the economy vulnerable to shocks, contributing to the collapse in 2001 of Fernando de la Rúa's centre-left government. An interim government took power until Néstor Kirchner of the Peronist party began a term in 2003. He presided over an economic rebound, which enabled his wife, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, to win the presidency in 2007 and secure re-election in 2011. Economic policy mismanagement drove a change of government in 2015, with a centre-right candidate, Mauricio Macri, taking office in December 2015.
Political structure: Democracy was restored to Argentina in 1983 after 50 years of instability and military regimes. A strong presidential system is in theory checked by a bicameral Congress, comprising a 257-member Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and a 72-member Senate (the upper house); in practice, however, the presidency dominates. The presidential term is four years. There are 23 provinces and the Buenos Aires federal district, each with its own government.
Policy issues: Pro-cyclical expansionary policies contributed to GDP growth of an annual average 6.6% in 2005-11. But expansionary policy also produced significant imbalances in the economy in the form of double-digit inflation, real peso appreciation and a deterioration of the balance of payments. Amid currency pressures, the Fernández government resorted to foreign-exchange, import and capital controls, as well as ad hoc interventionism, to the detriment of the business environment. These policies did not reduce devaluation speculation, and left the economy extremely vulnerable to currency crisis. Macroeconomic adjustments to reduce economic distortions and set the economy on a more solid long-term footing are taking place under Mr Macri; these include peso devaluation, and fiscal and monetary tightening. Microeconomic reforms to boost domestic supply are also getting under way.
Taxation: The value-added tax (VAT) rate is 21%, although VAT on some goods and services is charged at a lower rate of 10.5%, and some services are taxed at a higher rate of 27%. Corporate income tax is levied at 35%, and personal income tax at progressive rates between 9% and 35%. There is a 0.6% tax on financial transactions (deposits and withdrawals). Taxes on exports were reintroduced in 2002, and have since been expanded to account for around 20% of total revenue.
Foreign trade: The current account shifted from surplus to deficit in 2010. Despite comprehensive controls, there was a current-account deficit of 2.7% of GDP in 2015.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The president, Mauricio Macri, of the centre-right Propuesta Republicana (Pro) party, recently began the second year of his four-year term (ending in 2019) and is pressing on with a programme of economic policy adjustments to reduce economic distortions and return the economy to sustainable growth. Reflecting the scale of economic mismanagement under the previous government, the adjustment process has required politically unpopular austerity measures. These measures are taking a toll on Mr Macri's popularity, whose opinion poll ratings have fallen below 50%. The combined effect of a post-devaluation inflationary spike and cuts in energy and transport subsidies is hitting consumers hard, and patience with adjustment is wearing thin.
Voter weariness with austerity, combined with the approach of mid-term legislative elections in October, will complicate relations with Congress, where the president lacks a majority. The ruling Cambiemos alliance, which includes the Pro as well as the centre-left Unión Cívica Radical, has to negotiate support for its legislative agenda in both houses of Congress on an ad hoc basis with the various factions of the large Partido Justicialista (the Peronist party). So far this support has mainly been forthcoming, not least because the largest opposition force, the leftist-populist faction of the Peronist party, known as the Frente para la Victoria (FV), has been weakened by a series of damaging corruption scandals.
Going forwards, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects obstructionism to increase amid election-related politicking surrounding the October 2017 mid-term election, and as the October 2019 presidential election approaches. But mutual interest will ensure some continuing co-operation between Cambiemos and moderate Peronists. On top of this, a strong executive branch (the president has substantial powers to rule by decree) should provide Mr Macri with room for manoeuvre, even assuming that Congress becomes less co-operative. The president will also retain influence with powerful provincial governors, who largely control the Senate agenda but who are in turn deeply reliant on central government transfers, some of which are discretionary. As a result, we expect some continued progress on the govern-ment agenda.
However, we assume that with electoral considerations coming into play, there will be limited progress on legislation that would successfully address long-standing institutional weaknesses and structural constraints to growth. Compre-hensive efforts to strengthen bureaucracy, reduce corruption, or enhance the effectiveness and independence of the judiciary will be slow. We do not expect meaningful advances on a structural reform agenda.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
Mr Macri's Pro party is small but increasingly influential. Apart from the presidency, it now controls the governments of Buenos Aires city and province, which together account for almost half of the population. However, the Pro is in a minority position in both houses of Congress, and although it may make some gains in mid-term legislative elections in October 2017, it is likely to remain in a minority position throughout the forecast period, given the dominance of the Peronist party in national politics and its strong grassroots presence. The Peronist party is, however, split into various competing factions. As it loses the powers of patronage bestowed on it by the presidency and struggles with corruption allegations, the leftist-populist FV wing of the party will lose influence and the position of the traditional Peronist wing will improve, leaving it well placed to make gains at the expense of the FV in the 2017 mid-term elections.
The next presidential election is due in October 2019. Based on our assumption of moderate GDP growth and a return to single-digit inflation by then, we currently expect Mr Macri to win a second four-year term. There are substantial risks to this forecast, given the challenging external environment and the government's minority position in Congress. Reflecting the difficulties faced by minority governments in Argentina, no non-Peronist government has ever won a second consecutive term since the end of the military dictatorship in the 1980s. In this context, the emergence of a strong challenger from the moderate wing of the Peronist party is a strong possibility and the election will be closely fought.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Efforts by the Macri administration to repair relations with trade and investment partners have achieved rapid results, and we expect relations with key trade partners in the region and elsewhere to remain strong, with the possible exception of the US. Like most other governments in Latin America, the Macri administration was wrong-footed by the victory of Donald Trump in the US presidential election in November 2016. After cultivating increasingly strong ties with the previous US administration, led by Barack Obama, Mr Macri is likely to abandon recent efforts to secure preferential trade ties with the US with a view to an eventual free-trade agreement. The Argentinian government will remain keen to seek trade deals under the auspices of the Mercado Común del Sur (Mercosur, the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay; Venezuela was suspended from the group in 2016). The problem for Argentina and its Mercosur partners is that, just as the grouping has started to reverse its own protectionist tendencies, free trade has shifted off the political agenda not only in the US but also in Europe. Mr Macri recently visited Spain in an effort to drum up support for the deal, and negotiations are set to resume in March. But our forecasts do not currently assume a successful conclusion of free-trade talks with the EU, but the workings of intra-Mercosur trade are, at least, likely to improve in the forecast period. Efforts at joining the Alianza del Pacífico (Pacific Alliance, a regional trading bloc that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico) may also make progress, although this is not currently reflected in our five-year economic forecasts.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
A reshuffle of the economic cabinet at the end of 2016 was more a matter of management style than of substance, and we do not expect any dramatic shift in the economic policy agenda under the new Treasury minister, Nicolás Dujovne. That said, Mr Dujovne is widely considered a fiscal hawk, and his appointment provides markets with a signal of Mr Macri's determination to tackle one of the government's next big policy challenges: the reduction of the fiscal deficit. The Macri administration has already made good initial progress on a programme of adjustment intended to put the economy on a sounder footing, having devalued the peso, reduced agricultural export duties and energy subsidies, and secured a deal with holdout creditors (allowing Argentina to exit default). Attention will now turn to the reduction of inflation, another key condition for a recovery in private consump-tion and investment. Combined with still-tight monetary policy, reduction of the fiscal deficit and nominal wage growth will also be required to reduce inflation, and achieving both will be politically difficult. Our baseline forecast assumes that there will be some progress in both areas, which should slow inflation and ultimately boost investor confidence. However, there are substantial risks to this assumption, as adjust-ment is taking place ahead of mid-term elections in 2017. Even under our baseline forecast, we do not expect inflation to fall to single-digit levels until 2019.
Moreover, under any scenario, certain aspects of the policymaking environment will remain suboptimal, with progress on labour market reform (to improve flexibility) or comprehensive fiscal and tax reform (to reduce costs and complexity) unlikely in the medium term. Other reforms to improve the business environment will be more successful. The government has already passed new public-private partnership framework legislation that should facilitate an increase in infrastructure investment; efforts to reduce red tape and support the development of small and medium-sized enterprises should also prosper, as will reforms to support the development of longer-term finance and the deepening of Argentina's currently shallow capital markets.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
Higher-than-expected revenue from a tax amnesty on undeclared foreign assets will bolster the fiscal accounts and bring the government closer to meeting its fiscal targets for both 2016 and 2017. We expect the fiscal deficit to come in at 4.5% of GDP in 2017, only slightly above the 4.2% of GDP target. We expect the government's gradualist approach to fiscal tightening to continue in subsequent years, bringing the fiscal deficit down to a more manageable level of under 3% of GDP by the end of the forecast period, and eliminating the primary deficit by 2021. To date, the govern-ment has taken some important steps to try to narrow the deficit, particularly by reducing costly subsidies and the public-sector payroll. Even so, in the light of recently announced income-tax breaks and increased transfers (to expand the social safety net), deficit reduction will be slow. There are also downside risks to our forecasts, which rest on two key assumptions: that expenditure as a share of GDP will fall by slightly over 1 percentage point (reflecting a smaller public-sector workforce, a further drop in subsidies and a reduction in the deficits of state companies); and that revenue will increase by around 1 percentage point in the same period (assuming that recent tax cuts are more than offset by a pick-up in revenue from trade and increased economic activity).
In the aftermath of the holdout deal, and assuming that there is progress on deficit reduction, the government's ability to finance moderate deficits without resorting to inflationary money printing will be much improved. A moderate public debt/GDP ratio (and low levels of external indebtedness), combined with the attractiveness of Argentina's still-high yields, should facilitate international bond issuance in 2017-21, following Argentina's exit from default earlier this year. In January the sovereign issued US$7bn in five- and ten-year global bonds. As a percentage of GDP, the public debt will stabilise at slightly over 50% in 2017-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Notwithstanding a pause in the easing cycle in recent months, we continue to expect substantial rate cuts in 2017 and beyond. Between April and November 2016 the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the Central Bank) lowered the monetary policy rate steadily, from 38% to 24.75%, where the policy rate stood in early March. We expect further, albeit smaller, rate cuts over the course of 2017, to slightly below 20% by year-end. The BCRA has made clear that it will prioritise monetary policy that is consistent with a reduction of inflation over the medium term, and our forecasts assume moderately positive real interest rates, consistent with a deepening of credit and the development of long-term lending. This forecast is supported by the BCRA's shift to an inflation-targeting regime from 2017 (with a target range for end-2017 of 12-17%, moving to 8-12% in 2018 and 5% in 2019), and assumes reduced political interference after a period of politicisation under the previous administration.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
After a contraction in real GDP of 2.1% in 2016, we expect real GDP to return to positive territory in 2017. But with Brazil likely to post barely positive growth in 2017, manufacturing activity in Argentina will recover only moderately, limiting GDP growth to 2.8% (revised up from our previous forecast of 2.5% owing to stronger data for the fourth quarter of 2016). We currently expect the recovery to peak at 3.5 in 2018. However, the annual growth rate for that year masks an expected sequential deceleration in the second half of 2018, resulting from a projected weakening of Chinese import demand. By 2019, when we also project a cyclical downturn in the US economy, real GDP growth in Argentina will slide back below 3%, before a modest recovery takes hold again in 2020-21.
Our forecast for a still relatively robust recovery in the medium term is based on the assumption that a combination of macroeconomic adjustment and improvements to the business environment will eventually have some beneficial impact on both export activity and domestic demand. An easing of inflation, combined with efforts by the Macri government to address the problem of legal and regulatory uncertainty and reduce red tape, should set the stage for renewed strong growth in fixed investment and private consumption, supporting an acceleration of GDP growth. On the supply side, growth should be bolstered in 2017 and into the medium term by a positive outlook for agriculture, and for investment in both infrastructure (which should see construction activity accelerate rapidly) and energy, including renewables.
There are downside risks to our GDP forecasts, as attempts by the government to reduce economic distortions and engineer a smooth adjustment to a lower-inflation environment could prove extremely challenging, keeping both con-sump-tion and investment subdued for longer than we expect. However, there is also some upside risk, as investment could overtake expectations from 2017 once the gains from macro-economic adjustment materialise and depending on the success of efforts to improve the framework for doing business. However, even in this scenario, in the absence of deeper structural reform efforts than we currently envisage, the potential growth rate will remain closer to 3% than 4%.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
The Macri administration introduced a new consumer price index in May 2016 to address widespread concerns about the quality of official data. However, because of a lack of historical data to provide a full picture of 12-month inflation trends, we are, for now, continuing to use the Buenos Aires city consumer price index as a proxy for inflation at the national level. This showed 12-month inflation of 38% in January 2017. Although high, this does represent a steep fall from a peak of 44.4% in May 2016, which resulted from currency and tariff adjust-ments by the new administration. Assuming tight monetary and fiscal policy (spending will remain negative in real terms until 2018), the inflationary spike will prove transitory, and we expect gradual disinflation in the medium term, provided domestic demand remains subdued relative to the boom years of 2004-11 and domestic supply strengthens on the back of an improved regulatory environ-ment for agricultural producers. The main risks to this forecast stem from possible failure to tighten fiscal policy as projected, a weaker than expected peso and the difficult process of reining in nominal wage growth. However, if the government is able to tackle the high level of wage indexation (a key obstacle to the reduction of inflation towards OECD levels), there is also the potential for inflation in the medium term to slow more than we currently project.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
Some modest depreciation pressure following Brexit in June and the US election in November caused the peso to weaken to Ps15.9:US$1 by end-2016, from around Ps14:US$1 at mid-year, but it has since recovered some ground to stand around Ps15.5:US$1. We expect renewed modest weakening in 2017-21, particularly in the first half of the forecast period as domestic interest rates continue to decline and the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) continues a monetary tightening cycle. However, the positive outlook for portfolio and foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will be supportive of the currency, which will dampen depreciation pressure and produce some periods of real currency appreciation (as has occurred in recent months). In nominal terms, we expect the peso to end 2017 at Ps17.78US$1 and 2021 at Ps23.61US$1.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
As the terms of trade improve and a weaker peso gradually boosts goods and services exports, improvements in the trade and services accounts will cause the current-account deficit to narrow. From 2.7% of GDP in 2016, we expect the deficit to fall to an annual average 1.4% of GDP in 2017-21. We also expect the country's ability to finance moderate current-account deficits to improve, assuming that portfolio and FDI inflows pick up as investor confidence in the Macri administration grows. The result will be a rise in foreign reserves in nominal terms. Our forecasts currently assume FDI inflows averaging 2% of GDP in 2017-21, with foreign reserves equivalent to an annual average 7.3 months of import cover in the same period.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US

Full text:   Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit assigns a high risk to the grand coalition government of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) and the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) not serving its full parliamentary term to 2018, despite the coalition parties' recent renewal of their agreement.
Political risks have risen since mid-2015, as public unease about the influx of migrants and dissatisfaction with the mainstream ruling parties has boosted support for the anti-immigration Freedom Party (FPÖ) and heightened intra-coalition tensions amid still weak economic growth. Since late 2015 opinion polls have shown support for the FPÖ at about 32%, above the two coalition parties.
Following several years of policy paralysis, in January 2017 the coalition parties announced a renewed coalition agreement. However, we expect im-plementation of the announced measures to be troublesome. If the government does face significant difficulties in delivery, we would expect the federal chancellor, Christian Kern (SPÖ), to push for early elections. He already seemed to be doing so during the recent negotiations, and he may want to cash in on his continued popularity before a failed reform attempt sullies this.
Little progress is expected in most areas of the government's reform agenda. This policy paralysis will hamper efforts to improve competitiveness, which over recent years has deteriorated relative to Austria's regional peers.
The government budget is forecast to remain in deficit, albeit at less than 1% of GDP, throughout the forecast period (2017-21) as the fiscal consolidation process suffers under limited government cohesion and effectiveness. However, we expect the public debt/GDP ratio to fall gradually over the forecast period.
Economic growth in recent years has been tepid, as productivity has weakened and export market shares have declined. Real GDP grew by 0.8% in 2015 but accelerated to 1.5% in 2016, driven by domestic consumption and investment demand. We expect a slight acceleration of growth in 2017, to 1.7%, reflecting mainly catch-up growth, and forecast average annual growth of 1.5% in 2018-21.
Structural factors, including higher unit wage costs and more regulated markets, will keep inflation higher than in regional peers; after 1% in 2016, we forecast 1.9% inflation in 2017, rising to 2% on average in 2018-21.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Austria's business environment score improves slightly between the historical period (2012-16) and the forecast period (2017-21). As a result, the country rises to tenth place in the regional ranking and to 17th in the global ranking. Austria's strengths as a business location include decent infrastructure, stable institutions and co-operative labour relations, but high taxes, limited market opportunities and restrictive regulations will persist.
Country forecast overview: Austria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2017-18: Government works on reducing red tape, but progress is likely to be limited. Barriers to entry to network industries are likely to persist.
2019-21: Modest strengthening of the competition authority's powers. Administrative reform reduces red tape. More transparency in antitrust proceedings. Risk of political interference in private firms in which state owns substantial stakes.
Policy towards foreign investment
2017-18: Foreign investment is generally welcome, but underlying opposition to takeovers of "national champions" persists.
2019-21: Possible erosion of barriers against foreign takeovers as a result of commercial pressure and EU legislation.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2017-18: No exchange controls. Foreign trade, governed by EU rules, should remain liberal, except for agricultural goods.
2019-21: EU likely to accelerate shift towards bilateral free-trade agreements as multilateral trade negotiations stagnate.
Taxes
2017-18: No significant changes to the tax system, owing in part to government ineffectiveness.
2019-21: Some tax reform is likely if a government including the Freedom Party (FPÖ) takes power. Vested interests will continue to hamper large-scale reform and the high tax burden will remain.
Financing
2017-18: Financial stability to improve amid tighter regulatory requirements. Credit conditions ease gradually as banks' profitability recovers. Downside risks from financial, legislative and macroeconomic risks in central and eastern Europe.
2019-21: Introduction of systemic risk buffer of banks' risk-weighted assets. Further uptake in corporate bond issuance.
The labour market
2017-18: Economy-wide minimum wage is introduced. More stringent requirements for early retirement and invalidity pensions. Pay and hiring freezes in civil service. Unemployment trends higher as employment growth moderates.
2019-21: Continued expansion of labour supply, primarily via net immigration, but concerns about shortage of skilled employees in certain sectors are likely to persist. Early retirement phased out.
Infrastructure
2017-18: Further take-up of broadband services. Gradual improvement of transport links with eastern Europe.
2019-21: Improved transport network connecting main urban centres and providing better access to the country's interior. Gradual transition to low-carbon economy entails significant changes to electricity transmission infrastructure.
