a Actual.
Background: Austria became an important force in central Europe with the formation of the Habsburg empire in the 15th century and remained so until the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian empire at the end of the first world war. The Republic of Austria emerged in 1918. In 1938 Austria was incorporated into the German Third Reich. With the departure of the victorious Allied forces in 1955, it regained independence as a neutral country. In the post-war period Austria took great strides to catch up economically with the rest of the developed world and is now one of the most advanced nations. It is a member of the EU and a participant in the economic and monetary union (EMU).
Political structure: Austria is a federal republic and the head of state is the federal president. The government is led by the federal chancellor. The national parliament has two houses: the Federal Council (Bundesrat, the upper house), of 62 members appointed by state parliaments, and the National Council (Nationalrat, the lower house), which has 183 members elected by proportional representation. The last general election was held in 2013; the next is due in 2018.
Policy issues: The government's stated priorities are to reduce the budget deficit and debt pile, improve labour market participation rates, strengthen competitiveness, increase expenditure on research and development, continue to reform healthcare expenditure, stabilise the financial sector and raise educational standards. Progress on these issues will be modest at best as tensions surrounding immigration, security and border controls will remain elevated across Europe, diverting attention to security and migration-related policy areas.
Taxation: According to the European Commission, Austrian labour tax as a percentage of GDP is the second-highest in the EU. A 2016 tax reform lowered the tax burden for low- and middle-income earners, but raised the top personal income tax rate from 50% to 55%. Social security contributions, shared between employers and employees, are high. Corporation tax is levied at a rate of 25%. Dividend and investment income is subject to a withholding tax of 27.5%. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a standard rate of 20%, and a reduced rate of 13% (raised from 10% in 2016) applies for certain goods and services.
Foreign trade: In 2015 the value of exported goods was US$142.1bn and the goods import bill was US$140.4bn. The services surplus, traditionally boosted by tourism receipts, was US$11.2bn. Along with a significant primary income deficit and modest secondary income deficit, this yielded a current-account surplus equivalent to 1.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2017-21: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit assigns a high risk to the grand coalition government of the centre-right Austrian People's Party (ÖVP) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPÖ) calling an early election before the end of its term in October 2018. In May 2016 Werner Faymann (SPÖ), the then chancellor, resigned and was succeeded by Christian Kern (also SPÖ), then the head of the state railway firm.
A clear trend in recent state elections and in the presidential election in May-June has been gains for the opposition far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ) at the expense of the SPÖ and the ÖVP. Opinion polls continue to show support for the FPÖ at about 32%, well ahead of the SPÖ (at 29%) and the ÖVP (at 19%). The FPÖ is the well-established party of protest, attracting support from voters who are dis-satisfied with the current government. It is therefore not surprising that support for the FPÖ has increased at a time when there is a widespread perception of stalemate within the current coalition, along with concerns about immigration, stagnant economic growth and rising unemployment. The fraying of the decades-long dominance of the political scene by the SPÖ and the ÖVP will weigh heavily on political stability in the years ahead. The FPÖ candidate eventually lost the presidential election, and by a larger margin the second time round, after it was rerun following irregularities in the vote counting process. However, that the FPÖ candidate, Norbert Hofer, twice managed to gain almost half of the vote, and on a high turnout, endorses our view that support for the FPÖ has become entrenched.
Recently, the outlook for the coalition surviving has improved slightly, after the two parties presented a new coalition agreement in late January 2017. In this they presented a number of measures, including a new minimum wage and enhanced security measures. However, relations between the two parties remain tense, and there are serious questions over whether it will be possible for the coalition to implement the announced reforms. In particular, it is uncertain whether Mr Kern and Reinhold Mitterlehner, the leader of the ÖVP, have a sufficient hold over their parties (and over the social partners and provincial governments, both of which are vital to implementation) to deliver the agreement in full and to the agreed timetable. If the government does face significant difficulties in delivery, we would expect Mr Kern to push for early elections. He already seemed to be doing so during the recent negotiations, and may want to cash in on his continued popularity before a failed reform attempt sullies this. We continue to believe that an early election is a likely scenario.
The FPÖ is likely to win either an early election or the next scheduled one and subsequently to attempt to form a government, although it remains unclear with which party it will choose to do so. The FPÖ's proximity to power means that it tends to moderate its views compared with far-right, populist parties in other European countries, such as France and the Netherlands. Mr Kern has been vocal in his disapproval of the FPÖ, but has been moving towards the party, including by pushing for curbs on intra-EU labour migration and by recently stating that his own party and the FPÖ were the only parties in Austria who wanted change. Regardless of which coalition emerges, we expect political stability to deteriorate further in the second half of our forecast period (2017-21). Relations with fellow EU member states will worsen in the event that the FPÖ enters government, putting pressure on the FPÖ's coalition partner, and we expect a government led by the party to be unstable, as it would struggle to implement its policies.
Outlook for 2017-21: Election watch
Alexander Van der Bellen was sworn in as president on January 26th, following the re-run of the second round of the presidential election, originally held in May 2016. The next election for the primarily ceremonial position of federal president is planned for 2023.
The next general election is scheduled for September or October 2018. Whether it takes place then or earlier, we forecast that the FPÖ will become either the largest or the second-largest party, and will then probably form a coalition with either the SPÖ or the ÖVP.
Outlook for 2017-21: International relations
Austria was severely affected by the European migrant crisis, and this has been the dominant issue in its international relations since 2015. The country has been at the centre of many of the intra-EU spats regarding the bloc's response to the large influx of migrants, owing in part to its unilateral actions. Domestic pressure on the government to be seen as acting against this influx, and thus often against other EU member states, will remain high owing to the rise of the FPÖ, and it seems to have driven the government to lower its annual cap on asylum applications. The government is repeatedly hinting that it wants to limit labour migration within the EU, or at least give preferential treatment to Austrian citizens on the labour market, which will exacerbate tensions with many EU member states.
The rerun of the presidential election in December 2016 demonstrated the relatively broad support for EU membership. Many voters cited as one of their main reasons for voting for Mr Van der Bellen suggestions by Mr Hofer of a possible membership referendum in Austria if the EU did not reform or if Turkey joined. This experience should moderate any further attempts by the FPÖ to use the EU as a divisive issue.
Outlook for 2017-21: Policy trends
Alongside the 2016 tax reform, which provided about EUR5bn in tax relief to households, government policy has focused on challenges facing the country's financial sector. These have included the clean-up and debt restructuring of Heta Asset Resolution (Heta), a "bad bank" that was created to deal with the toxic assets of Hypo Group Alpe Adria (HGAA). The uncertainty surrounding Heta was removed in October 2016 when creditors accepted a debt-restructuring deal. The government has also had to manage the banking sector's exposure to central and east European economies.
In its renegotiation of its coalition agreement in January 2017, the coalition decided on a number of measures that it hoped to implement before the end of its term, in 2018. These include a new annual minimum wage of EUR21,000, as opposed to only sector-specific negotiated minimum wages, and reducing red tape for employers, including more flexible rules on working hours. However, we are sceptical that tangible progress will be achieved in most of these areas, owing to a lack of cohesion within the grand coalition and within the parties themselves at the different levels of government. The same is true for a coherent policy response to relatively high unemployment despite continued (albeit weak) growth and the sustainability of the pension system, despite a widely shared belief in the need for reform. The next government, which is likely to include the FPÖ, will move integration and immigration policy further to the right, but we would expect it to struggle to implement significant structural reforms rapidly.
Outlook for 2017-21: Fiscal policy
In 2014 Austria's fiscal accounts deteriorated, mainly reflecting the govern-ment's decision to create a bad bank to deal with HGAA's toxic assets. The fiscal deficit widened to the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP, from 1.3% in 2013, and public debt rose to 84.4% of GDP. Mainly in response to steady direct revenue growth, the deficit narrowed to 1% of GDP in 2015, although the public debt/GDP ratio increased further, to 85.6%.
We estimate that the deficit was unchanged in 2016, despite fiscally expansionary tax reforms and higher migrant-related public spending, at the equivalent of 1% of GDP. We expect the budget to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period (2017-21), albeit below 1% of GDP, as fiscal con-solidation will continue to be limited and growth slow. The public debt stock as a percentage of GDP is projected to decline gradually, from an estimated 83.7% in 2016, following a positive contribution from the Heta deal, to just below 75% in 2021. In the context of the quantitative easing (QE) undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB) and Austria's relatively strong fundamentals, funding risks are extremely low in our view.
Outlook for 2017-21: Monetary policy
Amid heightened political risk the euro zone economy is showing increasing growth momentum and we expect another healthy expansion in the region's economy this year, after growth of 1.8% on average in 2015-16. Nonetheless, the ECB is continuing to pursue an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy, with major policy interest rates at or below zero, a series of so-called targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs) aimed at pushing banks to lend more money and an EUR80bn per month QE programme, which will fall to EUR60bn per month from April until the end of 2017.
The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, has emphasised that the reduction in the pace of QE was designed to sustain the bank's presence in the market for a longer period than if purchases continued at the current rate, and should not be viewed as "tapering", which would signify a winding down of the programme. We expect tapering to begin in 2018, but downside risks to global growth during that year, including our forecast for an economic slowdown in China and tighter monetary policy in the US, suggest that the pace at which the ECB unwinds its accommodative policy stance will be gradual. We maintain our forecast that the ECB will not tighten policy rates before the end of our forecast period, in 2021.
Outlook for 2017-21: Economic growth
Austria's initial recovery from the global financial crisis was respectable in the euro zone context, but subsequently the economy largely stalled. Underper-formance in comparison with Germany in recent years-in terms of headline growth, consumption, investment and unemployment-is particularly striking given the traditionally high level of synchronisation between the two countries' business cycles. Real GDP rose by a sluggish 0.8% in 2015, and although it accelerated in 2016, to 1.5%, this remained below growth of 1.8% in Germany.
The economy's relatively lacklustre performance in recent years reflects a number of factors. Austria's domestic reform process has faltered, and along with higher inflation compared with its regional peers this has weakened productivity and competitiveness, admittedly from fairly high levels, in relation to countries such as France, Germany and the Netherlands, hindering export performance. This has depressed labour market prospects. In recent years the labour market has not been able to integrate the increased labour supply, caused in part by the influx of migrants last year, and this has pushed up the unemployment rate, even though employment has been growing. This, in turn, has weighed on consumer sentiment, meaning that much of the windfall for consumers from low oil prices since late 2014 has been saved instead of consumed. Although inflation has picked up recently following increasing global energy prices and positive base effects, we expect a modestly improving labour market to drive consumption growth in the coming years.
We expect the current phase of catch-up growth, following an underperformance even compared with fundamentals in recent years, to continue and have made an upward adjustment to our real GDP growth forecast for 2017, to 1.7%. This still compares negatively with, for instance, the Netherlands, where catch-up growth in recent years has been around 2%. We expect the lack of reform progress to continue to weigh on growth throughout the forecast period and expect domestic demand to be the main driver of growth of just 1.5% on average in 2018-21.
Outlook for 2017-21: Inflation
Annual consumer price inflation (EU harmonised) has been subdued in recent years, but higher than in most other euro zone countries. Inflation averaged 0.8% in 2015 and 1% in 2016, well above average inflation in Germany and the euro zone in both years. This largely reflects structural domestic factors, such as higher unit wage costs, more regulated markets and a period of faster increases in taxes and duties. Rising services prices, energy price base effects and the lagged feedthrough of euro weakness via import costs fostered a gradual rise in inflation in the final months of 2016 and January 2017, and will continue to do so in the rest of 2017, when we forecast full-year average inflation of 1.9%. We expect inflation to stay above the euro zone average in 2018-21, at 2% on average, as similar structural factors as in previous years persist.
Outlook for 2017-21: Exchange rates
The euro has moved in a relatively narrow range around US$1.10:EUR1 since mid-2015 and averaged US$1.11:EUR1 in 2016, with a year-end rate of US$1.05:EUR1, reflecting the sharp appreciation in the value of the US dollar following Donald Trump's election victory in the US. We now forecast an annual average rate of US$1.06:EUR1 in 2017 and US$1.07:EUR1 in 2018, reflecting heightened political risk in Europe and strong growth in the US, with the euro then appreciating gradually in 2019-21. We do not expect the euro to return to its long-term average value against the dollar even by the end of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2017-21: External sector
Low oil prices and subdued domestic demand compressing import values helped the trade balance to move into surplus in 2014-15, from a deficit in 2009-13. The recent recovery has pushed up imports and is estimated to have depressed the trade surplus in 2016. We expect further growth in the coming years and higher oil prices to push the goods trade balance back into deficit from 2018. However, this will be compensated for by a healthy surplus on the services balance, driven in large part by robust tourism inflows. Small deficits on the primary and secondary income accounts will not be enough to push the current-account balance into deficit, and we therefore expect continued, albeit slightly decreasing, current-account surpluses in our forecast period, of 1.8% of GDP on average.
